body:
My day started off great with a nice smooth shift at work, but went rapidly downhill from there; Hotter is sick and a nail in one of the MFA Beater's NEW tires (couldn't be one of the old ones, ohOOOOO no) turned ino $221, a new wheel hub, tire, studs and nuts, and two hours in MFA Mechanic's waiting room, then Hotter slept through Daddy Dinner Date Night after finding out Lefty is getting out of prison late next month (despite having committed SEVERAL felonies ON SURVEILLANCE VIDEO) for having ratted on someone, which means Lefty is highly likely to get shot over the holidays so MERRY FUCKING TURKEY-KAH-MAS. Then when he brought the kids back my ex beckoned me out onto the front porch to try to gaslight me into believing Little Child had actually ASKED for growth hormone shots at the appointment that I attended where the endocrinologist pronounced him a healthy shrimp with normal bone age and the child expressed nothing but satisfaction with his own stature, and when I gave him the hand and said he needed to stop trying to bend reality and project his own securities onto our son he screamed at me. YAY! Wait, no, SHIT! The XY has furthermore diagnosed yet another child with yet ANOTHER endocrine condition that I won't be discussing publicly but am pretty sure is Not Actually A Thing, and honestly I think he probably just needs his psych meds tweaked or possibly a beating with the Narcissist Be Cool Stick. And only because I don't think my back is quite up for this yet:
   

   So here are some things that I did not write, because anything I write today is going to be about Hotter's shitty timing and how cars and junkies are fucking whores and my ex needs to get over his Lilliputian penis (because the rest of the world already has, and it's less because of the size of his gear and more because it's dangling off a GIANT FESTERING ASSHOLE). 
This is hilarious. Who is going to help me stab The XY in the leg?*
This is thought-provoking stuff, and I thinks she's right. Lord, I miss the gym.
   I'm sure I read something else awesome at some point today, but I think I'm going slightly blind from rage so I'm going to go bed. 
 
*  In case his imaginary lawyers are reading this, that was tongue-in-cheek; if I ever stabbed the XY I'd aim higher****  Which isn't to say I'd ever actually stab my ex-husband, solicit anyone else in seriousness to stab him for me, or be creative enough to find any way of effing up his life any further than he already has on his own. Yes, I have an MFA in the creative field, but that shithead is a self-sabotage savant and half the reason we divorced is that I realized he didn't need me in his life to accomplish his evident goal of being a miserable fucking wretch, but I DID need him OUT of MY life to accomplish my own goal of remaining a pacifist.
title: two things worth reading that I didn't write

body:
*   Last night I had to have an actual phone conversation with my ex-husband. Oy. I only actually speak to the ex maybe once or twice a month, because it's highly unproductive, unpleasant, bad for the kids to witness if it's face-to-face, and did I mention how freaking unpleasant it is? But I had an open-enrollment counseling session scheduled and wanted to see what The XY's dental plan would cover as far as orthodontics, since Big Child was just referred for a braces consult by MFA Dentist; if it didn't cover braces or didn't cover very much I thought it might be worth adding just Big Child to my dental insurance and using it as a secondary plan for him. OHMYGOD. It was, at most, a five-minute conversation and I STILL have a headache, plus I didn't learn much about the XY's dental coverage, although I now know that if I expect him to pay the court-mandated 66% of medical expenses over $250 on this one I better make damn sure Big Child sees the cheapest orthodontist in town (ummmno, he will see the one MFA Dentist, who we trust, recommended, thankyouverymuch), because the XY knows how naive I am and the world is full of con-artists. Sigh.
*   This morning I waited on a table consisting of a man, his wife, and their teenage son, and the man was just THE BIGGEST ASSHOLE EVER. Not to me, he was perfectly pleasant to me, but he was berating his wife nonstop. "GET A BAGEL, ORDER SOMETHING, IF YOU DON'T EAT YOUR STOMACH WILL BE GROWLING AND IT WILL EMBARRASS ME. YOU DO NEED TO DIET BUT YOU CAN START TOMORROW, HURRY UP, THE SERVER IS WAITING!" I wanted to slip the poor woman a note telling her she looked great and didn't have to put up with that crap and offering to be a witness in their divorce hearing should she ever need one, or at the very least spill something ice-cold on the guy's crotch. The worst part was their poor son, who was staring fixedly at the table as his father scolded and belittled his mother. Just...ugh.
*   I saw on the Twitter where a blogger (many of you probably know who I'm talking about, but let's leave any naming of names out of this post and its comments) proudly posted a picture drawn by their young elementary-aged child that included the word "fucking" as part of the caption, and wanted to cry. See, I'm no prude but here is the thing: I was a foul-mouthed little kid raised by damn-the-man parents and in retrospect it SUCKED. Adults disapproved of me (and having been taught that it was perfectly okay for kids to curse if their parents said it was cool I just thought grownups didn't like me because there was something wrong with me), kids weren't allowed to play with me, and I spent a lot of time with the guidance counselor in elementary school until I learned to act a different way in public than I did at home. I know I'm probably offending a couple of readers by saying this, but people there is nothing cool or hip about letting your small child swear with abandon. You don't necessarily have to shelter them completely (in fact, I feel like that's almost as harmful because then you're letting other kids educate them on What Those Words Mean). My kids never hear me curse, EVER (with the exception of Festivus), because while I have a mouth like a trucker when I'm among other adults or blabbering on the innernet, I want to set the example that swear words are Not For Daily Use (that way when the first one crashes my car and I go YOU WRECKED THE FUCKING CAR??? they'll understand that shit has gotten real). I've never punished anyone in this house for language, mostly because it's never been an issue. They know they can ask me what any word means without fear of punishment for saying it. I'll provide an age-appropriate definition and describe the type of context the word might be used in and then let them know it's not a word they're allowed to use, and so far nobody in this house under the age of thirty has engaged in any swearing outside of Festivus. At Hotter's urging I've lightened up a little; the boys are allowed to say "fart" now, because yeah, it does sound weird for a middle-schooler to say "poot" and I don't want my kid to get picked on by his peers. But that's probably about as far as I'll go while these people live under my roof.
title: things that made me say "ew"

body:
Job: Nothing to report as of yet. DAMN IT.
Feelings Pills: Effexor XR for the moment. Hotter keeps trying to surprise me with sad animal pictures and see if I burst into tears. So far, no tears! Although I had a nightmare that the pills were not working and I lost my shit over someone crumpling up a brown paper bag. I don't know if that's clinically significant or not. Am hoping to have insurance soon and therefore be able to switch back to Pristiq if Effexor XR and I do not play nicely together, which brings us to...Insurance: I just talked to Anthem's underwriting department, which made me feel totally dumb and inadequate. They were like "When was the FIRST time in the past two years that you were treated for bronchitis?" and I was all "do normal people know this kind of thing?" Then they were wanting to know what DOSAGE of Symbicort I took that one time and look, it was whatever my doctor had a free sample of, it was a red and gray plastic inhaler that tasted like ass. After that they wanted to know my exact diagnosis for which I take antidepressants, which DUH, DEPRESSION. Major or minor, they wanted to know. I was like "well I guess minor, I mean, I've never been in the hospital for it or anything." One three-way call with my psychiatrist's office later and I can state with authority that I have been billed in the past for treatment for "dysthymic disorder." AKA non-major depression. Which, that's pretty much what I said, but apparently Anthem was questioning either a) my memory or b) my mental health after my not knowing or caring what was in the red and gray inhaler. By the end of the call I kind of didn't blame them. So yeah, no word on THAT just yet either. 
The Crazy Person Who Reads My Blog: Stopped checking umpteen times per day from their iPad via the IP address I mentioned after I called them out and started reading just as feverishly from their cell phone. Dance, puppet, dance!
   How are all of YOU?
title: updates, assorted

body:
*   I haven't blogged lately mostly because I've been lowly worm. I reinjured my back a bit uprooting pokeweed with my barehanded feelings (the same ones I had when last I wrote), and caught the 'flu-like ailment that's been making the rounds in my workplace. It's this super-awesome virus that takes ten to twelve days to resolve and runs the gamut from GI unpleasantness through chest, throat, and sinus pain, with general malaise throughout. FUNTIMES!
*   The kitten somehow got out and spent several hours IN THE COLD, WHILE IT RAINED. Despite that he's fine. I'm not!
*   Speaking of the kitten, those of you familiar with pitbulls will not be surprised to hear that Isis has adopted him. After his outdoor fright the kitten was chilly and scared enough to try returning the feelings, and now Isis is the proud mama to a hairless kitten. He nurses on her and everything, which freaks Hotter out, but bottom line is Isis + Skeeter = <3 <3 <3 and it is RIDICULOUSLY CUTE.

Figure One: "Pieta."
*   What's NOT cute, even a little bit, is that Hotter found a possum in Squatter Workshop on top of the henhouse--A FUCKING POSSUM! He chased it outside with a shovel. I am NOT OKAY WITH POSSUMS and was disappointed that he didn't come get me. "You're sick! What would you have done?" "GOTTEN OFF MY SICKBED AND BEAT IT TO DEATH," said I, and then he tried to make me feel better about there having been a possum by saying it didn't move very fast and he thought it was sick. And also it had a fuzzy tail (yes, I know, they don't HAVE fuzzy tails, but Hotter says he saw what he saw). So it's a sick, mutant possum. Greeeeat.
*   Speaking of Hotter and seeing things, I took him back to the eye doctor today and they confirmed that his cataract is worse and scheduled a date before the end of the month to remove it.
*   And speaking of major medical procedures, the younger two children both got 'flu shots today, as did Hotter. Big Child and I did not have doctors' appointments today and so remain unvaccinated thus far, which caused Big Child to lament that when he does get his 'flu vaccine this year he doesn't know which side to ask for it in, because his left side is the side where  he broke his collarbone and has been through quite enough trials and tribulations this year, plus he didn't want to re-injure anything with a needle, but his right side is his favorite one because he is right-handed. Both littles and I pointed out that the 'flu shot doesn't GO in your collarbone but rather in your upper arm, and Big Child insisted that when his collarbone ached from the recent change of weather it ached exactly where he'd gotten his last 'flu shot. "Then that wasn't your collarbone aching," I informed him. "IT WAS SO, I REMEMBER THAT PAIN," he insisted, and so I think this has become like Sophie's Choice for him. Will he incapacitate his writing arm and risk academic ruin? Will he rebreak his Achilles Heel collarbone and become a mere mortal? WHAT WILL HE DO? Stay tuned!
*   Cat farts: fecking 'orrid things! Lord.
*   Today the visitor deck at Local Teaching Hospital was full, so I had to valet-park the MFA Beater to take Hotter to Transplant Clinic. I left the Beater reluctantly in the valets' hands, worried its' trick clutch would act up but lacking a better option, and we emerged two hours later to find the Beater exactly where we'd left it (blocking half the valet circle in front of the hospital). Hotter doesn't think I should have paid them anything, seeing as how they failed utterly to park the car. I...am willing to call the cash a storage fee.
*   Because they bother the everloving shit out of me, Hotter has taken it upon himself to advocate for the possums of the world. "What's a possum again," one of the children wanted to know. "THE POSSUM IS ONE OF GOD'S MOST BEAUTIFUL CREATURES," Hotter intoned. I'm going to throw a shoe at him, I swear...
*   My mouthguard is missing. I am very, very sad about that.
*   How are all of YOU? Have you seen my mouthguard? Battled any possums lately? Had your 'flu shot? Tell me all about it.
title: worm

body:
I got some hopeful news, and since I know y'all worry I thought I would share: one of my references for The Job I Really Want called me earlier tonight to let me know that she got a call from the place! This means that I am still in the running! I've been angsting over not having gotten a call back yet (as those of you who know my on the facespace or follow me on the Twitter are WELL-aware), but I guess they just wanted to make sure my criminal background check came back okay before putting the time and wo/manpower into calling references. YAY!   If I get the job, I may just be able to avoid getting evicted/having something vital turned off/sending the kids to live with my ex. It won't be PRETTY, but...I might be able to keep all the plates spinning on top of their wobbly sticks with a little creative juggling.   Also, some GREAT news: we got a letter from the elementary school today letting us know they are recommending that MIDDLE CHILD begin participating in the school's accelerated learners program for mathematics next year! What the HECK with my kids and all the crazy math achievements lately?!? Apparently the hospital switched that baby, too, but I am not giving HIM back either :) GO MIDDLY! I am especially proud considering that when he was three and four we weren't even sure he'd be able to successfully participate in a mainstream classroom. Three cheers for early intervention and one very hard-working little boy!*
 
*   I debated even sharing this here, because that awful woman who sent me the eleventy-kajillion increasingly incoherent and outrageous e-mails seems to have a hard-on for my pride in my childrens' accomplishments in particular and accused me of making up Big Child's awards and recognitions. As those of you who saw the photos on the facespace are aware, I most certainly did nothing of the sort, but it still stung because I really don't brag about my kids half as much as I'd LIKE to on here. I don't want to be that obnoxious mommy-blogger who thinks her kids are better than everyone else's (and I don't, I just think they're the best kids I'VE got). But y'know what, FUCK HER. I'm not going to let some random stranger's psychotic break keep me from sharing something so amazing, so yeah: I'm proud of my kid and I bragged on my blog. Mea culpa! If it bothers you that I brag about my kids when they do something amazing, quit checking my blog umpteen times per day from your iPad, unnamed lunatic whose IP address starts with 67.197!
title: hopeful news and GREAT news

body:
Today got off to a rocky start, and didn't really get much better from there. I e-mailed The XY yesterday to ask whether, seeing as how his late payment of the child support had cost me my health insurance coverage, he'd be willing to cover the most expensive out-of-pocket drug as a goodwill gesture.
   Go ahead and laugh at me, Hotter did. But see, I can't maintain the level of ill will I bear for my ex-husband in good conscience without at least giving him the OPPORTUNITY to Do The Right Thing. As I explained to Hotter, The XY and I are both Jews, and the fine arts of guilt-induction and blame-assignment are very important to our people.
   The XY remains committed to his course of ever-increasing twatwhistlery, however, and threw in some bonus bullshit about how HIS child support isn't for MY health insurance, and Anthem wouldn't just DROP me like that (hahaha oh how I wish he was right about that), and it's my fault for not paying the bill on time anyway, but he guessed this was my way of asking for a loan and he SUPPOSED he could swing it in order to help me out AS AN OLIVE BRANCH even after all of the grief I have caused him IF I could promise a swift repayment. And then he launched into this long, sad tale of why he can't take the children for his weekend THIS time. And I will say that I'm proud of myself for not telling him to shove his olive branch up his arse. Instead I counted to ten and e-mailed him back saying that I'd only wanted to give him a chance to help mitigate the damage his delinquent payment had caused, but clearly he still did not prioritize doing the right thing any more than he ever had and clearly didn't care what happened to me AS A DIRECT RESULT of his actions (or, in this case, inactions), and I was not interested in setting a precedent of money-lending between us and thought it best that we both go back to keeping our personal struggles to ourselves. I then told him that a simple yes or no to his visitation would suffice in the future and life happens, so spare me the crying and oversharing about his life, the weather, and the traffic because *I* really didn't care what his latest excuse for not taking the limited parenting time available to him was.
   TL; DR - The XY retains his title as The Lord of the Douche.
   From there my day continued to suck with a desperate paperwork faxing hustle to avoid Big Child being dropped from his summer program for the gifted (mission accomplished THERE, thank goodness), me blubbering all over poor Hotter for no good reason (except that I'd skipped a dose of Pristiq trying to buy some time for Anthem to potentially pull their heads out of their arses, because once I pay out-of-pocket for the Pristiq I won't be able to pay Anthem even if I do get a managerial exception and they're willing to take all my money and give me back my coverage), spraying perfume in my eye while getting ready for work, and walking into everybody at work in shitty moods.
   At work I was at least able to pull it together; something in me turns on the perky at all costs in front of co-workers and guests, and despite having sniffled most of the way there I managed to fix my face in the parking lot and wade into the shitstorm with a smile. And I guess maybe there's something to the whole "fake it till you feel it" thing, because I'm drained and anxious and bone-weary of everything being such a fucking struggle, but at least my face has stopped leaking.
   If I disappear for a bit don't necessarily assume the absolute worst, but if things get any worse it'll definitely be for the best that I clam up for a bit, both to deprive Stalky of the spank-bank material and also to avoid being a bummer to y'all in general.
   Send baby animals, prepaid hitmen, and brand-name SSR/Norepinephrine Inhibitors, please.

title: jokes by Big Child

body:
I'm still alive! Things are considerably less grim here now that my bloodlevel of Pristiq has stabilized, or at least they SEEM that way, and perception is everything, AMIRITE? Here are some updates:
*   I bit the bullet and picked up the Pristiq, which meant giving up on Anthem, but oh well. As long as I don't get bronchitis or break a bone in the next month or so I'll be able to get on my employer's coverage at that point and this'll just be one more cringe-worthy memory. A reader-turned-Twitterfriend-turned-facespace-friend gave me a discount program code that saved me $30 on the prescription, which was a huge moral victory in that it took the cost from just OVER my former monthly premium amount to just UNDER it. SUCK ON THAT, ANTHEM!
*   The title comes from the fact that one of the Feed Store Six is...not a hen. About a week ago SOMEbody started up with this sad, half-whispered puberty-crow, and we've been trying to identify the culprit ever since. We'd hear the pathetic little quasi-crow, and turn around, and all six birds would be standing in a clump looking at us going "peep?" This morning Hotter caught Flash II in the act, though. Chicken soup to follow! If I'm honest it's kind of a relief that one of the six younger birds is not keeper-material, because that means I can let one of the older four stay, and while I am not one to get emotional about smallstock (anymore) (much), there is one bird among the older ones who thinks she is a pet and runs up to crouch at my feet for petting when I go outside. And while I have a heart shaped like an axe, I don't think I can butcher something that LIKES me! The other three would cheerfully kill and eat ME if they could, so they're fine to go in the pot, Blacktop (the friendly chicken) can stay on as our "chicken emeritus" and show the five younger girls the ropes, and we won't be in violation of the c(o)unty's six-bird limit or in danger of landlordly censure thanks to Trashcan Neighbor, who has our landlord on speed-dial, over a rooster.
*   The new job continues to be good! It's slightly less money than "The Ritz," but MUCH less physically demanding, and a much friendlier environment. I actually like some of my co-workers! The kitchen staff fills scrap bags for my animals! Management appreciates me, and tells me so on the regular! The hours are less favorable in that I now mostly work evenings (at "The Ritz" I mostly worked mornings), but evenings at The Ritzier are where the money is, so I'm okay with it.
*   The only thing I really dislike about the new job is that the most expedient route from home to work takes me directly through the neighborhood where I last saw The Narcissist alive; it's a long and unpleasant story but her final shitfit caused there to be a police search for her involving everything up to and including HELICOPTERS, and me, mere days out from not one but TWO abdominal surgeries, being stranded with my kids talking to the police about the old bitch IN THAT NEIGHBORHOOD. It's a nice neighborhood (another plus to the new job is that I don't have to drive through any shady areas of town where I feel compelled to lock the doors of the MFA Minivan), but puts me in a funky frame of mind that's not the best way to start a workday. Taking an alternate route only adds about two minutes to the commute but feels like admitting defeat, or at least it did...the past few days I've given myself permission to just go ahead and take the long way; I rationalize it by telling myself that highway miles are easier on a vehicle and more fuel-efficient. I think I'm going to give myself permission to take the highway from now on.
*   The XY is spiraling down into utter douchebaggery of late; he hasn't taken his visitation since he paid the child support late earlier this month except for one dinner visit where he picked the boys up two and a half hours late and returned them half an hour early, and the boys reported that they spent most of that abbreviated visit at Home Depot running errands with him. I hate that guy extra-much right now.
*   The new bees are doing well! I still haven't done a hive inspection since installing the package, but saw a drone come out of the hive yesterday. Bees only make drones when the colony is doing well (drones don't bring IN any food or help the hive in any way and are a drain on the hive's reserves--they only make drones to send their genetics out into the world when they feel they can spare the resources), so I was pleased.
*   Quote of the YEAR: "I'm buying a duck and making rabbit and duck confit out of Iden on a co-worker's recommendation, because if a guy named Jimbo with a Jesus tattoo on his neck doesn't know how to cook a rabbit I have lost all faith in The South." Jimbo did not steer us wrong; Iden was delicious.
*   How are all of YOU?
title: crouching landlord, hidden rooster

body:
Today I hauled my carcass out of bed bright and early (I worked late last night and slept poorly due to nightmares about locking my keys in the MFA Minivan and all of my teeth falling out) to attend this year's MFA Middle School academic awards ceremony, where I was frisked at the door by an armed police officer ('MURRICA!). Today Big Child was only in the top 10% for TWO subjects, not four like last year, and did not manage a perfect score on any of the standardized test subjects or straight As for the entire year (he had one B). I'm thinking I should ground him all summer!* Things continued to go downhill when Big Child and the other Top Five Accelerated Readers in the seventh grade were commended by the announcer for their "literal comprehension" (NOW THE COP MAKES SENSE, AND THIS IS WHY I DO NOT OWN ANY GUNS), but the kid was one of only two students in his grade to be recognized as a "Trailblazer" who fearlessly embraces new ideas, so I guess I won't put him on bread and water just yet.*
   The XY did not attend this year's awards ceremony, and has already announced that he will not be taking his next weekend either. Between that and his trying to weasel out of providing transportation for Big Child to get to and from the summer program for the gifted that he got into this year (which he had agreed to do since his job schedule is much more flexible than mine) he's totally blowing his chances at winning Father Of The Year (the schmuck). C'est la guerre! 
    Big Child's a pretty great kid, and I think I will keep him.
 
*   I am KIDDING, people. I would think that would be fairly obvious, but this is the innernet and you never know. I chalk this year's decline (if you can even call it that given that he's still kicking ass) up to cockiness and the advent of Teh Hormones. And maybe genetics on his father's side.
title: awards

body:
Yesterday sucked a lot in ways that were all new to me, which is kind of saying something as I am something of a connoisseur of shitty life-circumstance at this point! I don't want to be overly specific, but my day involved, in various effed-up ways, the US Military, a minor on-the-job accident (I am totally fine, but there are procedures that must be followed with these things...), a good-faith attempt at mandatory post-accident drug-testing on my part that revealed a monumental paperwork SNAFU between The Ritz and the local Urgent Care clinic, a brush with upper-level management at The Ritz ON A WEEKEND to straighten things out and ensure that we were all in compliance with company policy, and Hotter going missing.
   The end-result is that I can't go back to work until my pee is processed, which is why I was so eager to get that done in a timely manner (I even offered to pay for the test myself out of pocket if someone would reimburse me, which was why Management got involved in the first place), and that takes two to three days, so I have some unexpected and unpaid time off during which I get to stew over how I sometimes seem to be the only person working at The Ritz who actually remembers all of the policies and procedures (the security supervisor who processed the Incident Report wasn't aware I had to be drug-tested, didn't have the proper forms to give me for that, and wasn't aware of the "no working until drug test comes back" rule...and then they asked me out, which OMG I AM TECHNICALLY YOUR SUBORDINATE AND MARRIED TO BOOT). I am going to have one HUMDINGER of a debriefing with HR tomorrow! As for Hotter going missing, he was well aware that I had had a very stressful day but chose to disafuckingppear without any keys, jackets, or dogs so that I got home and spent twenty minutes searching the house and yard for a body, because I have NEVER come home and not been able to find him. He just doesn't go anywhere. EXCEPT FOR YESTERDAY. And when he finally did turn up, I discovered that Pfeffer had had babies AND EATEN THEIR BRAINS LIKE A FUCKING ZOMBIE GAHHHH!
   At that point, I will not lie, I decided that tennish weeks of not drinking was long enough to satisfy me that there was no chemical dependency issue at play and I did purchase and consume some Real Absinthe, with wormwood and everything, and take a hot bath (with Hotter supervising to ensure that I didn't pull a Whitney Houston). I am mildly disappointed to report that I did not hallucinate or anything, although as I pointed out to Hotter, given the kind of day I had had if the walls started to bleed I would have doubted that I was actually hallucinating and just put on a pair of gloves and gone looking for bodies (AGAIN. OMG HOTTER).
   And then I slept for fourteen hours.
   How are all of YOU?
 
P.S. Big Child says "How do you make a plumber cry? KILL HIS FAMILY!"
P.P.S. One piece of good news: backyard chickens are now legal again where I live! I am allowed to have up to six birds, which means that the chickens are coming home from Squatter Workshop and I am getting two more.
title: new to me

body:
Aunt Becky has gone all corporate with her bad self, which is awesome.  She's been a favorite read for a while and now she's like, an inspiration and stuff too--they grow up so fast!  *sniff*   I'm TOTALLY still on hiatus, but since Aunt Becky's celebrating such a momentous occasion and it looked like so much fun, I figured doing her interview wasn't the same about blogging about the unfolding big things.  Plus she's giving away a $50 Amazon gift card--stop by her blog for details; see the sexy lady in my sidebar on her hands and knees?  She'll take you there!1) Dave and I have a long-standing feud over cheese in a can. He
thinks it’s food of The Gods while I think it’s probably Of The Devil.
Your take?  Both.  I know, I'm so bi it's not even funny.  But if I'm honest here?  I both loved that stuff on the maybe three occasions I was low enough to eat it and hate myself for loving it, because it's so totally Of The Devil.
2) Is there any way you can think of to make the elder Gosselins go away? I AM ALL EARS.  Throw a million bucks down a manhole and slam the cover on after they jump in after (I know, I know, see y'all in The Hot Place)
3) Who is your ridiculous “I can’t admit this to anyone in polite company lest I be banned from life” crush?  I don't even know his name but okay, you know Britain's Got Talent?  The original/British version of American Idol?  Simon's on that one too, and then they've got the lady-judge who seems like a class act, and then that other guy...mmm break me off a piece of that other guy!
4) If you could fuck it all and pursue your dream (assuming, of
course, you were going to be GOOD at it), what would that dream be?  Exactly what I'm doing right now.  I know, I know, I just threw up in my mouth a little bit, but it's true.
5) They say “living well is the best revenge.” I think they are wrong. Do you?  No.  A year ago I would've said yes and gone to the mats over it, but there you have it: I'm getting less cynical by the day and...gawd somebody smack me.  Right?!?  Sickening.
6) What is the most humiliation you’ve experienced in public that you’d be willing to admit to The Internet?  No question: I won't go into detail but I've had some seriously FUBARed health stuff in the past that I've been so very VERY fortunate to bounce back from, and once you've had to use a walker in public before your thirtieth birthday and had neurological stuff going on (think random twitching, like, a LOT of it, like stereotype kind of bad...) at the same time and seen people look away all mortified when you catch them staring...well I thought my answer would be funnier too but WOW that's humiliating...moving on...
7) Are you honest with The Internet? Like, if I came over to your
house tonight (heh)(I’m coming over, yo)(heh) would I be surprised at
who I found?  Yes, I am, and no, you wouldn't.
8 ) If you could have one talent that you don’t currently possess, what would it be?  A MUCH better sense of direction.  Tom-Tom is less my co-pilot and more my co-dependent relationship.  But the devil is my bombardier!
9) There’s not always room for Jello. Is there?  Nah.
10) What’s your guiltiest of the guilty pleasures?  I could tell you, but I know you wouldn't respect me in the morning.  So um...chocolate.  Yeah.  That.

body:
Oh, man. Perspective is some crazy shit! Shortly after I wrote my last post, I got glutenated by some pizza that I am guessing was cross-contaminated (it was from a large pizza chain that until last week had managed not to cross-contaminate me, to my delight UNTIL LAST WEEK). As soon as I finished eating I had a horrible stomachache, like I'd swallowed a burning bowling ball, and things continued to follow the usual pattern of glutenation with me of Day One GI Unrest, Day Two Everything Hurts, Day Three EVERYTHING IS A HORRIBLE URGENT TRAGEDY OH GOD WHY AM I THE ONLY ONE CRYING? Day Three reminded me that while I may have a chronic depression issue, at least it does not generally get in the way of my living a fairly normal life. Day Three, though...boy. THAT was in the way!
   Somewhere in the middle of the glutenation my ex-husband got up to some fairly epic fuckery.
   Hotter courteously waited until the day AFTER that to get sick. And by "sick" I mean "his usual GI stuff got so bad that his electrolytes were out of whack and his BP was low and I invoked the Local Teaching Hospital." Funnily enough, Hotter's sickness came on shortly after he abandoned the gluten-free diet he'd been sticking to and started eating wheat again, and when he went back to being gluten-free things improved again so HMMM! You guys, I swear I'm not going to turn into one of those gluten zealots who claims that going GF will cure anything that ails you from acne to autism. But...damn. *gives gluten the side-eye*
   Every once in a great while, when life has been kicking my ass more than usual, I harken back to my fat alcoholic roots and hold a "cake and a six-pack" day wherein I bake a cake for no good reason and purchase a six-pack and silence my internal nutrition nag and spend a day consuming the cake and the six-pack. This year the 4th of July coincided with a cake and a six-pack day, so really it was like I made a birthday cake for America and raised a bottle (or six) to FREEDOM!
   That's my story and I'm sticking to it.
   How are all of YOU?
title: cake and a six-pack day

As we were tucking the Littles into bed tonight, Hotter farted.*
   "Oh Jesus Christ," I exclaimed, fanning the air while the boys rolled around laughing in their beds with their pillows over their faces.
   "It was Little Child," Hotter insisted.
   "HIS BODY ISN'T EVEN LARGE ENOUGH TO CONTAIN SUCH FOULNESS," I gasped.
   "We're practically the same size," Hotter argued. I lifted him.** "Eh, it's just about true."
   Middle Child pondered for a moment, then asked "Hotter? Do you not weigh ath much because you're mith-ing organth?"
   I explained that Hotter actually has MORE organs than the average person, since they left the old ones in.
   And then I suggested that perhaps he's lightweight because he's full of gas.
   I love Middly's logic, though!
 
* It bears mentioning that this was no ordinary fart. Hotter's chronic GI troubles cause, among other unpleasant things, frequent, loud, FECKING AWFUL flatulence. Or as I put it the other day, when children and their little ears were not present, DEAR GOD THAT SMELLED LIKE SOMEONE LIT A GANGRENOUS LIMB ON FIRE AND TRIED TO PUT IT OUT BY TAKING A HANGOVER SHIT ON IT.** Yeah, he's lost a lot of weight as a result of said GI problems' recent flare-up. Plus I'm freakishly strong, but mostly the first one. And yes, he has seen a doctor (and a specialist) about this, and they have tried various treatments, but not much helps. The prevailing theory is that between his being diabetic for twenty-some years and vessels that fed his intestines being diverted to sustain the donor organs his guts are underoxygenated and/or have nerve damage, or something like that, although it's sometimes better and sometimes worse, but there just aren't enough people with Hotter's constellation of medical issues walking around for anyone to form more than an educated guess.

body:
For those of you not already aware, I had me some Big Surgery last summer.  I was having some mid-cycle bleeding and occasional horrific abdominal pain, which I'd been ignoring for quite some time because hey, I knew I had endometriosis, right?  About the same time a good friend was having a health crisis of the OBGrrly variety and was all "ZOMG I HAVE OVARIAN CANCER AND I'M GOING TO DIIIIE!" but putting off getting it checked out, and because I am a total hypocrite I was nagging her to get it checked out.  Go, I said.  It's probably just some cysts, I said.  I went so far as to say that if SHE went to the doctor for that shizz I would do the same, and then she called my bluff and we both had ultrasounds and SHE ended up having some cysts, but there was a MASS on MY ovary (the left one to be precise).   I named him Steve.   My OB/GYN, who I pink-puffy-heart and who has seen me through some bad, gory health stuff including three high-risk pregnancies and a bout with MRSA wherein she removed a hunk of infection from my groin the size of a NY strip steak, said "I don't want to alarm you, but this thing is...suspicious-looking.  I want to get it out of there."  I said okay, well, since my ablation seems to be reaching the end of its period of efficacy (according to my doctor, 1/3 of ablations result in no more periods forever, 1/3 result in very light periods forever, and 1/3 reverse themselves entirely after about seven-ish years, and because my uterus was always a real joker I was in the first third for a year, then the second for a year, and then all heck broke loose) how about we go ahead and shoot Old Yeller while you're up in my guts, and she was like "word" and we planned a da Vinci Robot-assisted laparoscopic hysterectomy/Steviction combo procedure, which was supposed to last about an hour and a half.  The advantage of having the surgery with the robot, aside from it being the closest most of us will ever get to sex with a cyborg, is that rather than one big scar, you have five eensy ones, like this: Figure 1: What my belly was supposed to look like post-op.   Of course, I ended up in the hospital for severe pain and bleeding a week before my scheduled surgery date, and a CT-scan revealed that Steve had tripled in size, which I guess explains why I woke up from surgery after six hours looking more like this:   Figure 2: There went my lucrative career as a swimsuit model. Look of outrage on my face not pictured (to preserve pseudonymity, natch).   Apparently Steve had grown to the size of a baseball and put up quite a fight on the way out, so my doctor had had to abandon the robotic procedure, re-drape the field, and get all scalpel-happy on my midsection.  Okay, said I, fair enough; my lawyer was having a harder than expected time removing the other malignancy in my life at the time and whattayagonnado, y'know?  I wasn't even all that surprised when I got peritonitis a couple of days later and got a bonus second surgery, from which I awakened attached to a couple of these bad boys.     Good times.   Steve turned out to be benign, I lost twenty-five pounds from not eating while I had peritonitis, and all in all the entire Steviction debacle of Aught-Nine had started to look like a boon to MFA-kind once firmly ensconced in the rosy glow of the rear-view mirror.        But.   Oh yes, there is always a but.  See, I had naively figured that with no uterus and 50% less grrlnads I'd be done with PMS forever.  And PMS?  It's not my friend, y'all.  It makes my boobs all ouchy for like, a week, then I get a giant zit in some really odd location and crave sex, salt, and chocolate, usually in that order, and finally I get monumentally stupid and spend the next two or so days in a fugue-state during which I can't finish a sentence or stay awake for more than a couple of hours at a time (I also cry at the drop of a hat and become convinced that I am going to die: poor Hotter!).     It turns out that doing a hysterectomy and removing one grrlnad is kind of like castrating rapists: the rate of recidivism may drop for the most part, but sometimes you'll end up with an outlier who not only continues their crimes against humanity, but now as a result of the surgery leaves no forensic evidence when they commit their crime of choice.   Last month Hotter and I realized that there was a cyclical nature to my
periods (oh ha! Ha HA!) of uselessness, and just today after I nearly burst into tears reading the nutritional information on a box of Little Child's elemental formula (why?  I don't know, I was supposed to be steaming some broccoli at the time) I checked back
in my personal e-mail archives and realized that I did this exactly
twenty-eight days ago.  Which means two things:1.  Hi, I'm MFA Mama, and I'm an outlier.  This last weekend I had a zit on my eyelid, and then let my freak flag fly on Twitter, y'all saw how stupid I got, and now, well...wait, what was I saying?and2.  One of you science-types should feel free to write about the world's first case of synchronization via social media, because I've been exchanging a lot of Twitter DM's and e-mails with The Checkout Girl recently (and clearly she is the alpha bitch).

body: First of all, thank you all for your kind words about Big Child.  Now that he's been on the stronger antibiotic for a couple of days he seems better; less spacey, and his appetite has picked up a bit.  I am really hoping that the pediatrician was right and this is all from a bad infection.  We're still going to follow up with the hematologist about his wonky labs and I still plan to push for a referral to a pediatric endocrinologist, but it's very reassuring to see improvement with the antibiotic.     Hotter got jealous of all the attention Big Child was getting, though, and developed a Man Cold that seemed to be headed for Man-monia.     It went like this:Day OneHotter: Unnngh I think I'm getting sick.MFA Mama: DON'T YOU DARE!Hotter: Eh, I usually kick things in a day or two, it's just a cold.Day TwoHotter: Ohhhhgod I hate being sick.  MFA Mama: If you're not better tomorrow we're taking you to the doctor.Hotter: NO DOCTORS!  IT'S ONLY A COLD, AND THIS IS ONLY THE SECOND DAY.MFA Mama: We'll see.Day ThreeHotter: coughcoughcoughcoughhackcoughsniffleMFA Mama: You need antibiotics.Hotter: Do not.  Besides, I don't have a doctor down here and I don't know what antibiotics are safe to take with the transplant, remember that time I took a Z-pack and it messed me up and the nephrologist said I could've gone into rejection?MFA Mama: Yeah, that time I told you you should check with him before taki--Hotter: NOBODY LIKES A KNOW-IT-ALL!  And I'm totally turning the corner.Day FourHotter: Oh god, I'm dying.MFA Mama: That's it, you're going to the doctor.Hotter: I'M A LITTLE BETTER!MFA Mama: No you're not, and it's Friday.  I am NOT taking you and all three kids to the ER this weekend.Hotter: But I don't know what anti--MFA Mama: I just called your nephrologist.  They said Levaquin is fine.Hotter: I don't WANT to go to the doctor, I hate the doctor, I'll have the MEAN FACE the WHOLE TIME WE'RE THERE!MFA Mama: You go right ahead.  Here are your clothes.  Put them on.(everyone gets in the car)Hotter: Ugh, it's in my chest now, I don't feel so hot.  I'm NOT putting the gown on though.MFA Mama: YOU WILL DO WHATEVER THEY TELL YOU TO DO AND YOU WILL USE YOUR COMPANY MANNERS!(at the doctor)Nurse: Here's a gown, put it on, we're going to do a chest x-rayMFA Mama: ...Hotter: I'm--MFA Mama: PUT IT ON!Hotter: (puts the gown on, mean face in place)MFA Mama: (takes pictures with her phone, texts them to The Wrath)(The Wrath calls MFA Mama)MFA Mama: Hello?The Wrath: I SEE THAT LOOK ON HIS FACE, YOU TELL HIM I SAID TO KNOCK IT THE HELL OFF AND HE SHOULD HAVE GONE IN YESTERDAY!MFA Mama: Your mom says hi.Hotter: Nobody likes either one of you.MFA Mama: He says hi back.Doctor: Well your bloodwork is okay and so is the chest x-ray, but you definitely need antibiotics so this doesn't turn into pneumonia.  It's a good thing you came in.MFA Mama: It's a good thing he LISTENED TO ME.Doctor: He's lucky to have you.Hotter: (grumbling)Day FiveHotter: OH MY GOD, I'M REALLY DYING, THIS IS HORRIBLE, YOU SHOULD HAVE MADE ME GO IN SOONER.MFA Mama: I was trying not to be too bossy.Hotter: Next time be bossy.MFA Mama: Ooookay then.Hotter: Of course, I won't remember this conversation.  I have brain damage.*MFA Mama: You're welcome.*  Hotter had a stroke shortly after his most major of surgeries and while he is smarter than the average bear and can unsnap a bra with the hand on the side the stroke affected, which leads me to believe he has made a full recovery, he likes to point out whenever he forgets something that he HAS BRAIN DAMAGE and remind me not to "mock his wheelchair."  We take our laughs where we can get them around here.

body: There is a lot going on in my life, and most of it I can't write about on here.  What I can write about is so heavily tied into The Unbloggable that it's almost impossible to mention, but it's also too big to ignore.   What I can say is that I am Very Worried about Big Child's health right now.  We're on top of it, and we have follow-up appointments with the appropriate specialists, but I'm scared silly about what some recent lab work revealed.  I am so very grateful for my husband's educated observations as a former Type I diabetic that led me to take Big Child to the pediatrician for some symptoms that I thought were simply stress-related, and that the kindness of strangers allowed us to get the lab work she ordered drawn without insurance information from the policyholder.   There were a couple of alarming things on Big Child's CBC, but the main concern right now is that he might be a Type I diabetic in the making (he's not at all fat, in fact he's rather skinny, and he eats a very healthy, low-sugar diet* unless he's visiting The XY so if he is diabetic it would be Type I, not Type II).  His A1C, for those of you who know what that is, was 6.1, which did not please me because I was hoping it would be low enough to dispel all concern and instead it's in the "high-risk" category.  Type I diabetes is something that takes a while to go from "fine" to "not-fine" but then tends to convert rather rapidly, and since an A1C is the average snapshot of blood sugar levels from about ninety days my fear is that he's in the process of converting from fine to not-fine, with the most recent blood sugar levels accounting for the high A1C, and all we can do is watch and wait for follow-up labs to show us whether anything is about to declare itself.  He's also on some whopper antibiotics, because the pediatrician is hoping his very abnormal labs are the result of that sinus infection not going away (and yes, infection can raise blood sugar, but I don't think being sick for a couple of weeks could inflate an A1C like that).  His WBC was 6.6 so I'm not sure I buy the infection theory, but I would love to be wrong.   I hate waiting.*   Since Hotter used to be diabetic and I have occasional issues with hypoglycemia (plus two kids with ADHD) we tend to avoid sugar and simple carbohydrates here at Casa MFA.  I use half Splenda in baking things that call for sugar, and we usually have fruit for dessert.  Candy is something my kids only get on holidays, and they don't drink soda or straight juice (I dilute fruit juice 50/50 and mostly they drink milk or water anyway).  Lots of whole grains, lean protein, and healthy fats like avocados.  This is so unfair.

body: *   I can't really say much about what's been occupying my time offline lately, and it sucks.*   Big Child seems much better, and is still on antibiotics.  Hotter and Little Child are still sick-ish and still on their antibiotics, but improving.  So physically, health-related things are on an upward trend here.*   Mentally...I guess I can say that I had finally gotten counseling set up for the older two children to help them deal with the divorce fallout in general and some recent things that have happened outside of my household in particular (I've been trying to get them into therapy for well over six months, but since we have a primary and secondary insurance and very few providers accept the primary, which is an HMO, and even fewer providers accept the secondary, it's like the psychotherapeutic Venn Diagram from hell), but then the other party with whom I share joint legal custody canceled their first appointments, which were supposed to be yesterday (when I tried to get the appointments rescheduled they informed me that without consent from both sides it was a liability for their therapists, who are mandated reporters, ahem, to see my children at all but they'd make room in the schedule tomorrow), and then today I got a message from the office manager letting me know that suddenly they didn't have space in their schedule with providers who take both our insurances at all, and therefore they wouldn't be able to work with my kids.*   Due to some recent issues one child in particular has been having, it makes me ill that I can't get him some counseling and am back to square one with that.*   Per the MFA visitation schedule, this weekend is slated to be an "away weekend" for the children.  I am worried sick.*   I also kind of feel like I pulled a "bait and switch" on Hotter; he married me thinking that I was generally in good spirits and the children would be away from home once a week for dinner visitation and every other weekend, and for the past month that hasn't been the case because various agencies have been investigating certain events that have transpired while the children were away before and they couldn't go away again until various officials had mulled over the findings of said investigations, and I have been kind of a wreck.*   So that's really all I can say, except that I'm sorry I'm not all "whooo contest!  Heeeeyyyy recipes!"  Hopefully my blogging mojo will return shortly.*   Um...carry on.

body: Dear Mr. Marshall,   May I call you Bob?  You've presumed enough about my life that I feel okay about being a little presumptuous in return.  Look, Bob.  I've read your remarks about disabled children being a punishment inflicted by "nature" on women who have had abortions prior to parenting through birth.  Or is it a "special punishment Christians would suggest?"  You don't seem terribly sure, and I could blast you for smearing nature, which you did (and which offended me; leave nature out of your -isms), or smearing Christians, which you also did (and while I'm not Christian, I'm sure any real Christians out there, which is to say, non-hypocrites who practice Christianity, are shaking their heads).  I could choose to be annoyed with your opposition of an organization (by which I mean Planned Parenthood) that helps a lot of low-income women obtain vital healthcare, including contraception and abortion, as well as things like screenings for, oh, cancer and stuff.  Heck, I could even jump on board the teetering bandwagon of folks pointing their fingers through the gaping holes in your logic there or simply having bad fun with your general egregiousness (and briefly did, on Twitter).   I won't do any of those things here, though.   See, it took me a night's worth of very bad sleep to figure out just why I found your words so offensive, and now that I have I thought I'd share something with you, something that you may not have considered, something that I hope you'll actually hear.   That "punishment" you referred to?  Those are my children you're talking about, Bob, and I don't think you understand how far out of line you are in implying that kids like mine are any less of a gift than any other children are.  I'm not one of those "I'm THANKFUL my child has a disability!" types; if I could wave a magic wand and make the things my kids struggle with more than their peers go away I'd do it without a second thought, the same way I kiss their hurts and help them with their homework.  That's what parents do, we try and make our kids' lives better any way we can.  And they do the same for us without even having to try, whether they have a disability or not.  My children are not punishments to me, Bob (and if you didn't bother to click on the Twitter link I'll go ahead and throw it in here that I've never had an abortion or even a miscarriage, although your logic is flawed enough that I debated even saying anything about that at all), they're a privilege.  Children in GENERAL aren't punishments, which is also why I don't think it's for you to tell a woman who doesn't want to carry a pregnancy to term or can't do it safely that she has to do it anyway.  You have offended me personally, morally, and, since I teach people how to apply logic, even professionally.  Wow.   Shame on you.                                                                                                  Sincerely, MFA Mama
title: an open letter to Bob Marshall

body: Little Child, who we often call "Mini-man" around here, got jealous of the attention Big Child and Hotter garnered with their recent health crises and began coughing juicily and vomiting his feedings last night.  This morning I called Giant Pediatric Practice bright and early and made him an appointment while he and Hotter had a "sock battle" (they were supposed to be sorting and folding socks; instead they rolled them into balls and went to war, proving that with enough testosterone involved ANYTHING can become a weapon).     "He doesn't look that sick," Hotter noted.   "Uh huh," I said, helping a giggling Little Child into his coat.   On the way to the pediatrician's office Little Child was rather solemn, and then when we pulled into the parking lot he asked me to hurry up and get him out of the minivan and proceeded to vomit loudly all over the asphalt (leaning over and spreading his feet wide and managing to avoid soiling his clothes or shoes; it's a sad superpower to have but Little Child is a veritable virtuoso of vomiting).   The pediatrician we saw agreed with me that Little Child was doing That Thing He Does and getting dreadfully ill, and gave him the same dose of the same very strong antibiotic as Big Child is taking and some Zofran.   When we got home, Little Child informed me in a very pitiful little voice that he didn't think he could walk into the house, so I carried him.   Little Child hadn't kept anything down since yesterday morning, and when he requested ramen (he likes the noodles "naked" and will eat nearly a tablespoon of them at a sitting sometimes) I made a grocery run just for him.  I left him lying on the couch looking very, very sad, and when I came back I found him and Hotter snuggled up looking very content.   It warmed my black little heart, y'all.  They're so sweet together.   I'm pleased to report that Little Child kept his first dose of antibiotics and GI-doctor-approved decongestant down (with the help of the Zofran) and has kept down two very reduced-volume feedings (mixed at half-strength with Pedialyte) since then and perked up considerably (maybe he'll even pee soon).  But y'all?  Three out of four of my boys are on antibiotics right now, and if Middle Child drops next I will LOSE MY JUNK ENTIRELY.   Stay tuned...
title: mini-man cold

body: So like, a MONTH ago Middle Child and Big Child got good and sick and did a course of antibiotics.  Then it turned out that Big Child was STILL sick and that earned him a SECOND round of STRONGER antibiotics (and he is no longer showing symptoms of Type I Diabetes, so while I still plan to ask for a re-check of his A1C in a month or so, the person with the actual medical degree may have been correct about it all being due to infection, huh, go figure), and Hotter jumped on board the bandwagon because he was jealous of all the attention or something, the loser, and Little Child was next, and--   What?  Why yes, I did just call my loving husband a LOSER, because yeah do you know what he did?   He took his ten days of Levaquin and improved vastly while I quietly took vitamins and washed my hands raw and then...   he...   said "well hey, everybody's better and YOU didn't even get SICK!"   So naturally now I'm coughing.  Bastard.
title: I think this might be grounds for divorce

body: So I got one of these:     I've attempted the whole Blackberry thing before, with a little pink Pearl model, and was Not Impressed.  Engraftment failed and when I dropped it into a jar of olive brine (oh shuttit, that could totally happen to anyone!) after a month or so I wasn't all that sad to go back to my free-with-contract flip-jobby.   This time, though...well, I dunno if it's the touchscreen or what, but it's going better so far.  Still precarious, but my body isn't outright rejecting the technology.   I know a lot of y'all love your crackberries, and I...well, I need you to tell me just what applications I can no longer live one single day without and why.  Pretend you're telling it to my late gypsy-Jewish grandma and explain it like I'm technophobic, cranky, prone to magical thinking, and perhaps English isn't my first language.  Please?ETA: Yes, it's a Storm 9530.  And please to discuss pros and cons of various Twitter apps, I do not need the maps so much because they will pry my TomTom from my cold dead hands, and what the heck is Blackberry Messenger, anyway?  Does anyone even use it in the Age of Twitter?

body: *   I bought a lawnmower today, y'all.  That doesn't have much to do with anything, I'm just saying:  A damn hellsakes LAWNMOWER.  I think this means I'm officially a grownup.  Oh, wait...*   The XY shaved off ALL of his facial hair.  This is major, because a) it's only the second time he's done that in the ten years I've known him and b) um...it's an interesting look.  He was all "what do you mean 'interesting,' why are you laughing???" at the exchange today (it was a Daddy Dinner Date night here) and I was all "[silent rictus of mirth]" and he was like "it makes me look younger!"  And y'know, he's totally right (if by younger he meant "like my face-vagina got a Brazilian").  I may have offered to give him a PAP smear if he'd say "ahh."  I was hoping he would call me an aunt (spelled with a c) so I could be all "at least mine's not on my FACE" and then maybe ask him if this was a tribute, like when some men have their mother's face tattooed on them, but no dice.  Life is deeply unfair sometimes.*   Also today Big Child antagonized Middle Child until Middle Child LOST HIS EVERLOVING MIND and then Big Child was like "he has anger issues" and Middle Child roared "I DO NOT HAF ANGER SHOOSE!" and Hotter and I died, because that's how Middle Child says shoes, and anger shoes, y'all.  Then Hotter asked me where Big Child got the phrase "anger issues" from, and I gave him A Look and he was like "ohhhh, right."  *   So yeah, maybe The XY is hoping the new look (I call it the "porn face" and Hotter was all "why porn face?" and I was like "because it's shaved, obviously" and he looked at me like I was either the best wife he's ever had or the worst but I've met his ex-wife so I think it was a compliment) will distract people from his Anger Shoes?  I don't know, I graded until my eyes bled last night and I'm a little bit delirious from sleep-deprivation so this is what y'all get.  Maybe I should have put that part first.  Oh well.  THANK YOU AND GOODNIGHT!

body: Family therapy.  Oh man.     People's common need for boundaries and hatred of feedback sometimes take go in unexpected directions while you do the work.  Like the ones who seem fine in daily life will nut up in session, cry, yell, invade others' space with their pointing finger and their anger shoes and monopolize the whole discussion...meanwhile the one you thought was The Problem of the day will walk into the office, make mature and logical contributions to the discussion and generally handle their junk in admirable style then crap their pants or have a panic attack in the car on the way home.     If that's not enough awesome, after the requisite damage control and dinner and homework you can then put the kids to bed and pull out your laptop to look at some aspect of your work that is making you want to quit your entire field that day and WHAMMO!  You'll suddenly see where the same communication issues are to blame as the ones you have with the family member you'd most like to punch right in their big stupid jerkface that particular day except YOU'RE in the role of the big stupid jerkface this time, and ohhhhh it burns.   Throw in something most likely unrelated but ripe with potential symbolism like someone suddenly developing an itchy, skin-peeling rash under their wedding band and attempting to hide it for fear of being accused of harboring something but making it worse...good times, y'all.  Good times.
title: bad fun with family therapy

body: ...no not really, but you might after you read this.     My husband, who has brain damage, no really is wonderful, did a bunch of laundry and other cleaning-type stuff in addition to riding herd on the MFA children while I graded papers today.  Toward the end of the day he kind of came unhinged a little, as evidenced by his giving me the crazy eye and informing me in chilly tones that he was trying to clean (I had had the temerity to remove a small saucepan from the cabinet and place it on the stove for a cup of hot cocoa).  So I sent him to take a nap in his desk chair play WoW for a bit while I threw dinner together and took over the laundry and child-herding.   I noticed that the washing machine was making that "one of these things just doesn't belong here" noise as it ran, but thought it might've been the button on a pair of jeans and ignored it.  Then, while the chicken for my enchilada bake I gave the recipe for on Twitter was simmering in the sauce with the onions and garlic, I went to switch the clothes into the dryer.   As I pulled the load of wet clothes out of the front-loader, something metallic clanked and clattered, and bluish-white light flickered inside the washing machine.  I thought maybe it was getting ready to electrocute me, so I shut the power to the laundry room off at the breaker box, then investigated further and found all of these things inside the drum of the washing machine:  He really does have brain damage, y'all.   The red thing is obviously a lighter.  The blue thing?  Was the source of the light; it's a touch-activated LED flashlight that belongs to my middle child (the black strip is the touch-activated switch; anything moist will trigger it, so I set it off moving the wet clothes).  And that metal thing is a pill fob belonging to Hotter, which he is supposed to keep on him at all times seeing as how it CONTAINS EMERGENCY MEDICATION TO TREAT A LIFE-THREATENING MEDICAL CONDITION.   Guess which of the three objects were still usable after going through the wash?   If you guessed all three, you'd be right.  The flashlight continued to work, the lighter lights, and the rubber gasket in the pill fob kept the meds safe and dry.   Wow.
title: I believe in miracles...

body:
Y'all, I won't lie: the MFA household is feeling the financial pinch 
right now.  And rather than dwell unhealthily on the positive 
correlation between "how much it costs" and "how unhappy it will make 
me" (snuggles with my kids, reading my friends' blogs, and marital 
congress are free; family therapy, time with a lawyer, and time in front
 of a judge are not--SEE?), which would just give me a permanent and 
unbecoming case of The Crazy Eye, I thought maybe when I found something
 that helps me save a little I'd share my experience with y'all and 
maybe it'll help you too.  I am not receiving any compensation from any of the companies I'm about to mention (although if one of them reads this and wants to offer me a kickback my e-mail is on the "About" page!), just sharing information because I am a giver.
   For example, if you haven't already signed up for a Bing.com cash 
back account?  You're totally missing out.  It's free and you can earn 
varying percentages of "cash back" on purchases from participating sites
 (which include some of the big names like Sears, Home Depot, Circuit 
City, Best Buy, etc. as well as a lot of specialty retailers of just 
about anything--you can either search Bing.com itself or if you're 
looking for a particular store you can go to the "shopping" tab and 
select "cash back stores" you can get an alphabetized list--it's worth noting that you can usually order gift cards from participating sites at the cash-back rate as well) if you go to
 the site via Bing.com and pay with PayPal.  There's not really a catch, although you have to wait 60 days to get your cash back (you can have them deposit it directly into your PayPal or bank account, or get it in Amazon.com gift cards and I think there's an option to get a check but with a fee).  You can even use Bing.com to get cash back on e-Bay purchases, but only on "Buy it Now" items, sadly.   Drugstore.com (which gives you 10% cash back and free delivery on orders over $49, plus 5% "drugstore dollars," which you can only use on their site) is probably my personal favorite, because they sell all of the non-food items you would ordinarily buy at the grocery store at fairly competitive prices (sometimes you can do better at your local supermarket if you take the price at face value, but remember, 15% TOTAL CASH BACK).  If you've never shopped there before, it's worth doing a search for "Drugstore.com coupon codes," and you can find deals for new customers ranging from 20% off your entire order to $10 off plus free shipping on orders over $25.  They also have "online coupons" you can click to use on certain products, and occasionally offer 20% cashback on just Nintendo or Hamilton Beach products (my kids' holiday gifts and our new crockpot came from Drugstore.com!) or free gifts (like right now if you buy two Fekkai products you can get a free travel-size Glossing Cream with olive oil, and I'm a total slut for Fekkai; the Glossing Cream is my favorite product of theirs).  We get all of our paper products and toiletries from here, and stock up on sale items (if you happen to need Miralax, which Little Child does, daily, they often have the big bottles on sale for $19.99 so I keep an eye out for that).     If you're looking for grocery-groceries, at least the non-perishable kind, Meijer's participates in the Bing.com cash back program (their regular rate appears to be 4% currently, although for a new customer it's 15%!!!), and if you sign up for a Meijer's "account" on their site (not a line of credit or anything, just creating a login) you'll get a welcome e-mail giving you a coupon code for free shipping on any order over $75 (ordinarily the cut-off is much higher).  They only sell by the case (and the selection is limited but includes some stuff we use, like Campbell's soups, Gatorade, Stovetop Stuffing, canned tomato sauce, etc.), but it's worth doing at least once at the new-customer cash back rate.   We usually buy "EUC" (excellent used condition, yo) clothes on e-Bay, but Old Navy does Bing, and there are a ton of shoe stores on Bing.com, some of which give hefty cash back percentages (we've bought sneakers from Shoebuy.com and had good experiences with them).   Looking for appliances, furniture, a lawnmower or something else gigantic and heavy to ship?  Most of the home improvement chains will let you buy online and pick your item up at a local store.   And that's about all I have to say right now, because we're mid-drama here and if I started complaining this would be ten pages long.  What are you doing to save money lately that's worth sharing?  Talk to me!
title: a cheapskate's guide to online shopping

body: Last night I was in a cranky stupor, having spent the day grading.  The kids were up late and crabby, but I'd decided to reward myself with a few minutes' recreational innernettage before putting them to bed and stumbled across Want Not for the first time (LOVE!)...I was happily taking advantage of the awesome Restaurant.com deal Mir shared, having found an amazing local Hibachi restaurant that participated (Hotter is a huge Japanophile and has been wanting to take me to a real Hibachi place, because the fact that I've never actually been to one bothers him a LOT), when I had this flash of "what am I DOING buying us a dinner out ahead of time when something could happen to him ANY SECOND and then I'd get the gift card in the mail and want to DIE?!?"   I thought I was having a moment of temporary insanity, because while I suddenly felt like I needed to save him from imminent doom, my husband was right across the room at his computer, breathing in and out and placidly watching anime despite my Very Bad Feeling.  I decided not to say anything about it because I like to keep my crazy to myself, tried unsuccessfully to shake the Very Bad Feeling off, and turned back to the order form I'd been filling out.   Then Hotter jumped up and said "I'm going to have a seizure.  Find the Valium," and the Very Bad Feeling went away.      I'm actually pretty good in a crisis.     He laid down on our bed and I ran and got the Valium and brought it to him, checked on the kids, and then closed the bedroom door and sat next to him touching his fingertips (pro tip: you don't want to hold your loved one's hand if they're having a seizure) and making him smile nervously with my bad jokes until he started to twitch, then watched his airway until it was over.   Then I covered him up with a blanket and went and put the kids down and graded a few more essays like it was just one more Saturday night at Casa MFA.   If I get that Very Bad Feeling about my husband again, though?  I think I'll quietly make sure I know where his Valium is.

body: So last night I was minding my own business when a friend hit me up on g-chat, and after some small-talk asked me if I could keep a secret, then was all "so, you've slept with another girl before, right?"  I answered honestly since the friend in question was too far away to be laying the groundwork for a husband's surprise birthday threesome or anything (that's probably much funnier if it's never happened to you), and then she revealed she'd recently had a fling with another woman.   I asked her how that was, and she replied "smells like fish, tastes like chicken: it's ALLIGATOR!"   And just like that I nearly lost my life today when my iPod threw this at me in "shuffle" mode while I was taking a swig of my drink.  True story.

body:
*   I added ANOTHER new department to my list of job codes and checkstub lines at work this week, and it involved figuring out how to make waist-length hair play nicely under a paper chef's hat (in case you ever have to do that, the answer turned out to be a VERY high ponytail wound into a bun). This isn't something I'm likely to be doing very often, but I've discovered that once you have a job code for a department, you can usually pick up work there if they are desperate for bodies or someone calls out on a busy day. So that's nice.
*   I also went back to work in the department I quit working in a while back. They fired the two worst workers since I was there last, and it's a much more pleasant environment now in terms of the people I work with there. That's the good news! The bad news is that it's still pretty chaotic and really physically grueling. But it pays well! I don't know, I may well end up quitting it again, but this is something I'm very good at that can be a lot of fun when it goes well.
*   It turns out the culprit in my recent glutenation was a handful of jellybeans I ate at work during a moment of stress when a co-worker offered me the bag. I started to say no thank you but I really like jellybeans and figured there wasn't much chance of there being gluten in them, except no: modified food starch. Which contains gluten. GOD DAMN IT. I learned this when I went to buy myself a bag of the same brand of jellybean at the grocery store and now I'm sad.
*   Because life loves me, right after my last post I came down with pinkeye, although I didn't miss any work because I went to the doctor BETWEEN the shifts of a split double at the first signs of trouble and got some antibiotic drops before my eyes looked bad enough to advertise that I had The Filth. Don't worry, I practiced obsessively good hand hygiene. Like, more so than usual even :)
*   There has been some epic fuckery of the interpersonal variety amongst various parties at work, which has made life unduly interesting in a "DO NOT WANT" kind of way, but I think it's winding down now, so that's good.
*   I am SO tired/broke down/busted-up/burned out. Ten shifts in six days may just be the last stop before my absolute breaking point. I think I need to find myself a foot and ankle specialist, because between Paul on one side and my jacked-up ankle on the other that started hurting mid-February and has only gotten worse, I think I need at least one cortisone shot. But then I might just need to rest for a bit, since one knee and the other hip and my back and everyotherdamnthing is also acting up and it's possible I'm just really fucking worn-out.
*   I was simultaneously outraged and elated to find that the closest feed store was giving away six chicks with any feed purchase, and came home with six "Araucanas." Although I'll be surprised if any of them are rumpless and only one has wee puffy cheek tufts. They'll be cool-looking birds that lay blue and green eggs, though, I'm sure and that is all I really want. Well, that and for Skeeter to quit acting like MFA Birdie's old cage is his personal Easter basket:
Figure One: Although I'm not really sure what I *thought* would happen when I put out a six-pack of nuggets under a warming lamp with a cat in the house. Hence the bars.
*   Pfeffer is pregnant and due tomorrow-ish with what feels like a largish litter that she hopefully won't eat!
*   We're getting bees again! Hideously overpriced package bees from another state, which is everything I don't want in my hives, but all that was available by the time I got my finances to a point of being able to GET bees after Carmageddon. Oh well. They'll be Italians, which are the kind of bees I wanted to try out if local wasn't available, and my boss was gratifyingly cool about it when I told him I'd get a call at some point in a few weeks and have to drop what I was doing and leave immediately to deal with buzzing mail.
*   What's new with all of YOU?
title: bullets because I'm beat

body:
Hi there! I have been in kind of a daze lately of too much work and too little sleep, and spending most of my limited free time either gardening or reading smut. I've been feeling kind of "ehhh" about the innernet after the recent reminder that Stalky still lurks about the place, hence the lack of blogging, and had a few nights of nightmares that weren't about Stalky and were, in fact, highly ridiculous, but still extremely disturbing in the moment. Most notably one where I woke up one day to find the mummified corpse of Adolph Hitler smooshed between my mattress and box spring like a pressed flower in Nazi regalia. In that dream, convincing the authorities that I had the flat-Stanley Fuhrer in my house and to come and remove him was a challenge, and nobody else seemed nearly as exercised about the whole thing as I was. Other than that it's just the usual run-of-the-mill anxiety dreams that I have when something's eating at me, with a ridiculous twist here and there.
   Things at work are kind of here and there. The Bastard has taken a leave of absence, which is nice, because it means I'm able to work in the more lucrative department I left to avoid him. Someone else is acting the fool though, which sucks. But hey, it's always SOMEthing in life, and at least my next paycheck will be less pitiful than the last one (we are SO BROKE at the moment).
   I checked Bravo Hive and they died after all. I'm not having much luck in locating more bees at this late (bee-wise) date, and may have to be bee-less for a year.
   I guess maybe I'm a little depressed at the moment, which is no fun, but it could always be worse, right? RIGHT.
title: the flat-Stanley Fuhrer and other tales of ridiculous woe
