body:
*   I have Done Something to my right ankle, to the point that X-rays Were Taken. The good and bad news is that said X-rays showed nothing, so for the time being we're feeding it steroids.
*   Work has been a three-ring shitshow lately, although not always in a bad or me-focused way, but just in a "hotels be crazy" kind of way. Sometimes it's amusing, sometimes not.
*   Pfeffer only ended up having four bunnies, although they're thriving and last time, thank goodness, seems to have been a fluke! Iden had two, and then two days later had two more, and there were no survivors (no, she was not in with Haas for two days). Additionally, she seems to have become utterly deranged and is now dangerous to handle, so she's on the grass-finishing career path now and we're thinking we'll get another broodrabbit from fresh stock. Rabbit husbandry can be a right ugly little sideline!
*   I've started using Argan Oil on my hair, and am very impressed with the result. This is what happens when I don't talk to y'all regularly, incidentally, stuff just gets THROWN in willy-nilly.
*   The Feed-store Six are all doing well, despite the one with cheek tufts having almost met an untimely end via hairless cat the other day when I took her out to show Hotter her cheeks. Fortunately for Cheeky Chick, the would-be predatory action went down right at my feet, and unfortunately for Skeeter a swift kick put an end to the whole scene. A chipmunk-striped chick that Hotter has christened "Sparrow" (she does currently look a lot like a house sparrow) has emerged as the leader of the flock. They all need to get the hell out of my house ASAP.
*   Hotter going gluten-free is making me fat. Because he has to have ready-to-eat bread and cold cereals and sandwich buns and other THINGS about at all times. Oh, carbs.
*   I think I may be coming down with the Spring Allergen Creeping Crud. I'm coughing up...things...and my eyes look awful. I'm wondering whether I ought to do another round of antibiotic eyedrops for those, or whether I ought to just accept that sometimes you have to go to Urgent Care once a week for a bit and go back and have them listen to my chest and peep at my eyes too. But it's such a beautiful day out...
*   How are all of YOU?
title: life and other distractions

body:
*   Big Child went and got into a fairly prestigious and exciting summer program for the Gifted and Talented that's being held at an area highschool (he'll be in eighth grade next year but apparently his application essay was very compelling!); he will be studying robotics and is super-excited. GO BIG CHILD!
*   Middle Child has been reading a ton. Whenever he mentions a book he really wants to read and can't find in the school library, I buy it for him and send it to his Kindle if the budget allows, because BOOOOOOOKS!
*   Little Child...oh Little Child. When Little Child was a baby I spoiled him. Some of it was by necessity; he spent several months with an NG tube in and couldn't be further from me than arm's reach, and later on after he got his g-tube he was on continuous overnight feeds for a pretty long time, so he slept next to me because he's an active sleeper and I didn't want him to get tangled up on the food-line and pull his tube out or get formula all over himself. Some of it was stuff like letting him keep his pacifier until he was three and generally terrorize the household, because until he was about five no one was sure if he'd live or die, and if my baby was possibly going to die I wasn't going to deprive him of anything his health allowed that he enjoyed. A lot of people asked me what I was going to do if the kid DID get better, because he'd be a rotten little shit, and I always said that I would be delighted to have that problem and wouldn't be bothered. Now? I am having to walk my talk on that one, and that is all I'll say today about Little Child :)
*   Hotter has diagnosed himself via the innernet with Celiac disease, and decided to go gluten-free to see if it helps his ongoing GI woes and extreme difficulty with maintaining enough bodyfat to not shiver all the time and have to wear Big Child's hand-me-downs. I pointed out that his GI doctor had run some blood tests that indicated he did NOT have Celiac disease, but conceded that an intestinal biopsy, which he has NOT had, was the definitive test  and agreed that his going gluten-free for a while was a less-risky proposition than general anesthesia (which disturbs his precarious neurological state in scary ways) and messing with his intestines, which his donor pancreas is attached to, in ANY WAY. So we'll see how that goes I guess.
title: things people have been doing to keep busy while I've been at work

body:
I didn't want to admit it, but a lot of my depression of late has been work-related, and the reason I didn't want to admit it was a) didn't I just HAVE a shitty job? I'm giving mySELF the side-eye here because I am the common denominator in two back-to-back shitty jobs now and b) Hotter would be pissed at me. But I just can't go on being this miserable, and after last night I can safely say that what is going wrong at The Ritzier is NOT in any way my fault.
   The Ritzier is a great establishment, but unfortunately my manager there is a verbally abusive, belligerent drunk. This isn't just my assessment. There have been statements as to his drunkenness made and signed by entire shifts' worth of employees. Upper management has flat-out said things like "this guy needs to go. We are trying to fire him, but he's already threatening to sue us and we need a blood alcohol level to support terminating him, and he keeps evading that. We are so sorry you have to work with him" and "____, what the hell is wrong with you talking to MFA Mama like that?!? That is inappropriate, unprofessional, and constitutes harassment!"
   The whole thing kind of breaks my brain, and last night Drunk Boss tried to send me home "for being a whiny little bitch" (I needed a manager override for something and he resented being called to the restaurant because he is always super-busy elsewhere) (by which he means drinking and perusing the job listings on Craigslist), I went to the AGM and tried to quit, he begged me to "hang in there" and talked me down and yelled at Drunk Boss and said he wasn't allowed to send me home for asking him to do his job, and I spent my entire lunch break LITERALLY crying on the shoulder of my gay work-grandpa (that's a story for a happier post but I just love that guy!), finished my shift, came home, and told Hotter I'm looking for another job.
   That did not go over well. Hotter's concern for our family's financial survival manifests in the form of a lot of "every workplace has issues!" and "you'll never find a serving job without drama, so why leave a place with benefits?" and "you just need to be more assertive!" (which frankly sounds very victim-blamey to me, that last one, and also really fucking insensitive given that I've been on the receiving end of a lot of violence in my life and therefore REALLY DO NOT ENJOY CONFRONTATION) (plus also I TRY! Last night I stood up to Drunk Boss, with the AGM's support and backing, but you can't reason with a belligerent drunk and I don't think it'll improve the situation any).
   So yeah, I'm looking for another job, and Hotter initially tried to be all "I support you doing whatever will help you be happier" (I suspect because I was a total wreck last night and female tears are Hotter's kryptonite) but has, as I feared, devolved into making a lot of "I love you, but..." statements, and yes I broke the Blogging Prime Directive and talked about work, but the worst-case scenario there is that Stalky somehow figures out where I work and I get Dooced and honestly that would kind of be a relief at this point (mind you, being even very temporarily jobless would suck, but I can handle poverty better than THIS). Also? I was maliciously glutenated last night at work (don't ask...I REALLY need a new job) and today everything hurts and tomorrow I'm going to be an emotional basketcase, so that's swell.
   TL; DR: My job sucks and it's threatening my relationship, and that is why I am so depressed, and I need my people.
title: unfortunate

body: I woke up to two incredible things.   The first was that I had slept until eleven, Hotter had fed the kids a balanced breakfast and kept them happy and entertained, and when I stumbled out of the bedroom he was just sliding a frittata in the oven for brunch.  "Go back to bed," said THE HUSBAND OF THE YEAR, handing me a cup of caffeine and my morning meds, "I'll bring it to you in there."   The second was that the balance in my checking account, which I pulled up on the Blackberry to see whether some juggling on my part had been successful in preventing an overdraft, was: ($88,888,888,888.88)   That was the best picture I could get of the Blackberry screen with my webcam; when I pulled up my account on the computer to try and get a screengrab it said "account temporarily unavailable."   At least my husband really is a chef and all-around great guy.

body: There is a lot of administrative paperwork involved in getting married, more so if anyone in your household has any type of disability.  If you are combining two households involving people with disabilities, you should plan on spending a lot of time at your local Social Security office.   A.  Lot.  Of.  Time.   The MFA Branch of the Social Security Bureau, however, offered up the following gem for Little Child's and my edification a couple of days ago, and I can't stop thinking about it:    I texted Hotter and told him about the sign.  He said "Um...what?"  I said I was pretty sure it had to do with The Gays, but wasn't sure if it was supporting or bashing them.  Hotter was confused.  I tried to zoom with my phone's camera and get a picture of the sign, to no avail,* and finally explained that I couldn't decide whether the federal government was urging gay couples to do an end-run around The Man (our state does not currently allow gay marriage) or telling them to keep that filth behind closed doors.   Hotter said "Ohhhh...please don't start polling the waiting room on that.  We live in the South."  I said yes, yes, I know, and then told the people sitting to either side of Little Child and me never mind.   When I got home I took this to Google, which yielded this, which still doesn't tell us anything about the, ahem, subtext of the PSA.  What say ye, friends?  Are they a couple, or just, you know, short-haired identical cousins?     Either way the theme song from The Patty Duke Show has been stuck in my head for two days now and I blame the federal government.*  a few minutes later this happened, and someone, possibly the culprit, vacated the seat next to the sign, allowing me to capture it on film

body: I owe y'all some stuff (including a recipe and a giveaway, neither of which I have forgotten), but since it's the one-monthiversary of the start of National Delurking Week, I thought I'd do my Delurker Link List!  I already visited the delurkers' blogs, and commented where possible, but here without further ado are my 2010 Delurkers:Katie - We go waaay back, Katie and I.  I think we "met" in 2005 (haven't met her face-to-face, although maybe someday!) and I've been reading her ever since.  She's embarking on a new chapter in her life (newly single mama settling into a new-ish career as a nurse) and if she ever starts blogging regularly again (I'm like the Jewish Mother she never had, y'all, do you see that, the GUILT?) you should read her, because she has an awesome narrative voice.Angela - I think Angela read this blog the first time around...in addition to blogging she gives good Twitter!  Welcome to watch my kids any time :)Katie W. - Another old-school blog-friend, Katie is a sweet, slyly funny, and extremely TALENTED (seriously--she's knit us things before and is an ARTIST with fiber!  Go and look at her blog for pictures of her knitting projects!) girl from the UK.  We commiserate sometimes over teaching and she keeps me from driving my kids' teachers insane when I lose my head over things.  Gets big love from the MFA household for her amazing care packages, which generally include such goodies as British sweets for the children, Very Good Chocolate for mama, bath bombs, trinkets for my "break glass in case of emergency" distraction hoard of small toys, and knitwear made with love and her own lily-white hands (she made Big Child a pair of Spiderman mittens that are the envy of all his friends)!terri c. - Who occasionally goes by a pseudonym in the comments section :)  Terri is a longtime reader who also happens to be a screamingly hilarious writer.  Go and read her blog!  She has a gift for euphemisms, and writes with humor, compassion, and an amazing perspective on her work as a hospice chaplain.k - no link, because she likes to remain mysterious.  But she's always reading and we have amazing conversations on g-chat.  Much love, lady!Rayne of Terror, a.k.a. "devivo" - Another old blog-friend, fabulous commenter, entertaining and intelligent blogger, and mother of my Tiny Boyfriend (Quinn, a.k.a. giganto-baby).  Also notable for her incredible lactational prowess (all of that chub on my Tiny Boyfriend is breastmilk, y'all).Mel - no link as of yet, although there are rumors that she's starting a blog.  One of the Innernets Who Saved Christmas in 2008.May - yet another smart cookie and screamingly funny writer, although I wish the universe would give her some happier material; I regularly spit things out onto myself reading her blog and Hotter enjoys hearing excerpts.  Poor May has the worst reproductive luck of anyone I know, and is a fellow bleeder (without a formal diagnosis as of yet although I think she may have what we have and we've exchanged e-mails about it) who makes me very grateful that I had kids young and then had a hysterectomy.  Hairy Farmer Wifey - This lady is SO funny!  I say that about each of these gals but it's true!  Her son Harry reminds me a lot of Middle Child, but MORE accident prone, the poor little guy...I <3 Harry.  SO cute.  If only he'd stop falling and hurting himself :(  Her pictures of cakes she decorates make me drool.  Someday I will take Britain by storm and meet Katie W., May, and HFW for drinks.  Someday.J. - a fellow Hopeful Parents writer (although I missed my day yesterday because I forgot--I think I've remembered my day all of ONCE...poor Christina always has to remind me.  She's going to let me know if a "hole" comes up in the schedule and I'll be sure to tell y'all to go and look if I post something over there).  J. is another special-needs parent, and I love reading her posts from the trenches.RocketScientista - she found me via JustArikia's Twitter stream and delurked, and I clicked over and WOW!  She seems like she'd be VERY cool to have a beverage with.  Smart women are hot.  I have very hot commenters here.Lyrehca - Named after one of my prescription drugs.  I lurked on her blog for ages but recently commented on a post of hers about hormones and their affect on blood sugar (apparently some endos dismiss it whereas my own told me as soon as he diagnosed me with reactive hypoglycemia that progesterone makes your blood sugar wonky; this makes lots of sense given that it drives gestational diabetes and I'm fortunate that he told me this because before the surgery to remove The Tumor Formerly Known As Steve, a.k.a. The Steviction, I would have crazy lows during the latter portion of my cycles).  Lyrehca is a Type I Diabetic who blogs about her diabetes and its impact on her fertility.  She has one adorable son and is currently trying for number two.  Everyone should go and buy her book.Queen Bee - she found me through Not Me Monday! and is RAISING HER KIDS RIGHT, DANG IT!  Sadly her comments section rejected my advances, so I sent her an e-mail :)Melissa - another blog-friend from way back who sent me a VERY cool t-shirt years ago!  Melissa is awesome.Brigindo - I want to be her when I grow up.  She's an awesome mother, teacher, and academic who posts food-blogging pictures that make me hungry.  Our lives seem to be following a similar-ish trajectory, and if I end up like her in ten or fifteen years that's a-okay with me!Dianna - blogless, but delurked anyway and seems like a cool person.Beth - longtime reader and apparent lurker extraordinaire, but I'm onto her now!  I love me some librarians.Fawn - I love this lady, and not just because she sent me some awesome tea one time when I won a contest on her blog.  Her daughter Jade is on the ketogenic diet, which requires a level of precision I don't think I could handle.  She's another allergy mom, and we need to swap some recipes.  Also mother of Halia, future wife of my youngest son :)Ivan Toblog (a.k.a. IT) - found me through The Checkout Girl, who is hilarious, and left a link.  Funny stuff, y'all!Allison - another blogless wonder, but she delurked and I <3 her for it!

body:
Hotter talked to his mom today, and apparently things up in the Arctic Tundra are not so good. The Wrath lost her job a couple of months ago and has been collecting unemployment while looking for another one, but the job market is grim in general, and especially for someone who is pushing eighty and doesn't own a car. Plus Lefty is out of jail (WHY? WHAT HAPPENED TO ALL THE FELONIES?) and I'm sure that's expensive for The Wrath, since she can't say no to him. My brother-in-law, Loud and Crazy, who lives off with her, has apparently started to panic that they will lose her their house and be out on the street. I'm not sure how likely that actually is, although it's certainly a possibility since Lefty drained her retirement account via a checkbook he stole (she never pressed charges because he's FAMILY and so the money is gone) and unemployment doesn't last forever. What I wasn't expecting to hear was that Hotter had assured The Wrath that she AND HER THREE CATS could always come and live with us.   I just...in THEORY I am not ENTIRELY against this; The Wrath is good people, she's Hotter's mom, and she has helped us out before. I certainly wouldn't turn her away if she had no other option. But we are already five people in 1,200 square feet sharing one bathroom (and one breadwinner, who is allergic to cats with fur). There would need to be some very firm boundaries (i.e. This Is How Much You Contribute To The Household Bills From Your Pension Without Exception, Absolutely No More Animals, Lefty Isn't Allowed Here) that would, in and of themselves, probably be dealbreakers on her end (plus she doesn't want to live in The South). And even then it would be A LOT. By which I mean I am 90% sure it would break me, or at the very least my marriage.    So that's swell. 
   In other news I have a job interview tomorrow for a position I don't exactly love the thought of, but I'd like to have a second job lined up just in case things go south at The Ritzier (Drunk Boss being gone is fabulous, yes, but we don't know who will be replacing him and it's possible the New Boss will be just as bad or even worse so I'm not letting my guard down or celebrating anything just yet).
   How are all of YOU?

Given that the injury is situated on either side of one of the joints
of the finger and the animal that caused it (think livestock) weighs
roughly a ton I think the XY did the right thing by taking the child to
see a doctor, but...in all honesty had this happened on my watch I
might well have washed
it soap and water, applied some Neosporin, and called it a day.  The
bruising is minor and the abrasion superficial.  Middle Child's Xbox
skills are unaffected by the splint and he's pretty chipper about the
whole thing and pleased to have seen a "pitcher of my bones!"     I on the other hand am fit to be tied.  While it seems that the XY told Middly he wasn't allowed to call and tell me about what happened to his finger WHEN it happened (Friday, I now know) because "you don't want Mommy to be SCARED," informing me of what had occurred by presenting me with a bottle of heavy-duty antibiotics, a roll of splint adhesive, and the brochure from an orthopedic group who'd seen my child while dropping the youngest off yesterday morning?  Well, I may or may not still have the crazy eye.   We won't speculate as to whether scaring the pants off of me was intentional on the XY's part, because while it took nearly a decade of marriage to the man to get it through my thick skull, I did finally learn that it ultimately doesn't matter whether he does things because he's lacking in intelligence or, well, an Oedipus.  He does them, they suck, and we hate him now, the end.

body:
So I just went on a job interview. Spoiler alert: I will not be working at this place. First of all, it's a sports bar. I thought I could be cool with that, but no. I walked in and looked around and immediately felt all itchy. Strike one. Then the "manager" came to "interview" me. She had a tattoo of a pentagram on her middle finger. Strike two*. "You...went to...college?" I'm used to having the WTF Higher Education conversation with potential employers. They generally want to know why I want to be a waitress or bartender if I have a terminal degree. If they're educated themselves, they get that degrees (or at least, liberal arts degrees) do not unlock these magic doors that blast money at you any time you choose to open them, but this girl...not so much. She looked like she maybe had gotten a GED on her second or third try**. She explained that working the shifts I had indicated I was available, I would most likely earn $30-$50 per (six-hour) shift (STRIKE THREE YER OUTTA HERE!), and asked me if I was interested.
Figure One: This was me. I NOPE'd all the way to Trader Joe's, bought some wine and some organic kale for a baking project I intend to complete with the kids tomorrow on my day off, and went home. Tonight I work at The Ritzier, where I suspect I will be MUCH more content than I was before today's interview showed me what else was out there.
*   I have no problem with tattoos. I have tattoos. However, generic, ill thought-out tattoos in places that cannot be covered? NOPE.**   I have no problem with GEDs. I have a GED. It was the most expedient way to skip high school and get started on my college education, which was what I had to do to avoid being homeless given that dorms are the only safe place a minor can live without either being emancipated or having a family/sugardaddy. When The Narcissist went buckass crazy and threw me out of the house at fifteen I decided I didn't want a sugardaddy, so I went to college. By the time I was seventeen The Narcissist decided I wasn't suffering adequately from being thrown out and ordered me to drop out and come home so that she could torture me, so I briefly acquired a lawyer sugardaddy in order to get legally emancipated. AH, MEMORIES! Anyway, having taken the GED I can honestly say that if it takes you more than one try to pass the thing and you weren't super-sick at the time or something, you should go ahead and have yourself sterilized. GED = SUPER EASY.

body:
*   I found a new blog to read that I am really enjoying.
*   I tried a bite of rare steak at work and didn't hate it, but then all I'd eaten was a Larabar each for breakfast and lunch, so I'm not sure it counts. Am a little disgusted with myself, honestly.
*   The Ritzier has been slow lately. I'm thinking of getting a part-time job, because Hotter really wants to take a trip to the Arctic Tundra to visit his family and the MFA Minivan is terminally ill and I think one of my front teeth is about to need some serious dental work. 
*   Coincidentally, today I was offered a job at a strip club. Not taking my clothes off, just waiting tables (in a corset, booty shorts, and leggings). I'm considering it because a) it's crazy money b) I'm flattered, and c) it would be an interesting life experience to have that, if I want to give it a try, has a definite expiration date of sorts (I'm not getting any younger).
*   Last time I went to Trader Joe's I bought a jar of cornichons, because they are adorable and I'd always wanted to try them. Then I tasted them, and...WHAT FUCKERY IS THIS? Something tastes like...fennel? Anise? TARRAGON. I'm not sure how I feel about that.
*   Big Child's summer program for the gifted had a competition that parents were invited to attend, and I went. Big Child and his partner bombed in the first round but did well in the second. They didn't win or even place, but they weren't in last place or even next-to-last, and Big Child handled it with grace and good sportsmanship. I told him I was prouder of that than if he'd been a gracious winner, because it takes a lot more class, and that I couldn't be happier with him as my Number One Son. I'm pleased to report that thirteen is not too old to hug your mother around these parts.
*   Hotter has taken to doing this thing lately where he kind of swings his dick around in a "here is how it is going to be" way and it's not cute. It shuts me right down, because I refuse to fight, especially in front of children, but I'm not sure he realizes the big-picture price of that kind of victory in the context of a marriage.
*   I'm still pretty fucking depressed. A longtime friend of mine recently started working at The Ritzier, but we have opposite schedules. Tonight was the first time we've worked together there and she kept kind of poking at me. "Why aren't you more excited to see me? I feel like you should have all of these things to tell me, and you're just...quiet. WHAT IS GOING ON?" I was like "well, Hotter has been sick, and my ex has been a douche,** and I'm a little worried about my mental health because I can't seem to cheer the fuck up lately." Said friend is self-centered enough that she was like "oh" and proceeded to discuss her boy-problems. Which was fine. Or maybe it wasn't? I don't even know anymore.
*   How are all of YOU?
 
**   The XY has hit a new low in co-parenting, and I'd be outraged except it wouldn't change anything and I kind of forget how to make the face for that emotion anyway. I haven't written about it on here because I try not to trash my ex online and there is nothing amusing about how badly he sucks as a father of late. It's actually just really sad.

body:
Gentle readers, I will not lie, we have been having a tough time here lately at Casa MFA due in part to the current pox on our household but largely to things I can't share with you here.  Some of you who follow me on Twitter are already aware that...let's just say that there are serious factors external to my blended nuclear family under this-here roof that are having a terribly negative affect on my children's physical and emotional wellbeing, and that are quite emotionally taxing (but OH so necessary) for yours truly to talk through with them, and that is all we'll say about THAT.   So I have a kid who doesn't eat.  He has a developmental delay and the accompanying array of sensory aversions, so the wrong flavor, texture, or level of overall messiness (things eaten with the hands that have sauce are out, as are things thinner than oatmeal that require a spoon because if they drip on his shirt GODIVA HELP US ALL) will not only turn him off at the table, but if you push the issue he'll gag and even vomit.  It's frustrating as HECK.  It's also not his fault.  Said kid doesn't eat well when he's sick, which he is, or when he's sad or scared, which...yeah.  Some things, like cheese, are not okay at all UNLESS on pizza, and other things, like eggs (good, cheap protein...mmm...) are just never okay, except when thoroughly disguised in baked goods, waffles, and French Toast, which I often make Big and Middle Children for breakfast, and lately that's been out too.   Middle Child is way too skinny; my ex-husband remarks on this to me constantly in a "this will help me prove you suck as a mother in court" sort of way, and likes to claim that Middle Child wouldn't be so skinny if HE had custody because the boy ALWAYS eats for him, but he has literally never fed the MFA Children anything besides restaurant pizza and Happy Meals when he's had them for visitation (according to the children anyway, and that's not them trying to get one over on me--Big Child actually laments the monotony of the menu).  If that's all I ever served then Middle Child would probably eat without overmuch persuasion or creativity from me, too.  Because I'm a sadist masochist bit more concerned with following the food pyramid and building healthy eating habits than the XY, though, I insist on things like WHOLE GRAINS and VEGETABLES and SUFFICIENT PROTEIN that does not contain KNOWN ALLERGENS.  I know, right?  I'm such a mean mom.     I promise y'all I'm not one of those "we eat this because it's healthy even though it tastes like cardboard dipped in Omega-3 oil and dusted with wheatgerm on a bed of wilted spinach" types (not that there's anything wrong with that; I'm not here to judge or condemn).  I just do things like use half Splenda and half sugar in baking, half whole wheat and half regular unbleached flour in pizza crusts, lean meats cooked in EVOO and drained before adding to sauces, etc. and not to brag but most people, my ex-husband included, think my cooking is delicious.  Also, it's a good thing I like to cook, because I usually end up making three separate menus per meal.  The regular, delicious one that Big Child, Hotter and I eat, with spices, and sauces and flavor combinations.  The "hypo-allergenic" version for Little Child with no dairy or soy products, strong acids that will aggravate his reflux, excessive fat or fiber to slow his GI motility even further, or artificial colors, cut into very tiny and easy-to-chew pieces on a tiny, tiny plate and mind you, Little Child takes PERHAPS five or six TEENSY bites per meal (usually less and often none at all) and is dependent on his g-tube and elemental formula for nutrition but I feel the social benefits of his having a meal with the family and the oral-motor practice he gets make the extra effort worthwhile.  And finally, the Middle Child menu, with extra-light spices, nothing slimy, mustard on all meats, foods NEVER touching each other on the plate, and condiments served in medicine cups so that they don't make premature contact with the food itself and render it inedible.   This morning we had a snow day, so I agreed to make French Toast at Big Child's request (Big Child loves EVERYTHING I cook; that kid just likes to eat, period, and is the most gratifying person on earth to cook for because each meal is "THE BEST I'VE EVER HAD, WOW MOMMY YOU SHOULD OPEN A RESTAURANT" but he does have favorites and my French Toast is one of them) (bless!  Every cook should have a Big Child around to make them feel good about themselves), and Middle Child started sobbing immediately about how he HATED French Toast, he wouldn't like it, he wouldn't eat it, he wouldn't get to play games because he'd be WASTING HIS TIME sitting at the table, he'd starve to death and die FOREVER, etc. (he will do this the entire time I cook on bad days even if it's something he likes; he's kind of like the little brother from A Christmas Story at the table, but, you know, TURNED TO ELEVEN as the kids say).   Sometimes a change in texture makes all the difference in the world, and I was trying to think of a way to create sog-free French Toast.  The result?  Hotter was impressed.  Big Child was in hog-heaven.  And even Middle Child proclaimed it to be "AWESOME" (eventually...).MFA Mama's Very Fattening, Texturally Inoffensive French Toast(serves two adults, one child of average constitution, and one underweight five-year-old)You will need: Implements of DestructionTwo mixing bowlsA large cast-iron frying panAn electric mixerA rubber scraper (you might call these "spatulas"--I am referring to those white thingies you use to frost cakes, which I call spatulas--but Hotter has informed me that that is a good way to flaunt one's culinary ignorance and spatulas are what you use to TURN things, not scrape or frost them)A spatula (the turning kind, a.k.a. "a REAL spatula!")IngredientsSix slices of bread (we use whole wheat)Two large eggs
Three ounces of heavy whipping creamTwo tablespoons plus one teaspoon of sugarThe seedy goodness from a one-inch section of vanilla bean (I heartily recommend these)CinnamonA pinch of salt (I used this stuff, the fine version, because I happened to have some)ButterOptional (for you; mandatory for me)Ativan The Patience of Job1.  Toast the bread on "medium" and put the frying pan on the stove over medium heat.2.  Separate the eggs, reserving the yolks, and use an electric mixer to beat into stiff peaks, adding one tablespoon of sugar slooooowly as you beat (tip from the resident chef: adding sugar to egg whites as you beat them helps them fluff up faster and with less effort, which is particularly nice if the bowl you're using wasn't TOTALLY dry or you're beating them by hand).3.  In the other bowl, whip the heavy cream, then add one egg yolk, cinnamon to taste, the pinch of salt, vanilla bean guts, and a tablespoon of sugar; beat until all of the vanilla bean goo has broken up into flecks.4.  Pour the creamy vanilla mixture over the egg whites and whip them all together until they're thoroughly blended and the consistency of pancake batter.5.  Using the scraper, spread this on both sides of five of the six pieces of bread so that they appear smooth, and set those in the bowl from the creamy vanilla mixture.  6.  Add the second egg yolk and the remaining teaspoon of sugar to the coating mixture left and coat the sixth piece of toast with that, leaving it to sit and absorb as much as it will take in (this is for the underweight five-year-old).7.  Whirl a big hunk of butter around on the surface of the hot frying pan and fry the first five pieces until golden-brown and delicious (I usually add another sliver of butter to the pan when I lift each piece with the spatula before dropping it back down--this is not because the French Toast will stick, at least not if you've properly seasoned your pan, but because it ensures uniform golden-brown deliciousness).8.  Put another big hunk of butter in the center of the pan and drop the sixth (extra-yolky) piece in the middle.  While the first side is browning, use your scraper to pile coating mixture on top until it threatens to overflow, then stop.  Slide the spatula underneath it, toss another big hunk of butter onto the pan, and flip.9.   Serve dusted with confectioner's sugar and choice of topping to the other adult, the child of average constitution, and yourself.  Cut the underweight five-year-old's into bite-sized pieces, don't you DARE put anything on them, and present them on an otherwise-empty plate.  Assure the underweight five-year-old that this is edible.  Offer confectioner's sugar, maple syrup, honey, jam, whipped cream, or a nice crisp twenty if he'll just take a bite.  Threaten to ban him from video games.  Wipe his face.  Tell him lovingly that this is not, in fact, "torture" according to the Geneva Convention.  Studiously avoid eye-contact with your husband, lest one of you bust out laughing.  Confiscate the underweight five-year-old's fork and remind him that we don't hurt ourselves or others, especially at the table, and give him until the count of three to put a piece of French Toast in his mouth or he can go and calm down in his room.  Return the fork and deny having put eggs in any part of the food before him, because you KNOW he hates eggs, then remind him that you dislike the h-word.  Count to two-and-a-half, surreptitiously reach for a bowl just in case as the first bite goes in, then say "See?  I told you it was good" and eat your cold French Toast.FTC Disclaimer: I received samples of some of the finer spices in this recipe (namely the sea salt and vanilla beans) from Justin at Marx Foods, who is awesome.  I did not receive financial compensation for this review, nor did anyone except me have any influence over the opinions I expressed or editorial content.

body: I woke up today feeling...blah.     I'm not sure exactly what my problem is, although apparently it has something to do with my blood pressure bottoming out (I know this because with the addition of Hotter to our household came a home blood pressure monitor, and hey, lookie, why not stick my arm in there since I can, am I right?).      Sometimes this just seems to happen to me, and where before I would have had something salty to eat and a LOT of caffeine and just done my best to power through?      Today I had a glorious hot breakfast of frittata made by my husband the chef, then took care of some work stuff, took a long hot bath, and now I'm back in bed with the laptop while Hotter starts dinner, cleans the kitchen, and keeps tabs on the boys.   I am so very appreciative, and also?  I could totally get used to this.

body: My friend Aurelia Cotta and I were chatting earlier about kids and medical things.  She just noticed a symptom in one of her children that is rather worrisome; it could mean the child needs a minor medical intervention or...well, there's just no telling, because it's Friday night.   See, that's the problem with healthcare, not just here in the US but even in Canada: this stuff always goes down outside of office hours.   "Doctors should work 24/7," Aurelia said, "lazy bastards!"   "I want one to keep in the walk-in closet off my older boys' bedroom," I told her, "It writes the antibiotic prescription or it gets the hose!  And then I'd eat a Lean Cuisine."
title: some things about healthcare really are universal

body:
First off I would like to thank May profusely for writing this post (before we even get into the award bit), because I too have been sitting on an award and now I feel like less of a jerk about it.  You guys, look what Shannon gave me:    When someone gives you a Lemonade Stand you have to pass it on to ten bloggers who demonstrate "attitude with gratitude," and since I admire the heck out of Shannon, it made me squeal like a little girl that she a) has read my blog and b) felt I managed to sweeten my attitude with enough gratitude to buy for fifty cents a cup.   Or something.   Shannon, I'm sorry I sat on this for so long, but it came at a tough time when I didn't have a lot of gratitude on-hand.  So even though I was rude and didn't acknowledge it, I saw it the day you posted it and it gave me a much-needed boost.  Thank you.   Moving on, while I'm already all verklempt, if you keep reading that post of May's you'll see that she went and gave me THIS:     Y'all.  Beautiful?  Me?  May, you sweetheart, I'm blushing!  And, well, er...stammering a bit.  Thank you for this!  When you get a Beautiful Blogger award you're apparently supposed to:* Thank the person who nominated you for this award.
* Copy the award and place it in your blog.
* Link the person who nominated you for this award.
* Tell us seven interesting things about you.
* Nominate seven bloggers.
* Post the links to the seven bloggers you nominate.   So what I've decided to do is combine these two and do eight and a half interesting things, and give both awards to eight and a half bloggers who are beautiful and write with attitude and gratitude.     There's a joke in here somewhere about being bi, I just know it.   Here goes!  Eight and a Half Interesting Thingsby MFA Mama, aged thirty-one1.  I was born at home, in my parents' brass bed.  2.  At the house where I grew up, which was built around 1901-ish, the custom-made stained-glass transom over the front door still bears my maiden name in its entirety along with the date and time of my birth.3.  I can always find a four-leafer in a patch of clover, pretty much effortlessly.  I've stopped even picking and saving them.  My great-grandmother, who my mother named me after, could do the same thing.4.  Despite 3, I have the most spectacularly awful luck.  I think it's genetic.  To wit:5.  My other great-grandmother on the same side died in a BDSM accident, at a ripe old age exceeding AARP eligibility.  Yes, really.  Clotting disorders don't mix well with ankle restraints, and rubber-ball gags mask the symptoms of the resultant pulmonary embolism.  Play safe, y'all.6.  My great-grandfather, the other party involved in the incident, kept and bred canaries all his life, up until the day my great-grandmother died, when he released them all.7.  The sparrows in the neighborhood where my great-grandparents used to live still have patches of gold from the freed canaries' integration into the wild flocks.  8.  I don't speak to a single living relative of mine except for my father, who lives halfway around the world from me, and he's in and out of reality due to dementia.8.5  In what I now refer to as the "Great Love Quadrangle of 1997" I once bathed in hot chocolate with my roommate/girlfriend's b--scriiiitch oh look, that's the whole half!   Here are my eight and a half picks (I'm not even checking to see if they've already received the Lemonade Stand or Beautiful Blogger award, so if you're on this list and you already have one or both, just nod and smile, okay?) in random order:1.  The Checkout Girl: Sure, she's sassy and saucy and full of attitude, but her writing reflects an appreciation for the "quartz in slugs," as Neruda put it, the poetry of the mundane and gratitude for the five senses that makes her blog truly beautiful.2.  Dr. Isis: The Domestic and Laboratory Goddess serves up general hotness and snarky hilarity while making it plain to any perceptive reader just how grateful she is for her level of educational and professional privilege.  It's inspiring to see someone love their work so much, and well of course she's beautiful.  Duh.  Dr. Isis also coined Hotter's and my most favorite threat: I will cut you. Cut you in your face. You will not be pretty anymore.
 3.  Dr. Danielle of 6YearMed: I went to college with a guy who was pre-med, but in all of my undergraduate writing classes because dude could write.  He was also insanely good-looking and so nice and generally kind and cheerful that you couldn't even hate him properly; I've never met Danielle but I have a feeling she's a lot like my old friend from college.  She's a fine young physician who shares her observations about the medicine she practices with an amazing blend of naked, unflinching honesty and compassion, and I would probably never, ever lock her in my older boys' walk-in closet if I was lucky enough to meet her someday.4.  Kathryn, of Ryn Tale's Book of Days: I found Kathryn's blog through Dr. Danielle, and reading about the way she and Dave parent their amazing daughter Ellie with attitude, gratitude, and beauty is a privilege.  I occasionally drop her a g-tube-related comment, but mostly I just nod and blink a lot and leave silently, because I have nothing to add to what she says.  Good stuff, y'all.5.  terri c. of PS 121 Is My Friend:  Faithful reader, constant commenter, keen wit and gentle soul.  Her ability to appreciate the beauty in one of the most interesting but potentially depressing jobs I know of is, in and of itself, amazing, but the lady can also write like whoa.  I've talked about her here before; while she deserves a medal on a daily basis, my little blog-awards are what I have so I am passing them along to her.6.  Tiffany of Three Ring Circus:  She's a huge Aussie blogger and will probably never read this, but I'm giving her the awards anyway because...well...I stumbled across her blog while I was researching rare medical conditions in the process of trying to get to the bottom of The Question Mark that hovers over the sweet, curly head of my youngest and she stole my bloggy heart.  Tiffany is an amazing woman, mother, writer and photographer who has seven individually amazing children, one of whom, little Ivy, captured the innernet's hearts (and signatures!) in her quest to obtain much-needed IVIG treatment.  Tiffany knows the weight of The Question Mark, and occasionally rails against it, but mostly she finds (and photographs!) beauty in life anyway, and shares it in her wonderful blog.7.  Gwendomama:  My friend Gwendolyn is a force to be reckoned with--OH YES YOU ARE YOUNG LADY, YOU SHUT YOUR WHORE MOUTH WHEN I'M WAXING MAUDLIN ABOUT YOU!!!  Gwendolyn has been through so very much, and yet she continues to be one of the most involved and walks-her-talk-y parents I've ever had the privilege of knowing.  She and I met because she spoke about her sweet (late) son Elijah, whose medical quirks and oddities are so very similar to some of my Little Child's, on her blog and I hijacked her comments section then took it to e-mail.  She very generously shared medical information that may have saved Little Child's life, and now she's sharing information about the messy inner workings of an abusive relationship's unraveling via her blog with stunning bravery and heartrending honesty, and y'all, if more educated women had the ovaries to talk about this stuff it probably wouldn't happen to so danged many of us.  8.  Katie, of the intermittently-defunct Maybe Expectant: Oh, Katie.  Sweet, smart, loving writer of some of the best posts you'll never read because she just tweets now and again and fellow MFA mama.  I've read her since the beginning and she's made me smile with tales that aren't mine to tell here during some very dark times.  Posts like this are why I am giving her these awards, and I'm also hoping they'll guilt her into writing more.  There is lots left to say, lady.8.5 is for k, fourth-world blogger without a URL to share, occasional figment on Twitter, and true, good friend for the past five years.  She sent me care packages when Little Child was at his sickest bearing stamps of a foreign land, a postcard with cows and windmills that is on my refrigerator four, five, I forget how many moves later, and much love, late-night intellectual discourse, and steadfast encouragement from the other side of the Atlantic Ocean.  We've never met face to face but she's added so much to my life with her ephemeral friendship that she deserves a shout-out.  Smooch!
title: the one with the awards where I had something in my eye as I was writing it

body: So remember when I said I was going to do a review of a certain product that Eden Fantasys was kind enough to send me for free?*  Well, I wanted to wait until Hotter and I could both weigh in under the bonds of holy matrimony.  Because not that there's anything wrong with using a sex toy alone, but he's a total techno-geek and lover of gadgets in general and so a sex toy that hooks up to an iPod was right up his alley (no, that was not any kind of euphemism or anything, GAWD).   Remember how 2009 tried to redeem itself by bringing me the package from Eden Fantasys and a box of Godiva chocolates?  Not that it worked, because 2009 was seriously SO BAD that I kind of want to send it a sex tape of me and 2010 loving it up.  And then 2009 was all "here, have some female troubles?"  So I didn't even take the "machine," as Cecily called it (yes I am still giggling over that), out of the box until Hotter moved in.  We both admired the elegant packaging and then opened it up to find not only the "machine" itself but also adapters to allow you to charge the Freestyle pretty much anywhere in the world that has electricity, which is pretty neat (although I don't know that I would have the ovaries to try and fly anywhere with this thing, because I don't like to think about TSA agents touching my PANTIES even).   Y'all know I'm a recovering prude, and also that I have kids in the house, so first and foremost the Freestyle's case is EXCELLENT; it's lined with foam shaped exactly to the "machine" and the latch is pretty difficult to open but that is ABSOLUTELY a plus in my book (although if you're playing with this and also with, um...personal lubricants you'll want to open the case BEFORE you have those on your hands or else some totally unsexy hilarity would ensue).  While the "machine" was charging I had a brilliant idea--Hotter bought me an iPod dock/boombox (I have the model you'll see over at the bottom right in "stuff I use and like" but mine is pink, and the shade of pink happens to coordinate perfectly with the Freestyle) with an "audio out" jack, and the Freestyle's wireless transmitter that you plug into your iPod has a headphone jack.  Since we are a household of geeks it was pretty easy to find a cable to hook these things up so that we could both listen to the music when Freestyle is in music mode.  It was like a gadget ORGY, y'all, which in and of itself is enough to get Hotter and me pretty excited.  Someone may or may not have commented that the boombox and my little silver Nano were "spit roasting" the transmitter, and if you're not familiar with that term and also aren't easily offended then here is an explanation of what THAT is and no, not ever but HEE!   After we played around with the Freestyle's modes and such fully clothed and got all the giggling over with, we had a romantic dinner and a talk.  Hotter asked me what I was going to do with the "machine" since I have him now and was not comfortable with the idea of, um, putting the machine to its intended use in front of anyone.  I said well, we'll see, and we set the gadgets up, left the dishes in the sink and went to bed.**   After that it went kind of like:Hotter: So do you want to...MFA Mama: Eh, why not...Hotter: Here--MFA Mama: No way!  You um, hold the......MFA Mama: Okay gimme that thing...Both: WOW.Hotter: I'm going to go take a shower.  Want me to wash the--MFA Mama: Leave it here!Hotter: I see how it is....Hotter: Hey, I--wait, did you...?MFA Mama: Did you forget anything?  Still need to wash behind your ears maybe?Hotter: I'm totally going to hide that thing.  Why're you putting it on MY side of the bed?MFA Mama: [grinning] BECAUSE THAT IS WHERE THE SPOUSE SLEEPS!  Don't worry, my couch is very comfortable.Hotter: [laughs for a while before he catches his breath] Lord.  So what are you naming him?MFA Mama: Her.  I think I'll name her after the hot UPS lady.Hotter: Her?  Seriously?MFA Mama: Well yeah.  It's pink, duh.  Definitely a girl.  Also if I die before you I want to be buried with it.  The transmitter has a 25-ft range so it should go through six feet of dirt no problem.  Just charge it up before you put it in the...casket.Hotter: [cracks up laughing again] Ohhhh my.  I could get used to you doing product reviews!   So Hotter and I give the OhMiBod Freestyle, which is exclusively available through Eden Fantasys, a combined total of four thumbs up, and are very grateful that I had this opportunity to review the thing.  IF YOU WANT A FREESTYLE OF YOUR OWN, EDENFANTASYS IS HAVING A 30% OFF SALE TODAY ONLY!*   Oh hai FTC if you're reading.  Yes, they sent it to me free of charge so that I could review it here on my little blog.  It was the best $125.99 I never spent.**   If my ex-husband's lawyers are reading this, the children were with HIM at the time, so there was zero potential from them hearing the product-testing or seeing the "machine" out near the bed or anything; when not in use it's in its case on the very top shelf of a closet behind some cleaning products where the children couldn't see it unless the oldest got up on a chair or something, and my kids know that only grown-ups use the cleaning products so I think we're good.

body: Yesterday Hotter and I went out and chose Thank You cards to write our notes to The Wrath and The Grand-Wrath.  You may remember the exceedingly sweet note The Wrath wrote from her black little heart (and her repeated assaults on the spelling of my name) and I composed the perfect reply.  In it I addressed her as "Mom," told her touched Hotter and I were by her lovely note, and how wonderful it was to have her as a part of my family and that I couldn't wait to introduce my boys to her.  Then I assured her that I would take good care of Hotter, and that I had already located and made contact with the leading specialist in our area on Hotter's Very Rare Medical Oddities, so nothing to worry about there.  I signed it "All our love, MFA Mama and Hotter."   Then I addressed it to "Le Wraithe, XXX State Highway, Arctic Tundra, Northern State XXXXX"   It's on now!  Muahahahaha!!!

body:
I am thrilled to share with y'all that on January 11th, 2010 Hotter and I became man and wife in a small, unconventional, and utterly perfect ceremony at our home that also recognized us and the boys as a new family unit (Big Child was the Best Man and Middle Child and Little Child bore a ring apiece, making up in enthusiasm anything they might have lacked by way of aplomb).  While I have richly enjoyed toying with those of you who know me in real life and on Twitter by making assertions to the effect that I fully intended to marry the new Mr. MFA in my Apple Bottoms and a "This is What a Feminist Looks Like" t-shirt, I actually wore something a little nicer but no less apropos: a form-fitting little black dress with a brightly-colored sarong tied around my hips, my hair hanging loose to my waist, and no shoes (Hotter and I used to joke that we'd elope to the Bahamas; he wore khakis and a polo shirt that matched a shade of teal in my sarong perfectly and a pair of docksiders).   Hotter and I are both rule-breakers by nature, in case you hadn't gathered as much already based on our wedding attire, and so it shouldn't surprise anyone to hear that while he is a chef, I made the meal we enjoyed with our guests, and while I am a writer, he wrote his own vows (in which he promised to never intentionally hurt my feelings, support me in all of my choices, and love and respect me until he died) and I did not.  Instead I quoted from "God Speaks*" by Rainer Maria Rilke.  Which might not seem to make a lot of sense if you just look at the title, especially when you factor in that Hotter and I are both lifelong atheists, but if you look at the words I quoted it was, in my humble opinion, actually perfect given the lives that he and I have led prior to yesterday:Let everything happen to you: beauty and terror.
						Just keep going. No feeling is final.
						Don't let yourself lose me.
						Nearby is the country they call life.
						You will know it by its seriousness.
						Give me your hand.   Then I literally took his hand and slid a ring that matched mine onto his finger (smooth, right?) and we both cried like babies (I mean um, I put my waterproof mascara to the test and he had something in his eye...) and the Amish pastor's wife in attendance (yes really, and no, the Amish pastor did not officiate because we wanted a civil ceremony) took digital photos (seriously: I couldn't make that up) and we cut the coconut cake and called his mom and my dad and slow-danced to some Weezer as performed by my children on Rock Band.   I am SO happy, y'all.  *   I used the title of the translation I quoted; alternate titles of alternate translations vary from "Before He Made Each One" to "God Speaks to Each of Us" and your mileage may vary depending on your source and how many languages you read.
title: just married

body: The beginning of a new semester plus the happy (but hard!) work of integrating Hotter's and my households is taking its toll on my blogging mojo.  I've been on break for most of the life of this little blog, but during the academic year y'all will hear less from me than during the winter and summer breaks, and right now honestly I'm so danged happy spending every moment I can loving up on my husband that I'm okay with letting the blog idle a bit.   We've been hanging out with the boys (who continue to love Hotter as much as I do*) in between cleaning and putting away, loving and hotly debating kitchen logistics.  We're pretty hilarious about the kitchen, actually; while he's an actual bona fide chef I am quite the cook myself and we're both a little OCD about the things we care about; if we loved each other any less it could get ugly fast.  I was fine with not having a microwave but he was not so we have acquired one, but my OCD will not allow for it to be to the left of the sink whereas having it to the right of the sink eliminates a lot of potential prep-space; I was happy with organizing spices by culinary genre (curry, turmeric, cumin, etc. grouped together with cinnamon and cloves on the side of the "Indian" area next to baking section where the nutmeg, vanilla extract, vanilla sugar, etc. reside and the cumin on the side where the chili powder and various dried and ground red peppers are), but he likes the vinegars and oils separate from the ground spices and all of the salts together, even if the basil-infused olive oil rightly freaking belongs with the oregano, basil, and bay leaves and the sesame oil should, by all that is good and holy, go next to the soy sauce.  Ahem.  We won't even go into how habanero salt oedipal BELONGS with the Mexican spices instead of with the kosher and sea salts or I'll have to go and lie down.     So yeah, I'm busy and I don't have much to complain about (besides the fact that that ear infection from The Sickness came back and I'm on an extended course of antibiotics, but I went to the doctor ALONE, y'all, so...yeah).  Stay tuned for recipes (with pictures!) (after we finish feng-shuiing the living bejesus out of that kitchen we'll be reviewing some awesome spices) and an associated giveaway...soonish.*   It's actually kind of sad how starved my boys are for emotional engagement with a kind and gentle adult male--I was expecting, and it would be healthier, actually, for them to display at least a teeny bit of resentment over Hotter taking up part of my affection and free time, or have some issues with him gently interceding in video game squabbles because he's not their dad, but there hasn't been one nanosecond of negativity.  Hotter even commented to me privately that it made him a little sad how quickly they imprinted on him like ducklings and how worried Little Child in particular gets if he thinks we're going somewhere without Hotter or can't find him when he wants to tell him something, because of what that says about their relationship with the XY.  The psychologist I talk to about the boys' mental health was also disheartened on their behalf to hear about that.  But there are certainly worse problems to have than your children falling head over heels for their stepfather and being thrilled with the new family dynamic, and so we will focus on the positive there, which is huge.
title: it's not you, it's me

body: They (whoever they are) always do say one ought to observe, before marrying a man, how he treats his mother.  Hotter and his mom (we'll call her The Wrath, which is a joke in her household, as in "look out, The Wrath of [real name] is on a baking rampage!") have a very close, very sweet relationship.  She's also kind of a wisearse, but I figure that just means Hotter will be able to tolerate yours truly...   A bit of background: my real first name is a good, timeless Old Testament name (no I am not religious but I have studied both the Old and New Testaments at length at the college level and respect them as part of the literary canon) that many people corrupt with extra vowels where none should be.  It's like, MFA Mama vs. MFA Mamaa (usually).  Once in a great while someone will misspell it with TWO extra vowels, as in MFA Maamaa, which makes me apoplectic.  Also, I did not take Hotter's last name because I have had my current last name for all of my adult life and my children have that name (and Hotter is fine with that, in fact he asked me shortly before the wedding "so you're keeping Mama, because of the boys, right?"), and everyone in both our families knew that.   So when Hotter and I went out and got the mail today and I pulled out an envelope addressed to "Mr. & Mrs. Hotter [X]. [lastname]" I laughed out loud as I handed it over to Hotter, who got a good giggle out of it, too.  He opened it up to find a very generous check and a congratulatory card with a note inside.  I reached over to take the note, since Hotter didn't have his reading glasses on, and he said he'd have to decipher it for me later because no one but family can read The Wrath's handwriting.  I told him my dad had had a stroke and I could read anyone's handwriting, so he handed it over all "here knock yourself out."  I found it to be perfectly legible...   The note said:Dear Hotter and MFA Mamaa,   I am so very happy for you both!  MFA Maamaa, I'm especially thankful that Hotter met you; now I no longer have to worry about him.  He's in good hands.  And Hotter, you make sure you take care of MFA Maama.  I know marriage can either be beautiful or awful - so much depends on the give and take of each other and above all honesty.  I'm positive you will have a wonderful lifetime together.   Always remember - I'm here for you both.  Congratulations!  Now I have three more grandchildren!!!                                                                       Love to you always, The Wrath   Hotter and I both had something in our eyes there for a moment, and I finally said "The Wrath is awesome...I'm just going to have to sit her down and talk to her about my first name."  Hotter smirked at me and said "yeah she asked me how you spelled it when I wrote the address down for her and I told her how you are about that...You still took her baby away."   Touché.  And also?  Not that the XY's mother gave The Wrath much by way of competition?   Best.  Mother-in-law.  EVAR!!!
title: the real reason I married him

body: Today, Hotter and I lost three hours of our first child-free weekend as a couple to the local DMV registering our minivan.   It wasn't entirely a waste of time, though, as we are both avid people-watchers and saw an incredibly rotund and gravelly-voiced man who was standing right outside the door having a loud conversation into his bluetooth headset blow an impressively voluminous snot-rocket onto the ground right as we were passing him by, without even asking his caller to hold or anything.  Dude just went for it.  No shame whatsoever.  I mean, I won't even blow my nose loudly into a tissue if someone outside my immediate family is in such close proximity, never mind if I'm mid-conversation on the phone.  It was...astounding.   So now we keep singing "Snot-rocket man" to each other and cracking up laughing.   That is all.   Stay tuned for the link-list of delurkers (I haven't forgotten about that) and a recipe/product review involving fancy spices.  Hotter is getting his chef on with something chicken-y involving cocoa powder, cinnamon, one or more of these, and cilantro.  It should be awesome.
title: snot-rocket man

body: *   Twas the night before Christmas Eve, and all through the house children were sobbing.*   Middle Child said "_____ sucks" (naming the reason they were all crying).*   The other two stopped crying and looked to me, scandalized (we do not use language of even the mildest sort here, including "sucks," and I think they expected me to faint or something).*   "IT DOES SUCK!" I roared, for shock value, and Middle Child stopped crying too and they all gaped at me for a moment, and then Big Child lost it and started laughing.  "WHAT IS SO %^&# FUNNY?  SOME THINGS SUCK AND SOMETIMES YOU HAVE TO SAY SO!" I thundered, "in fact, THIS is what I think of THAT," I declared, shifting to one side and farting mightily (the spirit moved me, y'all, and I have BOYS--sometimes you have to do these things).  "OH MY GOD, MOMMY, YOU NEVER CURSE OR POOT!" shrieked Big Child, when he could speak.  "TODAY I DO, IT'S FESTIVUS!" I informed my belly-laughing progeny, and then introduced them to the concept of Festivus and the accompanying Airing of Grievances.*   Once they had double- and triple-checked that there would be no consequences, my children very tentatively began to curse (well, Big Child and Little Child did--Middle Child cut straight to the Mother Of All Curse Words with an emphatic "f*ck ____!" and went to bed crying because I didn't tell them it was Festivus and let them start airing their grievances until almost bedtime, stating that "you shoona talt us dat SOONER so I ken say f*ck all d@mn DAY!") (I was amused to note that his speech delay did not affect his use of profanity) (also if there's anything cuter than Little Child saying the worst word he could think of ["STUPID!"] and waiting for lightning to strike I'd be surprised).  *   Then I ad-libbed a Closing Ceremony involving the brushing of the bad words from our teeth and put them to bed in good spirits, despite _____.*   Last night, Santa left everyone electronic joy under the tree, and me a bar of soap for my mouth.  Great hilarity!*   From all of us here at Casa MFA to all of you out there, "Merry f*cking Christmas!"As far as what ______ was, let's just say the opening ceremonies of our new holiday coincided with their father calling them to say goodnight and give them some unwelcome news about how they would be spending Holiday Visitation and leave it at that.  They had begged me to do something about it and I couldn't, and I think we were all feeling a little impotent and in need of some grievance-airing.  If my ex-husband's lawyers are reading this, you will note that it was the first time my children had heard me curse or pass gas, which I think means I'm doing pretty well.  Also, I couldn't say anything worse than "d@mn" while looking at their cute little faces.  Talk to your client about where Middle Child picked up the f-bomb.  May the fleas of a thousand camels infest your backsides in the new year.

body: Separation and divorce bring their own special brand of suck to the holidays.  One year ago the Y chromosome had just sued me for full custody for the FIRST time and was claiming I was unfit; I not only had to pull the holidays pretty much out of my arse since he'd only made one child support payment in three months but was also afraid that at any moment Social Services would come and knock on the door and judge me for having a rotisserie chicken instead of a roasted turkey on Thanksgiving or wrapping the Festivus presents in newspaper, and take my children away (because when you're new to the world of custody disputes you think The Powers That Be will care about that kind of thing).  That first check barely kept the utilities on with the amount that was past-due by that time, and the pressure was still on to give the children, whose world had just been rocked to the core, a happy holiday (oh yeah, and figure out how I was going to support us, and where we were going to live when the foreclosure the Y chromosome was forcing rather than let me speak to the mortgage company and keep the family home was over, and how to get us through this with minimal therapy).   Then there was the guilt, because the thing that Big Child wanted most in the world (and he was taking the split the hardest) was completely beyond what I was going to be able to do for my kids gift-wise.  He wanted what every other kid on Earth wanted last year: a Nintendo DS Lite.  I plotted, I schemed, I vented to friends and entered give-aways, but things were looking grim.   Enter a certain very generous Redneck.  Who PayPal'd me a very generous amount toward the purchase of the DS Lite, because, as she said in her e-mail, "sometimes you might not be able to afford toilet paper but you still need to remind your kids that mom can work magic, and you can always just steal toilet paper from a public restroom."  She's a poet, is Tanis.   I couldn't believe it.  I ordered the thing, it came, Big Child's fondest holiday wish came true (with a little help from Katie W., who sent us a game for the thing that she'd bought, played, and beaten), and overall we had a pretty good time (also thanks to Mel, who sent us a gorgeous wooden train set that I gave the Littles).  The innernet saved our holiday!   This year, things are better.  We're not rich, but between the child and spousal support and what I earn we have enough.  We're renting a nice little house in the kids' school district, and none of our bills are past-due.  There's even a little left over for things we don't have to have, but just want a whole lot.  I'm spoiling my kids ROTTEN this year.  How rotten?  Oh, only so rotten that due to some miscommunication about who was getting what we ended up with an extra Nintendo DS Lite in the house.  I KNOW!  Ridiculous.  Wretched excess.  I was filling out a return slip while chatting online with a friend about holiday plans, when she mentioned that her oldest wanted something very badly, but it wasn't going to happen and she felt bad that her divorce (which is complicated by factors not so very different from those that complicated my own, which up the suck-ante on divorce with children a notch) and the current lack of child support from her ex were putting her in a place where she couldn't do something magical for her little girl (did I mention that her daughter wanted...a DS Lite?).   Well, crap.  I mentioned the inventory surplus to my friend.  She asked me to name a price.  I thought about it for a moment and remembered what the innernet did for us last year.  I named a price that was pretty much what I paid out-of-pocket for Big Child's DS Lite last year.  My friend asked me if I was serious.  Oh yes.  I absolutely was.     She sent me the amount by PayPal.   So I finished filling out the return slip and sent the DS Lite back.  Because it was a very boy color, and I noticed when I was shopping for it that the place I bought it from also had pink ones.  I don't get to buy pink stuff ever, so this was big fun for me.  Since I had to send the thing back as an exchange, SuperGirl's present came to my house.  I took a phone-picture of it and e-mailed it to my friend:    We chuckled gleefully and agreed that we kind of wanted to lick the thing.  I refrained from licking it because I had The Sickness, and instead repackaged it lovingly with freshly-washed hands.  Since I was sick and out of packing tape, I cocooned the box in Medipore (we always have a roll of that stuff around since one of us has a feeding tube that needs a dressing on it at times).  It wasn't pretty, but it needed to go all the way across the country in time for Christmas.  It took...a while.  My friend and I started to worry.  I tracked the package online.  It was almost there.  And then?   I am happy to report that the eagle has landed!  My friend has the goods and now her only holiday gift dilemma is whether to let the fat man take the credit for this one or give it to SuperGirl from MOM.     I vote mom.  Because sometimes?  You need to remind your kids that mom can work magic.
title: the great innernet Nintendo DS Lite love-chain

body: *   The universe has a sense of humor, y'all.  2009 decided to try to redeem itself on the way out by bringing this, this, and the certified copy of my final divorce decree in the mail on the last day of the year.  WHOO TITS!*   Of course, I can't do much more than look forward to what I plan to do with those three things, because when I was all "too late, suckah, to the left with you" anyway, 2009 was all "fine then, remember that Cold From The Hot Place that became sinusitis and an ear infection and finally you caved and took the antibiotics?  Well here's some female trouble for you!"  Plus Hotter has a couple of loose ends to tie up in the Arctic Tundra where he currently lives before he jumps on board the MFA Ship of Fools.*   Whatever, 2009.  I was totally faking it when you thought things were good anyway.*   So about the "machine" I mentioned above (Cecily called it that on g-chat today, which cracked me up).  Some of y'all probably read Cecily's excellent blog but in case you don't or haven't read it recently, Cecily recently started working for Eden Fantasys, which (cough okay, here goes my New Year's resolution I mentioned in the last post in action y'all) is a company that sells sex toys.  She manages blogger relations for them, among other things.*   Yeah, that big resolution?  I decided I'm going to lose my inhibitions when it comes to (sotto voce) the sex.  Hotter has gone a long (ohgod, no pun intended there) (well I mean certainly he...nevermind) way toward loosening me up OKAY YOU SEE THAT RIGHT THERE IS THE PROBLEM.  Sigh.  I'm MFA Mama, and I'm a recovering prude.  *   Which is why when Cecily put it out on Twitter that anyone interested in reviewing a sex toy for Eden Fantasys should e-mail her and I hadn't taken my Ritalin yet and did just that, kind of for the heck of it, I was all "what did I just do???"  Because, well, I mean, my goodness y'all.  I had just re-opened the blog (password-protected at first until I decided that haters will hate whether I hide from them or not) and hadn't even decided what my position on reviews (paid or otherwise) on my blog was, never mind addressed my little...issue...and just like that I had a discreet package from a sex toy retailer on its way for me to review on my blog.*   Fact: undermedicated ADD and courage can sometimes be indistinguishable to the naked eye.*   So anyway, I decided that a) no more Twitter before the Ritalin kicks in, b) I'm going to try an actual sex toy, and c) I'm going to review stuff on here from time to time.*   So sometimes I'll do a review or link to a product just because something is awesome (like the link to Godiva up there?  Yeah I got nothin' for that, I just love them and really love that they have a 50% off sale after Christmas!  But hey, Godiva, if you're reading this and need reviewers?  CALL ME) or, I dunno, I find an interesting new product that I feel like sharing my "road-test" of with y'all (probably because it's hilarious in either its great success or monumental failure), and sometimes because a company offers me something I'd like to try in exchange for an honest review of said product (that would be the "machine").  What I will do is this: see this new category called "reviews?"  I will tag all posts having to do with reviews as such and put a little disclaimer for our friends at the FTC at the top stating whether I did or did not receive any compensation for said review.  That way if you don't want to read a review post, you can skip that one.  What I will not do, ever, is write a dishonest word on here about any product, whether I'm reviewing it for fun, profit, or any mixture of the two (that way if something sucks you've been warned, and if I say something is awesome you know I'm telling the truth).*   Look for the review of the "machine" mid-January-ish :)*   Oh, yeah.  I said several resolutions last time didn't I?  Well there's the one I already mentioned, the one where I get serious about writing (that resolution is practically a tradition at this point so why stop now?  Plus this time I REALLY MEAN IT), and the one where next time I'm sick and it goes on forever?  I will just take the stinkin' antibiotics after, say, a week.  Because I do this every winter without fail, and am always like "gee I should've caved sooner."  The end.
title: in which 2009 is like a bad boyfriend and I decide to do occasional product reviews

*   I look at long-term employment as being similar to marriage: it typically starts off in a burst of optimism, there's a honeymoon period, and then there's the ongoing daily grind of living with it. Right now it's kind of like The Ritz came home smelling like strange perfume with lipstick on its' collar, and I'm sleeping on the couch. I have no plans to break up with it for real, but I'm perusing the Help Wanteds and considering seeing other employers on the side.
*   The XY still seems to be seething with courtlust, despite Little Child's lack of growth challenges and the whole HGH thing becoming a non-issue. This disappoints me on an ongoing basis. I would like to be able to not have an "emergency legal representation" fund to worry about paying into.
*   It feels like a neverending February of suck over here, but really it's March. I forgot that March is usually out to get me, and failed to beware the Ides. THAT WON'T HAPPEN AGAIN.
*   In an effort to clean up our yard, because Trashcan Neighbor will be Trashcan Neighbor, we got a Bagster, and then SOMEone (I actually suspect The XY over Trashcan Neighbor this time, although you never know) reported the Bagster as a zoning violation and the C(o)unty sent a letter to MFA Landlord, who e-mailed me, and I promptly scheduled the Bagster's pickup and it will be a nonissue in two to three business days, but REALLY? I sometimes forget that I must live as a paragon of internal and external housekeeping virtue as a result of my ex-husband, Stalky, and Life In General being out to get me at any possible opportunity, but then life reminds me. While I was at it, I ordered us a 96-gallon recycling bin with a tip-bar since the C(o)unty-provided bin doesn't handle more than a week's recycling, and recycling pickup is only every other week. I'm thinking of painting it hot pink just to see how long it takes for someone to report it as a public nuisance.
*   So that's the phone and electric bills that've gone UP, my income's gone DOWN, and it's fucking snowing AGAIN. I don't see how we'll ever get ahead, and am rather depressed. If by "rather" you mean "severely." How are all of YOU?

I never did get around to an update on the whole Brazilian situation, but after having two done by a professional I started doing my own at home and haven't looked back. My reasoning went something along the lines of "$50 a pop ($40 plus tip, and maybe 25% is high for the tip but if someone has touched my taint I kind of feel like I owe them) vs. $5 for a home-kit = no-brainer." Granted, there IS more pain involved with a home-jobby, not because of the quality of the wax or anything so much as the fact that it's hard not to wuss out and go too slowly, but it's not awful. I got a mark like this one, except down there, from my second pro-job; the waxer said they just happen sometimes, especially with bleeders, regardless of technique, and that was most of my rationale when it came to paying a pro (trying to avoid THAT). I also find that I can actually do a better job getting the stray hairs that are closer to the center of the universe on my own, probably because it's my own junk and I have no problem handling it in ways that might seem inappropriate in a spa setting.
   For those of you playing along at home, would I recommend trying to do your own Brazilian? Yes and no. Yes in that the end-result is just as good if not better than going with a pro, no in that you have to have a pretty high pain tolerance and possibly hyperflexible joints to git 'er done, both of which I possess, so YMMV. If you do decide to give it a whirl, here are some tips:
1. Use this stuff! It's great, it smells nice, and if you keep an eye out for sales and buy in 3-packs you can usually get it for less than $5 per jar:
 2. WEAR GLOVES. The wax will absolutely stick to and get under your fingernails if you don't.
3. Put down newspaper to protect your floor, because you WILL drip wax.
4. Don't forget to use the oil that comes with the kit before you wax. Trust me on this.
5. Use something on your skin afterward to prevent infection (pros also apply hydrocortisone, but I skip that step because yeast loves steroids and...yeah). I use this, because it's what the waxer I went to swears by:
