body: When I started this blog originally, halfway through the decade we're getting ready to kiss goodbye, it was because there was so much in my life that I couldn't express, couldn't have, couldn't even really grasp as a concept, and then I had to shut it down when I needed it most because people knew.   This blogging thing, it's tricky business; an intellectual fan dance at best, a "trainwreck" at worst.   I've spent most of the past decade feeling like I was failing.  The reasons don't matter; we all feel this way about our lives sometimes I think.  In retrospect, though, the failures were there but so were a lot of serious victories.  Yes, I have a birth mother, an ex-husband, and a handful of people on the innernet who know my (gasp!) real name and were present at (and sometimes personally engineering) the lowest moments of the decade and could be reading this.  A decade ago was the last time I felt free to be as outrageous as I wanted to, and then gradually I started adding layers, covering up, because I thought I had so much more to lose.  Family.  The chance to make connections in the writing world that I thought would get me where I wanted to be in life.  A marriage.  Half a dozen friendships with very interesting people that seemed important enough to sacrifice a bit of integrity over.   Well, I lost all of that, and at the time it felt like failure.  And I'm still standing, on the other side of those losses, grateful as hell.   I am ending this decade the same way I started it; single, broke, and really loving the process of finding my voice, making life up as I go along.  So I didn't accomplish a lot of the goals I set in hopes of pleasing others (reconciliation with my birth mother, the marriage to the man who seems perfectly charming and earns a decent living, the wealth, the superficial popularity), or even the one I had set for myself (to publish a novel).     Instead I got distracted by an ill-advised marriage (what happens in Vegas?  Does NOT stay in Vegas, y'all, remember this) that taught me a lot about what I don't really want to do with my life and why settling in matters of the heart is NOT okay, earned a terminal degree that everyone told me was too soon (and they were right but it's allowed me to earn a living while my heart catches up to my brain), had three great kids (none of whom would be here if I had spent the past decade being wholly "sensible" so that's another lesson learned right there), started a blog, made and lost friendships based on misery loving company, dropped off the map in a downward spiral of low self-esteem, illness, poverty, shame and desperation.  It could have broken me; for a while I guess it did but then?  Something wonderful happened, and I am throwing up in my mouth a little bit as I type this but y'all, even if the ONLY good thing to come from the past ten years was getting to a place in my life (however I had to get here) where I was ready for what came along next I would still have to call it a small price to pay.   It would be terribly wrong to call the decade that gave me my children and my livelihood and the love of my life a failure, even if it wasn't very pleasant to live through most of the time and I didn't do the things I had, for various reasons, hoped to do with it.  You've probably all heard the quote about success being the measure of how high you bounce after hitting rock bottom.  So I'm going to stop looking at this past decade as a failure and instead call it the first part of a great success, thank it for the momentum, and then cordially suggest that it not let the door hit it in the arse on its way out.     This is me raising my glass of sparkling white grape juice to you and yours with a rueful and amused "l'chaim" (to life).  Anyone got any resolutions?  I'm only making one this year, and it's a whole separate post that I'm waiting on a certain delivery to write.  Meanwhile what are yours?ETA: Scratch that, I'm making several resolutions including the one with the separate post.  Second resolution post to follow!
title: reflections on an interesting decade

body: If you haven't already delurked in honor of National Delurking Week it's going on all week long!____________________________________________________________________________________________   This New Year's Eve I stayed in with my kids.  The XY texted me around dinner-time to ask if I was letting them stay up until midnight and I replied truthfully that I wasn't sure but we were enjoying a special dinner and planning to toast 2010 with Sprite (this is the first time I've let my kids have soda EVER although apparently it's the beverage of choice at their father's house; I usually do sparkling white grape juice but I had The Sickness and Papa John's will not deliver sparkling white grape juice so Sprite it was) and they'd be up until ten at least.   Which makes his text of 9:45 to say "tell the boys I love them & will call them in the morning I'm going OUT" just sad.  I texted back "Drop postdated support check in mailbox or drive carefully either/or" and given that he did NOT call them in the morning (and has only called them once since then) I don't feel bad.   I did end up letting the boys stay up; I was especially surprised that Little Child hung in there and he was very tired but wanted badly to stay up "until MIDnight!" and have a sip of Sprite so that is what he did.   Big Child asked if we could do the "clicking glasses together thing;" I explained that that was called a toast and he asked what toasts were for and I said to celebrate something or say positive things out loud that you really hope will happen or plan to accomplish.  "So it's kind of like a wish," he asked, and I said yes I supposed it was and proposed that we each give a toast.     Little Child toasted "next year again I'll stay up until MIDnight!"   Middle Child toasted "to Santa and Mommy because I luff my xBox360!"   Big Child said he was still thinking, so I went ahead and toasted "To us, for surviving the divorce in 2009, and to all of our family's plans in 2010."   Out of the blue Big Child asked me if Hotter ever hit me.   "Um...no.  No, Hotter's never hit anyone as far as I know," I said nervously,* very conscious of the younger two's eyes on me.  I usually try to have these conversations with Big Child out of their earshot but I've also been careful never to imply that there's any shame attached.  It's tricky.   Big Child pressed on relentlessly.  "What about yelling?  Has he ever yelled at you?  Does he yell?"   I said Hotter had never yelled at me either, and that I'd never heard him yell.   "Does he say cusses?"   I said not at people, and not around kids.   "Okay.  That's good," Big Child said, seeming satisfied with that.   "Yes...it is...but what does that have to do with making a toast," I asked him.   My oldest grinned a front-toothless, mischievous little grin.  "I had to make sure before I made my toast," he said, and held up his cup.  "To 2010: no divorces this year!"*   If my ex-husband's lawyers are reading this, I have a policy that I try to live by: if you don't want to provide an age-appropriate explanation of your words and actions, don't say and do them in front of children.  I do not bring this up with the children but if they ask me questions I do my best to provide them with answers that are, to paraphrase Larkin, both true and kind, or at the very least not untrue or unkind.  The school guidance counselor and the psychologist who's observed my children in my home at my request both confirmed that this was the best way to handle our situation and I'm not ashamed of myself, nor should the children be ashamed of themselves as a result of your client's choices.  If you want to make any bones about my parenting you'd have to a) prove that this is my blog, which would take some considerable doing if you wanted to do it legally/admissibly and b) argue that mine is a true enough representation of events that your client's words and actions are unmistakeably identifiable.  Go ahead, I dare you.
title: I'll drink to that, or maybe because of that, either/or

body: If you haven't already delurked in honor of National Delurking Week it's going on all week long!*   I woke up this morning (and I use the term loosely in relation to the ungodly hour when this happened) with an OMG EAR INFECTION.  About two hours after I fell asleep.  I got maybe three hours of sleep total last night (nonconsecutive).*   So naturally when Little Child stopped keeping anything down at all even with Zofran I was extra-thrilled.  *   And then he started wheezing, which...MY CHILDREN DO NOT WHEEZE.  The only time any of them ever have was that one time Little Child was in the hospital for a week on oxygen, and we are not going to talk about that because it was a FLUKE.*   In case it wasn't a fluke Little Child is, of course, going to the pediatrician for a chest-listen and a dehydration check.  Also?  The XY will be taking him in because I have to drop the kids off and haul heinie to my OWN doctor's office to get a) more antibiotics for The Sickness, which might need its own category, geez, b) hopefully some Vicodin or something since I can't take NSAIDS, and c) an exorcism.*   Okay so technically I think an exorcism is when you cast out demons, not the son of god, but potato-potahto.  Hotter's going to be thrilled.  Brittany thinks so anyway. *   If Little Child has to go to Club Med things could get interesting, since his GI specialist is an hour and a half away and wants to treat him THERE any time he's having a gastroparesis flare unless he's too unstable to transport.  If he's not up for the trip we have to go to the local teaching hospital, which is a) kind of scary, b) VERY short on creature-comforts for parents who are staying with their ill children (sadly I could write a book on which hospitals have which amenities on their pediatric floors in this town), and c) where the GI team we FIRED for being USELESS practices.*   I'm having kind of a bad day.  I think maybe this is like a hangover from 2009.  Because 2010 wouldn't do me like this.  RIGHT?*   Oh and also?  Hahahahaha I needed a sickness of my own to keep me from cleaning the house and a sickness in Little Child to keep me from even BEING in the house and Jesus in my pants like I need a boil implant right now, because that special event is taking place in FIVE DAYS.  Awesome.

body:
* Now that I'm over the clusterfuck that was the 15th (scroll down, y'all, I can't link from The Precious), I suppose the GOOD news is that if Pfeffer as the older of our two broodrabbits can still have babies, then neither she nor Iden are likely post-menopausal! I'm doubling up on their vitamins then throwing them in with Haas.

* I'm pretty sure Bravo Hive lives! By which I mean there's a crapton of activity around the hive; I have neither seen a queen (no hive incursions since my last update due to weather and work) nor observed any workers bringing in pollen (which would mean that they have brood to feed and hence have had a queen laying recently enough that all is most likely well), but...it's a LOT of bees. So I'm hopeful!

* The MFA Chickens are laying pretty well for a quartet of perihenopausal biddies! We're currently debating how we'll expand the flock to our allotted six; I'd like to add two point-of-lay pullets, or maybe cull the oldest hen and add three new birds. Hotter wants to cull them all and start fresh, but I a) think that'd be wasteful if the older gals are still laying and b) don't want to process four birds unless I have to, because GROSS. So talks are underway, but I'm just so glad we can have chickens at home again!

* I have bought the first seeds for this year's Spring garden.

   So it may be dreary and cold, and I may be SLIGHTLY feverish and on my second "lunch" of my second double-shift day in a row, but I'm starting to hope that Spring (the real deal, not the calendar technicality) is on the way!

Sent from The Precious
title: signs of Spring?

body: I hate when Little Child is sick.  When he's healthy and doing well it's easy to forget there's anything wrong with him; sure he eats through a g-tube and takes three prescription meds per day to keep him doing okay from a GI and hematology standpoint, but usually he's the outward picture of good health.  Plump cheeks, still has creases in his sweet chubby thighs at four, tires easily but plays hard.   When he's sick he's a little bit scary though.  Vital signs don't do what they should.  His lips will turn blue in the tub, the same tub Middle Child is frolicking happily in full of perfectly warm bathwater, and his body temperature does weird things.  His intestines shut down.  He'll go from coughing twice over the course of a slightly whiny but otherwise perfectly normal afternoon to shivering miserably under crib-quilts wrapped around him in Big Child's arms while I run for the thermometer and the extension tube to give him some meds through.   He doesn't need a doctor or anything.  Unless his symptoms get worse to the point that I think he needs antibiotics or the Zofran doesn't work and he gets dehydrated and needs IV fluids it's just watch and wait, but man.   I hate when Little Child is sick.
title: Little Child is sick

body: If you haven't already delurked in honor of National Delurking Week it's going on all week long!   So I had a loud conversation with the XY (who had me on speaker) and the pediatrician seeing Little Child in my doctor's crowded waiting room, and since this wasn't one of the two doctors at Giant Pediatric Practice who are familiar with Little Child and his issues I basically had to go over his entire complicated medical history with them.  The lady sitting next to me was looking at me like "OMG seriously?" and I just smiled and gave her the "what like YOU don't poop?" face and explained to a skeptical pediatrician that Yes, Virginia, erythromycin IS a motilin-agonist!  Then the XY and I got into a heated debate over whether or not Little Child was congested, in which the pediatrician was the tie-breaker ("umm yeah I can see stuff draining down the back of his throat, your ex-wife is correct") and we collectively decided that Little Child can most likely ride this out at home with antibiotics and decongestants and Zofran.  Whoo tits!   Fortunately I finished that up before they called me back and my GP, who is lovely, came and asked me what was going on and said "The Sickness has been going on for HOW long now?" and then looked in my ear and asked me if I'd been putting anything green in there.  I said no and she was all "yeeeeeah that ear is a MESS" and gave me more antibiotics and something to get Jesus out of my pants and offered me Vicodin but sadly since Little Child is iffy I asked her if she could give me something topical instead.  Which she did, and said "next time come in sooner because your eardrum is all bulgy" and then I threw up in my mouth a little bit.   True story.   Little Child has kept his first dose of antibiotics and industrial-strength decongestant down along with some generic Pedialyte with the aid of the Zofran and seems a little more cheerful than he was this morning, and now I have to let everyone stay up late because I can't give him his Prevacid until he's had a chance to absorb the antibiotic.  So I'm drowning my sorrows and a pound of fresh asparagus in lemon juice and butter and hopefully everyone is MUCH BETTER tomorrow and I can GET SOME STUFF DONE.   So let it be written, so let it be done.
title: it appears that everyone will live (except Jesus)

body: Nurse: MFA Medical Group, how may I help you?MFA Mama: I have a high fever, a sore throat, and body aches, and I'm the primary caregiver of a medically fragile four-year-old so I need to be tested for strep and the flu per his specialists so that they know whether to put him on prophylactic antiviral drugs, and I need to take him back from his father today.  What time can Dr. PCP see me?Nurse: Actually it sounds like you might possibly have H1N1 so we'll call in a Z-pack and some Tamiflu for you.MFA Mama: I don't feel THAT awful, and I don't think I need antibiotics, I just want you to test--Nurse: You're probably contagious so we'd prefer you didn't come to the office.MFA Mama: But...you're a doctor's office...?Nurse: If you're not better in five to seven days we'll talk about having you come in.MFA Mama: No, look, I need you to swab me for the flu since my temperature's been over 102 and that's the guideline my son's--Nurse: Then everyone else would catch it.MFA Mama: I'll wear a mask.  I'll wait outside.  If you want to stick the swab out the mail slot I'll put it up my OWN nose, but you--Nurse: Well if you INSIST.  But if you take the antibiotics and the Tamiflu--MFA Mama: Have you ever had MRSA?  Is my chart in front of you?Nurse: ...Dr. Partner can see you at 4:15.  Make sure you ask the front desk for a mask.MFA Mama: Thank you.   The good news is that I do not have strep or the 'flu (swine or otherwise).  The bad news is that I have a ton of grading left over from the weekend when the other adult present said "you just laughed until you cried over a student's essay and invoked Godwin's Law in your feedback e-mail to them.  I'm taking the laptop away, taking your temperature again, and tucking you in for the night."   Aww.   And how was YOUR weekend?

title: point and counterpoint

body: Today was supposed to be Daddy Dinner Day, but the Y chromosome insisted on standing the younger two children up (to their chagrin and mine--mama's pretty sick y'all, and has grading to do) and just taking Big Child to go and sort gifts for needy children with a local charitable organization.    Stop right there.  Before any of you laugh, or scoff, or remark on how very uncharacteristic it would be of my ex-husband* to do something so selfless, I would urge you to take a moment and remember that you don't actually know him that well.     Yes, Virginia, the Y chromosome bulldozed his sick ex-wife into spending the evening taking Big Child's place at the mic in the house Rock Band assembly (with half a voice I might add, although I think it lent a certain je ne sais quoi to my rendition of Creep) in order to placate the two tear-stained younger fruit of their ill-fated union so that he could help the less-fortunate and teach the eight-year-old the value of community service.   Okay, and if you bought that I've also got a bridge you might be interested in purchasing.   This was a corporate event.  The Y chromosome's work-family was in attendance, and why on earth wouldn't he take his sweet, earnest, attractively gap-toothed and eminently likable son with him to show off to these people who have spent the past year giving him furniture "for the children" and covering for him while he dragged me to court repeatedly?  Miss a chance to show them that he, the real primary caregiver of our children (hand-to-my-heart y'all, that's what he claimed in court) is raising them to be good, polite, respectful young pillars of the community despite their mother being...well...*doleful look, pointed trailing-off*  He probably scored his next free used vehicle, made two or three old ladies cry, and went home with some chick's phone number.   Which, you know, bless his little heart.  All's fair in love and war, ce le guerre, etc.   Except that when Big Child got home, Middle Child put the Wii guitar down and wanted to know where Daddy had taken him.     "We went and...distributed...gifts...for kids who don't have a lot...of money!" Big Child said, leaning in and out of a doorway (all of my doorways have marks at hand-height to a tallish eight-year-old).   "We don't have a lot of money," said Middle Child.   Little Child nodded, wide-eyed, drumsticks in-hand.   "That was last year!" I said, hoping they didn't have a clue just how bad it was last year, before the court-ordered child support.  "That was just temporary, but now Daddy shares the money with us again!"   "This year he's still taking you back to court and you have to give the money he gives you for us to your lawyer so we don't have to go and live with him instead of staying with you like we want to," said Big Child.  "How is that any different?"**   Fa-la-la-la-la, la-la-la-la.* Yes, I'm still calling him that even if it's more like "my seemingly ex-and-now-currently-still-husband, who is clinging in a manner most undignified," because that's too long and consonant-riddled to make a cute acronym** It's not, really, except that now that I'm working, too, we can afford food, utilities, AND legal fees!  If my ex-husband's lawyers are reading this, don't feel too bad, okay?  Happy oedipal holidays, from my family to yours!

body: *   That totally wasn't me in the grocery store yesterday, if you happened to see a haggard woman pushing a cart and grimly ignoring a tattling eight-year-old, a five-year-old making laps around the cart while spelling curse-words wrong out loud, and a four-year-old shrieking for a gingerbread man.  That was someone else, because my children are cheerful and obedient at all times.  And if one of my little angels was going to spell a word, they'd spell it right, even if it was one of the seven words forbidden on network television.*   Even if that had been me, I wouldn't have gotten them to stop by whipping out my phone and threatening to text pictures to Santa.*   I did not pretend to be asleep for an extra twenty minutes this morning.  If I had heard my older two children loudly shushing my youngest in the hallway and telling him to "be QUIET, we're gonna let Mommy SLEEP so she feels better, you saw how she looked last night!" I wouldn't have stayed in bed grinning for that extra twenty minutes because I always wake up ready to spring forth and greet the new day with vim and vigor, even when I'm sick.*   I also didn't sit down to a breakfast of milk and the peanut-butter cookies we made last night with my children in celebration of having turned in final grades and officially begun my winter break.  I would never!

body: I don't plan to talk about my students much on here, because I love my job and would like to keep it.  And I will spare you my angry tirade on the subject of "phonics" vs. the whole-word recognition method of learning when it comes to reading skills, because really even I have to be in just the right mood to find that interesting.     Besides, when I start talking about these kids today and their LOL-speak I sound about eighty.   So we're not going to talk about how I teach the English language, because really I would've been better off grading today's batch of essay questions as if I was teaching Introductory Taoism anyway.  A little-known fact about MFA Mama: as an undergraduate I majored in English but I had enough credits in Philosophy and Religious Studies that I could have just as easily majored in that instead.  P'U, or the simple beauty of the "uncarved block," is one of the most basic tenets of Taoism, and so when I say that today my students were full of P'U I'm saying it with love and even a little bit of admiration.   Because I may be the one with the terminal degree in writing, but I could sit at my keyboard all day long and never come up with half as perfect a sentence to describe being snowed in with a bad cold as this:It was a time of great shivery.   Whether the student in question was commenting on the way societal expectations dictated gender relations in a specific period of British history as pertained to a work of literature is completely irrelevant here, because really, is it just the Day-quil talking or is that beautiful in an "embroider it on a pillow to keep forever" kind of way?  No?  Ah well.     Maybe it's just that when all you've got is a hammer and chisel, everything looks like an uncarved block.  Back to chipping away at the grading over here...u kno ur jellis.
title: hooked on phonics

body: So today I'm pretty much dying, and the Y chromosome was supposed to pick the kids up for a dinner date at four but shockingly he was late and I texted him to meet me at the grocery store a quarter mile from my house because I needed orange juice and soup and over-the-counter decongestant.  And he walks up as I'm getting fingerprinted for the Day-quil (seriously, I don't resort to decongestant but once or twice a year and when did buying it start to require a valid driver's license and a criminal background check?) and the look on his face...   ...well in his defense (and my ex-husband generally does need one) I looked so bad that the girl working the Starbucks counter randomly walked up to me and said "um...do you like latte?  Because someone ordered one and didn't pick it up and you can...have this if you...here..." and shoved a free $4 latte at me like "LADY GET IT TOGETHER, GAWD" and my eight-year-old asked me if I was really leaving the house "dressed like that" before we left, so it was BAD, y'all.   He was looking at me and I was sipping my free latte and coughing and filling out the Day-quil waiver in triplicate and the look on his face was just...well if I'd been able to stop coughing long enough I would've helped him out and just said "yes, they're pajama pants, no, I'm not wearing a bra, and I TOLD you I was sick you jerk," and if my kids hadn't been watching I would've grabbed two fists full of the front of his shirt, pressed myself up against him, and kissed him with tongue.   Yeah, these are the kinds of ideas that run through my fevered head when I'm signing my life away for cold medicine and embarrassing my third-grader and the Starbucks girl at the grocery store and I didn't DO it or anything but how awesome would that have been?  I would've backed him into the Family Planning Section, pulled away, wiped my entire face and been like "enjoy the incubation period, Oedipus, happy HANNUKAH cough cough cough cough cough!"      Perhaps I should go and lie down now.
title: the Grinch had a wonderful, awful idea...

body: If you look at the bottom of my sidebar you'll see that I've added "stuff I use and like," which is exactly what it says it is.  It is also, in the name of full disclosure, reflective of the fact that I have joined the Amazon Affiliates program.  That means that if you click on one of the products I feature in "stuff I use and like" and purchase it, I get a kick-back from Amazon.  I'm only featuring products I a) actually own, b) would recommend to a friend, and c) have reviewed on Amazon.com.   There are different schools of thought on monetizing personal weblogs that seem to range from "well then it's less writing and more whoring" to "good for you!"  My own opinion falls somewhere in between the two; I don't like it when blogs I read start looking like one big dollar sign but if someone manages to do it without being obnoxious in order to pay their hosting fees and maybe even earn a little bit of money writing the stuff I read and enjoy for free then I kind of look at it as win-win.     I'm going to try and do the latter, mostly because blogging is a hobby of mine and I'm not so rich (or so proud) that I'm going to take money I could be using to support my family to pay for my hobby if it can support itself and still be fun for me (and hopefully for you).  To that end, I put "stuff I use and like" at the bottom of the sidebar where you can look or not look, and won't be doing in-text links for profit (meaning that any links in the body of my posts are to help illustrate a point about or attribute information or ideas to the proper parties, and not "product placements" or anything I stand to profit from in any way).  You also won't see those "floating" ads or any interstitial advertising on here, because this is my personal space and I try to create the kind of reading experience I enjoy here; personally I find those things annoying (they don't usually stop me from reading someone else's blog, but I value the personal connections I make through blogging more than the few extra cents including those things in my own blog would earn me, and I still value the opportunity to connect and exchange ideas with those who are less tolerant than I am).     If you have feelings on my ads and the "stuff I use and like" (positive OR negative), I'd love it if you'd open a dialogue with me by sharing it in the comments section.  Y'all are welcome to give me a reality check at any time if I do something on here that you don't like, either in relation my ads and product reviews or just, you know, in general, and I'm open to constructive criticism.  At the end of the day I look at the blogosphere as a community.  MFA Mama is who I am within that community; it's the only name I use when I blog here or anywhere else and the only name I comment under, and this site is my home.  If you as my neighbor feel that it's an eyesore you have every right to come up on my front porch (in the form of the comments section) and tell me so, as well as visit with me (or even try to sell me something if that's your thing; everyone who's not an evangelist or or a vandal is equally welcome here).   You should also feel free just outright criticize me if you feel like it; I may or may not respond (probably not if it seems like you're just being mean unless your spelling, grammar, punctuation and/or overall reasoning amuse me and Satan gets the better of me that day) but I'll read it and so will everyone who reads this blog unless your comment fails the Miller test and/or discloses information about the name I go by offline and where I and my family are that I wouldn't share on here of my own accord (this is what I mean by vandalism).  Some feel that taking measures like this to preserve pseudonymity is cowardly, and maybe you do too, but I want to protect my children's privacy and safety, and don't want them (or my students) reading the things I write here unless I decide to share it with them.  I'm not ashamed of my words or I wouldn't publish them, but I also wouldn't discuss my sex life, my politics, or my warped sense of humor with my children or my students face-to-face the way I do with my grown-up friends offline or on here with y'all either, y'know?     I don't give enough identifying information about the parties I would prefer not to share my blog with for them to find this without help, nor do I let them see me writing this, simply because I like to compartmentalize that way and I think boundaries are a good and healthy thing to have in general.  I'm the same person as MFA Mama that I am at a dinner-party; I say the same things and follow the same personal moral code, but not everyone present knows or needs to know exactly where I live and work or my childrens' full names and what they look like.  I might share that information with someone if we form a connection, but only at my discretion.     Does that make sense?   In other words, I don't moderate comments because I want to censor anyone or am unwilling to hear dissenting points of view.  I moderate comments because there are a handful of former friends, bitter ex-lovers, and all-around stalker-types who from time to time like to let me know that they know my legal name, and where I live, and my birth-mother's and former in-laws legal names and where THEY live, and what my childrens' names are and where they go to school.  While these folks are entitled to their feelings, and fully capable, if their access to the technology and morals (or lack thereof) allow it, of publishing things (such as connections between this blog and my legal name, home address, or pictures of me and my family) that I'd rather not be out there for my kids and my students and the prospective publishers' fellow...let's say "non-respecters of boundaries"...to read, at least for as long as it takes me to reason with their hosting company and/or get a restraining order, I'm not going to let them make my hobby less fun for me by doing it here in my space that I pay for.  I'd probably hesitate to keep a blog at all if it weren't for the fact that a) none of these people know me solely through the blogosphere; I won't say they're not bloggers because some of them have blogs, but instead that they're folks I have associated with offline who also know about the blog, b) they do what they do whether I keep a blog or not and I don't like to do things (or not do things) based on how I think they might react, and c) I take precautions, such as moderating comments on here and locking the doors and windows of my brick-and-mortar home offline.   How about you?  How do you feel about the monetization of personal weblogs, blogging under one's legal name vs. a pseudonym, and "Internet home security?"  I always enjoy your comments and words of wisdom, and hey, it's still National Delurking Week...
title: disclosures on monetization and pseudonymity

body:
The uniform for my new job is kind of a big deal to them (as it should be, since it's a spiffy place and they have an image to maintain). It's also a huge pain in the ass. Not only is it wildly impractical for serving food and busing tables in, but it's also really hard to find certain key components, especially for women (for reasons I won't go into, the hardest-to-source component of the uniform is commonly worn by a trade dominated by male workers). I checked several local stores, couldn't find what I needed, and ordered two sets from different online merchants, reasoning that one or the other would get here within a fairly reasonable timeframe. In the meantime, I purchased a cheap, nearly-suitable iteration of the garment in question, which unfortunately shrank with each washing, to the point that it went from "almost-okay" to "not okay" by company standard. I was well-aware of the problem, and pretty self-conscious about it, and checking the tracking numbers online every time we had a break, but...the uniform is A BIG DEAL (I kind of think The New Job should either provide the whole thing or at least find a way to make it available to employees for purchase, but currently that is not A Thing). As in, you line up before each shift and might get sent home (or to the back, where there is an ironing board and iron) if your creases aren't crisp enough or you are missing a collar button. I don't fault New Job (which still needs a damn blog name but I'm stumped) for this, after all the employees' image contributes to the prestige and therefore the success of the place where I will only be making decent money if there is good business. But when you're poor and can't just buy another almost-suitable garment every two days until the TWO you ordered arrive, it's a kick in the teeth to be called into the office and told that your clothes aren't up to snuff and you can't continue your training (much of which from tomorrow onward will take place in the public eye) until you address that.
   All of which is to say that today I think I set a new personal record for "shortest length employed somewhere before crying at work." Cringe.
   Please don't think New Job are a bunch of meanies who are persecuting me. They're not. The moment my chin first quivered, the previously-terrifying higher-up who had been scolding me (she has the personality of a drill sergeant and Takes No Shit) bundled me into the one-person employee ladies' room (honestly I kind of thought she was getting ready to beat my ass, she's that tough) and told me to explain myself, and I outlined the situation and she went into mother hen mode and smooshed me to her bosom and assured me that nobody was going to fire me for being broke and she'd help me pull something together to wear for tomorrow if need be, and offered me free dessert, and was generally just incredibly nice. And then she took a step back, got her warface back on, and said "now don't you tell anybody though, I rule by fear around here" and stalked back out into the employee locker area where my fellow trainees all appeared to be wondering if in fact she HAD beaten my ass. The classroom facilitator, who didn't know what was going on and apparently thought I was just cracking under the strain of the class and all of the information when she saw my face, pulled me aside and was like "don't worry about the test, you'll be fine, honestly you're my best trainee and I am NOT worried that you'll fail so you shouldn't worry about it either!" Which was good to hear.
   And then I went home and found that the fucking uniform components had arrived while I was at class, and I lost my shit for nothing.
   Sigh.
   Tomorrow will be a better day. Right? RIGHT.
title: a new record

body:
Oh my goodness, y'all. Training at The New Job is really, really daunting. There are over 300 menu items I have to be able to identify by sight, and whose ingredients I have to be able to list, and they all start to run together after the second hour. At the end of the week there's a three-hour exam that you have to pass before you can work (if you fail you get one more try and after a second failure you're fired), and I am starting to feel like I won't be able to do this. Which...well. For chrissake, I have a terminal degree...I feel like this should come a little easier to me, y'know? 
   Hi, I'm MFA Mama, and my new job is humbling the everloving SHIT out of me.
   I keep thinking about all of my MFA Microlenders*, though. Not only is my family depending on me, but I also have all of these incredibly generous strangers who believe in me enough to help me get through this training. FAILURE IS NOT AN OPTION.
   If anyone needs me, I'll be over here making color-coded flash cards and weeping over garnishes.
 
*   About that. We're REALLY, REALLY CLOSE. I haven't sounded the all-clear yet, because I'm still concerned about how the next couple of weeks will play out (I have an entire week of on-the-job training before I'll be earning more than minimum wage at The New Job) and I still haven't figured out how Hotter is getting to his Transplant appointment this week. But I'm no longer hopeless. THIS WILL WORK. IT HAS TO! Thank you so much to everyone who has loaned and donated funds to make this week possible. <3
title: training update

body: *   Last night I couldn't sleep because my ear was killing me.  So I stayed up messing around on Twitter with the laptop turned on its side and my ear full of numbing drops.  At first they helped a lot and I was all "OMG numbing ear-drops are great!"  I couldn't go to sleep until I'd given Little Child his midnight dose of Zofran and decongestant though, and sleep deprivation makes my hand-ear coordination get dodgy, apparently.*   End-result?  Maybe numbing ear-drops aren't so great.*   I told you Little Child has a g-tube.  Mic-key buttons are great (no, that is not Little Child).  When Little Child was tiny he had to be on a feeding pump overnight to get enough fluids/calories into him without triggering his volume intolerance and making him throw up.  So I'd hang an eight-ounce bag of elemental formula on the IV-pole by his bassinet next to my bed (which was pretty much a stand for his bouncy-seat since he had to sleep upright due to reflux), set the pump to 30 ml/hr, swaddle him up and secure him in the bouncy-seat, and we'd sleep for eight hours.  And being able to sneak into a coughing, feverish preschooler's room with an extension tube and a couple of syringes and slip him half the medicine cabinet and some generic Pedialyte?  Is a thing of beauty.  Mic-key buttons are great.*   So is guafenesen.  I remember back in the dark ages before it was available over the counter.  You know what's not great though, at least not right now?  Mucinex Mini-Melts.  I mean, great idea, and great with my older kids, but YOU try getting those little son-of-a-whore beads through a g-tube extension sometime.  Mic-key extensions are about as big around on the inside as a pencil lead.  And then?  There's a right angle where the extension hooks up to the mic-key button.  See?*   And yes, you CAN get guafenesin in a syrup form, and that WOULD be a lot easier.  But the problem with that is that a) I have not yet found the syrup in a dye-free form, b) Little Child is allergic to red food dye, and c) while I would imagine that a dye-free version of the syrup exists, and that I could track it down and purchase it over the innernet, Little Child's GI doctor insists that Tylenol-brand dye-free children's cough and cold is the only thing to give him for congestion that doesn't POTENTIALLY have a negative impact on GI-motility.  Which was why I was talking motilin-agonists with the pediatrician yesterday, because he wanted me to give Little Child guafenesin and I really wanted to listen to him, but I also didn't want go against the GI doctor's advice because he seems to be the only physician who understands what makes Little Child tick and once someone has mentioned TPN in connection with your own personal baby you tend to freak out and get paranoid about anything that might have an adverse effect on gut motility.  So it's not something I plan to keep in stock, although in this one case giving Little Child some guafenesin to help clear his lungs up while the antibiotics kick seemed like a reasonable thing to do in order to keep us out of the hospital.  And Mini-Melts come in yellow.*   So you end up with the mic-key extension being like a narrow, hardened artery and the Mini-Melt beads being like red blood cells or maybe platelets and then this happens at three in the morning and you and your child's mic-key extension have simultaneous coronaries because the kid is asleep (coughing and gagging, but asleep) and tossing around and it's dark and you're trying to be stealthy.*   If that ever happens to you and the blockage is in the mic-key button itself and not the extension (which most insurance companies are pretty miserly with extensions but much more so with the buttons themselves), you can sometimes force Coca-Cola through with a syringe and salvage the equipment.  I doubt that very many of you need that particular Parenting Hack, but if you do?  You're welcome!*   I kind of have to wonder about you if you're still reading this, but you deserve a prize, so here:  This is maybe the funniest thing I've ever read.  They had me at the title (which I kind of want to put on a line of Zazzle products now) but then they refer to "the gays" in total seriousness and compare anal sex to cigarettes and MTV, and...wow.  If you're just the right combination of hurting and sleep-deprived and stressed-out and sick in the head that will win your heart entirely with its combination of dead-earnestness, bigotry, and bad logic and you will giggle for a WHILE.
title: sleep deprivation leads to analogies and questionable humor, and then you look at the word "analogies" and see a pun and it's pretty much all downhill from there

body: It's snowing, y'all.   I think that sentence up there encapsulates the wrongness of the situation nicely; we live in the benighted SOUTH and it is SNOWING.   This makes me happy though, because a) I have groceries, b) I have all-wheel drive and c) it allows me to end threats with "out in the SNOW" as in the following:Big Child: Are you done?  Can I put my stuffed animals back up there now?MFA Mama: [wheezing and climbing down from the top bunk in the older childrens' room where she has just wrestled the mattress cover onto his mattress] No, not yet.(MFA Mama goes and gets the sheets, comes back into the room where Big Child is piling stuffed animals onto the top bunk.)MFA Mama: DUDE.  Didn't I just say not to put those back up there yet?Big Child: NO.  I mean...well, I forgot.  MFA Mama: You forgot about sheets?Big Child: You already put THAT thing on there...MFA Mama: That's the mattress cover.  It makes your bed comfy and it's waterproof so if you wet the bed or get sick and throw up it doesn't ruin your mattress.Big Child: Or poop in the bed?MFA Mama: You're eight and two-thirds.  If you poop in your bed I throw you out of the house and it doesn't matter if you have a place to sleep in here because you'll be out in the SNOW.Middle Child: NO!  Don't throw my brother out in the snow!  I love him!*MFA Mama: You think it's okay if he poops in his bed?!?Middle Child: [thinks for a moment, then grins evilly] YES!MFA Mama: Ooookay, but your bunk is RIGHT UNDER HIS.  If he pooped in his bed some of it could fall on you...Middle Child: OUT IN THE SNOW!Big Child: HEY!Little Child: [cloyingly; he sounds JUST LIKE Caillou sometimes] Mooooommy?  Would you throw ME out in the snow if I pooped in MY bed?**MFA Mama: Hmm.  Well, you're still in a Pull-Up at night, but...Middle Child what do you think?Middle Child: OUT IN THE SNOW!  YEAH!****  Middle Child is on the autism spectrum, so he's very literal-minded, plus he likes an excuse to rumble.  He's at the point in his therapy where he's serious when he says these things, but if you question them he mostly catches on enough to SAY he was kidding.  Which is progress and we will take it.**  Little Child is a genius, an evil, Machiavellian genius, and said that knowing that a) there are different rules governing his toilet habits than those of the other two due to age and medical conditions and b) if I said no, Big Child, who has Asperger's Syndrome, might still be taking me seriously enough to feel terribly slighted in comparison.*** By letting Middle Child answer Little Child I avoided doing so myself.  Little Child knew I wasn't really letting Middle Child answer the question of whether I would LITERALLY throw him out in the snow but Middle Child didn't and was thrilled.
title: baby, it's cold outside

body: In a plot twist I never saw coming, a Higher-up at The Ritzier sat me down, said they'd researched some things I'd said, and that I was right, I'd gotten a massively raw deal, and they wanted to apologize on behalf of The Ritzier. "It was unfair, unscrupulous, and just plain wrong; you're a good employee and we don't want to lose you. What would it take to get you to retract your two-week notice?"  I said I'd think about it.  Sent from The Precious
title: Twist

body:
*   Worked a double today; STRESSFUL since I'm still learning the ropes but good money! Good enough that I should be able to get everybody's school supplies and pay back my MFA Microlenders in a timely fashion if I can just get through the next few days. YAY!
*   I'm still sick, and I *think* I'm getting better? But I still feel like crap. And if I end up needing a doctor that'll fuck EVERYTHING up. Booooo :(
*   The MFA Minivan recovered from its fit the other day. It was only MOSTLY dead! We've revived it for now with motor oil and automatic transmission fluid. YAY!
*   On the whole, the MFA Minivan still has two wheels in The Big Junkyard In The Sky, and I have no backup plan or safety net right now should it croak WHATSOEVER. Booooo OMG BOOOO!
*   Once I'm past the initial "OMG WHERE IS EVERYTHING IN THE COMPUTER HOW DO I DO THINGS HALP!" learning curve, I think I'm really going to love The New Job (which I can't manage to blog-name for the life of me...all of my ideas are too identifying but it's kind of the only place like it? I don't know, hopefully things go well and it'll just be "work" or "my job" and there won't be any more old/new/this month shenanigans). YAAAAAAAY!
title: quickly, some yays and boos

body:
Blogging will likely be pretty sparse until next weekend, as I am working both jobs full-time this week (regular shifts at The Ritzier and training shifts at The New Job) and studying for my Big Terrifying Exam next Saturday. If I pass that then I will be a full-fledged employee at the new place. YAY! Failure is not an option.
   I've gotten a couple of e-mails asking about Hotter's Transplant appointment. It was...I dunno, it just WAS. I wasn't there (I had to drop him off way early on my way to training and pick him up afterward), his weight is way down (shocker), they did a CT scan of some things along with the usual labs, and we haven't heard a damned thing about any of that. I have been asking Hotter to call and follow up and ask what the results of the tests were, but he pretty much refuses on the grounds that navigating their phone system is frustrating, and since I haven't had the time to play Mommy and call on his behalf I'm going to have to assume they found nothing that they need to act on (usually they call if his labs are wonky and I like to think that if they saw, say, a TUMAH on the CT scan they'd speak up about that as well). Big Child deserves some recognition for the fact that he babysat the littles during both Hotter's and my absence and kept everyone alive and happy (he is now old enough to do that per local laws; I wasn't thrilled with leaving him in charge for so long because I still feel like he's a really young thirteen in a lot of ways but The XY refused to take the children so it was a day of everyone doing what they had to do around here).
   The Ritzier has continued to go downhill; upper management has been doing some really effed-up things to middle management, making them cranky, which in turn means that line-level employees are more disgruntled than usual. Drunk Boss's position was finally filled, and initially I thought people were overreacting when they said the new guy made Drunk Boss look good, but then yesterday I met the new guy, and...wow. I don't even know where to START! He appears to possibly have Tourette's, which a lot of line-level employees are spouting off about but isn't something I would be comfortable criticizing, for obvious reasons (although it does mean he is unable to help on a hands-on basis due to being unable to hold onto things like glasses, trays, etc. without flinging stuff). Aside from that he has incredibly poor social skills, doesn't seem to understand personal space (HE'S A CLOSETALKER OH HELL NAW), and then there's the fact that HE PATTED ME ON THE ASS. I...well geez, there is a lot going on and I'm not exactly feeling VIOLATED or anything...I'm not really sure what to make of the encounter, honestly. He was standing behind me at the time so I didn't see him move in; it SEEMED to be deliberate based on context clues (he was saying "Seeya later everybody, nice meeting you MFA Mama" and then PAT!) but the guy definitely has some motor-control issues so MAYBE it was accidental (although I think most of us would be like "oh whoops sorry!" if we accidentally touched someone's ass at work and there was nothing like that afterward)? The middle manager who was standing next to me when it happened asked me how I wanted to handle things when I was like "dude he just patted my ass" and I said I was willing to call it an accident THIS time, but if it happened again he was going to be shoving his cocaine up his butt while his nose heals (yeah, he's also pretty obviously a cokehead, but it's kind of the least of his problems). After which she slapped me on the arm and then laughingly apologized, and I was all "don't feel bad, inappropriately touching me seems to be The Done Thing today, anybody else wanna get in on this?"
   ...
   Yeah.
   My original goal was to hang in there at The Ritzier until long about Thanksgiving and build up a little cushion for when the MFA Minivan or my front tooth goes, but I don't know that I'll last that long.
   Other than that, I am a flashcard-making FOOL over here and will be trudging around in an overcaffeinated fugue state mumbling lists of allergens and garnishes for the next week.
   How are all of YOU?
 
P.S. I tried rare Ahi and LIKED it...I don't know what this world is coming to. I definitely wouldn't order it, but it was at work and I always feel rude if something is GF and I don't at least taste it, so I guess my horizons have been broadened.
title: work/study

body:
*   My cold did indeed depart without medical intervention, which delighted me to no end considering that I am, as of 9/1, once again without medical insurance (dammit). Whoo!
*   Thanks to my having picked up an extra shift today, I am 99.9% certain that I have now paid back all MFA Microlenders for their generous help in getting my family through the training period for The New Job. That said, I suck with numbers, and while I starred all donations marked "loan" in Gmail and paid those back, I am paranoid that I have overlooked someone who will then think I am a deadbeat, hate my guts, and join forces with Stalky in slandering my good name across the innernets. IF YOU LOANED ME MONEY AND DID NOT GET A REFUND VIA PAYPAL, PLEASE COMMENT OR E-MAIL ME AND LET ME KNOW SO THAT I CAN PAY YOU BACK! I don't want to miss anyone, and have you think I just suck. I promise it won't be awkward! Speak now or forever hold your peace!
*   We think one of the pullets laid an egg. They're in with the older girls now (all three of them--Honeybadger died a couple of weeks ago of some mysterious chicken ailment--she just laid down one day and never got up; I moved her to a pen by herself so the others wouldn't bother her and she ate and drank for a couple of days then just keeled over dead without ever getting up again), and Hotter collected a very bright blue egg that didn't appear to be the work of Maria or Blacktop (Dottie lays brown eggs so it definitely wasn't her). Yay, egg!
*   We're getting lettuce and mesclun greens from the garden, as well as kale and zucchini and sweet potato greens and turnip greens. I'm the only one who eats most of that, but yay, greens! I've been hitting the naproxen pretty hard of late and bleeding like a stuck pig from even the smallest of cuts, so leafy greens are just what the doctor ordered!
*   The XY took the boys this weekend for the first time in a loooong while. I am hoping that this means his house is rebuilt (after the "Jewish Lightning" of last April) and his weekend visitation will resume, because the food cost of having the boys home all the time ALONE is killing us (plus he's been telling them for weeks now that the house is done and they can come and see it, but then it turns out there's been a delay and he doesn't take them). Who knows, though. We'll see I guess.
*   I'm so damn tired, y'all. Days of back-to-back doubles have taken their toll, and tomorrow's another one. 
*   How are all of YOU?
title: updates, miscellaneous (and a shout out to the MFA Microlenders)

body:
Today I made as much money over a weekday lunch as I'd been accustomed to making on a Friday night at The Ritzier. And I didn't have to do any heavy lifting or wait unreasonably long for any of my guests' food to come out. Nothing was made wrong. Everybody I served enjoyed their meal. And I didn't bus a single table. Also, today's Soup Of The Day was gluten-free and DELICIOUS, and I ate my fill of it for free and enjoyed it very much.
   The new job, whatever its' blog-name may end up being, is pretty much my idea of heaven.
   Best of all, after work Hotter and I went out and bought all of the school supplies the younger two MFA Children needed, as well as some wine for mama to enjoy while she labeled things and a few essential groceries, and then I came home and repaid the first of the MFA Microlenders.
   It may all fall to pieces tomorrow, as is always the case, but today, friends? Today was a very good day.
   And how are all of YOU?
 
P.S. My cold is getting better, and now seems like it will depart without medical assistance. Which is, obviously, A BEAUTIFUL THING.
title: happy

body:
*   I PASSED MY TEST! WHOOOOO TITS!
*   The Ritzier, out of nowhere, was like "Hi, MFA Mama's voicemail, thanks for giving notice but you don't quit, you're FIRED! Return your uniform or else!" What. The. Fuck. Yes, the same Ritzier that begged me to reconsider quitting. Although THAT manager doesn't work weekends, and this happened on a Saturday, so who the fuck knows. Bottom line: thank goodness for The New Job.
*   Today was my first day working there, and it was a double. I am still sick and it may be settling in my chest; I was just happy to finish the day with a voice and having made enough money that hopefully nothing bounces.
*   The MFA Minivan has a sick, or maybe a dead. It started fucking up on the way home tonight and never recovered as it has in the past. I am too sick and tired to worry about it tonight; we'll all still be fucked in the morning.
*   How are all of YOU?
title: switch

body:
*   I did not run out of Pull-ups and put my youngest child to bed in a Little Swimmer last night.  Nope nope nope.*  
I also didn't strip the child and the bed at 4 a.m. and then put
another Little Swimmer on the poor kid (if my ex-husband and his
lawyers are reading this, I could totally afford more Pull-ups in the
first half of each month if you'd stop suing the crap out of me).*   I am not bitter.*  
I have never, EVER put together an "eat the pantry" meal of hot dogs
wrapped in bread instead of buns, clementines, and cucumber salad, much
less done such a thing THIS VERY EVENING.*   I would never let
my children put yesterday's socks on in the mad rush to get to the
school bus, because that would be gross.*   And I most certainly
don't stand in my driveway in my fluffy pink bathrobe like a crazy lady
stalking my own children through the hedge out front to watch them get
on the bus with my own eyes.  Sure, their friends' moms don't do that
and the oldest is eight, and it's a very safe neighborhood and less
than a block's walk, but...wait, why am I rationalizing this?  I don't
do that anyway!*   I also didn't go out there, um...commando under the robe this morning, and even if I had it wouldn't have been because I needed to do laundry.  Nope, not me!
title: Not Me Monday!

body: Actual conversation with oldest child at the grocery store yesterday afternoon:Big Child: Hey mommy?  Why don't you buy some frozen sausage biscuits while we're here?  I'd like to have those for breakfast tomorrow and you haven't gotten them for us in forever.MFA Mama: Because we don't have a microwave, remember?*  You need a microwave to heat those up.Big Child: Oh...hey look, there's sausage!  You could make the sausage and the biscuits, from scratch!MFA Mama: I'd have to get up pretty early to--Big Child: Remember what Dr. Pediatrician said?  That my new concentrating pill would make me not as hungry for lunch so I should eat a big breakfast with lots of fat and protein?  Sausage has fat and protein, right?   So I got up early this morning and made biscuits and fried up some sausage, and the kids missed the bus so I drove them to school.  I have to hand it to the oldest child though; that was pretty crafty for an eight-year-old!*  Yes, that's right, we haven't had a microwave since we moved out of the "marital home," which had a built-in microwave.  My ex-husband took the stand-alone microwave I'd had since college AND the one from the house before that one, and I kind of like the way living microwave-free makes me less lazy as a cook.  I do miss microwave popcorn though...
title: In which I go on a guilt trip

body:
So Thanksgiving came early, in that I turned in my two-week notice at The Ritzier today.
   Nothing major went down, it was just another shitty day, and we were busy, and there were three managers standing around watching two employees scramble to meet the guests' needs and yelling at us for not doing more, faster, while they did nothing to help. Meh. Once the rush was past, the other server and I compared notes and realized that Uncle Bad Touch had done the same "maybe accidental but no apology and didn't FEEL accidental" thing to her, and we both wrote out our two-week notice and high-fived on it because we both have other jobs and were pretty disgruntled BEFORE we got manhandled by that clown.
   Apparently one other server already put in HER notice on Friday (no word on whether anyone touched her no-no place as of yet), and of the remaining three who work in the morning, two of them are planning to give notice in the near future and the third today told management that maybe they'd see them for their next shift and maybe they wouldn't.
   At this rate, Uncle Bad Touch is going to need to find a way to carry a tray and wait tables pronto!
   I went straight from work to the dentist today and had my teeth cleaned so as to take advantage of the insurance while I have it, and an x-ray of the current Bad Tooth looked fine (although MFA Dentist said I'm not nuts, the thing IS loose) so hopefully the bite adjustment he did will encourage it to tighten back up in the socket. Which would be grand.
   And now, back to my flashcards, which I am VERY motivated to study!
title: early

body: So someone gave the URL and username/password to someone else who lives in a foreign country who was NOT on "the list," and Sitemeter is my friend, and the person in question confirmed that they got a mysterious "hey check this out" message with the login info, and I'm more paranoid than usual since my ex-husband and his lawyers (yes, plural) are hounding me and the innernet (brace yourself) is full of CRAZY PEOPLE.   I know, right?  I'm still in a state of shock myself over that last one.   So this part of the site is going public and occasionally if something happens that I'd rather not share with the whole entire world (no, not YOU, just, you know, THEM) I'll be writing about it here and those of you who have the username/password can use it to get into that area of the blog.  I feel like that's a pretty decent compromise between "letting the terrorists win" and "having at least three lawyers read my blog post about that time one of the kids did something heinous* and everybody cried."   Also?  If you have the username/password for the PWP blog PLEASE do not share it with anyone.  Even if you pretty much know them and are pretty sure they know me and...yeah, just don't do it, okay?  If you don't have that information and would like to, please leave me a comment telling me who you are.*   That was totally hypothetical, because my children are happy and well-adjusted and NEVER act out.  Ahem.  I was just giving an example of what someone ELSE in my position might not want leaked to the entire innernet.
title: Passwords and Privacy

body: And so I'm back.  What have y'all been up to while I've been gone?  Leave me your URLs in comments so I can catch up.
title: Now with 100% less Husband

body:
*   My ankle is still jacked up. It's better than it WAS--the steroids definitely helped!--but it's still painful and I kind of wonder if maybe it's arthritis?
*   We've had some monster storms here lately; I was going to plant some beans today but the entire yard is a "sharsh" (think marsh but with a septic tank involved). I think this hurricane season is going to be a real bear. Today I bought one of these, because priorities:
 *   Animals! Our utility beasts are getting on my nerves. The big chickens are laying erratically, the little chickens are not quite big enough to live outside but TOO DAMN BIG to stay in the house much longer, I need to find a time when the kids aren't home to process Iden, and one of the little bunnies peed on me! The pet-beasts at least are comporting themselves fairly well FOR THE MOMENT. Skeeter in particular has been very sweet of late.
*   We're having some staffing shake-ups at work. I am not a fan but am hopeful that the changes will lead to better days ahead!
*   Hotter is going through a period of intense grumpiness and aggravation with the boys. I'm not really downing him, as they can be supremely annoying, but I wish everybody could get along better and am already worrying about the summer!
*   The MFA Minivan is rife with electrical issues, and the latest one is that it thinks there's a door open ALL THE TIME except there's not. If it was just the little light-thingy in the dash that would be okay, but it's also the "ding, ding, ding, ding!" alllll the fucking way to work and back. *sigh*
*   As if the bum ankle wasn't making me feel old enough, I now have a TEENAGER and the blister on my pinkie from taking the thirteenth-birthday cake out of the oven to prove it. Oy!
 
Disclosure: That-there link above is an affiliate one, which means that if you buy the charger-thingy through it, I get a nickel or something. I LIKE NICKELS!
title: my ankle and other annoyances

body:
*   I'm getting a cold. Like, a bad, headachey, sneezy, stuff-coming-out-of-my-eyes kind of craptastic cold. There is no time or money for this in the coming days' schedule.
*   Finances are worse than anticipated due to Hotter needed transplant meds at the same time as the kids need back-to-school stuff and the MFA Minivan is burning through gas like whoa because of my crazy-ass work schedule. If I can manage not to miss any work before the end of the month we should be okay, but it's a big if given the previous.
*   Speaking of the MFA Minivan, its progressive neurological condition seems to be getting worse, and yesterday it straight-up DIED at a stoplight. I am not a fan of this. That damn thing needs to hold on for just a little bit longer.
*   Shoes For Crews. GOD THEY SUCK! That is what I am wearing at New Job until I can afford a pair of white Danskos, and also what gave me Paul in the first place. I thought a few weeks of S4C would be okay but it is not going well. Paul is angry.
*   I'm worried that I'm not studying enough for Saturday's test, but I can't take any time off from The Ritzier to study because money. 
*   I am not looking forward to the next ten days.
*   To end on a cute note, the other day I desperately needed a highlighter, and I knew the MFA Children had some in their school supply stashes. *   Management has capped overtime at about twenty hours per week LESS than I've been aiming for of late, and I Am Not A Fan. Largely because this means I'll have to get another job in addition to The Ritz and juggle two schedules, and I don't WANT another job. I like all five of my existing jobs within the one resort property, and the simplicity of the single paycheck, HR department, timeclock, etc. In the short-term, however, this may mean more blogging, so there's that.
*   Today I only worked the one shift, so since the MFA Children had expressed an interest in trying duck (it came up in the context of it being one of the courses in a five-course Special Dinner Thing I worked at The Ritz, which I was describing to Hotter and the boys), I broke down a whole duck into skin, legs, wings, and boneless breasts and thighs, sliced the breast and thigh meat thinly, pounded it, and then put it to marinate in ginger, garlic, wheat-free soy sauce, and honey with a dash of vinegar. I then rendered the skin over low heat, pouring off clarified fat until I had a goodly amount. Two dogs and a cat then got the cooled skin bits to eat and licked their chops for the rest of the damn night. Meanwhile, I salted and scored the legs and wings, poured fat over them, and made confit for the grown-ups. For the kids I cut the tenderized and marinated boneless meat into bite-sized bits, dredged them in cornstarch, salt and pepper, and fried them in the rest of the fat until crispy. Then I popped the crispy duck-bites into the oven to make sure they were cooked through, and made a sauce with ginger, garlic, soy sauce, honey, and the juice and chopped peel of an organic navel orange. I made "deconstructed springrolls" (spring-roll veggies over rice) to go with the duck and sauce, and served it up, and EVERYBODY LIKED DINNER. *preens*
*   Suddenly it is ridiculously gorgeous outside! To celebrate, Poppy gathered an assortment of ticks around her...bathing-suit areas. If dogs wore bathing suits. Which ours do not. I don't know who I felt sorrier for during the removal process, Poppy herself, Hotter, who was tasked with holding her, or me (ticks are TINY, Poppy is covered in tick-MARKS, which it would be inadvisable to remove with tweezers, and my eyes are apparently not what they used to be) (which means my face was way closer to dog...underbelly...than I'd ever like for it to be again).
*   Valet continues to be a lot of fun. I got to drive one of these that was either brand-new or in mint condition. Black with a tan leather interior. It smelled like happiness inside! Sadly there was a space very near the entrance to The Ritz's garage and so I had no legitimate reason to take her out of first gear :(
*   I have a burgeoning chest cold, and I would rather not.
*   I am beginning to think Bravo Hive may still be alive after all! That would be fabulous news, for obvious reasons. Hopefully it stays nice and I don't get any sicker so I can check on the hive tomorrow after work (after that it's doubles for the rest of the week), although the last time I did that before working in the restaurant, as I will be on Thursday, I got to wait tables with a grotesquely-swollen face as a result. Hmm...
*   The TL;DR version: I heartily recommend Porsche Boxsters and well-cooked duck, ticks, money and chest colds suck, and bees are confusing, which is exacerbated by their hatred of close study.
   How are all of YOU?

body: Today I took the MFA Minivan in for an oil change and tire rotation.  It had been about 2,000 miles since the last oil change and one of the tires had...some kind of issue*...so I sent the MFA children out to dinner with the Y chromosome (who took his visitation this week--miracle!), swung by a drive-thru to pick up some tacos, and headed on over to the auto-repair shop.   I <3 MFA Mechanics, I really do.  They're a father and sons outfit who come to my house when the MFA Minivan won't start, give me a lift home when they have to keep it overnight and drop it off the next morning, and don't charge me for little extras like a bulb for a break light or, in today's case, a 20-amp fuse (that happened to power the outlet I use to power Tom-Tom, which I need because I have the directional sense of a drunken crash-test dummy).     We chatted while they examined the questionable tire for leaks, and they asked me if I was divorced yet.  I told them about the clause in the property settlement that states that not only am I not allowed to have unrelated overnight guests of the opposite sex, but also of the same sex if the party in question is "of romantic interest" (yes, really--my lawyer was all "he just called you a lesbian" and I was all "he's called me much worse" and nobly resisted the urge to ask him if that meant I could bring a girl home just for sex with no romance attached, because probably the look on his face would have been priceless).  "Nothin' wrong with that!" said MFA Mechanic, Jr., his eyes lighting up.  "No, not at all, I'm not saying I can't see where he was coming from, just surprised he spent the money to add THAT in."  We had a good laugh all hunkered around the tire looking for bubbles, and finding none agreed that I'd just keep an eye on it.   Next we checked out the electrical issue.  "That's the problem right there," MFA Mechanic, Jr. said, after probing the fuse panel with a voltometer.  I said I had figured as much but a) didn't have a 20-amp fuse and b) couldn't get the daggone thing out to save my life.  "Well, if it happens again look for the one that's this color, because the rest are orange, take your hair down, put some lipstick on and get somebody with stronger fingers to pull the sucker out for ya," said MFA Mechanic, Jr., handing me a bright yellow fuse, "then stick this in there."   I almost made out with him, I was so grateful.     Then he informed me that I need new brake pads, and shined a pen-light into the side of the wheel to show me what he meant.  Oy.  "Define need," I said, sighing.  "Prob'ly got another thousand miles in 'em, 'long as it don't start shaking or squealing when you brake.  Put it in the budget for after the fifteenth, maybe?"   As I told my closest friend on the way home, that is how you know you've got a good mechanic.  They grease it up before they stick it to you.  "Nice," he said.  "Always a lady, you are."   "I am," I agreed, and pointed the MFA Minivan homeward to perform brain surgery on my new computer.____________________________________________________________________________________   Speaking of which, have any of you upgraded from Vista Home Premium to Windows 7?  If so, how are you liking it?  I have an opportunity to do that for free but am suspicious of change in general.  Also Firefox is not my friend lately and I'm thinking of trying Google Chrome.  Any thoughts?*   Which seems to happen every time certain people who shall remain nameless get their panties in a twist around here; last time they clipped the valve stems off and the police got involved.  This time MFA Mechanic, Jr. was of the opinion that someone probably just let the air out of it "to f*ck with you."  Sigh.
title: my mechanic knows how to treat a lady

body:
*   Hotter's GI problems have continued to worsen. I thought maybe I was viewing the world through shit-colored glasses and it wasn't that bad, but then Big Child took me aside and privately asked me if Hotter was okay, because "lately when he sleeps he looks...dead." OH SO IT'S NOT JUST ME THEN. He sees Transplant in two weeks and so far my most recent attempt to use Ensure to put weight on him has only exascerbated things further.
*   Work. Oh, work. Things at The RItzier are kind of post-apocalyptic in the wake of Drunk Boss's departure, rumors of a wildly unsuitable promotion based on strategic fellatio have abounded (but thankfully seem to be unfounded as of this posting; the position remains unfilled), and I got another (second) job, the one I interviewed for AFTER the one I posted about. It's another waitressy gig at a new ethnic restaurant opening in a prime location, and I'm pretty excited about it, because it's food I really like that is by nature gluten-free in many cases, and I've never helped to open a new restaurant.
*   The health insurance at The Ritzier sucks rather a fat hairy one. There's a $3,000 deductible, and the plan only knocks about $40 off the price of Pristiq. One small bright spot is that they (inexplicably) lower the cost of generic Mirapex by 80%, so I've filled that and am hoping that better-quality sleep will make things look less grim, although currently I doubt it will.
*   The XY announced a few days ago that he was TAKING A WEEKEND for the first time in months, but then yesterday was like "oh, nope, PSYCH!" Hotter and the boys have all logged fewer years of being let down by that motherfucker, and are less sanguine about it than I have become of late. So while I have finally reached a point of being resigned to the XY's congenital inability to keep his own damn word, everyone I love is still processing, and that's just PEACHY.
*   The fact that I am still paying out of pocket (for all intents and purposes) for Pristiq AND paying a health insurance premium means that it's still up in the air whether I'll make rent for this month, so we're economizing a lot here currently. By which I mean that I made some surplus (wheat-containing) pasta for the chickens today, since they are out of feed, and have been trying to cut greens enough for the rabbits to not need much bought feed.
*   I've been working on the fall garden and am moving forward with a goal of growing more fodder and forage for the rabbits and chickens in addition to fruit, vegetables, greens, and cooking herbs. Our spaghetti and butternut squashes are looking good, and we my actually get some muskmelons this year as well. Currently we're getting beets and kohlrabi, and I've been making a lot of stirfry. Red stir-fry (from the beets) is delicious, but slightly offputting. Backyard honey and gluten-free tamari makes decent faux teriyaki sauce. I've yet to put beets in an omelet, but I'm sure it's only a matter of time as the Feed Store Six ought to be laying shortly.
*   All of Pfeffer's "final four" are still with us, and I had separated them into four cages to keep them from snuggling in the heat and/or breeding unchecked, but there was more rabbit drama. One of them got a little sickly for a bit; it knocked its water down and went without overnight while it was pretty hot out, and got a bit doddery and stopped grooming itself for a couple of days. Another got out of its cage when Poppy got off her leash and knocked the cage from its base; the rabbit was missing at first and then I saw it wedged halfway behind the chicken coop and not moving, and gloved up and grabbed its hind legs and pulled, thinking it was injured or dead. Turns out it was just really, really stuck, either because Poppy wedged it in there or it wedged itself in its terror to escape her. Once I pulled it loose it recovered and tried to eviscerate me. The doddery one I thought I'd need to euthanize, because it just sat and looked confused when confronted with food and water, and was really filthy, but Hotter had an idea. "I'm putting another rabbit in there. It maybe just needs to be reminded what to do and they'll groom each other. HERE IS YOUR NEW GROOMING BUDDY!" And he placed another rabbit in with the doddery one. I'll be damned if it didn't work! So we have two cages with one rabbit each and one cage with two.
*   My bad ankle has taken to buckling under my weight and forming a perfect right angle several times per day seemingly at random, and I'm rather dismayed. If I had to guess I'd say it's the kind of thing that would be treated with orthotics, therapy, and/or surgery, none of which are financially feasible or likely to be practical with my work schedule and connective tissue disease, so I guess what I'm saying is that I think I'll be hating this ankle for the rest of my life as I hate my lower back. 
*   Yep, still depressed; a friend on the facespace asked me how I was doing lately, and I was like "oh, you know. Worried about everything and drinking a lot."  I could maybe use a grooming buddy over here my own damn self.
*   How are all of YOU?
title: sickness, beets, depression, and poverty: time for some bullets I guess
