body:
So I thought maybe I'd take Isis to the vet and they'd find out she had a rotten tooth and scold me for being late on her cleaning and then I'd bitch about how it cost as much as the people-dentist to fix and we'd all have a laugh at my expense because I had convinced myself the dog was dying and OMG, NOT EVERYTHING IS THAT DAMN SERIOUS.
   Except instead of that, the vet was like "oh wow, hopefully this is just a tick-borne illness but she's lost a little weight and doesn't seem infectious-sick...have you ever heard of LYMPHOMA?" Which is exactly what Dr. Google said that freaked me out so badly yesterday.
   Fuuuuuck.
   So they did a full panel of bloodwork, and nothing came back abnormal there except for her "blood protein levels," which the vet says just indicates that something, somewhere in Isis is inflamed, maybe from infection, maybe from injury, maybe from lymphoma. Since her white blood count wasn't indicative of infection, they recommended that I let them aspirate all of the lymphnodes and send the fluid for testing, and that will tell us definitively whether this is cancer or not. SOMETIME NEXT WEEK.
   The vet said her only other theory was mayyyybe some kind of tick-borne illness, either ehrlichia, Lyme disease, or Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever. It's kind of longshot since it's been longer than the incubation period on those things typically is since Isis had a tick on her and she had the Lyme vaccine. The "tick panel" of bloodwork is $200, but since the antibiotic they use for All Things Tick was $60 and they wanted to put her on an antibiotic "just in case" anyway (the vet is concerned that if the lymphnodes on her neck get any bigger while we're waiting on the lab Isis won't be able to swallow), we agreed to just go ahead and treat her as if she had a tick-borne illness. I know that I for one would be perfectly okay with it if the lymphoma test came back negative, the antibiotics worked, and we never knew for sure what had been wrong.
   In the meantime, we're spoiling Isis ROTTEN. I don't think she's even been in her crate except to eat (Skeeter WILL NOT stay out of her bowl if there's food in it and while she's never snapped at him, she HAS--understandably--growled at him for this, so we put her in "protective custody" when she's eating to keep him safe) since I took her to the vet (I went back to work afterward, and Hotter is an even bigger sucker for that dog than I am). I worked a banquet tonight where we carved two Steamship Rounds, and brought the bones from both of them home for her. She's taking her antibiotics in more peanut-butter than is strictly necessary. And she can hog the bed all she wants for now.
   Obviously I'll let y'all know when we know anything...man I hope this turns out okay.
title: I'm not paranoid, the universe is just out to get me

body:
Yesterday I ran out of Synthroid and neglected to pick it up before the pharmacy closed. And because I go to work before the pharmacy OPENS, I didn't take it today.
   It turns out missing a dose of Synthroid when you're grieving is a bad fucking idea, almost on par with "getting married in Vegas" (yes, I've done that, and what happens in Vegas DOES NOT STAY IN VEGAS, as it turns out, no, it follows you home, knocks you up repeatedly, and ruins your credit rating).
   I just keep thinking about how she went and greeted every single person who came into the room to help euthanize her with love, from the vet tech who is violently allergic to pitbulls (and got down and let Isis lick her face anyway, even though we all knew it would give her hives), to the vet, to the new vet tech she'd never met (who had huge muscles and, I'm guessing, got saddled with the task of moving her afterward). Even drugged to the gills on doggy morphine and acepromazine, she lurched from person to person, tail wagging, ears back, so happy to see them all. That's the kind of dog she was. She never met a stranger, never once showed any aggression toward anyone. When you put a dog to sleep in this state, you have to sign an affidavit stating that "to the best of my knowledge, my dog has not bitten anyone in the past fifteen days." I wanted to write in "has never bitten anyone, EVER, is a big ball of love."
   It may sound strange coming from someone who butchers chickens and rabbits, but I am terrified of dead bodies. I refuse to go to open-casket funerals. I've been known to run screaming from a dead wormsnake, a dead mouse, MANY DEAD HUMAN BEINGS...Isis though? I held her face while the vet gave her the shot and told her what a good girl she was, and she sank down onto the blanket beneath her, and the vet reached under her with the stethoscope and listened, and said "she's gone," and I didn't let go. It was still Isis. I kept petting her, and holding her, and the vet said she'd take care of her, and then when I didn't move to go anywhere said to take as long as we needed and turn the light off when we were done. That damn dog was my fourth child, and I didn't want to leave her there. I even convinced myself that maybe the vet had made a mistake, and she wasn't quite dead, and told Hotter I didn't want to leave her alone just in case. Finally when her ears started to get cold even I had to admit she was gone. So I wrapped her up, and positioned her so that she looked comfortable, and closed her eyes, and turned the light off on my way out.
   I think if Hotter hadn't made me leave I'd still be sitting there with her head in my lap.
   On the way out, with the empty harness and leash in my hand, I heard the receptionist, who was the happy recipient of many loving maulings from Isis, gasp and say "oh no, Isis!"
   Indeed.
title: grief and Synthroid

body:
The day before Isis's lymphnodes swelled up, I came home from work, drank some hard cider, and accidentally reset the wallpaper on The Precious from the photo of Isis I used in a review post ages ago (minus the glasses) to the boys' annual matching holiday jammies pic (this year is exactly like the first, down to the goofy look on Big Child's face). And when I realized what had happened and that I didn't know  how to change it back, I thought "OMG ISIS IS GOING TO DIE." 
   I think I can best equate this to the way I know when Hotter is about to have a seizure. It just...is.
   When we got the confirmation I had another of my "feelings," that after we had Isis put down we should go directly to the pound because clearly some dog was out there that needed us. I told Hotter about it the night before Isis's last appointment, and he said he was cool with that as long as we didn't do anything hasty. I said well yeah, there'd have to be rules: nothing under twenty pounds, over sixty pounds, over three months of age because we'd want it to be malleable and grow up with the cat, and nothing chronically ill, at least half pit but not purebred because I want something strong and healthy, and we DO NOT BEND on any of that.
   We had Isis put down, and it was beautiful and awful. She greeted every single person who came into the room to help euthanize her with love, and they took turns petting her and thanking her, and then the veterinary staff discreetly maneuvered her onto a thick towel for ease of transport after, and I held her face and told her she was a good dog while the plunger went down, and she was gone in the blink of an eye. Afterward, I didn't want to leave. I was afraid they had messed up, and she wasn't dead yet, and I'd be leaving her alone. When her ears started to get cold Hotter said he had to get out of there, and I wrapped her in the towel and positioned her so that she looked comfy and turned off the light on the way out of the room.
   I wanted to go home and get drunk afterward, but Hotter reminded me that I'd had one of my stupid feelings about going to the pound and said we were going. It was a long drive, and I was crying, and we ended up lost in the huge government center complex where the local Animal Control headquarters is, between the Magistrate's office and the department of Public Utilities. "This is bullshit," I wailed. "This place should be easy to find!" Hotter snorted and said that after the day we'd already had it should be easy to find AND they should be handing out free puppies.
   Finally we found our way into a waiting room that reeked of cigarette smoke, with a chatty receptionist who was saying how it'd be a while because they were short a worker. I told her the rules and she said "hmm...I do have a mostly-pitbull puppy you might really like...she's very chubby and silly. I could just go and get her and you could play with her while you wait...?"
   Seeing that Hotter was the sucker in the relationship, the receptionist dropped a fat brown-cowpatched blob of oversized paws, ridiculous ears, and a wagging white-tipped tail into his lap and backed away to fill my ear with how the puppy was ten weeks old, had just gotten healthy enough to have been spayed, which "starts the countdown," and...by the time the worker finally appeared to show us the dogs, Hotter declared that we were "done here."
   "In that case, happy holidays: [redacted name of local fighting dog rescue organization] has actually sponsored this dog's care here and adoption fee to leave. Sign here to claim your free puppy," the worker said, grinning, and urged us to choose a collar, toys and treats from a pile of donated pet supplies on the way out.
Figure One: And now, THIS asshole.
title: Poppy

body: I have some kind of Virus Of Filth that is causing the worst damn body aches I've had since having "post-staph rheumatoid phenomenon" in the wake of MRSAgate Aught-Six. Also a fever, a pounding headache, and upper-respiratory disgustingness. I'm about as pleased with this as you might imagine, especially given that The Ritz has a three-hour call-out policy (if you call out less than three hours before the start of your shift, it's an unexcused absence unless an immediate family member has died or you've been taken to the hospital via ambulance/had an accident on the way to work) and this COULD just be a twenty-four hour bug. I don't want to call out unnecessarily, because I can't afford to miss work if there's any other option, but given that my shift starts before dawn this puts me in the position of having to set an alarm for 3 a.m. and make a decision THEN. Feh on that!   On the bright side, I just got a payment notification from the good people over at Lijit. If you don't care about the nuts and bolts of blog-advertising then skip this whole paragraph, but many bloggers shy away from talking about the money they earn from their blogs and I always wonder about that kind of thing myself, so I'm about to break my blog-advertising experience with Lijit down for the curious. They don't pay publishers until you reach a $25 minimum threshold, and given that I am a very small-potatoes publisher, that's taken me (counts on fingers, checks archives)...fifteen months? Yes. But hey, $26.07 is better than a poke in the eye with a sharp stick! And really, out of all the advertisers I've worked with, Lijit's customer service team remains the most responsive, and their terms the least restrictive. They haven't refused to let me create new ad zones due to my modest readership or assaulted my sensibilities with unauthorized noise-making ads a la Adbrite, or suspended me for talking about chickens a la Google. So two thumbs up to Lijit!
title: sickness and Lijit (unrelated)

body:
*   Man oh man, y'all, I love my job more with each passing day I work at...geez, this place needs a blog name. Let's call it...The Ritz (it's not, of course, although it could give that place a run for its money in terms of service and overall luxurious expensiveness). The Ritz rocks, y'all! I'm getting to know some of the "regulars," and there are customers who ask for me when they come in. It's nice to be able to make people happy and have little daily inside jokes at work. And the money doesn't hurt, either (on good days I make in excess of $20/hour, and even on my worst day to date I made more than my hourly rate at The Hotel California).
*   Speaking of money, look at this:

Figure One: This is a beautiful thing! I realize some of you would be very depressed if your bank balance looked like this, but you know what? All of the bills are paid, everything has cleared, and this number? IS NOT NEGATIVE!
   I think our days of repeated overdrafts may be coming to an end, and I am SO HAPPY about that.
*   I have Made A Friend. Like, a brick-and-mortar non-coworker, non-crazy one, even! One of my two favorite yoga instructors and I have a CRAZY amount of life-trivia in common, as we discovered when she remarked on The Jew Tattoo (that thing is a great conversation-starter, it turns out). She's super-cool and I love her classes and she wants to buy some honey from me and I may have just a wee tiny crush.
*   Having working AC in the MFA Beater during the current hellacious heatwave? Is so freaking wonderful I hardly know what to do with myself. 
*   Another good thing: my heartrate while working out has normalized. I think I'm going to go ahead and chalk it up to "yet another stupid thing my body does in response to infection" and forget about it for now, although I will mention it to my doctor when I see her (hopefully next week on my one day off--the Ritz is very busy for the next couple of weeks). And I now realize that I was feeling pretty shitty while working out while all of that was going on depite my protestations to the contrary, because now? I feel AMAZING when working out. Endorphins, yo. They're pretty great! 
*   I am making spicy cilantro-sesame slaw to have for dinner with gluten-free chicken tenders and macaroni 'n cheese. THIS. IS. EXCITING.
*   How are all of YOU?
title: assorted good things

body:
Work today was rather slow by Ritz standards, but I still made good money, and enough of it as cash tips that I was able to stop at the Very Fancy Non-Chain Coffee Shop Of Awesome that Hotter dearly loves (conveniently located between The Ritz and the parking deck where I house the MFA Beater on weekdays) and get him some French Press-ground Creme Brulee-flavored Fancy Coffee for his birthday tomorrow. I also treated myself to an Amazing Milkshake Of Locally-Identifying Name (consisting of three shots espresso, three scoops vanilla ice cream, three pumps coffee syrup, and three ounces whole milk--WHO WANTS TO GO AND LIFT SOME CARS?) while there, and stopped on the way home and got milk and yogurt and grapes and sammich fixins for the boys, all with just today's cash tips! It still feels absolutely miraculous to walk out of work with enough in my pocket to get what we need on a given day, and on Friday I'll get my first Real Paycheck from The Ritz, at which point I can start squirreling away my cash tips as an emergency fund.
   Tomorrow I am off work, which means I can go to evening yoga at the YMCA tonight (and visit my friend the elliptical trainer afterward, because MILKSHAKE) and sleep in in the morning. Although sleeping in has, due to my work schedule, turned into waking up at sunrise anyway half the time. Which oh well, maybe I'll do some yardwork before the heat gets terribly oppressive!
   How are all of YOU?
title: another good day (it never gets old)

body:
MFA Mama: *Gets up early on day off to go run an errand that is only necessary due to Hotter's three-year procrastination on a matter that took five minutes online to resolve from home.* Hotter: *snores blissfully*
MFA Mama: *Encounters administrative glitch that means paperwork with Hotter's signature is needed to complete errand in time to avoid negative consequences, grumbles, goes home and asks Hotter to get up and help find said paperwork.*
Hotter: *feels need to point out that if there IS a negative consequence as a result of his procrastination, he wouldn't be the only one in the house to have incurred one as a result of same, begins listing MFA Mama's past transgressions in an area where she has since taken his wishes into account and made changes to suit his preferences*
MFA Mama: *ignores Hotter in favor of finding and completing paperwork*
Hotter: *pounds on table with his fist like asshole*
MFA Mama: *presents paperwork for Hotter's signature*
Hotter: *says MFA Mama can go ahead and sign it for him, implying it was unnecessary to wake him for this*
MFA Mama: *declines to forge anyone's signature on financial documents, takes signed paperwork to complete errand, comes home and fires up Typepad*
   I don't know what to do with this one, y'all. The issue of this particular bout of procrastination on Hotter's part has become a major one in the MFA Marriage, and it's stupid as all hell. Hotter is 100% in the wrong on this one but has somehow decided that my voicing any hint of displeasure about the three to four errands per month this issue has caused me to have to run for the past three years is verboten and worthy of instant ire on his part. After this month the whole thing should be over and done with and no longer an issue, but Hotter's response to any real or imagined criticism from me is to trot out the same past issues, and I have already done absolutely everything possible to accommodate his preferences there. 
   I've speculated before that my second marriage is a tool that the universe is using to help me better understand the issues in my first one (aside from the things the XY did that were outside the bounds of common decency--yes, he did some stuff that was beyond the pale and made the divorce absolutely mandatory, but in addition to that there were still the typical interpersonal squabbles and grudges of any decade-long relationship). I certainly was guilty of holding past issues against my first husband and trotting them out any time we quarrelled, and now I can see where he was coming from with the "what more do you want" because yeah, it sucks to be on the other end of that one. In the case of my first marriage I just shouldn't have taken the XY back after he cheated, because I should have been self-aware enough to realize that his cheating on me while I was living in the hospital with a critically-ill newborn wasn't something I would ever be able to let go of. Live and learn. The issue Hotter has a problem with is a MUCH lesser offense (no infidelity involved, but rather something that is a matter of personal opinion), but maybe it is nevertheless one he's never going to be able to move past? In any case there was absolutely no reason for today to become A Bad Day, but it has, and now we are going to have to Have A Talk.
   Wish me luck.
 
ETA: We talked, and Hotter says he's going to Drop It. In my heart of hearts I am skeptical that I've heard the last of the issue, but if I continue to belabor it then I'm the asshole at this point. Hotter had a valid question when he asked me what more I wanted besides his assurance that he will, in fact, let it go. Realistically there's nothing he can do short of going back in time and dropping it sooner or speeding time up and demonstrating his ability to let this one die. GET ON THAT WHOLE TIME-TRAVEL THING, HOTTER, GAWWWWD :)
title: tetchy Tuesday [ETA]

body:
Today goes down in the books as the first-ever bad day at The Ritz. It's not The Ritz's fault, or mine, it's a co-worker who is...having some personal struggles. One of the many things I love about The Ritz is that they employ a diverse workforce and don't shy away from hiring the disabled. Unfortunately today a co-worker with an intellectual disability who also happens to be HUGE and male had a meltdown at work (yes, for those of you who are facespace friends, the same thing happened yesterday, and yes, same co-worker), and reader, I do not DO well with angry men losing their minds regardless of who they are or what their deal is.
   So that sucked.
   What does not suck is that I made excellent money today, someone came in and specifically requested to sit in my section, someone else was so happy with my service that they announced their intention to write a letter singing my praises to the General Manager, and I have the next two days in a row OFF. I picked up a bottle of Pristiq from the drugstore today, having finished the last of the Effexor, and it was $74, but while that was an annoying amount given that I have insurance, I had it. And because I am craving some pasta I went to the store and bought some artichoke hearts and good cheese and zucchini and grape tomatoes and white wine and gluten-free grilled chicken strips (yep, LAZY) and am going to go and make myself an extravagant dinner. So even a bad day at The Ritz isn't too shabby given that it pays the bills and allows for the luxury of my feelings-pill of choice and a fabulous meal just because.
   And how are all of YOU?
title: bad day

body:
Overnight, Isis declined dramatically. This morning she was panting and kind of lying there looking dazed with dilated pupils. I'd read online that that can be a sign of pain in dogs with lymphoma, and noted that at least four additional swollen lymphnodes had popped up since yesterday. She was also unusually thirsty, which can apparently indicate a calcium imbalance in end-stage lymphoma in dogs. I'd promised the boys that we'd do "breakfast with Santa" today at The Ritz, and Hotter and I agreed that we didn't want Isis to be alone so I flew solo at the event and called the vet from the road to tell her what was going on and let her know that Isis looked like she was in pain and would need some medication to make her more comfortable until we knew what was what. Honestly, I was kind of worried that she'd hit a point where it didn't feel ethical to let her keep suffering before we got the test results from the lymphnode aspirates back.
   There was a work meeting scheduled for today that I was supposed to attend even though it was my day off, and I found my boss's boss while the MFA Children were occupied with Santa and told him it kind of looked like the family dog might be dying and asked if it would be okay if I skipped the monthly staff meeting just this once (I have yet to miss one, and there are some employees who have been there longer than I have who have yet to ATTEND one). He was kind of wishy-washy about that, and said if I was worried about the boys they were welcome to hang out in the bar and watch TV during the meeting (umm, NO). So I hauled ass back home to drop the boys off and then doubled back to work. 
   Five minutes before I arrived at work the vet called me back. "I'm really sorry," she said, "but the lab called to let us know they didn't even need to complete the testing process. Isis has lymphoma, and it's pretty advanced." She went on to let me know that chemotherapy was an option, but that it would cost more than SHE could afford and the prognosis was pretty grim based on how Isis was doing. I told her we'd probably go the comfort care route and walked into the work meeting bawling and was kind of a dick about everyone's holiday goodwill.
   Hotter texted me while I was at work to let me know that Isis was absolutely miserable. I called the vet back and let her know and she said she'd prescribe some steroids and heavy-duty pain medication to give us time to say goodbye. I came home with pain meds in-hand for Isis, who came lurching to greet me leaving a trail of dropping fur behind her and covered in huge tumors and a painful-looking rash, panting and febrile with a distended abdomen (but still wagging her damn tail).
   This is fucking monstrous. Three days ago she was FINE.
   Telling the boys was...rough.
   We're going to medicate her heavily, love on her overnight, and have her put down tomorrow at noon EST.
   Fuck cancer.
title: Isis

body:
I haven't done a pet peeves post in a while, and my back is still killing me (it did not appreciate my performing a full hive inspection today, which involves lifting a 60-lb box of bees, wax, and honey at least twice) so PEEVES AHOY!
*   Moseyers. Life is too short to mosey. Initially I was just going to say "moseyers at work," because there is nothing like needing to fetch a customer something from a store room at the back of the back-of-house area and having to dodge various people with NO SENSE OF URGENCY on your way, but you know what? Moseyers at the grocery store piss me off just as much. 
*   Rude co-workers. I currently have two jobs, four dependents, a sore back, a burgeoning bunion, and a wee little cut on my forefinger that stings like a bitch every time I get lemon juice in it, and yet I smile and am pleasant to the people I work with as well as the people I work for and the people paying to receive good service from me. I therefore think they ought to return the favor, or at the very least not get pissy because "it's too early to be cheerful." Last time I checked we all worked in the same time zone and I have my gameface on so SUCK IT UP, BUTTERCUP, and join me or go home and be a cranky shithead on your own time.
*   The way you need tits to put toilet paper on the roll in my house. 'Nuff said.
*   Non-wipers of gym equipment. I work out longer than most, and therefore get to watch several people come and go during the course of my quality time on the elliptical. I SEE YOU, YOU FILTHY PIG. The absolute worst are the ones who wipe the equipment down BEFORE using it, proving that they know how to use the paper towels and disinfectant spray provided, but then leave their sweat on the machine for the next person. HELL NO.
*   Horrified-glancers in the lockerroom. Yes, I take ALL of my clothes off if I'm changing into or out of a bathing suit or showering. I'm sorry you're so ashamed of your body that you do The Dance of The Seven Veils with your towel and t-shirt, but I don't have time for that crap (see "moseyers," above). If my stretchmarks, scars, and tattoos bother you, quit darting your judgy little eyeballs over for another look.
*   Not entirely unrelated: people who misinterpret The Jew Tattoo. It's a star of David, not a pentagram. No, really. Yes, I'm sure. COUNT THE POINTS, JACKHOLE. Although the older lady in yoga class who pointed to it and said "I guess you must really like yoga, huh?" just..well. Bless her heart, that was hilarious.
title: peevish

body:
After reading up on the condition, and examining the fit of my workshoes, I have come to the conclusion that the thing on my left foot is, in fact, a bunion. 
   Hotter has named him Paul.
   Paul must die. Because I am not down with having a fucking bunion. The first thing I did was to stop using my custom orthotics temporarily, which created more room inside my shoes (I'll replace them the day after tomorrow, a.k.a. PAYDAY). This alleviated 90% of the pain by itself. Next, I acquired a pair of these:

Figure One: Good night, Paul!
   I figure my hypermobile joints will, in this case, work to my advantage--Paul can hopefully go the fuck away almost as quickly as he popped up with the proper encouragement. Finally, I got these toe-spacer thingies to wear inside my sock during the day to keep my big toe and second toe appropriately separated.
   Paul is going DOWN. If he's not gone in a month, I'll ask my doctor about him (I have a physical scheduled mid-Septemberish to generally kick the tires and discuss Paul, that weird thing my heart was doing for a minute, my TSH level, mammograms, and other fun stuff).
title: good night, Paul

body:
*   The customer who wore the "Joe Malone" I was wondering about came back today! I asked her which scent it was (since you wise innernets said that yes, Jo Malone was A Thing and I Googled and it turns out they have Many Different Fragrances) and she said it was most likely the Orange Blossom, although she also wears the Blackberry & Bay sometimes and they're both "quite lovely." An e-mail to the fine folks at Jo Malone revealed that it was most likely the Orange Blossom, as that is one of two fragrances they make that has Lily of The Valley in, and while there are samples for the asking at various department stores, I hate those things like poison and there are ALSO samples for sale on the eBay. So I'm hot on the trail of the fragrance that I so loved! I've been looking for a perfume I can stand to wear for ages, and I think this may be it. VERY EXCITING!
*   We have a group coming in at work next week that is certain to try my nerves. Those of you who are friends of mine on The Facespace know what kind of group I mean. I am preemptively terrified!
*  Speaking of my nerves,  I just realized today that the various Feelings, Comma, Excessive, that I've been having have Gone Away, and I no longer have to count and/or touch things a certain number of times to feel okay about life. Three cheers for my being back on the Pristiq! Three cheers for The Ritz, which allows me to afford same!
*   Here is where I fell asleep mid-writing last night, rather early, and since then I have spent several hours on the bathroom floor in a cold sweat having chills and...other symptoms. That started around 3 a.m., and I stayed up and went to work anyway, but had to leave early. Management was very decent about the whole thing, dosing me with Angostura Bitters in ginger ale until that was no longer enough to keep me upright then being kind about my having to leave. I really do love my job, y'all! I am currently ensconced in my bed, bundled in quilts, with Isis lying next to me grumbling because I won't let her have any of the crystallized ginger I'm nibbling on (that stuff works wonders for nausea, in my experience). She's never had any before, but seems certain that pitbulls adore it.
*   A dear friend-inside-the-computer is going through something utterly vile, unfair, fucked-up, and awful. "I may as well be standing on a bare mountain top wearing wet copper armour and shrieking 'All gods are bastards!'" she lamented on the facespace chat, and if I believed in gods of any sort I'd be inclined to call that a true statement. I wish there was something that I or any of us could do for her, but there's not, and I imagine her poor husband is feeling exponentially more that way, as well as suffering alongside her in all of this while trying to care for her, and damn, the universe is an asshole for this one.
title: this and that and all gods are bastards

body:
*   Customers tip skinny waitresses better, but are less likely to take their menu recommendations.
*   Co-workers are nicer to fat waitresses in the ways that one wants one's coworkers to be nice.
*   A certain subset of co-workers tends to be nicer to skinny waitresses in the ways that one does NOT want one's co-workers to be nice if one is happily married and/or interested in maintaining a certain level of professionalism and decorum in the workplace.
*   Skinny waitresses can squeeze between cramped tables and chairs more easily.
*   Fat waitresses don't HAVE to squeeze between things, because people will move out of their way rather than assuming they'll fit.
*   People express more concern for skinny waitresses lifting and carrying things.

body:
*   LAYS IS MAKING SRIRACHA CHIPS AGAIN!!! Yes, potato chips go against all that I feel strongly about re: nutrition. No, that did not stop me from purchasing a bag. I just...SO GOOD. YAY!
*   What the actual fuck, Old Reader? We Are Not Amused. No blogs for a day or two??? Boooo...
*   It's Hotter's birthday! He occasionally drives me to contemplate homicide, but all in all he's still the best thing that ever happened to me and my boys, and I love the fucker. In honor of the day I did not unblock him on the Facespace or anything, because let's not get crazy, but I did bake him his choice of birthday cake (Ghirardelli chocolate, with chunks of same in the batter and dark chocolate frosting). Happy birthday, honey!

Which means that I've had to let things go in that area, which I do not like to do, because since I had a hunk of flesh the size of a NY strip steak excised from my right groin during MRSA-gate '07 things are kind of bikini-on-the-left, boy-shorts-on-the-right, if you catch my drift. Booooooo.

YAY, BEING ABLE TO AFFORD THINGS! Do y'all have any words of advice, horror stories, or caveats to share in that, er, regard?

body:
Today I decided I couldn't take it anymore; my feet were KILLING me after work and I actually had a pretty short shift. So I went to a specialty shoe store that caters to people with foot issues and threw myself on the mercy of a salesperson there. She measured my feet not only with the slide-y thing but also with a computer-assisted pad doo-dad that made a pressure map of my feet and charted my center of gravity, and HOLY SHIT THEY ARE AN ENTIRE SIZE BIGGER THAN THE LAST TIME I HAD THEM MEASURED. That was maybe three years ago? A hideous, horrible miracle has occurred, and the reason my shoes were effing my feet up is that they were too small.
   So I bought Paul a pair of Dansko nonslip "professional" clogs at RETAIL price in a brick-and-mortar store, my least favorite way to shop, because DESPERATION, and they cost so much I kind of feel like they ought to not only eliminate my foot pain but also give me a happy ending. After that my nerves were so shot* and I was so befuddled by the mall that I blew $20 at Teavana. Because apparently today I am yuppie scum. And Earl Grey Creme tea is delicious.
   How are all of YOU?
 
*   In fairness to Paul...eh, fuck him, let's go with IN ADDITION TO PAUL...The Bastard was a real bastard today. Feh!
title: a hideous, horrible miracle

body:
*   Today I started my day off like a winner by dry-swallowing an Aleve on the way to work and getting it stuck in my throat. That sucked. Then, because I'm a genius, I did the same thing on the way HOME from work. 
*   The account is overdrawn, and it is ALL my fault. I guess it's nice that it's not poverty-related this time but rather idiocy-related, but overdrafts suck either way. At least Hotter was nice about it (depending on various factors he'll either be really cool about me screwing up or make me feel like the world's biggest fucking idiot).
*   Home waxing kits. Let's talk about those for a minute! Since I was so pleased with my first experience with wax as a hair-removal method, I decided to try a home kit, thinking that maybe I could save myself some money in the future given that I think I'll be waxing my ladygarden for the forseeable future (MUCH less chafing during cardio than with shaving, and no blades involved--WIN!). Here I demonstrated at least SOME intelligence in that I elected to test the stuff on my legs and underarms rather than The Center Of The Universe. What I failed to take into account is that a) I have abnormally elastic skin due to connective tissue disease, b) I have abnormally thin blood because bleeding disorder + NSAIDs due to Paul and my back, and c) to prevent bruising, you need to hold skin taut prior to yanking off wax, and if you already have one arm in the air because you're waxing under it, that only leaves you one hand with which to remove the wax. I don't think I'll stop letting a professional wax Ms. Virginia any time soon!

Figure One: But at least my armpits are smoother than a baby's behind! Speaking of my brightest moments, who remembers the tree incident of 2010? Left a helluva scar. Good thing I'm not an armpit model!
*   A guest at work smelled so fantastic that I was moved to ask her what she was wearing. She replied with something frenchy-sounding that my brain wants to turn into "Joe Malone." Does anyone know what floral, vaguely lilies-of-the-valley-smelling women's perfume might sound like "Joe Malone?" I would very much like to buy a bottle of it if it's not outrageously expensive, and I hate that I felt so awkward about asking that I didn't get clarification, but apparently I am made of fail lately.
*   How are all of YOU?
title: fails, assorted

body:
*   The Bastard at work is really getting me down. Without going into specifics, this person has crossed the line of interpersonal decency and What Is Okay Per Society in big ways twice, in addition to doing little things that damage my income and serenity on a daily basis for WEEKS now. The income bit I can't get but so upset about, given that I am STILL earning twice as much at The Ritz as I ever did at The Hotel California, although don't get me wrong it IS galling. The other...well. If this was a case of "The Bastard's and MFA Mama's personalities clash" then I'd have some work to do to fine-tune things on my end and it would be frustrating, but manageable. This, however, is less a personality conflict and more a "MFA Mama has a very common Israeli last name and The Bastard is of a nationality that has been oppressing The Tribe for thousands of years, and started treating MFA Mama like crap only after finding out her last name" type of scenario. Which, well, there's nothing I can do about that (I suppose I could attempt to convince The Bastard I just married into that last name, but the fact of the matter is that I am actually of Jewish descent either way, and am not going to argue semantics with an anti-Semite). The Ritz's HR department is aware of the situation, and The Bastard has ongoing interpersonal disputes with just about everyone who works with him, not just me, which helps my case. I am told I have to "trust the process." So I am, because The Ritz is a great company full of caring and competent higher-ups, and I do believe that they are doing what they can, it just really sucks to have to work with The Bastard in the meantime because nobody likes to be the target of seething, senseless ancestral hatred.
*   With that in mind, and knowing that I would have today off, yesterday after work I purchased a bottle of organic tequila, a lime, and some Sriracha chips and Had A Moment after putting the kids to bed. I am pleased to report that following my moment I slept for nearly twelve hours, which I really needed. Yay, sleep!
*   We had big plans for a family picnic today at our favorite park, but it doesn't look like the weather is going to cooperate. We're going to have an indoor picnic instead and see if we can all agree on a movie to watch (I keep hearing about Despicable Me? The boys have seen it with their father but don't mind re-watching movies).
*   My back has been doing rather better (knock wood), perhaps as a result of the better shoes? The Danskos do NOT hurt Paul, although I'm a little "meh" on them as a result of how unforgiving they seem and the way they MOVE on your feet (which the salesperson assured me is What They Are Supposed To Do). I'm withholding judgment until I've broken them in and gotten used to walking in them--the store where I got them has a 30-day satisfaction guarantee wherein you can return shoes for store credit, so if I decide to hate them I haven't just thrown away More Than I Have Ever Spent On Shoes, which is nice.
*   I've been lurking on eBay for a bit in search of smaller workout clothes (if you don't mind pre-owned, you can get the fancy moisture-wicking, non-chafing, brand-name workout clothing on eBay for what you'd pay for new, lower-quality stuff at a big box store, and I've found that chafing is an issue for me with the cheaper, low-tech gear with the amount of time I spend on the elliptical daily) (currently about 90 minutes--don't judge me, it's my way of coping with stress), and ran across something that has boggled my mind. Did you know that there are workout shorts for lady-persons with something called "inseam compression" built in? I find this worrisome and am hesitant to Google, but at the same time I'm pretty curious as to the "why" of it all (a Twitter friend suggested masochism as a reason for this feature). I don't have the slightest desire to compress my inseam. Do any of you know what the deal is with this?
*   Isis is deliriously happy to have gotten to spend so much time wallowing in bed with me. She's grinning like a fool.
*   How are all of YOU?
title: tequila

body:
*   My back and foot continue to make life less fun than it could be...my back has gotten worse again after recovering almost completely (the hell, back?), and Paul is troublesome still even though the new shoes are a huge improvement. I added a pair of gel insoles to them this morning, which cause my right foot to occasionally make the type of moistly squelchy sound you'd expect to hear on a blooper roll from a porn film. I am not a fan of that sound, although the inserts themselves are pretty comfortable.
*   The contrast between my mood today (The Bastard is off, and it was just me and the person who trained me working today; we make a good team and The Trainer's lack of Bastardry is delightful) after work and yesterday prompted Hotter to inform me that I need to not let The Bastard get to me. "Because then you bring your bad mood home with you. LEAVE WORK AT WORK." I sarcastically said I supposed he'd been GREAT at that (Hotter is a complainer by nature and used to have quite a temper so I was banking on him having sucked at it). He said he had, actually, mostly because he would drink heavily each night after work (Hotter used to be a totally different person before his transplants and stroke, and not necessarily one I would have liked). So I'm still open to input on how better to relax (besides keep upping my workouts--I'm already over the fifty-mile mark per week and don't think I can go up any further without it being ridiculous how long I spend at the gym each day and/or making my clothes fit funny--as it is I could wear a 6 in the waist but am sticking with an 8 because of my thighs) (I also do yoga two to four times per week, just throwing that out there as something I'm already doing).
*   GROCERIES! Man oh man, y'all, I used to HATE the grocery store, because I was constantly counting in my head, weighing whether to get this or this, if I buy that x will be happy but y won't eat it and then what, etc. Now I can get something everyone will eat, and buy things just because they look good and I think we might like to try them. Few things make me happier than bringing home a new kind of fruit or cheese for the boys to try. There is nothing like cutting open a perfect ripe apricot, pulling the pit out of it, and placing one half in each of Little Child's wee dimpled paws and seeing his face light up when he tastes it. We've discovered that everyone likes apricots, honeyloupes, and plums. Little Child and Big Child like feta, but only the plain kind; Big Child enjoys the herb-and-oil kind from the olive bar as much as I do but Little Child won't touch the stuff. Middle Child shares my love of all things spicy (Little Child won't touch spicy and Big Child will, but only up to a point). Hotter remains a slut for fancy coffee. Life is good.
title: ouch and grr and GROCERIES

body:
*   I have officially had my first Bad Day At The Ritz. It's not The Ritz's fault, though--more a case of The Bastard Is A Bastard. And that's all I'll say about that, except that as with everything else at The Ritz I was very impressed with their handling of said Bastardry. The Bastard aside, it really is just SUCH a great place to work!
*   Tomorrow is another day. I left my feelings on the elliptical (well, more like "I courteously wiped my feelings OFF the elliptical before leaving the YMCA") and am not going to let The Bastard get me down. I am kind of turning into a workout-junkie, y'all. Endorphins: they're pretty great.
*   Not only is tomorrow Another Day, it's PAYDAY! Since I am all about spoiling myself, in addition to getting The MFA Beater inspected and the extraneous hairs ripped from my body, I think I'll switch back to Pristiq. Effexor is good at keeping me from being panicky and tearful, but I'm having some issues with having to turn pages in books three times instead of just once and touch cans a certain number of times before choosing one off a shelf and check my alarm eleventy-seven times before bed. And also I've found that it's kind of...hard to, er...find my own private Idaho lately, if you know what I mean. A dose increase might solve the former, but it would probably make the latter worse, and while neither of these things are insurmountable issues (I mean, I can still do my job and, ah, arrive at my final destination), now that I am making a decent living and won't have to deprive anyone in the house of any necessities in order to get The Good Stuff, I think I'll go ahead and treat myself to the drug that works better for me with fewer side effects in a few days when my current bottle of Effexor runs out.
*   Lefty is back in jail, apparently. I am not entirely certain what-all he did. There is definitely a DUI involved, but also another acronym that Google has never heard of? Oh, Lefty.
*   Speaking of repeat offenders, Bad Ear feels a little funny and is doing that "speaker with torn paper" buzzing thing with sound a little. I'm not willing to say it's infected again quite yet, but if it's worse tomorrow I think I'll be visiting Urgent Care after work. Sigh.
*   That's about all that's going on in my happily-boring-these-days little world. How are all of YOU? I really do want to know.
title: Thursday afternoon bullets

body:
*   I just made turkey salad with some leftover Thanksgiving turkey, and OMG, it was SO GOOD! Big Child, Middly, and I had the turkey salad for lunch; it was the first time Middly has ever willingly eaten anything of the sort (nobody tell him about the emm-aye-why-oh). Yay! There's nothing left on that poor bird but the wings and enough scraps for soup, and I'm already fantasizing about eating the wings later (I'm the only person in the house who enjoys parts of the turkey other than the breast, and have been feasting as a result). Man, I love Thanksgiving turkey!
*   Know who else loves Thanksgiving leftovers? Skeeter. Hotter heated up slices of ham in some chicken broth for last night's dinner, and Skeeter found the pan and drank the broth. He then helped himself to both pumpkin and pecan pie all sneaky-like, and was shockingly bloated for the rest of the evening:
Figure One: I felt so bad for him! He was utterly unrepentant, and still tried to mug me for my bowl of Corn Chex shortly after this photo was taken.
*   Tomorrow I get to meet a friend and co-worker at Temp Agency #2, whose acquaintance I made through this humble blog. Since the whole Stalky debacle I've been leery of meeting any further innernet people (well, with the exception of Hotter I guess, HA!), but C is A Good Egg and I'm looking forward to visiting with her. Yay!
*   Because it can't ALL be good food, good friends, and funnies at the expense of the stupid gluttonous cat, I'm 90% certain the XY has lost his job. E-mails to his work address bounce, his work cell and landline are no longer his, and this would certainly explain his recent downward spiral in mental health and threats to stop paying the child support "because you are unreasonable about visitation" (meaning I've asked him to start returning the children on time and stop peeing in my yard). Oh, and the call I got from MFA Dentist's office asking if I knew why their claims for the boys' most recent cleanings and checkups had been rejected. Oyyy. The children were telling me their father spent $2,000 on electronics during visitation on Black Friday (they volunteered the information in the context of telling me what great deals he had told them he'd gotten--I do not ask them questions about their time with their father because that's not fair to them), so I'm guessing the insurance checks from his "Jewish lightning" housefire have come in?  Hopefully he saves a little something back to pay child support...that's due today and I'm really nervous. If he makes good on his threat to stop paying it'll be a grim holiday season here, and, well, a grim forseeable future. Because to even complain to a judge about lack of child support you have to hire a lawyer, and if I'm trying to feed everyone and make rent without child support I'm not going to be able to afford one. HO HO HO! MERRRRY FUCK-YOU!
*   On the bright side I didn't hear any negative feedback at work from my failed good deed of yesterday. So that's good at least.
*   How are all of YOU?
title: bullet salad

body:
Today I'm just...bleh. My back is still terrible, horrible, awful. The XY is refusing to provide me with his new health insurance information. I managed to eff up frozen pizza at dinnertime (THE HELL?). Hotter informed me that I am not myself lately and wanted to know what my problem was.* At one point I felt really defeated by it all and cried a little.
   Hopefully tomorrow is better.
 
*   My problem is nerve pain, lots of it, and fear that this will eff up my ability to keep doing the job that I enjoy so much and that has been so wonderful for our family. I try not to let this turn me into a raging bitch, and most of the time I think I do a pretty good job, but right before Hotter was moved to ask me this question he asked me why I was eating something, and I said "because I'm hungry," and he gave me A Look and said "no you're not." Then he wanted to know when I'll be off the prednisone, and the answer to that was "two days ago." I can be a fat bitch all by myself without any pharmaceutical help, apparently. I can also hate myself for it just fine without any help from him, though. I think in some fucked-up brain-damaged way he was trying to be helpful, but NO, BAD, WRONG.
title: bummed

body:
Today was PAYDAY AT THE RITZ! And my Direct Deposit kicked in a pay cycle earlier than predicted, which was nice. I was thrilled with my paycheck, and it included three days of "shadowing" others for minimum wage, so the NEXT one should be even MORE stupendous (especially considering that it will include two weeks with only one day off apiece due to busy-busy things happening at work). The bills are paid, the MFA Beater is inspected (IT PASSED!) and has a full tank of gas, and I walked into the grocery store after work like fucking ROYALTY and bought absolutely EVERYTHING we needed without running a tally as I went for the first time in MANY, MANY MOONS (and I still had enough left over to send a friend who is unemployed and struggling $25 without it causing us any undue hardship, because I have had people do that for me and I know how great a little unexpected windfall can be when you haz The Poor). It's pretty much the best feeling ever! The fridge, freezer, and pantry are stuffed, every type of animal in the house has food and treats, and Isis will be dining on a marked-down-about-to-expire hunk of blade steak (it was two bucks, I haven't TOTALLY lost my mind) this evening.
   Also, I have tomorrow off and will be taking Little Child to pick out a twin mattress set, because while it may not be fast enough to please the XY, the boy IS growing, and if he stretches out in his toddler bed and points his toes he can touch his head and feet to the top and bottom. So I got the new job just in time :)
   How are all of you?
title: happy Friday, y'all

body:
* My back has gone from bad to worse. It hurts all the time now. Even if I take Vicodin AND naproxen, and lie down. I don't know what to do with that.

* There has been great ugliness with The XY. I think he decided to go off his meds and go crazy for the holidays. I hate that for my kids, and also for myself, because I hate going to court, and there'll be at least one court date in the next few weeks (criminal, not civil) that I will have to attend.

* Hotter is, I think, feeling the strain of the above, because he is...not himself. I can only conclude, based on what he's said, that he is done with me (because some things you do not say to someone you want to continue to have dealings with). I was already so damn stressed out and upset that I can't even begin to process that, however, so I'm just hitting pause on Hotter and trying to spend all of my waking hours at work.

* As if all of THAT wasn't enough, I stupidly glutenated myself, and feel like I swallowed an angry badger whole.

* How are all of you?

Sent from The Precious
title: sucking

body:
*   I really don't care for morning yoga. I am achy and stiff in the mornings, regardless of what I have or haven't done the day before. I'd say it's hell getting old but I've been that way since I was a teenager. This morning I went to morning yoga anyway, because I read that you're not supposed to hit the gym for at least twelve hours after getting a Brazilian, and it was one of those practices where I stood, laid, sat, and twisted on my mat hating every damn second of it (yep, that happens, albeit rarely). But as the instructor pointed out to someone who was new to the class, "yoga is not just exercise, we come here to figure things out, and while pain means stop what you're doing, discomfort is an opportunity to practice the ways in which you handle stress." 
*   I then took Little Child to pick out a mattress. It's hilarious how different my children are. It once infamously took Big Child an hour and a half and a fit of tears to pick out a t-shirt for his birthday. Little Child walked into the mattress factory, glanced dispassionately through the showroom windows into the factory itself, and asked the salesman to show him the different floor models and whether he'd need to remove his shoes before trying them. He laid on each one for about 1.5 seconds, pointed to the most expensive model there, and said "I'd like that one, please, it's the most comfortable one." He then requested that I take him to Subway and get him a turkey and veggie sub on whole wheat to eat while we waited for his father (see below). Bless his cotton socks! He's really not a brat, but just very aware of what he wants in the manner of a wee little opinionated geezer and I think it's adorable. Plus I STILL have not gotten tired of watching that boy eat (if you're new to these parts, Little Child spent the first five years of his life being fed via g-tube and had to learn to eat with his mouth).
*   The XY was kind enough to transport the mattress set for me with his truck. I don't know what to say about that except that maybe he has a brain tumor.
*   I then headed to the spa to get a Brazilian wax. Quote of the day: "wow, you have some of the deepest-rooted hair I've ever seen!" Despite that, I did not find the process to be nearly as bad as most of you said or speculated it would be! The lone voice of reason was k, who said that on a scale of 0-OMG DON'T DO IT the pain was a 1.5. I'd mayyybe go as far as to rate it a 3 during the actual ripping itself, but that takes all of a second or so per strip. I'll definitely be doing that again, finances permitting, especially if it results in less chafing during my daily cardio!
*   Number of times I've slapped Hotter's hands since getting home an hour ago: 3 (you have to wait to do THAT until the follicles have closed, at least ten hours apparently, or you risk a skin infection)
*   Speaking of risk, Lefty...oy. Those of you I know on the Facespace have seen the articles about it, but I can't EVEN share the most outlandish and, in parts, hilarious tale of his offense on here without it being identifying by way of Lefty>Hotter>me because what he ACTUALLY did was that wild and ridiculous. I think he'll ultimately be convicted of a handful of felonies (possibly including attempted murder if the judge is unamused with him per a lawyer-friend of mine) and go away for A Long Time. Which, well, GOOD. I hope he stays in jail at least until my MIL passes, as awful as that sounds to say, because she is pathologically unable to set boundaries with him and he robs her blind.
*   How are all of YOU?
title: day-off boogaloo

body:
For no apparent reason, I have this everpresent sense of mild foreboding going on. It may be connected to Lefty's recent shenanigans and Hotter's having talked to his mother recently (typically when he lashes out at me with some kind of pointless nonsensical nastiness it's after speaking to his family, which he doesn't do very often but did a couple of days ago, and/or after something major goes down with Lefty), but I'm not sure. Possibly it's something to do with our being broke for a couple of days until the first of the month (not, I should clarify, "OMG BROKE" or anything, but rather an easy, pantry- and gas-tank full, no immediate needs kind of "just no great amount sitting in the bank account currently" broke that maybe just reminds me of worse kinds of broke we've been in the not-too-distant past?). I don't THINK I've been glutenated, although the combination of my current unusual achiness (my lower back is VERY unhappy) and the persistent bad mood makes me wonder. It may even have to do with my having recently been on steroids, or the fact that Effexor doesn't work quite as well as Pristiq.
   Whatever this is, my back hurts and I'm cranky and both of those things need to stop ASAP because life is pretty damned good over here for the most part and I'd prefer to go back to reveling in that.
title: foreboding

body:
You know how when you were a kid and you'd break your arm for like, the fifth or sixth time and be crying about it, and your dad would offer to smash one of your toes with a hammer to take your mind off it and laugh like it was as funny as the first time he'd made you that offer, except that only he had found it funny then, and probably because he was high? No? Just me?
   Aaaaanyway, my back is feeling much better, or maybe it just SEEMS that way because my foot is really sore and suddenly deformed. 

Figure One: Yes, I photo-edited my foot. I've never photo-edited my FACE, but then I don't have my father's face and I have his feet EXACTLY. I originally posted this photo on the Facespace, unedited, from The Precious, and then one of my friends pointed out how unfortunate-looking my feet are, because my friends are dicks. Dicks who all seem to think I have gout. Then I opened up the photo from my laptop and wanted to die.
   I seriously doubt it's gout (heh). Because I eat almost none of the things on the "stuff to avoid" list for gout, and the ones I do eat I eat rarely and in small amounts. Also, I get plenty of Vitamin C (I take it daily as studies have shown that doing so may help prevent degenerative changes in my type of connective tissue disease). But I suppose it's possible, as I'm a lifelong outlier. If it's not gout I think it's most likely a bunion, which wouldn't make a ton of sense either (I don't wear heels and while I have loose joints and a job that requires me to be constantly on my feet, that's not a new thing), but who the hell knows.
   In other news, my new work pants arrived today (arrived because I buy all of my clothes second-hand from eBay). I've been wearing the last pair of Dickies I bought for work at the Hotel California all this time, even though they were already too big when I got the job at The Ritz, because money. They were size 12s, and I remember being super-happy when I bought them, because that was a size down. My new pair are 8s. They're too big. The good news is, they're only a size or two too big, so I'll still look way less ridiculous than I have in recent weeks (it actually wasn't THAT bad, since I wear a bistro-length apron as part of my work uniform--I gathered the "pleats" at the front, secured them with a belt, and tied my apron over the whole shebang--STEALTHY). So I'm looking forward to being considerably less lumpy about the waist tomorrow at work.
   And finally: you know you've worked too many days straight when you get to your car after a shift and go to unlock it by swiping your Micros card down the crack of the door (I didn't actually stick it in--I said stick it in--but I did go so far as to hold it out toward the Beater and stare blankly, and that's bad enough).
   That's all the news from here. How are all of YOU?
title: ouch some more

body:
I know the official Day Of Thanks has already passed, and maybe y'all are full up on the thankful, but I am Having A Moment over here.
   I could have said that today was a bad day, given that I woke up in such excruciating back pain as to make ADLs (activities of daily living, for those of you fortunate enough not to know what those are) challenging, and my lunch-date canceled on me due to sickness on her part (feel better, friend C!), but it's really not. I have a warm, safe home. Currently said home is filled with the delicious smell of food my husband and I cooked together for the three healthy, happy children doing homework around the kitchen table, and there are some entitled housepets at my feet, and for all that my back is fucking killing me I can't be mad at the universe right now.
   Today I am thankful for friends courteous enough not to expose my respiratorily-compromised arse to further illness, a husband who is willing to do the heavy lifting when my back is messed up, and a home with a fully-stocked pantry and plenty of love to go around. For all that it's occasionally tough as hell, this really is my favorite life :)
 
P.S. I am also thankful that the XY did, in fact, pay the child support that was due yesterday, and I have finished the holiday shopping. The MFA Children and Hotter will be very happy with their gifts, I think, and I scored myself a pair of those gloves that allow you to use a touchscreen that were deeply discounted for "Cyber Monday," so yay!
title: thankful

body:
I have Done Something To My Back and It Is Bad. That said, it's just acting up in the way it has acted up periodically since I broke it over twenty years ago. This is miserable, but it follows a predictable course, and will likely run its course over the next week or two and leave me none the worse for wear. In the meantime, living at a seven on the infamous pain scale saps the joy out of life, alas.
   I think I got glutenated, also (and perhaps related?). My weight is up five pounds, and it would explain the foreboding out of nowhere. Stupid gluten.
   This too shall pass.
title: back, bloat, gluten

body: Have any of y'all tried ordering from AngelFoodMinistries before?   Money continues to suck here and we're going to give them a shot; there's a distribution site about ten minutes away from Casa MFA.  I found and verified a coupon code ("ZOOMFEEDBACK") good for 10% off, and between that and using my PayPal debit card (which gives 1% cashback) to order our box online, we can get the following for $26.73:1.5 lbs NY Strip Steaks1.5 lbs Pork Chops 28 oz Salisbury Steak w/gravy entree1 lb. Lean Ground Beef1.5 lbs Breaded Chicken Breast Chunks1 lb Turkey & Pork Sausage1 lb Frozen Carrots1 lb Frozen Corn1 lb French Cut Green Beans1 lb Rice1 lb Pasta1 25-oz Jar of Marinara Sauce3 lbs Fresh Baking Potatoes1 Dozen Eggs32 oz Milk (shelf-stable)and a mystery "Dessert Item"   So far, aside from the fact that we have to go to a church to pick up our order, and thus risk bursting into flames when we walk inside, this seems to be made of win.  I'm not wild about pork (partly for health reasons and partly I think it's some kind of ancestral memory because the stuff just skeeves me out although I don't dislike the taste), but Hotter and the kids love it and it certainly won't kill us to have it twice in a month.  Let me know if y'all are interested in seeing pictures of what we get when we pick it up in a week!
title: this could be great or terrible; either way you'll hear about it I'm sure

body:
So Little Child and I were at the Post Office mailing a package today and my mailman (okay, he's no longer my "carrier" but rather a manager of some sort--still, he used to come to the door almost daily between e-Bay purchases and certified letters of legal suing-ness last year and the running joke was that he would never recognize me fully dressed...for some reason Hotter doesn't like "Mr. Aeropostale" as much as I do but he's a nice guy who won my eternal friendship for delivering my mail one day in a "How many licks would it take?" t-shirt) saw us in line and bellowed: "MFA Mama!  Your chickens are here!" then raced back into the back of the building.   Cue everyone in the (packed) Post Office to start asking each other and me whether he really said chickens because chickens?  Really?  In the mail?   Really.  Mr. Aeropostale emerged, blushing, with a peeping box.  A loudly peeping box, with the peeps amplified as the box entered the lobby area, escalating in urgency as if the motion had awakened the chicks.  "Sign here please," said my clearly mortified former mail carrier, and y'all I couldn't help it, I just busted out laughing.  I died.     A couple of old ladies were very amused as well.  Mr. Aeropostale turned magenta.  Little Child observed that the birds were singing "extra-loud" today (he didn't know what was in the box, as the My Pet Chicken folks advise that you either let the chickens be a surprise entirely or else let the number of chickens be a surprise with children and ferchrissake don't open the box in front of them just in case) (okay I paraphrased a little but they really do warn you about that and it's brilliant of them to think of because...well, if there had been any loss in transit...yeah).  I signed for my chickens, took my peeping box and my oblivious pre-schooler, and fled the scene.   So we need names, people.  Six of them, because I am pleased to report that no peeps expired during their epic journey from Connecticut to Ourstate (which is in the South, so quite a journey).  They are Barred Plymouth Rocks, so they'll look like this when they grow up.  Right now they look like this:
  Figure One: All together now: awwww.  Now stop, because she'd eat you in your sleep if she could.
title: how to pick up chicks at the Post Office

body: Tonight was the XY's make-up dinner visitation (he canceled yesterday, and skipped his last weekend as well so hadn't seen the MFA Children in quite a while). He was two hours late and brought the children back half an hour early, meaning that he only took ninety minutes of the time he has gotten with the MFA Children for the past two weeks. Between being upset about Not Following The Routine, eating dinner late, and being returned early like three hot potatoes, the boys were not their most fabulous selves when they got home. I hustled the younger two MFA Children into the tub while Big Child worked on his homework, which he kept not doing, electing instead to yell the odd contribution to the conversation I was trying to have with the younger ones or ask at a bellow for us to repeat ourselves.    Big Child not only has both his parents' ADD, but is also the nosiest child alive and a world-class buttinski who can't help but interject his two cents, by force if necessary, whether they are wanted or not. Because I was refereeing a bathtub turf-war and, as usual, lecturing people about what not to do with their penises, the best I could do was bellow back dire threats as to what I would do if Big Child didn't get his danged homework done by the time I was done in the bathroom.   When I brought the (scrubbed, clothed) younger two boys out into the family room, Hotter had found my mouthguard (which costs as much as a month and half of my health insurance, is not covered under same, and had been missing for a couple of weeks to my detriment), and I thanked him profusely.    "WHAT ARE YOU SAYING THANK YOU TO HOTTER FOR AND WHAT WAS IN THE FRUIT BOWL? WHAT DID YOU SAY???" Big Child wanted to know, from the dining-room table where he was still not done with his homework.   "I SAID IF YOU ARE NOT DONE WITH YOUR HOMEWORK I AM GOING TO THROW A CLOT, THAT IS WHAT I SAID!" I snapped.   "What's 'throw a clot' mean? Like take a blood clot out of your body and throw it at me?"   I sighed. "No honey, like have a stroke, now do y--"   "COOL THEN YOUR FACE WILL GET ALL DROOPY AND YOU'LL ONLY BE ABLE TO KILL ME WITH ONE ARM!"   Hotter clapped a hand over his mouth and ducked into the laundry room. I sighed. "Well, if I really did have a stroke, then yeah, pretty much. How'd you know that anyway?"   "Because I saw a poster last time we were at the emergency room. It said you have act F.A.S.T. and look for a drooping face, one arm going haywire, something messed up with the way the person speaks, then save time if they flunk the test by calling 9-1-1."   "Yes, with strokes that is exactly what you have to do."   "So you SEE," Big Child gloated, "you're always saying how nosy I am but my being nosy and reading that poster could end up saving your life!"   "Or you could just finish your homework so I don't throw a clot in the first place," I grumbled, but I was kind of proud of the little bugger.   All threats, hyperbole, and kids-say-the-darnedest things stories aside, would you know how to tell if a loved one was having a stroke? My father and husband are both survivors. Click here for how to act F.A.S.T. and save a life.
title: F.A.S.T.

body:
I slept in this morning, which was awesome. I really needed to catch up on sleep, and nine and a half months in it is STILL a treat having a second adult in the house who is able and willing to wrangle small boys while Mama is lazy!   What was considerably LESS awesome was realizing that I'd gotten up twelve minutes before the end of pickup hour at our local Angel Food Ministries distribution site and thinking I'd just blown over eighty dollars in grocery money. If be "less awesome" you mean "totally took ten years off my life." Fortunately I can get there in six minutes, and while the volunteers may have been traumatized by seeing me greasy-faced and braless, they graciously held the order (Hotter called ahead) and even asked me if I'd like a few extra items that hadn't been claimed (does the Pope eat kittens?). So I came home with this:
 Figure One: The bean burritos will come in handy if the boys act up; lately I actually threatened to fart on some heads. Yeah.and this:
 Figure Two: These look much nicer than what is pictured; they're restaurant-style chicken tenders, like you would expect to get as an appetizer at Applebee's or T.G.I. Friday's, the kind of varying widths and thicknesses with the thick breading. Mmm...and this:
  Figure Three: We ended up getting the second combination pictured.   I actually lucked out, in that since a couple of people did NOT make it in time, the volunteers asked if anyone there wanted some extra items that wouldn't fit in the church freezer. So I also got a frozen Tombstone-sized supreme pizza, a two-pound packet of frozen smoked sausages, a one-pound bag of frozen corn, and a whole frozen chicken for free!   I can't say enough good things about Angel Food Ministries, y'all, I really can't. Money is very tight here right now what with the dog's mange-related vet bills on top of Hotter's immunosuppressant meds (yes, he has Medicare, which is awesome, but we pay twenty percent of the cost of transplant-related prescription drugs out of pocket and that's still a lot) and our usual household expenses, and I haven't gotten paid yet for the contract writing-type work I'm doing (the check's not late or anything, but the client pays portions of the contract amount as I complete the work and I just finished a big chunk of stuff).    This is pretty much our groceries for the month, aside from stuff like milk, bread, sammich components, condiments, and school snack items, and as I've mentioned before it's better-quality stuff than you generally get by doing The Grocery Game, The Home Version (yes, I have done a free trial of The Grocery Game proper, and it's a really cool service but I can do just as well without it--if you're new to poverty or not actually poor but just trying to save money I'd recommend it, bargain-hunting is just second nature to me since I grew up poor and did the single mother with deadbeat ex-husband thing for a while). I did run into my first taste of evangelism this month at the AFM host site, but they weren't tacky about it, just said something casually as I was standing there waiting on the volunteers to get my order together, and dropped it gracefully when I said we were non-practicing Jews (and in fact when they offered me the extra items the lady took that into account and gave me a couple of options, pointing out that the pizza toppings contained some pork, and that was thoughtful of her). I don't mind that kind of thing, as I realize that evangelism is part of some faiths; it's the kind who are pushy and/or ad hominem about other belief systems (or my lack thereof) who make me twitchy. In fact, I kind of wish the kids had been with me because that would've been a nice teachable moment, but oh well.   How are all of YOU this lovely weekend?
title: September AFM pickup

body:
This is exactly the kind of thing my children won't want to read about themselves on the innernet, and so therefore I would like to refer all of you to my About page before I tell this story. I'm having to manually install it, through a series of horrific and yet increasingly tedious lectures, such as:   Don't

I called the boys and Hotter into the dining room for a family meeting and when the MFA Children were all seated and Hotter was standing next to me with his arms crossed, prepared to nod emphatically, I imparted to my children the following henceforth unknown-to-them piece of information:   Every time I have to say the word penis in teaching you how to act, Grandma XY kills and eats an extra kitten!   * Okay. Now boys? If you're reading this? And some kid on the bus asks you

*   I am busy with work-stuff, and also intermittently sick. It's like a cold that comes and goes? I'm starting to suspect allergies.*   Meanwhile both Big Child and MFA Puppy are losing baby teeth, and growing adult ones, starting with the top front two. So far both their mouths are looking too big for the remaining baby teeth, and both their new adult front teeth look like giant chiclets next to the surrounding baby teeth:
 Figure One: Teefs. Or lack thereof. Ha! And yes, Big Child is nine and should have done this already but our genetic connective tissue disease causes delayed dentition. Fancy!*   In between being chained to my keyboard and hacking up a lung, I've been working outside a lot (Hotter too!). *   I got in a fight with a tree (I climbed partway up and hacked a branch off neglecting to notice that my underarm was holding down the part still attached, which then flew upward while digging into my flesh):
 Figure Two: This hurts more than you'd think. That's okay though, I got out the clippers and was all "HAPPY ARBOR DAY, MOTHERFUCKER!" So the tree paid too.*   Hotter and I also sorely tested our marriage assembled a 7x12-foot chain link enclosure together for the chickens. This thing was a bad project for two people who "don't work well with others" to tackle together designed by morons. 

 Figure Three: This started out as a big box containing a bunch of poles, a roll of chain-link "fabric" and a couple of bags of mounting hardware. Divorce attorneys not included.The too-effing-small tarp for the top and bag of flimsy zipties for that came separately as well. Also you can't really tell from the picture, but there is chain link above where the roof of the coop meets up with the open doorway so the chickens can't get out and nothing else can get in. *   All sniping and pot-shots aside, I really felt bad for Hotter. He knows a lot more about putting things together and using tools than I do, but since he had a stroke shortly after his transplants I am the physically stronger and more mechanically-inclined one of us. This probably makes it painful for him to try and assist me and my ADD in assembling things because I go off half-cocked and proceed to kill myself doing things wrong and he knows exactly where I'm screwing up but can't take over. Plus apparently I don't take feedback well in the heat of the moment. Things were said by both of us, there was a lot of "your mom" smack-talk, and we can't even have make-up sex on the dining room table because the XY canceled his visitation on short notice AGAIN (third time in a row, not that I'm counting, oh, wait...). Boo.*   At least the chickens seem a lot happier:
  Figure Four: They're so thrilled with the extra room that maybe they'll even lay some damn eggs!*   The dog is getting huge. Hotter still picks her up in his arms sometimes but now she looks like a freaking goat that he's carrying around. Or possibly a calf?
 Figure Five: Hey man, nice goat.

body:
You know how sometimes when you're deathly ill, you have to go out in public whether you like it or not because you're out of FOOD, and you maybe just throw a sweatshirt on over a pair of scrub pants from Local Teaching Hospital and call it good because you're just going half a mile to the Kroger? Maybe y'all don't do this. Good for you! I do, because I have ceased to care what the cashiers there think of me (although when we had WIC and food stamps I always made a point of dressing up and doing my hair because...well I guess I wanted to avoid snap judgments? Now that I'm working and paying my own way, however, it's somehow more okay with me to look like a walking Southern stereotype) (that doesn't make a whole lot of sense, but welcome to my brain when I have a fever and am mixing over-the-counter uppers and downers).
   ANNNNNYWAY.
   I should've known better than to tape a metaphorical "kick-me" sign to my back like that, because naturally after I bought a loaf of bread (yes, I'm THAT SICK--we haven't eaten store-bought bread in ages and the MFA Children are making no attempts to hide their disdain) the MFA Minivan wouldn't effing start. I turned the key a second and a third time, all hopeful-like, but got nothing except the impotent clicking of the starter. Eff.
   Fortunately I carry an extra-long set of jumper cables at all times, because yes, I have AAA but that's just a dumb use of one of the service calls from the account and I drive a teenaged vehicle with a battery older than at least one of my children. I had no trouble finding a nice young clerk to come out and give me a jump, which worked beautifully on the first try, so it's just the battery, which is good news (beats the starter or the alternator) but not GREAT news in that I think it's been fading lately and probably I need a new one and the MFA Minivan alREADY needs a new headlight and probably won't get it until Febuary or so (I just don't drive the thing at night).
   I see how it is, Universe. Hate to burst your bubble, but I'm already hating life and cursing the holidays, so you didn't really bring me down much (not that I'm suggesting you get smite-happy, just saying you'd be wasting more of both our time if you did). Now if you'll excuse me, the MFA Minivan has been out in the driveway for a while running and THINKING ABOUT WHAT IT DID and I'm going to de-ice it the rest of the way since it's good and warmed up anyway.
title: I see how it is
