So this morning Big Child informed me that Middle Child had a terrible headache, and then Middle Child came barrelling down the hall with flushed cheeks moaning "I GOTTA FROW UP, I GOTTA FROW UP!" Which: a) CRAP and b) aw, bless, Big Child NEVER made it to the facilities to throw up at Middly's age so it makes me love Middly extra-much that he does. Also, he only lets me snuggle him when he's sick, and while I'd rather he was healthy it's nice to get some cuddles in.
   Big Child and Little Child were fine, so Hotter got their breakfast and picked their clothes out while I rubbed Middle Child's back until he stopped heaving (this took a while--the poor kid is almost never sick but when he is it's brutal), and got their shoes on while I gave Midde Child a dose of Zofran (which we always have plenty of in this house due to two people with gastroparesis) and some Tylenol and installed him in a blanket-nest in the recliner. When a child here is truly sick (as in, too sick to want to play games or watch a movie) I drape their bedspread over their resting-spot of choice and make a nice "nest," which I think makes them feel cared-for and comfy but ALSO protects my leather furniture (win!), and Middle Child has been asleep since I tucked him in almost three hours ago. I've found that it's usually best to let Middle Child sleep things off, because he's pretty much immune to Zofran (yes, I gave him some anyway, because I suppose it could always be worse if I didn't, but he's the only one here who doesn't stop barfing after a dose of that stuff) and he's got some time before we need to worry about dehydration. I think Little Child has made me a much more relaxed parent to sick children; not only can I calculate the fluid volume a child needs by weight to avoid an IV (less than you might think), but I can also judge when a kid is nowhere near needing an IV and it's okay to leave them the eff alone and Middle Child is currently safe to leave the eff alone.
   But now I have a headache, and Hotter (who went back to bed after the school-bound boys left) is rather warm. Effff.

Yesterday I was outside trying to chicken-proof the winter garden and talking to Hotter about the compost pile (I was saying how I wished I still had access to fresh horse manure, or else cow, since it could compost all winter before I'd need to fertilize the beds next spring), when I heard the timer go off through an open window. So I sent Hotter inside to take a pie out of the oven for me, and while he was doing that I heard a loud exhalation that sounded equine in nature, looked up, and there was the Old Spice man.
   Okay, so it wasn't actually him but it was a good-looking black dude on a horse and instead of saying "I'm on a horse" he asked me what kind of chickens those were (the MFA Flock was out foraging). Apparently dude's grandma lives at the end of the dirt road off our street, and the local fire station lets him park his trailer and ride from there, and I was so excited to see a horse (I miss my horses, y'all) that I asked if I could run in and get my kids.
   The children were impressed with the horse, and the guy rode into our driveway and unclipped the bit from his trail bridle so we could give the horse some apples and carrots (except for Middle Child, who after getting bitten by a horse over at the XY's is afraid to feed them), and the horse immediately took an ENORMOUS crap in my driveway.
   I think that's probably the only time the guy who owned the horse has ever seen someone be tickled to death that his horse crapped on their property. I mean yeah, I wanted some manure for the compost pile, but pretty much the last words out of my mouth had been to wish for horse manure. Wow.
   So yeah, I'm going to have great compost next year, but it's too bad I didn't wish for a new minivan.

body:
Hotter and I called the Post Office bright and early the moment the boys were off to school, and lo! Paul the rooster had arrived on the early truck. Apparently there was ice on the wings in Oakland (Paul is a West Coast bird, which explains why my hens are all out there throwing gang signs) and the USPS won't fly live animals if it's that cold (which makes sense) so he was delayed. The West Coast ground crew reports that the Post Office here called them at 4:45 Pacific Time to report that Paul had arrived and they were getting ready to deliver him, which is at least half a damn lie, because Hotter and I had to go and pick him up, but oh well. We didn't want the poor bird sitting around the Post Office all day waiting for the mailman to bring him!
   When we got to the Post Office everything was all nice and normal for about two minutes, then--
COCK-A-DOODLE-DOO!
   Excellent! Mr. Aeropostale, who had been so mortified when my Barred Rock chicks came in last year, came out to the counter and I greeted him with "You finally found my cock!" He blushed deepest magenta, but admitted that "we've been making those jokes all morning!" While I signed for the package, Paul continued crowing his head off, and it echoed around the Post Office impressively. All of the employees seemed pretty tickled and said that Paul was very pretty and seemed friendly.
   This is the only picture you get until he's in better shape, because poor Paul has had a rough go of it--he started out as one of a few very pampered chicks in an upscale neighborhood, but was then confiscated by the local SPCA for being a rooster in the suburbs and got most of his wacky head feathers plucked by aggressive birds at the pound. Then he went from there to this box where he was stuck for two days:
 Figure One: This is the rather dark and blurry picture I snapped with my Blackberry the moment we had Paul in our possession and shared on the Facespace, so that the West Coast crew could stop worrying. Paul is a Polish Chicken, and kind of reminds me of Albert Einstein.
   I wasn't really looking for a rooster, per se, but Hotter and I had tossed the idea around some (hens are supposed to lay better with a rooster about). The main drawback, in our minds, is that a lot of roosters are ornery sons-of-bitches that'll attack kids, dogs, etc. and we didn't want an aggressive bird that the boys couldn't be around. Apparently Paul was very good friends with the small son of his previous owners, though, and several people vouched for his personality to me on the Facespace, so we decided to take him in. So far he seems very tame, although we'll see how he is when he's recovered from his USPS ordeal (he was a bit wobbly when he first came out of the box, and crowing like mad, but soon found the feed and water and settled down). And EVERY SINGLE HEN laid today--something that doesn't happen very often.
   I love a happy ending!

I'm BEAT! I mucked out the henhutch and chickenyard, spread crushed oyster shell in the mucky spots of the chickenyard, scattered fresh straw and re-bedded the henhutch, added fresh cedar trimmings and mint sprigs to the bedding in the henhutch to discourage pests, layered in a new compost heap with the happy straw from the henhutch and chickenyard, mowed the sideyard and far back with the mulching bag on and added fresh greens to the compost, then went inside and canned for a while.
   I put up a crockpot full of local MFApplesauce, several jars of organic refrigerator dills (spears and chips), a jar of spicy pickled carrots just for the heck of it, and made a local, organic apple pie from scratch with a woven crust. 
   I would've made bread today but the danged hens only gave us three eggs today (they've spoiled us for a while with four and I expected at least one more) and Hotter used two in meatloaf and I've got some organic bananas and lemons so I'm doing banana nut bread with the third. Tomorrow we'll pick up that stupid light setup and hopefully they'll start producing more, and after we get home with that there'll be at least enough eggs for baking.
   George and the Araucanas are starting to acclimate, although they still hide a lot and get dominated. I go out a couple of times a day and feed them by hand to ensure that they're getting enough. They've finally realized that walnuts and flaxseed-oil hen mash are good eating, and scratch in the straw for apple and carrot peelings like the Barred Rocks. The chickens have eaten the tops of my winter spuds twice now despite my mulching them thickly with straw and are grounded unless I have an eye on them, the mothercluckers. All of them will cut you for a strawberry.
   I obviously didn't go vegan just yet. I'm still working on figuring out carbs and protein and have an e-mail in to my endocrinologist, because I don't want to do anything that'll upset my blood sugar levels but also don't want to go "Atkins"/South Beach-esque because that actually sets you up to be MORE insulin resistant (after your body comes out of ketosis, which is what damages the organs most in diabetes, and how Hotter ended up with aftermarket parts).
   The dog is doing well. Today I gave her a thorough scrubbing with homemade sea-salt, coconut oil, organic lemon juice, mashed mint from the garden, minced garlic, and lavendar oil (just a tad). I really worked it into her skin and she sat down and thumped her foot in the water a little. After a thorough rinse and towel-drying, I got a LOT of dead fur out with the Furminator and she looks much better. Her coat is coming back nicely and I'll try to get pictures tomorrow if the sun cooperates.
   My face is on the mend! I remembered what our favorite pediatrician once told me about Mupirocin (that it penetrates 1/4-inch below the skin if you LEAVE IT ON and keep it covered, and kills most MRSA) and this morning scrubbed my face with Dead Sea salt-scrub, dried it with a rough towel, and really debrided the wound. All of the top layer of skin was dead and sloughed off, leaving an area the size of a dime that is raw and bloody, but clean. I applied pressure with a sterile bar towel, then slathered it with Mupirocin again and left it alone all day. Now it's healthy and pink, and if I let it dry it would crack and bleed, but as long as I keep it slathered with Mupirocin it doesn't even sting. I think I've avoided the need for medical attention, which is good, because we're still broke.
   How are all of YOU? Would you like a chance to win a care package full of organic goodies from Casa MFA including my better-than-most-sex-you've-had peanut-butter cookies, a jar of MFApplesauce, a bath bomb containing soothing, organic herbs from the MFA Garden in an attractive knitted sachet, artwork by the MFA Children, a handmade "I <3 MFA Puppy" dog kerchief in the size and fabric of your choice, and assorted other goodies from my BlogHer swag including things like a brand new aluminum water bottle with carabiner, Scotchbrite Greener Cleaning supplies, CheeseBurgHer temporary tattoos, and possibly even unopened door prizes from the SexIs party (batteries not included)? YOU KNOW YOU WOULD.

This is a nice, mouth-warming but not-too-hot vinegar-y BBQ base that I use mostly on chicken, although I've also used it for ground-venison "Sloppy Does" and it was fantastic in those, too. It's not too spicy for MY kids, but if you have picky eaters you might want to omit the banana pepper and maybe halve the black pepper. Or just throw a PBJ at 'em, make this as follows, and possibly eat it with a spoon, because it's THAT GOOD:
MFA Mama's Shebangarang! BBQ Sauce
1 c. ketchup (I buy store-brand when it's on sale if we're poor, Heinz Organic at the local big-box store if we're less-poor, depending)1/2 large sweet onion, diced up small2 tbsp red wine vinegar2 cloves garlic, finely minced1 small banana pepper (like, thumb-sized, or you can use a jalapeno if you want to make it really hot), deseeded and also finely minced 1 tbsp extra virgin olive oil1 tbsp Shebangarang!2 tsp honey 1/4 tsp black pepper3 drops "liquid smoke" flavoring 
Put the EVOO and onions in a small saucepan and cook over medium heat, stirring frequently, until the onions begin to clarify. Add the garlic and banana pepper and keep stirring until the garlic begins to brown (don't overdo it or it'll be bitter). As soon as you see the first hint of brown on the garlic, add the rest of the ingredients and simmer until it coats the back of a spoon nicely. This was makes enough to coat an entire picked chicken's worth of meat (if it's a backyard-raised chicken, so probably only the breastmeat of a store-bought roaster), which is dinner and leftovers at my house.
title: Shebangarang! BBQ sauce

body:
*   Apparently there was an earthquake yesterday. I say apparently because I honestly didn't notice at the time; I was driving to work, and thought the MFA Minivan had shit the bed on me. When I heard that it had been an earthquake, I was relieved. Meanwhile, back at the ranch, Hotter felt the 'quake and thought he was having a seizure until Little Child asked if he'd felt it. So he was relieved, too. We're strange people here.
*   Insurancegate is over! Or will be tomorrow (or Friday at the latest) when a PayPal transfer hits my bank account and I call Anthem. I...well, there's a reason more than one person in my life has threatened to make me wear a neck sign like Sandra Bullock in 28 Days (her character was in rehab and a therapist made her wear a sign around her neck reading "Confront me if I don't ask for help"). A reader of this humble site did just that a while back when we were really struggling, and offered me a generous loan. At the time I wasn't sure whether the XY was going to pay the restitution funds he owed me or not, and wasn't sure when or if I'd be able to pay back that kind of money, and said thanks but no thanks. Currently I know I'll have the funds as of the first of the month, and so I asked her if she was still willing to make me a (slightly smaller) loan, to be repaid in eight days, and just like that the nightmare was over. Thank you, friend-who-I-haven't-asked-if-I-can-name. Not worrying about losing my health insurance (and the dental benefits!) is an unbelievable relief and a wonderful feeling, but having someone I could call on like that is an even better one. I've said it before and I'll say it again: you people are like the extended family I lack offline (yes, even YOU Stalky--my family of origin had some loons in it that put you to shame!).
*   I have spent the past two days working. It was a very temporary temp-gig, just yesterday and today, wherein I helped a designer and their assistant furnish and decorate a model home for an upscale neighborhood. SO. FREAKING. COOL. We walked into an empty house with nothing but paint on the walls and two days later it looked like a very tidy, affluent family with impeccable taste was going to get home any minute. Also, how many people can honestly say they were paid handsomely by the hour to set up a Monopoly game and hot-glue all of the pieces in place (apparently people will knock over or pocket the pieces otherwise)? I wish I could show you pictures of some of the beautiful rooms (or heck, even the pretty piece of wall-art the designer gifted me when they couldn't find a good spot for it in the model), but I wouldn't want to potentially "out" myself to the client, who was so pleased with my work that they said they'd specifically request me the next time they're in town.
*   You know how I always talk about how "chickens are not nice?" Well, guess what? NEITHER ARE TURKEYS. Yesterday Hotter and I were outside looking at the mid-sized turkey, which is the nicest of the three (the little one is a menace to society, and y'all know how Loud and Crazy is). The turkey was looking at us from behind the chain-link (they really do look gentle and even intelligent when they look you in the eye, which is totally deceptive) and I was saying "Awww look at the mid-sized turkey. I dunno if I can kill that one, look at the way she's looking at us!" and Hotter was like "what, all doe-eyed?" and reached his finger into the fence. "Yeah, she's ni--" BLAM! The mid-sized turkey bit the everloving HELL out of Hotter's finger! "HOLY SHIT THAT HURTS!" he bellowed. Turkeys are REALLY not nice, y'all. It's a good thing they're delicious.
*   Hurricane coming. Ugh. Thanks to the loan from that reader, I was able to use a little of the money currently in our bank account to purchase several three-gallon containers of spring water (our water comes from a well, which means that if the power goes out we have no water), and I plan to fill the tub before the storm hits for flushing the toilet with, but that'll only get us and the MFA Menagerie through one day. The last time a hurricane kicked our arses in this area the way Irene is threatening to some folks didn't have power for over a week! I'm hoping it misses us, for all of the above reasons and also because closer to the date of the storm if the news tells us we're going to get thoroughly thrashed Hotter and I are going to have to drag one of the 8x12 chain-link pens we keep the poultry in into the garage. Because I don't think the chickens, ducks, and turkeys ought to be out in it if there are 100 mph winds. And I would rather NOT have to clean up after THAT.
*   How are all of YOU?

So I did my level best to make the past weekend a worry-free zone, and I think I succeeded pretty well. Unfortunately the health insurance thing was waiting for me afterward, and it's still not good, and I'd say there's maaaaybe a 25% chance I can fix it (my original estimates right up until squinting at the bank account a few minutes ago were much more optimistic, but I have to buy some gas to get to work today and tomorrow). But literally at the last minute (the 31st--IF Temp Agency #1 pays me on Tuesday or Wednesday for the work I'm doing for them today and tomorrow, which they generally--USUALLY--do, although technically they have until Friday to do so). So I'm a big ball of stress.
   Also apparently there's a hurricane coming. Which doesn't particularly scare me, as I've weathered plenty of those before, but if we lose our fridge we're fucked. Completely and utterly FUCKED. And as with everything else there's not a damned thing I can do except worry. So...yeah.
   If I lose the insurance I can replace it before I would have been uninsured for 60 days, but what I couldn't replace would be the dental policy, which took eighteen months of continuous coverage to kick in, and that would put fixing That Tooth completely out of my reach as opposed to just MOSTLY, and I won't lie, I'd be really, really bitter about that.
   It might be for the best if I take a little break from here until this is settled one way or the other, because I'm probably not going to have anything very entertaining to say. Mind you, that doesn't mean that I WILL...I might lose my resolve and desperately need to vent. We'll see.
title: the one where I admit I'm screwed

body: I just called and paid Anthem off, and all is roses there. WHAT A RELIEF! And now I have to go and do more pre-hurricane baking and laundry (I figure if the power's out for any extended period we'll need PBJ fixins and muffins galore, and it'll be good to have all the laundry done). THANK YOU, friend-who-saved-my-arse. Thank you lovely person who hit the tip jar this morning (that'll allow for the purchase of a few candles and some more jugs of water). Thank you everyone who held my hand. I'm a lucky girl.
title: Insurancegate '11 is OVER!

body:
*   This morning I woke from a bad dream where I was trying to leave the XY all over again (Little Child was a baby on my hip again, and very sick again, and his g-tube, which in the dream was the original pull-PEG, was venting copiously, which it hasn't in ages...also the XY was telling me that I couldn't leave him because I was too stupid to get through life on my own, for example today I had traffic court but would I know that without him to tell me? Nooooo) at dawn and ran to pull up the local court's website. Sure enough, I DID have traffic court this morning and had forgotten all about it! I was awake in plenty of time to get ready though, and got the last of the tickets from the expired registration dismissed. Perhaps my ex-husband is my new spirit animal? Oy.
*   I saw my divorce attorney at court and we exchanged pleasantries. That was kind of weird.
*   My kids are so excited about the hurricane that last night I finally gave them a Mason jar full of heavy whipping cream with a couple of marbles in and set them to making butter by taking turns shaking the jar just to wear their energy out a little. They crapped out when it was still just whipped cream and I had to take over, the little slackers, but seriously this creates the best damn butter you will ever taste and I highly recommend it.
*   Last night I ate too much at dinner but it was soooo good. Hotter made his famous potroast, which is unbelievably delicious, and I made fresh bread rolls that came out of the oven right as we were sitting down, plus we had the fresh butter (which is delightfully spreadable) to put on the rolls and for dessert, homemade strawberry ice cream.
*   Temp Agency #1 called today; they gave me a job on Monday that should take one hour or less, but I get paid for four hours because the contract is a four-hour minimum, plus the job pays 40% more per hour than I usually make. I'm basically going to be someone's stand-in at an important business meeting, like when royalty used to marry from a distance and they'd send a proxy to ceremonially "consummate" the deal by touching thighs with the person they were marrying. This tickles me to no end.
*   At this point, I think the MFA Children are going to be devastated if we don't get to eat shelf-stable foods warmed over Sterno cans for at least one meal. If you're reading this from anywhere along the Eastern seaboard, are YOU prepared for the hurricane? Don't forget a manual can-opener and a lighter for the Sterno cans in your hurricane kit! Honestly I think half the reason the boys are so excited is that we don't generally eat most of the canned and processed foods I bought in order to be prepared for Irene (Chef Boyardee ravioli, Handi Snacks, boxes of shelf-stable chocolate milk, etc.) because I consider them to be junkfood. Someone who shall remain nameless spent a good portion of yesterday evening dancing around the house chanting "CHILI-MAC! CHILI-MAC!"
*   This slays me:
 Figure One: Yes, I know, some folks have cracks in their foundations and are NOT AMUSED, and the Washington Monument is damaged, etc. but I don't think Japan and Christchurch feel overly sorry for us right now, is all I'm sayin'.
*   How are all of YOU?
title: pre-hurricane miscellaney

body:
I keep trying not to write about this, because nobody likes a whiner, but it's not going away. It being the question of what the hell we're going to do about the month of April.
   I sort of mentioned this a little while ago; the orginal three Bad Things. One I already told y'all about. The second I wrote about on Hopeful Parents. The third has to do with Hotter's side of the ledger and isn't mine to talk about, but it reduced our income by somewhere between things the first and second and, well, crap. I mean, any ONE of these things would have been bad, but we could have tightened our belts and been okay. Any two of them would have been pretty effing alarming but ultimately surmountable. All three though, not so much, and then...well, then came thing the fourth. Which I don't mind telling you has to do with my bastardous exhusband (who owes me a LOT of money, like we're talking the upper four figures, from marital assets he seized and liquidated in the early days of our separation and then got an extension on paying off in the finalization of our divorce) declaring bankruptcy. Domestic obligations (which this debt evidently falls under) are "protected debt," and when I spoke to the XY's bankruptcy attorney she told me I'd still get the money, just not on the schedule in the court order. The XY has since informed me that he just refuses to pay it on the schedule his attorney promised, and yes, this is enforceable BUT ONLY IF I take him to court, which I can't afford (the way our case is set up, I have to have an attorney file things for me; I can't just go as a citizen and file a damned thing on my own). So uh...yeah. Kiss THAT goodbye.
   I am at a loss here. Hotter's disability and the child support will cover rent, electricity, and either my health insurance, my prescription drugs, OR groceries, but not more than one of those three things. If I don't have the prescriptions, my health will go downhill rapidly. If I don't have the insurance, I can't afford the prescriptions. And food...well, obviously that's non-negotiable as well. I've been working odd jobs, and am scheduled to work for twelve hours tomorrow, which is awesome. The second place I'll be getting odd jobs from doesn't have anything until April fifteenth, which isn't going to help us survive the first part of the month. The freelance-y thing petered out, although I've put out more feelers. And finally, while I've applied to every single job I am even REMOTELY qualified for in the local "help wanteds" and online via various jobsearch sites, I keep either getting form rejections right off the bat or interviews that end in my being told I'm overqualified based on my education.
   That is really demoralizing.
   Morale aside, though, we've passed the point where if I got a job RIGHTNOW the first paycheck would come in time to save our arses in the first part of April. We've downsized everywhere we can, saved money every way we can think of (ordering from Angel Food Ministries, etc.)...hell, the last time Hotter and I ate out it was because I won a Burger King gift card from this blog-giveaway thingy. We don't see movies in the theater, we don't have cable, my kids don't participate in any extra-curricular activities...this is all fine with me, it just peeves me that it's not enough to be REALLY REALLY frugal and apply for every job in the classifieds.
   I don't mind living very simply, but I do mind what this situation is turning me into. I hate that I cringe when my kids come home excited about a new field trip their class is going on and am jealous of people who are eligible for unemployment. I'm becoming a bitter freaking downer; a friend posted something about this family who were living on unemployment and fighting to keep their home on Facebook and mentioned that she'd gotten their mailing information if anyone else wanted to help out a couple of weeks ago, and I said something bitter about not being particularly moved because these people were better off than my family, then erased it because nobody wants to see that, but at the same time, in the past month I have had my car insurance canceled, my innernet shut off (which made me late in getting a sponsored post up and threw me into an utter panic because for most of the jobs I've applied for I put e-mail as my preferred method of contact), I'm driving around in a car with one headlight, and I'm typing this on a laptop that'll die if the cord comes unplugged because the battery is dead. Currently we're making do without a working vacuum cleaner because SOMEthing happened to the power cord and I can't afford a roll of electric tape and a utility knife. It's hard not to talk about something that colors your life to this extent. Today my kids had a "Jammies for Japan" event at their school where they got to wear pajamas if they brought in at least a dollar for the Red Cross. I sent them each in with a dollar, and I am proud to say that they all emptied their piggy banks as well; I'm not proud to say that I begrudged the victims of the Japan disaster that three dollars out of my wallet (which represented thirty percent of what we have to get to the end of the month) and inwardly cursed because I'd been planning to raid those piggy-banks for milk money next week.
   I'm not telling y'all this for any reason other than I am tired of dancing around it. Please don't feel like I'm asking you to get involved in any way, because I'm not. It's just what's on my mind right now. I'm going to go on down to the local Social Services office on Monday and see if there's anything they can do, and hopefully they can help because my kids are starting to worry and I'm out of other ideas. If y'all have any ideas for ways to get work that I might not have thought of already, I'm all ears. I know that this too shall pass (slow and painful, like a kidney stone); I should have a lot more work starting next month as wedding and graduation celebrations ramp up and our garden will start to yield some produce. I'm just not sure how we'll get from here to there.
 
P.S. I'm sticking comments back on moderation for a bit (yeah, I took them off again earlier today before I decided to write this post) because if Stalky wants to carry on about how this is all my fault and richly deserved, she has Twitter for that. I'm sorry, I know that's annoying. I DID turn off word verification, though. You're welcome!
title: skip this one if you don't want to come to my pity party

body:
*   The worst of Irene is yet to come, but so far we still have power (although it's flickered several times and gone out for one five-minute interval) and innernet (obviously).
*   I just made a final run outside to check on the poultry; Hotter and I finally decided that the best course of action was to clear out the toolshed we don't use, spread straw in there, and turn it into a chicken and turkey storm-shelter (the ducks we left to their own devices with access to the poultry hutch should they choose to use it; we figure they're pretty waterproof and will be happier that way). Last night we carried all twenty-two squawking chickens and the three turkeys across the yard and put them inside (we put a small portable enclosure inside the shed to keep the turkeys separate). Today they all seem to be eating and drinking well, and even laying (I brought half a dozen eggs inside just now!). Neither of the windows in the shed are facing into the storm, so I think they'll be nice and safe (and it's good that they have enough light to see the food and water by).
*   Up until a few minutes ago I could honestly say that Big Child's comforter was our worst hurricane damage (the stir-crazy dogs went bananas and de-stuffed it), but just now a huge limb fell in the front yard. It didn't hit anything, so that's good.
*   The XY e-mailed me asking me to have the MFA Children call him. I e-mailed him back that authorities had asked everyone to forgo using phone lines unless it was an emergency, and could it wait? He said no, and since a close relative of his has been in poor health I went ahead and had the boys call him. But there was no emergency, he just wanted to alarm them with his panic-stricken shrilling of "DON'T WORRY! YOU'RE PROBABLY SAFE EVEN THOUGH YOU'RE WITH MOMMY! I'LL COME GET YOU IF IT GETS BAD!" So now the children are freaking out that he'll show up and try to take them out in the storm. THANKS, ASSHOLE! I assured them that that isn't going to happen (and it won't, because if the jackass shows up I won't open the damn door). Seriously, dude, WHY? I also don't see how they'd be safer with him given that HE lives in the middle of NOWHERE, but...oh well.
*   I hope y'all are all safe and dry. We're very well-prepared, and our house is sturdily-built of mostly brick, so I'm not terribly worried. I've been mostly using up my angst by fiddling with the blog (see my new Five Star Friday badge? FANCY! I was featured ages ago, but...it was something to do. Heh). Hopefully I don't break it before the power goes out. Probably I should quit while I'm ahead.
*   How are all of YOU?
title: so far, so good

body:
*   Today I had that "being a proxy" job, and it went well despite my having to have Temp Agency #1 fax me the checklist at the meeting due to the hoards of teenyboppers without power hogging up all the computers at the library where I usually print things (no printer here). Yes, I know, a minor ding to the professional image is a FABULOUS post-hurricane problem to have, and I will shut up now except to note that apparently I have gotten old. DAMN KIDS AND THEIR FACESPACE GAMES!
*   Temp Agency #1 also had another job for me that starts tomorrow. I'll be working 2:30-11 p.m. M-F for a couple of weeks, and while I'm a little sad that I won't be here to greet the MFA Children after their first day of school, I'm happy to have the work! Apparently it's for an out-of-town client that has turned two floors of an area hotel into an office-away-from-their-office where I and several others will be doing Work Of A Secret Nature. Like, the sort that even if I wasn't a pseudonymous privacy-nut who obfuscates the HELL out of work-related tales, I couldn't tell you because I'll be signing lots of things to that effect. Probably it won't be NEARLY as interesting as it sounds, but MAYBE! Either way y'all won't hear a thing about it except for things like whether or not the technology there confounded me or a wardrobe malfunction strikes on a given day (my tits have apparently grown, AGAIN, SOME MORE, since the last time I had to wear business attire, and the potential is high).
*   Other than that, I have a headache today that seriously needs to fuck off and die in a tire fire. It's not a migraine (my left ear is hurting, but no visual/GI manifestations), just a shitty headache that won't go away. Bleh.
*   Today I butchered George de Ebil and fed her to the dogs, as grocery money is very tight until Wednesday when I get paid. She'd been back to her evil ways and laying eggs that seemed to be water inside with a yolk, very strange (we haven't been eating them; they've been dogfood); on autopsy I think she had cancer or something. There were some bits in there the other birds I've butchered didn't have, and that's as much detail as I'll go into. Except to say that for the SECOND time in a row I had "Somewhere Over The Rainbow" stuck in my head and was therefore singing it out as I plucked and butchered. My little old lady neighbor complimented me on my singing voice, but sadly thought I was singing to new baby chicks or something and tottered over to the fence to see what I was up to. She won't make THAT mistake again! My poor neighbors.
*   How are all of YOU?

body:
*   Little Child's g-tube button got partially yanked the other morning while he was wrestling with his brothers, resulting in unholy screaming that roused me. I calmly and quickly grabbed a spare and a syringe full of water, deflated the old button the rest of the way, and replaced it with a new one. Believe it or not this is only the second time in over five years of Little Child's having a g-tube that something like this has happened (the other time it was a faulty balloon that emptied all the way spontaneously, causing the button to just FALL OUT). Hotter was dancing around in the background as I worked, holding a spare one of everything I was using and chanting "I'mSOgladyou'rehomeI'mSOgladyou'rehome!" Heh. Poor Little Child was so traumatized by the whole thing (it was probably pretty ouchy, but I think it mostly just freaked him the eff out, y'know?) that I came up with a new ritual on the spot: I buy Little Child's used tubes off him for a buck (my kids will do chores for nickels and dimes, so a whole buck at once is a BIG HAIRY DEAL). The other two MFA Children were jealous and wanted to know what I'd buy of of them. "Y'all don't have tubes. Nothing to buy," I said. "YEAH!" Little Child gloated. "NO FAIR!" the older two whined. "Life's not fair, boys," I noted. Oy.
*   I lost fifteen bucks in cash at Soulless Corporate Megalith; it was in my pocket and I got bumped by a co-worker and then it was gone. I know who it was, but what am I going to do, accuse them? Probably there was a camera on us at the time but mehhh. I kind of had to laugh a little, because it's only like, THIS WEEK that that fifteen bucks won't break us (don't get me wrong, I'm bummed, but WOW how lucky with the timing and hey look we're not killing chickens anymore because there are groceries! WHOO!).
*   The turkeys are getting BIG. I had to clip their wings again because one of them kept getting out somehow and the only spot it could have fit OUT of was at the top of the roof of that enclosure. There's one I'm SURE is a tom (ugh) and one that I'm SURE is a girl-turkey (hen?) and one that is either a very small, effeminate tom (???) or a very large, butch girl-turkey (hen, I'm just going to call them hens unless one of y'all knows a breed-specific term I'm unaware of?). I guess we'll find out eventually!
*   Oh, some things we call the poultry, in no particular order, because we're silly people: 
Chuzzards - full-grown chickens, from chicken + buzzard. Because they love meat, duh.Chuzz-nuggets - juvenile chickensChic-tacs - the silver-laced Wyandottes, because they're extra-tinyThe Turducken Collective - Hotter noted that he felt it was important we use inclusive language to acknowledge the turkeys' poultryhood, or something. I think he's getting mushy over those stupid turkeys. We're totally eating at least ONE of them mofos, Hotter!
*   Hotter woke me up well before I needed to be awake (think four hours), allegedly because he NEEDED a prescription and wanted to make sure the pharmacy wasn't closed. "At five p.m.?" I asked. "It's a weekday." "I COULDN'T TAKE A CHANCE!" he insisted. "Why, what drug am I picking up," I asked, feeling around for my keys in a half-stupor and also confused because I thought he had full bottles of both immunosuppressants and his seizure pills. "Nexium." I stopped and goggled at him. "BLEEDING ULCERS, I'LL GET BLEEDING ULCERS, AND MY PEE WILL TURN RED FROM THE BLOOD AND DR. KIDNEY WILL PUT ME IN THE HOSPITAL," he said, histrionically. "THAT DOESN'T EVEN MAKE SENSE, DUDE, WHAT THE HELL?" And y'all, he looked at me with pity and asked me where pee came from. "Your kidney," I replied. "Yes, and before that? Where does the stuff you DRINK come from," he continued, as if he was being very patient with someone very simpled-minded. "Most liquid is absorbed through the large intestine?" "WHATEVER, THAT'S ATTACHED TO THE STOMACH, RIGHT?" And then my head exploded. 
*   Yes, he probably WAS screwing with me (I HOPE) but now we're back to "woke me up way early because he was lonely" which, while sweet, OMG I NEEDED THAT SLEEP and work is going to suuuuck tonight. Wahhh...how are all of YOU?
title: blah blah bullets

body:
At the turn onto the major highway down the road from my house, the MFA Minivan suddenly sounded kind of rough to me. I needed gas anyway and pulled into the first place, set the pump to fill the tank, and checked the oil, and...there was none. It had heated up a lot more than would be usual but it's also really hot outside...I dunno. I'm trying to be optimistic, I really am. But my AAA membership lapsed when things got bad and I don't know anyone local I could call in the middle of the night for a ride and/or tow except the XY (oh yes, he owns a trailer big enough to tote the MFA Minivan; he's done it before) (many years ago, obviously--we bought the thing when I was pregnant with Middly, who OMG is seven).
   The MFA Minivan is thirteen now, and acting every bit the rebellious teen.
   Plus okay I'm SLIGHTLY superstitious about elderly vehicles, and the day before yesterday I FINALLY got the thing street-legal and it had a full-to-the-brim tank when I left it hushed in grim repose in the driveway over a cardboard box (that oil dripped onto), and therefore clearly the MFA Minivan is doomed. 
   Just when I'd kind of pulled our collective financial heads above-ground, now we might be back into the pit. 
   Damn it.
title: I already dread the boys' teen years if this is what teenagers are like

body:
That, in case you were wondering, is the sound of me literally vibrating with angst.
   Large doses of albuterol make me ring like a damned tuning fork.
   I'm worried about the van. I'm worried about my health. I'm worried, period.
   Last night since I couldn't go to work and was angsty, I suggested to Hotter that we take the dogs for a walk. It was night-time, and so not AS hot and humid, and a walk along the edge of the road for the width of our front yard (as far as we are comfortable going from the house full of sleeping children with the window propped open) seemed like a reasonable undertaking.
   Except I don't think my lungs and I saw eye-to-eye on that, because I woke at 3:30 a.m. with what I suspect may be a CO2 headache and a deep, rattling wheeze that wouldn't fuck the fuck off. I decided to eat a little something with some fat and protein in it to protect my stomach and hopefully keep my blood sugar from bottoming out if I slept for a while as a result of the Benadryl, take a whopper-dose of that to address any potential allergic phenomenon in action, some store-brand "Excedrin" to address the headache as best I can and also because the caffeine might help the lungs, do a nebulizer treatment, and hopefully get back to sleep, so that I'm awake tomorrow while the children are and also because Hotter was Very Annoyed with me for being up and told (!!!) me twice to go back to sleep.
   I guess maybe he's starting to resent my odd sleeping hours, but those are a result of my job and not something I can change at the moment. Also I didn't mention it last night but I think Hotter was at least PARTLY annoyed with me for turning back from the service station instead of going on in to work and keeping an eye on the temperature gauge. But the coolant was really low too (I forgot to mention that because the oil freaked me out so much but, well...yeah) and my AAA membership is lapsed and if the van dies that is GAME OVER...
   Of course, even if the MFA Minivan is fine, that does us absolutely no good if my lungs continue to shit the bed this way.
   It's possible that wouldn't be an issue, incidentally, if I had the money to have my actual DOCTOR manage the asthma, but I haven't seen her since well before the ER trip in April (yes, I was supposed to follow up with her after that, but I didn't have the money). I don't know if that's a big deal or not because thanks to the kindness of friends I have access to a nebulizer and the meds for it and that might be all she'd be able to do for me right now anyway (besides try to prescribe an inhaled steroid that I a) couldn't afford and b) would have serious reservations about using due to my body's effed up physical and mental reactions to steroids, even in tiny quantities, and I can fret about that right now without the actual prescription in-hand for FREE). It might be that she could figure out some kind of fix for the current monumental suckitude of my respiratory status, but I can't afford to sink any money into that until a) I determine what the minivan needs and b) I earn said money and if the van is dead then I have to keep on ignoring this for now and would rather not think about it, but oh look, too late. 
   I really hope I am not permanently harming my lungs by not having medical professionals handle their care and feeding right now.
   I guess you could also say that I'm worried about my marriage, although Hotter is not CURRENTLY being an ass (I mean the TELLING me to go back to sleep was a little bit assy, but he was half-awake and he didn't bellow or anything--Hotter is very sensitive to me "making the innernet hate him" so I thought I'd throw that out there), a month ago I wouldn't have hesitated to wake him and ask him to keep me company until the worst of the jitters from the nebs have passed and try to help me take my mind off the pain in my head. Now, however, I'm mostly just hoping I don't wake him by accident, because I'm worried that he'd be irritated with me, either because of the lost sleep or because he thought I should be able to ignore all of this and go to sleep myself so as to be up helping him with the house and the yard and the kids tomorrow, or...I dunno. Maybe I'm being unfair with him and he'd be wonderful and make me laugh and say all of the right things, but I am feeling a little too close to the end of my chain to take the chance he'd be pissy, and that makes me sad.
   Someone tell me a funny. Please?
title: bzzz

body:
*   Obviously we survived.
*   It was pretty impressive; hours and hours of roaring winds and a ton of rain; here is what our yard looked like during the eye of the storm:
 Figure One: Eerie green light. See the branch down? Also if you squint at the bottom right corner, you can see my fallen cherry tomato :(
*   I moved the MFA Minivan into the detached garage right before the storm hit, so it wasn't damaged by falling limbs. Very glad about that!
*   Our power was out for a total of about twenty hours. Not bad at all! I keep thinking of all the nice guys and gals I met at the Linemen's Rodeo and served coffee to. They sure were a good-natured bunch! I hope none of them get hurt restoring the power on the East Coast.
*   I'm really glad we were prepared; we used quite a bit of bottled water for drinking, washing, and flushing (apparently our bathtub drain-plug isn't all that watertight) and cooked two meals over Sterno cans. I was also able to use those to make Hotter some instant coffee this morning, so nobody perished in our house. The refrigerator stayed nice and cold (thanks to my idea of freezing a bunch of ice beforehand and putting it in a freezerbag, then transferring that to the top shelf of the fridge as soon as the power went) and the freezer stayed frozen. All in all our worst losses were Big Child's comforter (which the stir-crazy dogs pulled into the crate and de-stuffed) and a pan of fish sticks and french fries that were in the oven when the power blew (the chickens enjoyed those when we released them from their storm shelter). So clearly it could have been MUCH worse.
*   How are all of YOU?
title: hurricane, schmurricane

body:
So the MFA Minivan is all effed up. I dragged out of bed and went straight to MFA Mechanic's shop; they said when I called that they could give me a ride home, but then they were crazy-busy and asked me if I could hang out, and then the parts guy sent the wrong part for one of the repairs and ultimately I was gone for about five hours, most of which I spent re-reading the same issue of Better Homes And Gardens from 2004.
   The good news is, by not driving the thing to work last night I saved my engine. The bad news is pretty much everything else in my life right now. Today's repairs cost $300 and it needs another $400 in work ASAP (when I asked him to rate the work I couldn't afford to get done today on a scale of one to ten in terms of how important it was, MFA Mechanic said "six, maybe seven"). So there went the money I'd set aside to reinstate our car insurance, and now I'm going to have to let my health insurance lapse.
   But hey, at least the XY was here and Hotter was furious with me when I got home! The XY was taking the kids for an extra dinner-visit. Hotter accused me of deliberately timing my arrival so that they'd be leaving (???) and proceeded to hold me accountable for the lack of a spare guy to give me a ride home, MFA Mechanic's failing to offer a payment plan, and the children being unhappy about "never seeing" me. "What am I supposed to do when they say 'we miss Mommy, we wish she didn't have to work third shift?' When was the last time you spent a day with YOUR CHILDREN? Or ME," he wanted to know.
   I feel like I just can't win. I'm neglecting my health to keep the minivan running so I can go to work so my husband can resent the living shit out of me and we can STILL be broke! I...don't have a graceful ending to this post. That's all, really.

body:
*   Middle Child perked up some, so hopefully this was a short-lived bug.
*   I, however, still have that headache and it SUCKS.
*   Despite this, I was outside mucking out the chickens' enclosure earlier. We had some weather and it was very wet and gross in there (as a former horse person, wet mucky conditions in animals' living spaces make me twitch because with horses that is Asking For It), so I dragged Hotter out and made him guard the winter garden while the hens foraged outside and I dealt with the mess. I had to rake it down to the bare earth, cart off all the yuck to the compost pile, and spread layers of oyster shell, shavings, and straw before I was satisfied with it.
*   The chickens hadn't laid at all when I cleaned their area but immediately two of them produced eggs, so that's good but still only half what we're used to getting in a day. Guess I can't blame them (I told Hotter I wouldn't lay any eggs in those conditions either).
*   I won a giveaway on someone else's blog that involved a $25 gift card, and my prize package came today! We're broker than usual here so this is cause for celebration. I'm excited about the flavored vinegar, too (we got Roasted Garlic). So there's that.
*   This headache can seriously suck it though. I had big plans for today including a photo-shoot with MFA Puppy and the launch of a new product over at MFOrganics. Hmph. There  are still a couple of jars of Sea Salt Scrub left, so act fast if you want  some of that, and stay tuned for some holiday-ish stuff as soon as I can look directly at the monitor without wanting to gouge my eyes out!
title: oww my head

body:
Hotter is sick. 
   How sick?
   Well, he asked me to call off of work tonight so I could deal with the children today, knowing full well that Soulless Corporate Megalith has a "three strikes you're out" policy.
   I was absent once when I was sick my own self and once when the MFA Minivan shit the bed and tried to die.
   So I'm thinking it's deal with the kids, put them to bed, go to work on the "go forty-eight hours without sleep and hope nobody dies, either by my hand directly or when I accidentally drop building debris on their head" plan UNLESS someone ups and has a fucking seizure or something (fevers lower seizure threshold and Hotter doesn't look so good).
   If he has a seizure I'm going to nutpunch him.
title: y'know, just once I'd like to go like, a whole week without a catastrophe

body:
*   I SLEPT!!! Here is my actual Facespace update from yesterday, to give you an ideo of how grim the sleep-deprivation had gotten, between Hotter looking for reasons to wake me up and my waking up on my own with angst, asthma, and wretched headaches:
MFA Mamaplans to sleep tonight, for a change, and has put her husband on notice that if he knocks on the door and doesn't have a dying child in his arms that she needs to rush to the hospital (not an ALREADY DEAD one--at this point if anyone in the house is ALREADY DEAD they will STILL BE THAT WAY IN THE MORNING) he'll be relieved of every appendage longer than his nose. SLOWLY. 
*   My dental insurance kicked in! WHOOOO! There was some doubt about this as a result of the insurance shuffle of six months ago (where Anthem canceled my insurance because the rates changed and I'd been paying the OLD amount), because the dental insurance I have only covers cleanings and checkups for the first eighteen months and I wasn't sure whether I had to start over with that, but apparently NOT and it has now been eighteen months, which means that my out-of-pocket to fix the mostly-missing front tooth is only (hahahaONLY) $375, as opposed to $800. That's still not going to be doable any time soon thanks to the EFFING minivan, but it's nice to know that I've got coverage should the thing go bad and my face suddenly swell up (I've had a tooth pulled without anesthetic before due to finances, and it is something I am VERY EAGER to NEVER, EVER DO AGAIN).
*   I went outside this morning to collect produce and check on the poultry and found--SURPRISE!--a zucchini as long as my forearm. I just looked at the zucchini bushes yesterday and saw nothing larger than my thumb! It's been a while since I grew zucchini and I forgot how comically rapid their growth can be.
*   The MFA Children have all thanked me several times over for yesterday's picnic; they really had fun and I'm so glad. Everyone's favorite part was feeding the giant koi (some of which were nearly the size of Little Child).
*   Hotter is being lovely and funny and kind, which is his USUAL state of being, but hadn't been for a few days and so it's wonderful to see that he hasn't, say, grown a brain tumor that killed that entirely or something. Aside from the fact that nobody likes an asshole, I have extensive baggage to do with being married to an asshole and Hotter's recent assholery was taking a terrible toll on my mental health.
*   Today I got an e-mail from one of you that made me feel a lot less alone-against-the-universe and like somebody's got my back in life, after all. It was nice. When it's not on the rag (ahem, STALKY) the innernet is kind of like the extended family I don't have offline, and that's awesome. Sloppy half-toothless kisses to everyone reading this who isn't, you know, an actual stalker.
*   How are all of YOU?
title: less depressing

body:
Oh, y'all.
   I'm having myself a little freakout over here, because I don't see how I'm going to pay all of the bills that I need to pay in the next week and dammit, dammit, DAMMIT, why does Hotter have to go and be sick NOW?
   Coming up I have the rent, my health insurance (which I was going to let lapse, but now that the dental kicked in that would mean forfeiting the $425 they'll throw in toward fixing That Fucking Tooth and anything else dental that pops up in the next eighteen months, so eff, can't do THAT), the electric bill (which if I'm late with it they'd boot us off the budget plan and we'd have to pay everything we've saved by being on that in the past year, and that's...a lot), and all of those things together are about $150 more than I've got coming in...and that's without factoring in food and gas and assuming the MFA Minivan can hold its shit together and that nobody needs any expensive prescriptions filled (hahahahaHAohgod).
   I should have called around the temp agencies until I found something and worked this past weekend instead of taking everyone on that EFFING picnic. I should have told Hotter to eff off with his guilt trip about how the children never see me. And hell, while we're playing Revisionist History, The Home Game I shouldn't have gone to grad school, because then I wouldn't have so many EFFING student loans and we would have gotten our tax refund instead of the Department of Education...crap.
   Why the hell is it that every time I think I'm going to dig us out of the pit and start making some good progress toward financial solvency, something horrible happens and then like, two or three more somethings? I'm getting awfully sick of working my ass off and still not even being able to pay our bills. This sucks, and I know that some of the current angst is the lack of sleep talking, but I think this sucks objectively as well. 
   Tell me a funny?
title: the one where I freak out a lot (don't read this if you're looking for the cheerful)

body:
*   I feel like I should PayPal her the cost of a 50-minute hour. Ginny summed up a lot of Hotter's side of the fuckwittage nicely. Unfortunately for Hotter (well, and my mental health), after I wrote yesterday's post he said something much worse, as in "so bad that because I'll most likely end up forgiving him, I'm not recording it for posterity lest y'all all judge me for the fact that he still draws breath." Dammit, Hotter.
*   Despite the above, and a night of next to no sleep (because apparently at two in the morning Isis was whimpering for me so Hotter came and knocked on the bedroom door and WOKE ME UP, AND OH MY GOD WHAT THE FUCK WITH THE ALWAYS WAKING ME UP LATELY, GOD DAMMIT MAN???), I set out early to the grocery store and bought peanut butter and bread and strawberries and chips and cookies and drink pouches and took everyone to the park for a picnic. Because my kids haven't seen me not-working-or-sleeping in weeks, and it's when you feel the least like doing these things that other people generally most need you to do them (dammit some more). Hotter came too, despite my telling the boys that he wanted a break from us all, because they begged him to (and because of course the moment I was so disgusted as to want to forcibly GIVE him one, or possibly one in each LEG, he no longer wanted a break in the slightest), and it was fine. We all had a good time. We petted goats and fed bread to giant koi in a beautiful garden and admired ancient stonework and smelled flowers. The children rolled down a giant hill and nobody puked or got stung by a bee or skinned their knee or had an allergy attack (my lungs even behaved admirably, despite there being a lot of hill-climbing involved, and even some hill climbing avec five-year-old-on-shoulders on the way back to the MFA Minivan, which obligingly did not overheat). It's like even the fucking piece of shit van KNEW that the next one to look at me cockeyed would die with the asinine look still on their face. 
*   While we were gone, we missed a text from SOMEone in Arctic Tundra State where all of my in-laws live, saying "Im in ur neighborhood!!!!!" The moment I read it to Hotter (he can't see the screen of his phone well in daylight) we each went and locked a door. Haha. Hotter went and called his son, who said it wasn't him, and we still have no idea who sent the text (it may have even been a wrong number). I'm slightly disappointed, as in-laws (while well-intentioned, certainly) are EXPENDABLE and I think I'm going to need to kick SOMEone's arse before the weekend is up.
*   How are all of YOU?

body:
*   I called Anthem and spoke with a very nice rep and if I pay tomorrow that's okay with them. So hopefully if I enter the payment online tomorrow the XY will pay the child support before it hits the bank account. Hopefully. Fingers crossed.
*   My mouth still hurts. Maybe I burned it on a cup of ramen at work? That's uh, my dirty little secret by the way. Synthetic EVERYTHING, preservatives out the salty arse and it comes in a styrofoam cup wrapped in plastic...it's basically a fuck you to my body, the environment, and my every sensibility all at once but fifty-seven cents buys two of them and...I could stop any time I wanted, okay?
*   One of the turkeys rattled its bones at me today. It's not very impressive yet but OMG IT TOTALLY ACTED LIKE A TURKEY!
*   MFA Mechanic said to check the oil in the MFA Minivan every time I buy gas and it's time to buy gas on the way to work tonight and that means I have to check the oil and I'm skeert.
*   Little Child has been eating more every day, and I am kind of burying this under a heap of bad news because a) I'm trying to end this post on a good note and b) I am not at ALL superstitious about it, and I certainly haven't been avoiding my monthly Hopeful Parents post out of fear of jinxing it or anything, nope nope nope so just a). But it's literally been years since he's taken so much by mouth and THIS. IS. EXCITING. Naturally Hotter takes all of the credit.
*   I can't sleep. This is total bullshit. I didn't wake up until the last three hours at work. Figures. How are all of YOU?
title: mixed bag

body:
*   I slept for almost twelve hours but I still can't wake the fuck up. Like, to the point that if my caffeine doesn't kick in soon I may not make it to work TONIGHT because I won't be cool to drive. It's not mental or fine-motor (I'm typing this, obviously) so much as it is "dead arms and a bad case of the stumblies." Like, y'know how your arms are kinda half-paralyzed for a few when you wake up from a nightmare or just a really hard sleep? And if you get up to go to the bathroom or grab a ringing phone or whatever you're liable to bash into the side of the first doorway you try to lurch through? That.
*   I just opened the "we will CANCEL YOUR COVERAGE as of the last day of this month!" letter from Anthem. Sigh. Thanks to the MFA Minivan and the fact that the XY's recent surliness (he's blaming his lack of weekend visitation on me) (yes, this is due to his own poor parenting and life choices but try convincing HIM of his culpability--he seriously thinks he's perfect and unassailably RIGHT at all times--clearly it's MY doing!) has manifested as "paying the child support just a TIDGE late, not late enough to officially Get In Trouble but late enough to make MFA Mama's bills late" I don't quite think I'll be able to save the policy and DAMN IT TO HELL. Just when I'd gotten the dental stuff to the sweet spot but before I was able to make the tooth repair happen. BALLS.
*   Also my mouth hurts. Not from anything dental, but y'know how your tongue feels in the aftermath of when you take a sip of WAY TOO HOT coffee? That. For like, several days and it is the most ANNOYING THING. My lips too, and really, what the hell? I guess maybe I drank hot coffee at some point and have forgotten about it due to sleep deprivation? This isn't misery-making exactly, I mean, it's seriously minor, no doubt about it, but it's certainly ANNOYING as all hell.
*   If the title gave you pause and you're wondering what I meant by it, that's what my dad used to call it when you were kvetching about That Which Doesn't Kill You. I feel pretty lame for being so disgusted with life over this random assortment of non-emergent things, especially in light of the fact that nobody has had a grand mal seizure, the MFA Minivan hasn't frozen up and refused to budge, and my back and lungs have mostly sorted themselves out for the moment, but there you have it: death by a thousand cuts.
*   How are all of YOU?
title: pissing and moaning

body:
Okay, friends, I have a dilemma and I'm not sure what to do here, so I thought I'd just take a poll. Here's the deal:
   As y'all know, I had a freak dental accident on the way to a job interview about a week ago. This happened once before, about a year ago (I can't find it in my archives to save my life, but oh well) with the same (fake) tooth, and my dentist was able to glue it back together with some kind of dental-grade superglue. That cost about sixty bucks and was well worth it.
   Currently, thanks to a friend bailing us out in a big (at least to me!) way, I have enough in the bank to get my antidepressants refilled and have my dentist fix the tooth again (assuming it's the same fix for the same kind of money), BUT I don't know how we're going to cover rent and health insurance and prescription drugs next month (not to mention food) so I don't know if it's very smart to lay out the money for something as non-life-threatening as this tooth. It's a pain, yes (literally in that the exposed stump of the original tooth is very sensitive and figuratively in that I have to keep my mouthguard in 24/7 to prevent further damage plus OMG MY TOOTH GAHHHH), but it's not going to kill me. To further complicate things, I have a one-hour freelance-y gig in my professional field on Thursday that fell into my lap out of the blue and nothing says "dumb, unprofessional white trash" like a partially-missing front tooth (the freelance-y gig will not pay enough to cover the repair; it's worth slightly less than half, but I'm not turning down ANY work right now, for obvious reasons).
   So I'm debating whether to lay out the $60 that I don't really have on this tooth in order to not look like a damned hick on Thursday (and end the discomfort, not to mention that Things Dental skeeve me out to no end so this is pretty demoralizing, and also I can't properly kiss my husband or do anything ELSE to him involving my mouth while this thing is like this) and worry about the rest of it later or just suck it up, try not to smile on Thursday, and see whether we survive the month of April before I worry about my stupid tooth.
   Here, for reference purposes, is what the damage actually looks like:
 Figure One: I know, probably not as bad as you were picturing, but this makes me very unhappy.

body:
Figure One: The ayes have it; I go to the dentist Thursday morning. Thank you to everyone who voted, and especially to Bitter Divorcee, who is too kind!
   When y'all speak, I listen, especially when you're telling me to do what I'd like to do more than anything in the first place (seriously, you have NO IDEA how much I hate Things Dental, especially broken teeth--that's literally been my most frequent nightmare since I was a little kid plus OMG FRONT TOOTH NOOOO). There was no wrong answer to this one, though (I can argue for either side of what to do about the tooth, which is why I resorted to a blog poll in the first place), and I even see the point of those of you who think I should just shut the eff up about the negative. To that end I am going to go and volunteer at the Hippie Food Coop tomorrow, because going there always puts me in a more positive headspace (oh lord, they're rubbing off on me, aren't they?) and we could really use some free cosmetically-challenged veggies up in this piece. So if I'm slow to approve comments tomorrow, it's because I'm not home to do it. Peace out!
P.S. I have a lead on a possible job as a farm-hand through the Hippie Food Coop, and will hopefully be able to find out more about that tomorrow. I figure it'd be awesome to work outside and learn more about farming, I'd get in killer shape doing it, and the odds of losing a limb in an agricultural accident are probably pretty low with adequate safety precautions, even for me. Wish me luck!
title: the verdict is in!

body:
*    Hotter is way sick today. I don't know what's up with him, but his stomach is really bothering him and he has a fever, and last night he had a seizure aura (I didn't get my weird premonition thing, which has been 100% accurate to date, and was therefore unalarmed and skeptical that he'd actually seize, but he took some Lorazepam just in case as his auras have, until last night, been 100% accurate in predicting seizures) (yeah, about that, I am pleased and a little creeped out to report that I was right--the aura dissipated and the seizure never did materialize, which since the last medication adjustment his neurologist made seems to be the closest he's able to get to actually seizing).
*   Before I realized just HOW sick Hotter was this morning, I did in fact go and volunteer at the Hippie Food Coop as planned. I heart the Hippie Food Coop! Seriously, that place always improves my mood and today was no exception. I did some cleaning and watered a bunch of seedlings, so it was pretty much exactly like being at home, minus the sick man and plus someone else making me breakfast (the owner made everyone sausage sammiches--whoo!). I came home with a free container of lavender chèvre that someone (not me!) had dropped in stocking the cooler (the corner of the container cracked--the contents were fine but it was no longer suitable for sale) and a bunch of cosmetically-challenged apples, potatoes, and squash. Also, I mooched a couple of empty six-packs (the kind you plant seedlings in) from the Hippie Food Coop's greenhouse--my seedlings need repotting and I didn't really want to spend money for plastic crap to put them in. YAY!
*   The XY tried to cancel his dinner visitation on the grounds that he's sick, but I wasn't having it (the MFA Children are going to be exposed to sickness whether they go with their father or stay at home, so that being the case and given the state of finances here, I prefer the option that doesn't involve me having to provide dinner). I responded to his e-mail with word-for-word the same thing he e-mailed me one time when I asked him to keep the MFA Children an extra hour once so that I could go to the doctor ("You lie down with dogs, you wake up with fleas--ZING! Now THAT'S funny!") and he responded with "u really have a way with words is that really necessary?" I wrote back and reminded him that I couldn't take the credit, and asked whether it was only funny if HE mocked the person I loved. No answer--I should probably give up on trying to artificially instill a rudimentary sense of empathy in that mofo, but then what would I do for bad fun?
*   How are all of YOU?
title: this and that

body:
Enough with the depressingness! I can't promise you're not in store for more of that, but Hotter and I just had a good laugh and I thought I'd share...
   I heartily recommend ducklings as Nature's finest (legal) antidepressant. I've been pretty miserable lately, but I think it'd be a lot worse if I didn't have four fuzzy reasons to laugh in a box in the other room. I mean, ducks, like chickens and goats, are inherently hilarious, and then there are the various puns they lend themselves to...my husband, for example, reduced me to tears of laughter prancing around the dining room earlier this evening holding the smallest duckling (whose name he insists is "Billy," due to its smaller-than-average bill, despite the fact that officially we are waiting to see what gender the ducks are before Little Child and Middle Child get to name them) singing "Billy, don't be a heeero!"
F
Figure One: He has brain damage, y'all.
   By far the funniest thing to date, however, is the ducklings' terror of ramen. Yes, ramen, specifically the noodles. See, every night after the kids are in bed Hotter and I like to spread a towel out on the dining-room table, place a flower pot-bottom filled with water on top of the towel, and let the ducklings have a little swim. What can I say, we're two grown adults without teevee in the house who know how to party...
   Anyway, the other night there was a bowl with some ramen still in it on the table (we save any leftover foodstuffs to throw to the chickens, hence the bowl with the noodles inside sitting around that way) and after I'd finished feeding the ducklings some torn-up spinach Hotter picked up a noodle and held it over the flower-pot lid.
   The ducklings all shrieked in horror and flung themselves out of the water. One of them actually dashed off the table's edge, hit the floor with a splat and kept on hauling ass all the way down the two steps into the den (where we keep their box). "Huh, I guess they don't like ramen," Hotter said sadly after I chased down the duckling and brought it back to join the others (who hopped back into the water as soon as Hotter withdrew the offending noodle). "I wonder why that is? Ducks love carbs!" We pondered that for a moment and then I had a thought and started laughing so hard it took me a moment to be able to speak. "They...think...you're...a CHILD MOLESTER!" 
   Hotter looked at me like I was the one with the brain damage.
   "Remember that article, with the videos, that made the rounds a couple of years ago? About the duck-peen? It's SPIRAL! They think you're coming at them with a--HAHAHAHA!" and we both cracked the hell up. "They're like NONONO, UNCLE BAD-TOUCH!"
   And we pretty much died.
   Tonight there was ramen on the table again (ummmmyeah, notice the pattern? I haven't eaten this much ramen since I was an undergraduate...) and I picked up a noodle and brandished it experimentally at the ducklings. They recoiled again, peeping, although when I broke it up into smaller pieces they gobbled it eagerly.
   "Well now that you've compared it to that video that's just NASTY," Hotter observed.
   Never say we don't know how to have fun around here...
title: on the lighter side of things...

body:
As y'all are already aware, I went to the dentist this morning and got my tooth fixed. My dentist (who I pink-puffy-heart as a person, even if I am an anti-dentite) was able to do the same fix as last time for the same money as I'd hoped, so that was good, and the cosmetic result was excellent if I do say so myself.
   After the dentist, I went home and changed for the freelance-y thing, where I showed up with my game-face on (complete with teeth!) and rocked it. No, seriously, I ROCKED THAT GIG! So much so that it went from a one-hour, one-time thing to a one-hour-twice-a-week-for-six-weeks thing, and OMG YAY! As an added bonus, I genuinely like the client. Score!
   To celebrate, I went to the Hippie Food Coop (which is only three miles away from Freelance-y Gig) to buy a few groceries, and they asked if I was free to run the place next Wednesday (their paid employee has to go out of town again) in exchange for more groceries. DOES THE POPE SHIT IN THE WOODS? Whoohoo! From there I went to Big Box Store and bought a few things in bulk, then picked up a prescription for Hotter and came home to find an e-mail from one of the temp agencies I work with asking if I was free for a couple of jobs next week, and neither of them conflicted with Freelance-y Gig so DOUBLE YAY! Then, as if that wasn't enough, the OTHER temp agency I work with called to ask if I would be interested in doing a "mystery shopper" gig where I get to judge the performances of several people in the professional field I just spent eight years in. JUDGING FORMER COMPETITORS FOR MONEY? YES, PLEASE, HELL I'D DO THAT FOR FREE! I refrained for mentioning that little detail and just said I'd love to...
   Also, for today's final bit of win, you will NEVER guess what greeted me outside of Freelance-y Gig today:
 Figure One: I have no idea what this tree's deal is, but it makes me inexplicably happy that I get to see it again on a regular basis and you can bet I'll be trying to find out!
title: smile and the world smiles with you?

body:
*   Sorry about the pity party yesterday. I know it's not fun to read that kind of post, but I think I needed to get it off my chest. Thank you all from the bottom of my black little heart for your kind words, comments, e-mails, and offers of help. It means a lot.
*   Work yesterday was good. I would have been grateful for the hours even if it had sucked, but I honestly enjoy working food service and prefer to be busy (makes the time pass!) so yesterday was right up my alley (I worked concessions at a large event at an upscale venue with a full kitchen and a chef on duty, so it was fast food but also some fancy stuff). And hey, at the end of the night the employees got to take what we could carry before they threw everything pre-made out, so I came home with several burgers, a big bag of fried chicken tenders, and a bunch of soft pretzels, which meant that the MFA Children greeted me like a benevolent goddess :)
*   Unfortunately, I started sneezing halfway through my shift. I blamed the popcorn machine and its incessant fumes and practiced good hand hygeine, but woke up full-blown SICK with a NEW effing cold. FML.
*   Also one of the dogs has diarrhea.
*   Also we're out of a lot of things, like garbage bags and bread (and also yeast for baking more bread), which is making everyone cranky.
*   Also Hotter, who is the Best Husband Evar 99.99% of the time, decided to have a full-blown adult tantrum when we woke up to a child who had peed his bed and pajamas and the aforementioned dog with diarrhea, because "I NEVER GET TO SLEEP IN! I WISH JUST ONCE THAT I WOULD GET TO SLEEP IN, GOD DAMMIT!" I pointed out that I kind of wished I wasn't sick, or exhausted from being on my feet for twelve hours yesterday, and that the child in question would quit wetting the bed and also that money would fall from the sky instead of snow (IN LATE MARCH. IN THE SOUTH. THE HELL, NATURE???) but we don't always get what we wish for in life. His response was less than cheerful (understatement of the year) and I think I'm on my own with Things Household today, which is fine, I mean it was like that before I married him, but given the timing and the fact that I'm way sick it does chafe a bit. Oh well.
*   There are umpteen chickens and four ducklings and two dogs and three children waiting on me to fulfill their every (NUMEROUS) need, which given the state of the cupboards is going to require quite a lot of smoke and mirrors on my part, so I guess I'd better get on that. Ugh. Bleh. Grr. Hmph. 
*   And how are all of YOU?

body: I don't have a whole lot to say, because I am still at the tail-end of the autoimmune "bleh." I woke up, however, to Hotter cupping my cheek and smiling and saying he wasn't pissed, so that was nice. It was also more than a little confusing, given the events of yesterday, but we talked and he explained that it was more the situation that had pissed him off, and I can certainly understand that. If I wasn't a mostly angerless robot I'd probably be pretty pissed off, myself, but it takes a lot for me to get angry, nevermind realize that I've gotten angry. Sometimes I think that's a superior way to be and other times not so much, because I tend to take a lot more shit than the average person. I dunno. I also tend to dish OUT a lot LESS shit than the average person, which I suppose is good, but not particularly fair in that being a nice person and five dollars will get you a cup of coffee at Starbucks and not much else in life.***   I'm going to do a batch of Shebangarang barbecue sauce tomorrow to get an idea of quantities in order to post the recipe (I'm one of those cooks who does it all by eyeballs and intuition, which works beautifully for ME but isn't much help when someone wants the recipe for something I've made). Don't forget to enter the spice giveaway! If you've already entered you can always get another entry by tweeting about it and leaving a second comment with the link to your tweet.***   This isn't much by way of a segue or ending, but I also have to replace our crockpot, which came to grief by Hotter's hand (and yes, if you are keeping score at home this is the SECOND one he's killed since we've been married--perhaps as a chef slow-cookers threaten him?). Do any of you have one you are particularly in love with and would recommend? I was awfully fond of the last one, which was a Hamilton Beach, but since I'm having to buy another one and y'all always have such good input for me I figured I'd see what you thought.
