title: we have a winner!

body:
Remember when I said we had some money coming to us in August, but that I wasn't certain of whether we'd actually see any/all of it or not? Well, so far so good! We're scheduled to receive the money in a total of thirteen installments over six months, and so far we've received two of those. I'm not thrilled with the idea of using this money for anything besides socking away a nestegg to replace the MFA Minivan when it goes to the big junkyard in the sky, but the fact of the matter is there are a lot of broken things and things we've been doing without that have been making us feel pretty deprived at best (and downright bitter/in pain at worst). So here, in no particular order, are some of the things we've replaced, fixed, or caught up on recently, either because we had to or because I decided the improvement in our quality of life was worth the expenditure:
*   For the first time in many moons, none of our utilities are currently in danger of getting shut off.*   I replaced that part that Hotter was losing his mind over the other day.*   I ordered the parts for our crockpot.*   We've got a blender on the way; ours bit the dust a couple of months ago and I didn't want to replace it with a cheap piece of crap that wouldn't suit our needs (I use the blender for the usual stuff but also to blend things to put through Little Child's g-tube...while it's no Vitamix, which is the one you often hear about in connection with home-made tube-feedings, because I just can't bring myself to spend that kind of money on a blender, the one I've ordered is sturdily-built and comes with a nice warranty so hopefully it'll be almost as good).*   Everybody in the house has the prescription drugs they need (I have been skimping on my Nexium and Mirapex, because while my quality of life suffers without them, I won't actually drop dead or anything serious, unlike with the other meds I take and pretty much all of Hotter's).*   The MFA Children's school supplies are all ordered and on the way.*   Both dogs are going to the vet today to get vaccines, and Isis's itchy ears, which haven't improved with use of the prescription cleaning solution from the vet or coconut oil, will be addressed.*   While it wasn't feasible immediately due to the time-sensitive things I had to address first (such as the utilities, the school supplies, the prescriptions, and the vet), the MFA Minivan will be getting COMPLETELY fixed after the first of the next month and having a much-needed oil-change.*   Hotter will be seeing a dentist for the first time in years, for dental issues that make me feel like a total dick for being upset about That Tooth (I do not plan on fixing That Tooth any time soon, because all of the above is costing way more than I wanted to spend of the restitution money and currently I am without a job, so we may need it to live on body:
Hotter read my last post and then very sensibly asked me if I'd ever checked to see if replacement parts were available for Hamilton Beach crockpots. And lo, they were available online, and there was great rejoicing, for The Peacemaker shall be resurrected! For those of you who didn't read that post, and/or are not inclined to click the link, I named our crockpot "The Peacemaker" when we did a little research while ordering chicks and discovered that our backyard would contain a veritable UN of poultry (Dutch Welsummers, Welsh Orpingtons, Chilean Araucanas, Australian Australorps, etc.).
   This is especially good news given that Loud and Crazy the turkey has been getting awfully belligerent with the other fowl; if he doesn't simmer the eff down he'll be simmering until tender! I'm hoping that his "window of belligerence" will slam shut on him before it comes to that (male turkeys are meek as poults and too big and bulky to be very quick or nimble compared to other poultry as ill-tempered adults; Loud and Crazy is at an in-between point where he's still pretty light on his feet and also has quite the nasty attitude) because he isn't very meaty as of yet and I think he'll be an impressive-looking critter when he's full-grown. We'll see though, because he's also taken to stalking me when I'm outside; he creeps up whenever my back is turned and then retreats when I face him. I don't know what he plans to do if he actually succeeds in sneaking up on me, but if involves any sort of "fowl play" we'll be having an early Thanksgiving! He's got 7-9 days of shipping time to get his act together...

body:
So I'm not thrilled with the Anthem situation, but honestly I probably agreed to let them do all of that crap and more when I signed up for the policy and it's not worth raising any real hell about. Right now I'm just kind of whipped. Beat-down. DONE. Like remember how I said I was a little short but could fix the Anthem situation after I get my next unemployment disbursement? Turns out the drugstore.com one (for stuff like plastic wrap and toilet paper and snack bags, nothing frivolous) hadn't, and gahhhh. The unemployment disbursement AFTER the next one won't hit my account in time to fix Anthem, and MAYBE the four-hour paid gig I have tomorrow night will (barely) solve things, except I have to put some gas in the MFA Minivan to get there and back, which might make the difference between "covering it and having nothing to spare for the next two weeks" and "geez, another three bucks would have done it, DAMN it," and I AM SO SICK OF THE CONSTANT SHELL-GAME. I'm sick of eating the pantry. I'm sick of covering my mouth when I laugh in public so people won't see the missing front tooth. I'm sick of telling Hotter and the kids no every time they want something, and second-guessing every yes, and feeling like relaxing in any little way is going to upset the apple cart (and being right about that).
   A lot of my frustration stems from the fact that this is largely my own damn fault. I didn't open mail from Anthem because I thought it was the usual "pay up, loser!" that I get every month for paying during the grace period instead of "on time." I'm the loser who can't manage to support her family with a frigging Master's degree. I'm the one who married poorly the first time around and had the three kids with the jerk who doesn't pay enough child support, and the one who doesn't make treating her ADD a priority thereby increasing the FAIL-factor exponentially, and the one who didn't live up to her potential; I'm the one who could teach a Master's-level course in Shooting Yourself In The Foot. I'm doing all of the right things that I can for right now. I'm applying for every job within reasonable driving distance that I'm even remotely qualified to perform. I'm eating, sleeping, and exercising as I'm able, and after the first of the month I'll even call my shrink and make an appointment to get back on the ADD meds. I'm still failing, HARD, but I'm trying to fail better.
   Somebody tell me a funny? I could use a laugh.

body:
*   Biz asked me about my willingness to eat ham. Well, see this is one of the main reasons (besides non-belief in higher powers) that I identify as a "lapsed cultural Jew." Judaism is both a culture and an ancient Abrahamic religion (oh yes, it's not the only one), and my father was (allegedly; it's complicated) the first atheist in the line. We were KINDA Jewish. We celebrated Passover and Hannukah and Purim, but had a Christmas tree and ate pork and mixed meat and dairy. We bought a box of matzoh for Passover but also usually had chametz in the house. I took bagels to school in my lunchbox before bagels were a "thing" (oh yes, America is a Bagel Culture now, but hasn't always been), but don't speak more than a smattering of Yiddish. Since I don't believe in the god of the Hebrews, Leviticus doesn't dictate what I eat, although I have an uneasiness about eating pork that I sometimes think might be some kind of "cultural memory." I also cannot--CANNOT--bring myself to even sample most shellfish and seafood. I've overcome the pork thing thanks to bacon (mmm...delicious bacon) and ham, and have been known to eat and love casino-style clams while anemic, but would walk out of a dinner party before I'd put an oyster in my mouth. I'm weird.
*   Several of you expressed a real desire to know just how Hotter gets so many ticks in his fun-zone, so I asked him:
MFA Mama: The people want to know what's up with the ticks on your junk. Do you have any official comment?Hotter: Tell them it's ATTRACTIVE JUNK!
*   ...
*   Nobody ACTUALLY asked, but I am not at work currently because I'm sick. Fever, chills, body aches and wheezing with productive cough. Blehhh...I think I'm going to try to call in sick to court tomorrow. It's THAT BAD. At least if the judge issues a bench warrant I'll have free healthcare in The Stony Lonesome, right?
*   How are all of YOU?

body:
*   My father used to play the spoons while he was hovering over the stove (he was a chef, too, haha go ahead and say it) and sing a song whose proper title and lyrics I do not rightly know, but "hambone" was the protagonist and one line went "hambone went to the grocery store" and then there was ham and then the bone and then bean soup, etc. accompanied by rhythmic side-slapping and spoon-clicking, and often much bug-eyed face-making. His thyroid was overactive for much of my childhood, and he could make bug-eyes like nobody's business. Anyway, I digress: "hambone's" final stop here at Casa MFA is the layer pen (Paul and the grown-up laying hens and the "Nuggets 1.0" are in there). I really should have taken another video. Hotter and I watched one of the old Barred Rock hens meticulously pick the marrow from the end of the hambone for several minutes and just about laughed ourselves sick. Chickens are not nice.
*   Hotter tore enough of the skin off of his shins in his most recent man vs. well-cap adventure that even I was kind of impressed. I kept on eating my macaroni and cheese and leftover ham pickings, because I've gotten kind of shellshocked into not giving a shit about anything short of a dead body, and sent him to shower and fetch the tweezers and bandaging stuff. I don't know if my cleaning and bandaging abilities and level of preparedness is more awesome (WHOO! PUT ANY SEVERED BITS IN A BAGGIE AND THEN ICE TO PRESERVE VIABILITY FOR REATTACHMENT, KIDDIES!) or pathetic (that I am so used to blood and such that it no longer even interrupts my dinner), but I am seriously thinking of buying Hotter some shinguards.
*   I have to go to court tomorrow and am looking forward to it about as much as I do my next round of un-numbed dental work (no, not even soon, but SOMEday). It's for being too poor to pay a county tax, not anything to do with the MFA Children, but still. Same complex, same pool of judges as I've dealt with on many unhappy occasions due to the XY, same pre-court GI unrest. Bleh. This is especially awesome (no, not really) in that the child support check was a bit late and hasn't cleared so my story will essentially be "nope, still haven't taken care of that, yes, I know, six months, disgraceful, but the funds are PENDING so--"...yeah. I'll be lucky if I'm not thrown in jail for contempt.
*   For the first time in a loooong time I'd love a cigarette. Don't worry, I won't. Just saying. Effing poverty. Effing XY. EFFING COURT.
*   Our innernet was off for two days and Hotter managed not to snap at ME (he did thoroughly bawl out a bank manager for telling him the same thing I had tried to tell him about a common bank policy, but hey it wasn't me and I didn't hear it, being in the MFA Minivan with the kids, so YAY). That's the good news. The bad news is, he has every reason to lose his junk right now in light of some unbloggability, so bleh to that. He's MOSTLY forgiven for his earlier transgression; honestly I'm too tired to even be mad at him about it anymore. What did I miss while I was away?

body:
Those of you who are facespace friends or follow me on the Twitter may have been wondering whatever happened with the missing Jersey Giant. So were we, and Hotter and I set out to beat bushes and search the property (if she'd been carried off by something, the dogs and the other fowl would have been raising a ruckus, plus the Jersey Giants are about the least carry-off-able things out there besides the turkeys). 
   We came up empty-handed.
   Those of you who are facespace friends or follow me on the Twitter are also aware that the new duck, Uncle Quacker...well, he's a rapist. Originally when he was humping the chickens we thought he was just confused, but we've since decided he's just a plain old equal-opportunity sexual predator. He's raped the ducks, he's raped the chickens, he's RAPIN' ERRYBODY OUT THERE!
   Just as Hotter and I were admitting defeat, we heard a hell of a commotion coming from a thicket, and at first I thought Uncle Quacker was stuck head-down, because there was a duck-foot sticking up out of the bushes flapping back and forth. "Ehhh, he looks like he's fuckin' something," Hotter noted. "DAMMIT, UNCLE QUACKER," I bellowed, yanking him up and out of the bush by the foot, and...THERE WAS THE MISSING JERSEY GIANT! I scooped her up to check for injuries and underneath her were eleven eggs. She'd made a perfect chicken-sized hollow in the thicket and cushioned it with torn-out feathers on which she'd deposited her clutch.
   So the mystery is solved, thanks to the resident duck-rapist, who is still at large, and we're keeping the Jersey Giants locked up for a bit (we discarded the eggs--we don't want any chicks right now because we've got all the layers we need and are planning a pre-winter cull soon). Poultry. They're assholes!

body:
Pop quiz! Your children are playing outside and one of them runs inside screaming that a dog is killing one of your chickens. Do you:
A) Do nothing. Fuck the chicken! Nature red in tooth and claw FTW!B) Go outside and use your words to try and talk the dog (who is not yours) out of eating your chicken, because if you did anything more than that PETA and the Anonymous Twat Brigade on Twitter might have a problem with it (horrors!).C) Go out there and do whatever it takes, up to and including punching the dog in the head, to keep your chicken from getting eaten in front of your children.
   Those of you who follow me on the Twitter already know which option I chose.
   Apparently a certain innernet shit-disturber of minor reknown whose cadre of friends and alteregos once raked me over the coals for trying to SAVE MY DOG'S LIFE felt the need to retweet me and then devote a further three tweets to smack-talking me over punching a dog to get it to let go of a chicken (which hey, they're entitled to their opinion, although probably if I'd tweeted "hey I just watched a dog eat a chicken!" they would've gone crying to PETA over THAT; there's really just no pleasing some people, ESPECIALLY on the innernet).
   In the grand scheme of Things Happening In My Life, getting scolded by an anonymous asshole on the Twitter for going with Option C is VERY SMALL POTATOES. When you look at current world news, probably we're ALL assholes for tweeting anything other than "Text REDCROSS to 09000 to give $10 to earthquake relief in Japan, please RT," and I kind of just have to laugh at this, but since the anonymous asshole in question is friends with Stalky I'm sticking comments back on moderation for a bit just in case.

Thanks to Crystal Light for sponsoring this post. To learn more about how Crystal Light can flavor your day with 30 refreshing flavors, visit http://www.facebook.com/crystallight.
   Up until very recently, I worked from home as a freelance contracter, which...well. The best thing about working from home and the worst thing about working from home are one and the same:
   You're right there if anyone needs you.
   With three children who have various special needs, a bionic husband with two donor organs, a job, and the firm desire to remain in possession of my remaining mental faculties (I think at least ten percent of my brain exited my body with each placenta and a further twenty percent burned up in leaving the atmosphere of my first marriage), I have become an expert at unconventional forms of relaxation.
   Y'all already know that I have a very special relationship with my lawnmower, and that she is named after my favorite guided imagery guru. But that's not all I use my iPod for! I also have a Very Special Playlist that I only listen to when the MFA Children are not at home, packed full of some of the raunchiest, most vile and profane rap and hip-hop with a smattering of Dutch trance and industrial noise, and...here is where those of you with any remaining respect for my dignity as a person should look away...I SING ALONG TO IT LOUDLY, AND WITH FEELING as I go about my chores.
   See, I get time away from my kids when they are at school or with their father, and I get plenty of time at home with Hotter, but what I almost never get (and usually never want...usually) is time ALONE. Time where I don't have to worry if someone in the next room is asking me where something is, or whether I feel like having a snack, or if we're out of raspberry preserves. I suppose I could listen to some happy hippie music (I usually go for the Indigo Girls, Paula Cole, Blues Traveler, Don McLean, etc.) but then I think Hotter would be more likely to tap me on the shoulder and ask me to take my earbuds out.
   FACT: Nobody taps the girl spitting rhymes about finding some West Coast [kitty word] for her Detroit playas on the shoulder to inquire whether a shirt looks too small for the youngest child. It's just not done.
   I don't have to rely on Mommy's Bad Fun Playlist as much now that I'm getting out of the house now and then for work, but if I ever need to have a very special, very LOUD moment of Zen, my inner gangsta is only a shuffle away. So go ahead, come on over to borrow a cup of sugar, but if I open the door with my earbuds in and scream "TO THE WINDOWWWWW," then point to you? The correct response would be "TO THE WALL!"
 
Remember, visit http://www.facebook.com/crystallight to learn more about how Crystal Light can flavor your day with 30 refreshing flavors. I was selected and paid for this sponsorship by the Clever Girls Collective, which endorses Blog With Integrity, as I do.
title: how to be less approachable when you need a moment (sponsored)

body:
*   On court: I just couldn't get moving in time for court. I have a combination of "fever, aches, and upper-respiratory lurgy," "back that has gone from 'walking wounded' to 'you're not leaving the house today' overnight," and Terribly Sore Tits and it wasn't happening. I called in sick the minute the clerk's office opened, explaining that I wanted to appear before the judge and see if he would dismiss this but was too ill. "I'll ask him...you can call back later," she said. "Should I leave my phone number?" I asked. "No, nobody's going to call YOU," she said, and hung up. Awesome! Not! Still, "called in sick" probably sounds better than "almost got it straight in time" and the check has (of course, NOW) cleared and worst-case scenario I get automatically found guilty in absentia and fined as I might have anyway even if present, but without getting yelled at by an MFA County judge (oh I've had one literally kick the bench and bang on it with his fist AND his gavel--you never know what the crazy emm-effers will up and do, hi ho!). That would suck but I'd avoid a trip to the courts complex, and I'd almost be relieved. Hopefully they reschedule it, but either way I'll be okay with it I guess (until the night before any potential make-up court date, probably).
*   On Middle Child's birthday: oh yes, happy birthday, Middly! I don't know why catastrophic events (like his parents splitting up, on TWO out of seven to date, yes the XY and I did it to him TWICE! And court dates! And police presence!) always have to fall on your big day. Poor kid! Your request for my all-day chili and a very special cake made me glad I stayed home and slept last night, because otherwise I wouldn't have had it in me to pull it off. Court-date and illness/injury aside, the XY has been practicing lousy communication skills and Hotter is treading hazardously close to mah verra last nerve and I kind of want to crawl back in bed until Sunday at the soonest. But dinner and dessert tonight will be excellent if it's the last thing I ever do...
*   On the poultry: Hotter and I moved the pens today, and I have officially Seen Everything. I was waiting on Zombie Hen to lay her egg (I needed four room-temperature eggs for the cake, which is this recipe, but with cream cheese and milk instead of buttermilk, which I cannot stand) and kept finding her sitting, but no egg. The last time I checked I opened the hutch to find Paul the rooster sitting on the nest. He growled at me, sounding rather impressively savage, then flew up out the open roof-panel revealing Zombie Hen's egg, which he'd been keeping warm. I...huh. Well then. Hoookey-dokey. Freaky-assed birds!

I  hate dogs. No, actually I kinda hate chickens more. Wait, SICK MEN are  the wor--ah, fuck it, EVERYTHING UP IN THIS PIECE BUT THE DUCKLINGS IS  GOING TO DIE.*
   I'm running out of things to plant and places to dig. Currently I have planted, in addition to what I've already mentioned:
   German Chamomile   Curly Parsley   a TON of wheatgrass   more radishes   a striped bed of alternating spinach and arugula that ought to be quite fetching   several large planters of mixed salad greens   broccoli   artichokes (no idea whether they'll do okay here but...ARTICHOKES!)   more peas (sugar snaps and shell-peas)   bush limas (the closest I could find to true butterbeans, DAMMIT--if any of you could get me some Carolina Sieva seedstock for love, money, blog-pimping or sexual  other favors please leave a comment and let me know!) under cover   Royalty Purple Pod beans (string beans whose pods are imperial purple until you cook or blanch them, at which point they look like any other string beans--they're very easy to spot when picking and can also go in the ground well ahead of any other type I've ever grown), also under cover (mostly so the chickens don't eat the seeds)   Lavender    Marquesa onions
*   The MFA Children are with their father('s girlfriend) this weekend, so two of them are exempt. Yes, only TWO of them, because Big Child lost his everloving mind on St. Patrick's day and did something that...well let's just say that I do not practice corporal punishment (except on dogs in moments of life-or-death for assorted small stock, GAWD, still waiting for PETA to hunt me down...) nor am I a violent person but reader, I won't lie, after the St. Paddy's Day MFA Massacree I could absolutely have cut a switch and WORN IT OUT on a child were that sort of thing permissible and had said child not craftily escaped on the schoolbus (leaving his little victim behind sobbing in a ditch full of dirty storm runoff). But that's not how I roll. So instead Big Child got to transcribe letters that I dictated to both his beloved teacher and his father explaining that he had made a TERRIBLE choice and was in HUGE TROUBLE and done something that could have really harmed his little brother WHO WAS JUST SICK IN THE HOSPITAL, and then lied about a set of events that four child witnesses and one independent adult witness pinned UNEQUIVOCALLY on him, and they ought to therefore keep a VERY close eye on him and report any further incidents directly to me, POSTHASTE. And I haven't EVEN decided how long he's grounded for because that fool then kept his victim (who sleeps in the bottom bunk of their beds) up urging him to come and tell me it hadn't been Big Child's fault, and as I explained, IT IS AGAINST THE GENEVA CONVENTION to deprive even SUSPECTED TERRORISTS of food, sleep, or bathroom privileges. Big Child said he was going to call the police and tell them he didn't feel safe in my house if I was going to ground him, too, and they'd take him away and...well, I very calmly and pleasantly asked just where he thought the police would take him given that a gaggle of witnesses was willing to testify that he had arranged to board the schoolbus with his one brother and leave the other standing in filthy runoff up to his armpits in forty-degree weather, and then I sent all three MFA Children on their way with the XY, but...yeah. Someone's cleaning the chicken run Monday. Middle Child, bless him, immediately said "I forgive you Big Child, dat was a good letter, Mommy I forgived him!" I. HAVE. NOT.

body:
So the Great Big Unbloggable (what gives, Ides of March? Why you gotta do me like that every goddamn year?) was related to money.
   I don't like to talk very much about money on here, because I don't want people to think I'm playing a tiny violin to fill my tip jar. That is not why I keep this little blog, and while y'all bailed my arse out in a BIG WAY one time when I asked, I would never want to lean on you like that outside of a life-or-death situation (which that was, for my dog, which is still a very first-world problem but oh well, we do love her and she's doing great now). But I also don't think I could have told y'all just HOW BAD it was without some of you wanting to help, and I am not the type to NOT say thank you, and that? Is troll-bait, and the recent thaw has brought them out of hibernation and they're lumbering around the blogosphere right now RAVENOUS and trying to pass the plug of their own fur that they eat prior to denning up for the winter, so it's not a good idea to feed them right now (or really EVER) lest their constipation resolve ALL OVER YOUR COMMENTS SECTION.
   So anyway yeah, we got three VERY BAD and SERIOUSLY MAJOR pieces of financial news RIGHT ON TOP OF EACH OTHER (my getting fired was the first, the second is something I never blog about, and the third is on Hotter's end of the ledger, which I also don't care to discuss) and it was BAD. It still IS bad, but it's on the way back to good, because I have discovered that it's entirely possible to have your cake and eat it too, job-wise. I do not have steady, predictable employment, nor do I have any solid prospects on that, but I DO have several small gigs going on at once that seem like they just might cumulatively save our arses (one I've mentioned, one is private freelancing in my former career field thanks to the FACESPACE, of all things, another is sorta-volunteer-but-also-pays-in-barter, you saw the sponsored post earlier, and I have an interview for a second freelance-y thing tomorrow). And y'know, it's hell on the nerves and taxes next year will probably be an unholy nightmare, but it's also oddly exhilarating.
   I'm about two weeks away from being able to exhale completely, and the whole house of cards could still topple, but it's looking up and I think we can safely STAND DOWN and relax in my little corner of the world. Which is a very good thing. Because I have some really fun things to tell y'all (not least of which being how VERY COOL pet ducklings are).
   And how are all of YOU?

body:
*   This morning, on the way to my job interview, my front (fake, dead, root-canaled all to HELL and back) tooth kind of exploded. I don't know if I was gritting my teeth in traffic (doubtful; usually I clench in my sleep and so I wear a mouthguard for that but I have been under a wee smidge more than usual of stress) or whether, as one of y'all suggested on the Twitter, someone (or several someones?) has an MFA Mama voodoo doll or...well who knows. I don't guess in matters. It sucks.
*   I felt like a total jerk for having a hissy fit in my minivan over my stupid tooth (thank you to those of you who offered sympathy on the Twitter, by the way) when I arrived at my interview and found that the lady interviewing me had apparently been burned over most of her body at some point in time; every visible inch of her was scarred. She was awesome though; we chatted for quite a while over this and that and laughed a lot and I got the job. First paid gig for THIS employer will be Tax Day. Boo to nothing sooner! Also, I have to locate a tuxedo shirt (a white button-down will not do) that will fit across my tits, preferably for less than I'll make my first night working. Ideas?
*   I worked at the Hippie Food Coop for a bit today since they are located within three miles of the place where I had the job interview, and that was a lot of fun. I did two signs for them (one in dry-erase markers, one in liquid chalk), with some silly little drawings folks there seemed to think were a hoot. Yay! I'm always in a better mood for having spent some time at the Hippie Food Coop, and I returned home with some cosmetically-challenged organic potatoes, spaghetti and butternut squashes, turnips, and apples.
*   I made cheesy garlic-mashed potatoes and turnips, enough to have twice, and froze half. I also made an apple pie and have enough cut, sugared, and spiced apples for another in a Mason jar in the fridge, because today was VERY humid and horrid weather to roll pie crust in.
*   DUCKLINGS!
*   So tired...I feel like there's more I should be telling y'all, but...meh. Good night :)

That's the beauty of connective tissue disease, though: you don't HAVE to actually hurt yourself! Sometimes you get a random and sometimes even devastating injury for NO GOOD REASON! Ugh, I'm sick. My sinuses and left ear are very unhappy and my lungs, attention-whores that they are, have jumped in on the action. So far I'm resting, drinking, ingesting unholy amounts of garlic and vitamins C and D, using my neti pot, and uh, while *I* didn't borrow the dog's antiseptic ear wash, because who would DO that, I can see how one might be tempted to do such a thing in my shoes.

*   So remember how I was just all "WHOO, KLOUT!" a couple of days ago? I like it less now, as you may already know if you follow me on the Twitter. See, Klout wants you to link up all of your social media accounts so it can accurately tell how important you are, and I went ahead and connected it to the facespace, and then OMFG KLOUT PUT MY FULL NAME AND PICTURE UP FOR THE WHOLE EFFING INNERNET TO SEE! I changed my name back to MFA Mama but couldn't for the life of me get rid of the picture, even when I went so far as to change my facespace profile picture to something anonymous and reconnect Klout and finally I said EFF THIS, WHO CARES and put my face on my Twitter avatar for like, seven minutes or something. During which my Klout profile picture changed back to the horns of anonymity. So I changed Twitter back, too. If this isn't in the DSM-V someone should probably get on that, no? Oy.
*   Natasha is ALLEGEDLY a rooster, y'all. I say allegedly because ACCORDING TO HOTTER AND BIG CHILD she is crowing. I have not seen or heard this; reportedly her crow sounds very pitiful and weak. If in fact she IS crowing then I am not surprised, as she's been humping the heck out of the other pullets. No, in case you were wondering, we're NOT going to change her name or even adjust our pronoun usage. She's the one who wanted to be all "SURPRISE!" and now won't even crow in front of me, so WHATEVER, NATASHA.
 Figure One: "Look at meeee, I'm Natasha, I suffer from gender-confusion and pathological shyness!"
*   The damn turkey still won't puff up for me, either.
 Figure Two: The one in front is the alleged male. His "head-herpes," as Hotter calls it, is very pale in this picture. If you piss him off, it gets bright red. Turkeys are really difficult to photograph, which is why you don't see more turkey pictures. This is one of like, fifty pictures I took and one of the only ones where the turkey isn't half out of the damn frame or under a bush. Turkeys are dicks like that.
*   There's a squirrel in the neighborhood that's out to get me. I do the organic gardening thing, and Rodale's Guide suggests that if squirrels are biting into your tomatoes, they're just after the moisture. Because they're thirsty. And therefore if you provide them with a convenient water source from which to drink they will leave your tomatoes alone. 
 Figure Three: I call bullshit, Rodale. This squirrel is clearly just an asshole. I leave water out for it, and I wouldn't even begrudge it a tomato or two, because hey, squirrels get hungry too, BUT NO. It has to take a couple of bites out of EVERY SINGLE ONE, and then I don't even like to use them for sauce because I don't know how plant circulation works, but probably the whole fruit is contaminated by squirrel spit, and Hotter is immunosuppressed. Maybe the chickens put the squirrel up to it, since they get the bitten tomatoes. IT'S A CONSPIRACY.
*   So yeah. All of that plus the fact that I'm having my usual post-bacterial-infection autoimmune flare (the four horses of my own personal apocalypse: fatigue, depression, muscle pain EVERYWHERE and easy bruising) make me a very sad panda (although on the bright side, the autoimmune flare would seem to indicate that the antibiotics were, in fact, warranted). How are all of YOU?

But the bleakest depression on top of everything else, despite being on a big-gun antidepressant at a dose that would make Eeyore grin like the village idiot? Patently unfair.

Because since arriving here he's tried to hump several. I can't even really laugh at that, and honestly? It was a piece of glass, and what finally ousted it was a box-cutter and a needle (I figured why not try YET ANOTHER home surgery on the thing, since I'm currently on antibiotics) (also it was under a really thick callus, hence the box-cutter--I'm not THAT hardcore! Didn't even bleed). I would totally be posting a picture, except when I finally got the point of the needle under the thing and pulled it literally POPPED out of my foot, flew through the air sparkling, and hit the floor somewhere. I couldn't find it. Probably I'll step on it again with the OTHER foot and it'll be with us for ANOTHER holiday season.
*   As those of you who follow me on the Twitter or are a facespace friend already know, Natasha still has us guessing as to her gender (I'm using female pronouns because we always have for her and probably always will, even if she starts crowing). It turns out the white egg was from a duck (we know this because we separate the ducks at night and they lay very early) and now Natasha is vigorously...topping...the other pullets. But still no crowing. And no fighting with Paul. Aren't cocks supposed to fight, or is it like pitbulls where they mostly just do it because they're treated badly/trained that way? Perhaps Paul is just extremely tolerant (he is from San Francisco, after all). Or maybe Natasha is intersexed? Natasha the transrooster, y'all! 
*   Not all of our poultry are so tolerant, though. Loud and Crazy the turkey has developed quite a hatred toward the ducks. He even hunts them all stalk-i-ty like. If he gets any more violent toward them he may have to Go To His Reward before Thanksgiving. Fortunately we'd still have two turkeys if it comes to that. He's pretty scrappy though, so if/when I do him in I think I'm going to have to sneak up on him while he's roosting and drop a sack over him like Borat did to Pamela Anderson. I was talking to Morgan about this on gchat and she was like "oh emm gee, what would I have to do to talk you into vlogging that?!?" I was like "ugh, then I'd have to wear a mask, and the only ones I have are my kids' play ones, and I'd be That Crazy Lady Who Snuck Up On The Turkey In The Darth Vader Head." Which didn't make her any less excited about the idea. Quite the contrary.
*   How are all of YOU?

body:
I went to work last night, and didn't get stabbed.
   It was still a shitty evening. Scarface was thoroughly unpleasant at every possible opportunity, making ugly comments every chance she got and spending much of the shift standing around doing nothing but watch me. It started to unhinge me a little. I was so angry! WHY? I haven't done anything to this woman! Why should I stew in this fury, and be afraid to go into the cameras' blind spots? Why, I kept asking myself, is she doing this? WHY ME?
   On the way home it came to me, something I've been told on numerous occasions but never fully believed (because I'm so good at blaming myself): some people are just deeply unhappy with their lives, and looking for a target. I know, some of you are probably all "no shit, Sherlock!" but it took an encounter with someone like Scarface who doesn't even arguably have a reason to hate my guts, someone with whom I have NO history of ANY kind to cloud things, to help me recognize and accept this. The only way Scarface "wins" is if she makes me miserable, and that's exactly what all of the anger has been doing. I finally believe, in my gut (and thanks in part to the people who remind me from time to time), that I don't deserve what she and others like her are dishing out, that the people I care about think highly of me, and that I am good worker.
   I don't let anger out easily, because rigid self-control is my own peculiar form of rebellion against the people who raised me (thanks to the efforts over multiple years of a Harvard-trained therapist I can usually RECOGNIZE anger now, but that's about all), and I don't truly hate anyone enough to damage my own life by unleashing on them in grand style (I have, in the past, and I can honestly say that I regret it, if only because I don't like the person that even righteous anger turns me into). And punching pillows and such just feels silly. Maybe, though, rather than casting it out amid loudness and commotion, it's better to just set anger outside like a bin of recycling, knowing that it's served all the purpose it's ever going to in my life.
   Tonight, the first time Scarface tries to start with me, rather than continuing to ignore her (which isn't working) or saying anything ugly back, I'm going to smile. And tell her I'm sorry she has so much hate in her heart, but it's okay, I forgive her, and better me than someone who has to be in her life for longer than one more day, because I'm not going to let the ugliness change me. She's probably going to think I'm crazy, and maybe I am, but if she keeps it up after that it says more about her than it does about me. Worst-case scenario, she goes ballistic on me, which she might do anyway, and at least there'd be witnesses who would have to say I wasn't asking for it or anything.
   And while I'm at it, since I know she's reading, Stalky? I forgive you. Thank you for reminding me what a useless and toxic and UGLY thing anger is, and helping me arrive at the point of realizing that one of the most satisfying feelings in life is to lay it down and walk away. I hope you have a good time at BlogHer, if you really do end up going, and if you spend your entire time there talking smack about me, then that's okay. The people who matter to me aren't going to think any less of me because of you, and the quality of my work means you can't really threaten my livelihood. So, you know, go on ahead if it makes you feel better, and spares your husband and children and the other people who have to deal with you on a regular basis even a little from the rough side of your tongue: I wish you peace, and physical healing, and mental stability. If not for your own sake, then for theirs. If you want to continue doing what you do that's not about me, and now I can finally see that it never was.

body:
So the garden this year is kind of "meh." It's doing OKAY. The corn is a total write-off, and I'm starting to think that corn just doesn't grow well in our soil. The beans are producing, but not much. We've had a lot of fabulous salads, and gotten tomatoes (from the plants I grew from seed and the ones from The Botanical Garden) in dribs and drabs...this is partly the fault of my work-schedule and partly the fault of the weather and partly just that we're still working out the kinks in growing things here (I grew up in the area, but my ancestral home had completely different soil).
   We've also gotten a handful of tomatoes from the ones the chickens "planted" (we used to have their enclosure up by the house, but moved it to the very back of the property when Paul arrived so that his crowing would be minimally obnoxious to the neighbors--at some point the original MFA Flock had some tomato scraps to eat and pooped a bunch of seeds out, and we quit mowing in that spot after I recognized the plants). The plants have always looked better than the lovingly caged, watered, and weeded ones I cultivated, but the yield was about the same and I was starting to think Casa MFA was just built on cursed ground...until today. I was parting the very long grass around the "wild tomatoes" to pick the last few cherry tomatoes on a cluster (that's what most of the "wild" ones are, although there's at least one that's growing HUUUUUGE tomatoes; none of those have ripened yet but they are much larger than my fists) when it occurred to me that maybe there were more of them hidden from view. So I started parting the grass here and there and...HOLY MOSES!
   I brought in about three pounds of cherry tomatoes, and that's not counting the split ones (which I threw to the poultry)!
   So I've been outgardened by a bunch of gallinaceous fowl with brains the size of lentils, and next year instead of starting seeds indoors, nurturing them with great care, transplanting them outside, staking and fertilizing the plants, watering daily, etc. I might just take a dump in the yard.
title: the one where I'm out-gardened by a bunch of gallinaceous fowl

body:
I've been buying these totally awesome spice blends from the Hippie Food Coop for a while now, and out of the blue I decided to write to the lady who created them and ask about doing a review/giveaway. She responded enthusiastically, and I am just SO tickled to be able to do this, because my family is completely addicted to these products and now I get to share the goodness with one of YOU! I'll be posting recipes throughout the next week and on Friday, August 19th I'll be picking a winner via random.org.
   This is Jen. In addition to helping run a farm (including a CSA program!) and raise a family, Jen makes incredible flavors in the form of spice blends and all-natural lollipops. I've had her lollipops and they are TO DIE FOR, but the spice blends, believe it or not, are even better. Because you can use them any way you want to jazz up a favorite recipe or, in my case, get your kid who has been tube-fed for most of his life to EAT MORE (oh yes, Little Child is a Bangarang addict--he seems to prefer stronger flavors for some reason and likes to spice up his food). Jen herself described her four spice blends to me in an e-mail as "a flavor flight, from sweet to heat," and I really couldn't put it any better myself!
   Shebang, which is Little Child's favorite, is a spiced sugar blend with ginger, cinnamon, cardamom, and cloves. I could pretty much eat the stuff out of the jar, but it's also excellent in baked goods, coffee, on hot buttered toast or popcorn...you get the idea. It's a key ingredient in my Zucchini-Carrot Bread, which (here is where I fail modesty) is the best veggie bread I've ever had. It's crazy how good this stuff is! And because I am a giver, I'm going to share the recipe with y'all.  
MFA Mama's Crazy-good Zucchini-Carrot Bread
Ingredients:three cups all-purpose flourone teaspoon saltone teaspoon baking sodaone teaspoon baking powdertwo and a half teaspoons cinnamonone tablespoon Shebangthree duck eggs one cup coconut oiltwo cups sugarthree teaspoons vanilla extractone and a half cups finely-grated zucchinitwo large carrots, peeled and finely-grated one cup chopped pecans (optional)1. Preheat your oven to 325 degrees and grease two loaf pans.2. Sift or whisk dry ingredients EXCEPT for nuts (if you're using them), sugar and Shebang together and set aside.3. Beat eggs, coconut oil, vanilla, sugar, and Shebang in a large mixing bowl. 4. Add the premixed dry ingredients in several batches, beating as you go.5. Stir in the zucchini, carrot, and nuts if you're using any.6. Divide evenly into two loaf pans, sprinkle the tops with Shebang, and bake until a butterknife inserted into the loaves comes out clean (about 50 minutes). 
   This is a pretty forgiving recipe, and if you don't have any Shebang (although you should totally buy some, because it's THAT GOOD) you can use two and a quarter cups of sugar and three teaspoons of cinnamon (I guess you could also try adding tiny amounts of ginger, cardamom, and cloves if you wanted, too) and get a pretty good result. Coconut oil is kind of pricey, and while you won't get quite the same flavor or consistency, canola will work in a pinch. I use duck eggs because their higher protein and fat content produces a denser, richer cake-consistency than chicken eggs, but you can substitute three large chicken eggs if you can't find duck eggs for sale and that'll work, too.
   Next up: Shebangarang barbecue sauce, a.k.a. The Best Way To Dress Up Chicken Maybe EVER!
   To enter the giveaway, go and check out the entire Bangarang line and leave me a comment on this post saying which of the spice blends you'd most like to try. That's it! No facespace-liking, Twitter-following, or other hoops to jump through. Just pick the prize you'd most enjoy if random.org smiles on you on the 19th, and I'll draw a winner at noon on that day. You may garner up to ONE additional entry per day by tweeting this and leaving a SEPARATE COMMENT with a link to your tweet. Here is a sample tweet you can copy and paste if you like:
I just entered to win a kickass Bangarang spice-blend from @MFAMama and you can, too! http://bit.ly/q7SO1Y
 
I received one jar of each of the four Bangarang spices at no charge to review for the purpose of this giveaway. I am not being financially compensated for this or any other post relating to the Bangarang giveaway. All views I express on here are my own and do not represent the official viewpoints of Jennifer Lane or GreenHearts Farm.

body:
I don't know what to do, y'all. I am SO effing sick.
   It's the kind of sick where you seriously consider carrying a spit-cup around just so you don't have to swallow.
   My ears hurt. I spent all of last night alternately trying to wrap myself around Hotter, shivering, and moving to new spots of the bed because the sheets were too hot. I had an incredibly vivid, incredibly sad dream about finding someone's entire life-story in cast-off possessions in the gazebo on the beach that I was moving into. I woke up and cried for a couple of seconds, because that's totally going to be me, because I'm going to outlive my spouse and my children are going to resent me for being poor and OH MY GOD, WHERE WILL I LIVE WHEN I'M OLD AND CAN'T WORK AND HAVE NO ONE? In a gazebo on the beach, maybe?
   I think the fever is screwing with my mental health. I also think I may have forgotten to take my Pristiq yesterday. 
   I'm going to give it one more day, though, because between the cost of a co-payment, plus the co-pay for the only antibiotic I can really take without IV access due to allergies (hint: VERY EFFING EXPENSIVE, because OF COURSE IT IS), plus the co-pay for the only drug that works to treat the aftermath of taking antibiotics (ladies, y'all know what I'm talking about) going to the doctor would be $100, and I'm newly unemployed and don't have anything to cover that with right now except rubber checks.
   My life is kind of like a series of Hogarth's Engraving's, but with strep instead of syphilis. Except I'm pretty sure Hogarth never did a series on the sociopath's bankrupt ex-wife.
   Oh man, my head.

title: chicken updates

body:
So we now have a tank filled with:
   Two nine-day-old Welsummer pullets (Kristina and Rosa, after my Dutch friends)   One nine-day-old Americauna pullet ("Mer")   Two two-day-old Australorp pullets (Tiff and Nicole, as in Three-Ring Tiff and Ms. Kidman)   Two  two-day-old Russian Orloffs (from a straight run, so one or both could be male) (Boris and Natasha)   Two two-day-old Buff Orpington pullets (unnamed as of yet)   One two-day-old Red Sex Link (George II)
   All are happy and energetic except for one of the Orpingtons, which just isn't doing so well; it hasn't grown any (the others pretty much double in size daily--between the ten chicks, who collectively weigh PERHAPS half a pound, they consume roughly a pound of "starter feed" per day) and spends all of its time sprawled on its face (which sounds more alarming than it is--chicks all look remarkably dead when they sleep). When I cleaned the tank out it didn't get up, and, well, the situation looks rather dire.
   Hotter took a look at me crushing starter feed in a teaspoon with milk and sugar and drawing it up into a syringe and did a double-take. "Are you serious," he asked, which was a fair question. Usually I am the least soft-hearted person in the house.
   "Yes," I informed him balefully, forcing a drop into the chick's tiny beak, "I am serious. The TINY BABY CREATURE is FAILING TO THRIVE and MALNOURISHED, AND HISTORICALLY I HAVE A PROBLEM WITH THAT KIND OF THING."
   "Ah. Poor little thing," he said wisely, and left it at that.
   I know that in nature, sometimes things go wrong and tiny baby creatures die. It's just a three-dollar chicken, and it's on medicated feed, and if this is not a nutrition/hydration issue there isn't a damn thing to do (short of taking it to an avian vet, which please, I'm crazy but not certifiably so). I've gotten nourishment into it and left it in a warm spot in the tank on a bed of nice clean shavings. That's more than most would do, and either it'll be enough or it won't, but...damn.
title: tiny, depressing mortality

body:
...no clue.
   I am the cheapest woman alive and avoid the doctor even when I'm not broke, but throwing up is a deal-breaker plus then I staggered out of the bathroom and Hotter took one look at me and said "GO TO THE DOCTOR" so I landed in Urgent Care in a shivering heap, rubber checkbook in-hand.
   At Urgent Care they took my vitals (blood pressure: in the toilet, temperature: I didn't ask but the nurse said "goodness!") and sent me to a room and a nurse came and swabbed me for strep (negative, strangely enough! Middly has had it twice recently and I would have bet money that's what was wrong with me) and the doctor poked his head in and ordered a urinealysis and bloodwork and...nothing jumped out at anyone. My whitecount was right smack in the middle of the normal range, I wasn't dehydrated...WHAT THE FUCK? I mean, uh, yay?
   Then the doctor came and looked at my throat and cringed and during the part of the exam where they poke around your abdomen I almost jumped off the table and said "WHAT WAS THAT?!?" and he said "your stomach is REALLY not happy!" 
   So I said "it's just a virus then, right?" and he said "weeeell, strep's not the only thing that infects throats and yours looks horrible, plus YOU look horrible; I ran all those labs because I seriously thought we'd be sending you to the hospital from the look of you, so I really think you need a course of antibiotics. Also here is some phenergan."
   Crap. This is my least-favorite type of doctor-visit, y'all. I don't like to take antibiotics unless they're clearly 100% necessary. Plus there's the money-aspect. But they don't just hand out antibiotics like candy, right? Oh well, it's a moot point because I think if I refused to take the antibiotics I'd be getting another divorce, and I already have one ex-husband causing trouble. Also, if I'm totally honest, I don't think I've ever felt this horrible outside of a hospital so I'd try damn-near anything at this point.
   Even following doctor's orders.
   How are all of YOU?
title: mama called the doctor and the doctor said...

body:
Oh hai! So I've been mostly asleep since I posted last, because it turns out that phenergan knocks me out BIG-TIME. Actually, I'm about to pass out again. But I wanted to let y'all know that I'm feeling a lot better (no more fever! WHOO! I can swallow without whimpering! YAY!), so I guess everyone was right about the antibiotics (thanks, Dr. I and Gina, for talking sense into me) (also Hotter, for providing that vital offline IT TAKES THE PILLS OR IT GETS THE HOSE presence).
   Also did you know that Levaquin went generic? Because I didn't, and that means it's MUCH less financially ruinous for me to get sick in the future.* 
   What can I say, it's the little things in life.
 
* Not this time, though, because apparently my insurance company only paid PART of the cost of my last Urgent Care visit, and I had a balance of nearly $200 that I had to pay or they wouldn't see me. By the time I actually got to Urgent Care, I was starting to get these trippy visual effects from the fever and bursting into tears every time someone was the least little bit nice to me, so I just wrote them a bigger rubber check than planned because it was that or turn around and go to the ER. Oh well.
title: three cheers for modern medicine!

So as y'all may or may not have gleaned (due to my only referring to it in a roundabout sort of way), the XY hasn't had weekend visitation for the past three months due to assorted misdeeds on his (and his poor idiot girlfriend's) part and his refusal to comply with any sort of joint parenting plan. It's pretty much been his choice, since all he had to do to get his weekends back was agree to abide by the custody order as he insisted on it reading (namely, no cohabiting with members of the opposite sex unless you marry them). In the meantime, there's been a lot of posturing on his part and references to lawyers and the like, and I've been doing a good job of not letting him ruffle my feathers because a) I know for a fact that he is bankrupt and already owes SEVERAL lawyers money so BITCH PLEASE and b) I have come to realize that the local family courts do not give even a miniscule fuck about this sort of thing.
   Well, he's finally said that he would comply and that he'd like to take the kids this weekend, and I'm of two minds about this:
1. WEEKEND ALONE WITH MY HUSBAND, HOLLA!and2. OMG he almost let one of them drown the last time he had them for more than four hours and has given every indication that he'll do whatever the eff he wants this weekend regardless of any court orders or written agreements to the contrary, therefore this is likely to be a one-time thing that'll just screw with my kids' heads.
   So I'll either be totally absent from social media this weekend because I'm having SO! MUCH! FUN! or else checking in every five minutes to share my nervous breakdown with y'all. On the bright side, I do have work at Weekend Warrior Job, so there's that (money, whoo!).

body:
Houducki is missing, y'all.
   This morning I collected the duck egg and let the ducks out into Genpop, and we haven't seen her since (this is very unusual because we ordinarily see all four ducks marching around the property in a line). Her wings are clipped, so she couldn't have departed with a wild suitor, meaning that one of two things has happened.
1. Something et her.
2. She's sitting on her hidden clutch.
   I'm leaning more toward option two, because when we went to let the other three ducks out of Genpop we heard a distant quack. I've walked around looking, but of course she's not going to give herself away and she blends pretty well with the forest floor (the back of our lot is wooded). When we take the number of days she's been laying and subtract the number of duck eggs we've gathered, we get the normal Mallard clutch size.
   So I guess we'll keep feed and water out and cross our fingers that we see her in a month with a line of ducklings trailing behind her...not that we wanted ducklings. Oh well!
title: Houducki's final disappearing act?

body:
So the MFA Pullets have FINALLY started laying:
 Figure One: All your egg are belong to us!
   Can you guess who laid each of these beauties? Probably not, unless you're wayyyy into poultry, so here is a key:
 Figure Two: 1. Zombie Chicken, 2. George de Ebil, 3. Mer the Ameracauna, 4. Mystery Brown Egger, could've been Lenny the Sex-Link, Blanche the Orpington, either of the Australorps, or either of the Barred Rocks, 5. Natasha the lone Russian Orloff, Who Is Not A Rooster After All, 6. One of the Welsummers, 7. Houducki, 8. One of the Jersey Giants.
   How, you might ask, do I know who laid what? Well, it's like one of those word problems where you figure things out by hints and elimination. Zombie eggs we know by their color (blue and green layers each have a "signature" hue that they always lay in; it lightens as the bird ages but a blue egg layer will always lay blue, a green egg layer will always lay green, etc.). George de Ebil eggs we know by their size, color, and heft (for some reason hers feel much heavier than the others), Mer we know by color as well, Natasha is the only white-egg layer about, which makes her eggs easy to spot, the Welsummers are the only chocolate egg layers about so the dark one was definitely from one of them, Houducki's eggs are the only eggs of that color, have an oily feel to them, and are the only eggs we pull out of Duck Jail (yeah, we've contained Houducki finally), and the Jersey Giants are the only birds old enough to be laying in Cell Block C, where #8 was found. Right now we're getting a lot of wee small eggs because pullets lay small ones when they're first starting up. Hotter has offered his own crass speculation as to why that is, but it doesn't bear repeating :)
   Now, who wants to come over for quiche?

body:
Okay, sure, I had to use the nebulizer for the third time in forty-eight hours (I seriously liked it better when the mere presence of the large boxes full of albuterol amps intimidated my lungs into exhibiting their very best behavior) and Hotter got pissy with me for going back to bed (I stayed up much of last night AT HIS URGING to help my body get used to that idea ahead of tonight's work; I was productive, too, baking breakfast for the family and crunching a lot of very depressing numbers I'd been avoiding), which would either of them in and of themselves Ruin My Day a couple of months ago, but in the new-normal they're small potatoes; today is still going better so far than yesterday did.
  Thank goodness.
   I went to the grocery store and stayed under my budget amount (which was under fifty dollars, and we're out of EVERYTHING, which is why this was such a nervewracking task), but still managed to get nutritious things to feed to everybody (including the cockatiel and the dogs) until my next paycheck is in.
   And I made a payment toward my phone bill that SHOULD be enough to keep them from disconnecting me, which would make it very hard to keep working. So that's good. I bought gas yesterday on the way home from Weekend Warrior Job, at the small-town gas station near the Soulless Corporate Monolith job that I've discovered has it for twenty cents less than anywhere else in town, big-box membership stores included, so now we're stocked up and in a holding pattern (with enough for one half-gallon emergency milk in the bank) until payday.
   Having food and gas both be several days to the good is such a comfort, y'all. I didn't exactly take it for granted before, but I had become accustomed to having it be minimally worrisome for a good long run prior to the past few months and now I pretty much feel like a bigshot if neither is on my immediate radar on any given day. And the phone is good because that's my lifeline on breaks at Soulless Corporate Megalith; yes I need to be able to keep tabs on Hotter and the boys and know if there is an emergency with them or call MFA Mechanic if the MFA Minivan strands me somewhere, but the good it does my mental health to have my Twitter peeps at three in the morning when I'm on lunch and Hotter's sleeping is not to be underestimated.
   I do hope the universe doesn't feel like I need a little slap to keep me awake tonight at work or anything. A facespace friend recently compared my life to Wile E. Coyote, jumping in with "at least there was no giant box of TNT going boom?" I did laugh at that. Friends who compare me to a looneytune and sympathize with me on my "pullet wound" (yeah, a pullet attacked me and pinch-bruised the shit out of my arm) remind me that we can choose laughter. So tonight at work I'm just going to try and stay out from any giant safes or pianos on creaky, fraying ropes and hope for the best. It's all any of us can do I guess.
title: so far, today is better than yesterday, which is all I ask of it, really

body:
*   Houducki returned! After being gone for most of the day, she turned up in the evening, right in line with the other three ducks, so we went ahead and put her in Duck Jail with them for the night (actually they filed right in--they have already learned that that's their home and since Duck Jail includes a small run and the underside of the hutch that the hens lay in, which has three walls and a roof, I think they feel safe in there at night).
*   The ducks have upped the ante! TWO duck eggs this morning! In fact, the egg that I identified here as a Natasha egg? When I cracked it it was definitely from the second duck** (I didn't think a mallard would lay a white egg; the other lays camo-colored ones and that's what they're SUPPOSED to lay) (maybe her ducklings would be albinos?).
*   Big Child, who is my egg-eater (several times a week he'll ask for "eggs and toast and butter" for breakfast and I'll make him two fried eggs--he likes the yolks runny which makes ME want to puke but we know our eggs are from a clean source so ehhh) (he learned this from his father), asked if he could try a duck egg at breakfast yesterday. Hotter and I have talked about just trying a duck egg plain but somehow neither of us has had the nerve...Big Child is actually the most culinarily adventurous person in the house. Anyway, I made him one chicken egg and one duck egg, which we all agreed was the most logical way to compare the two, and plated them up, and everyone gathered around to watch him take the first bite. He pronounced it "GOOD! DELICOUS! I LOVE IT!" I asked him if it tasted any different from the chicken egg and he tried a bite of each, chewing thoughtfully. "Yep!" Good different or bad different, I asked. He tried both again. "I dunno. It's really yummy though!"
 
** Which means that Natasha still hasn't laid yet, putting her gender back into question (no crowing so we're PRETTY sure she's a hen, but she sure is flashy-looking for a girl-chicken and she carries herself different from the others and is very assertive...who knows, maybe she's intersexed?) AND meaning that she could theoretically lay pink eggs. Orloffs are supposed to lay tinted eggs according to some of my sources and we all keep hoping we'll get a pink egg layer (so far Zombie eggs are aqua, Mer eggs are a dark sky-blue, and Honeybadger eggs are green, but there's Natasha and three Easter Eggers who are younger than the other pullets who have yet to lay so here's hoping).

body:
*   The Reuben my chickens were eating was not food-waste from within Casa MFA (horrors!) (nor do we use bought bread at all, nor could I be arsed to make marbled rye; Hotter is lucky if I make him plain Swedish rye once in three months), but rather a "hot-box leftover" from the concession stand at Weekend Warrior job several weeks ago. Technically it was probably okay for human consumption, but just dried-up and fatty as HELL and Weekend Warrior Job has been kind enough to let me take leftovers on several occasions for my chickens with the caveat that they are NOT FOR HUMAN CONSUMPTION so I remain true to my word on that in the name of the local Health Department :) That is how my chickens have come to be connoiseurs of pricey hot sammiches and things like pigs in the blanket and marinated mushrooms. Lately I'm a fan of protein and fat for the poultry that I don't have to pay for, organic or no (and a surprising amount of the food served at Weekend Warrior Job actually is). So lest anyone think I'm buying and failing to eat fancy sammiches or letting them go to waste, that's the story behind the Reuben.
*   I tweeted a photo a while ago because the view from my seat at the dinner table made me giggle, and then almost immediately felt self-conscious because I've written openly about how grave our financial situation is on several recent occasions. In case anyone saw the tweet and was wondering/worrying/rubbing their hands together with glee and calling CPS on me, there was also a roasted chicken involved in tonight's meal, we just don't put the carcass on the table because SOMEone is sure to burn themself on the pan if we do (or start asking anatomical questions that will make at least one other person present queasy). The recent discussion of the tip jar made me worry that someone would either surmise that we had nothing else and feel uneasy/pressured to do something about that, or start a new Twitter account just to talk about how I'm a big misrepresenting liar who tells tall tales on the innernet to line their pockets via PayPal, or...hell I dunno maybe I overthink these things due to some of the stuff in Stalky's manifestos? Ennyhoo, there was a chicken. Swearsies! The end.
*   I also tweeted some garden porn today:
 Figure One: We thought the cauliflower the chickens ate was history, but it has made an incredible comeback!
 Figure One: Our first zucchini of the year forming on the bush with the flower still attached. I heart squash flowers! May have also inspired Backpacking Dad's new band-name!
Figure Two: Substantially less impressive until I tell you that I only ever got ONE artichoke seed to sprout and transplanted it triumphantly into the ground at the same time as the cauliflower. It met a similar fate and lost all but one leaf down so far down the stalk that I despaired of side-branches ever forming, but because I love a lost cause I kept watering it. WHOO TITS!
*   Time to get up and go to work. Gah. How are all of YOU?

body:
*   I got next to no freaking sleep today, due in part to my wanting to go to the Specialty Meat Store and redeem a gift certificate and in part to my ex-husband blowing up my phone just as I was drifting off and getting me good and riled up. Remember how he's sooooo poor he can't pay an additional PENNY in child support, and his job is sooooo inflexible that he HAS to leave the children with CATHERINE! or lose his livelihood and THEN where would we be? Well, he was wrecking my sleep (and yes, as I pointed out to him, it IS like he knew I was sleeping seeing as how I've e-mailed him in detail about my schedule) because he JUST TODAY decided that he needs to go to Big Apple City tomorrow and wanted to take his dinner visitation today instead URGENTLYOMGWTFBBQ. Do I even NEED to point out how many things are wrong with that? I THINK I SHALL!
1. His job is so strict he can't see his children and yet they are okay with this trip?2. He's so poor, SO POOR! But he can afford to rent a car and buy gas for it or fly up there and back (the XY-mobile is ailing and he rents a car whenever he goes to Big Apple City)?3. Three hours' notice for a schedule change is not adequate. I've told him and told him that we start cooking each day's dinner between twelve and three hours before the meal because we can't afford convenience food...meh, narcissists, whattayagonnado?4. He knew I was sleeping.5. BONUS! He then proceeded to tell me that third shift is USUALLY 4-midnight (huh?) and therefore "ure not working now!" Well hmm, someone forgot to tell my boss that because I work ten at night to seven in the morning and NO I WAS NOT WORKING, THAT WAS NOT THE POINT, I HAVE THIS SLEEP-THING I NEED TO DO SOMETIMES GAHHHHH YOU DO NOT DESERVE A HEAD, LARGE OR SMALL!!! 
   I let the XY know (and will now let y'all know) that my refusal to change the schedule was NOT due to him being an inconsiderate dick who wrecked my sleep for the day. I hate him like poison, but this is not All About Me. We had a special dinner planned (Specialty Meat Store, yo) and it was already cooking. BUT! If he makes a request I'll have to refuse for entirely reasonable reasons AND is a dick in the process? It does brighten my day quite a bit to say no to him! HAHAHAHAOHMYGOD. I reinstated the block on his line from mine (Verizon insists on letting those expire after 90 days, which is a dick move on their part, because people like the XY don't stop being creepers OR trying to call you after 90 days) and hopefully this won't happen again for at LEAST 90 days.
*   Ham, y'all! Specialty Meat Store is famous for their ham. It's rather expensive. The lovely reader who sent me the gift certificate said something along the lines of "enjoy the ham, not that $XXX buys much of it, hahaha!" DUDE THAT IS STILL A LOT OF HAM BY MY STANDARDS. Hotter and I gleefully brought it home and he cooked it up for dinner and no joke, I think I ate about two and a half pounds of ham. The MFA Children love All Things Pork and were thrilled. Hamhamhamhamham...
*   I just realized that we're not going to make rent without something bouncing in the process. AGAIN. Dammit. So I picked up a lunch-banquet Thursday a couple of hours after my shift at Soulless Corporate Monolith is over and will officially be a fucking zombie by this time Thursday night. Not that it'll help in time, but at least I'll recoup the inevitable bank fees. We just won't think about how my car insurance is going to get canceled before I can do anything about it right now, because then I might cry and that would make me even more tired than I already am. Although on the bright side, the Weepy Willy Score is me FTMFW and the weepies ZERO since I got the Synthroid refilled (excepting when I got the latest ticket). And also, after the fifteenth of the month we'll be caught up on everything and this shouldn't happen again any time soon. Plus, we won't starve. We've got spare chickens out back and a garden that's ramping up the production and HAM. Lots of delicious leftover ham. I think I'm going to go and drown my sorrows in cholesterol...
*   How are all of YOU?
