title: self-censorship sucks

body:
*   Everyone at work was losing their mind at once last night. The regular Soulless Corporate Megalith employees were hating on the temps, the various racial groups were eyeing each other up with malice aforethought (yes, I know, it's NOT POLITE to acknowledge such things, but this IS the South and SCM is rather like prison in that NOBODY wants to be there, 95% of the population there smokes, and everyone sorts themselves into gangs by color) (except the occasional odd duck such as myself; I hang with one of the minority groups because the other white people there scare the crap out of me, as in "I'm sorry, but I see that you have a tattoo of the rebel flag on the back of your neck and therefore we cannot be friends"), Management had their panties in a bunch, someone quit and stomped off the job site in a huff...I chalk it up to the heat.
*   That said, I also genuinely hate the living ish out of someone on the jobsite (a truly obnoxious regular SCM employee who has taken it upon herself to ensure that SCM gets its money's worth out of all of the temps and me in particular) and intend to curse her roundly on the last day of the project. Or maybe not, we'll see (after all, she has a poorly-healed slash across HER ENTIRE FACE and several prison tattoos, which would seem to indicate that she's rather scrappy). I certainly do derive a lot of pleasure out of mentally auditioning strings of targeted profanity I might use in the event that the opportunity presents itself though!
*   I'm also a little cranky because The Supervisor Who Enjoys My Arse promised and swore he'd teach me to drive a forklift, but two nights in a row something catastrophic in the eyes of Management but rife with Bad Fun has occurred that made it impossible for anyone to slip away unnoticed (the first night we moved the wine aisle and an entire shelf of wine bottles bit the dust onto the brand-new flooring; it's always been kind of a fantasy of mine to stand ankle-deep in the fruit of the vine and while technically I pictured a giant tub and several scantily-clad village girls I guess that counted...then last night a Steel Structure fell and not hit anyone, plus enough soda to fill the bed of a pickup truck exploded out of the bottles that had been stacked on the structure) and time is running out. Cross your fingers for me, because not only is that a REALLY useful skill to have, but also? FORKLIFT!
*   It's 103 in the shade right now, and I felt so sorry for the poultry that I bought a big bag of ice and filled the two poultry waterers and the duck bucket with ice water. I think I'll try and do that every day that it's over 100, because you have NEVER seen such enjoyment come from $1.89! The chickens and turkeys went from lying listlessly in heaps to drinking at length and then scratching happily in the dirt as usual, and the ducks took turns diving in the bucket and swallowing hunks of ice whole. They were SO happy!
*   I got The Cranky Old Cashier at the grocery store today. She carded me for an age-restricted purchase, which made me happy, but then when I gave her my ID she glanced at it, started to hand it to me, then snatched it back and squinted at my date of birth again. "Well shoot, you're not THAT young!" she exclaimed, and gave an evil, phlegmy cackle. *Sad trombone.*
*   How are all of YOU?
title: this just in: it's hot and people are cranky

body:
*   My evening started off with a bang, literally, as that is the sound that effing tooth made DISINTEGRATING YET AGAIN as I was on my way to work. Once again I wasn't even biting anything, and once again I suppose my dentist will have to glue the sucker back together, although once again I can't afford to have that done and it will have to wait. Eff.
*   Work was fine; I mean, it was catering a sit-down dinner for 3,200 so obviously it was a LOT of work, but I didn't drop any dishes or get in any fistfights (apparently that is A Thing in catering? I dunno, seems like every event I've worked a couple of employees have engaged in fisticuffs, usually over something stupid like "HE TOOK MY TRAY-JACKS!" or "DON'T BUS MY TABLES, THEY ARE MINE!"). So that was good. Also good? Dinner! There were enough pre-plated entrees that the staff ate what the guests ate, which was filet mignon. 
*   The drive home was where it got dicey--my debit card is missing. I have the rest of my wallet, and can only conclude that I dropped it or something (no funny charges on the account or anything to indicate that it was stolen). That left me with the $0.60 in my ashtray and the gas light on. Eff. I stopped at the first gas station I saw (which was NOT in a good part of town) and went in and handed the clerk my change and said "sixty cents on pump two, please." He TOTALLY laughed at me, and I skulked out to pump my three drops of gas and cross my fingers that it would get me home. As I was pulling out a young man dressed like a gang member chased the MFA Minivan yelling and waving, and I stopped. He caught up and motioned for me to roll my window down, so I did, halfway expecting to get carjacked. "I gave that jerk five bucks to put on your pump, ma'am. This ain't the place to be runnin' out of gas. You have a nice night," the guy said, grinning. I thanked him and got back out and pumped the gas, and smiled all the way home, broken tooth and all. 
*   How are all of YOU?
title: the kindness of strangers

body:
*   Overall, my life is not sucking in any acute, extraordinary way at the moment (meaning that yes, my minivan and my front tooth are broken, my phone is currently off due to poverty, I wish my ex was a better parent and human being, and I'm still working the accursed third shift at Soulless Corporate Megalith, but nothing NEW has happened). That was NOT me taunting life; I have learned my lesson with that and do not want another migraine, please and thank-you. Just saying I'm kind of blue but it's SNAFU here.
*   There are still good things happening, though. I mean, my phone is off, yes, but that is because I'm holding off on spending what I currently have in the bank JUST IN CASE That Fucking Tooth pulls any shenanigans. If it hasn't by Friday, I'll have the minivan repaired and I'll pay the phone bill after I get paid again next Tuesday, and until then maybe a few more bill collectors will give up on me. So really it could be worse! I mean, the phone could be off AND the minivan and the tooth could be broken AND I could be unemployed (been there, done ALL of that, and yes it sucked and you bet your arse I cried).
*   The MFA Ducks are laying! See? There's something good! It's also a little bit crazy, since ducks are supposed to lay LATER than chickens, and none of the chicken pullets (which are actually a couple of weeks older than the ducks) have laid yet! GO DUCKIES! To answer the questions that people I talk to about this offline all seem to have: Mallard eggs are about two-thirds the size of supermarket chicken eggs and sort of olive-drabby camo-looking, the inside of them IS different from a chicken egg but not disconcertingly so (the "white" is much clearer, not cloudy or yellow-tinted at all as you sometimes see with store-bought and farm-fresh chicken eggs respectively, and the yolk is darker and more orange than yellow), and they make the fluffiest, richest cakes you will ever shove in your piehole (I have not tried one by itself; I've always heard that duck eggs are fantastic for baking, and y'all know me and the baking, so that's all I've done with them so far). Also, something nobody thinks to ask but that I find noteworthy? The shells are very hard and thick, about as thick as a dime is. It took me three tries to crack the first one!
*   I'm kinda worried about finances (hahaha, okay, I'm always more than "kinda" worried about finances, and with good reason, so let me rephrase: I'm more worried than usual about finances), because the construction project I'm working on for Soulless Corporate Megalith by way of Temp Agency #1 is going to be wrapped up VERY, VERY SOON and I don't have anything else steady lined up (yet? See, I can SO be optimistic!). I'm not utterly terrified because a) the prospect of NO MORE THIRD SHIFT makes it hard to be entirely devastated about the end of the project and b) I should have some money coming in in monthly installments starting in August. I say "should" because while it's by court order, the party who is the source of said funds has demonstrated an extensive disdain for court orders in the past with very little by way of negative consequences. So I dunno. We'll see. It's not "free money," by the way. It's more like restitution. But the offense was so long ago now that it kind of feels like a bonus (or a bitter, bitter dividend on a truly crappy investment; potato-potahto). If in fact said funds DO materialize I would really like to save them against the inevitable day when the MFA Minivan goes to the big junkyard in the sky, but if we have to tap into them in order to keep the electricity on and avoid killing anything in the backyard to put food on the table then I guess we will. IF there is actually any money. 
*   I really hate uncertainty.
*   Oh but speaking of things in the backyard and killing and eating: TURKEY NEWS! The biggest turkey, which we have long suspected was a male, outed himself as such to Hotter by "displaying" and "strutting" yesterday (this is what it looks like when Narragansett toms do that--ours is only about a quarter the size of the bird in the video because he's only three and a half months old). I have spent probably a combined total of an hour or so since then chasing the poor bird around the yard gobbling at him, but so far I haven't seen it for myself. DAMMIT.
*   Yes, really. Shut up. I never claimed to have any dignity left. 
*   Hotter left his first-ever comment on the blog! He's kind of an asshole. Oh well, unlike the last asshole I married he's at least good in the kitchen and the bedroom, so I guess I'll keep him.
*   Today when Hotter and I took our early-morning walk down to the poultry pens (it's become our morning ritual--I get home around 7:30 a.m., wake him up, and we spend a few minutes caring for the fowl and catching up on anything little ears shouldn't hear) we saw a hawk land on a large nearby tree, and SO DID ALL OF THE POULTRY. They knew EXACTLY what it was, and in the blink of an eye all of the ones that were free-range at the time (we let the little pullets, the two Jersey Giants, the four ducks and the three turkeys out first thing, then after the layers have produced all they're likely to produce we corral everybody else and let THEM out--that way nobody lays in the woods or eats anybody else and everybody gets to forage) DISAFUCKINGPPEARED and the ones that were penned up (the pen does have a cover; both pens do because otherwise we'd have no poultry and some very fat local raptors) started RAISING HELL. Paul the rooster was sounding the alarm at the top of his surprisingly powerful lungs and two or three hens were cackling hysterically. The hawk (a big female Redtail, a.k.a. "chickenhawk," haha) sat on a pine tree and stared hard at the pen full of chickens for a few moments, then whooshed off empty-taloned. It was pretty cool, actually--for all that our domestic yardbirds are dumber than rocks, their instincts are pretty impressive in action!
*   I should totally be sleeping, but I read something very trigger-y that had me on the verge of a panic attack for longer than I care to admit (I haven't had one of those in over a year). I am very cautious about what I say about my ex-husband on the innernet; for one thing he's my kids' father and for another it's troll-bait (Stalky et. al seem to be almost as convinced of the XY's victimhood at my hands as he is). I wrote an entire post and then erased it, because it didn't say anything so much as it avoided saying anything. But you should go and read Belinda's post, because too many of us are silent about what mental illness can do to a marriage and a family, and judging by the comments she's gotten my experiences with my ex are straight out of the Bipolar Handbook.** I never knew that until after the fact, though, and damn if intractible/non med-compliant bipolars don't have a way of making YOU feel like the crazy one when you're still in it. If you recognize your current relationship in Belinda's brave and very compassionate words, then I'm very sorry, but it's better you know.
*   To end on a good note, I gave Middly his traditional summer mohawk a couple of days ago, and I may not be the most objective judge but I think he looks crazy-awesome. Neither of the other MFA Children are interested in having a mohawk, or any haircut at all, and during the summer vacation I let everybody do whatever they want with their hair. Big Child's 'fro is currently adding a good two and a half inches to his height and Little Child's cowlicks and curls are insane. But it's their hair (or at least it is until school starts up again, at which point everyone gets the haircut that makes them look the least homeless in MY opinion whether they like it or not).
 
 
** In case you were wondering, it's not libel for me to write that; one of the defenses against libel is truth and all of the XY's DSM-IV diagnoses (there were three of them as of the last time I was privy to such information) are on record in the transcripts of our custody hearings and in the XY's psychiatrist's deposition. It's not slander either, Stalky, because that's verbal and this is "print." I'm not going to work tonight.
   I don't know if that's the right thing to do today or not.
   I just can't, though; I haven't slept a wink PLUS I'd rather tear my own head off and light it on fire than walk back into that building tonight, in the wake of The Incident, while the workers are mutinous and Management is still het up. I don't know if I could sit through the "start-of-shift safety meeting," with the umpteen additional disclaimers there are sure to be, without calling bullshit and then they would DEFINITELY fire me (as opposed to only MAYBE firing me for a third strike--a few people now have had three and stayed, plus they're still hiring and we're nearing the end of the project so it's crunch-time) (the crunch of bones) (shudder).
   I don't know if this is right, and good, and healthy (I haven't slept, I'm definitely nowhere near safe to drive, I'm protecting my family from CERTAIN loss of income and myself from from a total mindfuck, no lube, as well as the sorts of potential injuries that come with working with tools and industrial balers and assholes who think that thirty people ought to be able to shift giant steel structures) or just plain stupid (we can't afford a loss of income at all, not even a little bit, we have bills to pay plus Hotter needs the dentist in ways I don't even want to DISCUSS and the MFA Minivan needs work and I am still toothless my own self...) and self-indulgent in the extreme (so what, my back hurts and I'm tired and morally-conflicted about working even indirectly for Soulless Corporate Megalith in the first place: ma nishtanah). Also Middly has strep (again).
   Either way I'm not going. Half the reason I haven't slept is that dead things give me the willies (why yes, yes I DO kill, gut, and butcher chickens when I have to and yes, it DOES bother me but not nearly as much as stumbling upon something that's just up and died of natural causes, oddly enough--perhaps that's my need for some semblance of control manifesting?) and not only did poor Blind Boris go to the great roost in the sky, but it's also so damn hot that the broody hen died on her nest, of apparent heat exhaustion.
   Birds sure do look extra-dead when they've Gone To Their Reward.
   Despite that, Hotter has a weak stomach (which I am not saying in any kind of insulting sense--after complete gastroparesis prior to his transplants resulting in the need for constant NG-drainage and IVs he's lucky to be alive and I will take him, weak stomach and all, even if it means being the resident undertaker) and so I got to deal with TWO dead bodies today.
   The other half of why I haven't slept, too, is the way that man screamed when The Steel Structure fell on him.  
   It's just not a very good day when I can truthfully say that actual dead bodies were only the SECOND most disturbing thing I've seen. So whether it's right or wrong, I'm calling in tonight so that when I DO finally give in to sleep it's in Hotter's arms and not, say, behind the wheel of the MFA Minivan on a local interstate. 
   I just don't know if it's actually all that wise.

Oh man, it's been so long since I had a migraine that I was Truly Affronted.
   Yesterday was my only day off of the week, and I trudged around in a horrid mood (due in part to a hellacious earache, which I forgot was an aura as it's been so long since I had regular migraines that I've had ear infections since then).
   I fell asleep immediately after the MFA Children, with a bag of frozen veg on my head.
   At some point, Hotter crawled into bed with me naked and freshly-showered, and I made him get up and put his robe on and take the bag of veg back and get me a fresh one from the freezer. 
   That's the last I remember before 5 a.m., when I got up, had a yogurt and some generic migraine relief (aspirin, a HUGE no-no, caffeine and acetaminophen OTC headache remedy which works shockingly well for me, but is a HUGE no-no so I reserve it for true emergencies, which this was).
   At seven I got back up, had bagels and naproxen, and effed around on Hotter's computer for a bit.
   Then suddenly a switch flipped and IT WAS GONE.
   I jumped Hotter's bones and served everyone breakfast all cheerful-like. I went to the feed store for poultry feeds, and they had old-fashioned wooden-handled rock candy pops. I got three, swung by the drugstore, and called the boys to the door. "Purple, blue, or green?" I asked Little Child, who got there first. "PURPLE! And I know what it is! It's LOLLIPOPS!" he yelled, jumping up and down, because usually I bring them dumdums when I've been to the bank. When he saw what I pulled out of my purse his eyes widened. Middly chose green and Big Child blue, as I knew they would, and it was the best expenditure of $0.69 x 3 ever.
   The rain ought to come down any moment from the look of it outside (damned low-pressure stupid-head weather mothereffer...) and we have all of the ingredients for BLTs for lunch. Hopefully I catch a good nap before work.
   I win, weekend.

This morning I woke up feeling mysteriously like ass (I think my blood pressure was too low, I dunno, SOMEthing wasn't right) and stumbled back to bed after the boys left for school. A couple of hours later I got up and staggered down the hall, pulling on my coat to go and check on the chickens.
   Outside, I ran into Hotter, who had gone to the mailbox to retrieve a check we were expecting. "It came," he said, waving the envelope, "do you still want to go food-shopping?" I grunted in the affirmative and went and got the eggs out of the chicken hutch, then went back to the house just as Hotter was shutting the door. "You have your keys, right?" he said casually. "I locked the door!"
   Now, Hotter is, as he often tells the MFA Children, "blind in one eye and can't see out of the other," so maybe the whole "coat over pajamas, hair not brushed, not wearing glasses" thing wasn't enough to tip him off to the fact that I wasn't quite ready to leave right that very moment, but...seriously?
   Seriously.
   So there we were, locked out of the house, without phones or ID, plus I had to pee and did I mention our landlords are currently in CHINA?
   After I was done yelling at Hotter I found an unlocked window, ripped the screen off it, and prepared to climb through (no small feat as said window was five feet up a brick wall, but I figured that was better than breaking one of the other--locked--windows). Hotter offered to try and climb in, but as his donor organs are housed in his abdomen I didn't think HIM scrambling through the thing (which would require some balancing on one's belly half-way through) was a very good idea. Actually, I think my exact words were "no, because then you'll break one of your donor organs and I'll have to worry about THAT." I am not my most fabulous self moments after waking up under the best of circumstances.
   So I gave Hotter the eggs from my pockets, declined his offer to boost me up (I still outweigh him), hauled a plastic bucket over to stand on, opened the window, and hoisted myself up to balance on my belly while I reached inside to pull something over to break my fall (the room inside the window has hardwood floors). Hotter grabbed my feet. "DON'T TOUCH ME, I'VE GOT IT!" I yelled. Hotter began to PUSH on my feet. "STOP IT, DON'T HELP, LEAVE M--" and then he gave a shove and toppled me the rest of the way over, so that the windowsill scraped my entire body from the waist down, which at least slowed my descent straight down onto my face.

body:
BlogHer. Damn. Where do I even begin? So many people have written better recaps of BlogHer than I ever could, and it was everything everyone has described and more.   The trip got off to an alarming start when my flight into LaGuardia got canceled due to bad weather in New York (or so they said; possibly there was a giant squid involved and the weather story was some kind of elaborate ruse). The ticketing agent was all "I can give you a refund, or get you on a flight tomorrow" but it was already Thursday and I was like "no, I need to get to New York TODAY" and he said "well everything is full so my best advice would be to drive." So I called home and got Hotter to book me a ticket on the next train from MFA-ville to NYC, which would put me in Penn Station around midnight, and went back to the ticket counter and asked for a refund because I'd found another way. The agent was all "why? You don't want to fly to New York" and I was all "dude, I would love to fly to New York but you just told me that wasn't happening" and he was all "but ONE SEAT just opened up on a flight that leaves in two hours" and I was like "fiiiine" and he said I didn't have to fly to New York, I could go ahead and take the train and I was all "WHAT THE FUCK, WHEN DID WE GET MARRIED" and he printed my ticket out and handed it to me all surly-like.   The crossdressers kind of wanted to go back and kick his ass but I placated them with my Rachel Simon book:
 Figure One: I'll be reviewing this book on here at some point, but the crossdressers wouldn't share and I didn't want them to cause a scene and get us thrown off the plane.   Right before we got on the plane, I saw this tweet, which did not inspire confidence. And Jenny was totally right. WHOSE IDEA WAS THAT, ANYWAY? Please come over here and collect your kick to the babymaker, courtesy of me.   On the ground in New York City, I caught a Super Shuttle to the Hilton. This was my first time riding the Super Shuttle, and I wasn't expecting them to card me. I also wasn't expecting to meet my first fellow conference attendee right as the shuttle was pulling up, and I think I got a little flustered juggling my cards and my driver's license. This would bite me in the ass later. On the way through Queens the shuttle passed the XY's ancestral apartment, which, well, what are the odds. Man, was she ever right! SO good. Then it was on to The People's Party, where the crossdressers and I got a non-weird hug from Miss Britt's husband Jared (there was much discussion of whether a man hugging a woman was weird or not; I voted no because apparently I have no boundaries but Britt thought yes and pointed out that it made him seem either like he was trying to have sex with the hug-ee or else was...not...if you know what I mean...and then I changed my mind because Jared is awfully thin and hipster-ish for a heterosexual and then we all drank Pink Twitters and forgot our differences) and met the infamous Avitable:   
 Figure Two: At no point did the crossdressers go anywhere near his balls. I made sure of that.   We also had the pleasure of conversing with the one and only Anissa and her husband Peter, who were every bit as awesome as you probably picture them. This was really neat for me because Hotter lurrrves him some Anissa and followed her recovery closely (he had a stroke six years ago himself) so texting him and rubbing that in his face was big fun (I never said I wasn't an asshole; we're well-matched like that).    After The People's Party we high-tailed it over to Columbus Circle for the Schick Intuition Kiss & Tell shindig, which...well, that was pure insanity. Like crawling with celebrities, open bar with drinks served in honey-coated glasses, models shaving in a goddamn indoor waterfall and cute boys with trays of cheesecake lollipops NUTS! My Blackberry crapped out so no pictures of the coolest thing I saw at BlogHer (namely Caitlyn Moe playing the electric violet with DJ Mia Moretti; holy HELL was that amazing!), but just before it died the crossdressers insisted I take their picture with one of the models. So I did, because they're belligerent drunks:
 Figure Three: The crossdressers hamming it up with one of the Schick models. And a razor.    Then Gavin Degraw played, and y'all I didn't even know who that WAS until he started singing and then I was like "OH SHIT, THAT DUDE IS FAMOUS." I don't get out much.   The sessions at BlogHer...well, there are official live-blog posts and podcasts of those, so I'll just say that I have a total girlcrush on Liz Henry which was (most likely) not the purpose of the fighting spam and hackers session but oh well, the session on writing about sex made me feel very vanilla, I laughed, cried, and handed around tissues from my purse at the one on grief, loss and tragedy, and OH MY GOD the memoir and poetic license one was SO FUNNY.   And then I got sexually harassed by Mrs. Potato Head:
 Figure Four: Yeah, you thought I was lying, didn't you? I couldn't make this shit up! WHY MRS. POTATO HEAD, WHAT BIG EYES YOU HAVE!   Saturday was the big Kirtsy Art Auction Thingy, where the floor signs were rather saucy...

body:
Today Little Child and I hopped in the MFA Minivan for a trip over the river and through the woods to the University Hospital Over The Hill where he sees his world-renowned GI specialist.   This was our first trip there in a long time; things have been as stable as they've ever been, which is to say that with just the right care Little Child continues to look as healthy as any other slightly-shrimpy almost five-year-old. I have grown to like Little Child's GI doctor a lot. He's a kind, grandfatherly man who used to irritate the living bejesus out of me. Not because he was rude or inept--people come from all over the world to bring their children to see this man because he's a legend in his field--but because he wasn't actively working to figure out what was wrong with my baby. His approach to treating Little Child hasn't changed, but I guess I have.   When Little Child was tiny and alarmingly ill, we bounced from specialist to specialist, and sometimes they would remark on some aspect of his labwork or clinical presentation that clued us in to why he is the way he is, or discover something (such as the elemental diet, the daily proton-pump inhibitors and laxatives, the chronic iron deficiency requiring aggressive supplementation) that would help improve his quality of life, help him grow when he stalled out, keep him out of the hospital through the winter. What they never managed to do was tie it all together in a way that makes sense.    I've written about this before, the question mark that hovers over Little Child. There was a time when it threatened to crush me. The things we know (from the GI doctor - he has reflux and intermittent gastroparesis and can only tolerate an elemental diet in quantities sufficient to sustain growth, from the geneticist - he has Ehler-Danlos Syndrome, hypermobility type and "something else syndrome-y going on, we'd like to follow him but at this point since the urine test for MPS was negative we just don't know," from the cardiologist - he's got a murmur, yes, but it's a benign one and his aorta looks great, from the hematologist "a mild PAI-1 deficiency and macrocystic anemia," from the orthopedist - metatarsus adductus, from the dentist - amelogenesis imperfecta and delayed dentition, from everyone - damn he's cute!) were, at first, overwhelming. I just wanted someone to tell me everything that was wrong with him, so that we could either fix it or plan around it, give me a prognosis, help me find him some peers.      The last time we saw the GI doctor he said that most children with Little Child's type of symptoms grow out of them by the age of five, and the ones who worsen instead of improving tend to end up with a diagnosis of something awful like chronic intestinal pseudo-obstruction or mitochondrial depletion syndrome. I took that to mean that at this stage of the game (Little Child will be five in about a month) we would Know Something.   Here is what we know: Little Child weighs thirty-six pounds and is thirty-nine inches tall. His blood pressure is 81/42. He's very cute. And his GI status is the same as it was a year ago, and a year before that, and a year before that.   "What do you think," I asked the doctor today, as he was palpating Little Child's abdomen and remarking on the nice, normal size of his colon since we started him on the Miralax. "You mentioned that most children grow out of this around five..." He smiled "Did I? Well, that's true, but some take longer than that. He's finally growing nicely and he's looking great so I'm not worried; the main thing is that he isn't any worse." I mentioned that Little Child's GI tract still screeches to a complete halt when he's even a little bit sick. "There's nothing we can do for the 
gastroparesis that we aren't already doing, in my opinion," he replied 
(we sometimes use temporary courses of erythromycin when Little Child is
 "stopped up" as a motilin-agonist, and this doctor doesn't like to use 
Reglan, which he says doesn't work well and has some nasty side-effects,
 but there's not really anything else he feels is safe and effective to 
use beyond the Prevacid and Miralax, and Zofran as needed). "We could run more tests but those wouldn't be any fun for him and wouldn't change the way we treat him so I'm just going to say that he's allowed to get sick and feel yucky once in a while. Keep doing what you're doing and bring him back in a year, or sooner if there's a problem the pediatrician doesn't want to handle." I asked if we'd be able to lose the g-tube any time soon, and mentioned that we were having a hard time getting the school system to accept responsibility for it. "Well, will he drink the Neocate?" Heck no, I said, that stuff is nasty. "So we leave it in. It doesn't seem to bother him, and if the school wants more paperwork that doesn't bother me." And he tickled Little Child's belly and gave him a hug and a high-five.   Two years ago, this kind of thing drove me nuts. Three years ago, I was certain that the lack of concrete answers meant that nobody knew what they were doing and my baby was going to die. Today, though, it made me smile. I don't know how, or when, but I've come to a point of being okay with uncertainty. It's like the flight of the bumblebee--it doesn't any more sense if you work yourself into a frenzy over the physics than it does if you simply acknowledge it and go about your business. I don't know why that used to feel like failure or how I managed to let go of the need to know and start being present in the moment rather than adrift in the hypothetical, but I'm so glad I did. He may not have "fixed" Little Child, but Little Child's GI doctor has helped me see my son less as a question mark and more as an everyday miracle, buzzing along. I'm so glad.
title: the flight of the bumblebee

body: I'm still sleepy but starting to emerge from my fog; only three more days of Levaquin to go and they can't be over soon enough! My blogging mojo seems to be a casualty of the war on bugs, and while I owe y'all some reviews, I don't feel like I can do Rachel Simon's fabulous book justice quite yet (beyond why yes, her book was excellent. Go read it!) and I'm not up to staging photos of MFA Puppy's adorable food and water bowls, either.   So I've mostly been reading, and in branching out from my usual Bloglines staples, I've encountered a lot of good writing buried under bad grammar and usage. Here (from an actual professional, no less) are some things you shouldn't do in your blog if you want to avoid stylistic errors reducing your readability:   Ask me to "bare with you." I might bear with you if you're having a hard time, but asking me to "bare" with you is a bit forward on a first date (see? When you use bare as a verb you're suggesting we get naked).   Tell me you're afraid of lightening. A lightning strike can kill you, but unless you're already underweight, lightening isn't a half-bad idea.   Speaking of which, your pants might get loose if you lose enough weight, and you might BE loose if you walk around without pants, but if you're talking about an inability to find something or an attempt to shed it, stick with one o.   If you do lose something, you might ask where it is. If you lose the pants you were going to wear, pick another pair.   There is a place. Their is a possessive. They're is a contraction of the words "they" and "are."   Your website as a whole is a blog. Your website and another website or websites together are blogs. You write blog posts. You're welcome.   See how I did that? You're with an apostrophe is a contraction of the words "you" and "are." Your is possessive, indicating something that belongs to you.   Affect and effect are tricky, so I'm less judgmental about these two, but it makes me smile when I see someone use them correctly. Generally affect is a verb and effect is a noun, but not always because the English language is tricky that way. Here's a good resource if you're confused.   Speaking of judgmental, there's no e after the g, even though it looks wrong.   Here's another tricky one: either/or, neither/nor. It makes me stabby when I see these mixed at random.   Finally, while LOL has its (<-- no apostrophe; with an apostrophe it becomes "it is") place in texts, on Twitter, and on I Can Haz Cheeseburger, I really think using it in a blog post (or more than once in the same text or tweet) is overkill. Ditto with emoticons--I'm not against them in non-academic writing, and I use them in texts and on Twitter, but if I see them all over your blog it's a turnoff.   How about you? Do you have any pet peeves (of the spelling or grammar variety) you'd like to see wiped off the face of the blogosphere?
title: pet peeves in spelling and groan-worthy grammar

body: To fully appreciate this, you need some background information. It's worth it, though. Here's the least you need to know:*   Casa MFA is situated in a...I don't want to name any one regionally-maligned race/ethnicity because that's not what this is about in the least, but suffice it to say that in one of the lily-whitest places to live in a very Southern state, we ended up moving into a lovely old neighborhood where we are the ONLY white family for several blocks around. I rather like this, as I worry about the MFA Children becoming cracker-fied in their top-rated yuppy-scum school system. I think getting a taste of being the Other is therefore good for them. But we? Are the minority in a neighborhood where pretty much everyone else is someone's sister or cousin or remembers their mama whuppin' them in the backyard one Fourth of July.*   While our immediate neighbors to either side and across the street are cordial to us and will lend us extension cords and exchange pleasantries at the mailboxes, anyone not bound by proximity to associate with us pretty much declines to do so. They know we're here, because we kind of stand out, and we know them by their vehicles (and wave when they drive by). The running joke Hotter and I have is that we're the trashiest folks in the neighborhood and they hate us for having a chicken coop and a vegetable garden in the front yard (the backyard borders some woods, whose inhabitants would probably like to eat both the garden and the chickens, so we put them up front).*   Our local Kroger ran an insane sale recently featuring, among other things, this for $0.39 per bottle. I bought some to drink after exercising or mowing, and because if it was calorie-free and $0.39 per thirty-two ounces, I would pretty much buy bottled horse piss.*   My husband and soulmate, as a former diabetic, has had a number of laser surgeries for retinopathy of diabetes and has very little peripheral vision, particularly on the left side since his stroke, and can't see a damned thing in dim lighting. The stroke affected his balance a bit. He also lost twenty pounds during his Surgi-ma-callit-ectomy and Massacree that spanned from mid-Spring to early this summer, and none of his pants fit, and he doesn't currently own a belt (we're planning to go and buy him one tomorrow).*   Our neighborhood has no sidewalks, just a narrow little blacktop road with deep ditches on either side.*   The MFA Children are with their father this weekend.   So it came to pass that the dog had to pee at one in the morning, and having no reason not to (and both still being up), my husband and I took our pitbull puppy for a walk. She's pretty good on a leash but we had to pass a roadkilled toad (which on top of being disgusting, would be poisonous if she got into it) that the dog was interested in, and I handed him the bottle of Powerade I'd been nursing since mowing most of the lawn this afternoon in order to wrangle the dog with both hands (he meanwhile was bitching because that only left him one hand to hold his pants up with).   Then a car barreled around the curve in the road just ahead of us (hi, Mazda with the one crumpled fender!) and I yanked the dog over to the right side of the road. Hotter was closer to the left side, and in keeping the dog from getting smooshed I didn't see him step off the edge of the blacktop (I usually let him know if he's near a curb, step, ditch or sharp incline). There are streetlights here, and I could see perfectly well, but remember, Hotter can't see in dim lighting. As he started to lose his balance, he evidently let go of his pants.   So the end result was that in the gleam of the neighbor's car's headlights, it probably appeared that the neighborhood's only white residents were out at one in the morning walking their pitbull, when one of them saw the car approaching and dropped his shorts, then fell in the ditch clutching a bottle of Purple Drank. Fortunately, I don't think our lead-footed neighbor saw the other one wet her pants laughing in the rearview (and no one was injured).
title: this story probably isn't worth the build-up, but damn it was funny, or maybe you had to be there

body:
A few months ago, we started ordering from Angel Food Ministries. I'd heard about them online, and read reviews both good and bad, but it finally came down to our budget getting really grim in April and us therefore deciding that we'd give it a try even if the quality wasn't all we might hope for.   The first month we were pleasantly surprised to find that the food is indeed "restaurant quality" as advertised; Hotter is a chef and I used to cook in an upscale restaurant many moons ago so we're food snobs and we'd definitely notice (and I'd definitely tell you) if we were getting poor cuts of meat or freezer-burnt veggies. So far, though, that has definitely NOT been the case! We've been very happy with all of the food we've gotten, and while you may be able to do as well price-wise if you clip coupons and watch sales like a hawk, I enjoy the predictability-factor of buying from Angel Food Ministries and the fact that you're getting staples with which to cook your own meals for the most part rather than processed foods that may have more sodium, allergens, or seasoning than you want. Instead of going on and on about why this program is so great for my family, I'm going to cut to the chase Q&A-style, and address the stuff I was most concerned about before trying Angel Food Ministries for myself, point out a couple of things I didn't know from my own research, and show you a typical AFM menu to compare against actual pictures of the food we got this month.Q. Is the meat nasty? Some online reviews are a little scary.A. Nope, not at all! We've found that the steaks are very tender (yes, they use chemical tenderizers, which we don't have a problem with, but if you do don't say I didn't warn you about the MSG), the chicken nuggets are nice, whole chunks of chicken breast without those nasty gristly clumps you sometimes get, and the sausages (the month that we got some) are nicely flavored and not overly fatty. I'm not a huge fan of pork in general, but even the porkchops we've gotten from AFM are fairly lean and nicer than a lot of the ones I've seen in supermarkets.Q. How are the veggies?A. Excellent! They all seem like they're frozen very fresh, and you're not getting a lot of broccoli stem pieces or carrots with the ends on or anything like that (as I've noticed with some of the inexpensive frozen veggies I've bought at the grocery store), and the corn doesn't tend to have cob-bits in it. They aren't in "steam-packs," so you have to cook them on the stove (although I imagine you could nuke them--personally I prefer not to cook with the microwave), but they're good quality and we've been impressed with the flavor.Q. Have you ever gotten broken eggs? What size are the eggs?A. No, every time we've gone to pick our order up we've seen the volunteers who assemble the boxes checking the eggs, and we've never gotten any with cracks in them. We've always ended up with "Medium" eggs.Q. How is the shelf-stable milk?A. Well, you don't want to drink it without chilling it first. If you have keen tastebuds you may notice that it has a flavor reminiscent of those little half and half tubs you get with diner coffee, which I'm guessing has to do with the way its preserved. If it's cold, though, and you're cooking with it (yes, I've used it for baking) or using it in cereal, you probably won't be able to taste any difference.   Some things you may not expect:*   There is a $2.00 fee for ordering online with a credit or debit card. You can get around this if you make an appointment at the host site and pay in person.*   You can buy Angel Food Ministries food with food stamps. This isn't something I've personally had any experience with, so I don't know how that works, but thought it was worth mentioning.*   The food does not come with cooking instructions, although those are available for some items online here. If you're not an experienced cook I'd suggest scoping out instructions on comparable items at the local grocery store if you are stumped on cooking times and temperatures.*   The frozen dessert items may not be cooked. We've only gotten one frozen dessert item (a pumpkin pie), but it was NOT precooked (fortunately I checked online before messing with it--apparently some folks thawed it and ended up with a mess on their hands--and found instructions).*   What you get may differ from what you see on the menu. This is something we've only experienced once, and it happened this month. The menu showed "1.5 lb breaded chicken breast chunks" and we got boneless wing fritter pieces instead. I was a little bummed because we love the chicken breast chunks, and wing-meat is higher in fat, but Hotter and Middle Child are both underweight so I plan to serve these to them on nights when the rest of us have breaded chicken breast nuggets or tenderloins from the store (shhh).*   You can find coupon codes online for 5-15% off either your entire order or a particular "box." ALWAYS search for coupon codes, y'all!*   You don't really need to bring boxes/bags. Or at least you don't at the host site we use. They've always had boxes ready and this month they had official AFM boxes and a strapping young volunteer carried mine to the MFA Minivan for me (in fact he pretty much insisted).*   Apparently in the past, you had to buy a Signature Box to get any of the special meat or veggie boxes, but not anymore--we got a steak box once in addition to the Signature Box and were happy with the quality.   Finally, here is this month's food menu picture:
  Figure One: Picture menu from the August 2010 Angel Food Ministries Signature Box    And here is what we got:

  Figure Two: What we got in our box. The spaghetti sauce is canned rather than jarred this month, although we've gotten glass jars in the past.
  Figure Three: A closer look at some of the veggies.
  Figure Four: The substitution wing fritters.
  Figure Five: A closeup of the end of the egg carton--note that the expiration date is a good ways away. I checked, and these eggs were NOT part of the recall.
title: my uncompensated, unofficial review of Angel Food Ministries

body:
The longer I let my mind dwell on the fact that from the look of it my kid's eardrum may have ruptured (burst of minor bleeding that he felt tickling his ear canal and investigated with a finger, pulling it back caked with dark brown and red bloody flecks? Also, diminished hearing on that side that is hopefully temporary? None of which would have happened, most likely, had he started antibiotics on Saturday when he woke up slightly feverish and crying about his ear?) GOD DAMN IT TO HELL SEE, I AM TRYING VERY HARD NOT TO WORK MYSELF UP INTO A TOTAL CONNIPTION HERE...
...deep, cleansing breath...in through the nose to a count of seven, out through the mouth to a count of seven...again, in with the good air...out with the tension...
   Anyway the longer I even THINK about Big Child's ear, the higher I can feel my heartrate climbing and I have deliberately not taken my blood pressure with Hotter's machine because I am not SUPPOSED to be monitoring that per any medical types and probably it's spiked into the "uh-oh zone" but seeing confirmation would alarm me further and...yeah. So let's talk about what I did outside to relieve my feelings, shall we?
   I transplanted my six little blocks of half-inch tall chamomile into the front bed in front of the broccoli (which is, in turn, in front of the sunflowers, and all of this is in front of the largest window of the house, into which the sun shines in the summer--I figure the shade will help keep our cooling costs down). I watered everything (I have two kinds of corn, two kinds of beans, half a forty-foot row each of turnips and onion starts, and more kohlrabi coming up now).
   three and a half hours later
   Well now the kid is coughing and coughing, and has already been up once apiece to complain of that and a sore throat, and Middly had fatigue and a headache an didn't eat dinner, and Little Child is the healthiest one in the house (!!!). It's looking like poor Big Child might not be well enough to go on tomorrow's much-anticipated and pre-paid-for field trip to a park a good trek away (eff. word.), and he's already weepy and emotional from pain even with anti-inflammatories, even though he says it's MUCH better since "it hurt so bad and I couldn't hear; now it just hurts SOME and I can hear SOME but the stuff coming out is gross." Yes, buddy, it is. The stuff coming out is PUS, and in fact I hope think we got you on antibiotics just in time to keep you from being REALLY sick. I bubbled the goo out with hydrogen peroxide and got the mucousy ropes of it off his outer ear canal after he drained it into a white cloth (turning it colors I won't describe). After he got up for the second time and came seeking comfort and help I promised Big Child we'd go to the park the next weekend I'm not working if he was too sick to go tomorrow with his friends (his eyes got HUGE above his flushed cheeks at that).
   I. Am. Livid.
   Livid.
title: stuff I did outside to relieve my feelings today (still furious though...)

body:
Y'all probably remember Zombie Chicken. Not only is she my spirit animal, but she's also a star of Chickens Eating a Reuben and the more recent, pissily-narrated Chickens Eating Breakfast. She's my favorite hen, mostly because she's terrifying and the closest I'll ever have to a pet dragon:
 Figure One: And in my fantasy? She also lays golden eggs. In reality they're a pretty shade of blue but not worth killing over, at least not in MY opinion--she and I have agreed to disagree on that.
   Hotter is the one who usually gathers the eggs, since I'm generally asleep when the hens are laying. Plus he's the only one in the house with the balls to face Zombie Chicken on a regular basis, as she guards her eggs fiercely. He has this technique for getting them that involves a feint or two to test how strike-y she's feeling that day, a test-tug of the tail, and then basically lifting her up by the ass. Here is what happened when I attempted to replicate his technique:
   As you can see it's uh, not for the faint of heart.
   Today when Hotter and I went out to check for eggs, we found Zombie Chicken sitting on a Barred Rock egg. He implemented the usual technique, and...she bit the crap out of him, causing him to drop the egg, which bounced off the edge of the henhouse and then, when he caught it, splattered all over his hand. Causing him to scream like a girl because "OMG, EWW, IT'S HOT, GAHHH" and me to nearly pee myself. He even got a sliver of the shell under his nail and it bled, so I'm pretty sure he and Zombie Chicken are blood brothers now.
   Oh well. He wins most of the time.
title: Hotter vs. Zombie Chicken

body:
My friend-inside-the-computer K. does this Love/Hate Friday thing that I keep meaning to try out. So here you go!
Love: Thursday night/Friday morning was my last "workday" of the "week."Hate: I dunno whether to say "yesterday" and had to think for a minute to decide what day it was today, because effing third shift screws you all up that way.
Love: I just got a nice 12+ hour block of sleep that I clearly needed.Hate: I woke up hungry and wheezing, with a godawful back/SI-joint ache that demanded forbidden-to-me NSAIDS, and had to figure out what to eat with those before sitting down with the nebulizer because third shift robs you of the normal rhythm of a day and you don't know whether to eat breakfast foods, lunch foods, or dinner foods at any given time. Like right now? I just had a banana, a peach, and some cheese and crackers. At six in the morning. Oy. Plus I'll probably crawl back in bed with Hotter about ten minutes before the boys wake for the day. 
Love: The way the nebulizer sorts out the gunk in my chest and saves me from doing the "do I go to the ER or not?" dance.Hate: The way high doses of Albuterol make me feel ASIDE from the whole "able to breathe" thing (hint: I've never tried the street-version of uppers but I'm guessing it's a lot like that). 
Love: My chickens.Hate: My rooster, who is crowing his effing head off, and also the THING on his head that I had to lance yesterday (during his time in the 'pound, Paul was attacked by other roosters who broke a lot of his head feathers off and one got VERY INFECTED). Poor bird has a bright red tonsure glistening with Neosporin. And since he's this kind of chicken it's extra-ridiculous.
Love: My Middle Child.Hate: That he had a total emo meltdown yesterday at the breakfast table shortly after I got home during which he refused to speak and sat there with fat tears darting down his cheeks answering all questions with a gasping-fish lip-puffing that looked exactly like what my father did to signify having just suffered a major stroke. I finally said "if you do not say SOMEthing I am taking you to the hospital" and he howled "WHEN I EAT CHEEWIOS IT'S LIKE...IT DOESN'T MEAN ANYFING!" Which was, in fact, SOMEthing but...existential crisis over cereal? THE HELL? Finally we figured out that he has taken a sudden and epic dislike to Cheerios and I gave him a cup of yogurt and he cheered the hell up but DAMN.
Love: The facespace and the funny little window it gives me into the daily lives of friends.Hate: The fact that I am so paranoid due to Stalky and Co. that an out-of-the-blue friend request yesterday sent me into a panic. I'm MOSTLY certain that the person who sent it is totally harmless and lovely, but did not accept just in case. Which felt rude. Hate 2.0: The invitation a friend-in-law on there (i.e. someone I am only friends with because they are an old friend of Hotter's) sent me THREE TIMES to a "wear purple for Caylee" event (this neatly outlines how I feel about the whole leave-your-porch-light-on/wear-purple/change-your-profile-picture-for-Caylee kerfuffle).Hate 3.0: Facespace "events" in general. 
   How about you? What are you loving and hating?
title: love/hate a la K.
