body:
*   In response to "why no undies," which is an entirely valid question...funny story there. Hotter lays out the MFA Childrens' school clothes for the morning each evening after they are in bed, and during my biggest grossing weeks this spring has taken over the laundry completely (like seriously, he doesn't even let me touch the machines, haha) to the point that rather than have me waking him up before dawn to ask him where stuff is he lays mine out too. The first time he did it I saw my work shorts and shirt and bra and undies and socks and keys and inhaler and purse all in a tidy little heap and laughed so hard that it woke him up anyway, bless the man. He has a poor memory for whether I'm wearing underwear after my evening shower and sometimes omits the undies (or lays out lacy, synthetic blend undies of the crawl-up-my-heinie variety that I wouldn't unload trucks of plants/cook hospital food/cater a fancy banquet in loose pants in for less than a double hourly rate, because NO THANK YOU to drawing the eye, truly), and sometimes when I know he's been up with a dodgy tummy and don't see any I'll just shrug and skip 'em (plus depending on whether I'm wearing pants that fit, meaning probably khakis or carpenter shorts, VPL may be an issue anyway as I've had bloating issues relating to prednisone off and on since Asthmapalooza '11 kicked off). I did that the first time in recent memory I wore my black banquet-serving pants, and plan to scout Goodwills and thrift stores at the first available opportunity, perhaps even tomorrow, since they so catastrophically NO LONGER FIT (which yay, really, just boo, money) and I DO NOT WEAR BELTS. That's the long answer. The short answer, I guess, would be "because I'm a spoiled brat."
*   I planted SO MANY TOMATOES today. See, I had this moral dilemma. The Botanical garden culls and replaces any plant that is less than perfect, even if that is just because a guest ripped the tags out and they're not certain of the variety. They compost TONS of vegetable plants, perfectly lovely four-packs with maybe one plant broken or all four perfect but untagged, and employees are officially NOT ALLOWED to take them home, but the boss was out one day and in wheeling out a truckload of plants for destruction a few most excellent tomatoes and peppers caught my eye and well, I just couldn't do it. It's like wasting food. So now I have lots of mystery tomatoes and peppers, which is awesome. I like that kind of surprise, since no matter what it is we'll be grateful for its fruit!
*   The prednisone is not treating me as well this time around. Prednisone baby is back with a vengeance to the point that I'm REALLY uncomfortable and may need to be seen by my doctor for diuretics and to have her listen to my lungs for signs of fluid overload in there, too. My lungs especially do not need this shit, as their struggling is what led me to be ON the goddamned Prednisone!
*   I ate a bunch of watermelon and drank a cup of coffee in hopes that the natural diuretics will help me get on top of my fluid balance issues, and have my fingers crossed. I wish I still had some Lasix about! I so can't afford to see one more damned doctor over this, although I can afford the ER again even less. Gahhh...
*   Three cheers for employers who are generous with leftovers ONLY because they know how bad I have it right now due to the recent communication foul-up. That stress may have been well worth it, in rosy retrospect, as we're now eating very well in the days after Weekend Warrior Job, and what we don't eat, the dogs and chickens enjoy!
*   How are all of you?
title: miscellaneous and sundry on a rainy Sunday evening

body:
*   The eggs did not hatch. I finally conducted autopsies (which is what you're supposed to do with a bad hatch, because you can learn from the results where you might have gone wrong) and only three had formed beyond the early embryonic stage; of those three they were all freshly dead and not fully formed so I'm thinking this was a combination of "temperature a little on the low side due to still air incubation as opposed to pricier forced-air" and "bad handling." With the handling, I didn't let the eggs "settle" point-down before setting the clutch (which you're supposed to do, evidently, so that the air cells move correctly into place before the peeps form) and also Hotter decided to MOVE THE INCUBATOR while I was at work a few days ago, about the time I think the three "good" eggs stopped forming. Take-home lesson at the end of the day, based on autopsies, innernet, and consulting my old Mennonite lady chicken-guru: let the next batch "settle" (which they are right now--we've been collecting for the past five days JUST IN CASE), skip the candling because I evidently suck at it anyway and it cools the eggs unnecessarily, and DON'T MOVE THE INCUBATOR. Also, buy an automatic turner if possible; even the little old Mennonite lady said she had crap luck until she got one of those. 
*  What I decided to do was all of the above EXCEPT buying the automatic turner, because while it's only $40 or so, that's money we don't exactly have to spend on a non-necessity right now (plus it's a bit late now to be hatching anything with the intention that it start laying before winter sets in), especially for only a POTENTIAL gain. I'll give the incubator as-is another go with the eggs we've collected and am hopeful that we'll get a handful of chicks out of that; worst-case scenario we wasted some eggs. Hotter and I also went to the feed store to pick up sweet potato tubers and got some chicks while we were there to fill the MFA Childrens' and my gaping baby-animal heart-voids left by the failed hatch. BABIES! We got a mix of Silver Laced Wyandottes and Easter Eggers.
*   The turkeys seem to have turned a corner of sorts and are now loud, active, and being pains in our arses. Yay! They seem much less likely to go feet-up now.
*   I've been trying to keep myself busy with weeding, mowing, fencing, etc. while the rest of the steroids exit my system (last dose today!). Things are still getting on my nerves more than they should, but between good nutrition, lots of exercise, and baby animals I think I'll be okay MENTALLY. My lungs...eh. They're another story. If they get even a TINY bit worse or are not any better tomorrow, I'll go back to the doctor, which the Scrooge in me hates to shell out for, but it beats another ER trip.
*   How are all of YOU?

body:
So I have spent most of the past three days since Middly got out of the hospital sick as a dog watching Grey's Anatomy on Netflix from the first season. Because if you're an emotional trainwreck staring into space for hours at a time then you're catatonic and you need serious help, whereas if you're an emotional trainwreck staring into teevee (or your laptop) for hours at a time you're just relaxing and that is a HEALTHY thing to do.
   Aaaaanyway, I just mentioned to Hotter that I'm surprised by how much I've enjoyed learning from the show--they mention a lot of really cool medical procedures that I end up having to Google and some of this stuff just blows my mind. Like did you know there's this thing called a heterotopic heart transplant where the end result is TWO hearts in one person's chest? Wild! Hotter pointed out that this was useless knowledge (which it mostly is given that I am not in the medical profession) on the grounds that "we don't have an abnormal amount of surgery or anything" (which is a crock).
   So I counted and I have, at the ripe old age of thirty-two, had a total of NINE operations involving general anesthesia and scalpels, and I'm not even counting wisdom teeth or anything wussy like that. Hotter has "only" had seven (and that's WITH two organ transplants--they were done at the same time but involved separate incisions so I let him count the transplants as two procedures instead of one). My children, between them, have had a total of twelve.
   We are not normal here.
title: we are not normal here

body:
So I got fired today. For blowing a deadline while Middle Child was in the hospital, and yes, my client knew WHY I blew the deadline, but that didn't help them have what they needed at the end of the day and I get that.
   I am so relieved.
   Yes, I should be panic-stricken, but handling the amount of work I was plus everything else was stressing me out and I had already told Hotter that I didn't care if I'd been working with these perfectly nice people for eight years, the job was making me hate writing, and life, and humanity in general, and I was not going to renew my contract when this quarter was up. It's nobody's fault really, the job just wasn't a good fit for me anymore. And yes, it seems fishy that my client would can me for one blown deadline and who knows, maybe Stalky had something to do with this and maybe it was colossally unfair of my client to make this decision because my kid was sick, but y'know, I'm so damn relieved I don't even care.
   I was sick of the work, and the toll it was taking on my mental health and in turn my physical health wasn't worth it, and I have been feeling really trapped and unhappy and now I am FREE. Yes, I need to find something else, which I will start trying to do tomorrow, but it was time for a change. I want a job a monkey could do. A job that doesn't require me to use an overly-taxing amount of brain-power. Something I can do OUTside of my home and leave in the building at the end of the day.
   Any ideas?
title: whatever, universe

body:
*   So we took Isis to the vet expecting to hear "doggie sinus infection" and instead got the news that her immune system has more or less tanked.
*   I should have had them put her down, but couldn't.
*   The treatment, which could kill her, cost everything we had in the bank, which means I can't get my antidepressant filled until November (I was going to get that refilled today because I only have one pill left), which means I'll probably be in bed crying until about the second week of next month.
*   I am pissed at myself; I should have put my foot down and had them euthanize her, but she looked so sad.
*   Also Hotter is pissed at me, because he's seen me miss one day of my crazy-pills by accident before and I cried for eighteen hours. He'd be more pissed if I put the dog down, which is part of why I couldn't do it. I don't know why he's pissed, because I can't squat down and give birth to a gold bar.
*   Hopefully if the treatment (which consists of megadoses of antibiotics and steroids for at least the next month) fails monumentally, as the vet seemed to think was entirely possible, or it turns out that this is actually cancer (a slim but real possibility; we elected not to do a biopsy because we can't afford it) the poor dog can at least limp along until November, because we can't afford euthanasia now until then.
*   I think it's best if I just don't blog until this is over one way or another, possibly mid-Novemberish. When I'm off the meds I'm not myself, and what I am is...alarmingly unattractive, at best.
*   I also definitely have a sinus infection, but there's not a damn thing I can do about that. It won't kill me, right?
*   I am pissed at life.
*   But mostly at myself, because I know--I KNOW--that I made the wrong call in not having them just put the dog down. This just sucks. But I'm going to split the last pill and taper down, so don't worry, I won't have a seizure or anything, I'll just be a fucking basket case. The children will be fine because Hotter is here, and he'll keep reminding me this is chemical, and no one ever died of The Sad, this is just going to suck a whole lot.
*   Catch y'all on the flip side.
title: I'm pissed at myself, pissed at life, and going on hiatus

body:
Remember that mystery lymphnode of DOOM on MFA Puppy's neck? That Dr. Brightside saw and said to keep an eye on? Well, the bloody thing is enormous and my mantra of "listen to the vet and just keep an eye on it as long as she's acting happy and healthy" went out the window this evening when Isis refused part of her dinner.
   I can't imagine her throat doesn't hurt with that great bloody thing on her neck. I'd take a picture except that that would require getting up and I'm sick as a...YOU know...my own self. I'm sure it'll still be just as big and gnarly tomorrow so I'll get one then.
   I can't really AFFORD to take either of us to the doctor, as previously mentioned, but damn, if she's getting sick and we don't treat it right away it could make her relapse with the mange and...yeah.
   If you can spare anything toward the veterinary treatment fund, the Donate button is still on the lower right-hand sidebar, and I'd appreciate it, because we already dipped into the household budget to cover Friday's fill of Ivermectin and even if the dog just needs antibiotics I'm risking not being able to pay something REALLY important for the human AND canine family members' comfort (like the electric bill) if I lay out for that tomorrow. Sigh.
P.S. The Donate Button says "Isis's Demodectic Mange Treatment Fund" but maybe I should change that to "WHAT THE FUCK IS WRONG WITH THE DAMN DOG THIS TIME, FOR FUCK'S SAKE?" I still win, Google.
title: oh fer fuck's sake (I can say that now, so I did)

body:
We took Isis back to the vet this morning, and Dr. Brightside was VERY pleased with her progress on the immune/autoimmune front. He's halving her time on steroids as a result, which is great news since they aren't the best thing for a young dog to be on while still growing (plus there are the liver and GI side effects and let's not forget the risk of another mange relapse). YAAAAY! He did say there was a chance the Lymphnode of DOOM would swell up again as we decrease the dose, and if that happens we're to immediately jack the steroids back up and call him to plan long-term treatment. So let's hope that stupid thing stays gone!
   The BAD news is that Dr. Brightside checked her leg out and while it doesn't appear to be hip dysplasia (which apparently wouldn't show up on an x-ray this young so no point in taking any films just yet) or anything else terribly sinister, her ACL (I didn't know dogs had those!) feels "loose" to him (looser than her other back "knee") (he said knee but isn't it a hock? Or am I just thinking horses?) and he thinks she may have injured it somehow. He doesn't think it's torn, just pulled, and said he'd put her on NSAIDs if she wasn't on the steroids but the combination causes ulcers, so we're supposed to keep the steroid-crazed puppy's activity minimal for the next week or so and let him know if she doesn't improve. Sigh.
   The other not-so-great news is that she's lost nearly a pound from her illness, which isn't something you want to see in a growing puppy. Dr. Brightside wasn't too concerned about that and probably it's better that Isis be a little on the lighter side given that she has a joint injury, but we're upping her rations a bit (she would DEFINITELY eat more) and I'm giving her the yolks from my eggs in the morning (I don't eat yolks due to cholesterol issues). Those should have a lot of good Omega-3s in them, which she needs for her coat ANYWAY, due to all the flaxseed and walnuts our hens eat.
   In neutral news, Dr. Brightside refilled Isis's Ivermectin script to hopefully prevent a mange relapse due to steroids, but he wasn't too happy about doing that because the poor freaking dog is on so many drugs and her liver is still very young. I'm happy we're leaving her on it for now, because I'd hate to see her relapse again and GOOD GOD MANGE IS EXPENSIVE AND NASTY TO TREAT!
   I'm off to bake some more bread, and later I'll have to tell you about last night's animal mayhem here at Casa MFA (those of you who follow me on the Twitter are already aware). It was nuts!
Pee Ess: If you haven't already read it, you should totally check out my guest post over at Meredith's place! The Donate button is still up because we're still in the hole quite a bit for vet expenses (by which I mean we spent some people-medicine money at the vet--we have no credit cards here because our credit sucks due to my divorce and custody battle and Hotter's transplants), and THANK YOU and BIG SQUISHY HUGS to all of you who have already helped out!
title: Isis update

body:
*   Yes, I finally did get my Pristiq in time to avoid going all emo. Yay for drugs! Boo to Express Scripts, YOU HEAR THAT EXPRESS SCRIPTS MAIL ORDER PHARMACY? YOU SUCK. Those of you who are new around here may be wondering why all the vitriol: this is why, and also this although I kind of have to give them props for their creativity--they're so determined, for whatever reason, to keep me from having my antidepressants that when I started filling those at a greater cost LOCALLY because I stopped trusting Express Scripts to handle that, they froze my bank account for three days (perhaps in retaliation?) to keep me from obtaining my drugs locally. CRAFTY! So, yeah. Express Scripts: They screw me so much my husband is starting to get jealous. *rimshot*
*   Don't forget, guest post going up tonight over at Meredith's place (around 8:30 p.m. EST). Meredith, like me, is a lapsed Jew who wears glasses, bakes a lot, and has kind of a thing about her long, pretty hair. Biz introduced us on the Twitter, and she's become kind of like the younger, better-looking sister I never wanted! (<3 you, Meredith)
*  The chickens laid three eggs today, but one was a double-yolker so I'm calling it three and a half. GET IT TOGETHER, CHICKENS. THERE ARE EIGHT OF YOU.
*   Isis seems to be feeling great overall and the Lymphnode of DOOM is down to the size of a marble (after growing to the size of a golfball Tuesday morning). YAY! Unfortunately, she's now limping more with that one leg that she's been favoring off and on, and we can't find anything stuck in her pads or any swelling or anything to explain this. She has an appointment to see Dr. Brightside for a re-check tomorrow anyway and I guess we'll ask about it again and maybe get it x-rayed then (to be fair, the last time he saw her she was trying to die on his table so her sometimes-wonky leg was pretty far down the list on things to worry about). I wish I didn't have such a bad feeling about this, but I'm thinking either hip dysplasia or some kind of godawful bone cancer with the way OUR luck is running. I hope I'm wrong.
*   I'm cranky today because I have stress-acne that needs its own place-setting at the dinner table. Seriously, I look like I'm rocking some Smallpox. Not cool, body. NOT. COOL.
*   Also, my new-to-me coat arrived and fits perfectly, except that it's REALLY tight in the bust. I am hoping that when I lose this stress-weight (thanks a lot, Hotter-with-your-summer-of-hospitalizations and Isis, the Dog Who Is Determined To Die) the girls will shrink down some. Also I haven't worn a bra in a couple of weeks because even the double-D grandma bra I bought at a special bra shop where I had to get measured and groped while topless won't contain me anymore. Don't worry, I wear tanktops with shelf-bras in them under layers if we have to go anywhere where decorum is required (so pretty much to the doctor or the vet--sorry, Kroger, Post Office, and Pharmacy). Hotter thinks this is awesome. I'm just glad our house is a rancher, because if I'm going down stairs in a hurry I have to hold 'em still with my hands. Yes, really. My grandmother had this weird condition where her tits grew until she died, and I'm starting to think I'm doomed to the same fate, which means that in ten years or so I'm probably going to have to consider a reduction. Greeeeeat.
*   Why yes, yes I DO still have that Deadline of Suck, and maybe I AM procrastinating just a little bit (okay fiiiine, I'm talking about my tits on the innernet and not even getting paid for it, so I'm DEFINITELY procrastinating...wait, no, it's still Breast Cancer Awareness Month--CHECK YOUR TITS, Y'ALL! There, now it counts as my good deed of the day--you're WELCOME).
*   Yeah, yeah, I'm going.
title: more bullets, because I still have that deadline

body:
Ohhh innernet. If I believed in reincarnation I'd probably think I was Caligula in a past life, because there just isn't any other good explanation for this.
 Figure One: Or possibly that Pharoah who wouldn't let Moses' people go, the one with the plague of boils.
   That WAS what seemed like your common, garden-variety stress-pimple until long about the time Urgent Care closed tonight. Then that red area spread over the course of like, half an hour, and suddenly that whole side of my face hurts like the blue blazes and I'm starting to wonder if I need the ER. Infections are not something we screw around with in this house. But um, I don't have any MONEY for the ER. Which means Local Teaching Hospital, who is obliged to take all comers and is chock full of gunshot wounds this time on a Friday night. If my temperature doesn't do anything scary I'm going to try and stick it out until morning with hot compresses and Murpirocin and see someone at Urgent Care (which is a twenty-dollar co-pay plus the cost of drugs, which we ALSO don't have, but I could conceivably come up with...somehow...at least a lot more easily than the $200 co-pay for the ER and whatever any labs would be, since I have a high deductible).
   Or just go out back and look for a nice dying hole to crawl into.
   Tell me a funny.
title: well up yours too, universe

body:
*   The Wrath to the rescue! Hotter called and begged his mom to step in and help us out so that we can at least get my crazy pills filled for the good of mankind. Aww.
*   I still have an untreated sinus infection and a probably-dying dog though, so life still sucks and I'm going to go kick the chickens or something.
*   Thank you for the sweet comments, e-mails, face-space messages and @replies on the Twitter. Y'all are the best friends-inside-the-computer a girl could ask for. Even in the midst of the suck-vortex my life is currently turning into I appreciate the hell out of that.
*   In answer to your questions, we should know within about twenty-four hours whether Isis is going to respond to the treatment favorably. That's the first hurdle (that she stops going downhill--she was sick enough this morning that we definitely wanted the vet to have a look but just while we were waiting in the exam room she fell apart and was shaky, feverish, flushed bright red on her belly and the inside of her ears, and whimpering with her tail between her legs; her whitecount was almost NINETEEN which is REALLY bad). Assuming she can pull out of this tailspin with the assistance of the meds, the second hurdle will be whether she can tolerate the full course of treatment without her liver or GI tract throwing in the towel (she's on an adult-human dosage of antibiotics and steroids--TWENTY MILLIGRAMS of Prednisone, y'all, and she only weighs thirty-six pounds!), and after that it's a question of whether leaving her on the Ivermectin can keep her from relapsing with the mange (since Prednisone is an immune-suppresant). It would totally suck if she responds to treatment and tolerates it well but then relapses with the mange, because we can't afford to treat that again, but right now I'm not going to worry that far ahead.
title: not going on hiatus although life still sucks a fat one and maybe you should go on READING hiatus for the next little bit

body:
The vet said that MFA Puppy would respond to the steroid/antibiotic cocktail in one of three ways:
   1. Too little, too late, dead dog by the weekend, or else they fry her liver and GI-tract, dead dog soonish.   2. Slow but steady improvement, but possible mange relapse, liver/GI damage from longterm-usage.   3. Miraculous turnaround overnight, whoo tits, fantastic news and we can wean her off early to minimize the chance of a(nother) mange relapse and liver/GI damage (and call him if his happens because he's worried, too and it would drastically improve her prognosis).
   As of right now? The giant Lymphnode of DOOM has shrunken by HALF!!! This morning our poor dog was half-dead and the thing was nearly the size of a golfball, and now it is ping-pong-ball-sized and she is feeling well enough that she knocked the kitchen trash over in a steroid-fueled food-sniffing frenzy! Well okay, this knocking over the trashcan crap is bullshit and needs to stop but YOU GUYS! SHE'S FEELING BETTER AND MAYBE WE'LL GET LUCKY??? C'mon, Isis, GOOD DOG yaaaaay!
title: AWESOME NEWS, Y'ALL!!!

body:
*   Isis continues to improve; the Lymphnode of DOOM is now maybe a quarter of the size it was yesterday (if that) and she's got the a bounce in her step again.
*   Actually we'd be fine with her having a little LESS bounce in her step. Puppies are a pain in the ass. Pitbulls are tenacious. Pitbull puppies on steroids are a tenacious pain in the ass (think wrapping you like a damn Maypole with the leash and then digging on top of your feet while yapping maniacally).
*   My sinus thing seems to be on its way out WITHOUT ANTIBIOTICS. I'm not a fan of antibiotics, and try to avoid them whenever possible, so I usually wait until the second week of misery and then go and collect a prescription and a lecture from my GP--I don't usually get sick OFTEN but when I do...look out! Only once in my adult life have I been sick like this and NOT needed antibiotics. If I do in fact get through this (now that I've gone invitin' the lightnin' by saying something) I'll credit the neti pot with turning the tide. Seriously: get one.
*   Hotter's gramma is in ICU due to congestive heart failure but is alert and oriented now that they tapped off a boatload of fluid from her chest (gross) and Hotter's mom and aunt (both of whom are nurses) say they think she'll make a full recovery. She's ninety-five but she's a tough old bird--she fell down a flight of stairs last year and was fine aside from needing a few stitches in her head (I would've broken every damn bone in my body). I'm still worried because she's the only old person I'm not terrified of (Hotter's gramma is adorable) and I'd like the boys to meet her one of these days.
*   I took my last dose of Pristiq this morning and we still haven't picked up the refill because Hotter's mom had a brainfart and didn't transfer the money (lest ye think I'm being insensitive because her mom's in ICU, she had no idea until Hotter saw it on his cousin's facespace and called) and aiiieeee...we COULD pick up the refill without her help thanks to a very generous innernet friend except that ExpressScripts put a hold on the funds for refills of my other three prescriptions (I no longer trust them with this one), then drafted my account for the cost of them when they shipped them without removing the hold for that amount. They promised it would be gone today, but it wasn't. ExpressScripts is a bunch of lying cocksuckers who lie and (I've said it before and I'll say it again) don't deserve to have heads. Hopefully the "one-day hold" will be gone tomorrow (day THREE) and it'll all work out okay, but if not I won't be blogging until we get that straight because no joke, y'all don't want to see that much emo. If I miss even one dose of Pristiq not only do I get a killer headache (with bonus risk of seizures!) but also everything is a dire, tragic EMERGENCY and everyone sucks and all I can do is cry. It's the sexiest thing ever.
*   But in case I have to go AWOL and you start getting MFA Mama withdrawals, I have a guest-post going up at oh,THAT meredith tomorrow evening.
*   After a four-egg day yesterday, the hens only produced ONE stinkin' egg today. Eight hens. One egg. LOSERS! If I'm not in bed crying tomorrow we'll be picking up our new outdoor light/timer setup from the local ACE Hardware store (ebates and site to store free shipping rock my socks off) and that should get their freeloading feathery asses into gear.
*   Good night.
title: a few quick bullets, because I have a deadline

body:
*   We went to a Locavore Potluck event at a local(ish) hippie food co-op.
*   Big Child loved the food and has declared with great conviction that he wants to become a vegetarian. I pffted at him but plan to go vegan myself temporarily for health reasons and will certainly prepare enough of everything to share with him.
*   I canned some beets, onions, garlic and hard-boiled eggs from the MFA Flock in habanero salt and balsamic vinegar, which I'll let pickle in the fridge for a couple of weeks (they'd technically be fine outside the fridge but we don't fill the whole thing anyway and with Hotter's transplants and Little Child's GI issues I'm extra-careful. It should be delicious, and make the very fresh eggs easier to peel (did you know that only "older" eggs peel easily when you hard-boil them? The more frustrating it is to shell the fresher your eggs was). Win!
*   Hotter and the boys are begging me for a rabbit. Like we don't have enough critters.
*   Mama Mouse has kept all fourteen pinkies alive and seemingly in good health. She had them in a corner where some of them kept getting caught, or buried in litter so I scooped the pinkies into a small (pre-warmed) flower pot with some cottonwool. The mama and babies seem much more comfortable there and the pinkies stay together. When the mama gets up to eat, drink, or hit the exercise wheel, she tucks them in with her tiny snout and paws. It's very cunning.
*   The new chickens have finally warmed up to me enough to take my word for it that new things are food. Today they feasted on organic home-made calcium/flaxseed-oil mash, walnuts, and a slice of bread that fell on the floor. We're going to try and pick the lights up tomorrow.
title: miscellany, the mixed fruit bullets edition

body:
I spent much of today filling out applications for jobs, and WOW. It has been a LONG TIME since I sought employment outside the home, long enough that the 89-question online aptitude test to determine whether you're a good fit for Company X is new to me. Some of the questions involving actual on-the-job scenarios make perfect sense, and others, such as "I believe it is okay to steal from my employer, yes or no" seem unlikely to garner an honest response from the type of person they're designed to weed out but at least somewhat relevant.
   Others...well. "My use of marijuana, cocaine, methamphetamines, and/or ecstasy has interfered with my ability to arrive at work on time and complete my job-related duties 0, 1-2, 2-5, or more than five times in the past month" just seems silly. First of all, who's going to cop to doing any of those things on a job application? Second...say someone really does have a problem with street drugs and yet feels oddly compelled to fess up...do you really think they're going to go with "more than five times???" Would anyone with that bad of a drug problem even be LOOKING for honest work? Also, I want to know who answers "strongly agree" to "I often feel the need to physically attack others."
   The only question that gave me pause was a rather long-winded one to the effect of (and I'm paraphrasing): "If I were the owner of a large company, and found out that an employee had stolen from one of my stores, but the amount of stolen goods totalled less than $5 over the course of a year, I would fire them" (yes or no). I picked yes, because regardless of whether I'd actually fire someone for stealing less than five bucks from me over the course of a year, it seems unwise to condone stealing in any way on a job application (the honest answer is: I'm not sure), but then Hotter pointed out that maybe this question was geared toward weeding out the overly-rigid, and now I wonder if I chose wrong?
title: I want to know how many people who these questions actually apply to answer honestly (my guess: none)

body:
You may have noticed that I no longer have Google ads on here.
   It started out with me unwittingly being too sexy for Google.
   See, I got this e-mail that they were suspending ad service to my blog because it contained adult content. And I was like "huh?" So I looked into it, and apparently this post set off their morality-bot because it contained a link titled "that big black cock."
   Except, um, Google? I was talking about a ROOSTER. You know, a boy-chicken? And the correct term for those actually IS Cock.
   Get your mind out of the gutter, Google.
   So I thought this was all a misunderstanding, since OTHER people, people who aren't ME, have perverted the meaning of that perfectly good word and I changed "cock" to "rooster." But then I was looking around on the innernet for other livestock-related terms that have been perverted by, well, perverts, and discovered that www.donkeypunch.com? Has Google ads. For things like "one night stand wanted" and "meet cheating local wives."
   Seriously, Google? People can solicit MARITAL INFIDELITY with Google, but I can't talk about roosters? So I changed "rooster" back to "cock" because this was blatantly unfair and I was starting to think Google was in cahoots with the patriarchy. Then they decided they had a problem with my use of the f-word. Because it's immoral for me to say that, or something. And also my use of the word "black" in conjunction with the word "cock."
   So in addition to being a pervert, and stupid, and a hypocritical tool of the patriarchy, Google is a racist, and y'all, I'm just not down with that kind of hate.
   You know what, Google? You don't SUSPEND me, I QUIT. This is my blog and I will talk about Australorps all I want, and if I ever DO want to talk about black mens' penises on here I'll go ahead and do that, too.
   Also? Fuckitty fuck-fuck-fuck FUCK. That is more cursing than I've ever done on here including all of the times I've discussed my ex-husband, and the misdeeds of the health insurance industry, and politics, and it was ALL YOUR FAULT, GOOGLE. So you're really not even making the innernet a more moral place at all.
   Me: 1/Google: 0
title: I am too sexy for Google, mostly because Google is just stupid, and also possibly a racist

body:
So I think I talked Jo into getting some peeps on the Facespace today...she mentioned when I posted pictures of the newest members of the MFA Flock that she was thinking of putting "coop and chickies" ahead of "new Craigslist couch" on her household priorities list and then I was all "oh but y'know, the first couple of months they live in a box in the house so you could get the chicks NOW and the coop later, and then you'd have eggs by August!" A few hours later she posted on my wall "All right, Fowl Temptress, I am making preparations now..."
   YES!!!
   I already helped talk Morgan into getting some pullets. Who's next? There is seriously no better way to get fresh, organic, cruelty-free eggs than to keep a small backyard flock, and they're very cheap to feed and maintain. Plus kids love hunting for eggs and herding chickens around...
   In other news, I applied for six jobs today, and also got in touch with the local hippie food coop. They're not hiring right now for any paid positions, but said I was welcome to come and put in some "volunteer hours" in exchange for food, which is made of win in that I love hanging out there and running my mouth ANYWAY.
   It's also just about time to start some seeds indoors for this year's garden. I spent an hour today cutting the bottoms off of plastic water bottles and poking holes in them for starter-pots and the next time it's warm enough to have all the windows open I'll be baking some soil in the oven (to kill germs and weed seeds) and filling those. When you shop at the hippie food coop here they offer you a little plastic baggie from a basket at the register filled with smaller plastic baggies containing 5-10 seeds from 5-10 varieties of edible garden plants. I think I've got enough tomato and cucumber seeds from that alone to meet our needs this year, and I have a bunch of leftover seeds from last year that may or may not germinate but there's no harm in trying...
   How are all of YOU?
title: I am the shoulder-devil of backyard chickens

body:
Oh, man! I forgot how great I always feel after digging in the dirt and planting things! I just dug a twenty-foot trench in the yard and planted kale seed in it, then covered it with one of these. I'm hoping that'll do well, because thanks to Gwendomama giving me a recipe last Fall I am totally HOOKED on kale chips.
   Much to my family's chagrin, I've also got a Dutch Oven full of dirt mix (half potting soil, half sifted compost from the ground the chicken coop stood over all winter) baking in the oven (this kills mold, bacteria, and weed seeds) to fill my little water-bottle starter pots and start my cruciform veggies and later my tomato and cucumber seeds indoors. I'm not gonna lie, it smells NASTY, but it's warm enough to have the windows open and no one'll die of it.
   Have you planned YOUR garden yet? What are you growing this year? Remember, even if you live in an apartment you can plant a windowbox or balcony container-garden with some kitchen herbs--they taste better fresh and you'll save money, too!
title: YAY, GARDENING!!!

body:
I went and volunteered at the hippie food coop (where I got to dig in THEIR dirt) today, and they gave me a TON of cosmetically-challenged organic veggies! Like a ginormous stalk of brussels sprouts (seriously, it was as long as my arm) that needed a lot of fiddly peeling and picking but yielded enough for the MFAmily to have brussels sprouts with dinner twice, apples with big wet spots that needed trimming away (but were 2/3 perfectly fine and will make excellent pie), sprouted red potatoes (which are exactly what I need for the garden and I'm so glad I didn't buy any seed spuds!) and such, as well as some extra eggs (when we're flat-broke the dogs eat a lot of eggs), plus all the butternut squash and turnips I could haul off. YAY!
   I have only tried turnips once before in my life (boiled to death in a stew--I thought they were gross), but Hotter mentioned that he liked them mashed with potatoes and since they were free I figured I'd try them again and OMG. Half red potatoes, half turnips, mashed together? Rocks. Seriously, try it.
title: turnips, man

body:
Because the whole job thing is is bummer (and never fear, I have set a goal of applying for at least two new jobs per day until I am employed again; the current count of applications out is six), I was thrilled when Winter from the feed store called to tell me that two of the chicks we ordered came in early.
 Figure One: Nothing cheers me up like a baby. Baby human, baby chicken, whatever.
 Figure Two: The Welsummers have chipmunk stripes. CHIPMUNK CHICKS ZOMG SQUEEE!!!
  Figure Three: Okay, so I didn't order this one or anything, but I couldn't resist adding an Americauna chick--they were ON SALE! Middle Child named this one "Mer."
title: cheer-up chicks

body:
*   Apparently the XY got today's pediatrician to tell Big Child that ear candling was beneficial if done right (*headdesk*), which means that I probably ought to make a phone call and ask said pediatrician just what exactly he DID say before asking whether he's taken leave of his good sense, but I lack the ability to bug him during business hours and I'm kind of out of fight. I dunno. 
*   Money...gawd. What little stability we'd created the frail illusion of has utterly disintegrated thanks to my stupid effing ER trip and the resulting prescriptions. I literally do not have three damn dollars for a class field trip, and just had to tell the XY as much. That was fun.
*   Lungs still sucking; tolerating the steroid taper okay but I have a feeling I'm only one forgotten antihistamine or night of lost sleep or puff of blown pollen away from catastrophe, and that is...not pleasant. What the fuck, y'all? I had asthma as a kid, outgrew it and never even kept an inhaler about, then caught RSV with Little Child when he was a newborn and haven't been the same from a respiratory standpoint since. I do not WANT Asthma With A Big A, as in the kind that sends grown-ass adults to the ER unexpectedly. Do. Not. Want.
*   Hotter's sick. I mean, of course he is. Something GI, as usual. Maddeningly, he JUST SAW the GI specialist, who thought everything was fine.
*   We got the baby turkeys (I went in early today so I could pick them up after work), and five minutes after I brought them home the heater for the tank died. I made an emergent Southern States run (that cost us the last fifteen bucks in the account) for a heat lamp, and so far they look mostly-dead. Or maybe that's just how baby turkeys look? I dunno, they're either sleeping a lot or in the early stages of death, which is apparently normal for turkey poults up to six months of age. Sigh. 
*   Maybe the steroids are making me depressed? I thought they were supposed to be like uppers. Or maybe it's just my life. Either way, this kinda blows. And it's 6:30. And no one has started dinner. Guess I'm it.
title: whatever

body:
*   I am very tired but didn't want to leave y'all hanging after mentioning how Hotter was sick and that Local Teaching Hospital had been mentioned here. Hotter is still poorly but a bit less so, and we're back to thinking "virus, it'll pass." Which still sucks for him, but could be worse.
*   The training thing today went REALLY WELL and it looks like I'll have as much work as I want from this employer (so uh, let's see, it's two temp agencies and a professional freelance collective now, plus the Hippie Food Coop in my spare time, which I think is about to dwindle down dramatically) (YAY!).
*    Actually, this employer (one of the temp agencies, but a temp agency with a twist in that it's an internal one--all of the jobs are for the same massive global company) is Terribly Impressive. I had heard of them and knew they were big, but hadn't realized they were all over the planet and employed more than a quarter of a million workers (of which I am now one). They're also a Fortune 500 company and one of the 100 Best Companies to Work For, and as if that wasn't enough, they've been honored for their environmental initiatives and commitment to diversity in the workplace. I'm really stoked to be getting on board with them!
*   I'm considerably LESS stoked that it looks like about a third of the jobs I do for Terribly Impressive Company will be in hospitals, primarily Local Teaching Hospital (yes, the one that tends to make me want to peel my skin off and dash screaming down the street; hopefully I will get over that). I'm trying to view this as a personal growth opportunity.
*   Tomorrow I have that "mystery shopper" thing, which should take between one and three hours, but it's a four-hour minimum contract so I get paid for four. AND I am getting paid to judge others. PINCH ME!
*   It's looking about 50/50 that I'll be working Sunday for Terribly Impressive Company, which is cool. Monday I have nothing SO FAR, Tuesday and Thursday I have Freelance-y Gig, Wednesday I am running the Hippie Food Coop, and Friday and Saturday I am covering events for Original Temp Agency. DOLLA DOLLA BILLS, y'all!
*   As if that wasn't enough, I got some unexpected GOOD financial news today in the form of a check in the mail, some expected but still damned-nice good financial news in the form of a second check, plus a totally sweet card from K., who is lovely. Seriously, it made me squee like a little girl--I totally need to take a picture to post, but am too lazy to go and do that right now, so for the time being just take my word for it that the card is ADORABLE!
*   If this is some kind of April Fool's joke on me on the part of the universe, I will not be amused. Fortunately, it all appears to be real. Good night!
title: quickly (everything is fine--BETTER than fine!)

body:
Hotter seems to have a stonking great incisional hernia in his lower abdomen, precipitated by reconfiguring the MFA Childrens' bedroom furniture (including a bunkbed that he, er, debunked is the wrong word, I know it, but I so want it to be the right one...) and then having the stomach flu. This is significant in that a) it's a NEW one (oh yes, he has several that are old news and asymptomatic), b) transplant surgeons have mentioned their great reluctance to implant a synthetic mesh in an immunosuppressed patient in the past when he's asked about elective repairs for cosmetic/convenience-related reasons, c) MOTHERFUCKING FUCK, I JUST GOT MOTHERFUCKING WORK, GOD DAMMIT and d) did I mention he's an utter bastard when he's in pain? Har de motherfucking har har.
   At least with temp agencies it's okay to not work on any given day (you just don't accept an assignment for that day) and are only penalized if you accept and then don't show? Sigh.
title: Oh, I see universe. Good one!

body:
Hotter is at Local Teaching Hospital, in their ER. I continued cooking and cleaning my feelings today, even going so far as to mow the lawn and construct a ghetto-fabulous poultry playpen for what Hotter calls the "chibi-chickens" and of course, the ducks:
 Figure One: Ducks to the right in the white run, chicks to the left in the preschool colors.
   When Hotter didn't even feel well enough to stay sitting in the comfy chair (with ottoman--I dragged them both onto the porch as it was sunny and in the 80s today!) and stated that his pain was a seven on the infamous one-to-ten scale,* I snuck out to the chicken coop with my Blackberry and called Dr. Kidney's after-hours answering service like a coward. They paged the transplant coordinator on call, who called me immediately and confirmed without my so much as breathing the h-word that this sounded like an incisional hernia based on Hotter's symptoms (EFFFF!) and needed to be seen in the ER.
   I very nearly came to blows with my husband over this when I went inside and fessed up to having ratted him out. I pretty much threatened to drive him to either the ER or the motherfucking train station to ship him back to his mother, and he said that if this was nothing or even if it was something that they couldn't fix immediately then we were getting a divorce, and I said "I love you so much that I'd rather see you healthy and face your wrath than risk a catastrophe happening in your good graces, NOW PACK A GODDAMN BAG OR I'LL TAKE YOU IN WITHOUT ONE," and so he is there and I am here and I have to be at work there (yes, at Local Teaching Hospital) at 6:30. 
   Watch them decide to have him ride this out at home and discharge him at 2:00 a.m. You. Just. Watch.
*   Hotter has a pretty robust pain tolerance, and such extreme distaste for Club Med in general that probably what he meant was a nine or so...dammit.
title: short but not very effing sweet

body:
Hotter is home; they called me to come and get him the moment I hit "publish" on my last post.
   I have to be up in four and a half hours to spend eight hours in Lunch Lady Land back at the hospital, and all the numbskulls at the ER did was run bloodwork to determine that his kidney was functioning (oh, and they said his whitecount was elevated, IN AN IMMUNOSUPPRESSED TRANSPLANT PATIENT WITH SEVERE PAIN RIGHT WHERE BOTH GRAFTS ARE). Didn't even feel him up. Told him to see Transplant at clinic on Wednesday (when I am slated to be working at the Hippie Food Coop, not as a volunteer but actually, you know, WORKING working). He's pissed and says I'd better cancel something. I think it would make more sense to aim for Tuesday, as it's a) a day earlier and b) a day when I only have to work for one hour; also God's Tree is only five minutes from Local Teaching Hospital so I could bring Hotter along and he could either nap in the car while I do my freelance-y thing or else I could drop him at the hospital and meet up with him afterward. He says I can fucking call them, then (yes, he STILL has the attitude, and the pain, and the rigid lump of SOMETHING in his lower abdomen, and I have threatened, if either of his testicles or donor organs is not where I left it when I get home from work tomorrow, to take them back downtown and rub someone's nose in them and shout "YOU SEE THAT? WHAT IS THAT??? BAD! BAD DOCTORS!"). 
   Happy fun times!
title: I could deal with being right less often, actually, thanks

body:
*   Hotter isn't any worse, in fact he is faking improvement out of the desperate desire not to see the inside of Local Teaching Hospital again during non-business hours arguably a bit better.
*   I forgot how much I love big industrial kitchens, and the one I worked in today was the biggest I'd ever had the run of. Bliss! 
*   Several people offered me a full-time job today. I said FUCK NO, ARE YOU INSANE? Okay, I said something along the lines of "thank you, but I'd prefer to be your very favorite temp!" Lots of people with Terribly Impressive Staffing would love to be full-time; I would love it too if it paid as well and allowed for a chaotic anyone-might-need-the-hospital sort of life. As it is, temping suits me just fine.
*   I'm totally going to hell; only one specialty in Local Teaching Hospital validates parking and a member of my household is unfortunately a patient of that department so I dropped the MFA Minivan off with the valets and shamelessly stopped in on the way out to save five bucks.
*   My lunchbreak lasted all of fifteen minutes and allowed me just enough time to appreciate that my natural peanut-butter and jam-from-the-Mennonite-butcher's-wife sammich on homebaked bread was by far the healthiest piece of food in the building, and had more care put into it. Hospital food'll kill ya.
*   I got home before the MFA Children and dragged my seedlings, chibi chickens, and ducks outside for a couple of happy hours during which I raised hell with the leaf blower (WHOO!).
*   Check out this video of Paul the Rooster and the rest of the MFA Flock dust-bathing! Haha!
*   How are all of YOU?
title: the one where against all odds, it's a good day

body:
...question mark. In Hotter's belly. Here's what our day was like:
* 8:00 a.m. get up, MFA Mama too achy to move right away but can't take anything until Synthroid kicks in because NSAIDs require food and Synthroid requires an empty stomach, Hotter furiously resentful.
* 8:39 a.m. Hotter wakes MFA Mama again to deal with Durable Medical Equipment issue (totally reasonable).
* 8:44 a.m. MFA Children out the door. Hotter bemoans his unshowered state given that MFA Mama is to drop him at Local Teaching Hospital (on the way to her 10:30 appointment at God's Tree) for a day of appointments and testing. MFA Mama suggests five-minute shower, and stresses that she literally means five minutes.
* 9:56 a.m. Hotter steps out of the shower.
* 10:01 a.m. Hotter attempts to pick a vicious fight wherein he compares going to have one's abdomen palpated without a shower to going to the "vagina doctor" without same. MFA Mama declines to discuss OBGYN + no shower vs. vigorous belly-rub with "adequate" shower, citing that Hotter's reasoning is inherently fallacious (faulty analogy). Hotter insists on an answer to the question of whether MFA Mama would go for a pelvic exam unshowered and proceeds to perseverate.
10:06 MFA Mama turns the radio on, begins car-singing with FEELING.
10:15 Hotter turns the radio off. MFA Mama continues acapella.
10:16 Hotter informs MFA Mama that she is an asshole, turns radio back on.
10:26 MFA Mama drops Hotter at Local Teaching Hospital, nobody says goodbye.
10:36 MFA Mama arrives at God's Tree, uponwhich the client has an emergency and calls from inside the building to ask to reschedule.
10:45 MFA Mama goes and moans on the shoulder of Hippie Food Coop-lady about the state of the universe, horrifies innocent Mennonite boys by saying the word "vagina."
11:45-12:45 p.m. MFA Mama back at God's Tree.
1:15 MFA Mama back to Hippie Food Coop while Hotter is in Radiology for a CT-scan.
3:10 Hotter out of CT.
3:45 Frantic text to neighbor results in impromptu playdate for the MFA Children
4:30 Home.
   Also, while we are still awaiting CT results and bloodtests, Transplant does not believe that any of the current hernias are the cause of Hotter's woes given his symptoms and now feels that his malaise is Infectious Disease-related. While the virus they are thinking is to blame is Certainly Very Manageable, Certain Very Manageable viruses I do not want to make Google-able can have sinister implications in transplant recipients, and we are all really hoping that this isn't that. Fuck.
   How are all of YOU?
title: it's a...

body:
*   Hotter is feeling a lot better!
*   To celebrate that, we went out to dinner last night (!!!). Before you throw rotten tomatoes at me for such an act of fiscal irresponsibility, a dear friend gifted us a Red Robin gift card, so we did not spend any money out of the household budget! The last time we went out to eat together was over three months ago (and I'm not sure Burger King one time on a gift card I won in a blog-contest really counts as going out to eat...) and it was really, REALLY nice to sit down together and people-watch and eat something neither of us cooked! We also had rootbeer floats, which were AWESOME.
*   To further celebrate, we built a second poultry-pen today (a permanent one, rather than my ghetto-fabulous shelving-unit doo-hickey of a few days ago...) and moved the ducklings outside! I'm not sure you can even call them ducklings anymore...they're about half-grown and starting to look like adult mallards! It was fun having them inside while they were tiny, but they are not tiny anymore and they ARE stinky, so YAY! Two out of four ducklings can still fit their bodies through chain-link fencing (improbable as that seems from looking at them), so I made an emergency trip to Southern States for some chicken-wire to run around the bottom two feet of the enclosure. SUCCESS!
*   We haven't heard anything back from Local Teaching Hospital, although it appears that I missed a call from them earlier today (I freely admit to having hidden from my phone all day). Hotter'll call them tomorrow about his CT scan and bloodwork, I guess.
*   I had a horrible nightmare last night wherein I was married to someone (they weren't Hotter, although they weren't anyone ELSE I recognized either, so I dunno what THAT part was about...) and they were going to die, like within days. I kept exclaiming "this is bullshit, this is so unfair!" Not that much of a stretch to figure out where my subconscious mind was going with that one, given that I did quite a bit of reading yesterday about Certain Very Manageable viruses and transplant recipients, how it shortens grafts' lifespans, etc. But as I said, Hotter's doing better syptom-wise and we don't really know anything, so...meh.
*   I and all three MFA Children went to the dentist for cleanings and checkups today, and NOBODY had any cavities--a minor miracle given that we all suffer varying degrees of amelogenesis imperfecta. My dentist said he's never seen three boys with cleaner teeth. HOLLA!  
*   I am working all day tomorrow, and an outrageous fifteen hours Saturday, so if you don't hear from me, that's why.
*   It's starting to look like we're going to survive the month of April after all. WHOO TITS!
*   And how are all of YOU?
title: it's all good!

body:
*   If I ever say anything about working sixteen hours straight in hospitality again, someone please gently remind me that there will be an awards banquet and that will be seventeen-and-a-half hours straight if you're lucky and management remembers you came in early, and then if I say "but...teh AWESOME MONIES?!" go upside the back of my head (open-handed, I'm a bleeder)? Thank you in advance.
*   I work with a really fun group of people at job #1. I <3 them.
*   Decorating for weddings is EXHAUSTING.
*   We got a very cheap incubator and put some of Paul and Baldy's eggs in it (we're continuing to collect them until we've got half a dozen).
*   One of the events I worked this weekend had vendors giving out plastic toy hardhats, and the MFA Children are having a lot of fun with those. Love it!
*   Hotter and Paul had...an altercation. Hotter didn't herd the chickens into their coop (the hens will put themSELVES to bed) because he was busy with the boys, then after the boys were in bed went out to shut the door, but in counting lumps on the roost found that we were missing a rooster. Then he heard a weird cluck above his head and Paul was in a tree! Hotter was able to reach him and thought he'd gently put him in the coop but halfway through the procedure Paul apparently had second thoughts about the whole thing. Hotter describes it was "a vicious attack!" It didn't break the skin, so I am factoring his personal bias into my mental reconstruction of events. Whatever may have happened between them, both of them are peevish and extra-vocal this morning.
*   I find it grimly amusing that I have broken nearly thirty bones in my life (including my back), and nothing really REALLY hurts except the stupid ankle I sprained last year. So. Effing. Lame.
*   I am off today and just have Freelance-y Gig tomorrow: WHOO!
*   I am cooking at Local Teaching Hospital on Tuesday: BOO!
*   How are all of YOU? I've gotten some awesome comments lately and have some new blogs to check out this weekend...right after I take a nap.
title: weekend brain-dump

body:
Okay, I'm not even gonna lie to y'all, I was totally thrilled when Clever Girls Collective let me join their fine organization in the first place, but getting to review something cool that I can't afford to spend money on right now, like a video game for my boys is...well, I was way WAY excited about this. Almost, in fact, as excited as Little Child himself when he found out he got to help me earn money by thoroughly checking out a video game... 
   Little Child's health continues to be much-improved, but I make him stay inside during extreme weather or when he's feeling punky. I recently gave him my review copy of Petz Bunnyz Bunch on a sick day and found his "slow-ca-vore" (slow, local food-eating) take on the game to be rather hilarious. See, we grow and/or produce a lot of our own food (as much as possible), including chickens and ducks for meat and eggs. So this is a typical day at Casa MFA when Little Child is feeling good:
 Figure One: Harvesting the first turnip greens of the year! Little Child ate these raw :)
  Figure Two: Feeding the ducks--they like turnip greens too!
   Video games here are either a treat you work toward after dinner or else something to distract you when you're sick. Little Child spent a sickday home happily "caring for" his virtual bunny (which he named "Jet"). He liked that the bunny was "easier to clean up after than the peeps or my brothers' dogs" and noted that radishes were on the menu of fruits and veggies he could "buy" to feed the bunny ("I'll give him lots of radishes; radishes grow fast so it's okay if he eats them all up!").
   I was pleasantly surprised to find that Little Child picked up several new sight words from the way the game incentivized reading comprehension (if you want to take good care of your bunny, you have to follow occasional written prompts, which we sounded out together), and aside from the spelling of the title of the game (come on, you HAD to know I'd have feelings about that) I thought this was a really cute little simulation of pet ownership. As for Little Child, he has mentioned on several occasions that "I definitely want to keep this game like you said I could after you write about it," and reminded me just today to tell "everyone on the Internet" how much he was still enjoying it after a week, so I think that's two thumbs up!
 
Disclaimer: While Ubisoft provided me with this game to review, the opinions I've expressed here are solely my own and represent my honest viewpoint. Ubisoft, Clever Girls Collective and I promote Blog With Integrity.
title: the official Little Child review of "Petz Bunnyz Bunch"

My main job duty seems to be putting up with the dragon-lady who runs the kitchen there, and while I can see how I'd hate her guts if I was stuck working under her indefinitely, I kind of think she's a hoot. I bet the full-time employees who spend the day hiding from her and talking shit behind her back hate my guts.

body:
*   The night before last, my "rescue inhaler" (I hadn't had one in a while, but the ER doc wrote for one and I'd been using it about every hour at The Botanical Garden due to all the pollen) got washed in the pocket of my work shorts. Hotter came to tell me my work clothes were in the wash, I asked if he'd checked the pockets before throwing them in, he ran for the washer...the inhaler? Was fine. I cried like a baby. I'm not a crier. But oh my fuck, I can't breathe well enough at work to avoid another costly hospital trip without that thing and don't have ten bucks to replace it and IT WAS FINE...yeah. My head, I think, is broken.
*   The turkeys live! Hotter reported that they perked up quite a bit yesterday, and they're eating, drinking, and tottering about! I'm very glad.
*   Work is grueling. I uh...well, I unload trucks of plants, mostly. I am not cut out for that sort of thing. Yeah.
*   I saw a friend of The Narcissist's at work today. She's a designer. She was picking out plants. She didn't recognize me and asked me for help. I helped her. She hung out for a couple of hours walking around. I ducked her. She kept trying to come up to me. This is someone who ate dinner at my house several times a week when I was growing up. Someone who knew what was happening to me, and did nothing. I don't know what, if anything, she thought she ought to say to me, and I didn't know what, beyond "NO I DO NOT KNOW WHO THAT IS, NO RELATION!" I would have said in reply. It sucked. I was kind of looking forward to coming home and talking to my loving husband about it, except...
*   Hotter effed up. He made An Unspecified But Downright Stupid Mistake, I called him on it, and he...went all Ad Hominem on me. Yeah. Ouch. There's not really much to say about that (I mean, I could tell y'all EXACTLY what he did and we could talk about Teh Stupid, and I could tell y'all EXACTLY what he said to me, and we could agree that he's a petty, injudicious dick, but...well, it was stupid and then he was a dick, the end, y'know?) except that it was the very last thing I needed and it hurt a lot. I'm disappointed.
*   The advantage to working long hours of hard labor is that you get too tired to dissect things very far; well, that and you lose weight (especially if you are out of groceries). I'm going to bed the MOMENT the children are home from dinner visitation and in bed. 
*   Oh, well, they're back. The XY asked if I was sure I didn't want him to take the MFA Children this weekend (I told him that after the ear candle bullshit I wouldn't be sending them to CATHERINE'S house so they were staying here unless he promised to care for them himself). I said of course I WANT you to take them, they miss you and I can't afford to feed them, but they don't much enjoy your girlfriend, as it turns out, and she makes stupid decisions involving their health that I can't deal with, so unless you're going to take care of them yourself I'm not turning them over. He...didn't even offer to do that, and wasn't all that upset. Didn't seem to care. That made me sadder. I didn't think that was possible.
*   I have not felt this low in a long time. I'm working my ass off, it's still not going to be enough that we'll make rent, I've never NOT made rent, the most solid thing in my life (my marriage) has had a wobble, I feel bad that my kids don't have a decent father, I feel ashamed of my missing front tooth and ashamed of myself for CARING so much, I'm worried that my lungs aren't handling the steroid taper so well anymore, I'm worried that this will all finally be what breaks me and feel lame that my life has come to this...I used to have such big dreams, and now I can't get the dirt out of the cracks of my hands or stop crying. Fuck. Someone tell me this is just the steroids.
title: life goes on

body:
*   My day began slowly and my lungs were assholes until after dinnertime (coincidentally also when I stopped moving around).
*   Work was excellent, except that every single fellow employee (probably about thirty or so?) and two customers had to ask me If I Was Okay, Did I Need Water/A Manager/Medical Care? and How Long Had I Had Asthma Like THAT? Don't get me wrong, my lungs were utter dicks and I did cough for most of the day because I won't take codeine at work, but if I had saved the breath I used up in explaining that I Wasn't Quite Dead Yet to everyone it would have been easier to power through the day (which I did, in fine style, and even garnered several compliments on my work from supervisory-types and one very nice little old lady buying flowers).
*   Big Child's ear is still leaking blood and pus, and while he seems to FEEL perfectly fine this troubles him (and me). I have shamed the XY into picking him up from school to take him to the pediatrician for a re-check as my next chance at a POSSIBLE day off is Friday; perhaps this is normal with a ruptured eardrum but I seem to recall my own experience with same drying up by this point into antibiotics and would like someone with good equipment and a prescription pad hand JUST IN CASE to take a gander.
*   Hotter hadn't made much progress toward dinner, because he was busy with other things, and I had fun helping him in the kitchen even in dinner was late. At least I did until Big Child began to interrogate me about dinner as he likes to do while I was carrying the Shepherd's Pie to the table, getting me so flustered (not because him questions were tough ones, but just because they were like a staccatto stream of machine-gun fire; it's a combination of developmental delay-driven angst to know about the food, ADD-fueled impulsitivity and speed, and desperation for my attention that I have banned at least once for every twice that he does it, so multiply ten years minus the two it took him to speak at all clearly by three hundred and twenty or so, to account for time I've been in hospitals or he's been with his father, THAT MANY TIMES, not that it helps to prevent a damned thing and do you see how this was all one run-on sentence, yeah, it's like THAT) that I burned all four fingertips on my left hand.
*   I set dinner down intact and told everyone to stop what they were doing and be aware of the fact that Mommy Needs Five Minutes Badly and leave me alone, went into the kitchen to run my hand under cold water, declined Hotter's assistance, sent Little Child to wash his hands, told Big Child to stop wiping his face on the couch (it wasn't wet or dirty, but that's Not Acceptable Sensory-Seeking In My House And You Wouldn't Do It At School, At Least I Hope Not), refused to let Hotter see my fingers, grabbed something from the freezer to grasp, told Middle Child to Wash HIS hands, scurried into the den, turned Big Child back from following me because I needed three minutes, JUST THREE MINUTES WITHOUT ANYONE IN MY FACE STARTING NOW, told Hotter I meant him too, assured him that even though he WAS a chef and The Expert In Burnt Things it wasn't That Bad and I needed just ONE MINUTE, SERIOUSLY, ALONE, NOW, REALLY IT IS FINE IT JUST HURTS and then I got about thirty seconds of everydamnone in the house palpably sulking in my general direction and decided to call that a win.
*   I then declared to my bickering children and pouting husband that we were going to have a pleasant dinner during which we would voice nothing but positive thoughts about each other and words of appreciation about our delicious meal that we were fortunate enough to be eating together as a family, and I must have REALLY had The Crazy Prednisone Eye because I only had to warn everyone at the table (except Big Child, who loves black-and-white rules like a fat kid loves cake and was cheerful and correct enough to irritate the bejesus out of everyone else) once apiece that they were "dangerously close to non-appreciation" and say to Middly ONCE that I knew I was only hallucinating from a long day at work and he wasn't REALLY chewing on his shirt because Six-Year-Olds-Do-Not-Do-That and I knew that when I turned back around his shirt would not be anywhere between his teeth SEE THAT'S MY GOOD BOY!
*   I did a bit of after-dinner-and-bedtime-for-children candling, and of thirteen MFA Eggs currently incubating, there are eight yeses, three maybe-could-go-either-ways, and two "looks-like-a-no-to-me-but-I'm-no-expert-yet-so-we'll-reevaluate-in-two-days"es. Hotter has been turning the babies eggs diligently, perhaps because I text him to the point that he's utterly sick of it to ask after them every day.
*   Every effing bone in my body, the fingertips of my left hand, my leg muscles, and my lungs hurt. Also my skin where my pants rest because my Prednisone Baby is nearly big enough that old ladies have started to guess gender based on how I'm carrying it. I'm going to bed. 
*   How are all of you? I do check comments throughout the day from my Blackberry, which seems to be acceptable workplace behavior at The Botanical Garden (probably the Damn Kids there are mostly texting, actually, who knows--Phone-Looking Is Cool) and they all make me smile (Mary Dell, you in particular are a fount of useful information! Zyrtec makes me speedy as hell and I think I might gnash every remaining tooth out of my head if I mixed it with Prednisone so I take Claritin, or rather Generic Cheapo-Store Brand Loratadine but I did not know about the tooth-spackle!). Tell me about YOUR day, it'll either make me feel better that it isn't mine or distract me from my own mishegas.
title: no luck with the Tooth Fairy

body:
Apparently February 6 - February 12, 2011 is Feeding Tube Awareness Week, and since my Little Child eats primarily via g-tube, I thought I'd say something. As more and more severely premature children and children with protein allergies/malabsorption issues or anatomical defects survive past infancy and beyond, feeding tubes are becoming pretty common. My son's smallish elementary school alone has four tube-fed students in attendance, and chances are you'll run into a kid with a tube sooner or later. Here's a quick overview of what a "feeding tube" actually is and some things NOT to say if you notice that you're in the presence of a child with a feeding tube.
   NG (nasogastric) tubes, the tubes you sometimes see running out of babies' noses and taped to their cheeks, are usually the first type of tube a baby or child will get, because they don't require surgery and are very easy to remove when the child doesn't need the tube anymore (you just pull them out). If the child's stomach isn't functional or they're at high risk of aspiration, sometimes a radiologist will help guide this type of tube down to the jejunem (small intestine), bypassing the stomach.
   G-tubes are a more permanent solution for children who need long-term tube-feeding; they are surgically inserted into the child's upper left abdomen, and after an initial healing period with a "pull-PEG" starter tube (kind of like how you get "starter earrings" if you pierce your ears) consist of a "button" held in place by a water-filled balloon. There is a valve on the side to inflate and deflate the balloon with a syringe and a port to attach an "extension" (thin, flexible tube through which you give formula or pureed foods) to. Some kids end up needing a "G-J" tube (a type of tube that uses a "button" at the G-tube site to anchor an internal tube threaded down to the jejunem) or even a separate J-tube (these are a few inches lower than a G-tube).
   If you notice a little kid running around with a tube running out the bottom of their shirt into a small backpack, probably they have a "Kangaroo Pump." Children whose stomachs don't tolerate high volumes sometimes need to use a pump that delivers a measured rate of formula. Little Child had a pump for the first year or so that he used his G-tube (after five months of an NG or NJ), but is now able to have "gavage feedings" (where I attach a 60-cc syringe barrel to his extension, hold it up, and pour formula down it, letting it run in via gravity).
   It's normal to be curious when you see something different, but how you express that can be the difference between making a new friend and being "that IDIOT" some mother of a tube-fed child rants about to her friends.
   Asking about a feeding tube is usually fine, but just come right out and ask "is that a feeding tube?" rather than saying "what's wrong with your baby???"
   Asking how long the child's doctors expect them to need tube-feeding is fine. "He won't have to have that thing FOREVER will he?" and "when will he get that taken out?" are not. Because maybe the tube IS expected to be permanent, and if it is then probably the kid's parents are just grateful they're alive--you could hurt their feelings or worse, make the child feel uncomfortable by implying that a permanent tube is such a horrible thing.
   Asking about a child's prognosis on a first encounter is NOT okay. First of all, if you don't know the child or their parents, it's none of your business. Second, if the prognosis is uncertain or poor, you're asking a stranger to tell you their greatest personal tragedy on the playground, and that's rude. And third and probably most important? If the kid is right there you're being grossly inappropriate; you don't know how much the parents have told the child about their condition. Also, if you say it like "but he's going to be fine...right?" you're essentially asking the child's parent or caregiver to reassure you for your own peace of mind. That's not their job.
   Asking the child questions about the tube (unless the child engages you and brings it up) is not cool. If you have questions about the tube, ask the parent or caregiver, and if you're just making conversation, make it about the child's super-cool shoes or beautiful curly hair or whatever you'd remark on to another child withOUT a tube. The kid is probably keenly aware that they are different, so you don't need to emphasize that.
   Finally, and this is kind of odd but I've heard it on several occasions, do NOT watch the child's parent or caregiver prepare to feed them and then point and shriek "IS THAT STERILE? THAT DOESN'T LOOK STERILE!" Feeding tubes are not like central lines; they are not sterile. The gut? Is not sterile. Formula that goes in the tube and the implements used to deliver it therefore do not need to be sterile. I tell people "it just has to be dishes-clean" and am usually pleasant about it but really? The child's parent or caregiver knows what they're doing. If you see them do something with their child's feeding tube, probably that's exactly how they're supposed to do it.
   Thanks for reading, and hey if you want to help brighten the lives of lots of kids like mine, click and support this organization, which is trying to get Sesame Street to include a castmember with a feeding tube.
title: I didn't even know there WAS a Feeding Tube Awareness Week!
