body:
*   Our hens have continued to collectively produce one egg per day (we don't know whether it's one hen laying daily or two hens taking turns, since we've had many small eggs and two ginormous double-yolkers, or whether EVERYONE has produced at least one egg and then quit, but the end result is one egg per day). I am fretting because it's rather late in the year for any of them to START laying and I had hoped we'd be getting at least two eggs per day throughout the winter (Barred Plymouth Rocks lay through the winter, which is one of the reasons we chose this breed).
*   I have some kind of abscess-type thing on my boob, and I'm none too pleased about it. I brought it to a head the night before last with compresses and it drained some; I've kept Mupirocin and a bandaid on it since then and it appears to be getting better but I'm awfully wiped out. We'll see I guess (if you're wondering why I don't go to a doctor, a) I can't swing the co-payment right now unless it's a dire emergency, which currently this is not and b) I try to avoid using antibiotics unless there's a clear necessity due to my allergies limiting what I can take and my history of resistant bugs, also c) Mupirocin penetrates a quarter inch below the skin and can therefore take care of many local infections without systemic drugs--I have successfully treated staph infections with it several times in the past).
*   FOOD! We're eating local more here at Casa MFA, and while we've never been huge consumers of processed foods, we're trying to cut back even further on those. We haven't watched Food, Inc. yet because I know I would end up losing my junk and going vegan again, but this image, which has been making the rounds on the innernet, scarred me for life and the more I learn about the way commercial dairy products are produced, the more I have The Crazy.
*   MFA Puppy is recovering well after being spayed on Friday; this morning in the wee hours she woke up and yakked on Hotter's side of the bed (GOOD DOG!) and so we think perhaps the Rimadyl was too much for her delicate stomach even though we were giving it to her with meals. We held the morning dose today to see how she'd do and she's still bouncing around and wanting to play; I think she'll be okay without pain meds from here on out. Hotter and I have both had multiple abdominal surgeries our own selves and several times a day we stare slack-jawed at our energetic and happy dog and remark to each other on how we hadn't even ditched the catheter/stood up/eaten anything/etc. at this point in our own recovery from _____. Dogs are amazing!
*   If you have small boys and a dog and are ever in need of a laugh, I highly recommend buying a pizzle stick for your dog and telling them matter-of-factly what it is when they ask (we don't make a habit of buying such short-lived and pricey delicacies for the dog due to financial constraint, but I got her a couple in anticipation of needing to keep her calm and occupied in her crate during her recovery).
*   And now I have work to do. Blehhh...
title: I should be working but here are some bullets

body:
So Hotter and I have become addicted to Bones. This is kind of hilarious to me because I hate hate hate television like poison; Hotter on the other hand loves it and I think it was a bit of an adjustment for him going from premium cable and pay-per-view to "no teevee in MFA Mama's house," but he's handled it gracefully (for the most part) and suffered minimal DTs.
   Many times he has tried to seduce me with various teevee shows. He especially enjoys the various CSI iterations. I do not. He occasionally coaxes me into watching a movie, but that's about all I'll put up with in terms of "chewing gum for the eyeballs." Maybe it's all the extraneous education, maybe it's the ADD, maybe I'm just prematurely crotchety. Hell, I spent a solid five minutes today scolding my checkout girl for saying (when the bag boy out of nowhere volunteered that he was reading The Great Gatsby for AP English) that Fitzgerald failed to hold her interest because "that novel was like, all over the map." Oh yes, and I may have even shaken my FINGER at her all "not only is The Great Gatsby one of the most magnificently compact examples of a fullfledged novel, but it's also a seminal work of American literature, and was in no way ALL OVER THE MAP!"
   For whatever reason, though (well okay because it's masterfully written), Bones has captured both my attention span and my heart, and over the past several months Hotter and I have spent our evenings snuggling on the couch with episodes from Netflix. We've worked our way up to the current season playing, and that isn't available through Netflix. Hotter then pointed out that it was on Hulu. So we settled down to watch this evening, and five minutes into the first episode--
--YOUR FREE PREVIEW HAS ENDED! 
   Oh yes. Apparently Hulu only makes it LOOK as though you can watch things you really want to see, and chooses five minutes into whatever it is you're watching to hit you up for $7.99. Which is more than I currently have to spend on additional entertainment, so now I have blueballs, and I just wanted to take this opportunity to let all of y'all know, lest the same thing happen to you. This is some of the very WORST and most infuriating marketing I have ever seen in action, and honestly? When I get paid on the 15th I'll probably be willing to cough up a few bucks on something fun and had Hulu been HONEST and posted that those episodes of that show were available to "Plus Subscribers" for a fee I might've just made a mental note and come back to Hulu next week. But this little ploy on their part has ensured that I will never give them a penny; I'll either pay for the episodes elsewhere or watch them next year. FAIL!
title: dear hulu.com, you suck, love MFA Mama

body:
*   My ribs do not feel any better. In fact, they feel quite a bit worse. I'm not alarmed by this so much as chagrined, since my lungs have responded nicely (albeit slowly) to treatment and my initial dismay was mostly because it was so very tempting to connect the two (the pain and the breathing difficulties), and those two things when connected are usually Not Good. In conjunction they can make you wish for death repeatedly, but are not any more dangerous than the sum of their parts. I am proud to say that throughout this most recent illness I have stayed AWAY from Dr. Innernet, up until today when I asked Twitter whether dislocated ribs usually get worse before getting better (apparently yes, they do) and whether they take long to heal (yes). That's reassuring in that I now know I'm following a typical course with this bullshit, but also disappointing because while I was under no delusion that this would be TOTALLY FINE any time, say, this week, I was rather hoping for "this month." Boo.
*   One of the Araucanas has gone broody, which makes egg-fetching a stimulating exercise for all concerned. Araucanas have terrifically scary beaks. Hopefully it's a sign of an early Spring this year?
*   Isis is mysteriously limping (mysteriously in that she hasn't injured herself in any way--we know it's her ACL) (dammit). So I'm in bed today with my sore ribs and my limping dog, and now all I need is a puking child and I'll have the trifecta.

I just found a new blog to read, and for the first time EVER subscribed to a blog via e-mail (I'm a feed-reader kind of girl, but it's for a good cause):
 Figure One: This lady can write!
   Amy Rauch Neilson is in the process of writing a memoir that promises to be an amazing piece of creative non-fiction, the story of the BRCA gene and its effect on four generations of women in her family. She has an agent, and now she needs a publisher; to get a publisher, she has to prove that she (as the writer of this amazing story--I seriously think this could be the next The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks) has a platform.
   Amy is trying to get 5,000 (the number her agent threw at her) subscribers by March 3rd, which would have been her four-year cancer-free date. Unfortunately, about three weeks ago Amy got the news that her cancer was back, but she wants to get this story out there and I really want to read it, so I subscribed. You should, too! Because that would put Amy one subscriber closer to her goal and give you another awesome blog to read. I told you it was win-win! Just click the artwork (which was done by Amy's neice!) to get to her site and type your e-mail address into the box in the upper-left sidebar. Please?

*   This morning The XY took Middle Child to the pediatrician for an ADD med-consult. This is huge, as he was in denial about the kid even HAVING ADD until the IEP modification meeting last week where they doubled his hours with the special ed. teacher and let us know that currently he is failing first grade. Of course, the XY was half an hour late to the appointed meeting spot, where Middly and I sat in the MFA Minivan from 7:44 a.m. to 8:20 a.m. (his actual appointment time), and THEN the XY arrived assuring me that he'd called to tell them he was running late and barking at me to cut him some slack because he's under a lot of stress. Apparently the wheels are coming off the bus? I am really hoping that the pediatrician located the notes from the Very Pompous Neurologist I took Middly to see as a toddler when we were worried he was having absence seizures (his EEG was clean although the neurologist DID diagnose him formally with PDD-NOS and ADD).
*   I'm working on a deadline currently, so I'm probably going to be a little absent here for a bit (more).
*   I debated whether or not to say anything about this on here, but I'm kind of worried about Hotter. Lately he's really absent-minded and I'm not sure what's going on. He does, as he often throws out to excuse various things he does that make me twitch, have brain damage, like for real not just to kid around about. But as I told him, I fell in love with and married him with the brain damage, and I have accepted the fact that he will never, ever, EVER put the butter away after he uses it or remember my birthday if I put him on the spot (to his credit, he does consistently gets the month and the digits correct, he just reverses the date). What BOTHERS me is when he's bumping into way more things than usual, spilling ALL of the milk one day, and dumping orange juice in his coffee the next. Part of this is likely vision-related, as Hotter and I both need new glasses and he has recently had a small bleed in his "good" eye (this isn't anything that needs medical attention unless it obscures his entire field of vision, which it apparently has at least once in the past, and they drained all of the vitreous fluid from his eyeball and replaced it with saline and even thinking about that makes me gag but anyway it's a known issue). Hotter's vision, thanks to diabetes and dozens of laser surgeries plus a stroke, is dim, blurry, and lacking peripheral perception on a good day and he hasn't had one of those, eye-wise, in a while. So maybe that's part of it. But then there's also the way he comes up to me urgently and tells me the oatmeal is too thin and the oats are too hard, then when I ask where it is says it was perfect, so good that there's none left, the kids inhaled it, what do I mean he just criticized the oatmeal? Nevermind, don't pay any attention to him, he just needs coffee...etc. It's gotten to the point where he'll be off on a tangent and realize he's off on a tangent and sigh, hold both arms out, and bare his teeth because he KNOWS I'm going to jump his case with a home neuro-exam. I don't like this, but it doesn't seem like an emergency because his seizures are completely controlled right now. But I don't like it.
*   And how are all of YOU?

So I got up and took Liverbaby to the doctor this morning, and while my doctor was late due to another patient chewing her ear off in the next room and scared me with her reaction to Liverbaby, all in all it was a GOOD appointment because she pronounced Liverbaby to be Nothing Sinister.
   Unfortunately "not sinister" and "not painful" do not go hand-in-hand, and in fact the reason for the horrified look on my doctor's face was "that just...that must be HORRIFICALLY PAINFUL!" Well yes, yes it is. As far as WHAT it is, apparently I dislocated a rib from the rear and it'll migrate back into place on its own (thanks to the rigid cast my body is making for it out of spasm-ing muscle) once I'm not coughing so damn much. So I left with instructions to continue the inhaled steroids for another THREE WEEKS (not that I am complaining, per se--not only did I not have a horrible reaction to the steroids, which is a beautiful thing, but I also seem to be among the rare few who LOSE their appetites on the things and have lost thirteen pounds in the past week) (no, that is not an ideal rate at which to lose, but I have plenty to spare so nobody is concerned about it) and another prescription for hydrocodone syrup to take at night so I can at least get some decent sleep while I heal up.
   "I really just think it's going to take you a while to shake the cough because you were VERY SICK," my doctor lectured me, "and now you know to come RIGHT IN next time you start wheezing like that and I'll give you sample inhalers if need be, okay?" So I promised that I would and that is that. I love a happy ending!
title: the one where I'm not dying

body:
During yesterday's missing-chicken debacle, I Googled around to see what the odds of finding a replacement hen locally would be (mypetchicken.com is excellent but expensive when you factor in shipping, too rich for our blood around here anymore!)--because we love our chickens, but we also want to make sure we have enough eggs--and found that the feed store I used to patronize back when I had horses (and where I had a credit on the books from eons ago, but I know the proprietress and she happily dug up the record of it) had LAYING PULLETS FOR SEVEN DOLLARS EACH!
   We were delighted to find that our missing chicken had merely hidden herself to make a nest (the chicken in question laid her first egg, finally, after much fanfare, late yesterday afternoon in the nesting box WHERE IT BELONGED but I think she'd been struggling, the poor thing) and was not, in fact, hawk-meat, but...SEVEN DOLLARS? When I had a credit for TWENTY-THREE (the price of three bags of feed I never picked up for my former PMU rescue Clydesdales)???
   It was like kismet, y'all!
   When I asked about the laying pullets via the feed store's website contact-box this morning, they told me they had ISA Browns, and I said "great, we'll take two!" and Hotter and I packed up a Rubbermaid tub and hopped in the MFA Minivan. We figured we'd get two pullets and a spare bag of feed.
   At the feed store's chicken house, the girl in charge of the chickens went into a large, eye-wateringly stenchy pen and netted us some pullets. I was sad to see that the birds were debeaked (I hate that!) and very, very scrawny. Meanwhile, Hotter meandered over to where a pen of assorted fancy chickens was milling about and called my attention to a magnificent rooster (I think it was an Australorp--Hotter wanted to get it so that he could "take people out back and show 'em my big black cock!" but I vetoed that because...well do I even need to justify that? No, I think not). Then I saw a flash of gorgeous plumage and it may make me a very lame panda, y'all, but I swear my heart skipped a beat.
   "ARE THOSE ARAUCANAS," I shrieked. Yes, the highly-amused chicken wrangler said, they were.
  Figure One: This is an Araucana.
   YOU GUYS! Just yesterday all three MFA Children were (after a conversation about eggshell colors during which they wanted to know if brown eggs and white eggs looked or tasted different when I informed them that eggs were like people and no matter what color they were all the same on the inside and equally good and why yes, I AM proud of that one) begging--BEGGING!--me for some "Easter Eggers," as Araucanas and Americaunas are collectively called in the chicken world (most "Easter Eggers" are mongrels but the ones we saw today were show-quality Chilean Araucanas). Why, you ask, were my children throwing a fit over chickens? Because this is the kind of chicken that lays multi-colored eggs.
 Figure Two: Like this.
   Since first of all, I do not get to give my children what they wish for nearly enough due to finances, and second, they remained despite my best attempts CONVINCED that "easter eggs" would taste different, I pretty much had to get at least one of these birds if at all possible to reinforce that we are all the same (and prove they don't lay blueberry eggs!).
   I asked how much they were, prepared to hear that we'd only be getting one chicken, and...THEY WERE SEVEN DOLLARS, TOO! The only reason they hadn't mentioned these birds when I asked about laying pullets is that they haven't laid yet (they're a week younger than the ISA Browns, who hatched the same day as the original MFA Flock)! I said nevermind, we'd just get two of those, but...well, the girl had already netted the one ISA Brown and put her in the Rubbermaid tub, and she was so little and skinny and pitiful with her uneven and half-missing beak that I wanted to take her home and make her oatmeal and love her and pet her and call her George.
   So we ended up with three new chickens. Innernet, meet Nameless the First, Nameless the Second, and George:
 Figure Three: And they'll all live happily ever after as soon as the new pecking order is sorted out (the Barred Rocks, not pictured, are Not Amused and were on the other perch on the far end of the coop throwing gang signs).
title: fresh meat in the MFA Flock

body:
*   I went from feeling fine--GREAT, even!--the day we got the new chickens to being miserably ill by that evening and have been sick as a dog with upper-respiratory yuck ever since, although I think it's finally on its way out. The day before yesterday was NOT PRETTY AT ALL. Yesterday I took three naps. Two so far today. So, yeah.
*   Little Child had his first field trip yesterday! We slept late and I had to drive him to school (I had to drive all three kids to school, but ran Little Child in first so he woudn't miss the bus!) but he made it in time and was VERY excited when he got home. The class went to a local shopping center and visited several businesses there. Apparently the Japanese steakhouse was a big hit--a chef there did some tricks involving fire. WHOO, FIRE!
*   MFA Puppy went for another skin scraping and Mitaban treatment today, and I'm worried about her. Not only because those dips kick her poor little arse, but also because she has one VERY enlarged lymphnode in her neck. JUST one. I'm hoping it's not a tumah but with our luck? Oy. I'm not going to think about it any further until the vet weighs in, la-la-la...
*   Three eggs yesterday! Two from the Barred Rocks and one from George. I'm having to lock the original flock up a couple of times a day so that the newcomers can eat and drink in peace, so we know who's laying what (I provided an extra "nesting box" consisting of a Rubbermaid tub full of straw outside of the henhouse but they wait until they've got access to the house itself and do a sort of "chicken pee-dance" outside it when they have to lay, which is kind of hilarious). George's eggs are also a darker brown than the Barred Rocks' are, and almost spherical.
*   The new chickens are breaking my heart, y'all--they won't eat treats of any kind, just chicken feed! Those birds need to learn how to live the good life, especially George, who is so damned skinny I worry about her laying daily as she's been doing since she got here--it seems like that would take a lot out of a body and she's just bones and feathers! She gobbled up some ground oyster shell that I provide all of the hens with for calcium, so that's good, but I want to see her gain some weight before it gets super-cold.
*   I'll probably be doing some more fundraising-type stuff on the Twitter today while Isis is at the vet getting scraped and dipped and having her stitches removed. The Donate button is still up at the bottom right and if you have a few bucks to spare we'd appreciate the help in getting Isis better...we're almost at the fundraising goal!
*   Yesterday I baked bread, cleaned an entire pumpkin and roasted the seeds, made half of it into a pie (the other half is in the fridge and will probably become soup), and made cream of broccoli soup. Today I had planned to bake our caption contest winner some cookies...look at me all domestic and shizz!...but I think I'll hold off and do it Monday so that the cookies a) do not have cooties and b) do not sit in a mail truck all day Sunday. Also yesterday wore me out. For the holidays this year I would very much like a working immune system, please and thank you Santa and Hannukah Harry!
*   Something I love about having chickens, aside from how much fun they are to watch and how nice it is to have fresh organic eggs? FOOD DOES NOT GO TO WASTE ANYMORE. Hotter and I are both leftover-eaters, but when the kids are sick-ish or have made a mess of something by gnawing off just the toppings or something that creates wasted food (which on top of being a sin in general is extra-appalling since Hotter and I are both excellent cooks and we're using a lot more high-quality organic ingredients lately, which are not cheap)...or at least it DID until we had the MFA Flock, which happily devours pretty much any kind of leftovers (I don't generally give them meat, not because they won't eat it but because I worry about scraps creating bacteria in their enclosure that would then potentially make their way into the eggs, but the dog is more than happy to have trimming and half-eaten leftovers of meat from the table in her dinner). Today a half-eaten piece of pumpkin pie left over from breakfast (yes, I let the MFA Children have pie for breakfast just this once--I made that pie and the top three ingredients are organic pumpkin, condensed milk, and organic eggs so while it also had more sugar than a typical MFA breakfast it was actually pretty nutritious, plus it was a special treat for them--I baked the pie last night and they're going to their father's for the weekend, so...) became brunch for the hens, and WHOOBOY, stand back! The MFA Flock approves of my baking, too.
*   How are all of you?
title: in which I am sick and we have a three-egg day

body:
The vet called, and MFA Puppy's skin scraping was CLEAN! While we've been here before, this time we're sticking with Dr. Brightside (who won't let her outgrow her dose of Ivermectin and seems more aggressive than the other two vets we've seen there) and he's very happy with the way Isis looks overall and feels like we have turned a major corner. WHOOHOO!!!
   As far as where we go from here, Dr. Brightside said he's definitely having the vet tech go ahead with today's Mitaban dip since Isis was just spayed and that can weaken the immune system and cause relapses--we don't want to let those nasty mites get a leg up!--and keep her on the Ivermectin, then do another scraping in two weeks and if that's clear, we "call it good." He's pleased that we went ahead and ordered the woo-woo supplement he suggested (apparently he's seen good results in using it to boost dogs' immune systems in situations like Isis's, and so I decided it was worth a try), and said to continue that, the Omega-3-rich salmon oil we've been adding to her food, and the Pet-Tabs Plus vitamins.
   Today's fill of Ivermectin could conceivably be the LAST mange-related expense we have, which would be awesome. Since the dose went up, we're about $30 short of having it covered, so the Donate button is still up, but if we can raise that we'll be DONE* and the button can go away and we can all get to living happily ever after. YAY! Thanks so much to everyone who has helped us out so far, by donating, by retweeting, and by offering moral support and positive thoughts.
 
*   Assuming she doesn't relapse again. Knock wood, etc.
title: BREAKING NEWS! Isis update!

body:
Remember when I said Hotter was way sick? Well, he's STILL like that. He's not any worse, but he's also not any better. Symptoms include GI malaise, lower-abdominal pain that seems tied to position (one day his body had to be straight, the next he had to be bent, and today he's just all-around miserable), fever, and body aches. He doesn't look AWFUL but he doesn't look all that good either.
   I wouldn't have a whole lot of sympathy except that his donor organs are both housed in his lower abdomen, so. Yeah.
   I have to leave in half an hour and go to a job-training thingy that is supposed to take about two hours. Hotter was groaning and carrying on this morning in a "could be man-flu, could be The Beginning Of The End" sort of way, so in deciding whether or not to cancel, I resorted to my Litmus Test of Last Resort.
   "You know," I said casually, "technically lower-abdominal pain with fever is one of those things we're ALWAYS supposed to call Dr. Kidney* about."
   "Uh huh."
   "And if I call Dr. Kidney and tell her that you have a fever and lower abdominal pain, she's going to tell us to go straight to the ER at Local Teaching Hospital. Does it hurt THAT much, or are you being a drama-llama?"
   "I feel a bit better!"**
   Alrighty, then. So I'm going to the training-thing, and I'll re-assess when I get back.
 
*  Awww...it's their anniversary today!
** Um, yeah, when he had surgi-ma-callit-itis he was crying for Dr. Kidney and Local Teaching Hospital's ER like a little bitch, so this means that a) his sense of humor is still intact and b) this is somewhere between "man-flu" and "not YET a surgical emergency."

body:
I'll start with the good: THREE EGGS TODAY! All were from the Barred Rocks; I think poor George has stopped laying for a bit due to malnutrition (she and the Araucanas have only been eating a couple of times a day while the Barred Rocks are locked up to give them a chance). Today I started a new system of going out first thing and locking four Barred Rocks up in the smaller run with access to the hen-hutch and leaving George, the Araucanas, and Speck with the run of the pen (and a nesting box consisting of a Rubbermaid tub full of straw, which Speck laid in today). Speck seems to be the alpha-hen, but this way she's outnumbered and has no choice but to treat the newcomers well; I figure her accepting the new birds will set an example for the other four Barred Rocks. After everyone lays I let the original MFA Flock (including Speck) outside to forage and leave the newcomers alone in the pen to have some stress-free time, then an hour before dusk I throw everyone in together (they willingly share the hen-hutch at night now--I think they suspend hostilities in order to maximize the warmth from all crowding together in there).
   In non-good news, I feel like I'm getting one of those sucktastic secondary infections I tend to get, and this sucks even more than in just the "oh crap I'm sick" kind of way, because I really can't afford to go to the doctor and get antibiotics if I end up needing to (which I kind of think I will unless I improve overnight) due to having "borrowed" from the household budget to cover MFA Puppy's Ivermectin on Friday. If I have go to the doctor and pay for antibiotics, I won't be able to cover the power bill, and if our online payment to them gets rejected for non-sufficient funds, they'll kick us off the budget plan (which would mean paying several hundred dollars extra to maintain service, which is NOT doable). Balls.
   I'm going to go and make some more soup, and take some more vitamins, and try to hope for the best. Just so y'all know, if the MFA Children return from visitation tomorrow sick and needing the doctor, I'm going to end up on the news. If that happens, please remember that the camera adds ten pounds. That is all.
title: Ooof

body:
*   Those of you who follow me on the Twitter already know that The XY gifted me a small stroke this morning with his narcissistic fuckwittage. That was nice. I needed that to remind me I'm alive! I was looking forward to discussing this with Hotter, who had ceased his OWN fuckwittage (thankfully).
*   Oh except he really didn't, see, when I called him on my lunch and told him what I would need from him to let go of this and forgive and forget? Yeah, he said "absolutely, done, I love you baby!" and then totally went back on that, and oh my lord y'all, this isn't open season on Hotter or anything because I do love the damn fool and if he's only going to make me want to wring his neck twice in sixteen months that's still a pretty good average for a husband, but that said, REALLY, DID HE HAVE TO DO IT TWICE IN TWENTY-FOUR HOURS WHEN MY EYELID WAS ALREADY TWITCHING, SRSLY DUDE? He assures me it won't happen again, and y'know, this me-gone-all-the-time thing is hard on all of us and I'm not my most fabulous self right now either, really, I underSTAND, but one more tomorrow and you'll see me on the news, is all I'm saying. He failed marriage today AND yesterday, and it was the absofuckinglute LAST thing I needed. For one thing, I kind of wanted to ask him if he thought I was being an asshole on the issue with the XY, but if he can't be relied upon to tell when HE'S being a petty shithead then how can I rely on him to tell me whether I'M being a petty shithead? Plus SRSLY DUDE?
*   I got a comment on here that scared the crap out of me. Now, I'm not saying this to guilt the person who left it. As far as I can tell (although I freely admit that I misread people, OFTEN), they left said comment from a place of sympathy and caring, and they actually had a really good point vis a vie perspective that made me think about where my life is and realize it could be AND HAS BEEN worse, and therefore I can do this, really, even though it sucks, and for that I thank them whatever their motive might have been. But this is someone who in the past has clearly wished me quite a bit of ill, and therefore I can only conclude that either a) I am so fucking pathetic anymore that a former tormentor felt sorry for me or b) they were trying to breech my defenses and move in for the kill and well...damn. I don't deny being pathetic, hell, I don't even know why I'm talking about this crap except that I feel kind of alone against the world right now for the first time in a WHILE and in the past I've treated the innernet as the family and friends I lack and it's (mostly) been very kind in return (incidentally, y'all's cyberhugs and words of support and affirmation in the comments section really helped prop me up today, and I big-puffy-heart every single one of you for that)...but clearly I am having some kind of mental stability challenge either as a result of my life sucking balls or the steroid taper or both, and it occurs to me that maybe I ought to shut the hell up until that's over with since there ARE those who wish me ill, y'know? Especially since the XY has, as of this evening, declared his intent to sue my arse off (which could totally be bullshit, as he only actually sues me about once for every twenty times he threatens to, but still). So I'm not blogging until I recover my zen, which'll either be when the last of the prednisone (which I took today) wears off, and/or the next paycheck comes in, and/or Hotter manages to string together two or three consecutive days of not-making-me-feel-like-the-girl-who-marries-stupidly. SOMEthing's got to give, right? I can handle this. I've handled worse. It'll all be okay in the end, and if it's not okay, it's not the end. But until things are a little less godawful I don't think I ought to be running my mouth on the innernet, just in case. I'll be checking e-mail if you want to poke me with the pokey-stick-of-making-sure-she-ain't-dead-yet, and I'll probably check in on the Twitter, but uh...yeah. I'll catch y'all on the flipside.
title: the one where it gets worse

body:
Today was Middle Child's "Mother's Tea." 
   Mother's Day and I have issues. The Narcissist had a way of ruining all holidays when I was growing up, reminding everyone how we were letting her down, and so naturally a holiday all about her was extra-awful.
   The first-grade teacher put out a call for photos of students with their moms. I didn't have one of me and Middly, and had to take a quick snap early one morning. Me in my work-shirt, trying to smile without showing any teeth, Middly puffy from recent sleep. I looked at that picture and hated everything about it. I looked at it and saw everything wrong with my life.
   Last night was rough. Things actually went downhill some more, and I ended up drinking quite a bit and crying quite a bit more. I woke up hung over and feeling brittle, irritable. I forbade Hotter to speak to me. I stomped around and made plans to slaughter a chicken, because there's nothing much left in the freezer.
   Then I remembered about the tea. I didn't want to go. I didn't want people to see my missing front tooth. I didn't want to ruin Middly's event by being shy and sad and grubby and grim. I felt thoroughly sorry for myself. And then I thought about The Narcissist, and how her feeling that she deserved so much better than her life including me always came to the forefront, and was ashamed. I think part of why I'm so very down when I'm down is that at my very worst I remind myself of her. And well, fuck that.
   I thought about Middle Child, and how excited he was, and asked myself, what do little boys want from their mothers? They want them to be pretty and happy and carefree. And I set about making myself at least look that way. I scrubbed as much of the dirt as would come out out of my cracked hands and painted my nails. I put on a lacy shirt and a flowered skirt, even though my tits have gotten too big for the shirt and I had to sew myself into it. I pinned my hair back and cut rosebuds from the bush out front to put in it, because Middly sometimes talks about "fancy ladies wif flowers in dere hair." I put on my makeup, which required using a mirror, and just tried not to look at my goddamn tooth. And I put on my party shoes and drove to the elementary school.
   The tea was very sweet. Middly ushered me proudly to his desk and pulled out the chair for me. The children served us crudites and cookies, tea in little plastic tumblers. They sang us songs. Ours wasn't the only last-minute-looking picture in the slideshow. My necklace from Middly matched my skirt:

   On the wall was a bulletin board covered with articles the children had written about their moms. I remembered Middly interviewing me one time when I was hot and tired and grouchy, asking me questions, and I forget what I said, but this is what he wrote:
My mom is the best. My mom works a lot and she misses us, but she is still a good mom to me, Big Child, and Little Child. She loves us no matter how tired she is. My mom will not give up. She is strong and she has a big heart.
   Oh, buddy. 
   After the tea, the special education teacher and the classroom teacher took me aside to tell me that since he started ADD meds Middly has completely caught up to his peers. There is no more talk of him being held back; he doesn't even need to go to summer school. The reading specialist dropped in to tell me that Middly is one of the dearest children she has ever worked with: he is just such a joy, I cried when he reached his goals to stop working with me every week, she said. We all had a little weepfest.
   I am still Not Running My Mouth On The Innernet about myself, but I had to come on here and brag about my kid. He works so hard, and loves me so much, and I don't see HIM moping around feeling sorry for himself. Way to shake me out of my funk, kid. Your mom will not give up.
title: Mothers' Tea

body:
I really debated saying anything about this, because there are those who live under their bridges and wait for something good to happen to someone else so they can start with the verbose begrudging, and I didn't want to draw their attention to my happy little corner of the innernet.
   Yep, happy. It really is, most of the time, hell, the innernet gave me Hotter and saved my dog's life, and today y'all have gotten me gas and grocery money that will hit my account FRIDAY and hell, I can figure out one day even if, as I said to someone after I e-mailed them a thank-you and they responded (it's someone REALLY SUPER-AWESOME, TOO, LIKE YOU HAVE ALL HEARD OF HER, BUT DAMMIT SHE WON'T LET ME SAY)(because I want to THANK her by name, not just brag about how we're acquainted), it's "cous-cous egg mcfuckingmuffins with ketchup optional."
   It's not though. I realized that my totally picked-bare pantry and back yard contained all of the ingredients for a modified version of my chicken mock-tortilla soup. I call it that because I originally threw it together in imitation of a local store-brand chicken tortilla soup, but it lacks several key ingredients due to a combination of household-members' food and textural aversions, current poverty, and personal preferences. I kind of married tortilla soup and a Mennonite pork recipe I used for chicken and fell in love with involving squash, tomato, onion, and cumin.
MFA Mama's Mock-Tortilla Soup
Set a canning kettle of water to boil and go into the yard, watch the bald hen until someone comes along and picks a feather, grab the feather-picker, take her inside, and shampoo her feathers with dish soap. Bind her feet, hang her from the engine hoist out back, slit her throat, and leave her to bleed out while you get the kettle. Scald her until the wing feathers will come out easily, then re-hang her and pluck her, saving the breast and back feathers for a pillow. Gut, de-foot, and behead the bird according to these instructions. Serve the organs minus the gallbladder to the dogs along with the head and feet. 
Put the chicken in the crockpot along with water, a can of tomato paste, a four-ounce jar of pumpkin preserves, a couple of tablespoons chopped onion, half a dozen whole peeled cloves of garlic, half a jar of salsa, cumin to taste, pepper, salt, one packet of sazon, and a dash of cayenne. Cook on low all night.
In the morning, carefully use a spatula and serving spoon to maneuver the chicken onto a plate and stick it in the freezer. Put the broth in the fridge. Make corn tortillas and mash a can of pinto beans while they chill. Pick the chicken carcass until all outside meat is off, chop that, and add back to the broth after it cools enough skim the fat off and strain the broth. Put the broth in a large pot on the stove, add the meat and mashed beans, and heat to simmer. Add a handful or two of rice, and remove from heat when that is cooked through. Instruct your spouse to top with fresh cilantro from the herb garden and fried strips of tortilla, put comments back on moderate, and go to work at a large venue out of town without worrying about food, gas, or trolls. Whoo tits!
title: in which I chin up and make mock-tortilla soup

body:
Let me preface this by stating that I actually do understand more than most laypeople do about infectious disease and its transmission methodology, and am crystal. effing. clear. that being cold, for example, does not cause one to get a cold and then pneumonia any more than antibiotics offer any measure of protection against, say, viruses (or prions, I'd imagine). 
   That said? I AM ALREADY FELLED BY ANOTHER EFFING COLD AND I HAVEN'T EVEN FINISHED TAKING THE COURSE OF GOT-DAMN LEVAQUIN THAT WAS SUPPOSED TO SAVE THE END OF 2010? NO, SHUT UP, THAT'S JUST BULLSHIT.
   Also, sick + asthma + v. cold air outside + just got up and did the morning cough-out = "here, take both leashes honey, I am going to take my lungs inside and let them sit and think about what they've done just now." 
   I feel the further need to clarify beyond any shadow of a doubt that I do not have it that bad with teh asthma. It's a pain in the arse chest at times, and it's inconvenient and costly (at least by my standards), but I have never had a hospital admission due to asthma, for example. I am whining here because I don't like what I've got, not because what I've got is so epically tragic and awful, and I get that.
   Hotter is so very sweet about it when I'm sick. He brings me heated Bed Buddies for my feet and boxes of tissue and hot tea and smooches. I am very cognizent of how lucky I am to be sick on a day when I don't have to work or wrangle small boys, in a warm, clean bed, with a Hotter about.
   I guess I'm nervous of doing anything even approaching whining or complaining, not only because I am wholly fortunate and well-aware of that, but also because I've got to adjust to writing with a stalker all over again. I write, and then I ask myself, does that make you seem too ill to be a "fit" mother in the eyes of X or will someone say you're angling for Y to happen with the sickness? 
   But I'm learning to let go of that. Sometimes I'm just telling true stories of what goes on inside my head, because this is my blog, my narcissistic little sandbox where I pound out mah feelings and anyone reading is, at least a little bit, engaging in voyeurism because people of the innernet: I AM NOT REALLY THAT INTERESTING OR IMPORTANT. I mean, I read a lot of blogs myself because I think there's still that anthropological pull in us toward commonality, and also in some of us toward understanding what makes us different; I'm not saying you're some kind of cyber-perv if you're reading this (or at least that you're no more of a cyber-perv than I am, technically, so) but just that...really? If I'm writing about how I'm sick and need a wahhhhmbulance because I couldn't play in the snow and you're a) not enjoying it and b) reading it like an amateur literary critic trying to find something to point to as indicative of my inherent narrative unreliability then HELLO, OH MAH GAH, POT? KETTLE??? 
   But then, I already covered that on my About page, and most of you have better reading comprehension skills than, oh, an adolescent rhesus monkey. So! I am sick, my lungs are being buttholes: woe. WOE I SAY! And you?
title: eesh, my lungs are buttholes when I'm sick

...however, the painful, expensive years since then have taught me that managing NON-surgical "emergencies" with stable vital signs is ALWAYS better at home, even if you luck out with providers and treatment and get the best of both.
   And if this...thing...in my right ribcage was endangering me (as opposed to just making me wish for a hastened end), I think that would have "declared itself" by now through negative changes in my respiratory status or perhaps a festive hemoptysis (and it has done neither); at least a crackling-hot fever or something. Therefore this? Is "just" pain, and "just" pain tends to get you a slow-ticket through triage at the local teaching hospital (and if you're VERY unlucky, accusations of drug-seeking/hypochondria). And if that place can't fix me, the local community hospital chumps couldn't even BEGIN to fix me (although in their defense, presented with a frank surgical emergency I've had them rise magnificently to the occasion several times in the past), and then it becomes a question of "is this a good use of the ER (no) and the fastest route to recovery-hastening treatment (nope), or just frustration and pain convincing you to pay your full deductible amount in exchange for IV narcotics, basically?"
   Having scored MY sweet, sweet fix of medical treatment (in the form of strong antibiotics, steroids, and LIQUID HYDROCODONE) during business hours, I now invite you to guess who has two thumbs and just chased a Nexium down with a slug of Tussionex (bleh) before their evening inhalers...seriously. Three guesses. And the first two don't count. GO!
 
P.S. I have to grudgingly concede that after my second treatment of inhaled steroids I do feel the inflammation in my chest has decreased somewhat...or maybe it's the placebo effect, in which case I do not want to know. Because while I'm feeling nowhere near BETTER, I do feel as if I'm finally on my way to (painfully) coughing this crap UP and clearing my chest, and that beats a poke in the eye with a sharp stick.

body:
Last night I didn't really sleep; I got maybe an hour and a half propped upright in a recliner but every time I climbed into bed and backed into Hotter's warm body to spoon I'd end up coughing until I gagged and that was The Suck. The only GOOD part about all the not-sleeping is that I checked Anthem's website in the wee hours and almost cried, I was so happy to see my name listed with an active policy.
   As soon as business hours commenced, I called my primary care physician's office and they told me to come on in.
   I left with four new prescriptions. *sad trombone* My doctor wasn't worried about the rib pain so much (she agreed with me that it didn't need an x-ray; the technical term is "autoimmune costochondritis" and it sucks but it's not dangerous or anything) but she made the Mr. Bill face as soon as she put her stethescope on me and wanted to put me on Predisone, which she said would also as an added benefit make my rib feel better. I reminded her that I react badly (VERY badly) to systemic (or even localized) steroids and she speculated that she could always do a twenty-three hour admit and put me on them in-house. We compromised on a month of inhaled steroids, which I worry will still trigger the godawful side effects, but breathing trumps just about everything else so there you have it. She's also having me do another course of Levaquin "just in case" since I'm not moving the junk in my chest around very efficiently, and ordinarly I'm not a fan of antibiotics "just in case" and will demand a CBC with demonstrably elevated white count or "left shift" before I'll even entertain the notion if I don't have a fever, but I've been rather worried about my inability to cough effectively due to the rib thing and decided to go with the medical professional's judgment on this one. Since I agreed to do the steroid inhaler and the antibiotic, she even took pity on me and wrote a script for some kind of super cough-syrup that's supposedly quite strong (I couldn't read her writing but it started with a T and I'm hopeful it's the stuff you make Purple Drank out of, because that would be cool), and also re-wrote the scripts for my four maintenance meds (since I've decided Express Scripts is simply not to be trusted and plan to fill everything locally and absorb the extra expense), and y'all, when I walked into the pharmacy and handed them my eight prescriptions I was SO FREAKING GRATEFUL because DAMN.
   I have always felt fortunate to have health insurance but never so much as I did today, because one or two more days of this and I think my arse would've landed in the ER an unfetching shade of blue. And how are all of YOU?
title: the one where I'm REALLY happy I now have health insurance

body:
There's this thing that's been going on, that I haven't discussed with y'all, because it's kind of crazy. See, I felt like I was getting kicked in the ribs by a baby when I coughed, and since one rib can't move on its own I assumed this was coming from my lung-al area and something to do with either the asthma or the steroids kicking its arse or the years of smoking cloves as a teenager or something.
   Then I discovered (through remembering my father's recovery from his bypass surgeries and friends on the Twitter offering suggestions for what one ought to do about agonizing chest pain with coughing) that holding a firm pillow, rice sock, or other giving, pressure-distributing object up against my ribs HARD before coughing easied the pain by about 80%, and the antibiotics and steroids started kicking in, and then speaking of kicking, WTF?
   Now, I have been largely incapacitated for several days, meaning Hotter has done the lion's share of household-y things and I have spent a lot of time on the couch wrapped in sweatshirts and robes, bracing my ribs and sucking on inhalers. So a few minutes ago I was caught by a pending coughing fit in the kitchen (where I was getting ready to put an artichoke in to boil before watching something on Netflix with Hotter, and now he's sulkng because I'm on here but I HAD TO TELL Y'ALL ABOUT THIS) and didn't have anything on me (because the MFA Children are not at home and I had just taken a hot bath), both literally as in clothing and as in anything to brace my ribs in, and so I pressed my hand against my bare chest and--WHOA! On the third cough, I FELT IT. I braced and coughed three more times. Yep.
   I grabbed Hotter and shoved his hand up under my right boob and coughed three times and--"WHAT THE HELL IS THAT?"
   "Remember how I said it felt like a baby kicking in my chest? MEET THE BABY. OH MY GOD, IT'S LIVER-BABY! Your LIVER is under your right chest! You felt her, right, I'm NOT crazy?"
   "Oh I felt it alright. That's nasty, honey. Seriously, you need to get that checked out."
   True story. Because it's Friday night, and why not? Now I get to spend all weekend asking Dr. Google what it means when it feels like a baby is kicking in your chest. Awesome.

We plan to just keep an eye on her here at home since Banfield is open on the weekends if she takes a turn for the worse.*   The mange treatment fund is coming along; we're almost three quarters of the way there and I'm starting to think we can actually pull this off--YAY! THANK YOU SO MUCH!!!*   I am still worried though, and I still mow when I'm worried so I fired up Belleruth and did a very little bit of that, and now my ankle is killing me. Booo.*   The MFA Flock has continued, between the five of them, to produce one egg per day, which is better than no eggs at all. I made them some chicken treats out of flaxseed meal, flaxseed oil, cornmeal, peanut butter, and ground TUMS (for calcium) rolled into balls. They love that stuff! Hopefully bulking them up a little encourages them to step it up a little with the egg production.*   Big Child is lucky it's a Daddy weekend, because I was about ready to...well I don't KNOW what I would have done since We Do Not Beat Children Here, maybe boxed him up and Airmailed him to the Hague so they could try him with the other war criminals? He hurt one of his little brothers, which is not cool, and lied about it, which is REALLY not cool, then tried to talk over the littles when I was interrogating witnesses, and then the XY rolled up.*   The XY took in the situation (sobbing smaller child, Big Child with his telltale Lying Face on, me with the Crazy Eye and Hotter standing by with his arms crossed, which is what he generally does when I am reenacting that scene from Downfall, minus the subtitles, because of something the children have done) and got The Crazy Eye too, because apparently Big Child is feeling his oats at the XY's house lately as well. Messed up as it might sound to say this, it felt pretty good to be scolding Big Child in concert with the XY today as a cohesive coparenting unit out in my driveway; we presented a united front for maybe the first time EVER with the MFA Children. YAY!*   And now I have a weekend alone with my husband and dog ahead of me for the first time in a month and I feel pretty danged lucky over it, I'm not gonna lie. We may be broke but we've got plenty of projects to tackle around the house including a dining-room table to refinish (and by "refinish" I mean "have sex on"), and food the children wouldn't eat to cook, so we'll have a good time.  *   I hope y'all all have a lovely weekend!
title: updates in bullet form

body:
Well I am pleased to report that we all three got a good night's sleep here (me, Hotter, and Sabrina) (what? Oh, well, if I'd ever had a girl it was either that or Isabella and seeing as how all three MFA Children are boys and I am lacking 2/3 the reproductive organs necessary for NORMAL gestation, Liverbaby is my last chance at a girl and it was always going to be either Sabrina or Isabella, but I like Sabrina a hair more today).
   Which is good because last night the little scamp had me nearly in tears despite copious hydrocodone syrup. She's more active at night, as a rule, or when I'm worked up or moving around/lifting overly much, and so while I can see that probably the wisest thing would be not to get worked up, move around, or lift overly much, the problem with that is that I'm stressed to the max, the pregnancy is most uncomfortable when I'm sitting or lying down so it feels good PHYSICALLY to be up and doing things as well as mentally because I haven't yet managed to balance my laptop on my burgeoning belly and walk around typing, and EVERYTHING I lift (from my laptop, with less than both hands, to Bumpus, who really doesn't weigh much at all, to a watering can full of water for the MFA Flock) is overly much depending on when I last took a fistful of meds and Sabrina's mood.
   This is very frustrating, y'all. I mean, obviously it sucks that I need to be really ABLE right now and I'm really NOT, but this is also a) freaking my shit out because I HAVE BEEN DISABLED FOR LONG PERIODS BEFORE AND NONONONONONODONOTWANT! and b) not even the SORT of disability with which I am familiar enough to have a mental list of life-hacks to help survive it. I know how to deal with "post-op/autoimmune everything hurts" and "can't stay awake more than ten minutes due to drugs/endocrine failure" and "catastrophic GI issues, all sorts" but RESPIRATORY PROBLEMS? Fuck this, y'all. I am not cut OUT to deal with shortness of breath, not even a little bit, not the kind where you sometimes get winded from walking to take a piss, just NO. I'm pretty upset about things I dont' share here, and obviously about the job, and there are life's ongoing niggling worries (Little Child was in semi-GI shutdown when I handed him over and I won't know how THAT'S going until I either get him back Monday or hear from a doctor's office or emergency room that needs his accurate medical history and vital statistics, Middle Child's IEP just got emergently modified because it's turning out to be much harder for him to learn than expected this year and he may need meds, Hotter needs to go and see Dr. Kidney, etc....) and OF COURSE we all hate to be sick, but...I really do take this rather personally. Lungs? Feh.
   Also I am beginning to suspect (this being day five of the antibiotics and steroids and such) that if I feel this bad now, I won't feel that much better when I've completed the course of treatment, and I'll have to go back, and I'm not looking forward to finding out what the next level of diagnostics for this sort of shit is and how much that'll cost. Phooey.
   How are all of YOU?
title: updates from the expectorant mother

body: *   In-laws. Man oh man. As I explained to a laughing Hotter earlier today, while Grandma XY can out-nut and out-manipulate any one of his family members any day of the week and twice on Sunday AS AN INDIVIDUAL, the difference between the XY's family and his is that his is less vicious in general, which means they are capable of the sort of cooperation it takes to hunt AS A PACK, making them arguably MORE dangerous in the end.*   As I also explained to Hotter, I am too sane and tired for any amount of familial drama. He says it's one of the things he loves the most about me. So I gave my facespace friends-list an enema and it was awesome.*   In case you missed the cryptic tweet lizzee was referring to in the comments earlier, here it is. Due to the circumstances surrounding the situation I obliquely referred to in said cryptic tweet being not-my-story-to-tell, all I can really say is that there will be no sixth MFAmily member of the human variety afterall. Stand down, y'all! This is good news and bad news, in that we need another body in this house like we need scabies, but the reason we won't be getting one is rooted in a tragedy my husband is keenly affected by, so: boo, universe.*   I think my poor husband's beard turned about 50% more gray today. The reasons for that were entirely outside of my control, so I screwed his brains out before the children got home from school, then sent him outside to take out his remaining feelings on the deadwood in the line of cedars along our driveway with a pruning saw, handled dinner, and baked two kinds of pie for dessert. With whipped cream. *   Big Child would probably be very much in favor of daily tragedies if he had any idea at all what was going on behind the scenes in light of the TWO. KINDS. OF. PIE, but as the situation in question is not unfolding under our roof and does not involve people the MFA Children know very well at all, they are blissfully unaware and I think that is exactly as it should be.*   My weekend sucked quite a bit overall, I won't lie. Friday was excellent, but I spent most of Saturday in bitter, bitter tears, most of Sunday literally and figuratively hung over, and most of today in a protracted state of suspense and outrage that only ended shortly before dinnertime (the suspense bit, anyway--the outrage I think is mine to keep). FIE ON THAT. FIE I SAY!*   MFA Puppy is doing much better, did not throw up at all today, and seems to be starting to itch a little less. So I think it was the dose of wormer she received along with her Mitaban dip that made her so ill and not the increased dose of Ivermectin (which she is still on and will be for at least a couple of weeks), which is good. She needs that stuff to kill the mites! Tomorrow I'll see if she can handle a fully normal diet again (we kept her on half regular dogfood, half bland prescription GI diet today), and if she does okay then on Wednesday we'll see how she manages without Benadryl every eight hours for the itching. Friday is her appointment to get spayed if her liver enzymes aren't out of whack so I would imagine the fewer drugs in her system by then, the better. If you'd like to contribute to her treatment fund, go here.*   I'm in the process of separating the entries in the caption contest from the identifying information and will be sending them to our celebrity judge, Pal M.D. of Whitecoat Underground, tomorrow. I heart Pal; his blog is excellent and you should all go and read it, because I probably won't have anything interesting to say for a day or two while I'm taking care of some stuff here and trying to cheer Hotter up. At least I hope I don't. Because this weekend was interesting enough to last me until 2011. Seriously. *   How are all of YOU?
title: in which I do not particularly explain the obtuse tweet

body:
*   So it turns out that tree surgery is VERY good for relieving one's excess feelings, and also that hyperflexible joints are an asset in tree-climbing. Hotter and I took the clippers and the pruning saw out and felled a smallish pine, cleared two coppiced fencelines, tamed the wild azalea corner, and cut some large deadwood from that tree I got in a fight with.*   It also turns out that that tree is trying to kill me! Or else something-something-self-confidence-not-looking-down but anyway I climbed up the thing like some kind of monkey-ninja to get at a particularly large and unsightly broken dead limb and sawed the limb free no problem, then looked down in handing the saw down to Hotter and...well, my feet were way up over his head and I had to crouch down holding the end of the saw for him to be able to grab the handle and then I was all stiff and nervous-like climbing down and wedged the top of my leg between two trunks somehow.
Figure One: This is my left outer thigh. It is normally blueish-white, because that's how I roll, but not blue-ish blue and purple--THAT is all the tree. Up in the upper left corner you can kind of see my belly. Not pictured: my maturity and sense of shame. That tree is out to get me and if it keeps this shit up I will figure out how to work the chainsaw out in my garden shed and WE WILL END THIS ONCE AND FOR ALL.*   MFA Puppy had a pretty good day today. No more barfing, she's back on her usual food, and she made it through the morning and afternoon without needing any Benadryl (I think it helped that she was outside "helping" us and thoroughly distracted). She did need a dose of the stuff toward the evening when she started scratching herself half to death, but she's doing better than she was a few days ago (when sadly, even WITH Benadryl, she was pretty miserable).*   Tomorrow Hotter and I are going to go to an indoor Farmer's Market that sells fresh local foods (fruits and vegetables, eggs and meat, dairy and artisan breads, arts, crafts, etc.) with a 50% off coupon in-hand, and we're VERY excited! Between that and going mostly-cloth here at Casa MFA (I say mostly because yes, we cook and clean with bar towels, dry our hands with napkins I keep in baskets by the sinks, and use cloth napkins but I draw the line at cloth arse-wipes), growing veggies, and keeping chickens, we're turning into damn hippies over here or something. I'm looking forward to the Fall vegetables and local dairy the most--I think we'll spring for the bottle deposit and get some milk (as long as it's not "raw" because we are not down with extraneous bacteria here) and I definitely want to try some farm-fresh butter!*   The situation I'm not discussing is mostly over with, or at least it seems that way, and I am hoping that tomorrow things will be at least somewhat back to normal. Or else I may have to cut a bitch. We'll see.
title: the one where I post the naked picture

body:
There are two major components to why I am so GOD-damned miserable right now, and I have treated them both as Unbloggable because a) specific commentary in a public forum would obviously be stupid if I was to be involved in any kind of ongoing lawsuit, obviously, as in the case of the first one and b) believe it or not, I do keep some things to myself (two things, actually) and the second thing is one of them.  
   Thing One is just Not Up For Discussion, and y'know 99% of the time I am FINE with that, because it's no fun to discuss and nobody is going to have any new ideas that I and the various professionals I have hired and my various friends with experience with such things have not already had. I don't lose anything by not being able to talk about Thing One except for maybe the "ability to vent," which honestly (and yeah, you might laugh at this and I'm certainly not going to tell you not to) I think is overrated. The fact is, you see as much Evil* as you will look at, and you hear as much as you will listen to and give voice to on your own. This is a lot of why I don't have the teevee here; I know my own capacity to deal with Evil and it very rarely extends to matters outside of my own four walls here. I would literally rather have my teeth drilled without anesthetic (and that is not me being all metaphorical, it's something I have done before, several times, because my jaw is UnNumbable) for half an hour straight than watch a primetime news program, be it local, national, or global. Just...no. I do my best to keep up with curent events selectively through the innernet so as not to become ignorant, and I do know what is awful about things like the wording in the "forcible rape" bill and the unrest in Egypt, I just don't want to discuss them with the people I love or dwell on them. And Thing One is the closest thing in my life to pure Evil and therefore I am usually more than fine with not giving it any space on here.
   Thing Two falls under the category of "self realizations; painful" and involves People Who Aren't Me, and I try not to discuss the ongoing events in PWAMs' lives because generally unless someone has asked for an opinion, they don't care to hear yours. I would like VERY much to be able to discuss Thing Two with y'all, but I don't because I have learned painfully the lesson of Don't Write About PWAMs' Lives On The Innernet. Especially if you know that Other People are probably right and you are not doing what they would in your shoes, or that Other People are probably wrong and know it, and/but don't want to hear it from you. Both of those scenarios can fall prey to Mob Rule and end in Godwin's Law faster than you can say "what I really meant was--" and oh, y'all. I just don't need that. I'm not up for it.
   I'm talking to you as though I'm going to Reveal All or something, and because I hate to let you down I'll go ahead and say right here that I'm not going to do that. What I am doing, here, is less filling y'all in on these two things and more trying to describe a problem I have encountered. See, Thing One is 99% Evil, and Thing Two is 99% Good, and normally they balance each other out. Sometimes, VERY RARELY, Thing One is that 1% Good and it screws with my head, oh lawd does it ever, to the point that I'd pretty much rather Thing One stay bad. Thing Two is ALMOST NEVER that 1% bad, and THAT screws with my head as much as when Thing One is good, plus it pisses me off because of the two Unbloggable Things, Thing Two is the one whose involvement in my life I VOLUNTARY submit to. There has been ONE occasion in the years that I've been dealing with Thing One and Thing Two that they've both been in 1% mode, and that had me cross-eyed and dicombobulated for the better part of a week.
   What's going on right now, though, is that Thing One is bad, and so is Thing Two, and in times like this I look at the two situations and I know that I cannot possibly deal with them both and the only solution (as Thing One is unescapable in life and 99% bad and Thing Two is something in my life that I involve myself in voluntarily) that I can see is to say "I can't take 100% Evil in my life and can't control 99% of it, so the 1% coming from Thing Two has to go."
   Of course, if I'd been able to deal with moving through life with only the 1% of Good from Thing One, I would never have sought out Thing Two, and nobody held a gun to my head and MADE me do that, and in fact 98% of the time I am the first one to pat myself on the back for working things out rather nicely overall. But in those other 2% I feel like a goddamn idiot who stupidly ruined their own existance, and this is one of those times.
   When it rains, I guess it pours.
 
*  To borrow terminology from the "see no evil, hear no evil, speak no evil" monkeys, not to say that I believe in the archetypical judeochristian concepts of Good, big g and Evil, big e
title: the unbloggable

body:
Okay, remember this post? About as clear as mud, right? GOOD!
   In the eight hours since then the following things have occurred:
*   Something Truly Uplifting that I thought was lost forever was rediscovered thanks to a friend's sleuthing, and I got to marvel at it.
*   I opened my mail for the first time since last Saturday because I've been THAT OUT OF IT and discovered Life-changingly good news. Like, drop the mail, scream and jump around, dance with your husband even if you're officially miffed with him and about seven months pregnant in your liver kind of good.
*   My main freelance client PAID ME EARLY! Well actually they paid me right on time, but since I'd spent the past two years dusting off my resume with a secondary client who paid later, I hadn't planned on having the money yet. I mean, it's not FREE MONEY or anything. Just money I already expected, in time to keep from having to bounce any checks, forego any medical care or prescription drugs, or default on anything, which I hadn't anticipated or dared to hope for. I'll even be able to Fix What Ails The MFA Minivan (it's always something) and contribute a little to savings. Hot damn!*   Hotter, knowing that a good dark, nutty roux on chicken is the way to my heart, cooked us a fabulous meal after I made a victorious trip to the grocery store and there was WINE INVOLVED**
*   I am still choosing not to blog openly about Thing One or Thing Two. But the end result of all of the above is that Thing One, while Evil, is in Good mode for the forseeable future, and Thing Two, while still pissing me off in general, therefore has some time to get its shit together and remember that it's Very, Very Good 99% of the time. I can deal with 1% Evil. I can do that with both hands tied behind my back and a baby kicking me in the lung. Just watch me.
 
 
** Why yes I am drunk now. A little. Maybe.
title: so much can happen in only eight hours, it'll make you dizzy

body:
*   As of Saturday I am once again in midst of a rather urgent legal imbruglio, and as a result I will most likely have to go to court sometime this week. It's never wise to discuss legal things online, so I won't be any more specific than to say that *I* am not in trouble, it's civil, not criminal, and it does NOT involve the MFA Children (for once, thank Godiva). This is therefore a rather stressful and expensive pain in the arse, but falls pretty low on my own personal Richter scale. I'm more worried about what I'm going to WEAR than anything else.
*   Liverbaby was a real pest last night and I didn't sleep very well, so I'm going back to the doctor tomorrow to see what she wants to do about this. Here is where I have to give a shout out to my good friend Marie-Baguette, who in addition to being an innernet pal from waaaay back kindly thought of me when she was downsizing (heh) her bra collection, post-lactation. See, the place where you can feel Liverbaby kicking requires you to stick your hand under my right tit if I don't have a bra on, and I DID NOT HAVE ANY BRAS THAT WOULD FIT. Like, not even close. I wasn't looking forward to being all "so yeah, just lift that up and it's RIGHT THERE" but the package arrived today and therefore spared me some embarrassment. Thanks, MB!
*   We took both dogs to the vet this morning, because Isis has been scratching her ears to death and Bumpus needed to get enrolled in the Wellness Plan and start his shots (I know, I know--I was putting it off because we were so damn broke, but it turns out that might've been a good thing because they have to be a certain age to receive some vaccines and he's quite a bit younger than we thought). Isis has a bacterial AND fungal infection in both ears, because of COURSE she does, so we've got some earwash and drops to use for that (to the tune of a hundred bucks, dammit). Bumpus was pronounced healthy and still nutless by the vet, and also UNDER sixteen weeks of age (he has a few adult incisors but no adult canines or molars yet, so the vet said DEFINITELY under sixteen weeks). Which means the poor dog was only about a month old when we found him, and explains why he was so tiny and determined to nurse off of Isis. "He's going to be BIG!" the vet said, admiringly (currently he is twenty-six pounds). As far as WHAT he is, the vet agrees with Devivo that he's most likely a Redbone Coonhound with maybe a little of some other kind of hound in there.
*   We went to the feed store for chicken feed but they were out of the organic stuff AGAIN. I've just been baking for the hens for the past few weeks because they were out LAST time...grr. The GOOD news, though, is that our feed store now carries fancy chickens and orders peeps in the Spring, so we placed an order and YAAAAY BABY CHICKS! We'll save a lot of money by not having to pay for overnight shipping from MyPetChicken.com. The new additions to the MFA Flock should arrive March 1st, and will be a mix of Buff Orpingtons, Welsummers, Australorps, and Russian Orloffs. It's gonna be like the Chicken UN up in here with the Barred Rocks and the ISA Brown representing America, the Araucanas from Chile, the Buff Orpingtons from the UK, the Welsummers (Dutch) and the Orloffs! I hope they can all get along. Also, I'm renaming my crockpot "The Peacemaker."
*   We're also thinking of getting a heritage turkey to raise for Thanksgiving, which should be good for a laugh (baby turkeys and particularly adolescent turkeys are HILARIOUS-LOOKING). And yes, yes I would ABSOLUTELY eat a turkey I raised. Better that than a COMMERCIAL turkey I DIDN'T raise, and without a CSA membership our grassfed organic turkey from this past Thanksgiving would have cost well over seventy-five dollars. Baby turkeys are like, three bucks, and since we already have poultry underfoot we might as well save some money there. We'll most likely try to get a female, because fullgrown male turkeys scare the piss out of me and Hotter both (before you laugh, have you ever MET one? They're very aggressive, and THEY RATTLE THEIR BONES AT YOU).
*   How are all of YOU? That's not a rhetorical question, by the way, I really do care and want to know.

body:

body:
*   I have a laptop messenger bag lost somewhere in this house with Middle Child's birth certificate inside it, and I need to locate that before the 31st. GAH!
*   I finally came to the uneasy conclusion that keeping Anthem on the grounds that it's the devil I know is just silly, and am at peace with that decision for various reasons that only fully make sense if you know MUCH more about the situation than I am willing to divulge to the innernets at large. Big love to Alex of Late Enough fame for helping me articulate it and laugh instead of crying, and especially for her candor, which is refreshing.

title: oof

body:
I.
   Kathy from Anthem e-mailed me and kept doggedly searching for better solutions for me and has made me an offer I almost can't refuse (by which I mean if Anthem will take payment on or after 2/1 for coverage starting 2/1 without a pre-existing condition waiting period then no, I can't refuse it).
II.
   I was telling Hotter that some of y'all also...uh...get a kick out of his understanding of female anatomy and physiology. He sighed and looked put-upon and said "I just thought that when the lining was shed, the egg was shed with it." I said that that was largely factually correct. "Then what the hell happens to your lining and the egg?" I scraped all of the pieces of my head up into a clean cup in case Anthem re-approves me and I can have it reassembled later, and took a deep breath and said "yes but I have no lining because I have no UTERUS" and he said "ohhh and the egg is just one cell." Then I cast the pieces of my shattered head back onto my good wool rug like dice in a game of Yahtzee because I quit, y'know?
title: oh but then (a.k.a. the one where the worm turns)

body:
So for those of you who haven't been playing along at home, I have been all kinds of sad Keanu* because of my ongoing health insurance debacle and Hotter was trying to convince me that it would be a good thing for him to somehow knock me up in my liver. I considered hocking my engagement ring (which made Hotter kind of...upset) and then did the longterm math and decided I was at peace with going four more months and hoping PCIP was decent. Then Kathy at Anthem went above and beyond, and tempted me with her dogged pleasantness and offers of continued coverage, and she and I exchanged several (dozen) e-mails, culminating in (I will not publish any of her words but rather my own, to her, unedited):
Dear Kathy,   Yes, thank you SO much, that does make sense! I am  fine with the $XXXrate with a 2/1 effective date and will pay the  balance due ($XX?) at that time. Is that doable without the waiting  period as you and I had previously discussed? Because if so that is a  deal and I have to build a small (tasteful, I assure you) shrine to you  in my living room. MFA Mama P.S. Oranges or incense or both?
and
Thank you, THANK YOU, so much! Seriously, you've gone above and beyond  the call of duty and I really appreciate your work on my behalf. In a  wholesome and non-creepy sort of way. Probably. MFA Mama

Because we need to name something after you and I don't want another dog. XOX
 
* I just now found out about sad Keanu. WHERE HAS HE BEEN ALL MY LIFE? It almost makes me regret my self-imposed media blackout. ALMOST.
title: liver-baby has a name, y'all

body:
*   I was joking to Hotter this morning that first thing Tuesday when I have health insurance again Imma walk into my primary care physician's office, spread my arms wide, and just shriek "DO ME!!! DO A CHEST X-RAY AND TAKE SOME BLOOD AND CALL A SPECIALISSSSSSST!!!"
*   Joking aside, as Hotter asked me to clarify, there still isn't anything anyone can really do for me, health insurance or no. The generalized nerve pain and sacroiliitis have subsided to entirely tolerable levels at this point, meaning that Lyrica wouldn't help me enough to be worth the side effects, and while the rib thing continues to be agonizing, the only thing to really do even if it IS cracked or dislocated is whimper and perhaps take narcotics. Narcotics sound delicious right about now, in that they could probably bring the pain level down to a nagging three or four on the much-vaunted one to ten scale, but I'm not so certain that'd be an entirely good thing--probably if I felt that much better I'd overdo it and aggravate everything. Plus when you have a history of refractory pain issues and long-term narcotic use due to same, any time you throw your system another hit you're jacking your tolerance back up in a way that'll bite you in the ass if you're in an accident or have to have general anesthesia, so kind of like the Lyrica, narcotics remain an option I reserve for use in cases where I am hurting so badly I don't even GIVE A SHIT ABOUT ANY OF THAT, GIVE ME THE DRUUUUUUUGSSSSSSSSSSS. We're not there yet right now. Right now we're just at the point where it's a really nice fantasy, the idea of walking into a doctor's office, having them locate something fixably wrong, and dispense with the relief and healing, and fond as I am of that happy daydream I know that the reality of any medical interaction I'd have right now would disappoint (and cost a lot of money).
*   My primary freelance client of the past nearly-a-decade effed up BIGTIME and sent my offer letter for this quarter's (much more than usual) contract work to a many-years-old address of mine LAST MONTH, where it was apparently noticed TODAY and opened by...my ex-husband. EFF. WORD. He now knows exactly how much money I make, which he could have found out by filing an official request with the courts at any time, but that would cost him a couple thousand dollars and require someone thinking he needed to know, and now he knows FOR FREE and I still don't have the same intel on him. I think if I wasn't in such exquisite, agonizing pain currently I would be a lot more irate about this than I am, but still, ANNOYING. Hotter pointed out that as I have a voicemail in which the XY essentially reads my mail to me out loud, I could probably have him charged with a federal offense. Which: hee! Also: too much trouble and would make me look petty. Ah well.
