   She continues to find the river an affront of some kind, and plunged in teeth first to teach it a lesson:
 Figure One: "Oh, YOU again! Prepare to die!"
   The river put up more of a fight than Isis was expecting, and she made many frantic passes up and down the rocky shore snapping at the ripples in the water:
 Figure Two: "You may not understand that I am a pitbull, here--MY DEATHGRIP, LET ME SHOW YOU IT!"
  Figure Three: Her ears are like that because this is an action shot and she is pouncing.
   Finally, when biting the water failed to conquer it, Isis had the bright idea of drinking it down to a more manageable size. I think our dog drank about a gallon of the river today, y'all--I never said this was the face of intelligence:
 Figure Four: Potentially identifying landmarks obscured. As an aside I guess I can see why people who want pitbulls to look fierce crop their ears, because that? Is pretty hard to take seriously :)
   So yes, a good time was had by all and I will need a LOT of hand-holding tomorrow via the Twitter, because mah baybee is having SURGERY! And how are YOU?
 
P.S. Our celebrity judge (eminent physician-blogger Pal, M.D.) is mulling over the caption contest entries, and I have ingredients for cookies on-hand and a dishrag ready to go in the mail. Stay tuned!

body:
I've been all "ow, ow, my peripheral nervous system" and wrapped up in the unbloggable lately, and have therefore neglected to fill y'all in on a certain...scituation.
   Due to partially manmade dentition on my part, amylogenesis imperfecta in four fifths of my household (and the other having damaged his teeth beyond repair from the gastroparesis involved with diabetes and end-stage renal failure, not that I'm naming any names, AHEM) I have a...thing...about teeth.
   TEETH ARE NOT TOOLS. 
   You, (collective you, not anyone in particular, cough) even those of you with fine-motor delays and lingering effects of major strokes, have opposable thumbs that occupational therapists have deemed usable and therefore you will take the step that SEPARATES us from the animals god damn it, and use a scissors to open or sever whatever the hell it is in my house.
   Being a benevolent dictator, I have endeavored to make sure there are scissors available to those in need and therefore it is entirely reasonable that I own at least twelve pairs of scissors.
   What is NOT entirely reasonable is that even though I can name and describe:
* the good kitchen shears that belong in the knife-block* the first school scissors Big Child ever owned, which are still around, covered in puppy-teethmarks* the Good Haircut Scissors* the shitty Replacement Haircut Scissors that pull more than cut and are forever scorned* the Fair-to-Middling New Haircut Scissors* the two pairs of antibacterial-coated handled scissors meant for the two older children, ordered in bulk off the innernet, that turned out to be PINK and therefore stayed home* the three similar-to-first-school-scissors scissors that I bought on clearance and opened in times of desperation* the stolen-from-local-teaching-hospital ER scissors that look like surgical tools* the tiny, shitty sewing-kit scissors for threadsnipping
   ...NOT A GOT-DAMN ONE OF SAID IMPLEMENTS CAN BE LOCATED IN THIS 1,100-square-foot house.
   Hotter and I have therefore declared that the first child to locate a usable pair of scissors (and I would even accept two or three of the missing cuticle trimmers, mind you) is UN-grounded (there have been groundings, oh yes) and the two losers unsuccessful searchers will possibly even be grounded EXTRA-long.
   This is perfectly reasonable, see? (don't anscwer that)

*   The unbloggable vagueness has come to a head today and is, I think, approaching its climax (heh, I said climax). I have issued an ultimatum (which I hate doing, because nobody takes those well) and it's out of my hands. At this point the best possible outcome would still involve some legal expenses and protracted unpleasantness, and the worst would involve a LOT of legal expenses, protracted unpleasantness, AND major changes that nobody really wants (Hotter and me, the MFA Children, OR the other party). The other party has always been a go-down-with-his-ship kind of guy, so I'm not terribly hopeful that we'll end up with the lesser evil but will still be sad if/when things go (further) south from here.
*   Five eggs today! This is noteworthy because production has been down overall since Deathtrek '10 (the hens are spoiled and don't appreciate treatless days). Yesterday we only got TWO eggs. Today I made organic mutigrain waffles, ethically-farmed local bacon, and our own eggs for brunch and gave the chickens two leftover waffles, so perhaps that inspired them?
*   Bumpus is staying. Yes, you all told me so. Dammit. But on the bright side, we can't afford to buy any gifts this year so HEY OMG PUPPY! Also he's really very cute and gives good snuggles, plus Isis is in LOVE:
 Figure One: Awww...
*   And now after a quick trip to the mothereffing GROCERY store (because someone had a mental breakdown and ate the fried onions that were to go atop the greenbean casserole and now we need more of those) I need to start baking (two loaves of bread for stuffing, the pies, and the rolls) and also pick up our weekly CSA share a day early. And despite the unbloggable vagueness I'm REALLY looking forward to cooking with my husband tomorrow and having a wonderful Thanksgiving dinner with the boys.
*   Oh and hey, despite the mental breakdown involving the can of fried onions I appear to be losing weight (we still don't own a scale but things are fitting a little better and yesterday Hotter grabbed my ass and asked if I'd lost weight because it felt smaller to him) (and why yes, he DID get lucky shortly thereafter). body:
*   Our fuzzy houseguest is still here, and the kids have started calling him Bumpus, as in "The Bumpus Hounds." While that is hilarious and he remains ridiculously cute, we are still Making Inquiries (so far no one has reported him missing per the local SPCA).
*   I cannot for the life of me get exercised over the new TSA regulations, I just can't. Maybe it's because I've had three children and lots of medical procedures and I see my body as public domain where gloves are concerned, maybe it's a sign of mental health (or mental illness?)...I dunno y'all, but if a gloved professional has to touch my goodies in the capacity of doing their job I don't see the point in getting het up about it. I've been getting SPESHUL PATDOWNS for ages because a) I have big boobs, that require a big underwire, which sets off alarms and b) I usually fly Priceline at the last minute, which apparently marks you as suspicious and earns you closer scrutiny. I've never had the agents be anything but politely disinterested as they do their thing. And as to having children get patted down, I think if I were to fly anywhere with my children (which is highly unlikely because I'm poor and also NOT INSANE) I would just say "this is only okay because they're doing their job to keep us safe and I'm right here" the same way my pediatrician always tells them "this is only okay because I'm a doctor and Mom is right there" when she checks their junk out. If it's not okay with someone for a TSA agent to touch them or their child, there's always the bus, and I know that might sound harsh, but...well, honestly it seems rather narcissistic to me for anyone to be all "I'M not a terrorist and therefore if they touch ME it's ASSAULT." I've been assaulted. That's not assault. The TSA has definitely failed some travelers with special needs by not showing sensitivity to their situations, and some specialized trainings may be in order there, but overall? I think people need to get over themselves. YOUR GOODIES ARE NOT THAT SPECIAL.
*   What might actually be assault is the way Bumpus keeps trying to suckle off of Isis. It's hilarious. Maybe he's a little younger than we think? At any rate, Isis desperately wants to either hump or play with the puppy and is mystified as to why he keeps darting underneath her to put hickies on her belly. She's been surprisingly good with the little runt overall, and he has no problem letting her know when he's had enough (you have not laughed until you've seen a puppy that looks like an overgrown weiner dog snarling and baring his milkteeth at a pitbull and the pitbull cocking her head like "seriously?" and whimpering in confusion).

body:
In nearly a year of sharing my life with y'all from back here at my old Typepad URL, I've blogged the good, the bad, and the ugly, and there's been way too much bad and not a little ugly, but before I vanish in a slick of butter I wanted to take a hot minute and be thankful. Because for all that this past year has had its moments of great suckitude, I've still had more to be thankful for than any other year in my life.
   Many of y'all are aware that I've blogged in a couple of other places over the years (I can't believe I've been doing this since 2005), but MFA Mama was my first blog, and the only one whose name reflected the good in my life, the things I'm most proud of (my studies in my career field and being the mother of three great kids), and it's good to be back.
   In this wretched, conservative state getting divorced takes FOR-E-VER (even if the other party doesn't fight it, which in my case...yeah), and my divorce was uglier than...well, pretty much anything outside of Hollywood...and was the culmination of a decade of 99% sheer misery in the marriage department. So as odd as it sounds, I'm damned thankful to have finalized my divorce not quite a year ago.
   Speaking of the divorce process, there's one real gift it gave me: an extra shot of empathy that I lacked before hitting my own personal rock bottom. Last December I had the chance to help a friend out as another friend once helped me, and as much as it pains me to admit it in a public forum, I'm not sure it's something I would have done before, so while the divorce process was less fun than losing a hunk of my crotch the size of a NY-strip steak to MRSA, at least it left me a better person (unlike the MRSA thing, which just left me a BITTER person).
   I'm grateful for this every damn day, but it definitely needs to go in the list: this past year I married my best friend (yep, pretty much the moment the ink was dry on the final decree of divorce, and no, we were not romantically involved during my first marriage; he was my PLATONIC best friend for a couple of years before the XY and I separated and in the year and a half-ish between that and the finalization that obviously changed). I'm so lucky (love you Hotter!).
   I've heard enough blended-family horror stories to be VERY thankful for the fact that my kids have loved Hotter from day one :)
   I've been INVOLVED in enough in-law horror stories to be thankful for my mother-in-law being a good egg.
   This year I got back into gardening, and I'm so very thankful that the home we rent came with a couple of acres of good soil and that my health permits me to take full advantage of that!
   Speaking of my health, it's the best it's been since my oldest child was born, and having almost bought the farm on at least one a couple of numerous occasions since then I'm deeply thankful to be able to say that. Hotter's health was...problematic...this year, and he gave me a real scare this summer but came through it and I think we can finally say he's fully recovered, so obviously I'm thankful for that, too.
   I think it was Gudrun who said that in her opinion a dislike of pets reflected a major heart/brain disconnect, and until July that was pretty much me. I didn't like dogs one little bit (mostly because my birthmother and ex-husband prioritized dogs above me, I think, and owned spoiled, obnoxious dogs). That all changed when we added MFA Puppy to the family. Now I'm one of THOSE dog people, whose dog sleeps in the bed, sits on the couch, and comes along on family road trips (and now there's Bumpus, too). I'm not so sure I OUGHT to be thankful for the worthless curs, but I am. Especially since Isis was so sick so many times (too many to pick a single post to link to) and y'all saved her life. Thanks for that!
   This year I got to go to BlogHer for the first time, and I'm thankful as hell for the experience (and the fact that nothing godawful happened to me in New York City, because it and I have a long-standing and thoroughly mutual hatred for each other).
   Possibly best of all, Little Child seems to be making that turnaround his doctors told me to hope for around age five (they predicted that five would be a watershed year where he'd either grow out of most of what ailed him or receive a truly grim diagnosis). This kid has been turning me gray since he was born, and there have been way too many times I've thought I'd lose him. Now for the first time ever he's ON THE GROWTH CHARTS and NOT ANEMIC and has NO DIETARY RESTRICTIONS and OMG YAY GO LITTLE CHILD!!! I'm so thankful for that that I've been scared to admit just how well he's been doing; I've been MIA over at Hopeful Parents, even. But y'know what, I really don't believe in "jinxing" and if I'm listing things I'm thankful for I can't not mention this. Today he got popped in the nose, and while it bled impressively and I had to drain a bunch of blood out of his g-tube and give him a dose of Amicar, it was so nice not to have to go to the ER or call the hematologist...thankful doesn't begin to describe it.
   Finally, I'm thankful for all of you. I considered linking all "you and you and you"-style, but was afraid I'd leave someone out, so y'know what? If you're reading this? I'm thankful for you, even if you're a troll, because they're a pain in the arse sometimes but remind me to live as exemplary a life as possible on and offline, and that's all good. Of course, I'm MORE thankful for those of you who have cheered me on, offered sage advice, cracked me up, saved my dog, delivered loving reality checks where needed and just reminded me you're here when there's nothing else to say. Y'all are the best!
Happy Thanksgiving!
title: thankful

body:
I'm all bunched up, y'all.
   Part of the reason the XY and I are at odds is that he's been taking the boys to spend the night at his girlfriend's house on his weekends (excepting this last weekend, during which they evidently went home late at night and came back early in the morning for breakfast...sigh) and they LUFF her.
   Yes, it's better that they love her than hate her. No, I would not prefer that she lock them in the basement and feed them bread and water. But does it sting that my kids got a stepfather they'd met TWICE due to the XY's writing it into our final decree that there be "no unrelated male overnight guests, or unrelated female overnight guests if they are of romantic interest to WIFE" and he's now easing them into his new love interest by having her bake with them and squirt whipped cream in their mouths on his weekends? You bet your arse it does! Does it aggravate me that they come home with baked goods from CATHERINE*, singing their praises? Yes, especially since personally I think her pie is nothing to write home about.
   They said she makes better pumpkin pie than I do, y'all.
   But my catty thoughts on that and pride in my baking prowess aside, there's more. This weekend? He brought them home early (he claims to be getting sick, probably he's just Getting Some, but whatever, I want them home Sunday nights anyway because they'll go to school on time, having had a good breakfast, and wearing clothes they haven't been wearing all weekend) with girlfriend apple pie AND homewrecker brownies.
   From Jan**. Jan the woman he moved in with while I still loved him and our infant was in the hospital fighting for his life and we were still (allegedly) a family five years ago this very week. This is not okay. Not just because they're obviously box-brownies, but because if he's taking brownies from Jan, then he can't be that serious about CATHERINE***, and in that case why are my children getting attached to her? I was already worried since a couple of weeks ago they were apparently fighting and the kids saw her crying...they do not need to watch him destroy another woman.
   So I'm sitting here with a girlfriend apple pie in the fridge and a plate of homewrecker brownies on my dining room table, worrying. "Think of it this way, Jan did you a favor! She stole a shitty man and baked you brownies. YOU WIN," Tara counseled me via facespace chat. "I'm overthinking the brownies, aren't I?" "You're overthinking the brownies."
   Poor Jan, she's probably trying to win him back with her box brownies and has no idea they'd end up on his ex-wife's table, the target of innernet mockery.
   Poor CATHERINE, I wish I could meet her, follow her into the ladies' room, and tell her that if he hits her I'll testify. I wonder if she knows about the brownies?
   Poor boys. I wish I could see this somehow not ending up as a(nother) mindfuck for them.
   And while I'm at it, poor me. I know I need to get down off my cross, use the wood to build a bridge, and get over this, but the pumpkin pie thing? Really stung (also I woke up with a brand-spanking new pinched nerve in my neck, and there's a virus moving through Casa MFA, and I swear those stupid effing processed box-mix brownies are taunting me and reportedly CATHERINE is skinnier than I am, too).
   How are YOU?
 
*  Lord no, that's not her real name.
**  Not her real name either.
***  I have no idea why it's CATHERINE, in all caps, but it is. Tara urged me to do all-lowercase, like e.e. cummings, but she's CATHERINE, all-caps. My children say her name that way and CATHERINE she is.
title: homewrecker brownies and girlfriend apple pie: how is this my life?

body:
I lost my temper on here earlier. And I'm not proud of that at all. Not because I feel it was unwarranted, exactly, so much as because while I'm guilty of MANY uncharitable thoughts, I don't generally verbalize (or write) those types of things. It's one of my least-favorite things to hear (or read) others do, and I'm a big believer in the whole "criticize someone and it says more about you than it does about them" school of thought.
   So what did the events of earlier today say about me? I guess most obviously that I'm jealous of people who appear to be a lot more financially secure than I am (and downright pissy when they still complain about being broke). See also: people with large, loving families (Hotter and the boys are great, but they're all the family I've really got; my dad is still alive as of the last time I checked, but doesn't remember who I am most of the time, so, yeah...I am jealous as hell of people with one or more living parents who are in their lives, people with siblings, people who would automatically have a place to sleep if their house burned down, because yeah, I don't have that). It's also pretty clear I'm jealous of people who get an arse-load more child support than I do (especially if they get it for fewer children and/or children with less expensive physical and mental healthcare needs). Also, I'm jealous as HELL of people who get any kind of help with their expenses, because while my family has in the past, currently we do not qualify thanks to my having gotten a job (although I still make well below the federal poverty line for a family my size...why the heck do they HAVE that thing, anyway?).
   It probably also says I'm a shitty feminist for judging another woman's life-choices.
   It reflects poorly on the completeness of my understanding of how human nature works, because generally if someone's a dick to you and you're a dick back and are all "how'd THAT feel?" Well, they're not that likely to have second thoughts about having been a dick to you to begin with. If one of my kids was in a situation like that I'd probably tell them to tell the other person how their words or actions made them feel and ask them not to do it, and if the person in question continued to be a jerk then they weren't a good friend for them.
   Finally, it says I'm probably feeling defensive about having let my kids keep the damned puppy given that we just finished having a huge freaking crisis over here with Isis's health, which I am, and probably that's because it wasn't a very smart thing to do. I effed up there, y'all, not that it makes it particularly nice for anyone to shove it down my throat after I've indicated that they ought to stop it, but maybe I should just accept that as a natural consequence?
   We already all knew I hate the mothereffing holidays like poison.
   Hell, I dunno. But I feel pretty lousy over the entire thing, because none of my personal failings or character flaws are y'all's problem and I brought the nasty here, to a place that I generally try to keep positive for all our sake, and for that I'm really sorry.
title: the one where I owe all of y'all an apology

body:
Here at Casa MFA, everyone woke up on the wrong side of the bed this morning. Having chickens but not one of those heated watering thingies (yet) means that you can't truly sleep in, even on a childfree weekend, because you will have brought the poultry waterer indoors (after knocking the ice out) before bed and the chickens are up with...well...themselves...and thirsty. And overly thirsty hens will not lay as well, so you will sleep until your eyes pop open, detect sunrise, and the guilt kicks in that will not abate until you've filled the poultry waterer and run it outside.
    A dash over frosted turf in a parka, an over-washed fuzzy pink robe, and a pair of clogs does little for one's serenity, in case you were wondering, especially first thing in the morning before you've had any Synthroid or caffeine. Bonus points if you're asthmatic and going from room temperature to below freezing makes you chug along the way like The Little Engine That Could.
   While I was wheezing my way to the chicken run bearing a dripping poultry waterer and a couple of "hen waffles," Hotter was seeing to the dogs. They sleep in Isis's crate lately (no, you should NOT crate two dogs together, but they both whine incessantly unless you do here because they like to spoon) and apparently our taking a night off from the 4:00 a.m. alarm during which we attend to the needs of the puppy's bladder had Had Consequences. The bedding in the crate was soaked and at least one dog needed a bath.
   Out by the chicken run, I noticed a strange sound that, upon investigation, turned out to be coming from our heat pump, which also appeared to have continency issues gauging by the amount of leakage. OKAY! AWESOME! EXCEPT NOT REALLY!
   Hotter and I were regrouping on the front porch (if by regrouping you mean taking turns interrupting each other's soliloquies on the suckage of our life, because clearly this was a tragedy of the highest order) when the mail truck pulled up and left a large package for us.
   Thank you, friend M., for cheering us up so thoroughly. The pants and shirt are the perfect size for Little Child, and he's gone through a sudden growth spurt after wearing the same winter wardrobe for the past three winters that has left us scrambling for things that fit him (not many, as he's just grown into the size Middle Child was during the greatest poverty of the divorce--the hand-me-downs from Big Child took a beating during heavy rotation for Middly) and that he hadn't worn yesterday of a morning. So we are more pleased with that little outfit than you could possibly know! Little Child will probably enjoy it too I guess.
   The jacket is just the size for Big Child to grow into, which he probably will by Spring, and he is of course The Boy Who Loses Jackets, so a spare jacket is a wonderful thing (on one memorable occasion he went to school wearing MY hoodie, which wasn't pink or anything but was cut a bit girly, AND THEN HE LOST THAT).
   The boys will ALL love the checkers, because OMG CHECKERS and the pieces are big enough that hands with delayed fine-motor sklls ought to be able to manage them without incident (I've shied away from teaching the boys checkers due to visions of intersibling violence at men being knocked asunder by mistake dancing through my head). The oversized pieces are PERFECT! The other games are sure to be a hit, because, ELECTRONIC JOY, but I'm particularly excited about the checkers as I can play that with them (I fail at the electronic games).
   And finally, with boys you cannot go wrong with anthropomorphic trucks that have fangs. A were-truck? WHOO, TRUCK! 
   Friend M., your hand-me-downs are made of WIN and the boys are going to love them! I'm going to wrap them up before they come home from their father's house and hide them away in my closet, so it ended up being perfect timing, too (in more ways than one). You rock!
   And now I'm going back to bed.
title: in which a package from a friend cheers me up considerably

body:
So last night, I locked BOTH sets of keys in the minivan.
   Yeah, I'm not even going to try to defend that, because, well.
   This is why I have AAA.
   This morning, I called them, and within half an hour a driver was pulling up in a tow truck. Dude was about 300 pounds of bald, tattooed muscle with facial piercings galore, and when he asked where the keys were and I said "which set, because they're both in there" he laughed and said "girl you ROCK!"
   Of course he had the door open in less than ten seconds with that blood-pressure-cuff-thingie and a bent piece of wire. "I have GOT to get me one of those," I said ruefully.
   "Why? You'd just lock that in there too," he pointed out.
   I told him he was lucky he was big and scary, he laughed and complemented me on my "SHUT YOUR WHORE MOUTH" t-shirt, and we all went about our business.
   I heart AAA.

Okay. So.
   Letting the boys keep Bumpus was questionable judgment at best. I will be the first to admit that. We all know dog numero uno has done broke the bank over here and thankfully dog numero dos seems to be a nice, healthy little mutt but it could've gone either way and he still eats, shits, and needs love. I totally let my guilt over not being able to give my kids everything they deserve and the cute-factor interfere with my good sense.
 Figure One: He's very cute, yes, but not as cute as financial solvency would be.
   Some of y'all have given me some grief over this, and rightly so. Unlike a lot of bloggers, I don't generally take umbrage when I receive unsolicitated life advice, because I do kind of put myself out here in the first place and we all have opinions. 
   However.
   Hypocrisy? Gets my hackles up every damned time. So while I debated even saying anything, and conflict isn't really my thing, I did in fact tweet a little something passive-aggressive.
   Then someone else tweeted "The emperor has no clothes" and I was like "heh" and then someone ELSE retweeted it, adding "And owns too many animals" and I was like well eff this, if it's "tweet openly provocative shit targeted at one particular person day, let's go" and sank to their level (also not something I'm proud of, but I have enough real problems lately that I decided the high road in pretend dramaz was a challenge I didn't care to take on any longer).
   It was round about the time they decided to snark at my pronoun usage (which was intentional, mind you--I fully believe that men can be twats and women can be dicks, and if you think otherwise then I might go all preachy on you about your overly strict views of gender, but that's a different inconsequential pissing contest) that I decided class was overrated. And so here and now I will go ahead and vent off my excess nasty. If you're not interested in pettiness and an exemplary demonstration of what's wrong with women as a whole, click away now.

body:
Don't mind if I DO do that thing where I zoom out because things are sucking here in a very much not-y'all's-problem unbloggable sort of way!
   My main freelance client of the past...seven? GEEZ...years paid me a week earlier than they usually do for this quarter. WHOO!!! I mean, it was already all earmarked for various bills, but one of the items in the budget was a bag of chicken feed and I was VERY happy about that because I'd been throwing together "hen waffles" out of the pantry for a few days and I prefer to scoop and dump and not worry about the nutrient balance (not enough sodium = no eggs, not enough calcium = no eggs, not enough protein...you get the picture), y'know?
   So Hotter and I rolled out of bed after taking a nap on Saturday, hoping that this would "reset" the day, and headed to the feed store in the small town where I lived for a number of years pretty recently. It's owned by a prominent local Mennonite family and operated by a delightful older gal and her assisstant, who we'll call Winter (not her actual name). Winter is the one who helped us capture George and the Araucanas when we went hen-shopping and is good people. When she showed us the Araucanas we could choose from she pointed out two with scissorbeaks as "Lefty and Righty," and said she was taking them home in case we were also suckers for gimpy ones. What, I ask you, is not to love? WInter is adorable and she and I talk chickens and husbands all gossippy-like, because that is what you do at the feed store.
   We rolled in ten minutes before closing, and a rotund, rosy-cheeked, blond and exceedingly cornfed-looking fellow was sitting by the door haranguing Winter when we arrived. He was surely either her brother or her husband, and after she rang up our purchase she handed us our receipt and said "Mouth over there'll git your feed." That's also what you do at the feed-store--you give your receipt to the teenage nephew or "retired" grampa farmer hanging out on the porch and they pull it from the storage area and load it into your vehicle if you're a girl or look like a city slicker.
   "ORGANIC???" Mouth sputtered, upon reading the receipt. "Yep." He looked at me slackjawed for a moment. "Organic Layer Pellets?" I nodded. "WHO--" he began, and Winter cut him off. "Boss orders it special for 'er." Mouth swept his hat off his head, scrubbed at the back of his neck with it, and slapped it back on more securely before heading off to the storage area.
   At the rear of the MFA Minivan, my tow-hitch and the fact that the rear cargo area was strewn with straw seemed to set Mouth at ease again. "I know what you use THIS van for," he noted, smiling. He plopped our feed down and was halfway through wishing us a pleasant weekend when he shut the lift gate and noticed my FCKH8 sticker. "Eff...Cee...Kay...what does that say," he asked, squinting at it.
   "Fuck hate," I said, since that was about the only thing to do, talk my walk right there in the feed store parking dirt-strip. Mouth goggled at me, as if surely I hadn't just..."what did you say?" I cleared my throat and spoke up. "Fuck hate; it's showing my support for marriage equality." Mouth crossed his beefy arms and leaned back on his heels, chewing on that a minute. "You mean like, a boy and a boy, or a girl and...?" I nodded. "Yep. Now run tell Winter about the dirty hippies and have a good weekend!" And I got into the driver's seat next to Hotter, who was clutching his face in the passenger seat, and we both made it to the dirt road  before busting out laughing.
   Educate and fight the hate, y'all!
title: bad fun at the feed store

*   Today I don't expect to make a great deal of sense, as I've mixed enough decongestants, antihistamines, and other over-the-counter goodies in an attempt to avoid needing antibiotics I can't afford to probably enjoy The Wizard of Oz on mute and The Dark Side of The Moon. Why don't I have that movie on DVD, dammit?
*   I'm ill enough that Hotter tended to the MFA Flock today, which meant that the poultry princesses waited until 11 a.m. for their water to be de-iced and also suffered an empty feeder. They produced five eggs (including a blue one, so this may end up being our first six-egg day, even) during their mistreatment, and now I'm thinking of skipping a day once in a while just to shake things up if this is the effect it REALLY has on the dumb sluts.
*   You know how certain Tibetan monks can sing more than one note at a time (also some Mongalian nomads and the Xhosa people of South Africa, it seems)? And when we (meaning Westerners) first found this out we were all "it's holiness, holiness at work, it's a miracle!" Well I have empirical evidence that up to three distinct notes is nothing holy whatsoever, because Bumpus can do a keening whistle-whine, a more common canine whimper of eagerness, and a playful growl all at once. I call this little trick his "polyphonic squee," and no one else here thinks that's as funny as I do. Maybe I won't either when I come down from the entire cough/cold aisle at Kroger, but I thought I'd share it with y'all while I'm still giggling.
*   I used to say as a young adult that it wasn't a real holiday unless the lady of the house (I was thinking of my mother at the time) had accused someone else of DELIBERATELY RUINING THE MOTHERFUCKER and apparently either a) this is a Real Holiday, b) I am turning into my mother or c) both of the above. I haven't put any of the MFA Children into debt to finance a new set of tits or slept with any random guys yet, so probably I shouldn't really worry about a), but when your biological mother is the most human evil you've ever beheld in one body, pretty much any little similarity is grounds for contemplating seppuku on the front lawn.
*   I am still Very Unhappy about things I can't talk to y'all about. Dammit. They're not really the sort of stuff you discuss with anyone in your life outside of the professionals you hire to deal with them because they're THAT personal and unpleasant, and so they're pretty much the sort of thing blogs exist for but...sigh.
*   I have a deadline that I've been trying to avoid until I am less consumptive, but apparently I'm not going to recover before said deadline arrives so I suppose I should go and attempt to make the best of the fact that I'm not currently sleeping or doubled over hacking. Ho ho ho.

body:
Once you have whisked your dry ingredients together, you're ready to add the wet stuff (if you didn't read part one and are like "the hell?" then welcome to my long-overdue bread post, which I decided to break into a series so it wouldn't seem so overwhelming, because I make the best, most nutritious and thoroughly OVERTHOUGHT bread evah) (and if you're reading this going "jesus, it's just bread" then I invite you to go and read this lady's archives and see if you ever feel the same about food again afterward) (also, I'm sorry if you just went and had your mind blown, well, not really, but...anyway).
 Figure One: Oh look, it's that giant bread graphic again. Not only does this let the idiots among us know that I will now continue to talk about bread, but it also took me a LONG BLOODY TIME to do with MS Paint so here it is! Ohhh. Ahhh.
   This is where you add 2 and 1/2 cups of the same temperature water you'd use to bathe an infant (or your poodle, or your own self, I don't use a thermometer but make it comfortably warm, okay?), and since water is fairly boring (well actually it's not but I'm trying very hard not to turn this into a manifesto so just use the same water you and your family drink) there's no picture of that but heeeey look! An egg! And some oil!
 Figure Two: This is the kind of egg and oil I prefer to use, but remember the first rule of home-baking? I'll now proceed to talk about some different options, but not in italics, because they annoy me.
   For the egg, just use whatever kind of egg you feed your family. I have issues with "factory-farmed" commercial eggs (in that the chickens that produce them have miserable lives, and eat diets containing things I don't want to indirectly ingest through their eggs, plus those eggs in the store are often several weeks old), so we have the MFA Flock. Our chickens eat organic layer diet plus lots of table scraps and extra omega-rich treats like flaxseed and walnuts, as well as fresh vegetable scrap from cooking and canning like pumpkin guts, carrot peels, wilted spinach, etc. They also spend part of most days "free-range" in the backyard foraging for bugs and weeds, which gives their yolks and even the whites (to a lesser extent) a distinctive orange hue:
 Figure Three: I'll shut up about chickens and eggs now, but would you LOOK at that YOLK?
   For the oil, I use organic flaxseed oil when I can afford to, because it's SUPER  good-for-you, and nobody really notices the difference (I can taste it  if I think about it really hard) between that and something tastier/more  texturally suited for baking like butter or coconut oil (organic,  ideally, but it's a personal choice and I totally get that it's likely  to be dictated by finances--nutrition is TOTALLY a class issue, sadly,  and you will not save any money baking bread the way I do it). I do NOT  use hydrogenated vegetable shortenings at all, ever, because they have that  fucked-up plastic fat that I don't care for from an ideological  standpoint alone, without even getting into the possible health  repercussions. The egg in both pictures is from an Araucana, and there is  no logical reason why since they taste the same as the brown eggs do, but I always bake with the fancy-colored eggs. It just seems festive, and I'm easily-amused is why :)
   After you stir the wet and dry ingredients well enough that your mixer won't kick up a dustbstorm in your kitchen, beat this at high speed for approximately three minutes. I suppose a stand-mixer would be best, but alas, I do not have one. If you do, then use it at this point, and know I hate you just a little bit in my heart of hearts. If you're thinking "screw that, I'm going to knead the dough anyway and that'll mix it just FINE so why dirty the mixer?" then COME HERE AND KISS ME because you are my PEOPLE, and also here is why you should use the mixer: a lot of what makes bread have the texture you want it to have has to do with the gluten (this is why we added extra gluten to the dry ingredients as well), but no matter how much gluten you add, there's a mechanical aspect to helping it reach its full potential. The main purpose of kneading bread dough is to break up and release the wheat's gluten, which requires smooshing of the dough. Beating is kind of like cheating at this, because it agitates the HELL out of the particles in your sponge (yeah, it's not quite dough yet) and brings the gluten out to play so that the yeast can make big, stretchy bubbles in the dough as it rises. I don't even set a timer when I beat the sponge anymore because I can see by the ripples in the top when it's done. I couldn't capture those very well on film, but here's what you should have at this point, and where we'll leave off for the day:
 Figure Four: No, YOU don't scrape your mixing bowl enough!
title: our daily bread, part two: wet ingredients

So today I went to pick up a prescription, and I'll spare you the boring details but the end result is that I am uninsured effective 12/1 and didn't realize it (my premium went up and I didn't know; my insurance company doesn't accept "partial payments" and so has shunted my past two months' payments into an escrow account from which they will be returned if I can't come up with about ten times what I can get my hands on by the end of the month).
   So. The reason I haven't gone for a "public option" plan is that you have to have been uninsured for six months,* and I'm scared silly to be uninsured for obvious reasons, so I've had continuous coverage. But maybe there's a silver lining here? I mean hey, almost two months down and not dead yet, so perhaps I can get by for another four (yes, I know I need my prescriptions--the out of pocket cost of the one pill I would NEVER miss is about one third the amount of my health insurance premium and Synthroid is dirt cheap...the other two daily prescriptions I am on improve my quality of life vastly but are not necessary for SURVIVAL and if I have to have heartburn and get lousy-quality sleep for four months that will suck but not be the end of the world)? I would of course set aside the money I would have been using for the premiums (minus the cost of the prescriptions) in case I have to go to Patient First for antibiotics or something...
   Is this nuts? The other option is to re-apply for individual coverage next month after I get paid and continue paying out the NOSE. Either way currently I am uninsured and I will be for at least another month and...crap. Do any of you have any experience with the "public option" health plans?
 
*   Actually, you have to have been uninsured for six months AND have a pre-existing condition that's caused you to be turned down for health insurance or offered a higher premium than a healthy person. So YOU may not qualify for Public Option Healthcare before 2014, but I...hahahahaha, boy DO I ever have pre-existing conditions, hahahahahahahahaohLORDY.
title: the one about healthcare

body:
I've left my bread series hanging in order to worry full-time about my health insurance situation (I've re-applied with my former insurance company as of the last day to do so before I would have been uninsured for sixty days, which for the blissfully healthy and unaware is the point where any "pre-existing conditions" because something your insurer can decline to cover, and should know sometime in the next week whether I've been accepted--if not then I have no choice but to muddle along for four more months and go with the public option) and distract myself with petty bad fun on the facespace, and honestly I've been having a pity party (nay, a catered, black-tie pity GALA) for myself and had planned to spare you a post until I was in a better frame of mind (which realistically means that as soon as the caterers delivered the ice sculpture of Sisyphus being crushed by the boulder I was probably going to send all of you engraved invitations to my pity gala)...
...and then I fired up Google Reader and saw this, and my black little heart broke into shards. May is such a damned good writer that sometimes I wish she wasn't, because I dare you to read that post and not break out into a cold sweat and the nervous fidgets in your desire to DO SOMETHING ABOUT IT. I don't think there's much any of us CAN do about it, sadly, except to lift May up with our love, so if you've got a spare minute could you please go and do that?
   If anyone wants me I'll be having a stern talk with myself and working on a deadline, and after that I'll be back with more about bread.
title: in lieu of attending my pity party today...

body:
I have had a horrible weekend filled with bad news, bad health, and the worst bad mood ever, which probably still doesn't excuse what I am about to admit to so much as it just explains it, but oh well...
   I logged onto the facespace a little while ago because my phone made the facespace notifier sound, and found an interesting follow-up comment to a comment I left on a friend's wall...see, the Friend In Question had posted a link to this article (an op/ed piece proposing that insurance companies charge anti-vaccine parents higher health insurance premiums based on their child's voluntarily--on the part of the parents, anyway--increased health risk, sort of like they already do with cigarette-smokers) and was all "Haha, this is brilliant," and of course I "liked" that and also left a comment stating that the anti-vax wackaloons* make my blood boil since I'm allergic to the pertussis vax and have asthma, making me dependent on herd immunity.
   THEN!
   Someone Friend in Question is friends with on the facespace jumped in and specifically addressed me, stating that she didn't think I had any right to call anyone a wackaloon unless I myself had a child with autism (as she did).
   Then angels sang and a heavenly light shined down upon my keyboard, because seriously, MY BIRTHDAY WAS A WEEK AND A HALF AGO, SHE SHOULDN'T HAVE!
   A better person than I might have had the restraint to leave that shit alone, but a better person I am not and so you bet your ARSE I jumped right back in with "Well, X, actually I have TWO children on the autism spectrum so I'll say it again: THEY'RE WACKALOONS. Also, as a fan of logic I object to the notion that only those of us with children on the spectrum are allowed to comment on an issue of public health."
   Then X went and erased her comments, so I erased my second one and then Friend In Question saw me gloating about the whole thing on the Twitter and was like "TELL ME THE DRAMAAAAA!" and checked her e-mail notifications, then DMed me and said "Is it wrong that I was thrilled that you have two children with autism? I'm ashamed." I assured her that there was NOTHING wrong with that, or that I was at least equally wrong in that I was thrilled to have two children with autism spectrum diagnoses right then. I mean REALLY, how often does that make me the unequivocal winner in life?
   At the very least, hopefully X will think twice before she plays the "autism card" again. Teachable moments for the win!
   Also, sadly, this was the high point of my weekend. How are YOU?
 
 
*   Why yes, yes I did just call anti-vaxxers wackaloons. They deal in hysteria based on falsified data and the toll in human lives as a result of their collective insanity is very real. Ordinarily I avoid flame-wars on teh innernet like the plague, but if you're one of the "well of course I don't vaccinate my child, I'd hate to have to raise a kid with autism!" types then a) you are insulting two thirds of my children by implying that devastating and potentially fatal illness is preferable to being like them, b) your logic, and I use that term VERY LOOSELY, is flawed, and c) YES I ABSOLUTELY JUST CALLED YOU A WACKALOON, YOU FUCKING WACKALOON, BECAUSE YOU'RE ENDANGERING MY CHILDREN AND YOURS AND FURTHERMORE YOUR MOTHER WEARS COMBAT BOOTS. WHEN IT COMES TO A LITERAL MATTER OF LIFE AND DEATH FUCK YES, LET ME GET MAH CAPS ON.
title: this may be the worst "bad fun" I've ever had

body:
*   No, not because of the bullets in this post, because gun humor isn't funny right now or really ever unless we're talking about Elmer Fudd getting his shotgun barrels tied in a big loopy bow by a certain wascally wabbit. It just seemed like a good title in that that's what ails me physically at the moment: I'm not sick, I'm suffering from a painful reminder that my own freaking immune system gets as fidgety under stress as my children do (and is even less cute in the ways it occupies itself when it hits a breaking point than they are, which is saying something).
*   I guess the bright side here is that if I was sick with, say, a sinus or chest infection that needed antibiotics my uninsured state would be harming me, whereas even with access to medical care there's not much to do for an autoimmune flare-up (for me, with my particular issues--if you have an autoimmune condition or are researching them for a loved one please don't think I'm a typical case because I'm not, and I'm also not a doctor, etc.). I can't take steroids (my body reacts to them in dangerous, bad ways), I'm unwilling to take Lyrica at a time when my asthma is flaring and I'm using the rescue inhaler daily because it makes me retain so much fluid that I worry that wouldn't be a very nice thing to do to my heart, and narcotics are never a good long-term solution when one needs to work and drive and manage small boys. So I'd be waiting this out and alternating ice and heat and balancing illicit over-the-counter NSAIDS (I'm not supposed to take them, per se, due to a very mild bleeding disorder and GI issues but if I'm in agony I use naproxen with great caution) with leafy greens and antacids either way. Also while I hate, hate, HATE to let go of my denial and admit that I'm still broken (I know it's silly but after each flare part of me hopes this'll just go away as mysteriously as it arrived in my early twenties and never happen again), almost two years is a good run as far as remissions go and it's not like I haven't been under an unusual amount of stress recently, which beats a random attack I suppose?
*   I've been hurting for several days and trying to pretend it was just the aftermath of that godawful coughing sickness (yes, I'm still coughing SOME but it's improving, FINALLY) or from, you know, all of the hacking, and today I did that stupid thing I do at least once per flare-up where I try to pull myself up by my bootstraps. I baked bread (which we ran out of Friday evening but the children weren't here and I felt like death warmed over so I didn't bake all weekend, then yesterday I was working and also feeling crappy so today I kind of HAD to), fed and watered the chickens, cooked dinner, and gave the boys some overdue haircuts. That is not a lot of physical exertion AT ALL and yet I feel like I ran a marathon in high heels with my nine-year-old on my back. Possibly uphill. In August.
*   These "flares" can last anywhere from a few days to several months, so while I'm trying to take it a day at a time and stay positive, it doesn't exactly give me the warm and fuzzies when my body does this. I apologize if I'm not very entertaining for the next little bit. I'll finish up the bread series soonish, but right now I'm going to go lie on a heating pad and whimper.

title: on a different subject altogether

body:
Kali asked in the comments, and others of you have asked me via DMs on the Twitter and via e-mail, so I thought I'd go ahead and answer this (well, not really, but sort of).
   I do not have a diagnosis of one of the big-name autoimmune diseases (Lupus, Rheumatoid Arthritis, Ankylosing Spondylitis, etc.) at this time. I have been through all of the testing by several different rheumatologists, and while the general consensus is that I sure do have some kind of autoimmuney-looking thang going on, yep, my symptomology, labs, and imagery results do not fall under the specific umbrella of any one known condition as of the last time I had any. At various times general practitioners filling in for former primary care physicians of mine have speculated that I had Ankylosing Spondylitis, polymyositis, myasthenia gravis and a host of other seriously scary diseases, but I've gone to the trouble of ruling those out, because obviously I wouldn't want to have one of those and not be treating it. I *have* had a couple of different doctors formally diagnose me with fibromyalgia, and whatever it is that I have DOES respond very favorably to Lyrica, so I have no problem with letting them call it that as it gets me access to a medication that's very helpful to me when I'm at my absolute worst, painwise, but honestly I think I was hurting everywhere they pressed because my entire body from skin to bone, head to toe, hurt at the time that they did the "trigger points" test. At that time I was recovering from a bout with MRSA septicemia and the theory that has held the most water in my opinion was the one that classified my woes as some sort of "post-staph rheumatoid phenomenon" plus neurological damage from an extremely potent and toxic drug I was on to rid me of the infection and a side effect it caused in conjunction with another medication I had been taking when I fell ill (seratonin syndrome - which I would quite literally rather die than go through EVER AGAIN).
   That is all a very convoluted way to say that I'm not keeping anything from you, dear friends, when it comes to a formal diagnosis. I just don't have one I'm comfortable latching onto due to lack of empirical evidence, so I say "autoimmune DOOOOOM" and leave it at that. Whatever I have responds EXTREMELY well to systemic steroids (another point in favor of this being autoimmune), however I have very bad reactions to those (as in congestive heart failure) and can't take them anymore. There's not a lot I can do except take it as easy as possible, soak in the tub and use heat and ice as needed, take NSAIDS when my H&H and stomach will allow, and complain bitterly unless I have the means to procure more Lyrica (I am out, alas), but I am not terribly frantic over that because I am not at the point where I would go back on it long-term due to...yep, side effects.
   This isn't to say that what I have is so bearable that I'm snubbing good treatment options so much as that the pain level has to be bad enough to make me seriously not even care whether the drugs to relieve it are potentially dangerous to my wellbeing or not. Steroids I have specifically instructed my physicians NEVER to give me outside of a life-or-death situation with close monitoring, and Lyrica is stressful enough for my circulatory system and fluid regulation that I hold it in reserve for getting me through the very worst of times. This current "flare" is brutal, but not THAT brutal (yet?) (I mean, um, AND IT WILL NOT BE, DAMMIT).
   Is that about as clear as mud? Okay then. Now you (don't) know (either).

The new light ought to be here tomorrow though (the old one broke after only a few days' use, but rather than do an exchange I did a return and reordered it with eBates) and hopefully they'll step up production. *   I am getting sick. I mean, of course I am. Chowing the yogurt and garlic, slurping tea and soup.
*   I think some things are going to bounce, just because PayPal  transfers take time, and it's making me die a little to think of the  fees. Maybe not, nothing to do but wait it out, but I have a woogy feeling about this waiting, either way.
*   The XY sent me a truly shocking e-mail. Shocking as in "a real  grown-up wrote this." I wonder if it was the girlfriend? If he walks his  talk I will be very impressed.
*   Hotter and I are taking the dog and remaining mice to Artic  Tundra State with us (the mice because they'll run out of something or  one will die off and stink...the runt of the litter is still hanging in  there but only just barely), but Poe ate six babies and the extra adult  so we're down to a manageable number. They'll probably ride buckled into  Little Child's Britax Marathon in their tank. The dog will ride in her  crate, which we'll secure in the mid-cabin after removing the captain  chair row with seatbelts on either side. I think it will be nice for her  to have a place to be and we'll pack her pillow in there. It's too bad  this isn't for a happier occasion because I'm rather pleased with how  the trip itself is shaping up, funeral aside.
*   I gave Hotter a haircut and it looks fantastic, but he's carping  about it because that's what he does, complain and moan and grab my  arse, then suggest that the Great Clips girls used to massage his  shoulders, etc. (at which point I remind him that they work for tips and  I am rewarded simply by having him be presentable).
*   Rhetoric. My head hurts. If you follow me on the Twitter or are a  facespace friend you know which rhetoric in particular has me het up,  but y'know fuck ALL of it. At least today.
*   Sadly, I still have deadlines, and they make my head hurt extra-much.
*   I scrubbed the burn with MFOrganics Lucky Dog today, and debrided all of the dead skin from around the worst of it (which I think went down to the muscle? I dunno but it's gonna leave a hell of a scar). That stuff is great on such things even though it made Hotter shudder to see me do that. He was all "doesn't that HURT?" and I was all "it'll hurt a lot MORE if it gets INFECTED." All in all in looks pretty good, especially, as Hotter said, "for a burn healing on [me]."
*   I am VERY displeased to be getting sick. That drive to the Arctic Tundra state kills me on a GOOD day. Ugh...
*   In-law drama. Oh lord. Loud and Crazy's wife left him about a month ago and initially he didn't care because Big and Scary introduced him to some chick but then she dumped him for the same reason my former SIL did and now Loud and Crazy is very sad panda and Big and Scary has mortally offended me (details not For The Innernet but he's OUT OF THE HERD) and I can't promise that no one will get junk-punched, especially if their pets accost Isis.
*   Hotter is getting on my very last nerve. Mostly for petty reasons that make me a bad person, but I think we can all agree that failing to get my password on the Blackberry (his birthday) correct enough times that it perfomed a complete wipe and deleted my entire life is a great irritation at best. Bless his heart.

body:
*   There is something I'm not telling you about this trip that is  keeping me from saying much about anything past Saturday night. Sorry  about that. We're in DEFCON-5 mode here and I'll tell you about it when  it's resolved (probably no later than tomorrow afternoon). Everyone hold a good thought that we can make the best decisions, and I'll tell y'all about the trip itself.
*   Loud and Crazy (my brother-in-law, not to be confused with Big and Scary, my STEP-brother-in-law, who is Out Of The Herd) was his usual bipolar self, but for the first time got attitudinal with ME and I didn't relish it. Hotter wasn't there at the time, but wasn't surprised when I told him what went down (in short, Hotter's mom's household consisting of her and Loud and Crazy, the Big and Scary family, Hotter's son and his vapid girlfriend, and the MFA contingent were all venturing from Arctic Tundra State to motherfucking New Jersey for the funeral and there were logistics involving everyone BUT the MFA contingent wanting very much to not drive their own vehicles there, because I was the only one who naively feared for the age of my vehicle and the sanity/fitness of its driver less than I was petrified of MOTHERFUCKING NEW JERSEY TRAFFIC and Hotter and I had discussed it beforehand and agreed that we would take no passengers) (this was less to do with us both being antisocial curmudgeons and more to do with the fact that MFA Puppy's crate took up the entire cabin behind the front seats, leaving zero legroom in front of the rear bench seat--other parties involved wanted to take the crate out and pile either themselves or their least desirable loved one in with us but we weren't willing to leave MFA Puppy in Arctic Tundra State, period, end of story so she needed a safe place to chill in the MFA Minivan unattended for brief stretches) (which she really didn't because I mostly stayed with her anyway--she was my excuse for boycotting the funeral itself because I was led to believe it would be a church service and I can tolerate that but not a funeral home because I KNOW WHAT GOES ON THERE). Loud and Crazy was trying to avoid transporting the Big and Scary household in HIS vehicle, and wanted to have The Wrath drive her car with him riding shotgun so that he could remain unsober, and so was telling Loud and Crazy over the phone that everyone could ride with me and Hotter without so much as asking. I corrected that immediately and he was all "YOU ARE TAKING X, X, and X IN YOUR VAN, MAWWWWM TELL HER" and trying to get The Wrath in my face about the whole thing and I pretty much said "not happening, believe me now or believe me later when it doesn't happen, up to you." Hotter's entire family tiptoes around Loud and Crazy but between my family of origin and the ten years I spent with the XY it takes true shit-throwing psychosis to faze me anymore. *shrug*
*   Hotter's son (yes, if you're shocked that he has a son that might be  valid, because I don't much discuss young Lefty on here, but  Hotter has an adult son who lives in Arctic Tundra State) looked great.  Really, really great, and I'm not going into the whole story because it  isn't mine to tell but there was Reason For Concern there and seeing him  cleancut, well-dressed, and minus all of the extreme piercings in his  face was like a breath of fresh air. It was Very Encouraging, and I  haven't felt optimistic on my step-son's behalf in a long time (and  neither, I think, had Hotter) so that was good.
*   This was my first time spending any great length of time driving  in New Jersey, so you'll have to pardon my observations on the state,  especially if it's where you live and you're somehow NOT an asshole, but  OH MY GOD. The drivers.    Now, I am quite the road warrior and  always have been--I made my first multi-state road trip alone within a  few weeks of getting my driver's license, commuted from MFAville to my  graduate alma mater a hundred-ish miles away for four years, married an  effing NEW YORKER when I was young and stupid, and after rectifying that  error proceeded to commute from MFA State in The South to Arctic Tundra  State visiting Hotter every other weekend for over a year because love  makes you stupid.   All that to say that I thought people drove like  assholes around our nation's capitol but no, they're just in a hurry.  The motherfuckers in New Jersey (which borders Arctic Tundra state and  is where The Grandwrath lived and died) all have ISSUES and apparently  think they're immortal, and while I'm offending everyone from New Jersey  I'll also throw in that OH HAI, YOUR STATE SMELLS LIKE THE ROOM WHERE  MICHAEL JACKSON GIVES SATAN HIS DAILY RUSSIAN PROSTATE MASSAGE, LORD,  WHAT IS UP WITH THAT?
*   I may not have totally explained to y'all just how bad my phobias of  the elderly and of dead bodies and of night-time driving and being lost  all are, but being LOST, in NEW JERSEY, at NIGHT on the way to the  open-casket funeral of a nonagenarian? DEAR LAWD. I was keeping an eye  out for a giant hairy spider and/or a hidden camera after the fifth stop  for directions, when I got out of the car and walked briskly up and  down a block before I could speak to Hotter (who had accused me of not  Having Respect in that I was ready to quit effing wandering New Jersey  whether we found the goddamn funeral or not) (don't worry, I set him  straight on how we wouldn't have been there in the FIRST place if that's  what my issue was and he either realized I was right or saw that I was  ready to cut a bitch and dropped it).
*   It's brutally cold already in Arctic Tundra State, and ALSO in motherfucking New Jersey.
*   For all of my feckless meanderings across the map of our country,  I never had done more than scratch the surface of West Virginia before  this trip (why no, West Virginia is not even remotely in between MFA  State and Arctic Tundra State, but we like to multitask here and had  business to attend to there and so we went between The Funeral Debacle  and home). West Virginia was very pleasant (scenic, not terribly  populated, speed limits of 70) and then it provided us with the best and  most needed laugh EVER when, in driving between two mountains, the  radio of the MFA Minivan simulcast at least two stations at once (one of  which was playing some Collective Soul and the other of which was  playing Jimmy Buffet) and created an impromptu mashup of "Shine" and "Margaritaville" that...well..."Ohhhh-oh-oh-oh, it's my own damn fault!" West Virginia wins.
*   I am really fucking sick now. I can't imagine that had anything to do with the five hours of sleep in seventy-two or anything.
*   In summary, crazy people suck, I hate New Jersey, Hotter eventually Paid His Respects, I am now MISERABLY ILL, and I Have A Secret. Also, if The Wrath dies tomorrow I no longer have enough respect for the sanctity of my marriage or the memory of any hypothetically-dearly-departeds to take my little household to the GOT DAMN funeral, so she had better take her vitamins and get her flu shot. It probably sounds crazy, but I think the fact that Little Child is doing SO WELL now has been hovering over me like a rain-heavy cloud waiting to open up and pour down on my head the past couple of months. It's like for the past five years I've been pushing a boulder up a hill, and yeah, it was hard and painful and exhausting but it wasn't until I got to the top of the hill, sat down, and looked back at how far I'd come that my legs gave out.
   When your child might be dying, doctors focus on the positives, the things still left to try, the possibilities still open...you know the possibility of a bad outcome is there but you're so damn busy dealing with everything necessary to (hopefully) achieve a good one that you don't give it a lot of airtime in your head.
   When your child is a walking question mark and no one can tell you what will happen except to say that it'll go one of two ways, the absence of any indication which way it'll ultimately go sends your mind into overdrive. You question every symptom and sign, research every treatment and trial; you get used to the constant buzz of adrenaline that comes with random reinforcement (and is responsible for casinos the world over staying in business).
   When you get your answer and it's the one you've spent five years hoping for with every fiber of your being, it's a wonderful thing, the BEST thing, and I AM NOT COMPLAINING EVEN ONE LITTLE BIT, PLEASE DO NOT THINK THAT I AM FAILING TO ACKNOWLEDGE HOW FUCKING LUCKY WE ARE but that said? The sudden calm in which to reflect and lack of jitters can (apparently) reveal just how little was holding you up all that time, and if it was that hard how hard would it have been without the happy ending and gahhhh I dunno y'all, my brain is broken now or something.

body:
I've found myself the object of much envy since acquiring a flock of hens. It's kind of hilarious, actually. At least half the people who hear that I have chickens respond with some variation of "I HAVE ALWAYS WANTED CHICKENS OMG CHICKENNNNNS!" (the other half are split pretty evenly between "heh, cool," "WHAT! WHY?" and "hahahahachickensbawwwwwkbegawkhahahaha"). Of the people who aren't downright envious, the vast majority are at least curious, and the main question we get is "how many eggs do you get from the chickens?"
   Our first hen laid around seventeen weeks, I think, and our last ones JUST started a few weeks ago around six months of age. Currently we have eight pullets (five Barred Plymouth Rocks, one ISA Brown, and two Araucanas), and we usually get between four and six eggs per day (in a typical week we'll have maybe one four-egg day of "WTF," two five-egg days, and four six-egg days) from them. Let's round down a little, though, to account for the two or three per month that get broken in the nest boxes, and say five eggs per day as an average. This month we gave away half a dozen eggs to a neighbor and kept around 144 (twelve dozen eggs).
   That breaks down to...three dozen a week??? Wow.
   You'd think we'd have eggs coming out of our ears but honestly we don't tend to have more than half a dozen usable (not hard-boiled or put away to age before being hardboiled--very fresh eggs are IMPOSSIBLE to peel and you save a lot of cursing by keeping them for a couple of weeks...most of the eggs you buy at the supermarket are at LEAST that old) eggs on-hand at any given time. I usually use one or two per day in cooking and baking, Big Child and Hotter eat them microwave-poached for breakfast, I am an egg-salad FIEND (I only use one out of maybe four yolks due to cholesterol concerns but the dogs are happy to eat those yolks so they don't go to waste), Isis enjoys an egg cracked into her bowl at mealtimes...I'd say for our family of five (only three of whom actually eat eggs except in baked goods) eight chickens is just about perfect. We are DEFINITELY going through more eggs than before, because they're cheap and nutritious and RIGHT THERE, but if we weren't keeping the chickens as a money-saver/green/sustainable-living endeavor rather than a hobby (or were in a place right now to afford hobbies) I'd probably have more birds just so I could give the eggs away to friends and neighbors.
title: how many eggs do you get from the chickens?

Today I found a disk of photos that had been missing for a couple of years, photos I never thought I'd see again and some I'd even forgotten about. They were from Little Child's "coming home from the hospital" normal-babyhood (all three frames of it) through the second hospitalization, by which time my first marriage had disintegrated for the first of two consecutives times and I'd acquired my first online stalker. Suddenly OH LOOK there I was weighing a good sixty pounds less than I do currently, six weeks after giving birth (at which point I weighed considerably MORE than I do now, thankyouverymuch), trying to convince people that things were okay and make everybody around me happy.
   Of course, things were NOT okay and NOBODY was happy and oh god, look at the baby's big, starving eyes, the tape on his cheeks, the cannulas, lines, tubes, and explaining to Hotter that no, Little Child's SKIN on his cheek wasn't that color, heck no, that was dermapore, or maybe tegaderm, one or the other, this stuff that stuck onto his cheek for up to a week at a time and we'd rip the tape off of and press it back onto that stuff instead of his skin, to keep it from tearing right off his face, with tiny, dehydrated babies that's easy to do...and suddenly my heart is in my throat again and my life is in ruins outside of the hospital waiting for me but all I can care about is making sure his skin never touches hospital linens or pajamas, because god dammit doesn't the poor baby suffer enough? Hanging tiny laundry from the bars of the metal crib, chasing away nursing students and residents who want to Mess With The Baby, watching the numbers, always going further in the wrong direction--
(this is where if you are me, you find yourself staring at the monitor until your husband decides that maybe you're done showing him pictures and meanders off to play Warhammer, and again just now in trying to write about it, because god DAMN there's a lot I didn't remember about back then but there's so much more that I do, I just didn't know)
   --anyway, it's been one of those days.
   We've been cleaning and purging, I've been cooking and baking, Hotter's been intermittently getting annoyed with my snappish fugue state and asking if I'm SURE it's "just" the pictures in conjunction with the normal financial, legal, stalker-related, and existential crises that's got me antsy, and yes, actually, it is, and the harder he finds that to believe the more I feel like hitting something.
   It's 11:30 at night and I have bread rising, dishes in the dishwasher, and a bad case of the Mondays. They'll pass, I'm sure, and until they do I'm going to go back to trying to make the most of the angst-driven productivity. How are YOU?

body:
I want y'all to know that I wrestled with what to call this series. Because the title I finally did give in and use is SO. OVER. DONE. but it's pretty much inescapable; it's even emblazoned on the end of the slicing guide my kids pooled their resources and gave me for my birthday, so it is what it is. See?
 Figure One: Cropped from an image I took in my kitchen; that is the bread we eat in all its glory!
   I've shied away from writing this post, even though several of y'all have asked specifically about it, because bread is so huge to me, but then I decided I'd do a "bread week" and since I'm eating a lot of feelings doing a lot of baking right now why not, right?
   The Mennonite preacher's wife who taught me to really make bread did it as a home-based business; she shared her "secrets" willingly with me over several flour-dusted baking days I spent in her home drinking tea with my babies crawling around our feet ages and ages ago.
   The first thing Mrs. MPW taught me is that flour really matters. I rode with her out even further into the country than her small farm to a Mennonite country store where spry lady of perhaps seventy waited on us and rang Mrs. MPW up for fifty pounds of red wheat. We took our receipt out to the parking lot and the lady from behind the counter appeared with the sack on her shoulder and tossed it into the back seat of the truck as if it weighed nothing at all! Back at the farm Mrs. MPW showed me her wheat grinder and apologized to the babies before firing it up and WOW THAT THING WAS LOUD. The fine, off-white flour it produced from the wheat kernels was silky and unlike any other flour I've worked with...
   Due to financial constraints I can only long for and covet a grinder so that I can someday use local whole wheat; for now I buy my flour from the store. What kind of flour, you ask?
 Figure Two: I heart me some Red Mill. This is my favorite flour for bread, hands-down.
   The first rule of home-baking, though, is that you have to be able and willing to work with substitutions. One time when I was just a leetle bit short on flour I added some of this stuff, and it came out so nicely that now I use a half a cup in every batch!
 Figure Three: I actually bought this for Isis's BARF meals, to add fiber and some complex carbs. Live and learn! It gives the bread's flavor a subtle complexity that we really enjoy here.
   That's not all I add to the flour, though. The first part of my bread recipe, the dry ingredients, is as follows, in fact:
3 cups flour of your preference1 packet dry yeast (I use fast-rising but the slower kind produces the same outcome, just not as fast)1/2 cup coconut flour2 tbsp. flaxseed meal2 tbsp. wheat germ2 tbsp. pure gluten (this acts as a "dough conditioner" and helps make the bread spongy and soft)1/2 cup brown sugar (this was also the result of a substitution when I ran out of white; now I use brown)1 tbsp. salt
 Figure Four: Here is what it all looks like in a big stainless steel mixing bowl. I use a whisk to combine the dry ingredients thoroughly before adding the wet ones. We'll discuss those in part two!

*   I give up. I am at...well, not an ALL-TIME low, but a lower point than I ever thought I'd be at again, due to a variety of factors, most of which are highly classified. Just take my word for it though that 2010 is forever on my shitlist.
*   Does anyone know whether "easter eggers" like Araucanas consistently lay the SAME COLOR eggs? As in, "may" produce blue or green eggs but once it lays a blue egg will it ALWAYS lay blue or can the same bird also lay green? We got a green egg today for the first time (we'd already gotten two blue ones) and I'm wondering if this means that both Araucanas are laying (but just not every day yet) or whether that's impossible to determine. Either way, SIX-EGG DAY TODAY!
*   I think I'm going to fail at shaking this bug without medical care. Which is a damned shame since currently there's fuck-all I can do about that. Eff.
*   I made some ROCKING bread today. Those of y'all who follow me on the Twitter might already be aware that I attempted to bake 100% rye bread and failed miserably (it was like bricks without straw and even the chickens struggled to eat the stuff) a few days ago. Then we ran out of bread and I used some regular table-bread sponge to attempt a "Swedish-style" rye today and OH MAH GAW, it came out PERFECT! This is the chewy, carraway-rich rye of the Jewish delis of my childhood, and I'm so very tickled with myself!
*   I never thought I'd say this, but I'm actually feeling some Jewish guilt. Like, actual JEWISH GUILT. I thought I was immune, but the fact that my children don't have any idea what kugel is (this came up while Hotter was reading a Slate piece about why Jews shouldn't have "Christmas trees" out loud to me this morning--I woke up without a voice and can make squeaky mid-pubescent-boy sounds now but didn't have it in me this morning to do much more than hiss "kugel is kugel, dammit, it's got noodles and it's sweet like a dessert!" at him) bothers me in the sense that we are, culturally if not religiously, Jews (I and the MFA children are, I mean--not Hotter) and the boys have no idea. I'm seriously going to start taking them to a local reform congregation's services, I think. Just maybe not this week since there's apparently going to be some kind of effing blizzard. WORK WITH ME, GOD OF THE HEBREWS, GEEZ*.
*   I haven't done teacher-gifts yet, and my kids' teachers totally deserve them. Am thinking something homemade. Possibly cookies? Am debating salt-scrub, only because I dunno what each teachers' stance is on homemade. My ex-husband, for example, wouldn't eat my homemade bread because (and I quote): "I saw this thing on, like, Discovery Health or something, where someone was baking their own bread and because it didn't have all the preservatives and stuff that store-bought foods have they opened the bag and these SPORES shot up and their WHOLE FACE FELL OFF. Now they breath through two straws in the holes where their nose once was and can't leave their house."
*   How are all of YOU? I genuinely want to know. Don't feel like you can't tell me if you're GREAT (I'll be happy for you--I'm capable of that, still) and if you're horrible don't worry about bringing me down. If you don't have anything nice to say this holiday season, just come and sit by me.
