   At work it was slow, and usually this is the busiest day of the week. Instead of serving, the servers for the most part stood around and got to know each other better while polishing things. As a trainee I make minimum wage either way, but some of my co-workers were (understandably) unhappy not to be making more money.
   After work I went to the YMCA; I missed today's yoga classes due to my work schedule but I wanted to get in some time on the elliptical; I skipped a few days while getting over that cold and adjusting to getting up at oh-god-hundred and don't want to lose my momentum. The first machine I got on was not the one I usually use (yes, I am a creature of habit that way), and when it couldn't pick up my pulse and kept beeping errors at me I switched to a second machine. The second machine said my pulse was lower than I have ever seen it. Puzzled, I switched to a third machine, my usual one, which concurred with the second machine. At that point I decided it was probably me with the issue and not the machines and just went about my business:

Figure One: Correct me if I'm wrong, but shouldn't one's pulse be higher than this after forty minutes of, um, CARDIO?
   Yes, I was that douche using their phone's camera in the gym today. This was just so weird, though, that I wanted to get a photo for when I have my next appointment with my GP (I had to promise I'd come in within a month to get her to call in the Effexor). I asked Twitter what they thought after I got home, and medically-inclined friends of mine were all "surely you're on beta blockers? No? Irregular heartbeat or impaired circulation, maybe?" Concerned, I decided to check my pulse manually and see if I could notice anything amiss. I probably wouldn't be able to spot a subtle arrythmia if bit me in the arse, but I like to think I'd notice something hospital-worthy. I didn't feel anything out of the ordinary, but my resting pulse was 88, which was much higher than my average pulse while working out. I don't have any cardiac symptoms, so I'm sure this is just another weird-assed quirk of mine, but as I said when I next see my doctor I'll ask her what she thinks now that I have insurance again.
   See? Opposite day.
   And how are all of YOU?
title: opposite

body:
*   One benefit of having to be up and at work at oh-god-hundred is that it's fairly easy to find parking. I was super-early to work, but it beats being late! Yay!
*   The code for the employee entrance didn't work for me and the security person was kind of a butthole about having to buzz me in. Boooo, security guard.
*   I really like the crew I'll be working with. My immediate superior seems genuinely nice, and that is always a plus. The senior employee who is training me explained everything very well without being condescending, and was patient with my confusion over the one part of our job that has anything to do with numbers. I didn't meet a single person today who seemed like an asshole, including the customers even! Yay!
*   I noticed about halfway through my shift that sounds coming from the left were...not right. Like you know how your speakers sound in the car if the paper inside them is torn, that weird vibratory buzz that you get from the bass? That. By the end of the shift it was quite apparent that while I am already over that orientation-day cold IN GENERAL, Bad Ear is getting infected, and there is absolutely fuck-all I can do about it until the fifteenth. Boo :(
*   To end on a positive note, the restaurant at my new workplace has an entire gluten-free station in their breakfast buffet, and when we were closing that down my boss asked me if I'd like to try something from it. THERE WERE BLUEBERRY MUFFINS! I had already asked the kitchen staff where they got the cookies, which actually looked really good (most gluten-free baked goods are a little odd-looking), and they were like "hey, have a cookie too! In fact, take one of each kind because we're just going to throw all of this stuff out anyway." I HAD A BLUEBERRY MUFFIN AND A SNICKERDOODLE AND AN OATMEAL RAISIN COOKIE YOU GUYS, OMG. If you are not gluten-free you will not get what a big deal it was to get to have high-end gluten-free baked goods without paying an arm and a leg for the privilege, but I think even the gluttens among you will have some idea of how exciting it was to have a muffin AND cookies for the first time in eight months (yes, there are gluten-free things like this available for purchase SOMEwhere in town, but I can't justify paying eight bucks for a bag of cookies or twelve bucks for a four-pack of muffins that are JUST for me when we are this broke and I am trying to lose weight anyway). YAAAAY!
*   And how are all of YOU? What are your yays and boos today? I really do want to know.
title: first day yays and boos

body:
*   We saw the vet who first diagnosed Isis today; we really like him. *   Hotter and I met with him to discuss the prognosis, and there's good and bad news there. Between ten and twenty percent of dogs with demodectic mange can't be "cured," and relapses during treatment are obviously not good. BUT. He pointed out that Isis has nearly doubled in size since she started treatment and had outgrown her dosage of Ivermectin long before she stopped taking it two weeks ago. Then flames shot out of my eyes and I had a conniption right there on the spot, because I called THREE TIMES to ask if we needed to raise the dose, and spoke to an actual (different, and apparently clueless) vet myself once, and all three times they told me nono, the dose was fine. THE DOSE WAS NOT FINE. I asked why the dose hadn't been adjusted based on weight, particularly since I'd called and ASKED ABOUT IT SPECIFICALLY and today's vet said "I don't have a good answer for that; I've been on vacation and I'm not pleased about it either. The good news is, we can't call this a true treatment failure and that puts her odds of beating this with the correct dose a little higher than if she'd been on the right amount for the full course before." We'll call him Dr. Brightside.*   So Dr. Brightside changed the Ivermectin dosage from 0.4 ml (what she was taking when she weighed two pounds less than she does right now) to 0.75 ml (yeah, nearly double, which is what her weight has done since she started the previous course).*   I asked about getting Isis spayed, since she is five months old now, and going into heat usually brings on relapses (as does surgery or major injury/illness), and also if worst comes to worst and we have to place her in a no-kill shelter, most of them won't take unaltered pitbulls. Dr. Brightside said he's willing to spay her while she's in treatment as long as it's between dips and her liver enzymes are okay (they'll check those before operating and if they're elevated it'll force us to hold off on the surgery), and that he agreed with me it was better to get that out of the way and THEN finish treating the mange rather than get her well, have her go into heat or spay her and bring on a relapse, then treat her all over again. So we have a tentative surgery date for next Friday, with the caveat that her bloodwork has to look good the day of surgery or it's off.*   Dr. Brightside said that if this doesn't work there are two things we can try. One would be to go to weekly Mitaban dips for a while, but he doesn't like to do those because they're so rough as far as side effects. The other would be to try a drug called milbemycin daily for at least a month, but that stuff is about ten bucks a pill, so that times thirty...well, let's all hope she responds to the correct dose of Ivermectin plus the dips, yes?*   You may have noticed that I'm speaking as if Isis will be staying right here and completing her treatment and living happily ever after. Yes, well. We've raised half of what that will (hopefully) cost and I'm trying to think positive. Please feel free to spread the word if you know anyone who might be able to help out. *   Also if you have a dog or a cat, the Banfield Wellness plans? Are totally worth it. I'm not being compensated in any way for saying so, but have a look at this and judge for yourself:
 Figure One: Y'all are the only reason we're still in this fight. Thank you.*   Hopefully the money that's supposed to come in tomorrow comes in a timely fashion, because I totes floated a check to the vet all "oh it's still September?" See how sneaky I am?
 Figure Two: I know, I'm awful. Also I just felt the need to say that this is a sample checkbook we got when we opened the account and haven't used up yet; there's absolutely nothing wrong with patriotic checks but I am a) too cheap to pony up for anything but the generic bank-logo ones and b) not stockpiling canned goods and ammo for when The Rapture arrives or anything. Just um, wanted to clear that up. Also my handwriting sucks, but usually not THIS much. This is what happens when you write a check while holding the leash of a dog who desperately wants to get OUT of the vet's office.
title: the treatment plan

body:
I just heard from the vet (I dropped Isis off this morning for what we thought would be her last Mitaban dip), and the follow-up skin scraping was positive.
   Two weeks off the oral Ivermectin and the mange is back. She's been itchy and I was thinking maybe she was allergic to something she ate or had another infection; I hadn't even considered that she could have relapsed.
   Crap.
   I don't know what we're going to do, y'all. I went ahead and told them to treat her today, because I'd planned on the expense of a skin scraping and dip, but this has killed our budget the past two months in a row and we can't afford to keep doing this. We used the last of the donated funds to cover half the cost of the latest secondary infection, and at this point the total of all the vet bills to date is approaching a thousand dollars with no end in sight because to get her better would mean at least three (probably more) dips and two skin scrapings, IF everything went perfectly. In all honesty I probably should have told them to put her down when they called, but I couldn't do it and I'm mad at myself for that because intellectually I know that people trump dogs and we're at the end of what we can afford, and at that asshole breeder who swore the mother didn't have mange, and at life in general. This sucks so hard, and I have no freaking clue what I'm going to say to the kids.
   The Donate button is back up, at the bottom right.
   If any of y'all can spare a few bucks we would really appreciate the help; I'm not sure what we're going to do and I guess I'll have to reach out to some local no-kill rescue organizations to see if they can take her or something, but in the meantime I want to at least keep up with her treatment if at all possible. I kind of doubt we can raise enough to keep her here with us, but if any of you are filthy rich feel free to drop $500 on us and save the day (I am pulling that figure out of my arse, but it's what we've spent on mange treatment so far and is therefore probably the minimum treating this would take; if we had that much we could probably carve the rest out of our budget over the next couple of months).
ETA: I am speechless--you wonderful, amazing, borderline-crazy-but-in-a-good way people have ponied up half the funds it'd take for us to keep Isis right here at Casa MFA and treat this mess! I'm starting to think this is do-able. Thank you SO MUCH! At the very least this will buy us some time to try and find someone who can take over Isis's care and treatment without putting her in a shelter or anything awful like that. xox
title: asking y'all for help [ETA at the bottom]

body:
*   Yesterday I had a FABULOUS day at work! I had expected to be sucking on minimum wage as a trainee through the end of the week, but once they realized that I knew what I was doing with the POS system, table service, etc. I got turned loose on the general public a little early due to it being busy, and I? LOVED IT. I had a great time interacting with the customers, and everyone was very generous with the tips, including way more in cash tips than I had grown accustomed to receiving at The Hotel California (not like, "we're gonna be rich" or anything, but cash tips were rare and exciting there). To the point that I was able to tip out the bus boy, pay for my parking, and get the MFA Children a little treat (my employer owns a Starbucks on property that I get an employee discount in, and yesterday they had lemon cake pops, which everyone was raving over, and so for less than $5 I was able to get one for each of the MFA Children, who were surprised and ecstatic to get such a treat after very grim times here at Casa MFA), and still pick up a few vital groceries on the way home. And with what I made today, I will not be unable to get to work later in the week due to running out of gas, which was a real concern prior to today. YAY! Charge tips were pretty decent, too, both yesterday and today, and all in all I am MADLY IN LOVE with my new job (and not just because of the money--my co-workers are awesome, management is helpful and kind, and the clientele is classier and more congenial than the demographic I was used to dealing with in my former workplace).
 * Unfortunately, when I got home yesterday Hotter greeted me with an angry tirade, which...well. In addition to being kind of fucked up (he was mad because I mentioned my frustration with him over something that I was 100% NOT WRONG about on the facespace--he knew how I feel about said issue already and I didn't say anything I hadn't said to his face--he actually FORBID ME TO SAY IT AGAIN the day before yesterday, which went over about as well as you might imagine now that I have worked and exercised my way back to something resembling self-respect),  I had come home ecstatic about my workday and bearing gifts (our department at work is currently doing Candygrams as a fundraiser for a charitable cause I can personally get behind--each month a different department raises money for said cause and this month happened to be the turn of the department I was hired into so I got Hotter a Candygram in addition to the cake pops I got for the boys) and walked into a spouse eager to shake his finger in my face with rage and scold me until I was in tears. Which a) I was not in the wrong, and b) what the fuck dude, give me a minute if I walk in the door with a smile on my face and bags of gifts in my hands before you shit all over me, I think that is just basic common courtesy and a good way to make sure I actually COME HOME after work. So I unfriended and blocked him on the facespace (again). Not because I plan to talk shit about him on there or anything, but because anyone I know on there who goes off on me for something I post and threatens to talk shit about me to everyone else I know on there would get unfriended and blocked for such behavior, and he doesn't get to behave in such a manner simply because I am married to him. 

*   I swear, it's like the universe just decided I was TOO FUCKING HAPPY what with the gainful and rewarding employment times two (yes, I still work for Temp Agency #2 and will continue to do so for as long as it remains awesome), the health insurance, The Narcissist no longer being a threat to me and my family, the relative good health, and the working out and doing yoga. So yesterday life was like "here, have some totally unfair marital discord and also a really bad earache. ENJOY!" Today Hotter finally, after three got-damn years of my asking, took care of The Issue via five minutes spent online. I'm really happy about that, and I love Hotter to bits, don't get me wrong, but I swear, sometimes when he's being a jerk like he was yesterday I just want to high-five him. In the face.

*   Speaking of working out and my health, I did thirty-five minutes on my usual elliptical machine and then seventy-five minutes of Yin Yoga yesterday. I felt fine the whole time, but am officially Slightly Concerned about my heart's health, because my heartrate started out by bottoming out in the low sixties in response to exercise, then after ten minutes rose into the range I would expect the heart of a non-smoking, relatively healthy thirty-four-year-old host-body to be in during strenuous cardio and stayed there for most of my workout, then bounced (seemingly at random, given that I kept the machine at the same incline and level of resistance throughout my workout and maintained a consistent number of strides per minute until the last five minutes of cooling down) between the low sixties and as high as 203 beats per minute. I...don't know what the deal is with that and will call my doctor tomorrow and make an appointment. I don't think I need to quit exercising seeing as how a) I FEEL perfectly fine aside from some occasional dizziness relating to standing up quickly (I have been chalking that up to the med change from Pristiq to Effexor XR since the onset roughly coincided with the med change, but in light of other variables am not sure I should write it off as such given that it's been a couple of weeks now), b) exercise is good for the heart, and c) the YMCA where I work out has a blood pressure machine and my BP immediately after I stepped off the elliptical was 115/79. But yes, I am concerned about the low heartrate in immediate response to strenuous exercise, the wild variability of my heartrate, and the bottom number of my BP creeping up toward the undesirable range. I don't know enough about Things Cardiovascular to tell whether the nice, low top number cancels out the heading-into-the-undesirable-range bottom number (or, in fact, they have anything to do with each other), or how worrisome the weird heartrate stuff actually is, and given my strong family history of coronary artery disease, valve issues, and arrythmias don't think I ought to ignore this longterm. Dammit. Hopefully after I get this checked out we can all laugh at my concerns.


* Actually I kind of wonder if the whole heartrate thing might fall under the umbrella of "weird shit MFA Mama's body does in response to infection." Because Bad Ear started draining copiously today while I was at work (AWKWARD!), and the pain became excruciating bordering on incapacitating. So I called and got an appointment to see one of my GP's partners after work, and went and had my ears looked at, and I'm sure it will surprise no one to hear that Bad Ear was indeed pretty badly infected. Antibiotics and Tramadol for me, and while it sucks that this happened I felt pretty damned lucky to have my shiny new insurance and a job where I was able to make alllllmost a copayment's worth of cash tips (yeah, I took the old rubber checkbook to the doctor today, because I kind of had to get my stupid ear addressed in order to be able to function and go to work tomorrow, where I will most likely--HOPEfully--be able to make good on the rest of the copayment and get that into the bank before the check hits the account). The prescriptions I was fortunately able to cover with a CVS gift card from the bay of E that I already had for Hotter's meds. Three cheers for having the ability to get much-needed medical attention and prescription drugs!
*   How are all of YOU?
title: work is great, bad ear is bad

body:
*   Bad Ear took a turn for the worse this morning, and was hurting like a bloody bastard. Since Anthem will only cover up to five Zithromax pills at a time (after which it will require you to get the rest as a refill and pay a second co-payment) (I'm not mad about that, just explaining it to y'all--this is still SO MUCH BETTER than paying out of pocket), and I was due to pick up the second lot today, I decided to talk to the doctor on call and make sure that was the thing to do (I thought maybe this meant the antibiotic wasn't working and would need to be changed, and didn't want to pick up another batch only to end up not using it). The doctor on call was very nice, and said no no, Zithromax should kill whatever was in my ear, but if I was still having pain and taking the antibiotic and decongestant as instructed then it was time to add in a steroid for the inflammation as well. Stupid Bad Ear!
*   Work today was lovely as usual. Everyone there is just SO very nice. Well, except for one person, who wasn't there today. I worked alone with that person on Wednesday right before my days off, and everyone I worked with today was eager to know how it went. I said pretty well, a little confusion at first but management sorted that right out (with extreme prejudice I might add), so no big deal. By confusion I mean they tried to do something unfair and underhanded, and I threw them under the bus without hesitation because if you screw with my money that is what I will do, but I was trying to be nice so I went with "confusion." No one was surprised, and told me that said person was A Bastard. I guess that is good to know. But even The Bastard at this place is at least pretty decent to your face and doesn't threaten anyone or go on angry tirades, so if The Bastard is the worst I have to deal with there all is still roses as far as I am concerned. Because even The Bastard at my new job is nicer than the nicest person at The Hotel California.
*   I spent an hour on the elliptical trainer working off the initial high-dose steroids, and exhausted myself. No yoga today; I missed that due to my work schedule. I do hope I'm not sore tomorrow, but it felt necessary. 
*   OH! I couldn't eat it because probably gluten, but HR sent me a candygram at work today! How nice was that? The wrapping paper said "Welcome to the family!" Aww.
*   Our female animals are broken. Pfeffer kindled a couple of days ago and had...three kits. One of which was stillborn. So another litter of two. And the same day one of the chickens laid an egg with no shell. It had a membrane (that fiddly rubbery-thing that you find under the shell when you peel a hardboiled egg), and so I brought it up to the house to gross the boys out with (they actually thought it was pretty cool, although Hotter screamed like a girl when I put it in his hand). WTH, animals? I blame the heat.
title: bullets because steroids make my ADD worse than usual

body:
*   I am at the tail-end of two days off, and it was nice to get to sleep in. I had the noblest of plans to go to Tai Chi and then yoga yesterday, but ended up sleeping through both. I think, as Dr. Anon pointed out on the facespace, that that was my body's way of saying it needed the sleep more (although I still hit the elliptical after getting up and getting my act together). 
*   Days off are something I am not accustomed to. But MFA Mama, you might say, weren't you just mostly unemployed for two months? Yes, but what that means is that I spent every free moment either working for Temp Agency #2 or else applying for jobs/calling to follow up on applications/working in the garden to grow food. Now that I have A Real Job, I'm still working for Temp Agency #2 on my days off because we need to catch up on the bills and I need to get the MFA Beater inspectable by the end of this month (*gulp*), but I feel less pressured about it and can take some time time do fun things like watch historical programs on Netflix with Hotter or make extra-nice meals for the family.
*   Bad Ear is better. It's still crackling a bit here and there, but I am not quite halfway through the course of antibiotics and the pain, thankfully, has abated. Three cheers for improvement!
*   Hotter and I have Made Peace. He corrected the issue we clashed over, which had to do with his SSDI going into a bank account in another state so that I would have to withdraw it from other (local) banks' ATM machines as cash in four installments (due to maximum daily withdrawal limits) every month, paying a total of $12/month in bank fees for the privilege and making rent a couple of days later than our landlord would like it to be EVERY MONTH. So that's a total of $528 we've spent since getting married for me to make 176 inconvenient extra trips to the bank. All because he wouldn't switch his direct deposit over to our account. I even suggested he open an individual checking account locally, in case it was the security of having the money be in his name only that he was after. NOPE! Toward the end of the monthly disagreement he FORBID ME TO MENTION IT, and I got seriously pissed. I finally put it to him in the context of "do you just not care about our financial wellbeing or my time?" and he put his hackles down and changed it. It took FIVE GOT-DAMN MINUTES. But it's done.
*   I'm going to go to the YMCA now and attempt Zumba. I tried to last night, but the instructor didn't show up. Hopefully I don't jinx the class again tonight!
*   I am actually looking forward to going to work tomorrow. I'm excited to see how much I make in tips, curious to see what the employee cafeteria will offer (I mostly just get salad from their salad bar because gluten, but sometimes they also have fruit which is nice) and eager to do my job some more. That is an amazing feeling.
*   How are all of YOU?
title: days off are good and bad ear is better

*   I'm feeling much better all-around, YAY! My neck, having stayed back in alignment, is less painful with doses of OTC anti-inflammatories that would make my hematologist blanch. It's only for a few days, I'm on Nexium, I eat with NSAIDs and take copious Vitamin K in the form of leafy greens and avoid alcohol for the duration, the end. But HEY! Neck! On the mend! Whoo tits! Also coughing less and less, so I think this truly was a stupid virus at the tail-end of my antibiotics for that last round of filth and...moving on...
*   On the plus side, Hotter has handled everything beautifully while I've been useless except as a second set of eyes and figurehead. His puppet regime has been seamlessly executed, and the children are clean, well-fed, entertained, and tucked into bed since an entirely decent hour. Hotter rules.
*   There is so much I'd like to say about various friends' situations and my thoughts about and reactions to them, but I can't really go into that without divulging stuff that is NOT mine. I would worry less if all of y'all were my friends, but, well. Anyway.
*   Speaking of which, you know how you DM someone and say "look out, Stalky is following you on the Twitter, pls be careful xox" and then Twitter does that "unfollow at will and at random" thing and unfollows them and then you follow them back mortified and try to explain that it wasn't drama on your part, but then it just...Reader's Digest version? body:
*   The burns are still healing well, so that's good.
*   Pretty much all of yesterday sucked though. Hotter decided to be an asshole, which is rare, so rare that I convinced myself I was being paranoid and he wasn't really being an asshole, he just wasn't aware of how he sounded (in my defense, this isn't total delusion on my part as the brain damage that I sometimes joke about does make Hotter occasionally unable to tell where "funny" leaves off and "divorce proceedings" begin; he'll totally think he's being all sarcastic/ironic and hilarious and I'll totally be cut to the quick and it SUCKS but I've learned that if he sounds like an utter asshole then there's a 98% chance he thinks we're both enjoying his little joke). I was even on g-chat with a good friend beating myself up for getting annoyed at all, because the poor guy doesn't know he's doing it and what kind of wife gets mad at their husband for something he can't control? I had gotten as far as wondering whether it was fair to poor, sweet Hotter that I have so much emotional baggage surrounding men who are assholes and get my feelings hurt SO EASILY when he is having a spell of Shittyremarkitis when he came in and asked what was wrong. I agonized briefly over phrasing things in a tactful, non-demeaning, low-reactivity way and explained that I was really upset but trying really hard to get over it, and he stopped me and clarified that no, HE MEANT WHAT HE SAID AT FACE VALUE.
*   What he actually said is irrelevant; I will say only that it reflected an incomplete understanding of what my capabilities were yesterday as far as what I could and couldn't do with my left arm bandaged up and threatening to deglove and that it was NOT anything to do with the sex. I'm not interested in rallying the innernet to prove how right I was in being shocked and horrified by my husband's insensitivity because I already know he was in the wrong. I don't generally write about marital discord on here, first of all because this is only the third time in eleven months of wedded bliss that I've even been angry at Hotter, so it's not really something I have to consciously Not Talk About. I also don't think that making him feel attacked by involving y'all in the context of "and BY THE WAY the innernet thinks you're an asshole, too!" would be conducive to letting things simmer the hell down, and finally as I said I have baggage relating to men who are assholes so half the time I'm overreacting anyway. This, however, is not one of those times.
*   The dog escaped out the front door yesterday and did her level best to kill both the chickens and yours truly; we did about three complete laps of the property (and by "we" I mean at least one frantic chicken, the dog, and me) before Hotter came out and helped and I effed my ankle up again. Ow.
*   Because I had nothing nice to say to anyone, I took my hurt feelings and my bum ankle and went on a garbage run, then stopped at the grocery store to get something in case we ended up getting any trick-or-treaters (we didn't), and because we're health nuts over here lately I ended up getting some organic animal-shaped fruit snacks. When I got home I decided to taste them, since my blood sugar was in the toilet, and my furthest molar back on the lower left side (which wouldn't be YOUR furthest molar back, as I had to have that one pulled due to infection and poverty during the very worst of my separation and divorce a couple of years ago) came apart entirely. That tooth had had a small "sticky spot" that my dentist put a filling over just to be safe a couple of years ago, and the evidently it is rotten under the filling, which came off taking some tooth with it, and there was (is) a big, black hole leading straight down to what I think may well be my VERY LAST EFFING NERVE. And the Vicodin I'm on for the burns? NOT EVEN HELPING A LITTLE BIT.
*   I retreated to the bathroom with a flashlight to assess the damage (which looked even worse than it felt, which is saying something), ascertained that it would be More Dental Work Than We Can Possibly Afford (I do not have dental insurance), remembered how awful getting that OTHER tooth pulled without anesthesia was (I am immune to novocaine and general at the oral surgeon is about $250 that they demand up-front and I didn't have then and don't have now), and just lost. My. Junk.
*   Hotter (who I am STILL furious with, but actually start to feel a little sorry for at this point in the narrative) heard me crying and came and asked (rather belligerently, as I suppose he thought I was trying to make him feel guilty) if I was crying over what he'd said earlier. I yelled at him, y'all. I am not a yeller. I don't generally express anger at all. But I effing LOST IT and hollered something to the effect of "NO IT IS NOT ALL ABOUT YOU, I AM CRYING ABOUT A LOT OF THINGS LIKE HOW I OVERDREW OUR FUCKING BANK ACCOUNT TO PAY FOR EMERGENCY MEDICAL CARE AND WE CAN'T AFFORD THE FEE AND MY ARM HURTS AND I AM MISSING HALLOWEEN WITH MY CHILDREN FOR THE SECOND YEAR IN A ROW AND MY ANKLE HURTS AND JUST NOW MY TOOTH FELL THE FUCK APART AND YOU KNOW I STILL HAVE NIGHTMARES ABOUT DENTAL EMERGENCIES FROM THE LAST TIME AND WE CAN'T AFFORD THE ANESTHESIA AND I CAN'T SIT STILL FOR ANOTHER TOOTH TO GET RIPPED OUT WITHOUT ANY, I JUST CAN'T AND IT HURTS SO MUCH AND THIS MEANS THE HOLIDAYS ARE CANCELED AND I FUCKING GIVE UP! I CAN'T EVEN DRINK WITH THE VICODIN AND YOU'RE ALSO A DICK, WHY DID YOU HAVE TO BE A DICK TONIGHT? WHYYYYYYYY????!!!!??!eleven?!!"
*   The rest of the night consisted of Hotter attempting to hug, spoon, pat, and otherwise comfort me, me giving Hotter the cold shoulder, my dentist failing to answer his pager, and then I stepped on a tack with my GOOD foot (we think the tack fell from a child's school art project, because we don't even USE tacks) and it went all the way in. I just had to laugh grimly while I rummaged for a butterknife to slide under the head and pull the thing out because we JUST established that I'm up-to-date on my Tetanus shot at Urgent Care due to the burn and REALLY universe? At that point a tack was kind of lame. Even in the good foot.
*   So the bank account is overdrawn, my arm still hurts, the tooth is exquisitely painful, my children will be home any moment, I am waiting for the XY to pay the child support before I can go to the dentist but I can't imagine that'll be anything less than THE STUFF OF NIGHTMARES, and probably my foot will turn gangrenous and fall off soonish.
*   I give up. I just fucking give up. I think I'm going to go back to bed and try that denial thing for a bit because eating my feelings is out (tooth) and I can't even go for a nice run to clear my head (ankle) and...yeah. Wish me luck in avoiding falling safes for the rest of the day; I'll be back when I can think of something, ANYTHING nice to say. I hope y'all are all in better spirits than I am on this shitty, shitty Monday. I really do.

body:
I do not tend to talk overly-much about my health on here. Some of you may be smiling and shaking your heads because I bitch about having colds plenty and occasionally mention prescriptions, but that's really only the tip of the iceberg (and while in some households mine might be the most egregiously bad health of all, this is not one of those households, heh). There are several reasons for this:
*   It's troll-bait to complain about your health struggles on your blog no matter HOW bad they are.*   Some of my health problems are pretty rare and the combination of numerous very-rare health problems is rather identifying if you're a medical professional, or a troll, or a troll who plays a medical professional on the innernet.*   Some of my health issues are shrouded in mystery, as my health was Very Fucking Bad for about two and a half years and then improved so dramatically with the "surgical removal of the spouse," as my endocrinologist termed it that it's kind of unreal, even to me, and I lived it. Plausibility issues in writing bug me because I spent years in Gradual School learning how NOT to write, and plausibility issues on a blog are...troll-bait.*   In my opinion, it's entirely possible that one of my most pressing physical health issues is a misdiagnosis, although ultimately that question is academic as the diagnosis I have been given is widely misunderstood and there's not a heck of a lot of doctors who know much about it and not a lot known even among those experts about how to treat it, and so is the other condition we already know based on empirical evidence that I have, which I think is the actual culprit for the symptoms that lead to a clinical diagnosis of condition the FIRST, so it's irrelevant really and OH MY GOD DO YOU SEE HOW BORING THAT JUST WAS? I went through an intense phase of knowledge-acquisition with each diagnosis as a geeky sort of empowerment exercise but honestly, I have reached my saturation point for discussion and debate and the SEARCH! FOR! ANSWERS! and I think my saturation point on the matter is higher than most, so: BORING!*   I don't like to dwell (anymore; I laid down in this initially and wallowed but that's just unattractive from the inside and outside). I may seem pretty damned zen about all of this but there is a small part of me that I've compartmentalized in my head that never stops shrieking in dread over a certain (as in certainty, not as in particular) prognosis and I have no desire to play peek-a-boo with it because it's all very cute until that ESCAPES.*   It's troll-bait to discuss money on your blog, and doctors cost money, and prescriptions cost money, and money definitely influences my treatment decisions, a LOT, so I can't logically discuss my health without explaining why I'm not doing x, y, and z, or taking drug a instead of drug b, etc. and there are those (by which I mean trolls) who would say that that is the same as asking for something.
   All of which is to say that I woke up feeling much better and think I just had a stupid little cold on the heels of the infection the Levaquin was killing off, so yay, but then I put my arms up to fasten my hair into a ponytail and pinched a nerve in my neck/shoulder area, and OWWW. There's a certain non-narcotic (it's actually a neuroleptic) prescription drug that helps this sort of nerve pain for me (whether it is due to condition one, an autoimmune/inflammatory one for which said drug was prescribed, or another facet of my underlying connective tissue disease), and I have a bit of it on-hand, and it may or may not be enough but more of the same drug would be prohibitively expensive, so I'm worried, and stress exascerbates the condition this allegedly stems from in some part so I feel like I shouldn't worry JUST IN CASE the medical professionals are right but DAMN, y'know? Add to that the fact that the MFA Minivan is tits-up and I am not impressed with 2011 so far, not at all.
   I've been propped on the couch for the past hour since this happened with an icepack and a Lidoderm patch on my neck, and have taken some anti-inflammatory drugs and the prescription I have for the nerve pain, and I think it may be SLIGHTLY less acutely and searingly painful but honestly I'm not sure. Also, due to some previous nerve damage my left hand is goofy on a good day and the current pinched nerve is affecting my RIGHT arm, so this should be...interesting.
   Sigh.
   How are all of YOU?
title: the one where I make vague and disgusted reference to my health

body:
Zumba is NOT MY FRIEND. I should have known as soon as the instructor came into the room that this was not for me; she was as big around as one of my thighs (I'm a size 8 these days, for reference), and if you had turned her head backward on her neck her body would not have looked any different from the front. I had the thought that, should she compete in the Olympics, the judges would want to see a karyotype done to prove she was female, and then mentally scolded myself for having that thought. Bodies come in all shapes and sizes, I told myself. She's amazingly fit and you're just jealous! 
   Then the class began. I was aware going in that Zumba is pretty intense, but looking around the room I would put myself in the top 25% fitness-wise, so I thought I would be okay. I do thirty-five minutes to an hour of cardio a day and have a physically-demanding job. How hard could it be? The answer: too damn hard.
   Gentle Readers, there was no way I could physically move my body as fast as that, even trying as hard as I could and completely disregarding my soft tissue continuing to fly in one direction while my skeleton moved in the other, like a whiplash of flesh. I looked around surreptitiously and saw that nobody else was keeping pace with the instructor either, and decided I was being overly self-conscious. So I started keeping up with the direction the instructor's body was moving, but omitting every other step-ball-change so that I could at least keep up without losing an eye to one of my own flying tits or elbows. 
   Fifteen minutes into the class, my chest began to hurt. It was mostly on the right side, not the left, so I told myself it wasn't a heart attack and to woman up.
   Half an hour in the chest pain intensified and I started having trouble breathing. Surely the class is almost over, I told myself, and then I looked at the clock and said FUCK THIS and got out of there.
   So yeah. Zumba and I are NOT FRIENDS and I will stick to yoga and the elliptical from here on out. I kind of hate dancing anyway. I'm still coughing stuff up the way I do after an asthma attack and sweating after taking a shower and chugging a bottle of Gatorade. Fuck. That. Action.

body:
About ten years ago, when I was pregnant with Big Child, was the second time I almost got divorced (the first time I almost got divorced was when I didn't abort Big Child, but that's neither here nor there). Reason being? We had just found out Big Child would be a boy and I refused to have a bris in which some shaky old fart powered by Manischevitz hacked at my (then fetal) firstborn's foreskin with a dubiously sterile blade in my living room. Just, no. I may not be religious at all, but I'm pretty down with cultural traditions that don't involve amateur gentital mutilation (or professional genital mutilation, in all honesty, but the compromise that the XY and I ultimately arrived at was that Big Child and the subsequent MFA Children were circumcised, just in hospitals, by MDs, with topical anesthetic). The XY, however, was irate at the time, and yelled and blustered and thundered, and accused me of everything from failing to resist the diaspora to wanting the future Big Child to be mocked in the locker-room in high school.
   It was not pretty.
   All that to say that the CATHERINE situation came to a head tonight when the XY returned the children over an hour late (and a solid half-hour past their bedtime) claiming that Big Child had failed to do his homework in a timely fashion. Big Child sold his father down the river the moment the door closed, however, and said that they were late because they had gone out of town to CATHERINE's house so that she could cook them dinner, and he hadn't been permitted to start his homework until after they'd eaten, which took a while because she made something special and I don't know, I think my eyes kind of glazed over for a little while there, but I really was determined to be nice and said that I was glad they'd at least done something special for the first night of Hannukah.
   "No, Daddy forgot! I asked him if we were going to light the candles and he was like 'oh it's Hannukah?'" Big Child said, looking digusted. "We didn't have any gelt, and I was excited because this year I can have the dairy in the chocolate," Little Child said, lip quivering. And my heart broke a little bit and I grabbed my father's menorah and a couple of candles and started digging around for a lighter, because that is what I do, I try to make it up to them when their father's hypocrisy lets them down.
   "You're supposed to light the candles at sunset anyway," Middle Child said derisively, "it's too late." I said that while that was true about lighting the candles at sunset, Hannukah was a holiday that celebrated the Jews' ability to make do with what was on-hand, and since I hadn't had them on hand as they were at CATHERINE's house with their father failing to resist the diaspora we would just hearken back to our roots and light the candles (yes, it's the first night, but you start with two, the shamash or "helper candle" and the first proper candle of the eight) "WELL THAT'S DUMB AND I BELIEVE IN JESUS LIKE CATHERINE ANYWAY," Middle Child bellowed, and then I told him that he could go believe in Jesus in his room while the rest of us lit the dadblasted candles but couldn't quite keep the quaver out of my voice because REALLY? Middle Child wanted to mix it up some more but Hotter stepped in and told him to quit making his mother cry and marched him to his room where he proceeded to pitch an overtired fit. Good old Hotter!
   "It's okay Mommy, I won't hassle you about Jesus tonight," Big Child said magnanimously back out at the dining room table where I was fiddling with the candles (the miracle of Hannukah! Big Child loves to razz me about Jesus because he's a punk that way), and Little Child said he was okay with waiting until tomorrow for the gelt, and I told them how our menorah had belonged to my dad and to his mother before him, and how my father always burned his hands trying to melt wax to make candles stick to the rims of the impossibly small and crooked holes in the cheap piece of junk and cussed, and then I burned my fingers and Big Child said I could cuss if it would make me feel better but I said that was okay, and we talked about the probability of one night's oil lasting for eight days. "I dunno buddy, I wasn't there," I finally said. "Maybe it did, maybe it didn't, maybe the atmospheric conditions or the length of the wick in the lamp helped it last longer, who knows, but Hannukah is a holiday that celebrates things working out so that you have what you need even when it seems like there's no way that's possible. The Jews had just had their tuchuses almost handed to them, the Maccabees were some scrappers but it was an improbable victory and they were the underdogs, kind of like us. It probably wasn't pretty, and it probably didn't look good at all, but they made what they had work kind of like we do today, I mean look at me, I didn't buy gelt or make any latkes because I thought you were celebrating with your father who was being a bad Jew this year and failing to resist the diaspora with CATHERINE, your brother is down the hall pouting about Jesus, and I'm out here in my bathrobe with a snotty nose burning my stinking fingers past bedtime with a couple of birthday candles and a jacked-up menorah, because it's what we do. We make do with what we have, even when things suck." Then Big and Little children giggled over me saying "suck" and headed to bed.
   After that, I had a talk with Middle Child, who said he wanted to change and be like CATHERINE so she'd like him, and told him that changing so that people will like you is never a good idea, because either they like you the way you are or they don't, and if they don't they're not worth trying to change for and that didn't tend to work anyway. "But I really want her to like me," he bawled. I asked him if Daddy had ever liked me even though I tried to change who I was. "No, Daddy has NEVER liked you," he said. I asked him if I seemed happier when I was trying to change who I was for Daddy or after I gave up on that. "After," he said. "Well okay then. You find people who like you for you, and don't worry, CATHERINE sounds like she likes you plenty and I like you just fine even when you take a poop on me while I try to make the best of a bad situation because you're awesome, but please don't do that again. It really hurt my feelings." He said he wouldn't.
   After the children were in bed, Hotter asked what the hell kind of Jew forgot about Hannukah. "The kind whose girlfriend puts her tree up BEFORE Thanksgiving," I reminded him (yes, the MFA Children ratted CATHERINE out as being one of THOSE). "Isn't it the same time every year?" I said no, no it wasn't, it was actually pretty confusing, but those of us who weren't failing to resist the motherfucking diaspora looked it up on Google AS GOD INTENDED and we had a laugh over that, but...well, hell, y'all. I guess it's not such a mystery why hypocrisy is making me blow my stack lately afterall.
   I hate the effing holidays.
   Can I go to sleep and wake up around Boxing Day, y'reckon?
 
P.S. My Twitter stream is unlocked once more; Stalky got shut down for TOS violations. I have grumbled about Twitter plenty since they wouldn't do a thing about it a few months ago when Stalky first started up her "anonymous" antics on there, but apparently trying to get a pseudonymous blogger fired by talking smack about her professional abilities with two-thirds of her full name on Twitter is okay but posting several timeline pages' worth of butthurt vitriol because it wouldn't put the lotion on its skin and Stalky has no hose you got called on your bullshit and don't WANT to provide your own address is NOT okay if you're all "but since you had to go and get CUTE about it here's YOUR home address, neener neener!" and include said blogger's home address in your next tweet. HAPPY HANNUKAH TO ME! Thanks, Twitter. I'm sure Stalky will just start a new account, because she doesn't seem to have a whole lot else to do with her time, or maybe start leaving hateful comments or sending e-mails from anonymous g-mail accounts as she likes to do to let me know she's pining for me around holidays, but maybe she'll find something productive to do with herself instead. Here again for her reference (because I'm sure my NUMBER ONE FAN is reading this) is the list K so sweetly provided.

body: *  This is the fastest I've ever felt THIS MUCH better from one of my clusterinfuctions (ear, sinus, upper-respiratory); the ground-glass filled rubber cement is on the move and the worst of the swelling has gone down. THANK GOODNESS. That was the most acutely horrid I've felt in quite some time.*  MFA Puppy is also much improved. Just the past few days something has shifted; she's lengthened out, filled out, and really come into her own personality-wise. I don't quite know what the major shift there has been, or whether puppies go through developmental leaps like human babies do or what, but suddenly there's a quiet intelligence in her beady little eyes, a presence. The dignified sort of presence very large, noble-looking dogs like Wolfhounds or Great Danes have, almost dignity. Don't get me wrong, she still picks up, tugs on, mouths, and plays with every damn thing she comes across and has fits of heightened stupidity and rampant silliness, but she listens now and understands that you're communicating with her, whether she chooses to listen or not. Her first fully-mastered command, "sit," got its first actual real-world use today when we took her to Petsmart and placed her on the Banfield Pet Hospital's scale. She scrambled and lunged and strained to be off the stainless steel plate as usual, but I pulled my hands away and barked "SIT!" and she plonked her butt down and sat perfectly still long enough for the number to steady. GOOD DOG, OMG YES!!!*  I don't want to jinx myself, but I actually think that the combination of catching up with my sleep deficit and treating the infection that must've never fully gone away is going to make me feel much better than my recent baseline "blah." I thought it was BlogHer hangover and maybe old age, but maybe not. I was starting to think maybe I ought to get my thyroid levels checked because of the persistent fatigue but it seems to be lifting. Yay!*  The reason we were at Petsmart, although we also picked up more food for the pitbull princess, was to buy feeder crickets for The Undertoad. OH YES. I caught him last night when he leapt out of a potato ditch I was weeding, and since I had my gloves on and he was RIGHT THERE...yes. For those of you who don't know me offline or on the facespace, Underdog slithered underneath the big rock in the sky and we had an empty terrarium. Don't worry, though, if you're one of the several people I instructed to junk-punch me if I rescued another critter you may STAND DOWN. This was not a rescue and the toad is not a pet (although Hotter, who has always loved and rooted for the toad, is trying to put that kind of spin on things). This was an apprehension and the toad is a prisoner. That motherfucking thing was my nemesis and he can't leap out from under foliage across my bare feet and terrify me if he's locked up tight. I WIN, TOAD.*  How is YOUR holiday weekend treating you?
title: oh, man, so much better

body:
*  Sorry for disappearing, y'all. Hubris got the best of me after I posted how very much better I was feeling and I have been humblingly ill the past few days since then. My ear IS better, and the sinus pressure is much improved, so I think it's more that the original virus is taking its time fucking off and less that the antibiotics aren't doing their job. Usually by the time I go to the doctor much later in the process, I think the virus has run its course and the infection is all that ails me, but this time I was gun-shy enough about the ear that I still had some misery in store from the original virus when I went on antibiotics.*  Hotter didn't catch this particular bug, which is somewhat miraculous given just how much swapping of fluids we did over the holiday weekend (the MFA Children flew to Yankee State with the XY for five days to visit family and Hotter and I had Wednesday through Monday footloose and child-free). I think he was feeling a little outshined by my spectacular phlegm production or something, though, because he has developed a new and unpleasant Mystery Malady of his own.*  This is what's wrong with Hotter:
 Figure One: Back off, y'all, he's MINE!   It started as a blotch like this on the side of his neck, about the size of a saucer, and now there's one like a dinner-plate on his back and this one on his flank right around where one of his kidneys would be if he was a normal person (his native kidneys are dead and shriveled up and he has one good, donated one in his BELLY of all places). The initial blotch was just funny-looking for nearly a week, then felt like a bad sunburn, and now he says all of them hurt pretty badly, all the way down through the muscles, badly enough that he ASKED to go to the doctor yesterday (usually I have to drag him in with a pole-snare, more or less). The doctor was all "Jesus, wow, what the crap is THAT?!?" and said he'd never seen anything like it, and ran a CBC (which was normal except for slight anemia, which is actually a good thing given that Hotter has polycythemia) and a creatinine level (a bit lower than Hotter's last one, so also good), and sent blood off to test for Lyme Disease because Hotter (like 98% of the general population here) got bitten by a tick over the summer and dang if the spots don't all look like bullseyes. He said that if this IS Lyme it's a rather atypical presentation, but that's probably what I'll end up putting on Hotter's tombstone in fifty years so we all agreed it was worth checking. In the meantime Hotter is on some antibiotics just in case (since nobody likes infections in a transplant patient) and has some acetaminophen-free narcotic pain pills to take if he needs them (he said the pain if you touch one of the spots is an eight of ten and then declined when the doctor offered, but I overruled him and pointed out that if he didn't need them he didn't have to take them and the doctor sided with me--Hotter hates to take narcotics but last night did cave and take a half dose, so probably he was in agony).*  The dog, at least, is muchmuch better. We didn't realize how much hair MFA Puppy was missing until she'd started treatment for the mange--it turns out her butt and underbelly aren't supposed to be bald, after all. Go figure. She's grown back nearly all of the hair on the affected area on her back and neck, and while Hotter and I can still see the spot on her head, the XY couldn't when he saw her last (we picked him and the MFA Children up from the airport and he gave us some gas money--why yes, that IS awfully grown-up and civil and I don't know what to make of it either but am just going to go with it), and to look at her now you'd never know the dog was in such a bad way just two weeks ago. She's also added "shake" to her repertoire of tricks and seems to pick up about one new command a day now (currently she knows come, sit, shake, drop it, and "get in your crate") and is shaping up to be quite a bright little dog! *  So yes, hi, I'm boring and I think I'll go and take ANOTHER nap before the children get home from school because this summer cold is kicking my arse. How are all of YOU?

body:
*  Hotter's Lyme disease test came back negative, so we're back to not knowing what the hell that rash on him is from. The symptoms are unchanged, except that now he says it itches a little in addition to hurting like a sumbitch. We have a call in to the Transplant team so that they can take a look next (the internist who saw Hotter kept mentioning that he just didn't know about "all those weird drugs!" and said he didn't want to send Hotter for a full dermatology work-up when this could be something Transplant sees all the time, which I guess is fair enough).*  MFA Puppy went to the vet today for her first follow-up skin scraping:
  Figure One: Isis was less than enthused when she realized that we were going into a treatment room instead of just stopping off to use the scale.   When we hoisted her up onto the exam table, she looked positively sad:
  Figure Two: She drooped considerably the moment her paws hit the steel, and I don't think the rabies vaccine and skin scraping did much to brighten her day.   As unhappy as Isis was with our visit to the Banfield Pet Hospital today, the results were good! Her skin scraping from today was negative for demodex mites, and if her next one is negative, too, she'll be officially cured of the mange! Her next dip is Monday, then two weeks after that she'll have another, and then the next follow-up skin scraping after that will determine whether she's done in three dips.*  The final negative was a bit less happy. This is the sign on the door of the room where my youngest child goes for his after-lunch tube-feeding every day (I asked that they not feed him in the clinic, as he's pretty susceptible to viruses and who wants to eat where they send the pukers and the nosebleeds?):
 Figure Three: MEDICAL PROCEDURE??? SERIOUSLY? I'm sorry, but once my kid can read I think that'll have certain...connotations.   When you go inside the room, this is what you see:
  Figure Four: Yeah, another sign in case you missed the first one, and a pair of rubber gloves. Little Child has some VERY negative associations with gloved people, and looked pretty nervous today while I was talking the clinic aide through feeding him.   I am trying not to be a bitch about this, y'all, I am, but...gloves? For those of you who have never fed anyone through a g-tube, it is NOT a gory procedure. You don't touch any body fluids, there is no sterile field, and there's pretty much no reason to wear gloves while you do it. For all I know there is some procedural code in place that says they have to wear gloves to do this, but it seems like overkill and combined with the signs...well could they make my kid feel like any more of a freak, y'think? Maybe I'm being over-sensitive, I dunno. I am deliberately refraining from commenting on the signs because I'm aware that this might just be my "stuff" but what do YOU think? Would it be unreasonable to ask that the sign just say "reserved?"

body:
First the good news! As I mentioned earlier, MFA Puppy went for her second Mitaban treatment today, and Hotter and I picked her up around 2:45. She is MUCH less affected by the dip than last time, thank goodness, and is probably functioning at a solid 85% so far (I say so far because it's just now getting fully dark, so we'll see if she's night-blind this time around although she's not uncoordinated or apathetic and is drinking normally so fingers crossed).   The bad news is that the small lump I noticed was in fact the beginning of another secondary bacterial skin infection, in the opinion of the veterinarian who saw Isis today. She said that unfortunately it seems that Isis is going to be one of those dogs who's just really prone to this, either due to strong genetic predisposition/a chronically weak immune system OR due to her rough start in life as an early weanling who arrived in our home very ill from a bacterial GI infection. Obviously we're hoping it's the latter, and that once the mange is long-gone Isis will stop getting skin infections, but either way this bought her another two-week course of a different antibiotic (the vet skipped the impression slide this time around since this presented exactly like the last infection and coincided with the cessation of the previous antibiotic, and I'm glad she spared us the lab charges and agree with her reasoning). Or rather, y'all did:
  Figure One: Y'all did this . Thank you so much!   After her veterinary ordeal, Hotter and I (or, uh, the doggy tooth-fairy, since Isis lost a puppy-tooth last night) treated our pup to a nice smoked beef rib (they're under two bucks and provide three to four hours of solid happy gnawing time during which she's not looking for trouble or harassing whoever is cooking dinner). I think she forgives us for abandoning her at the pet hospital yet again:

body: *   I am being crushed by a deadline so this will be short (some contract writing-type work; I'd love to be more specific but my unfriendly blogosphere stalker likes to make threats relating to my continued gainful employment so from time to time I'll mention a deadline and that's all I can really tell y'all except hey! I have a job again! Whoo!).*   MFA Puppy is at the vet for her second Mitaban dip as we speak (thank y'all so much). I'm a nervous wreck and probably won't get much done until Hotter and I pick her up (hopefully in about two hours if all goes the same as it did last time). This stuff effed my poor dog up so badly last time...stupid demodex mites! Also she has one tiny little lump on her back that I asked the vet to look at; Isis took her last antibiotic tablet four days ago and I hope the skin infection isn't returning! I'll let y'all know what the vet says either way.*   The XY and I are having the dumbest fight we've had since the separation (although sadly it's far from the dumbest fight we've ever had). In a nutshell, he has wanted for years to pursue a career for Little Child as a child actor and I am against this, but lately he's really got a bug up his butt about it, and since I can no longer bring him back in line by threatening to withhold sex (seeing as how I've been doing that for two years and counting ANYWAY) he's not dropping it this time. I feel like Little Child has enough making him "different" with the g-tube and the stunted growth, and his brothers have enough reasons to feel resentful and/or like Little Child gets "special treatment," and furthermore I can't think of a single child actor who went on to be a happy, sane, well-adjusted adult. When I said that to the XY he brought up Scott Baio, and the conversation went downhill from there (Google "Scott Baio Twitter" if you don't know what I'm talking about). At this point things have deteriorated to the point that I'm worried our newfound amicability is in grave danger, and I'm extra-stabby because really? We're not going to go to the mats over medicating anyone's ADHD, whether to send the boys to Hebrew school so that they can have bar mitzvahs, or the wisdom (or NOT) of putting the baby on growth hormones? We're going to go back to acrimonious hostility to the detriment of our childrens' mental health over whether to let Little Child become a white Webster? This is my life, y'all. STAB STAB STAB!

body: I keep meaning to finish writing about BlogHer, and today is as good a day as any, although I've already waited so long that the memories are all jumbled together.   So much stands out in my mind. The Bloggess signing my boob, decorating dildoes at a sex-toy party, meeting Aunt Becky on the dance floor and getting a free We-Vibe from Sandy of Toy With Me (I heart their sex toy reviews and have been meaning to write one about that thing, but Hotter is scared of it and calls it the "cootchie clamp" so...yeah). Fabulous sessions, crazy parties, the madness that is Sparklecorn (this tweet pretty much sums it up). Losing my friends, my suitcase, my ID and my composure in Manhattan (I found the suitcase, by the way, which was pretty much a miracle, and TSA found my ID in my back pocket while searching me extra-close as an unidentified flier).   You know what stands out the most in my mind, though? The shuttle-ride to LaGuardia. I debated whether or not to even write about it, but I can't get it out of my head so I think I kind of have to.    When the Super Shuttle pulled up to take me to the airport, the driver took my suitcase and said "I'm sorry but you gotta sit in the front." I climbed into the front passenger seat, turned to fasten my seatbelt, and found myself face-to-face with none other than Tanner Bawn. Yes, that Tanner. Catherine of Her Bad Mother, who I'd had the pleasure of meeting and talking with at some length during the conference, and Katie of Motherbumper, who I hadn't managed to actually connect with, were sitting in the far back with Tanner's mom, and Tanner's chair was secured in the middle of the shuttle, which put him right up behind me, so I said something silly like "OH! You're TANNER! HI!"    We talked the rest of the way to the airport, about a half-hour ride, about our pets (when I told Tanner I was allergic to cats, he looked at me with obvious pity and asked if I'd ever gotten to pet one and feel how soft they are), the kinds of houses we lived in versus the types of buildings around us, different forms of mass transit we'd ridden on, and license plates. We played the license plate game (Tanner has a keen eye and was able to spot plates from different states much faster than I was). He asked me if I had any kids, and whether they'd started school yet (kids in some parts of both our countries were going back to school that day, although Tanner and my own kids still had a few weeks of freedom left). I asked him if he was excited to be getting on a plane to fly home, and he said he was worried that his chair would get messed up again. I told him I didn't think so, that I was willing to bet the airline would be super extra-careful since they now knew that all of his aunt Catherine's friends would fuss at them if they weren't. At the airport, Tanner and I said goodbye and wished each other safe travels, and I've thought about him every day since then.    It's one thing to read about a kid like Tanner; of course you think "wow, that poor kid" and "those assholes better fix that chair!" But when you meet him, and he's every bit as sweet and goofy as your own nine-year-old at home, and likes the same things and kills time on a long car-ride the same way...well, damn. The idea that a kid like that could be dying just doesn't compute.    I don't know what I'm trying to say here. I don't know what to do with this memory of a shuttle-ride that keeps tapping me on the shoulder. I think I'll wear my tutu when I go running tonight, maybe, and hug my kids extra-close. But there you have it: my favorite celebrity sighting from BlogHer. Happy Friday, y'all.
title: the long overdue BlogHer wrap-up post

...Hopeful Parents has a fundraiser going on through Pampered Chef (details here and on the HP sidebar), wherein they receive 15% of sales made through the designated link (it's on the page I just linked to). AND! If you make a purchase through there you are entered in a raffle for a $50 Pampered Chef gift certificate. BUT WAIT, if you go there and make a purchase and e-mail Hopeful Parents letting them know that you read about the fundraiser here (you will need to include my "name," blog name, and e-mail address, a la "I heard about this fundraiser from MFA Mama at www.mfamama.typepad.com and her e-mail address is mfamamablogATgmailDOTcom" then we BOTH get entered in a raffle for a $50 Pampered Chef gift card. PLUS ALSO Pampered Chef products are fabulous.
   We here at Casa MFA regularly use a few Pampered Chef items that I've had for years and years since I was rich enough to buy such things; this is what I use to divide my dough when I'm baking bread (and scrape it off the table after kneading and during clean-up), this is an excellent scraper that is pretty hard to melt (not that I haven't tried) and as an added bonus, uh, a...friend...told me it makes a satisfying "thwack" if spanking is your thing (Disclaimer: I mean the kind of spanking that goes on between consenting adults when children are with their non-custodial parent. We do not spank children here), these are great for baking everything from pizza to cookies to oven fries and fish sticks on, and their knives really are all that and a bag of chips (I have a HUGE serrated one that is four years old, no longer appears to be for sale, and cuts tomatoes without denting the skin and hot bread without tearing the loaf apart; it's what I'd use if I ever had to perform a kitchen-table amputation).
   What, you never contemplated what your go-to blade for such things would be? I'm terribly sorry for your lack of imagination then!
   SO! The key points are:
*   MAKE SURE you go to HP and use the link FROM THEIR SITE to make any purchases to make sure they get credit. You'll also need to enter their organization name ("Hopeful Parents") in the box for that when you place your order.
*   Definitely e-mail HP (writehopefulparentsATgmailDOTcom) if you do buy something, and let them know you hear about the fundraiser from me (include my "name," blog URL, and e-mail, which you can c&p above) so that we both get a raffle entry.
*   The last day to order and have 15% of the proceeds go to HP is December 14th, and FedEx will deliver on December 21st.
*   I am sick in the head. But if you're reading this, you already knew that.
*   If you don't need any kitchen wares and want to purchase an organic, homemade gift for the health-nut or dog-lover in your life, I still have a few jars of MFOrganics sea salt scrub in each scent left and it's not too late to order :) Happy shopping!

body:
*   So we decorated the tree tonight. I try to avoid saying "Christmas Tree" and call it a Hannukah Bush or holiday tree. I encourage the children, if they prefer not to refer directly to Hannukah and "out" themselves as Jews to call things holiday decorations, holiday cookies, holiday presents, etc. After dinner, one MFA Child was being a knucklehead about getting his homework done, and we were waiting on that to begin decorating. Hotter (who for the record insists that he is not grouchy) got up from an after-dinner nap, waded into the fray of the other two children who were trying to badger me and get me to call it a Christmas tree like CATHERINE, and promptly tripped over a toy one of them had left on the floor for the umpteenth time this week. A child who was NOT the toy's owner immediately blamed the other non-owner of said toy, who after the actual toy-owner, also the homework-dawdler, came forward and apologized, said "no that's okay if you're going to kill someone kill me, I'll just go to HEAVEN!"
*   I reminded the children that when they're adults they may believe whatever they want, but they are being raised Jewish, dadgum it, and then we decorated the tree and sent the kids to bed and I went through backpacks. The same child who volunteered to martyr himself (not that anyone was in danger of dying, which makes it that much more aggravating) had brought home some Thanksgiving-themed artwork from school, including a piece of lined paper with a turkey printed on it in which they'd listed things they were thankful for:
 Figure One: This is where my eyelid started twitching, for real.  Figure Two: It was pretty much like this, except if I also knew how to use Photoshop and could Photoshop Jesus in there throwing lightning at the menorah like the emperor in Return of the Jedi. No, YOU have a blown-glass Yoda, Darth Vader, Boba Fett, and C3PO on YOUR motherfucking HANNUKAH BUSH and are motherfucking outraged!
*   So I am going to take the nice gay couple with the Labradoodle from the dog park up on their offer to bring the boys to their Reform temple, because god dammit if people are going to insist on being religious around here they're going to be the religion of their forefathers. And I am not kidding. And I enjoy houses of worship early on a non-school morning about as much as I enjoy family court.
*   Lest ye think my mood could not get any worse, Hotter (when I told him what I intended to do) asked if he was going. I told him he didn't have to and he said no what I mean is would I be welcome and I said it's a reform temple that's cool with out and proud gay couples so I'm guessing an agnostic of Christian origin would be permitted to observe, although they might want him to wear a yarmulke, or maybe not, it'd been a while since I had dealings with the local Jewish community. He then proceeded to make a bad joke about the hats Orthodox men wear and speculated as to how long it would take him to grow sidelocks, and well lookathere.
*   I think I will have an adult beverage and watch something mindless on Hulu. I don't really have a good last bullet point. How are all of you?

body:
When I first because friends with Hotter, I had a blog. I've had a blog for most of the time we've known each other (and we were friends for a couple of years before my separation from the XY, so we go back a ways). Hotter has always, always read my blog. I love that about him; he gets almost as much of a kick out of my blogging as I do. He'll be all "remember, terri c. said..." or "are you facespace friends with the girl with the wonky uterus? Because I picture her a certain way, and..." He'll torment me over typos, ask if I've checked recently for new comments, etc. and really the ONE thing he'd never done, EVER, is comment on a post via Typepad (he comments plenty on just about everything, mind you, just not online). Not as himself, not as his online alias he was using in the forum where we met, NEVER. And I've always been fine with that. I mean, I enjoy comments as much as the next blogger does, but I'd still write without them. Last night, however? Hotter decided to comment. Oh, Hotter.
   As big a pest as he is with his bat-themed midlife crisis, I still can't say how great Hotter is, y'all. After blowing off two or three colds in a row like a normal person with a hearty immune system (I credit giving up white sugar, going organic, and taking my vitamins and herbal supplement regularly, and also the Neti Pot) I have been felled--FELLED, LIKE A MIGHTY SEQUOIA--by what May would call a Cold of Filth. And it IS! So currently I'm sick, the kind of sick that makes you whimper as a grown-ass adult, and Hotter has tucked me in on the reclining couch with a blanket and a hot Bed Buddy. Everyone should have a Hotter, I tell you.
   Dr. Isis is always hilarious, but this week she outdid herself. Behold, y'all!
   I was just looking on my own blog to click and link that and I am mortified; I recently performed open-heart surgery on my blogroll, and I was a bit vexed at the time and appear to have eliminated Ann from the thing in the process. That was long enough ago though that if I were her and noticed I might've taken it personally. Probably she isn't petty like I am, but I'm sorry, Ann! I'm going to try and put you back in now!
   Whee, decongestants. Maybe I'll become the fourth person in the house to convert after seeing Jesus on these things!* I'll keep you posted.
 
*   Yes, I do have a sense of humor about the Jesus thing, finally. Last night Bumpus did a wee on the floor and I told Hotter we ought to wake Big Child up and tell him that since he loves Jesus so much we're sending Him Big Child's dog. *snort*

body:
*   I don't think the MFA Children are the target of any particular evangelist...the older two went (over my objections) to church-based preschool programs (supposedly these were secular programs, but there were Christmas and Easter pageants) and honestly the single biggest thing turning them into little Jesus-puppets is Kennedy. Kennedy is not the real name of the kid who bullied Big Child for two years straight (first and second grades), but it's something equally last-namey and pretentious and KENNEDY wanted everyone to vote for John McCain and KENNEDY said if you don't believe in Jesus you'll go to hell and KENNEDY KENNEDY KENNEDY. I kind of want to track the little shit down and smack him. This started Big Child on the God thing, and Middly picked it up from him, and Little Child parrots everything they do. I've asked all sorts of questions and apparently this is just a) the fact that my kids are followers in general and b) peer pressure (they're in a 95% WASP school district).
*   Yoda appears to be about as happy with this entire Jesus debacle as I am:
 Figure One: So angry is he.
*   The dogs used a few moments of unattended freedom to eat the offending Jesus-turkey. GOOD DOGS! I didn't even have to smear it with peanut butter...
*   Hotter is having the weirdest midlife crisis ever. His reply to pretty much everything on the innernet (as those of you who are friends with him on the facespace will have noticed already) is "I'm Batman." He even changed his facespace avatar to the bat-signal, prompting me to comment and assure everyone he wasn't doing that pointless "end child abuse by changing your facespace avatar" thing. No, he's just...very, very special...is all. Not that I can comment on this overly much, since my left lower eyelid has been twitching since the first Jesus-fit.
*   The Araucanas (well, one of them anyway) produced the first blue egg today!
 Figure Two: The egg at the top left (darker brown) is from George the ISA Brown. The other brown egg is from one of the Barred Plymouth Rocks, and the blue one is from one of the Araucanas! Great excitement here today!
*   I have a cold. Yes, another one. Damn it. I felt fine this morning, mucked the chicken coop and turned the compost this afternoon after rocking Hotter's world, and then all of a sudden right before dinner BOOM! Sick as a dog. My left ear hurts, and...well, damn it all to HELL.
*   Fortunately no one caused any trouble at the candle-lighting tonight, and with a little luck this should be our last one for the year (tomorrow is the last night of Hannukah, but the boys will be with their father at sunset). I suppose it could have been worse:
 Figure Three: At least we ended on a good note.
