body:
Hotter and I want MFA Puppy to be a friendly, social critter, especially since my kids are dead-set on training her to be a therapy dog when she grows up (and I support this: if they want to help I will pay for the obedience classes because it beats video games and I like that they came up with the idea all on their own based on how much they've enjoyed the therapy dogs in their hematologist's waiting room). Socializing the dog responsibly (i.e. watching her like a hawk to discourage jumping, mouthing, and other undesirable behaviors and make sure other people's kids don't maul her) is hard to do while also keeping tabs on three kids who are apt to do a lot of the same undesirable things, and so we decided to start out by taking her out in public without the children. Eventually we'd like to take her to some dog parks, but since she hasn't had all of her shots and is still pretty small we decided that a (dog-friendly) local outdoor shopping center was a better idea for right now; that way she could meet and greet new people and see other (leashed) dogs too. The shopping center in question also has a fountain consisting of jets embedded flush to the ground in the junction of several brick walkways that they allow children and dogs to play in as long as they're supervised and playing safely, so it seemed like an ideal destination on a day when the weather was like this:
 Figure One: Fuck you, nature.   This was our first time taking the puppy out in public, and while I've heard other folks who own pitbulls refer to the "pitbull stigma" before, I had never encountered it myself (Hotter grew up with a pitbull but MFA Puppy is my first) and (being as prone to thinking others feel the same way I do about things as the next idiot) didn't think it would be an issue. Personally I've worked with domesticated animals (mostly horses) enough to know that barring some sort of organic illness (like rabies or encephalitis) or logical, situational factor (being territorial over food or young, or just scared silly) they just aren't inherently vicious or aggressive toward people. Domesticated animals who aren't used to being handled (such as the two PMU foals I raised and trained while I lived on a small farm) can be dangerous in that they might hurt you if you corner them or they're frightened, but that's because they're trying to escape from you or defend themselves against a perceived attack (and they often don't know their own strength!). So while I'm not much of a dog person and had never owned a pitbull, my reaction when I moved into this house and met my neighbor's dogs was the same as if they'd been any other kind of dog: I just hoped they were used to children and weren't howlers. I knew that dogs were good therapy for sad kids, and after seeing my kids with the therapy dogs at Local Teaching Hospital and reading about how useful companion/therapy dogs can be in helping kids on the autism spectrum overcome sensory and social aversions, I knew I wanted to get my kids a dog someday. They (and Hotter) had been begging for ages, but Middle Child's depression since the Unbloggable Horrors of January came to a head a couple of months ago and convinced me it was time to put "Operation Family Dog" on project status.   As I've mentioned before, bringing a dog into our household wasn't as simple as deciding it was time and loading everyone up to go to the pound, though. With Hotter being on immunosuppressants and Little Child's native immune system being rather puny, I wouldn't feel good about bringing a dog into our home unless I knew it was healthy and not carrying anything that could infect people (such as parvovirus or c. diff), particularly those with weakened immune systems (and any group housing environment with a lot of turnover, from a nursing home to a dogpound, is bound to be a hotbed of contagion). So while I would have preferred to rescue a shelter dog, I was too worried about germs to go that route. I also wanted to get as young a puppy as possible, simply because the younger the animal the blanker the slate, and developmentally-delayed kids (and kids in general, for that matter) aren't great at impulse-control and remembering rules; that could be a recipe for disaster with a dog who'd been traumatized or mistreated by people outside my household and had "triggers" (bad associations to do with things like swinging stick-like objects such as Nerf swords, for example, that might cause them to feel like they needed to behave aggressively in order to protect themselves). If it weren't for the fact that relative amicability with the XY is a recent development and he has a history of trying to take my children from me entirely through false allegations as to their safety (or lack thereof) under my care, I might have been a little less adamant, but that took the whole "blank slate" thing from "probably for the best" to "absolutely mandatory." I couldn't take the risk of having an already sad situation with a scared dog and an injured child cost me several thousand dollars in legal fees and possibly custody of my children (I like to think that a judge would understand that shit happens and trust me to keep it from happening again, but in my experiences family court decisions often have less to do with reality or justice and more to do with who can produce or fabricate the most "evidence" and afford the attorney who will put on the better show in the half-hour the judge spends learning about the situation so I don't assume a danged thing or take any chances).    So I wasn't just looking for a dog, I was looking for a puppy whose history I knew as much as possible about, and preferably of a breed that would be sturdy enough that I wouldn't have to worry too much about the kids accidentally hurting the dog (dachshunds, for example, have very delicate backs and a child leaning on one the wrong way could be expensive at best or tragic at worst). When our neighbor mentioned casually several months ago that he was planning to breed one of his females (a dog I'd met and knew to be friendly and gentle with my children) it was the ideal opportunity for our family. He just happened to breed pitbulls and so that is what we ended up with.   Honestly I didn't even think about "the pitbull thing" when Hotter and I took our puppy to the shopping center; MFA Puppy is MAH BAYBEE (don't tell Hotter I said that; he teases me enough given that I didn't like dogs AT ALL until we got this one "for the kids" -- air quotes because she has decided to be My Dog and I'm secretly thrilled) and who wouldn't love this adorable little biscuit face?
 Figure Two: Doesn't *actually* want to eat your children.   A lot of people, apparently!   The reactions we got tended to be either:   A. "AWWWWS! What kind of dog is she?" and then      1. "Oh I couldn't tell because of the ears" followed by         a. "She's gorgeous! What an unusual color!" or         b. "But she seems so friendly!/I hope you don't also have CHILDREN!/She'll turn on you eventually!"   B. "Is that a pit(bull)?" and then      1. "They're such great dogs/I love pitbulls!"      2. "I wasn't sure because of the ears" and then (A.1.a. or b. or B.1., above)   C. "Ohhh, a pit(bull)!" and then        1. (B.1., above)        2. "I have/had a pit(bull)/s," then "how old is she/can I pet her/(inarticulate babytalk)"        3. (A.1.b., above)   or   D. "OMG A BLUE PIT, WOW, SHE'S GORGEOUS!" and then      1. (C.2., above)    Hotter even had a little old lady come up to him while he and MFA Puppy were sitting outside of P.F. Chang's (where I was getting takeout for our dinner) and ask about the dog, then turn very chilly when her companion noted how friendly the puppy was and say "Sure, for NOW!" Hotter took umbrage at that, but said he refrained from comment because the companion immediately said what I usually say ("They act how you treat 'em") and looked ashamed. I'm kind of glad I wasn't there for that because I might not have had his restraint!   All in all it was an eye-opening experience, and I guess "the pitbull issue" will only get worse as MFA Puppy gets bigger and less adorable in the eyes of the general public. I was interested to note that the uncropped ears totally threw most people who were anti-pitbull (some were already cooing and fawning over the puppy when they asked what kind of dog she was and seemed rather nonplussed to find that they were patting an OMGPITBULL, and I like that some of them recovered from their shock to say that they didn't know pitbulls could be so SWEET or ask questions that showed genuine interest in learning more about them) or just unfamiliar with the breed. I also found it interesting (and sadly, not surprising) that it was mostly white people who were clueless as to what sort of dog we had and/or anti-pitbull (the shopping center is located in an affluent part of town and the shops are pretty upscale for the most part, so there were more WASPS than we usually run across in our neighborhood, where we are one of only two white families). The whole experience made me both sad and COMPLETELY FARKING DETERMINED that MY pitbull? Will be THE BESTEST DOG EVAR. The "therapy dog" thing is no longer something I might do for the kids' sake, it's something I'm DAMNED WELL GOING TO DO to help show people that pitbulls are, like any other dog, very pleasant to be around when they're well-trained.   Because, you know, I didn't have enough things in my life (autism spectrum disorders, adaptive medical equipment, blended families) to feel passionate about demystifying in the eyes of strangers (so that they'll quit being afraid of/ignorant about them and acting like assholes).    Just for the heck of it, if you wouldn't mind, could you leave me a comment and let me know whether you a) would be more cautious around a pitbull than another breed of dog (and if so, why) or b) wouldn't be any more or less cautious around a pitbull than any other breed of dog? Thanks!
title: "is that a pitbull?"

body:
Dear [redacted - I know your names but have more class than to publish them],   Long time no see! I was beginning to feel unloved, but thankfully you knew that filtering your last e-mail address in G-mail, reporting your activities to the IC3 (report #I0911242345379791 from November of last year and #I1007312129083222 from today), and sending your blog comments to spam was really just my way of playing hard to get. Now that you've proven you're truly my NUMBER ONE FAN I'm going to go and carve our initials into a special tree out back!   I could point out the ridiculousness of accusing someone of having an obsessive and disordered personality via "anonymous" harassment coming from a webmail address consisting of their maiden name, current last name, and blog names strung together, but it would probably go right over your head. I hear you when you say I use too many words, and I don't want to confuse you, so I'll say this very simply:Get a life, and get over your unhealthy fixation surrounding me and mine.   There, you can stop reading now if you want (well, you don't need my permission; like everyone else reading this you have the option to simply close the window and rather than say I'm writing the rest of this for me I'll just point out that, duh, I'm writing this whole blog for me, obviously).   All kidding aside, I know you like to troll my blog and e-mail me before major events (everything from holidays 
to my wedding day to BlogHer) and wasn't really surprised to hear from 
you. You've made me take a long, hard look at a lot of the things that I
 do, a lot of the relationships I've had, and what I choose to share 
about my life online, and for that I should probably thank you. You've 
helped me learn to spot and avoid toxic personalities and risky 
situations, and recognize dysfunctional behaviors (in myself as well as 
others, contrary to your repeated claims to the contrary I'm not 
laboring under the delusion that I'm perfect), and kept me from posting 
enough to let unsavory types who'd do more than just harass me via blog 
comments and anonymous e-mails know how to find me and my family. So in a
 way you've helped me to become a safer, more compassionate, and savvier
 individual, and I honestly can't say I regret knowing you.   I can, however, say that it's time for both of us to stop thinking about this. I'm not going to stop enjoying the holidays, forging and maintaining relationships with other mentally stable adults who share my interests, attending social gatherings, or blogging here, and I'm also not going to turn my blog into an ongoing dialog with you. I'm sorry things between us didn't go as you hoped they would; I'm not thrilled with how it went down either but you don't see me devoting years of my life to dwelling on it. I've reported your most recent communications to the IC3, Google (since as I said, your new G-mail address, which I've set a new filter for, consists of my rather unique maiden, married, and blog names combined), and BlogHer (since the organizers of the conference deserve to know that someone is threatening criminal acts at their event), and I'm done. I wish you luck in finding the peace that will allow you to move on from this someday as well, because that's so much nicer than trying to fan life back into the ashes of what was, trust me.                                                                                                      Ruefully, MFA Mama

The baby potatoes are poking up through the loose composted leaves around them, fourteen at last count, my six kinds of beans are flourishing since I Sevined the chewing insects into submission (the guy at the greenhouse made these greenhouse jazz hands in diagnosing "chewing insects" and it was awesome), baby peas are coming up y'all, so adorable, like clover, our cucumber vines are climbing eagerly up the decorative cast-iron pillar next to their half-barrel, tied with Surgilast, which is great stuff for training green vines...I'm gardening out my anger shoes and our corn here is as tall as a small cat and the sunflowers just reached one foot high.  Baby spinach in our salad NEXT WEEK, people, this is exciting stuff!  Hotter's cauliflower bed is coming along nicely too, and our cedar-box porch watermelons are taking off, as are the baby dill, basil, cilantro, and leeks.  Radishes shortly after the spinach and more peas and some carrots sprouting in pots with cherry tomatoes.     This isn't a post about garden porn, though, it's an introduction.   There is a toad that is stalking me, y'all.  Hotter likes toads, he says toads in the garden are good luck.  I don't like or dislike toads exactly but would prefer not to touch one and this one in particular has been coming up onto the PORCH, people, the PORCH, and surprising the bejesus out of me.  I think he's pissed because I caught him once in a bucket, the first time we saw him, all "look boys, a toad!"
  Figure One: I need to feed this mofo a Timex or something.  He's totes all "TickTock, MFA Mama!"   Never piss off a toad, people, because this little mofo has mad ninja skills and he was springing up over the lid of the MFA Mop Bucket, which has successfully contained skinks, snakes, and every foul insect known to MFA, and he emitted a terrifying war-squeak as he did so.  Hotter was moved to pity but I took this in the spirit the toad meant it: he is coming for me and he will follow me to the end of one of our days.   I see him every night now.  He likes to hop around the cauliflower bed.  Hotter, the only one in the house who is truly passionate about cauliflower, says he's keeping guard, but I know better and now so do you.  That's the face to look for if anything happens to me.  Learn it.

body: *   Last night things looked bad.  VERY bad.  Hotter was satting in the low nineties on six liters of humidified oxygen, CT scans were showing possible fluid build-up around the donor kidney, and he sounded...well, I'll spare him a public sharing of the details, but he sounded awful, y'all.*   I made myself a stiff drink and went to bed, where for the first time in almost a week I slept eight hours straight.*   While I was passed out, Hotter was getting his act together in a big way over at Local Teaching Hospital; last night's MRI showed NO fluid around the kidney, decreased fluid around the liver (to the point where they're no longer worried about that), and he is now OFF oxygen support entirely (with a pulse ox of 95, which isn't great but is better than he was managing on an arse-load of oxygen yesterday).*   At this point he is still there because a) they want to see how it goes when he eats something, which aside from some ramen on Sunday he hasn't really done since Thursday and b) before they have him eat something, they want to do a few more tests including an ultrasound of his abdomen, because when one of their peeps falls apart in such spectacular fashion the transplant team likes to leave no stone unturned (for which I applaud them--I want ANSWERS and when I do bring Hotter back home I want to feel reasonably certain he won't pull another boomerang on us and have to go right back in via the godawful Local Teaching Hospital ER).*   If today's test results are all good, Hotter is hoping they'll send him home tomorrow.  He sounded crabby and rather put out about being at Club Med today, which is always a good sign.*   I haven't been able to find it in myself to care about this even a little bit until today, but right before Hotter went back in-patient my lodging arrangements for BlogHer kind of fell apart, and apparently that trusting the universe thing is still crap if you're me.  The universe is still a cunt.  So please let me know if you need a roommate (I'm fine with sharing a bed or hell, I'll sleep on the floor!), and also let me know if you're trying to acquire a full conference pass, because I'm starting to think my getting to BlogHer this year is a lost cause (dammit).*   My mother-in-law.  Lord, y'all.  The very least I can say about her right now is that she promised Hotter she'd come down here to see him, but then remembered that it's been 6,000 miles since her last oil change, refused to let Loud and Crazy (my brother-in-law) change her oil (which he is perfectly capable of doing, mind you, it's not that he isn't), and then refused to let Loud and Crazy take her car to Big and Scary (my other brother-in-law, who is a professional mechanic) and let HIM do it, and that is her official reason for not coming to visit her son in ICU: she is overdue for an oil change.  Discuss!ETA: Well, shit y'all.  I just spoke with one of the surgeons and the chief radiologist reviewed Hotter's MRI from last night and determined that they ARE concerned about the fluid around the liver, it has NOT decreased (although it has also not INCREASED dramatically, which is kind of the best possible worst-case scenario), and it is, in fact, bile.  Which is undesirable to have leaking in your abdominal cavity.  They're leaving him NPO and doing an ERCP this afternoon to figure out whether the bile is coming from one of the ducts they clipped during surgery or from the liver itself (which is what they currently suspect).  If that is in fact the case they're going to have to open his incision back up, wash him out, possibly do some minor repairs, and place a drain.  He is NOT coming home tomorrow but at least they're closer to figuring this out?
title: Hotter and BlogHer and in-laws, oh my! [ETA: now with update]

body: Y'all probably didn't notice, but I am running our first-ever MFA Contest over on the Twitter.   Also I watered and seeded, pruned and sprayed, filled the bird's and snakes' water dishes, and got kids down for a nap, then told Hotter what I thought of some things.  I wore my anger shoes like a big girl after handing him his own damn-hellsakes Valium because if he's going to go and have a seizure or a gallbladder attack stomping around outside with garden tools I'm going to have a clean conscience about having stalked away from him.   I didn't mention it before, but yeah right before the gallbladder attack?  I stood up to him when he was angry.  And while he didn't exactly bust me in the mouth like he did when he had the seizure, it was ugly afterward, but up until someone needed IV access it was a breakthrough moment.  Ha!  So this time I upped the ante and got heated my own self and even made dismissive hand gestures of smallness in going full ad-hominem.     If you'll excuse me, I'm going to go out there with a bottle of water for him and make sure he's okay and then if he his Imma tell him to eat a bag of dicks.  Wish us luck!

body:
Big Child knew the entire alphabet by the time he was eleven 
months old.  I didn't even think about it much one way or the other 
until Hotter was asking me why Big Child is such a mama's boy and the 
other two are such alpha males and I said I'd stayed home with baby Big 
Child just to supervise his emotional and intellectual development 
because he was Big-brain Superchild, truly something special.  We'd been
 talking (okay, I'd been waxing emo while he patiently listened) about 
the boys as babies, and things I hoped to show him if the XY does in 
fact return my family pictures as has recently been proposed via Mr. 
Family Therapist.     I had kind of just given up on ever seeing 
myself or either of my older children as babies ever again because 
believe it or not I was slow to embrace digital and well, as my attorney
 growled, rolling his eyes and chortling a bit when I told him the XY 
had snatched those from the marital home during a police-supervised 
break-in of sorts, "oh atta boy!  That's really nice."  
Lately I've allowed myself to imagine the hilarity I might show Hotter 
in MFA Historical Occasions (such as an incredibly intricate Hannukah 
cake I made one year that no one ate because they were all burying a dog
 outside in stormy weather under a big oak tree in the middle of wooded 
or enclosed for livestock nowhere and damn that was a nice cake 
but did anyone appreciate my efforts?  Pfft) that I attempted to 
document only the good snippets from and well, anyway, I can laugh now.  
 There's also the possibility of saying, offhand, to my gawking husband,
 "Oh yes Big Child was really something else as a baby and toddler," in 
remembering the wall with Big Child's heights marked off in the former 
family home of many year, our grudging little farm, on the pantry door 
just visible in the pictures of that masterpiece of a cake.  The true 
mindfuck of particular subtypes I won't name of some specific autism
 spectrum disorders is that your child develops just fine up to a 
point, and often better than fine, but then they just, well, don't 
anymore.  Hotter, being an honest, average member of the community who 
is not intolerant of little boys with issues but uneducated in many of 
the specifics of those issues because he doesn't know anyone affected, 
at least as far as he knows, exclaimed with obvious confusion and 
concern, "what happened?"   Big Child is a good kid, a 
real sweetheart.  All of my boys are.  I may occasionally refer to us going to family therapy, and even of one 
child particular making a nonspecified bad choice, possibly with a soupçon
 of exasperation if I'm really het up, but they're good kids.  I was
 just marveling at the fact that I now have a nine-year-old and I have 
not yet had anyone get a black eye from a playmate, get in trouble at 
school, light anything on fire, swear out loud (except on Festivus) or 
perform any acts of intersibling heinousness necessitating medical 
intervention.  I talk to other people about their kids (many of whom are
 also really good kids, I am not saying a kid isn't if they've done any 
or all of the things I mentioned, just trying to convey a mental picture
 for y'all of what my particular good kids are like and not like) and 
used to find myself saying "I hope none of mine will do that when they 
get older," but now my oldest and middle children are actually older 
than the children from a lot of these anecdotes, especially now that Big
 Child is now nine.  I was a good kid at the same age but, well. 
 My own nine-year-old has never (at least as far as I know from my 
custodial time of him) operated a lighter or book of matches, fetched a 
beer or rolled a joint for a parent, or had unsupervised access to a 
remote control and a TV where Cinemax will pop up and I count myself 
lucky that I as their mother and Hotter as their stepfather are on the 
same page in wanting to raise these boys better than either of us were 
raised ourselves.   I don't know that the above paragraph 
contributes to what I'm trying to tell y'all except to perhaps indicate 
how defensive and guilty I feel about some of the disabling conditions 
that affect my children.  This isn't because any of those conditions are
 the result of wrongdoing or lack of medical diligence on my part, but 
simply because I guess I don't want anyone to see my child as less-than,
 or if they do, to think that I agree with them in any way, shape or 
form.  Big Child now struggles with things he seemed proficient at early
 in life.  When there's nothing but a syndrome or phrase of latinate 
obfuscation to offer yourself or anyone else by way of explanation for 
something about your child that clearly deviates quite a lot from the 
norm, a lot of folks look at you the same way you yourself looked at 
some of the professionals who educated you on the same things: like 
you're saying Harry Potter himself put several curses on the kid and 
you're waiting for Hermione Granger to figure out how to undo them.    
 So anyway yes, all of my children have difficulties that I've had to 
learn about in order to be a good advocate and caregiver, and in the 
absence of any family members I've had to explain my kids' conditions to
 I haven't discussed many of them out loud with anyone I cared deeply 
for (I mean, I love some of my kids' doctors, nurses, therapists and 
teachers, don't get me wrong, but just not like that) since the MFA 
Starter Marriage fell apart, and in discussing a lot of this stuff with 
Hotter I've relived a lot of unpleasant memories and had to look closely
 at some ongoing worries, and I'm halfway tempted to tell the XY he can 
keep the bloody pictures.  

   I try to do a good job of talking about the happy and the silly 
and the deadpan-serious on here, and want to also tell you how Ourtown 
got a new and rather kickass radio station that has this vintage 
historical name and awesome streaming radio, and get my crackberry back 
up and running so that I can show you some true garden porn, but right 
before I mowed the front yard yesterday that is the conversation I had 
with my beloved about one of my sweet boys and it wasn't the type I'd 
typically share.  Too close to home.  But yeah, this too.     They're growing up fast.  Which is what I should have said at HP this month but tempus fugit whether you have any fun or not, like procreative sex or zeroes in attorneys' fees, yes it do, and sometimes it's downright rude about it.
title: Big Child and the beanstalks

body:
Last night Hotter had a bad case of the "nothing-to-eats," which is easy to do here at Casa MFA because honestly, most of the time?  We have our AngelFoodMinistries box, we have meats and frozen veggies purchased on sale to defrost, we have a smattering of fresh veggies and we have pasta, rice, beans and flour.  Snack foods are only for the boys' school snacks and lately I'm sending them with lame-ish snacks because cool snack food gets hoovered up at home.  If your palate years for more than cheese and crackers or perhaps a bagel, and wants it fast, you generally end up with a spoonful of peanut butter and "Angry, Lonely, or Tired" to choose from if you're still feeling froggy; we're not addicts here but H.A.L.T. is what winners do, see?   Winners here were "angry" all around last night, due to Things Not To Be Mentioned On The Innernet and surgi-macallit-itis and, well, MY BAGGAGE surrounding both those topics, and also apparently during four specific days of the month and 
occasionally when I'm just REALLY het up (see archives from February 
onward) my blood pressure is going to be all ridic, and I'm going to 
have to start running again, which I wanted to do anyway, and do more 
yoga and maybe cut back on salt but shh...         Marx Fine Foods in Bulk to the rescue!  Seriously, I keep meaning to do up a real post all fancy-like for these folks, because Justin?  Is the man, not just a CEO but also a totally nice guy who is knowledgeable about his wares in a way that's niche-market HAWT!  Let's just say that when he used "umami-ful" in a sentence Hotter was lucky that I am as faithful as an old hound, y'all, because Justin not only TALKED about these salts, sugars, chilis and vanilla beans with me, he also SENT ME FREE SAMPLES AND OH MY GOD HE'S BETTER THAN SANTA, JESUS, AND ELIJAH THE PROPHET COMBINED!   It is nothing short of amazing how a pinch of habanero salt or crystallized honey in the right spot can brighten an entire snack, meal, celebratory confection or ripely foul mood.  Seriously.  So here is what I made last night for Hotter as cheap, tasty, soothing "filler" so that he has something in the fridge to be sneaking tastes out of and doesn't open up and waste a can of specialty veg I'm saving for stir fry or anything out of boredom (alas, pickled baby corn, we hardly knew ye).      You will need:   Implements of Destruction   medium saucepan with lid   set of nesting measuring spoons   measuring cup (you'll need a half-cup and a full-cup at various points)   ladle   Pyrex pie plate (the oven-safe kind)   stirring spoon   a butterknife or pointy-ended spoon      Ingredients   1 c. aromatic basmati rice (the kind you buy in a burlap bag with a cock or an elephant on the side)(I said cock, y'all), pre-rinsed TWICE   1.5 c. milk (I used one percent because it's what we had, subbing out a higher percent milkfat or part heavy cream would tip this more toward "dessert" than "snack/breakfast")   1 can coconut milk (the kind that's half oil anyway)   1 tbsp. butter   2 large eggs   1 tbsp. granulated maple sugar   1 tbsp. vanilla sugar   1 "snack-pack"-size box of raisins   1/2 tsp. cinnamon   1 jot nutmeg (seriously, way less than 1/8 tsp, just a hint)   1/2 Tahitian Vanilla bean   1 pinch Black Truffle Salt1.   Put the rice (which you pre-rinsed, yes?) in the saucepan with the butter and the milk and turn it up to medium while you add the sugar, raisins, cinnamon, nutmeg, salt, and the guts from the half vanilla bean (I found that the Madagascar ones, which are actually my favorites, were a bit too powerful for this dish--I was trying to create something reminiscent of morning oatmeal here but less dairy-y due to someone's potassium issues and the Tahitians were exactly what this needed) and stir it halfheartedly in between.  2.   Put your vanilla bean husk away in your sugar jar and top that off as needed after you add the tbsp to your pan.  Turn the oven on to 350 while you're at it.3.   Open the coconut milk and dump that on top, then grease your Pyrex pie plate while you wait for the "milk" to scald (you're looking for steam and little bubbles collecting around the edges but not actual boiling-boiling).  Once that happens, whisk the eggs in and remove from heat.4.   Place the Pyrex plate in the oven empty, then use your ladle to transfer the rice mixture to it (it should juuuust fit but trust me you'd spill if you filled it first, you know you would); it should juuuust fit.5.   Bake at 350 for forty-five minutes while you cuss and pull weeds outside.  When the timer goes off, use a butterknife to test for done-ness and possibly to gouge out a core sample while the rest cools off.  Mmmn.   I have a headache now.  I'm supposed to be staying in here playing possum until "Mother's Day Breakfast" but Hotter hasn't even done the dishes and I already had some rice pudding so maybe that can count as breakfast?  JUST LET ME OUT, YOU GUYS, AND THAT WILL BE SPECIAL ENOUGH AT THIS POINT!
title: comfort food the Marks Fine Foods in bulk way

body: Two things that are utterly untrue, because no I di'int:I.   I was going to tell y'all how this morning I realized that oh my goodness, my husband and I have become pet people and I've gone all soft and zen-like.  I know this because I woke up to pee off some diuretic at about 6:00 a.m. and rather than go back to bed (the only way I am guaranteed to sleep enough to be functional before the alarm goes off two hours later) I turned the heat on.   Our thermostat allows you to set a minimum temperature if the heat is on or a maximum temperature if the air conditioning is on, and the weather here is bipolar right now.  It'll be in the low fifties the night after a low-nineties day and Hotter is a Damn Yankee and of the constitution not to use climate control unless it's truly righteous (it's the Dutch/Lutheran in him, dang it) to do so.  This would aggravate me more were I not cheap/green and so the MFA Children all have robes or fuzzy blankets as is age- or developmentally-appropriate and I draw the line at leaving windows open even a crack due to security concerns but it can get a bit chilly of a morning.     Except as Hotter said when he welcomed me back to bed and let me warm my chilly haunches on his body "I'm glad you did that, the two cold-blooded animals and the tropical bird were probably not too happy" and I said "yep, probably they were out there going 'y'all can eat a BIG bag of dicks'" and we giggled a little.II.Representative from Hencefore-Unnamed major insurance company whose HMO subsidizes Medicare: Hello, wel--Representative from other department of Henceforth "H.U.M.&etc.": I have MFA Mama here, she's Hotter Lastname's wife and apparently [truncated for brevity and anonymity]MFA Mama: Yes but what I am needing YOU to hear is that someone at H.U.M.&etc. has got to take ownership of your collective errors, whether that is you or you have to escalate this further via another warm transfer RIGHT NOW I am going to have to spend two thousand dollars in the next twenty-four hours to either purchase out of pocket drugs H.U.M.&etc. is supposed to cover through a federally-funded healthcare program that my disabled husband needs to survive or else on suing y'all in small claims court, and I know that even an expedited emergency hearing in small claims court wouldn't fix this in time for it to not become a wrongful death suit but that's ten hours of attorney's fees I can spend for my guy to guarantee you reimburse those fees in addition to any eventual settlement because that's one of two prescriptions like that he's going to need and he'll die and I don't have four thousand dollars to save his life now but I do have ten hours of noise I can make if you and I don't rectify this TODAY in a manner so as to allow H.U.M.&etc. to deliver the care and coverage my husband deserves and that your company promises directly, me to save that two thousand dollars for feeding my family, and y'all to save yourselves the headache of letting an administrative foul-up kill my husband, because I will outlive this gaffe on your part and I am the one of us you have to be afraid of since I have a lot of years of anger issues still left in me! [pauses to inhale briefly]  Let's both let him live to play good cop another day, shall we?"   So maybe not, maybe not.  Hotter and Mr. Family Therapist keep comparing me to Stalin and Mussolini lately and I'm not any happier so I don't know about this whole "embrace your war face and show people the crazy eye without smiling" thing.  So far I've gotten as far as the first part but I'm still smiling and probably sounded to that H.U.M.&etc. rep like a cheerleading coach and my husband is avoiding me after having heard the entire exchange.  Phooey.
title: Not Me Monday, the soft and hard

body: "That sounds like a first-world problem" is my way of ending a discussion with my children who are being unreasonably demanding as to what they ought to play with next or who should put that in, etc.  So many of our problems here are, and we know that, down to the four-year-old.  We are grateful to have drinkable water both for well, drinking/cooking/mixing the four-year-old's formula feedings and also ant-walking one purple watering-canful at a time to my vegetables.     Sometimes when I say it I'm being facetious but I do take levels of privilege into account in results of similar activities at a pioneer subsistance level and was discussing privilege-based vs. survivalist horticulture/agriculture with the husband as well--our germination rates aren't just better than we remember our mothers' germination rates being, even if our mothers had green thumbs and good soil and indisputable superiority in their respective heydays, they're better because we're grownups who learned to garden as poor kids using better seedstock.  My garden isn't ridiculous because our soil is good or my anger shoes never too worn to garden in, it's ridiculous because I still plant "one for the rook, one for the crow, one to die, and one to grow" as my mother did, and her great aunt, and my maternal grandmother's entire immigrant family but hardly anything dies and the birds don't mess with MY stuff (because it's right around our front porch by high-peopletraffic spaces).   So it is a first-world problem, my not being able to work on my crops tonight on the basis of poor health, and yet I am taking it very hard.  Hotter is being swell about it.  I love that man.  We of course kissed and made up because we weren't fighting over who did which dishes, we were fighting because I felt that his health was going to tank but had decided not to say anything and he had decided the same thing and taken the same course.  We now know that when one of us is a jerk the other needs to figure out what the jerk is covering up with their jerkishness.  Personally I hide my blood pressure lately, a lot.  There is a total double standard in this house on that, by the way, and we have a two-user machine with separate memory lists, and hmph, it's giving me warnings lately.  Stupid thing.  I could dig the SHIT out of a trench but gave Hotter the spare and everyday keys to the toolshed and the MFA Minivan until my BP is down in the "normal" range and my heartrate is lower than that of, say, a neonate.   Also by making that about me and my stupid case of the vapours I distracted Hotter from the whole "oh look my wife is putting away and locking up our outdoor tools and stocking the pets up on food and water and randomly organizing the medicine cabinet into see-through totes because of my surgi-macallit-itis thing and the fact that she's worried I'll have a seizure, it's almost like she's getting ready to ta--"   See right there?  Y'all only got that far because I didn't involve the webcam but that is pretty much when I make a gesture so crude you've only ever seen another woman make it to a woman without getting rebuffed and reprimanded and they were both drunk at the time, like THAT kind of nasty, anything to keep my husband from realizing that while I have pledged to respect his wishes on hospital or home while his doctors are okay with that but only if he allows me to care for him in a way that will either work for him here or indicate that he's faltering here.  He needs hydration, supervision of his meds in general while he's on strong painkillers for the surgi-macallit-itis and really he needs surgery, but can't have that until probably the week after next and boo.  Still, we know what's wrong with him, we know it's fixable, we're just holding out for the best way to treat such a procedure and the right surgeons on board and this is, well, down to and including my ability to predict this hot mess by dint of working at home and being with my husband at all times this is a first-world problem.   But dang if it isn't unpleasant to me here and there and then and now.   Whatever.
title: first-world problems

body: *   Last night Hotter was in horrible pain, and he finally asked me to take him to the ER so you know it was bad.  I dropped my husband off, tracked the XY down (on a date, the poor bastard) and dumped the three over-tired MFA Children on him, and doubled back to the ER.*   Hotter's white count was trending upward, a CT-scan revealed a pocket of fluid where they operated, and while we were waiting he spiked a temp, so they admitted him.*   Currently he's in the Transplant ICU with O2 sats in the low nineties despite six liters of humidified oxygen and doped up on a morphine PCA.  The nurse still described him as "miserable" when I called to check a moment ago.*   Yes, I had to leave him there, which I hate, hate, hate, because the XY missed work again and was not pleased (although the displeasure of the newly personality-transplanted, post-alien-abduction XY is prefaced by genuine-sounding inquiries into how Hotter is faring and how I'm holding up, and I may have been hallucinating from exhaustion at one point today but I'm pretty sure that part was real).*   So I came home this morning, but then the XY didn't actually return the children after all, and I don't even care because I really needed to sleep and did in fact crash hard after fourteen hours of sleep in ninety-six hours.*   Don't even ask me how I am, because hell if I know besides "abjectly fucking grateful my shrink doubled the antidepressant last time I saw him, because damn."   *   Infection in a transplant patient on immunosuppressive drugs is bad though, and most of the really strong antibiotics that treat things that pop up while someone is already on Cipro post-op are hard on the kidneys even if you have two factory-original ones, and well, shit, I think my feelings are hungry for another box of Jalapeno poppers and half a bottle of ranch dressing and an ice-cream sandwich and some pretzels with cheese.  Also it would be very nice if the puppy was already here so I could snuggle with her.  The bird is happy to let me scratch her head for as long as I'd like but draws the line at spooning.  So that's how I am I guess.
title: ungood

body:
Acute surgi-ma-callit-itis.     But hey at least I mowed an
 acre of semi-wooded--meh, screw it I smiled when Hotter admitted he'd also forgotten his blood pressure medication because after the last time I'd had Dr. Kidney's NP overhead paged so that she could assure me that's never overly dramatic ever and confessed to not bugging him for eating salty guacamole on Cinco de Mayo I hadn't let Murphy drive, as one of you termed it.     The anger thing is mere correlation, one of you say it for me, okay, please?  Because when I try I just tend to smile grimly and bake things from scratch since I can't garden or mow, and clean the bathroom, and repair home electronics and say absolutely nothing, just in case.
title: the it's good to be right redux

body:
*   It stormed off and on all weekend here.  In between storms it was hot like the wrath of an angry Old Testament god, which I said and Hotter, who was raised with the New Testament only was all "why, is the Old Testament god of the Hebrews kind of harsh?" and HAHAHAHAHA!  I told him "mmmmyeah y'know how Jesus was all healing little birds and doing parlor tricks at weddings?  Well, Yahweh was like "wander in the desert for forty years and make your camp under this motherfucking pillar of fire at night or else I will SMITE YOU!"  Ha!  So yeah the weather was more like that.*   This has evidently become A Cursing Blog.  I kept meaning to go all meta about that but tell me, what do you think?  I suck with polls and the like but do you a) not notice, b) notice but not care, c) notice and care in a good or bad way, d) pretty much hate it and think I need to shut my Playboy mouth again?  I suppose if any of you are fellow pedants you could also e) feel that it represents a blight upon my etymological creativity that indicates bad things or f) find it heartening in that apparently my heart and mind are more connected given that my lexicon has shaken its hair down out of the bun and undone a button at the top of its blouse.  Personally I just kind of felt like I had Hit a Limit after Hotter's acute attack of surgi-ma-callititis and our visit to That Awful Hospital.*   Hotter had another big attack on Thursday, and a smallish one yesterday, and oh I cannot WAIT for him to Have His Procedures.  Oh yes, we have Been To The Doctor and I didn't say much about it but they pretty much said "this doesn't present like textbook surgi-ma-callititis" and I pretty much went "but his abdominal architecture has been so remodeled at this point and blah blah referred pain when the radiologist [...]" and they were like "but people can live with that for xx years and never--" and I reminded them that Hotter is immunosuppressed and opined that it might be preferable for them to do this NOW instead of when he goes SEPTIC and they conceded that I had a good point and planned an open, non-laparoscopic procedure for that surgi-ma-callititis but were still concerned about strictures or adhesions on the small bowel being The Root of What Ails Him and Medicare not liking "exploratory surgery" and I very sweetly suggested that they could declare this Surgi-ma-callitits Proper seeing as it met the criteria for atypical cases, perform the appropriate -ectomy, and then "run the bowel" while they're in there and have a look at that as well, since I was sure NONE of us wanted to submit his kidney to CT contrast and they had SUCH good eyes and hands I was sure...so yes, reason prevailed and the current plans are to open him up, treat this as surgi-ma-callititis, examine two hernias from within (both from major surgeries, not the uh, turn-your-head-and-cough kind, I feel I should specify for the sake of Hotter's Manliness On Record) and repair at least one, and run the bowel as best they can since part of it is attached to a graft that nobody wants to disturb.*   Hotter and I are pleased with this decision.  Neither of us are fully convinced that this is Surgi-ma-callititis Proper but both of us are convinced that this is A Surgical Issue and that the transplant surgeons need to Exorcise The Demon.  Because no one is at their best when they're in abdominal agony but that gets old for the spouse almost as quickly as it gets old for the sufferer, particularly if the non-suffering spouse is really quite fond of the affected spouse and shares their distress even before the affected party begins expressing any...feelings.*   Family therapy, y'all.  Oh man.  It continues to be a motherfucker.*   Had a bit of a breakthrough (breakdown, same diff) as to Why All The
 Angry Feelings of Anger and Angry-ness and fear of same, and it made me sad.  It's good I
 know where my pique is coming from now, and I'm working on learning to 
express it.  This weekend, in the heat of the moment, I deliberately 
watered Hotter's (actual, literal) shoes with my soaker-can.  So I'm uh,
 still working on the whole "appropriate expression of" thing and it's 
fortunate that Hotter just cracked up laughing and was like "you watered
 my shoes, is someone feeling some anger, maybe?"  I replied that 
perhaps I was, and watered his shoes again.*   I continue to garden out my Anger Shoes.  This weekend saw the relocation of a grave-sized strip of sod (which became a bed for sweet corn and peas, yes, more, and some intercropped carrots and iceberg lettuce), the ruthless pruning of pretty much every big, thorny, spiky, or just all-around bushy bush surrounding our little house (surprisingly many), thinning, weeding and spraying of all existing plants (with paraffin against mites and fungus, bloom-boosting hormone, and Sevin on non-leaf crops without any seed or fruit forming if they're getting demolished--judge away but while I prefer organic methods, in the end I'm going with What Will Make Us Lots of Food), and lots of raking up and watering.  *   This purging of undergrowth did not stop my nemesis from paying me a visit one evening on the front porch while I was a little bit inebriated.  It was so...well, anyway...that I'm holding the story back for a proper post of its own (do any of you know how to make a GIF like the Hillary Duff BJ one?  Don't act like you haven't seen it, unless you really haven't in which case go and ask YouTube, but if you know how to do that could you educate me please?  Thanks).*   Oh and that Levaquin I'm taking for my Clusterfuck-itis of the Upper Respiratory/ENT virus of filth and secondary infections?  Those big warning labels all over the bottle about sun exposure?  SO NOT KIDDING.  I'm awfully prone to heatstroke anyway and even with SPF 60 and a bandanna, etc. I got a case of true heatstroke (the kind where you stop sweating), which I've had before, and had the sense to down a bottle of water then heave myself into the tub and turn the cold tap on with the shower running before I passed out.  When I came to I knew I'd be okay because I started realizing how it would look to paramedics and sheepishly shucked off my clothes, washed my hair, and eventually stood up and went about my business all casual-like (Hotter was recovering from an attack and some residual feeeeelings and unaware why I charged into the house; he's used to my zipping around in and out banging the door like an obnoxious kid when the MFA Children are away).  Also I do not have a burn, per se, thanks to excellent sunblock, but my skin does have that tight "eh, too much sun" feeling, which I hate.*   The pet snakes are ridiculous.  The worm snake is great but the rat snake is a wimp and I had to force-feed him for the SECOND time (he's doing SO much better now though), plus now we have a mouse that was supposed to be for the rat snake but it made friends with the stupid thing and then Hotter named it.  Bah, grumble.  I should've known the moment I said I didn't care whether they gave me a male or a female one at the pet shop and watched them drop a smelly male mouse into the cardboard box that it would live to stink up my house for years to come.  Grr...*   Also?  Chickens.  We're getting some.  I know!  I owe you garden porn and you'll see why this is not at all over the top...also I grew up with chickens that laid excellent brown eggs and want my boys to experience that, too.  Plus apparently I've lost my mind.  Still, look.  Awww...we're getting some of these because as I recall they're very sweet if you handle them a lot as chicks and lay well.*   We picked up our second AngelFoodMinistries order this weekend too, and it's fabulous.  We've eaten well; I swear it feels like we lived a whole week just this one weekend, good and bad and everything in between.  Maybe it's the fever?*   And how are all of YOU?
title: partly cloudy with a chance of bullets

body: This is still just a placeholder, and I have loads to tell you about in-laws and MFA Puppy and the children and life, but am about to pass the fuck out.  I wanted to let everyone know first, though, that Hotter surprised the entire transplant team by getting his shit together and not requiring the second surgery, to the point that this afternoon they let me take him home.  I have only JUST NOW stopped running around like a crazy person, because I had to hand the MFA Children over to the pleasant clone of the XY the aliens left us, and go back to the hospital and sleep a little bit, and then pack Hotter up for discharge this morning, bring him home, pick up four different prescriptions from two different pharmacies and do a bunch of catch-up watering and mowing, and then we had a late dinner featuring mashed red potatoes and green beans from the garden, and now we're getting ready for an early bedtime.  Utter physical and emotional exhaustion has NEVER FELT SO GOOD and also I may have had a couple of adult beverages, because, well, obviously.   It'd be alright with me if shit stopped happening so fast for a bit now, how about you?
title: home

body: I didn't want y'all to worry, so here I am, waving not drowning, but righteously pissed off.   My Blackberry finally died an ignoble death the day of Hotter's emergency surgery, the moment I answered the call from the surgeon after the procedure and before I found out if he was dead or alive.  I should have thrown it but instead tried small-electronics CPR (repeated reboots, plugging in, etc.) and finally had to give it up as a bad job.  Boo!  I may go throw it now, in fact--REST IN PIECES, BIATCH!   Then three days ago my laptop installed a new Windows update and lost the ability to connect to the innernet completely (not even with a cable!) and I dug out Big Child's laptop and it worked UNTIL I shut it down, then it downloaded the Update of Doom as well and shit the bed just like mine.   Hotter's machine remained unscathed, because he has XP.  Arsehole.  And of course I can't get on The Beast for even a moment, because that is HIS, and He Just Had Surgery or somesuch.  Whatever, Hotter!   I've only just now managed to uninstall the update and undue the carnage it wrought on my machine, and of course now I just feel like taking a damn nap, but I wanted to let you know that we are all home and together and afebrile, so overall it's still a good day.  How are YOU?
title: in which I am supremely aggravated but we are otherwise fine

body:
I have no earthly idea what is going on, although my best guess would be
 that last 
week's "Hail Mary" emergency procedure has, in fact, failed as 
everyone predicted.  The other possibility would be that the 
surgi-ma-callit-ectomy was not the "fix" for these recurrent bouts of 
horrid epigastric pain Hotter's been having, and we're back to the 
drawing board entirely on that (the surgeons' best guess as to what 
they'd need to do if Hotter still had more attacks involved cutting him 
from hipbone to hipbone, removing loads of adhesions, and installing 
some synthetic material to hold his guts together so honestly I'm rather
 HOPING the Hail Mary has failed).  Either way, after spending much of the night awake either whimpering (him) or fetching pain pills and threatening to call an ambulance (me), I ended up saying to Hotter what we always say when one of us is headed to the ER or the OR:   "Be good.  NO DYING!"   The paramedics got a kick out of that, but I could barely even manage a smile, because it was six in the goddamn morning and already the day had included a 911 call and honestly?  I'm more than a little bit sick of this.
title: what we always say

body: *   I won't be starting work at that new employer this summer after all.  I'd finally managed to get a little big excited about it but Hotter is having multiple surgical procedures under one anesthesia at the local teaching hospital the first week of classes at Higher Learning, Inc. and even I am not insane enough to think I could handle both without poisoning at least one relationship, be it professional or personal.  So that's that.*   As for Lower-Level-Institute of Higher Education (where I currently work), I don't know if both of us still want me to teach that summer class or not.  Currently yes but ugh.  It's become rather apparent lately that there is only so much I can do at one time without failing across the board and possibly dropping dead of something or other in the process.*   Yeah, haha, about that.  The first day I thought it was from mowing the lawn and the second day I thought "eh, maybe a virus" but the evening of the second day I was frantically, tearfully delirious to the point of I think maybe scaring my husband a little bit (let's just say that "severe respiratory infection," "asthma attack," and "panic attack" can all make breathing a little fraught, and agree that the trifecta of "fever-driven terror plus hyperventilation with airway constriction and accompanying bagpipe-orchestra of sound/requisite gallon of mucus" is NEVER PRETTY) and when I woke on the third day Hotter took advantage of the grandiose, expansive bonhomie a crackling fever instills in me during daylight hours to persuade me to see a doctor despite my lapsed health insurance coverage and distaste for the prospect of surviving the next six months in general.  Which, BOO, am I right y'all?  I get to be truly happy about twice a year, once on my way under general anesthesia for something or other and once due to fever and people can't let me have my damn fun.  THE MAN Western Medicine has already gotten me down to 99-ish with their expensive, side-effect-riddled antibiotics of oppression.  Someone else fight the power for me for a while, okay, because I need another nap.*   There are a great many Ugly Things that'll be waiting for me when I wake up, too.  Family Therapy continues to be slightly less enjoyable than female genital mutilation (at least in my humble opinion), lots of things are UNDECIDED!  UP IN THE AIR!  JUST HAVE TO WAIT AND SEE! and...well, it would all thrill me a lot less if it wasn't for the fact that I think my temperature is creeping back up.  Hmm...yep, I just successfully thought about my own potential ABDOMINAL SURGERY THIS SUMMER, AGAIN, BECAUSE WHY NOT A FOURTH SUMMER IN A ROW and didn't even start doing that creepy laughing-but-with-tears-coming-out-too thing, so I'm going to snuggle under a blanket and we'll catch up on the rest later.
title: so scratch all those plans, we've got new ones here that I'm sure we'll learn to love almost as much, maybe, with enough drugs, or maybe not but I have a fever, so.

body: So, yeah.  The transplant team admitted Hotter to Local Teaching Hospital (where I demanded the very sweet young paramedics* take him this morning, and NOWHERE BLOODY ELSE!--it's not as convenient to Casa MFA as two or three other hospitals are, but it's also the only transplant facility within an hour of here) and worked him up and the official verdict is that apparently someone took "low potassium" to mean "eat three Snickers ice-cream bars before bed on the downlow," and now has high potassium and a Dilaudid-grade tummy-ache.      Bless his heart.   Yes, I say that as an atheist, but also as a lifelong Southerner, and when old Southern ladies can't think what else to say about a loved one that's what they say.  The past two weeks have aged me a lot.*   Oh yes, I have apparently skipped grown-up and gone straight to old because whereas five years ago I would've looked at these same paramedics and thought "why aren't you in school you whippersnapper!" because they would've been jailbait, and two years ago I would've been like "Oooh!" and checked out their arses, this morning I thought "aw, what sweet young kids" when I saw them, in uniform no less.  Probably they were within five years of my age, but I'm sorry, anyone in the medical field who isn't at least five years older than I am makes wonder if we shouldn't ask a grown-up to handle this.
title: death by chocolate

body:
There are two good ways to chase the tsuris away, and we like to git 'er done here at Casa MFA, so we had an excellent meal together for the first time in a week and also had a visit from a puppy!   I won't bore you with the details of dinner or even gooey cream-cheesy pecan dessert, since puppies always win.  Here ya go!
  Figure One: a boy and his puppy (identifying blankie anonymized).  All together: awww!   Why yes, I know it's dark.  They were taking a moment together.  Middle Child was having a kind of rough day and the neighbor needed help photographing the litter, so MFA Puppy came to take her afternoon nap over HERE, tucked in with Middly so that she can get used to her new place and not be scared come mid-July when she joins the household.  I asked him to keep her occupied while I punched down and kneaded our dinner bread, so he tucked her in nicely with his special blankie and gave her her first taste of puppy treats (shavings of soft, dissolving treat the size of my pinkie-nail, just a taste) while Hotter kept an eye on them both.   Hotter is doing great and reports that Middly is excellent with the puppy.  Once more: awww!

title: blogging the BPocalypse: the top-ten list of reasons I'm thanking BP

body:
MFA Puppy, whose real name is Isis and who snuck on the Twitter when our backs were turned, has arrived.   We actually got her a day early because the mama dog and entire litter are sick. Bad-sick, as in "let me take her a day early so I can get her patched up before the children meet her" and the breeder being an ignant fool and hitting on me and swearing the dogs are entirely healthy (why yes, yes he does live next-door, because life loves us).   Yeah. It was, to quote mom, the Poopocalypse. I blame BP.   The good news is that Isis is totally guaranteed to be the Bestest Dog EVAR because we not only bought a purebred pup with national grand champions in her pedigree, but we also rescued a dog, as I think I can honestly say given that said dog is on three (THREE) prescriptions (THREE.PRESCRIPTIONS.) and her first trip to the vet involved IV fluids and a Parvo test (thankfully negative). I like to think she knows she owes us big (because otherwise she's not very bright seeing as how we've reminded her on several occasions). The good news is, she's going to be just fine and is already 150% perkier.   The bad news is that the vet took one look and said we couldn't sign Isis up for the well-puppy plan due to her pre-existing condition.  I don't think she ever got our reaction before ("That's our dog," Hotter exclaimed, and we both made googly eyes as I handed over every cent we possess until the fifteenth) and she commended us on our attitude and made an appointment to take a second look and reevaluate in a week.     It's totally like having a new baby, and we're madly in love, and also I've never been so glad to be surgically sterile in my life.   
     Figure One: Even domesticated goddesses get dog-tired when they're sick as a...well...

I was just falling asleep/convincing Hotter No One Would Know...NO I will not snoogle you right now, GO TO THE BATHROOM.GO. TO. THEBATHROOM!I told you you had to go to the bathroom, no hold still, let me get a Clorox wipe and a biohazard space-suit...After you eat we'll play with that.OUT OF THE KITCHEN SO I CAN MAKE YOUR FOOD.OUT. OF. THEKITCHEN.And that is why you stay out of the kitchen when I'm busy in here, your foot is fine, I didn't step all the way down on it, okay let me kiss the boo-boo now OUT OF THE KITCHEN.Yeah I know it's not your favorite but it's what the doctor said you had to eat, and it cost a lot of money, and it's all you're getting.WHERE DID YOU GET CANDY? GIVE ME THAT.GIVE. ME. THECANDY.I'll watch you play with it after you eat, oh look here is your food.See it's not bad stuff, now let me just wipe your face with a--NO WIPING YOUR FACE ON THE FURNITURE. EAT YOUR FOOD. NO TOYS. [sotto voce to the husband: Ritalin! Stat!]Yeah I know you don't have to go to the bathroom, but you DO have to TRY.Stop playing with that. You can't play with your toy and poop at the same time.WHOOOOO POOP! [sings poo-poo song]Let me wipe your feet before you go on the--MY RUG, NOOOOOOO!!!Yes, I know you didn't know that was against the rules, but I was trying to TELL--It's like talking to myself. Like I'm some kind of crazy person, I HAD BRAINS BEFORE YOU CAME ALONG Y'KNOW...Because you are a grownup in the house too is why, I don't care if it's mine or not, what's mine is yours so TAKE OVER AND WATCH OUT FOR THE PEE DANCE.That's totally the pee dance.I'm just sayin' that pee dance means you need to--NO I WILL GET IT, JUST DON'T LET ANYONE STEP IN IT...No, no snack for you, you should have eaten your dinner.I JUST SAID NO AND NOW YOU ARE LIKE THE YES-FAIRY OVER THERE WITH THE SNACKS, THANKS FOR HAVING MY BACK, DUDE.Oh, come here, it's okay. You may either sleep or lie there quietly.I'm not getting it for you again, you shouldn't be playing with it so that it flies out of your reach, keep it in there with you.   So basically it's exactly like having another kid except I really do want to watch the dog play with her toy ONE MORE TIME because dogs are hilarious with their toys. What? If my children looked half as silly or invested in their games I might want to watch them too. Or maybe rope-knot bones are inherently funnier than DS games and Bionicles.
title: also I got the dog on purpose, but otherwise *exactly* the same

body: *   MFA Puppy is muchmuch better. She improved by at least 150% from her "hunchbacks" (subcutaneous lactated ringers--puppies scruff is nice and loose and aww poor thing--when we got her home and took her collar off it left a dent in the stuff but immediately she was up and about. After a nap and an epic piddle she ate a bit of prescription food and took her Panacur and generic puppy-Flagyl and at her evening meal gulped a third of a can at a go and made scoopable poop. Yeah.*   #Bewbfest10? Who knew? NOM. Hotter and I studied and commented on each and every one without reading the names because we're very happy pigs. The puppy sure did provide enough shit!*   Yeah totes pottymouth but seriously, the dog coulda pooped her name in the snow. Just sayin'.*   It was an utter poopocalypse and I credit my children with the dog's life. Pre-MFA Children I wouldn't have been down with catastrophic GI failure on that level but now? Awws, her had a sick!*   Aaand bringing it full-circle writerskool-style, the running joke is that the seven pound, seven-ounce baby with GI-related special needs is our honeymoon child and I'm thisclose to lactating. *rimshot* *   Thank you, thank you, here is your prize for reading!*   Oh by the way no, I did not just become dog people. Not me!
title: perky

body: Well after much waffling over whether to even go, a firm lecture from my husband on the importance of doing something Just For Me for once, a very generous bail-out from The Wrath, and a lot of scrambling for lodging, I am DEFINITELY going to BlogHer this year, with a plane ticket and a room to stay in and everything!   I am totally geeking out over here, people.  I've been blogging in various places since 2005, and will finally get the chance to meet some people I've "known" online for AGES.  If you're reading this, and you want to meet up at some point, here's what I'm definitely planning to do:Thursday, 8/5 - The People's Party and QueerosphereFriday, 8/6 - The BlogHer 5k (eeeeearly in the morning) and Sweets in The CitySaturday, 8/7 - A Green Affair, Blogalicious, Sparklecorn, and CheeseburgHerSunday, 8/8 - (I catch an evening flight home so this is when I'm free to hang out)   How about you?  If you're going, or are local to NYC, and want to hang out on Sunday let me know!
title: in which I geek out over BlogHer

body: I just spoke to dogbreeder-neighbor for the first time since our pitifulbull recovered and he was all pissy! It was super awkward! I made Hotter (who tries to avoid this stuff) come out with the dog and Middly showed her to the neighbor, who had to smile at the Middly-hawk and the gorgeous little dog (she really is, totes better if a bit of a diva) but y'all? Dude was fuming.   Hotter said I hurt dude's pride, and I said he doesn't deserve to feel rejected by someone MUCHOLDER than he is who is TOTESMARRIED and turned him down drunk and sober (him--me not so much drunk no), and then Hotter was like "no he misses your help with the dogs" and I said "either they're ALL sick and I'm not re-exposing our dog or they're FINE and it's JUST her and I'm keeping the cooties here. WhatEVER! Either way dude doesn't deserve a head. So glad the pup is paid in full and bouncing around happy.   Middly is so. very. proud. of the dog and Little Child finally has a haircut (buzz? DONEZO to the back and sides but curls? HECANHAZCURLS still, yes indeed, trimmed a bit but awws no AWWS!) and the dog had YET ANOTHER BATH today and dried in the sun and has to eat again.    I'd better put the food on to soak for Middle Child's dog. body: *   Hotter and I are totally becoming creepy dog-lover people. I guess it means we're too old for babies and not old enough for grandbabies? He calls me "Mommy" when he talks to the dog. As in "there's Mommy, stop crying, she is so bonded to you, gawd."*   Isis the dog may be bonded to me but she also big-puffy-hearts Middle Child. It is so cute. He is so proud. *   Speaking of Middle Child, I gave him a mohawk today. See, I told him he could let his hair grow if he wanted, and he did, and it was gnarly, so I convinced him a mohawk would be OMGAWESOME and he would be ZOMGSOCOOL and one thing led to another and Hotter's father's day gift (a beard trimmer) was in my hand and...yeah.*   I'd show y'all a picture but...too identifying. Let's just say it's not the same mohawk every boy under the age of ten in the blogosphere has had. My kid is hard-core buzzed to the skin except for a 1/2-inch wide strip of three-inch spiked BADASSERY. And his head doesn't smell worse than his dog.*   Big Child told Middle Child he looked crazy, and "bald, hahaha" so I shaved his head. Big Child's. And Middle Child laughed, HAHAHAHAHAHA, and Big Child whimpered but his stanky head will smell better now.*   As I told the XY when I took the kids back after his dinner visit, Little Child didn't get buzzed because I scrub his little head and keep it clean and sweet-smelling, and the other two need to start over. It'll grow out by the time school starts. Heh.*   Quote of The Day (year, really): I'm walking my dog with my mohawk, Big Child is crying because he's so jealous of my dog and my mohawk. I know it's horrible that I didn't squash it, but he was very discreet and no one else heard. So I had him go and quietly repeat himself to Hotter and then we both died. *   It's so good to see Middly so happy and proud of himself. This puppy has changed his entire demeanor. *   I don't know how the mama dog and Isis Puppy's littermates are faring. I hope they're doing okay. We got Isis handed over the fence by the scruff of her lethargic little neck just in the nick of time for her recover physically. If the breeder had to treat all of those dogs as we had Isis treated it was cost him around $3k and...well, sadly he gave us our pup early to get his hands on cash for dogfood. Sigh. I wish I was rich and could have them all treated but we have done what we could by our one and that is all we can do.*   Hotter is way better by the way. His surgeons cleared him for um, light exercise and while the MFA Children were at dinner visitation we MAY have crated the pitifulbull and gone on an ADULTS ONLY garbage run and then to the grocery store. I may have splurged on Starbucks for us, and we got our favorite kind of deli sandwich (smoked turkey, spicy pepper jack, southwestern mayo on twelve-grain bread with crisp lettuce and OM NOM NOM) and came home to find that the puppy didn't die and wasn't still howling like a tiny wolf, so we did things that might not even be legal in this state some stuff we couldn't do with the dog in our bed.*   I could have been talking about lying in our new fan's path and sighing happily--that upright fan we bought with bing.com cashback and picked up locally is BOMB given that our central air doesn't quite reach the dinky room at the end of the hall (ours). Little Child's room is smaller but cools well and the older MFA Childrens' room has multiple vents. Ours is bigger than Little Child's and smaller than the big boys' and the one vent doesn't quite cut it. This fan is awesome. I thought I was going through early menopause until we got it but no, I was just hot.*   I totally have a head and chest cold but am doing this feed a fever thing. Would any of you like a recipe I free-handed together for peanut-butter macadamia-nut cookies of sinful yumness? I won't be all pushy but if anyone WANTS it...*   The dog is lucky she's on a speshul diet or I woulda peanut-buttered the roof of her mouth but good, and LOLed at her for ages. *   I also, at Hotter's request, made some blueberry muffins. He is starting to get a tiny bit of junk in his trunk. Shh, if you ever meet him play it cool and don't stare but his leg-spine junction is coming along nicely and almost a butt.*   I ran today. A lot. But not in my tutu and not in a straight line. This puppy sucks at running. She'll heel along nicely at a trot then sit suddenly on her bum and bite leaves or blades of grass. She was so much more likable when she was lethargic. SRSLY.*   I mowed a swath just for the diva, and mulched up all of the leaves, HAHAHAHAHA and sticks HAHAHAHAHAHAHAHA and keep the bug population down.*   Middle Child is great about scooping the poop. We use this (I am not being compensated by them but Swoop? If y'all wanna drop me some free poobags hit me up, g-mail style) and the XY saw it and was impressed. Heh. It's great and we want to keep there from being anywhere for worms to breed or whatever, because let's just say the third time worming Isis was the charm and leave it at that. You're welcome (hrnk).*   Speaking of gaggy things, the pup still doesn't drink enough because she was weaned too early and grr so I still have to syringe pedialyte into her, and the apple flavor is all she'll voluntarily drink. PitbullFAIL. She's not allowed to dehydrate again though, because we want her to qualify for the well-puppy plan when the vet sees her for follow-up next Monday.*   The XY met the puppy, as in saw her moving under her own steam and TOUCHED HER even though I told him not to. I was all "YOU'RE NOT IN THE PACK" but he was googly-eyed and cooing at the stupid dog and she frisked right up to him. We told him how she'd been more likable when she was lethargic and he was like "oh so now she's acting like a puppy?" Pretty much, yeah.*   It's nice interacting with the pleasant husk the aliens left when they abducted the father of my children; he's actually likable, as Hotter said, making a face like the one I'm making as I type this. What happened to him not deserving to have a head (as MissGrace would say, which I <3 her for)? *hums Twilight themesong**   My prize from Niobe arrived today and I like it. Hotter thinks it's revolting. More for me. WHEEE!!!*   You guys. This dog sleeps on her back and runs all night long. *   The chickens love the leftover dogchow. We figure for $50 a bag (of thirty pounds of delicious, delicious nutrition) SOME critter will eat any bit before we waste the stuff. They now cluck when they see Middle Child putting his dog's food dish down. I think they're disappointed that she doesn't leave much anymore. Poor chickens.
title: so the dog's ADD and mine feed off each other, go figure
