body: Hotter and I have been working in the yard a lot, planting vegetables and landscaping and pruning the overgrown trees and shrubbery into some semblance of order and generally enjoying the outdoors and each other's company.  We had big plans for this weekend (the MFA Children are Away this weekend) including some bedroom acts illegal in our state and much sleeping in and cleaning house, but instead we're camped out at the local major teaching hospital.   I have no earthly idea what happened yesterday (and so far neither do any of the doctors here) but yesterday afternoon Hotter doubled over in pain, pain bad enough that he was whimpering, and my husband is a very stoic man.  We were both worried enough that I called Dr. Kidney's on-call transplant coordinator, who said that maybe he was just a bit dehydrated and overheated, and to give him a cool drink and an icepack on his neck and wait an hour, then if the pain hadn't gone away to go to the ER since their office was closing within the hour.   Hotter did his "I don't want to go to the hospital" thing and said the pain was not as bad, and we dropped the MFA Children off at the police station and headed home.  I went to pick up dinner and came home to find Hotter facedown on the living room floor gasping and pale from pain.  I quickly gathered our pills, my computer, and an emesis basin and frog-marched Hotter to the MFA Minivan.   The drive to the hospital was hell.  Sheer hell.  Hotter began to vomit from the pain on the way, and I'd pull over and have him empty the basin and go back to speeding like a demon, because by this point Hotter was screaming that he couldn't take it.  By the time we got off the expressway (where I blew through every toll because I didn't have change and didn't give a rat's arse for their video enforcement; by this time I was rather HOPING to pick up a police escort) he was talking about wanting to die and saying he was sorry and...I was scared, y'all.  I roared into the ambulance bay, ran into the ER and snatched a wheelchair informing them that my double-organ transplant husband was violently ill and they were treating him IMMEDIATELY, and handed Hotter (who was begging me not to leave him and looked almost as terrified as I was) over to the triage nurse.     I swear I came thisclose to just abandoning the MFA Minivan to the tender mercies of the local police department and figuring out what to do about it later.  When I got back from parking I found that they had indeed found "screaming, vomit-covered double transplant recipient" to be a compelling enough reason for immediate treatment (this would seem like a no-brainer, but I have NO EXAGGERATION seen people with knives sticking out of them sitting in chairs waiting to be triaged in this ER before).   After twelve hours in the ER during which Hotter felt much better and was halfway through discharge, but then failed the portion of the discharge where he had to prove he could eat and drink without the pain returning or any vomiting (epic fail there) and now we're in the "Critical Care Hospital" on the bone-marrow transplant ward thanks to my "he is immunosuppressed and we are NOT catching anything while in-patient" speech trying to figure out what Hotter's deal is (aside from having been severely dehydrated when we got here).  He woke up this morning pain-free and cracking jokes, but they've discovered something irregular about his heartbeat and want to do an abdominal ultrasound to check the bloodflow to his grafts, and he still hasn't eaten any actual food (just a liquid breakfast, although yesterday even a sip of water would set him off with the pain and vomiting).  I'm hopeful that this was just a particularly vicious GI bug but it would be nice if they could make a definitive diagnosis and tell us whether it'll happen again or what to avoid to prevent it, because DAMN.   And here is a doctor to talk to us.ETA: Very nice, very knowledgeable doctor pulled up a chair and sat and talked us through the differential diagnosis (which included some scary things that are unlikely and furthermore very difficult to test for in someone with Hotter's after-market anatomical layout) and Hotter's labs (which are excellent--potassium is nice and low and his creatinine is now the best I've ever seen it after being high last night from the dehydration) but said that in the end he thought my suggestion was the way to go.  I suggested that if the abdominal ultrasound and EKG are clear and Hotter can eat a solid lunch without the pain returning, they send us home with a bottle of very strong painkillers because we can just as easily scratch our heads and watch and wait from there.
title: live from the local teaching hospital

body:
Something about my husband's stay in a critical care hospital upset me more than the situation warranted.   Don't get me wrong, that is a very upsetting thing in and of itself whose magnitude needs no explanation.  I actually for the first time EVER resented my kids for about 0.5 seconds when I ditched the MFA Minivan, booked it into Major Teaching Hospital, and found a triage nurse giving up on assessing my sobbing husband and starting to take him back to a room just as he was reaching for my hand.  Hotter had made me promise in the car that I wouldn't leave him and then the ER staff made me do it again and the charge nurse was not even kidding or waiting for hellos or goodbyes.  I just squeezed his clammy shoulder and whispered "it's okay," then stepped back and let the nurse gently push his hand into his lap to wheel him away.  "It is not okay" he moaned.  "It will be!" I said firmly, out loud, even thought what I wanted to say was "don't die, because if you go I will too and I can't, I'm a mother."   He's home now, by the way.  The EKG was completely fine and the abdominal ultrasound was not but operating on someone whose abdominal anatomy has been rearranged to the extent Hotter's has is a big enough deal that barring another acute event the transplant team, surgery team, and whoever else want to plan it together and we can wait at home with morphine and Zofran just as easily as we can wait at the hospital with the same two things unless one of two godawful warning signs presents itself, in which case back we go and they deal with it on the fly.  So it could have been better news, but it's the best of the worst-case scenarios in that his grafts are fine and the surgical issue isn't something that'll kill you dead in a matter of hours without treatment, more like days (and we know what to look for).  We're both feeling pretty grateful about that.   America, by the way, is not ready for absinthe to be legal.  By America I pretty much mean me, but this is my blog, so.  Yeah.  I pretty much disgraced myself, and you might say it was understandable under the circumstances but I say that kind of disgrace is downright inexcusable and there was nothing understandable about it, even to me.   The next morning it hit me: the last time I took someone I loved will all of my heart to the Major Teaching Hospital was when my baby almost died and the XY's crimes against humanity shielded me in a way from ever having to process any of that.  So my husband's medical emergency triggered my PTSD and I remember a bunch of stuff I'd blocked out that had been tapping me quietly on the shoulder all weekend and damn, just damn, y'all.   Today we have family therapy and it's going to be all about the newly-turned-nine-year-old, who made a really poor choice that could have seriously injured one of his brothers.  I should go and make cupcakes.  Also we have a new pet here, because suddenly I can't abide suffering in any form and yesterday while taking the scenic route home from Hotter's favorite restaurant through a neighborhood of moss-covered mansions we saw a rat snake coiled in the road with three crows attacking it.  The snake was doing its best to look terrifying by emulating a viper, and putting up an impressive front, but didn't stand a chance and I threw a jacket over it, bundled it into a paper bag, bought it a good-sized tank and a heating pad and named it Poe.  Because god dammit, nevermore universe.   And that's all I really had to say today.*I was a sprinter as a young whippersnapper and in my absolute focus on 
getting back to Hotter's side I was aware of other people only as 
obstacles no different than curbs, pillars and traffic cones, but there 
are human strata around that accursed institution and it must have been 
as I flew through the drunk and homeless into the hospital security and 
city police layer when someone hollered "GO GIRL!"
title: said and unsaid

body: Mr. Family Therapist keeps saying things like "find something to do that you enjoy" and "you need to do something just for yourself" and "she needs to go on vacation" and then giving me the "what the what" eyebrow when I say how I'm going to my ladies' social media convention in New York in August and giving Hotter pleading looks like "I don't see how you can possibly tap that with the big stick up there but you SO need to do something about this," but that's because he hasn't seen my yard.   Hippie parents + dirt-poor Southern ancestry = rad horticultural skills, and when you garden to wear out your "anger shoes," well, so far I've planted and got growing:SpinachRomaineSweet CornTwo Kinds of Shell PeasBush and Pole Green BeansBush and Pole Lima Beans (although no true butterbeans; you cannot get Carolina Sieva seedstock for love or money, even on the innernet, due to a blight last year.  Woe!)LeeksRed PotatoesCauliflowerRadishesCarrotsCucumbersWatermelonsCilantroBasilDillSunflowers (the edible seed ones with flowers the size of manhole covers)andTomatoes   And I still need to assemble one more cedar planter box for mixed baby greens, and might still put in a bed of sweet potatoes, and it is something I haven't done in a very long time, gardening, but suddenly I'm all "I LIVE in the dirt!"  Whee!   Originally I was all "if I can't eat it, I'm not growing it," but then Hotter expressed a wish for some pretty flowers, and one thing led to another and I started landscaping as well.   My sweet older neighbor gave me one of her big old variegated hostas, which I divided into six spindly little ones along a terrace Hotter built of stone and the odd cinderblock from around the property and filled with displaced earth from my seedbeds (oh I so totally bought soil, you bet your arse I did, because you could fire the clay from our ground here) under a big old tree.     That neighbor and I get along splendidly.  I think Hotter is right in that as the president of the neighborhood association (which I think is just this lady and her sister, who lives on the other side of us; they are adorable) she is very happy someone's fixing up the yard here, but she also just stands on her side of the fence and laughs at me a lot.  She'll be all "nono, I insist that you take this giant pot of irises, I have too many and you were saying you wanted to extend that bed of them on your side of the mailboxes" and "these giant loppers of mine would slice through those branches hanging over our fence like butter, if you want to try them out..." because she knows I'll take the bait EVERY TIME and so do I but meh, we both win.  Hotter took her a bowl of his famous coleslaw the day before he got sick and the two of them were giggling at me for climbing up a giant crepe myrtle to perform tree surgery.  "I love to watch her go!" said our neighbor, and Hotter was all "haha, me too" and waggling his eyebrows, and I was ignoring the both of them so I wouldn't get to laughing and fall out of the damn tree.     "It's alright," the neighbor said to me one time when she walked up on me trash-talking a dandelion I was yanking out of the driveway, "working outside is good for ya, and I talk to my plants too!"  Which she does.  She fusses at them and says things like "what in the world do you think you are doing going all over the yard, my goodness" and "well I NEVER!"  I call weeds "illegitimate sons of hired evening companions" if the children are about, and when they're not I stand over my seedlings and yell "GROW, you assholes!"  Tomato, to-mah-to.   I also enjoy mowing.  I haven't really let Hotter touch that lawnmower yet.  He wants to, but too damn bad.  It's gotten to the point that we'll drive by an unkempt median strip without the children in the car and I'll point it out to him: "I could mow the SHIT out of that!"  He laughs at me but whatever dude, you want to get back into YOUR hobby of painting miniature action figures.  He points out grassy knolls now: "You could go up the side of that with the self-propelled mower."  I'll probably buy him some decent paintbrushes next time we have some money that I don't blow on rescuing everything that slithers (before Poe there was a worm snake that I nearly mowed over and it has an escape-proof tank with a lock and a heating pad as well; Hotter named it Underdog and I kept meaning to mention the blasted thing but then we would go to the Local Teaching Hospital and I wouldn't have anything to say for a bit so actually we're up to TWO snakes but that is absolutely IT with the reptiles).   So yeah, I have hobbies but they're pretty lame and I'm also kind of touched in the head.  I can own that.
title: I do TOO have hobbies, they're just lame is all

body: Figure One: the mighty worm snake (actual size that of a coiled-up #2 pencil).   This is Underdog.  He's tiny and scared of everything except for earthworms, and he thinks you should go and read my new post at Hopeful Parents.  If I was putting up a picture of Poe it would be like "Poe says go and read HP or face his wrath" and you'd probably be intimidated enough to go and check it out whether you want to or not, but alas, I don't have any good shots of Poe yet because he's over three feet long and requires both hands and my undivided attention to wrangle.  And Underdog has no wrath.  So it's more like "Underdog wants you to go and read HP please, but you don't have to or anything, he can't do anything about it if you don't, it's really just a timid little suggestion."     Seriously though, go and read it, you know, if it's not too much trouble.
title: Underdog wants you to go and read HP today

body: Sometimes, friends, life sucks mightily in ways you could never have predicted in your wildest of terminal-degree-in-making-crap-up dreams, and you get drunk.   You, not me.  I'm not judging, though.  We're all friends here.   Just, you know, saying.   When this happens, sometimes you stay up way too late being all maudlin, to the point that you start to get that morning-after feeling while still awake, and you lurch make your way quietly to the medicine cabinet and steal what you really hope is one of your husband's Zofran.   Or else, you know, maybe one of his immunosuppressants (if your husband's an organ transplant recipient) or blood pressure pills or...well anyway, you never know when your husband's medicine cabinet takes up an entire kitchen cabinet (both doors' worth), do you?   So because I you love my your husband and he needs his sleep after a day like this, maybe you decide to post something exonerating him of any foul play should you be found tits-up in the morning.   Oh, relax.  I'm joking, of course.  YOU would never do any such thing given that your ex-husband's lawyers could be reading your blog.*  But if you did?  Your readers would know how you'd want to be buried.   Now go to bed, you freak!*  Even if by "drunk" you meant "had two glasses of wine but are a total lightweight with awful reflux whose children were a) asleep and b) under the care of your (totally sober, healthy, responsible) husband, their loving step-father, at the time and by "really hope" you mean "verified despite double-vision and lack of glasses-on-face because drunk or sober or even half-dead, in this house even the four-year-old knows that 'O-R-D-A-N-E-S-T-R-O-N' spells 'N-O P-U-K-I-N-G,' but, you know, even half-hung-over and stressed-to-the-max you would want to clarify that, because you never know who's reading your blog and getting paid by the hour to do it.  Ohhai XY's lawyers.  You lucky bastards, you; everyone else is reading this on their own time.  Of course, you're probably the only ones reading this from under the staggering burdens of twenty-pound yet still-stumpy pricks for heads, so there's that to make the rest of them feel less bad about the whole thing I suppose.
title: just in case

body: So Hotter's whole family (Hotter excepted) is on Facebook.   Including my step-son (I call him "Lefty" due to his only having his left ball because of a bout with testicular torsion and my being sick in the head), my crazy brother-in-law "The Mouth" and his wife, my other crazy BIL "Big and Scary, " his son "Big and Scary Jr.," and even The Wrath, (whose fault it is that I am on Facebook, and who still has not accepted my friendship request because she never logs on and The Mouth set up her account including her hilarious and adorable profile pic in which she looks like The Mouth is up in her grill with a camera and she is not amused) (although she is friends with Hotter's ex-wife so HMPH to her!).   Today The Mouth posted a picture of a fish he caught, and Big and Scary made an asinine comment about how there was a 7% tax in the works on fishing in polluted water and a 3% worm tax to benefit the working class all to pay for ObamaCare or somesuch so enjoy it while it lasts because THE GOVERNMENT IS OUT TO GET US.   Oh, Facebook, you are full of rejection and ignorance, and remind me why I don't speak to any of my OWN relatives!   I of course jumped in with a remark about how healthcare would allow my family to both eat AND pay for the drugs to keep my husband and son both alive long enough for Hotter to take Little Child fishing so Big and Scary should go start pulling trash out of the nearest body of water and message me his address to send some worms from our yard.   Big and Scary then went off on a rant, and Big and Scary, Jr. chimed in with the suggestion that we pass him some of what we were smoking (to which Big and Scary replied that the medical marijuana tax would then apply), and I decided not to make any further contributions to the fray.   Then Big and Scary went and deleted all of his comments, leaving my rant the top comment on the photo, and left one at the bottom saying "Nice fish, Mouth.  Wonder what the hell MFA Mama and Junior are talking about?"     Fortunately I have Facebook updates sent to e-mail, which makes my crackberry chime, which means that only stood for about ten seconds before I jumped back on and deleted MY original comment and left one saying "Yeah Mouth, nice fish.  Big and Scary needs to have an intervention for Junior, though.  Wonder what he's on?"   Aw, Facebook, way to remind me what I miss out on in not having family I speak to.   Also Big and Scary, who is a bit sweet on me in the creepy-yet-benign way that only a six-foot, three-hundred-pound crazy BIL who would die for my husband can be, has been nagging me to post more pictures (until today I only had a profile picture of my face).   So I put a lizard album up and told Big and Scary in Facebook chat that I'd posted some pictures JUST FOR HIM when he messaged me to apologize and urge me not to EVER take him seriously.   "Oh?" said Big and Scary.   Yes, I said, fresh out of the shower!  You'll love 'em.   "Haha.  They're pictures of Hotter, aren't they?"   No no, I assured Big and Scary, these pictures are all girl.   "I can't look at those, OMG I can't have THAT in my head, you're Hotter's girl..."  Poor Big and Scary, I almost felt sorry for him.  Almost.   Oh go on, I said.  Hotter helped me take them, he doesn't mind.  Go and look at them and I hope they give you sweet dreams!  And I signed off cackling.   It's on now!
title: bad fun on Facebook

body: In warm weather, skinks hang out on our front porch.  No matter how ripely foul my mood is, I get a kick out of seeing them EVERY SINGLE TIME because, well, they're COOL!   Know what's NOT cool though?  Hearing scuttling and crunching in your bedroom at night for two nights in a row, thinking you have mice, and arguing with your spouse over whether HIS desk-snacking or YOUR bed-snacking drew the vermin.   What's less uncool but still not great is when it turns out the scuttling and crunching was a skink in the house (which is cool since the crunching means less bugs, but uncool in that if you're me you worry about it getting stepped on/tortured by small boys/into something toxic to lizards), and trying to figure out how to apprehend the bugger without making her (yes, it was a girl--the boys are flashier-looking) drop her tail, because then you would cry.   If this ever happens to you, the best way to humanely capture a lizard in your house is to corner it in the bathroom, lay the flat side of a paper grocery bag against the floor in a corner, open end by a corner, and scare the lizard into running inside.  Then fold the top over and release your scaly little friend outdoors.  If it was behind the only toilet in a house with four male occupants, only one of whom has any ability to, er, aim then the nice thing to do would probably be to fill a plastic cup with warm water and pour that over the lizard after releasing it (but before it recovers enough to run like hell) to remove any cleaning product residue or pee.   Or, you know, do that and THEN subject it to a photo shoot:  Figure One: Say hello to my leetle friend!  This was right after her shower.  Figure Two: Right after she leapt off the wall ninja-style at your camera-toting heroine, tumbling into a mop-bucket containing a pollen-covered umbrella. Probably she was just going to give me a big hug; you can totes see the gratitude on her face!  Or maybe that's outrage.  Reptiles are tough to read like that.  Figure Three: Sunning herself and recovering from her ordeal.  Or possibly plotting revenge.  Again, hard to say.
title: how to humanely remove a lizard from your house, with PICTURES!

body: There are a great many Big Things happening in the MFA household, and most of them I cannot share here.  Instead I will tell you that I've been doing a lot of gardening and Hotter has been trimming an overgrown corner of our yard (holly grows wild here and had overtaken the big rose bush and creeping English ivy, then poison ivy came to the party and yeah, I wasn't touching that with a ten-foot pole but Hotter seems to be immune, the bastard).     Today when I went to the local police station to hand the kids over to the XY for a dinner visit I ran over a lone sprig of holly that had blown into the driveway and apparently dragged it caught in the MFA Minivan's undercarriage for eleven miles.  The XY saw me pull in and said "you've got a tree under your van."  I got down on my hands and knees and looked: nada.  "I see no tree," I told the XY.  "There's a tree.  I'm telling you.  A tree."  I finally looked again (no tree) and then said "okay very funny, a tree, haha you win" and started to leave when I saw it: a big sprig of holly resting on the slight incline where you pull in and out of the parking lot.     In the name of walking my talk from family therapy I stopped the car, got out, and called to the XY.  "I apologize," I shouted across the parking lot.  "Hotter was trimming the holly in our yard and there's no holly here so this must be, uh, mine and you were right.  I'm sorry I doubted you.  Thanks for letting me know."   I don't think he quite knew what to make of that.  It was kinda funny.

body:
You may have noticed 
that I've been quiet, and Not Mentioning a lot of things, and many of 
them are still Not To Be Mentioned On The Innernet but the one most 
troubling to me was that I pretty much lost my everloving mind.  I am talking 
about "paralyzed with anxiety, can't answer a simple yes or no question,
 afraid to leave the house, hiding under a pile of blankets with the 
iPod and Belleruth Naparstek huffing lavender oil having taken two 
Benadryl to take the edge off" kind of crippled by panic, y'all, and I 
won't lie, I was worried about my mental health.    The MFA 
Minivan had a coolant system leak several months ago due to a
 loose hose; the XY said something about it when we were exchanging 
children at the police station and I was all "your MOM smells like 
antifreeze" because the temperature gauge was fluctuating appropriately 
but no the vehicle was overheating AND the in-dash computer needed a 
re-build and I may have owned a vibrator AND a jar-opener but the 
minivan made me feel lonely for not knowing the smell of antifreeze.    

 I used to carry a jug of inexpensive premixed 
coolant everywhere, even after MFA Mechanic and Son fixed the leak, but 
stopped when Hotter moved in because I try to 
rein the crazy in for his sake and be graceful in accepting feedback on 
what's good planning versus clinical neurosis.    It's a true 
testament to my marriage that I didn't go at anyone wielding a dipstick 
like a rapier last Saturday when a chime went off at the exact moment 
that Hotter said he smelled antifreeze and I pulled over to find that 
the coolant level was dangerously low.  Not because he had convinced me 
to leave the coolant 
behind just recently; coincidences happen all the time and correlation 
and causation are two things I keep separated in my head with a fair 
degree of success.  I am not superstitious or narcissistic enough to 
think my preparation or lack thereof can affect the outcome.  No, I was 
annoyed with myself, because the minivan overheating is a pretty good 
example of the way in which 
many of the 
things Not To Be Mentioned On The Innernet have been going down: 
something will happen that I was prepared for at one point in time but 
stopped being prepared for or wanted to prepare for but didn't because I
 or someone else whose input I value
 thought I was being neurotic, and I am unprepared, and it sucks.    
 What really gets my goat are the things I see
 coming that are so far-fetched as to make me look both neurotic AND 
paranoid when I prepare for them anyway but then happen as predicted.  I
 enjoy being right as much as the next person, but these things 
freak me out because I can't explain them.   The day after the 
minivan overheated, I had a familiar Very Bad Feeling.  After some hemming and
 hawing I decided it was better to say something about it and then have 
nothing happen and look insane than to say nothing and have something 
happen and feel like a jerk, so I said something.  Even now I am kicking
 myself, because while I doubt my saying "I feel like you're going to 
have a seizure" can make even the most obliging of husbands proceed to 
do just that, the observer effect is real and I was NOT following the 
scientific method.  I maybe should have written the date and "totally 
saw this coming" on a slip of paper and tucked it into the vial of 
Valium instead.     Hotter said "okay" and made sure he knew 
where the Valium was, and then we proceeded to bicker over my failure to
 buy an outdoor faucet handle and his taking that personally.  I was 
lying on the bed working on the laptop and he was looking for something 
he thought had fallen between the bed and the wall hovering kind of 
half-overtop of me.  He made a snide comment about my ADD and I said 
"well you know how Mr. Therapist says I need to work on being less afraid to 
express anger normally?  HERE GOES!" and told him what I thought of 
that, and then he busted me in the face.   At least, that's what 
it seemed like, but actually he had had the seizure I had predicted.  
 I'm not sure what the take-home message from this is, other than that 
our family therapist needs to give up on me ever doing much aside from nodding and smiling when I'm truly furious because 
that fear that my displaying actual discernible anger would result in my
 (second) husband hitting me?  NOW IT WILL NEVER GO AWAY!  Well-played, 
universe.     I am not a believer in psychic phenomena, Hotter 
doesn't have any behavioral "tells" that either of us are aware of when 
he's getting ready to have a seizure, and things that I can't come up 
with a logical explanation for confound me utterly.  I don't like this. 
 It makes my brain hurt and I think it's contributed in part to my 
recent loss of equilibrium, although I think that's mostly due to the 
fact that my gut telling me to be very afraid for valid reasons and 
fears borne of neuroses/past traumas feels EXACTLY THE SAME. 
   This is complicated by the fact that my gut is often right in 
ways that might be neurotic for someone else with a very different life 
from mine, but are good sense if you're MFA Mama and have an elderly 
vehicle and a medically interesting husband you share a brain with, but I
 also have some fears that are just, well, fears.  Last weekend's 
anger/seizure clusterf*ck aside, Hotter has never hit a woman, and I 
know intellectually that he would rather chop off his arm than harm me, 
but man, what a disaster that was!   I'm having a hard time 
trying to learn to trust my gut on inexplicable matters that defy all 
logic but ignore it when it shrieks about ducking and covering in a 
marital disagreement when based on personal statistics, anyone I am as 
close to as I am to Hotter (family members and lovers included; 
basically any adult person I share a roof with) has about a seventy-five
 percent chance of beating me until I need medical attention.  I'm good 
at logic, but it's no use around here lately, and I suck at trusting 
myself or anyone else, which seems to be the only way to get through all
 of this.
   Hence my recent quiet and overabundance of angst.

   I had my quarterly appointment with my psychiatrist today 
(generally this is when he asks me if the Ritalin is still working for 
me, I say yes, and he writes for another 90-day fill of that), and I 
told him what's been going on (and also the things that are Not To Be 
Mentioned On The Innernet).  He laughed ruefully and said that I 
continue to have the absolute worst luck of anyone he's ever seen and 
it's amazing I'm not insane, but that he still doesn't think I'm even 
close.  He agreed to up the antidepressant I've been taking for years in
 case that will help me cope, but deemed my recent issues with anxiety 
to be situational and appropriate under the circumstances.  Which 
doesn't make it any more enjoyable.  

   Mercury had better get its arse out of retrograde or whatever the 
crap is going on around here, because April is kicking the MFA Household
 in our collective junk with steel-toed shoes and I'm ready for a break.   And how are all of YOU?
title: in which I am schooled by life and do not enjoy it: an explanation of sorts

body: This is all I have to say about the crisis in the Gulf, because I have reached my saturation point on the topic, but...   Have y'all seen this?   I found it via Erin's post on her kids' turtle art auction, which warmed the cockles of mama's black little heart, but then I played the game, and...   What the FUCK, Dawn?  I used to think of your company in a positive light as helpful and benevolent, which is exactly the kind of PR you want, but having played this game I have two things to say to you:1.  Calling the character that most resembles my actual person (a blonde caucasian woman) "Mrs. Mom?"  Is deeply uncool with me as a feminist.  The only two adult males outside of the also-caucasian "couple" (whose white hair, incidentally, leads me to wonder whether you see heterosexual unions as the sole purview of the elderly) are a caucasian "Businessman" and a caucasian "Mr. Golf Man."  Aside from the female component of "Couple," there is no other female character to choose from (I'm leaving out the non-human characters, consisting of the dog you call "Man's Best Friend," the fish called "Tuna Fish," and the androgynous, anthropomorphic "Race Car").  Even the sole kid-like character, "Skater Dude" (also caucasian) at least has a hobby.  Are y'all trying to imply to the target demographic of your cute little video-game-for-a-good-cause that caucasian women don't get a childhood at all and are either mothers or fucktoys for heterosexual caucasian men, reinforce the notion that adult men are not parent material, suggest that hobbies, friends, and careers are only for men and boys...help me out with that, and then tell me: do non-whites and same-sex couples not exist or do they just not help clean up oil spills?2.  Contributing a percentage of the proceeds from the sale of bottles of your product like the one beside my own kitchen sink, or even bottles of the product itself, to help clean up oil-contaminated wildlife is excellent: it's relevant, helpful, and kind of noble, but creating a game wherein some white men plus a fucktoy, a mother, a car, a dog, and a tunafish try to stop a cartoon graphic that literally paints an unrealistically vibrant portrait of the Gulf's crumbling floor just smacks of the racist, sexist, homophobic capitalization of tragedy.   So now the one thing I have actively done about this whole clusterfuck (reach for the bottle of Dawn at the grocery store over other brands even though it was a few cents more due to the "helping wildlife" blurb on the packaging when I normally prefer Palmolive if I'm getting fancy and going above store brand) feels tainted by your -isms, and I actually feel a little more hopeless about life in general than I already did given that I'm unemployed, my family is in entirely lousy health, and the environment is going to hell in a handbasket.   I just went and bid on a little girl's drawing of a sea turtle, and having done that won't weep for the fraction of a cent you would have donated from any further purchase of your product next time I buy a DIFFERENT brand of dish soap.

body: I've mentioned all funny-ha-ha how Hotter lost my 90-day script for Ritalin (which being a controlled substance, is not something I can ask Dr. Shrink to replace a lost prescription for, and maybe the mail-order pharmacy is a bad idea for Ritalin, which is a very cheap drug, come to think of it), but what I haven't shared with y'all is the very real impact this is having on my ability not only to punctuate but also to hold a grudge.   Shut up.  Seriously, that's important, because grudge-holding serves to help you communicate better with the offending party.  Savoring your own fury indefinitely like an everlasting gobstopper may be a character flaw, but holding onto it long enough to package your dismay into a "I feel x when you do y" statement at least gives someone in your life the chance to stop being an asshole.  And I?  Can't stay pissed long enough to articulate it, and people continue being asinine, and not until they've sinned again and I'm overcome with white-hot déjà vu do I remember that this has Become A Problem, Crap.   I might think about it again, but not until after I've seen the offender again and greeted them like I'm their dog and they just came home from work, and then I look like I'm the one with the problem if halfway through kissing them hello I'm all "Oh that's right--YOU FUCKING SHITHEAD!"   I'm not saying I've never gone that route, just that it's a horrible idea, because if the other person is a man and they find my fury hilarious then suddenly I might break my perfectly good "Patriarchy Be Cool!" stick over their fool head and have to go out in the yard and find a new one to brandish when people are wrong on the Twitter.   Like last night, my nemesis ambushed me on the front porch and threatened to fling his vile little pod-body at my bare feet as I was coming into the house from slug-patrol (what, you don't round them up and flush them?  Well then I'm sorry to tell you that you are not living), and I was afraid that if I opened the door enough to go inside the damn thing would GET INTO THE HOUSE, and that is uncool because we already have (in addition to the flock of chickens, food-dish-humping cockatiel, two rescued snakes and pair of small brown mice going by Thelma and Louise in case the big snake is hungry that we ALLOW in here because we're sick in the head) at least one skink (again) and a "visitor mouse," as Hotter calls it, that I think is drawn to either the peanut butter or the lady mice in Poe's cage.  We keep finding it on or around the cages, and I refuse to accept Hotter's explanation that Thelma and Louise are now charging locals out the arse to come teabag a real, live snake a la Balzac, but anyway yes, LOL VERMIN and FUCK NO, TOAD so I opened the door a tiny crack and yelled for my husband, who...didn't show up.  Fortunately I do yoga and so I was able to contort myself in a manner that allowed me to grab a nearby broom without moving my feet (and thus provoking The Undertoad, as we've started to call him) and fend off my wretched foe, and once I was was armed and had hollered "HOW DO YOU LIKE ME NOW?!?" and brandished my weapon I was tickled enough that I called for Hotter AGAIN thinking he'd get a kick out this, since he likes The Undertoad and secretly roots for the damned thing and HE DID NOT ANSWER AGAIN.   Now, I'm not an unreasonable person, so when I did go inside I looked to see if Hotter was wearing his headphones, but y'all he wasn't, he was just playing his stupid computer game and ignoring me so yes, this was righteous fury, and I was all set to smite him when the toaster went off and I was like "OH: bagels!" and forgot to kill him and later when we were talking and I remembered and was like "heeeey why didn't you answer me, earlier?"   If he'd copped to just being really caught up in something I think I might've been able to resist the call of the Crazy, but no he denied hearing me either time, which was clearly bogus, so then I was like "suuuure so basically I could have been eaten by a bear and you would have just let it happen."   "Of course not, you wouldn't get eaten by a bear in the first place," he said, all patronizing, and it was on.   "I could SO have been eaten by a bear!  There was a bear sighting in this area a couple of years ago!  A black bear, but still--"   "Aww a black bear.  If you'd said a brown bear I could maybe see it, but--"   And see, then I felt like I had to stand up for the bears, because he was being patronizing toward them too, and I was all "Black bears can fuck you up, y'know.  Just because they're like the black labs of the bear scene doesn't mean they want to fetch you your slippers and snuggle by the fire.  I read one time where one mauled somebody so badly they had to have a glass eye and a prosthetic face, okay?"   "They'd be afraid of you, though, you'd just have to make yourself look big and scary and yell at them, they'd back down."   "BULLSHIT!  What if I didn't see it coming because hello, it's night-time, they're black bears!"   "I don't think they're nocturnal."   "Yeah well, if it came to attack me during the day I might not necessarily notice in time to be scary, I could be out there spending quality time with Belleruth* all in the zone, mentally summoning the presence of everyone who's ever supported and cared for me, calling every good wish home, every positive thought and--RAWR!--EATEN BY A BEAR!"   "Maybe they are nocturnal."   "Okay, so if it's out during the day it's rabid, way to make me feel better, then it doesn't even have to eat my face because it's infectious!"   "Your mom is infectious."   "PROBABLY!"   So yeah, now I'm starting to wonder whether he really lost the thing at all; maybe it was premeditated because he planned to be a jerk until after his surgery?  I don't know.  And now I'm kind of depressed, but not suicidal or anything, or even if I was, I'd never get around to doing anything about it.  Sigh.  I wasn't really worried about the black bears though, or at least I wasn't until I started defending them, but now I don't know, I mean they are still bears.  Maybe I should start playing Bingo just to be on the safe side.   Also those little cilantro and chicken mini-wontons from Trader Joe's are amazing.  That is all.*   Yes, that's right.  I listen to guided imagery (specifically the album for transforming anxiety) on my iPod at full-blast while I mow and that is why I love the mowing so--because it's what I do when I am about to come unhinged.  I stop, take a deep breath, and go fill the mower with gas and I tell myself that if I still need to cut a bitch after I've burned a gallon with Belleruth, the good kitchen knives will be right where I left them.  I even named the lawnmower Belleruth.  Shut up, plenty of perfectly sane people name their lawnmowers after famous psychotherapists and everything is normal here.
title: the short version is that Ritalin is good and black bears can kill

body:
The chickens are now three weeks old, and good lord they grow fast.  Look at Speck!
  Figure One: Looks pretty much like a chicken now, doesn't she (a chicken wearing a ratty maribou boa, but still, totally a chicken))?  I found Little Child squatting over the chickens' box yesterday and asked him what he was doing, and he very earnestly informed me that "I was jus' telling the chickens IT LAYS THE EGGS OR IT GETS THE HOSE, Mommy, that's all."*   Gender relations are a hot-button issue here lately at Casa MFA.  Not only has the ongoing chicken-sexing debacle been at the forefront of dinner conversation (out of six supposedly female chickens, two are definitely cocks and one is a maybe, which is either a 33% or 50% rate of inaccuracy--well above the "industry standard" margin of error mypetchicken.com claims, which is 10%, and while they'll refund the difference in price for the incorrectly-sexed birds, that's only $0.50 per bird and their offer to throw in a free chick on my next order doesn't help me find homes for two or three cocks and I still have to pay the shipping, which is the expensive part, plus they won't do anything for thirteen to fifteen weeks by which point introducing new babies to the flock would be...fraught), but Big Child uttered some words that will live in infamy last night, words that have gotten under Mama's skin.   Do you want to know what that child said?   See, I debated whether or not to even share this, but we were talking about balls last night after dinner here, because Little Child was darting back and forth while animatedly telling us a story about something I've already forgotten, and as he darted back and forth he was whacking Hotter with his outstretched arm on each pass to and fro, and Little Child's arm outstretched at the shoulder is about an inch below The Danger Zone on your average adult male.  Hotter was caught up in how cute the story was and trying manfully not to laugh (and also assuming a more guarded stance), but I decided that this was a teachable moment.  Because see, Little Child gets away with a lot of really obnoxious crap by virtue of being little and adorable and medically-fragile, but the fact of the matter is that he is going to kindergarten next year and I feel we owe it to society to turn him into a human being before that occurs, which means less eating with his hands, finding his Inside Voice, wiping his own arse, and not running back and forth whacking people in their junk while he's telling a story.  So I said "Little Child, stop hitting Hotter please, you're about to hit him in his junk and that will NOT be funny."   "What, you mean his balls," Little Child asked.  Big Child, who was sitting on the couch, leaned forward expectantly and Middly's eyes lit up with Bad Fun.   "That's right, you don't hit Hotter in his balls."   Little Child stamped his tiny foot.  "But I hit Daddy in his balls ALL THE TIME," he pouted, and y'all, he does.  I've seen it.  Little Child tends to greet his father by running up to him like a tiny linebacker and BLAM!  Right in the junk.  And his father wheezes and clutches himself and goes "NOT IN THE PEE-PEE LITTLE CHILD, NOT IN THE PEE-PEE, OH GOD" but doesn't put a hand out and stop the kid or enact a predictable consequence or anything, and if it was anyone else I would step in but I have decided that this falls squarely into the category of "not my problem."  Plus it's hilarious.  The XY's balls are expendable.  I would, however, prefer that the children not maul their step-father's balls, because it makes him sad and could potentially result in Mama not getting laid should the great GI Debacle of 2010 ever fuck on off the way it ought to before Hotter's surgery.   So I said "well, if your father lets you hit him in the balls then those are Daddy's Rules and that's all fine and good, but Daddy's Rules stay at Daddy's House, and in our house we have Mommy and Hotter's rules, which include not hitting Hotter in the balls because it could really hurt him and that's not nice."  Yes, I seriously had this conversation!  I know, I'm still reeling myself; I did not at any time during my graduate studies at a top-five school in my field picture myself unpublished and lecturing my third (!!!) child about about hitting his stepfather in the junk at this point in my life, but it happens, I guess.   Big Child, who has a fine future ahead of him in litigation (if no one kills him first), swooped in and said "wait, Mommy, I thought hitting was never okay, and if he shouldn't hit Hotter in the...private...then he shouldn't do it to Daddy either.  I think you should punish him."  Big Child is possessed of a rather Victorian sensibility and also apparently a death wish.   I looked at Hotter and then very deliberately did not look at Hotter, because he was crying silent tears of mirth behind his hand and that was Not Helpful, and said "well, Big Child, as we have discussed I have no control over Daddy's Rules and I don't punish y'all for things you do at his house because I'm not there to see it happen and my rules are different anyway."   "Well still!  It looks like you're trying not to laugh, which means you think Daddy getting hit in his...man area...is funny, and you shouldn't think that's funny, it's MEAN, what if Little Child really hurts Daddy's..." and he gesticulated in front of his pelvis.   I did laugh a little bit then, because I challenge you to keep a straight face in a situation like that, and said "well buddy that's kind of the way it goes in a divorce.  The ex-wife wants bad things to happen to the ex-husband's genitals and if your father is letting Little Child hit him in his balls then I might go ahead and laugh, and yes, it's mean, but you'd laugh too if it wasn't your father and Daddy is no longer part of my family.  Plus if it's hurting him he should make Little Child cut it out.  Until he does, I'm sorry son but I find this hilarious."   Three quarters of the people who were not me did exactly what I wanted them to at this point and cracked up laughing and yelling out various names for male genitalia and were generally ripe for a Changing Of The Subject.  Big Child, however, said "MOMMY!  Shame on you, you need to STOP saying balls and STOP talking about balls!  It's...inappropriate...for a woman to discuss these things!"   What?   Hotter and I both stopped laughing and gawked at Big Child.  "You just messed up," said Hotter.  "In fact, I'm going to move over here to where I am not between you and your mother..." and he did, too.   "Why," Big Child demanded belligerently.  He could tell he'd stepped in it, I think, but apparently decided to go down with his ship (he gets that from his father).   Everyone looked at me and I was still speechless.  "Be...cause you just made a sweeping generalization, and those are always offensive to someone, plus they're faulty logic," Hotter finally said, "and the one you made was a really bad choice on top of that in that you were talking about women, and your mother is a feminist who yells about faulty logic in her sleep.  Big mistake.  Huge."   "WELL IT'S THE TRUTH, WOMEN SHOULDN'T--"   At that point I regained the ability to speak and asked what women shouldn't do.   "Talk about...nasty things...like..."  Big Child trailed off and looked at me like I was some kind of idiot.   "Like balls?  Why shouldn't women talk about balls?  Because they don't have them?  Because that's nasty and women should only talk about nice things?"   "YES," said Big Child.  "Suitable things.  Balls are not suitable for women to discuss, especially mothers."   At that point Hotter really did cover his balls, and Middly even stopped chanting "BALLSballsballsballsBALLS!" and, when he saw the look on my face, looked over at Big Child as if he was waiting to see him vaporize on the spot.   "So by having a child, a woman gives up her right to discuss certain topics?  Is that what you're saying," I asked pleasantly (as I've mentioned before, I get extremely pleasant when I'm furious, more so than if I'm actually in a congenial mood, and it freaks people out and I am working on expressing anger in ways that others can more easily recognize).     "Well no, it's just that women who are mothers shouldn't--"   "STOP generalizing!  Do you really feel like you are at a point in your education where you can take and defend the position that all women or all mothers or all any group should or shouldn't do or say anything?  YOU ARE NINE, you don't get to say what anyone should or shouldn't, you get to say how YOU feel and ask grown-ups questions, and learn about things, and that is pretty much it," I reminded him.  "Make I statements.  What is this really about?  Tell me how YOU feel, and leave society and all women as a sex and all women who are mothers out of this."   "I...don't feel like y-y-youImeanMY mother, who is a woman, should talk about balls in front of me.  It makes me uncomfortable," Big Child said, looking rather deflated.  And yes, actually I did feel like an asshole, a little bit.   "Okay, that's better.  That's helping ME understand how YOU feel about a SPECIFIC situation, and I'm sorry that makes you uncomfortable.  I don't really enjoy discussing your father's junk either, and I hope it...the subject...doesn't come up again.  As your parent, though, and yes, your mother who is a woman, it is my job to say something if your four-year-old brother is getting ready to hit someone in their balls or anywhere else in my house whether either one of us like that or not."   "And I am happy to discuss anything with you, at any time, if you're uncomfortable talking about it with your mother, but that's not because I'm any better at explaining stuff than she is, that has to do with your level of comfort, not her level of knowledge about whatever it is or whether it is a suitable topic for her to discuss.  Period," Hotter chimed in (have I mentioned that I love him and plan to keep him?).  "Now who wants DESSERT?"     That was the end of the discussion, thankfully.  I was very relieved, and I'll admit that I felt a little...not out of my depth but...tenuous.  We were on new ground with that discussion, and honestly y'all you're prepared to hear "I hate you" and "you embarrass me" from your kids, and when there's a divorce involved you're even prepared (if you go to family therapy regularly) to confront qualities of your former spouse's in your children that may trigger you and not snap and do anything that rends the fabric of human decency, but...what I was not prepared for was for the raw, primordial components of a little baby misogynist to come together before my very eyes and rise up from the swamp to hiss at me.   This is troubling to me, y'all.  It isn't Big Child's fault that whatever he's exposed to when he is at his father's house or at school is causing him to flirt with fallacious reasoning and even outright chauvenism, nor is it mine, but it IS my job to Fix This Mess and raise him to be a more educated, rational, morally upright man than his father is and I plan to ask our family therapist for some pointers here before I go off half-cocked (ha!  I said cock!) and start reading him Betty Friedman and Sharon Olds at bedtime.   So.  Back to actual cocks and what to do about them in the avian context.  Not only do I have at least two cocks...
 Figure Two: Not a hen.   ...but I also have to figure out something to do with them, and now I'm worried about the message this is sending to the boys.  Because chickens aren't very good examples of gender relations as is appropriate in human society.  The hens really do pretty much sit around eating bon-bons and cranking out offspring:
  Figure Three: Speck really has gotten full of herself.  Also, chocolate is actually toxic to birds.     And the cocks...well, all they do is scream their fool heads off, fight, and fornicate, and then you have to either lock them up or send them away because they beat the hens up and the neighbors get tired of the ruckus and...okay, fine, chickens are a perfect example of gender relations circa my first marriage.    Balls.   Well anyway, here's what the chickens look like now:
  Figure Four: The one on the left is a hen.  The one on the right is...most likely not a hen...and today I feel perfectly capable of wringing its neck for that alone.   And how are all of YOU?*   No, my four-year-old has not seen The Silence of The Lambs, at least not at my house.  Hotter and I like to say "or it gets the hose" and he was probably copying that, although his father has seen fit to let him watch R-rated movies in the past, so who knows.  I seriously doubt he knew he was quoting anyone but Hotter.
title: in which the patriarchy rears its head at my house, or, simply: cocks and balls

body: *   This morning I took Hotter to see his new neurologist.  It takes a while to get in with them, see, and this was his first time seeing neurology since moving here.  This involved getting up heinously early and dropping the older two MFA Children at a neighbor's house to wait for it to be schoolbus time, going downtown, and dealing with the Major Teaching Hospital valets (remind me to tell you sometime about my ongoing jihad against the entire hospital parking system).*   I big-puffy-heart Hotter's new neurologist, who we'll call Dr. Brain.  Not only is he clearly excellent at what he does (he took a comprehensive history and discussed all the ways that Hotter's various health concerns could affect his seizure threshold, risk of another stroke, etc. and stopped in his exam to explain things to his resident then to us in layperson-friendly terms), but he's also a really nice guy (the first neurologist I've ever met who wasn't a flaming arsehole, actually) and rather amusing in that he clearly suffers from raging ADD.  After asking where Hotter was from he exclaimed "______ Park!  They have that crazy wooden roller-coaster there, I went with my summer-camp group when I was eleven, that thing is SCARY, what was it called, oh, heck, GOOGLE can tell us," and then proceeded to Google the amusement park in question muttering "c'mooooon, take me back, YES!"*   The only part of the appointment I didn't love was the part where Dr. Brain used an ultra-sensitive electronic stethoscope to listen to the blood flow in some major arteries having to do with Hotter's brain and then suddenly paused like a setter pointing at a game bird, yanked the earpieces out while holding the end of the stethoscope in place, handed them to his resident, and said "listen to this!"  It's never a good sign when they use you or your loved one as a teaching case.*   The long and short of it is that Hotter may need neurosurgery on a rather emergent basis, as in I am taking him back to Major Teaching Hospital tonight for an MRI/MRA and we may be doing this either instead of or in addition to the planned surgeries on Friday.  As Dr. Brain said, "SCREW the surgi-ma-callit-itis, the brain always takes priority and anesthesia won't put you to sleep for anything else until this is fixed anyway."*   There's still a chance that this isn't a majorly big deal, because while there is definitely Something Very Wrong, the problem is in one of two arteries, and if it's one then yes, immediate neurosurgery, but if it's the other the worst-case scenario is facial paralysis (and nobody wants to operate in this area over possible facial paralysis).  That would be a bummer, but not as much as another paralytic stroke would.*   I'm really glad, in retrospect, that we got bumped on Monday even though it sucked mightily at the time; if it's the one of the two arteries that would necessitate surgery then general anesthesia on Monday without knowing about this could have been catastrophic.  I am not, however, amused by these shenanigans in the least and would really like for the Universe to stop kicking my family in our collective junk.
title: in which this isn't all that funny anymore

body: We got there, and Hotter wasn't speaking to me because we were four minutes late, and then we sat around and waited for three hours due to a liver transplant underway that was tying up the transplant surgeons.  Then that apparently went south and they said they'd be a while and rescheduled us for Friday.  And the XY does NOT have the kids next weekend.     Good times!
title: rescheduled

body: The scans were clear.  Thank you all for your kind words, and please allow me to convey my thanks via this YouTube video that I've been laughing at intermittently for the past three days.     Seriously, it never stops being funny!  Surgi-ma-callit-ectomy, Take Two tomorrow at first light!  WHOO!* ETA: No, y'know, I actually don't know about the whole facial paralysis thing.  A nurse relayed the message to me after my second phone call to Neurology and specifically said "the interior carotid is PERFECT," and so I suppose the exterior carotid could be "perfect" or SHOT TO HELL but when you're talking about the possibility of an occluded or stenotic interior carotid artery in your loved one who already has a history of stroke, a fucked-to-hell exterior carotid starts to sound like a Get-Out-of-Jail-Free card, and I guess we'll find out eventually.  Tonight, we celebrate!
title: /freakout [ETA]

body: *   This time they actually did the surgi-ma-callit-ectomy.  Whoo!*   Unfortunately, they don't think Hotter really had true surgi-ma-callit-itis, and the transplant team doesn't know why he was hurting the way he was; they said to call THEM (not Dr. Kidney) if it happens again and most likely they'll try fixing the giant umbilical hernia he's got as a souvenir of his post-transplant appendectomy (they didn't do that today because it's so big they'll need to use mesh to close it, and putting synthetics in at the same time as the other stuff they did today is, apparently, begging for infection in an immunosuppressed patient).  BOO!*   The PCA seems to be controlling his pain pretty well and he has a nice nurse.  Whoo!*   So he's very boring.  Snoring thunderously even with an NG-tube and oxygen cannula in his nose (impressive, but...).  BOO!*   The hospital has wireless!  Whoo!*   This particular unit doesn't allow overnight guests and Hotter's going to be very displeased when he wakes up and finds that out (no, they're not willing to let him leave until tomorrow and even that is only if everything goes perfectly; the transplant surgeon laughed when I dutifully asked about that and said "he can be pissed off all he wants about it!").  BOO!*   How are all of you?
title: mixed bag

body: *   Hotter is home!  We picked him up at lunchtime, and the MFA Children and I were very glad to see him again.*   The MFA Flock is now five, not six.  Blondie (who is definitely Not a Hen) went to live on my in-laws' small farm in the Arctic Tundra when they left, and Loud and Crazy posted pictures on the facespace demonstrating that Blondie is alive and well in his new home.  Yay!  That still leaves us with Stripe (also Not a Hen), and of course the four Most-Likely-Hens.  Stripe can stay as long as he behaves himself (no ripping the hens' feathers out or all-night cock-a-doodling).*   ELEVEN MORE DAYS UNTIL THE PUPPY COMES HOME!  Oh gawd.*   OMG you guys, guess what!  I got my first "Dear Blogger" PR pitch!  I am super-stoked about that; now I can be all cool and "ZOMG you will not BELIEVE the PR pitch I got from this one place" at BlogHer like all the popular kids do.  Except that this is actually a company the MFA Family could do a kickass review for, so I e-mailed them back and we'll see if anything comes of it.*   I totally need to lose some a lot of weight.  Suddenly I'm more than twenty pounds above my happy number, and none of my pants fit.  I may or may not be wearing maternity yoga pants right now.*   We've been getting cucumbers from our garden lately, and they are very tasty.*   Our neighbor?  Who breeds pitbulls?  Is scared to DEATH of my chickens.  "They're birds," I reminded him.  "They got BIG BEAKS," he'll inform me in his baritone voice, looking terrified.  "You're over six feet tall and you breed pitbulls.  Doesn't it strike you as just a little bit ridiculous to fear chickens," I'll ask.  "My dogs are under CONTROL" he'll say, as if my chickens are out marauding, dealing drugs, and tagging the neighborhood.  This amuses me.
title: miscellaneous news and updates

body: I'm MFA Mama, and I'm a Facebook hater.   See, if I lose track of somebody?  Probably there's a good reason.  Also, while I love me some social media, I use a pseudonym on here and on Twitter, because I prefer to keep my full legal name OFF of the innernets.  Between my students and my ex-husband's lawyers, I am leery of "socializing" online under my full legal name; there's a big difference between going to a party at a friend's house and telling a funny story about a dumb thing you did, or your kids' latest mondegreen that sounds like a term from the porn industry, and publishing it online in your own words where anyone with OR without a sense of humor or context can read it.   So I have happily stayed OFF of Facebook, broadcast my opinion that if anyone ever saw me on there it was an imposter and/or probably meant the world was ending, etc.  Until.   The Wrath got a computer last week, and my brother-in-law sent Hotter (who also hates Facebook) a link to her Facebook page.  Oh dear.  So I reluctantly opened an account in order to keep an eye on The Wrath and "poke" my in-laws, and if you are reading this and already know who I actually am, maybe we can be friends.
title: probably the world is ending, and naturally it's all my fault

body: Yesterday Hotter, Little Child and I went to see Dr. Kidney, the local nephrologist who will be monitoring Hotter's after-market parts.  MFA City's rush-hour traffic did not amuse Little Child, who suggested that I simply run over the cars in our way.  I told him I couldn't do that unless I tricked the MFA Minivan out with a monster truck chassis.  He loved that idea and we decided that if we ever get rich and crazy enough to do it we should re-christen her "The Mominator."   I was very impressed with Dr. Kidney.  Hotter doesn't like her one little bit; he thinks she is a "battle-axe" because in flipping through his chart she grunted upon finding an old, old entry where he left a hospital AMA and said "non-compliant?  What's THAT mean?"  He also pointed out that the resident working with her (who in giving us the run-down of how the clinic handles transplant patients said "if you're ever admitted--ANYWHERE, FOR ANYTHING--you need to call and let Dr. Kidney know, because when people get admitted and they don't tell her she gets...very upset") was visibly quaking in her presence.  I think she is AWESOME and have a small crush now.    The woman doesn't even take crap from pigeons, y'all:  Figure One: Dr. Kidney dares the pigeons to try and crap on her electrified window ledge.   So naturally Hotter thought it would be hilarious if his potassium level came back in the "heart attack" range after yesterday's labs, and Dr. Kidney was all "here, have some powdered medication that refuses to dissolve in water, and do your best to mix it with water then wait for the wicked diarrhea to set in."   Dr. Kidney: 1/Hotter: 0.   Hotter tried to whine about this, but that got him nowhere because the transplant coordinator said it was that or Dr. Kidney'd stick an IJ line in his neck and run dialysis in the ER to pull the potassium out, and I was like "OMG DO NOT ANTAGONIZE THIS WOMAN, HOTTER!"  She wants him back in her office at 8 a.m. Monday, partly so that she can get the labs back quickly and partly I think because he tried to give her sass.   I could go off on Hotter on Dr. Kidney's behalf about how authoritative alpha-behavior in male doctors is reassuring and reflects competence but in female doctors it's being a bitch, except I don't think she needs my help; the woman has legitimate reasons to have her underlings stick things in his penis if he doesn't check hisself before he wrecks hisself.     And he knows this and is a big boy, so, yeah.  I'll keep y'all posted.
title: the one where Hotter's new nephrologist PWNs him

body:
*   Those of you who don't follow me on the Twitter missed a bunch of drama at Club Med over the weekend.  Basically Hotter's one kidney got lazy with clearing him of the anesthesia meds, and we had to take him off IV pain relief for a bit and then he had withdrawal and for a while it looked like he was going to end up vented in ICU or else maybe there was a problem with his kidney but then he got his act together and we came home last night.  WHEW!*   I couldn't update here because my free year of Typepad that I won over at Winecat's place ran out and I couldn't make a payment from Club Med (well, I could have I guess, but their network wasn't secure so I elected not to chance it).  I apologize to those of y'all who left comments that didn't show up; I couldn't approve them.*   Also when I tried to update the billing information I kept getting a message that what I'd been trying to do had failed for unknown reasons, and then Typepad was all "yeah, you have to switch to the NEW Typepad to make that change."  Which, well, why not just say so in the error message instead of "unknown reasons" if you know that's what it is?  So I switched to the new Typepad and added my billing information and then switched back, because I hate the new Typepad with a white-hot passion.  It's not better than old Typepad, just different and, in my humble opinion, not as intuitive or user-friendly.  Ptooey, ptooey, ptooey!*   At some point we need to talk about the personality transplant The XY has apparently received courtesy of benevolent aliens, because not only did he take the MFA Children for Hotter's surgery and keep them longer than planned due to Hotter trying to up and die on me, but he also VOLUNTARILY kept them an extra night just because (which was more than fine with me because I got a total of maybe thirteen hours' sleep in seventy-two hours and was a wreck last night when they were supposed to come home) and hasn't yelled at me or called me names in WEEKS.  At first it was super-nice and I guess it still is, but it's also more than a little bit creepy.  I'm not complaining, exactly, it's just very unsettling to have him be polite, reasonable, and interested in being a father after a solid decade of pleas to abort, domestic abuse, and legal/financial murder/suicide on his part.  Now I'm the arsehole if I question his motivation and don't relax certain boundaries given his new attitude, so I'm playing along, but I also don't trust the SOB and keep waiting for the boom to drop.*   Motherfucking Poe BIT ME.  I guess it's my fault for not handling him much as we prepared for Hotter's surgery (and we were gone for a couple of days) but damn, yo, I saved your life!  I mean yeah, I knew damn well he was a snake, but...as terri c. noted, it's like Poe is holding the XY's personality for him.  Which he can keep doing, since Poe is easier to contain than the XY, but I miss the nice, latent homosexual creature I rescued from the mean streets and...OMG it is JUST LIKE my first marriage!  I'm wondering if this means that I should get rid of Poe, or whether I'm reading too much into this, or...gah!  Anyway it TOTALLY broke the skin but I've kept Mupirocin on it and that stuff kills everything so hopefully it won't get infected.  That would really suck.  *   Middle Child has had a birthday (his sixth), and was very depressed and saying he was a bad boy, didn't deserve to have a birthday, and would give away any presents he received to his brothers or Hotter because Middly = bad.  Which is just so VERY untrue; Middly is the best-behaved MFA Child most days.  The XY has even noticed this and mentioned it to me, and Hotter and I are addressing it with the family therapist, but this is almost as awkward as it is sad because I think most of Middly's ennui is him feeling "guilty" for telling on the XY for doing some heinous things that other grownups ABSOLUTELY needed to know about during the ugly days of the divorce.  Which I can't exactly say to the XY, who sees himSELF as the victim in all of this (or seemed to last time we spoke of that hot mess, by which I mean the last time he screamed at me about it in a police station parking lot).  Gah!  Anyway clinically depressed six-year-olds are really heartbreaking, desperate times call for desperate measures, and we got Middly a puppy for his birthday.  *   Puppies always win; Middle Child decided right there on the spot that he would keep at least this one gift.  Hotter and I have been planning this since before the mama dog was even bred (our next-door neighbor is the breeder) and I've wanted to get the boys (especially Middle Child, given that kids with developmental delays can really benefit from animal companions) a dog for a while, it was just never a good time what with my traveling back and forth to see Hotter before we got married and me working and probably it'll never be a "good" time but on July 12th Casa MFA will get that much crazier (that's when MFA Puppy 
will be seven weeks old and ready to come home).  Plus look, aww:
  Figure One: No really, AWW!  Yes, she is a pitbull.  Try not to be terrified, I realize she is very fierce-looking.  They're wonderful family dogs if you treat them well and this breeder raises show dogs, not fighters.  I know some of you are probably wondering why I didn't get a pound puppy or rescue dog, and under different circumstances I absolutely would, but with an organ-transplant recipient on immunosuppressive drugs, two children with developmental delays, and one child with a weak native immune system in the house, it was absolutely necessary to not only know our prospective dog's entire social history but also their medical history from day one in order to have this be safe for the entire family.
title: catch-up and a new family member

body:
*   I had managed to blame two days of exceptionally shitty runs on my running partner (Bumpus seems to really want/need plenty of stretching for those Fraggle-arm-esque legs of his and has become my running shadow, both to satisfy his need for "speed" and also to make Hotter feel better about me running at night with earbuds in).
*   I think my gut knew better than my head though, because yesterday I had this desperate urge to get caught up on the backlog of cooking requests I'd built up from the MFA Children while working for Very Nice Company. I made the chicken soup and pumpkin pie Little Child was wanting, the homemade noodles Middle Child was craving, the fresh, fluffy bread and home-churned ice cream Big Child had begged for...Middle Child and I rolled peanut butter "cookie dough" balls for the ice cream before I added duck eggs to the rest of the dough and baked it into my famous peanut butter cookies...I even made myself a pan of kugel because I hadn't had it in forever. 
*   Well-played, gut. You called it. I am sick as a DOG today. Like, as in "swollen up hugely, earache, congestion WTH" sick and hating life. Which...well. You can probably imagine how much I'm enjoying this. BALLS!
*    Figure One: Oh, Mint.com. I know you're new around here and have only ever known life with me employed by Very Nice Company, but let me explain a few things, okay honey?

body:
*   I had a really sweet run earlier tonight. I went a bit too fast, but didn't hurt myself and I got that runner's high...ahhh ENDORPHINS! I need to get one of those air-warmer mask things now that the air is getting chilly, though. 
*   I struck out at Goodwill. Found a couple of skirts that'll be good for if I GET the job, but nothing interview-fabulous. Fortunately there was a perfect pair of slacks in one of the Freecycle bags I picked up last week, but I'm ambivalent about my shirts. I have one striped shirt that I think will do...I'm going to try the entire outfit on tomorrow morning after the boys are off to school and if I'm not thrilled there's time before the interview to run to Target. 
*   There is a motherfucking mouse in the house (specifically Hotter's and my bedroom somewhere) and it is UNACCEPTABLE. Hotter and I disagree on this. He thinks I should leave the poor mouse alone. I think the little bastard is carrying Hanta-virus around looking for someone to give it to, and his habit of scurrying around our bedroom (remarkably LOUDLY for such a tiny critter) gnawing on things (what things? WHY SO LOUD? WHAT THE HELL?) is just...well it's DISRESPECTFUL. They're supposed to be AFRAID. Maybe it's rabid? Hotter and I can be in here having a conversation and we'll hear a scuttle and a pitter-patter of tiny feet and...well I baited the Havahart trap last week and this asshole wanted NOTHING TO DO WITH IT and today I just SNAPPED (oh haha, keep reading) and put out a snap-trap with peanut butter smeared on the bait-tray. Hotter, meanwhile, is trying to talk me into taking that up because he has named the mouse Frank and doesn't want anything bad to happen to his little friend. FRANK HAD HIS CHANCE TO TAKE THE EASY WAY OUT TO THE WOODS IN THAT HAVAHART TRAP, HOTTER. If I hear the snap-trap go off I will seriously come in my pants, I hate this effing mouse THAT MUCH.
*   Yeah, I actually said that. 
*   How are all of YOU?
title: run, outfit, mouse

body:
*   I've been sleepy all day. This morning after the boys left Hotter and I went and got the oil changed and the tires rotated on the MFA Minivan, and its' blown headlamp replaced. The couch in the mechanic's waiting room would've been perfect for spooning on had it not been in public. Dang it. I took a nap after we got back but still...sleepy.
*   There's drama with the XY's pending nuptials. Apparently HE wants a pre-nup (I...okay. I mean...he has nothing and is neutered and she's a rich idiot who's already dumb enough to be signing up to spend a six-month childless-divorce waiting period the rest of her life as the third Mrs. XY...I...this just breaks my brain, sorry, go on without me) and they're having a hard time putting together enough lawyers an affair to remember on less than two weeks' planning time or something.
