They seem pretty impressed with my brainstorming/problem-solving abilities, too:
Co-worker #1: Hey MFA Mama, could you call the maintenance guy on duty to lift this giant suitcase full of books over the hallway to the carpet on the other side for me, please? If I drag it I'm afraid it'll scratch the hallway floor and The Boss will kill me.
Co-worker #2: He's REALLY busy. He says he's gonna throw something at the next person to ask him to do ANYTHING. Have fun with that!MFA Mama: How about you just drag it REALLY FAST and if anybody asks we'll all say we have NO idea who did it?Co-worker #2: MUCH better plan!Co-worker #1: Ummmyeah except there's probably a camera that would capture my face.Co-worker #2: Riiiight. Crap.MFA Mama: You both give up too easily. Here's what you do, Co-worker #1, for occasions such as this. You carry a ketchup packet on your person at all times, and if you absolutely MUST drag something heavy across a freshly-polished floor on camera you squirt a little behind each ear and under your chin, make sure the camera gets a GOOD look, and then you call in and you have to sound really BEAT UP and you tell The Boss a masked assailant hit you over the head and STOLE YOUR FACE like in The Silence of The Lambs, and because he has that sense of context he'll believe you. But then you have to disappear for a few weeks, and you can pretty much only use this once.
Co-worker #1: Wow. I... *wanders off looking dazed*
Co-worker #2: You? Are brilliant. I bet she's going to the cafeteria to get a ketchup packet.

DISCLAIMER:  WHAT FOLLOWS IS A HUMOROUS AND SATIRICAL AND OH WHY NOT, LET'S CALL IT "FICTIONAL" ACCOUNT BASED ON ACTUAL EVENTS FROM MY DAY, AND NOT A SWORN AFFIDAVIT OR ATTEMPT AT A TRUE AND ACCURATE REPRESENTATION OF ABSOLUTE FACT.     Remember what I said about coping through inappropriate humor?  Yeah, well.  Today in family therapy we found out what it takes to get me to stop laughing.   Namely one of my children putting on a remarkable one-man revisionist history improv performance (because these firm limits and predictable consequences are cheesing him off royally) and convincing the counselor that I'm doing the wrong kind of wrong (see, I'll own that what I'm doing when I am at the end of my rope is wrong for the kid, because this isn't my first couch-rodeo, but what the kid ACCUSED me of was losing it in spectacular screamy fashion à la XY whereas what I actually do is, as Hotter corroborated and the therapist then got to witness, get very, very unnaturally calm and pleasant and even-toned, which is probably even creepier).  And y'all, having spent the past two years tying myself in very ouchy and unflattering knots to avoid being accused of any sort of abusive treatment of my children by the XY's lawyers in a court of law (why?  Well good question seeing as how nobody seems to give a rip in this state if a biological parent actually DOES beat the holy crap out of a small child and the child tells the authorities what happened AND it turns your kids into basket cases*), the kid accusing me of every fault of his father's that I've ever tried to shield him from to an authority figure totally screwed with my ladylike composure.   Unfortunately, I couldn't do what I usually do after getting very calm and pleasant and even-toned (tell the kids I'm running out to check the mail, collapse sobbing into the kids' little red wagon on the front porch for five minutes, and wear my sunglasses into the house from there) because I left my mailbox at home, so I ended up following several excellent "I-statements" with an f-bomb, bursting into tears in FRONT of the therapist (but not, at least, my kid, who he'd sent to the waiting room) and calling my kid a dick.   This week's lesson from family therapy: psychologists get awfully judgy when you call eight-year-olds dicks.  They also don't appreciate it when, in getting your LOLJK game-face back on before checking on your children in the waiting room, you (jokingly!) deny allowing your ghosts of abusers past to tinge your perception of current events and say "no no, this is what I'm like AFTER four years of individual therapy for that!  I'm better, I swear--I haven't cut anyone in AGES!"   Imma go rest on my laurels now, and by "rest on my laurels" I mean "sulk on my front porch in the little red wagon, LIKE A GROWNUP." *   If my ex-husband's lawyers are reading this, for all YOU know I was talking about my own mother, but if your client recognizes himself in my writing and wants to say so in front of a judge then have at it, although I'd ask that you try and append it to one of this month's pre-existing hearings, because I could only afford a three-pack of pantyhose for the month's family court dates with the April support check after paying the therapy co-payments, okay?  Thanks!

Ooookay, so back a couple of days ago before my own eye-doctor dropped the boom on me about my vision, I was bouncing-off-the-walls kind of happy because I had arranged to bring you a truly awesome giveaway.
   As y'all know, I had to let some things slide due to finances...things like prescription eyeglasses (and of course the tooth, which is getting permanently fixed TOMORROW thanks to the wonderful people over at Brighter and my friend Morgan), and I know a lot of y'all are probably struggling, too. So when Eye Buy Direct asked me if I wanted to do a review and giveaway where I would get a free pair of eyeglasses for myself and one for a reader I was allll over that!
   I was a little curious how it would all work, but it was surprisingly simple. I got my vision checked (well okay, there was nothing simple about that for ME but chance are YOU will have better results), and had my doctor give me a copy of my prescription (which was greek to me, but I just made sure I could read all of the letters and numbers). She mentioned that when you buy eyeglasses online you often need to know your PD (pupillary distance) and had me go and get that measured by a nice lady who gave me two different numbers, but also explained that if the website I was using asked for one number I could get that by adding the two. With my prescription in-hand I went home to look at some glasses!
   The selection on the website was pretty extensive, but my biggest reservation had to do with how I would tell what would look good on my face. I've been wearing glasses since I was two, and have therefore picked out enough pairs to know that what looks good on the shelf doesn't necessarily look good on your face (in fact, sometimes it will make you look like a bug-eyed stick insect...or worse, your own elderly grandmother). This is where it got SUPER-cool, though--YOU CAN TRY THE GLASSES ON ONLINE by either capturing a picture with your webcam or uploading one that you have in digital format! I decided to use my webcam since I was already wearing glasses in all of the pictures I already had of me, and GET THIS: the website estimated my pupillary distance from the webcam capture! It wasn't exactly what the optometrist who took mine in-person got with her machine, but it was very, very close and I was impressed that the website was able to do that.
   Y'all know how I am about maintaining my pseudonymity, so I can't show you a picture of my new glasses on MY face. I did, however, find a member of the MFA Family who didn't mind modeling them:
 Figure One: I thought models weren't supposed to eat??? She snarfed a TON of liversnacks during our photo-shoot. Also, apparently we have the same pupillary distance? Or else possibly the dogface threw off the program. Which means that if you're ordering glasses online for your dog you may want to have someone check that in person. Oh, god, nobody is ever going to work with me on a giveaway again, are they?
   I was going to wait until my glasses arrived to actually post this, but then I decided to see if Eye Buy Direct participated in eBates and LO! When you go on eBates' site and search for the company you can not only get 7% cashback (not that it's much, because these are incredibly cheap eyeglasses, but every little bit, right?) but ALSO 20% off your order with an eBates-only coupon code through the end of the month, and I didn't want those of y'all who don't win to miss out on that deal if you really need some new glasses! body:
I don't know why, y'all, but today when several co-workers came bustling out to the lobby with the news that Robert Wood Jr. was found alive I about lost it. I hadn't been following the story very closely, because I avoid the news for the sake of my mental health most of the time, but oh, y'all, my heart. It wasn't so much that he'd been found that got to me (although obviously I was relieved to hear it, especially with the weather all over the South going to shit today), it was the way everyone was talking about him.
   "He was probably hiding from the searchers, those autistic kids are a handful!"
   "I'll bet it's because he's autistic that he survived. A normal child wouldn't have had the animal instincts." (yes, someone SAID that)
   "They say he probably didn't know he'd been lost, or even notice; those kids aren't all there."
   I get that most people don't "get" autism. Hell, I'm not even claiming to fully "get" Robert Wood Jr.'s type of autism; my two boys on the spectrum are both verbal, and made so much progress with therapy that both of them have mainstreamed successfully from kindergarten. It's apples to oranges, and I'm not trying to pull up a soapbox and be all "I am the Lorax, I speak for the autistic kids!" But after a couple of gentle attempts to correct some of the more egregious misconceptions I had to mentally take a step back and shut my trap on the matter, because I was about to lose my junk and say something really scathing.
   I don't know what I'm trying to say here, except that I'm really glad that little guy is safe and warm with his family tonight, and I wish everyone would just say that and no more about the matter.

body:
*   Another looooong day at the office. I have truly never worked with such a nice group of people though, to the point that it's almost creepy. I haven't seen anyone get angry or visibly frustrated, heard one word of ill out of anyone's mouth about a fellow employee, caught the rough side of anybody's temper...and that's everyone on up the foodchain, too (part of my job is to run the mailroom and deliver messages and documents, so I see everybody daily). The company even stocks a sweet basket (Tootsie Pops and miniature candybars and full-size cereal bars as well as mints and gum and jawbreakers), a salty basket (bags of various chips, packets off peanut-butter crackers, etc.), a fruit basket, and a single-dose over-the-counter medication basket for the employees! There are complimentary Torani syrups by the coffee machine in the break room and bottles of water in the fridge...hell, today someone gifted me with a large basket of fresh-dug sweet potatoes, for crying out loud. They're generous with office supplies, eager to know whether your chair is comfortable enough, nobody minds if you take your iPhone everywhere with you and listen to Pandora while you work as long as you use earbuds...I am getting a cold and three different higher-ups noticed me sniffling and urged me to take the day of tomorrow if I'm not feeling 100%. Seriously, where is the catch? And when the mothership comes to beam these benevolent aliens back up and take them back to their home planet, can I go with them?
*   I haven't heard anything from CATHERINE! today (she was supposed to be e-mailing me some pictures of the destroyed vehicle and the XY's head; the boys are anxious to see the damage) and I'm actually a little worried since she said the doctors told her the XY's concussion would get worse before it got better. Hopefully he's making a speedy recovery and has merely forbidden her to speak to me, and he'll soon be back at work earning child support money and oozing his misleading charm all over anyone who doesn't run away fast enough. I keep having to remind myself not to feel too sorry for the SOB; just because he almost succeeded in killing his damnfool self doesn't mean he isn't as evil as ever.
*   Hotter and I got to giggling last night when I said CATHERINE! sounded like she was kind of hoping we'd offer to babysit her concussed adult toddler (and his elderly and very ill father, who he's apparently been taking care of)...he was like "hey, if somebody'd pay me I'd take 'em, I've already got the boys and the dogs and the chickens, what's two more? I'd have 'em in bed by eight-thirty, too! You'd call home to check on us and I'd be like 'Hi honey, we're good LITTLE CHILD DON'T HIT YOUR GRANDFATHER! Everybody had their gruel and I'm about to turn them out into the yard for a b--XY, that's two and if you get to three your Blackberry will go in the no-no bag!'" Maybe you had to be there but I seriously about died laughing.
*   I really hope I don't wake up sick as a dog. For all that I'm hating the long days, the money really is fantastic and by not having a scheduled day off during this pay-period I'm poised to rake in some truly obscene overtime.

Meh is for people who everyone follows so I followed them and then they followed me and now I don't want to offend them by unfollowing, and people who lurve me but I'm just not that into them and I don't want to HURT them by unfollowing. body:
Figure One: Today, * represents time spent talking to my ex-husband's girlfriend and parents.
   So my phone was blowing up at work, and I finally picked it up, irritated, to a rather hysterical CATHERINE! The XY nodded off behind the wheel of her truck this afternoon and flipped it five times a few hundred yards from her house; she was pretty convinced he was going to die.
   I told CATHERINE! not to worry, that the XY is basically a human cockroach and you can't kill the arsehole with a meat cleaver, gave her his blood type and SSN just in case and tried to get back into my data-entry groove. But I kept getting texts asking for his mother's phone number, etc. (which I couldn't look up at work because using the office computers for anything but business is a big no-no and I have all of those people blocked on the facespace), and after I spent fifteen minutes in the hallway bellowing at my ex-father-in-law (for whom English is not his first, or even his second or third language and who also sufffers from dementia) to get him to have the XY's mother (who is evil personified and still, as of this afternoon, a huge bitch) call me so that I could get her number for CATHERINE! (I didn't have it in me to give her CATHERINE'S number and therefore unleash her on the poor woman, and I know from experience that the Local Teaching Hospital ED has shitty reception anyway), I finally gave in to my coworkers' entreaties that I take the rest of the day off and went home in high dudgeon.
   The XY is going to be fine; he apparently has a huge laceration up the back of his head (which sucks for him since he rocks the totally bald look and couldn't grow enough hair to cover it if he tried), diminished breath sounds (so possible pneumo/hemothorax, I'm guessing), and a probable broken shoulder. Wah.
   Lest you think me entirely heartless, I surprised myself by actually feeling sorry for the XY, because apparently he and CATHERINE! are on the rocks and as of the last time I spoke to her, she was disgusted with him for flipping her truck and then crying about it like a big bitch-baby. I was actually kind of appalled to hear that she was leaving him in the hospital by himself because "if I keep looking at that head-wound I will THROW UP, I've already reassured him that he isn't dying, GAWD!" I mean, I know what it's like to be in the hospital alone and scared and afraid you're dying, mostly because the XY left ME in those very circumstances on several occasions (at one point actually bitching that I hadn't arranged childcare, necessitating his early departure from his workplace, and informing me that he was "out of sympathy" -- that was actually the exact moment when I stopped loving him), but still. The poor asshole's never spent the night in Club Med or even had an IV and is usually pretty much impervious to pain (physical or emotional). It made me feel bad to hear that he was crying.
   Just not bad enough to actually drive downtown and fuss over him.
   I'm really hoping that tomorrow * will represent time spent fapping or having a quickie with my husband. Or at least something that doesn't involve someone else's medical emergency. A girl can dream, right?
 
P.S. The MFA Children are fine. I brought a box of doughnuts home from work (a co-worker brought them in for everyone and there were extras that they sent me home with) and they were pretty much like "he's not dead? Okay, may we please have our doughnuts now?" They're mostly just bummed that the truck didn't burst into flames, and that they won't get their weekly fast-food fix at Daddy Dinner Visitation (I dunno if the XY will even be out of the hospital by Wednesday, much less up to taking three children anywhere).

body:
*   I have never successfully done a chin-up of the literal variety (too many broken arms I guess?) (meaning too many breaks to my TWO arms; I do not have any extra ones, dammit), but usually I'm pretty good about the metaphorical kind and so I'm trying. I'm really, really trying with the help of family, friends, and retail therapy. I'm just not having a ton of success.
*   I'm still pretty damn lucky. I crawled into bed and had a good cry, and then when the MFA Children got home from school Big Child knew I needed a hug (suddenly it's like hugging a PERSON--no stooping! THE HELL?) and asked me what was wrong. I explained the bare bones of the situation and my kids set about cheering me up. Big Child reminded me that I wouldn't have to see his ugly Bumpus-hound anymore if I go blind. Middle Child said he'd take care of me--"I'll stay wiv you ALL your life until you die, Mommy, and I'll do everything except wipe your butt!" And Little Child reminded me that sometimes the blind develop super powers ("YOU CAN BE LIKE DAREDEVIL!"). Friends loved all over my comments and Twitter feed. Dr. Anon dragged clinical details out of me via the Facespace and located a clinical trial for treating the second eye condition that came up today that seems pretty promising (and really, that is huge because while the first eye condition is definite and bad and can make you go blind, there are some non-surgical treatments...the second one there was nothing as of when my father was diagnosed ages ago and I was under the impression that that was still the case). And Hotter...well, Hotter did what one of us always does when the other one receives some devastating medical news and reminded me not to be a pussy all my life, and it did in fact make me giggle as did his suggestion that I use Loud and Crazy the turkey as a service animal. Even I with my stupid brokedick eyes can see how loved I am, and that is a beautiful thing.
*   As far as retail therapy, I did in fact choose and order those new glasses, and while it's not much consolation for the prospect of losing my eyesight, the iPhone is still pretty badass. Plus I hit Goodwill to pick up some work clothes (the new, obscenely high-paying job requires business attire and I am sick and tired of popping out of my shirts and wearing Hotter's khakis) and the thrift-shopping gods smiled on me: two pairs of Talbot's slacks with stretch in my size that looked brand new, a very cute dress that WAS brand new (tag and all), and a button-down that ought to contain my rack. Whoo tits! 
*   Tomorrow I start the new job, and it's twelve-hour days six days a week so I might be a sucky blogger for the next month or so (yes, it's a MONTH instead of just three weeks, which means that in addition to making one-third of last year's earned income in one month I'll be eligible for unemployment should I need it after it's over, although I doubt that I will because there'll be a bunch of holiday parties and such needing banquet servers and I've got clients at two of the three temp agencies now who specifically request me when they need a worker). Someone should probably tell my feelings that this full box of Triscuits they're making me eat are going to cause me to crap a two-by-four tomorrow at the office; I've tried but they just gave me a withering look.
*   I'm still so damn sad, and the distractingly compromised vision in my left eye (which I was able to ignore previously because I was certain I just needed new glasses) isn't helping matters. How are all of YOU?
title: chin up

body:
You know how stuff on the top shelf of a disorderly closet closed on a mess will all fall on your head if you open the door?
   My life is kind of doing that right now.
   Today we got a visit from the local zoning compliance officer. Even though Casa MFA is zoned agricultural, they still prosecute if you have chickens or other "farm animals" on a plot under three acres (I thought it was under ONE). Ours is 2.7 and therefore barring a very slim chance that we can get grandfathered all of the poultry have to go pretty much immediately. They can't reveal the identity of the complainer but the (shockingly nice and very apologetic) zoning guy said the complainer was really weird in the way they made the complaint and refused to give their name or callback number and he got the impression they weren't from around here. Oh, Stalky, that was so mean of you!
   Plenty of other things went wrong today, including something someone did absentmindedly that caused a chain-reaction of bank fees that will be one costly clusterfuck, my locking myself out of the MFA Minivan on my lunchbreak (with my wallet inside so that I could neither hire a locksmith nor prove ownership of the vehicle in order to get the police to help me out) while shocked by the awful poultry and financial news, which arrived together while I was in the ATM line, work announcing that while they want to try and keep me on until late November they'll be cutting my hours starting next week, and BUMPITY BUMPITY OUCH OH GOD DAMN IT ALL RIGHT STRAIGHT TO HELL SUDDENLY EVERY ANXIOUS THOUGHT I HAVE EVER HAD HAS COME HOME TO ROOST.
   I was literally scared to drive home from work because I was certain that between the way today was going and the rain I'd wreck the damn minivan; a coworker literally had to shoo me from my seat at my desk with assurances that whatever I was working on (which unbeknownst to them was pretty much JUST a small nervous breakdown at that point) could wait until tomorrow, and when the XY was late returning the MFA Children from dinner visitation I was certain he'd managed to wreck again with them in his car.
   Obviously I made it home safely, and so did the MFA Children or I would be in no fit state to post a thing, but it sure does feel like nothing will ever been good again. Hotter and I are both really upset (as are the children, but honestly I think the grownups are taking it harder) about our birds, and hating that we can't move to his hometown with them (my mother in law, who is a saint, is bringing a truck from several states away and taking the MFA Flock to her farm), and wondering if we'll ever stop getting nasty surprises from Stalky, whose ability to screw with my life I thought I'd eliminated by changing career fields. Now I wonder if I don't also need to change my damn name and move, and oh yeah maybe just get the hell off of the innernet permanently and stop sharing any little goddamn thing at all about my life with the general public (I hesitated even to talk about the poultry thing at all to try and avoid giving Stalky the satisfaction, but I think y'all would notice if I never mentioned the birds again).
   I doubt I'll do that, and I'm sure tomorrow will be better (although I will not tempt fate by doubting that it could possibly be worse), and I'll be fine because I always am, but...today can pretty much fuck right on off and die in a tire fire.
title: bumpity bumpity

body:
*   I am doing a review and giveaway that is SO amazing...I'm excited for me and for whoever among you gets to win it! I can't do it justice right now so I won't even try, but look for that post soon and the upshot for me PERSONALLY is that I get a free pair of prescription glasses (my first in nearly six years--yes I have had these frames AND these lenses for that long)!
*   I just got a job offer from Temp Agency #1 in which I will make as much money per week as I usually do in a month of working fulltime for the next three weeks. Obviously that is a wonderful thing.
*   Then after work today, which finished early, I went to the eye doctor to get my prescription checked (I was pretty sure it had changed a lot, since my vision has started to suck pretty badly) and found out I'm going blind. Yeah. BLIND. Not maybe, and not even from ONE progressive eye disease, OH NO, but TWO of them. The first one was not a surprise, since I have it on both sides of my family, but the youngest person on either side to need treatment was in their late forties so I wasn't expecting to hear at thirty-three that the eye doctor was just SO terribly sorry my corneal issues rule me out as a candidate for any type of eye surgery and I needed to start medication for it immediately like RIGHTNOW. The second one she was more like "I...yeah...I don't even have the EQUIPMENT to tell you what kind of ____ it is, you'll need laser retinal mapping for that, but it's DEFINITELY ____" and when my face fell because I had heard of _____ before she consolingly said "well, but...in RARE cases it's JUST A CATARACT!" in a "hey, maybe you won the lottery, wouldn't THAT be exciting!" kind of tone and I looked at her and said "wouldn't a cataract need--" and her face fell. "Surgery. I...I'm very sorry. The good news is that treatment won't change you prescription, so you can go ahead and order those free glasses," she finished lamely. "I just don't have the machine in my office to measure your pupils, so you'll have to go inside to the optical shop" (this was the eye doctor at the local Big Box Store). I took my prescription and left, feeling numb, and the numbness lasted until I couldn't find my membership card and went to get a new one. "No problem," said the clerk, "I just need to see your driver's license and I'll give you a new card." I went to get that and there was the membership card (which I'd searched my wallet for three times already) and I started to say "oh, whoops, I guess maybe I'm just--" and I was going to say "blind" and instead kind of sobbed in her face. "It's okay! That happens to a lot of people, I see it at least once a day...?" said the membership clerk, before she realized that clearly I wasn't really beating myself up about the card and was instead in the midst of an acute mental health challenge. I didn't even try to explain myself, just walked away.
*   So I bought myself an iPhone. As a consolation present. 
*   It didn't work. I am still really, really depressed and now I ALSO don't know how to work my phone.
title: the one where I knew my life was going too well lately

body:
*   The poultry (at least most of the poultry) can stay! It turns out that we just have to file some paperwork and pay a $75 filing fee to have domestic fowl on less than three acres on an agricultural-zoned property in our locale. We'll be limited to a dozen birds, so we're still sending some to the Arctic Tundra with The Wrath (who is coming early next week to fetch them). The ones who go will include both roosters and the loudest cacklers among the hens, and hopefully that will pacify the neighbors (if in fact it was a neighbor and not Stalky who complained). With the number we keep we'll have plenty of eggs for our family (although we will have to stop giving dozens away to neighbors, which under the circumstances given that maybe it WAS one of them I will not feel bad about). Y'all, I did not want to admit how upset I would have been if we'd had to get rid of all of the birds; they're a large part of why we love living where we do and more than just a source of eggs, meat and feathers. They're FUN. SO happy about not having to get rid of them all!
*   I got word that I get to keep my current lovely job (which is through Temp Agency #1) until late November! They're cutting my hours, but only down to 8-5 Monday through Friday, which will be a welcome change as I'll get to have dinner with my family and do homework with the boys, as well as sleep an extra hour in the mornings. I have weekend work lined up for two coming weekends through Temp Agencies 2 and 3, which will be good as we're trying to save for an inexpensive second vehicle I can drive to and from work and such when we don't need the passenger capacity of the MFA Minivan to save on gas. Also, the day job through Temp Agency #1 lasting as long as it is means I'll be eligible for unemployment when it's over should I need it (I hope not to need it, but better to have it as an option and not need it than need it and not have it as an option, right?).
*   A fabulous reader informed me that I could change my signature in the iPhone so that now instead of "sent from my iPhone" it says "sent from The Precious." This tickles me to no end!
*   I do NOT have anything lined up through any temp agencies for THIS weekend, which means that I get to spend it entirely with my husband. We plan to give our mower a tuneup (new spark plug and air filter), mow the lawn, and spoon a lot. 
*   How are all of YOU? I do genuinely want to know when I ask. Talk to me!
title: good news: yay!

body: Well, yesterday didn't manage to be any WORSE than the day before, but it also wasn't any BETTER. I somehow got the last dose of Clindamycin stuck halfway down, or maybe it was lodged in the pouch of my hiatal hernia? I dunno, but it was awful. Seriously one of the top five most excruciating things I've ever felt, right up there with "open fracture" and "gallstones." I spent all of yesterday snowed on Benadryl and Vicodin, taking Zofran and trying to sleep through my misery, since I decided calling in sick was less foolhardy than trying to leave the house while desperately unwell and functioning on a night of zero sleep. Someone tell me a funny, please. I'm back at work today with what feels like the world's worst heartburn and a crummy attitude.

Y'know how you clean when you have in-laws coming? I know I'm not the only one who does this. I mean, not that we live in squalor or anything but our usual "lived-in, one person works fulltime-and-then-some and the other juggles three kids and various animals and also is technically kind of disabled" look, which normally doesn't bother me, starts to make my lower eyelid twitch when my mother-in-law (who don't get me wrong, I LOVE) is coming below the Mason-Dixon line. And then every sphincter in my body puckers up and I see a dust-bunny somewhere and...you know that scene from Downfall that's been parodied by everyone and their dog to the point that there's a parody where Hitler reacts to all of the parodies? Well, it's like that, but without my having the technical wherewithal to jury-rig some subtitles especially for this occasion.
   Poor Hotter.
   So naturally I decided, in all of my infinite wisdom, that this afternoon was a fine time to get my annual flu shot (and tweet my annual flu-shot tweet). Never mind that I already feel like ass because of the ongoing GI fiasco, no, what I clearly needed was A SORE ARM! 
   Oh well. When push comes to shove I need the flu like I need a hole in my head and I guess I don't regret getting the shot today, since I don't have a ton of time off in my future and flu season is upon us. I think Imma swallow my pride and take it easy tonight. How are all of YOU?
title: the one with the flu shot

body:
*   My friend lives! I hadn't exactly planned to update the blog but I know y'all worry. She's feeling rather sluggish and "blah" but her gums aren't pale, her heartrate is within normal limits, and she isn't short of breath so while her H&H probably took a hit based on what she's seen, there's no reason to think she's in any great danger. Best of all, she's having less pain with swallowing than yesterday, so things appear to be healing in there. She's hoping she's dodged the bullet and that this will heal up nicely and not need any sort of intervention at all, but just getting through the weekend without an emergency is a wonderful thing in and of itself and she's grateful for that.
*   The poultry drama continues as Hotter and I make some tough calls on who stays and who goes. We're going to be limited to twelve birds, total, which means that Hotter's and my differences in how we view livestock (namely that they're more pets and individuals to him and more mouths to feed/utility critters to me) have gone from "amusing" to "causing some friction." The ducks in particular have become a bone of contention, in that I think keeping the pair that's bonded and sending the two extra girlducks (who seem to have more a relationship of necessity than a true pair bond, like prison-spouses) to The Wrath is reasonable and Hotter wants to keep them all. I wouldn't have a problem with that if it weren't for the twelve-bird limit, but we really don't use that many duck eggs, so...yeah. We're already keeping a lot of non-laying birds because of the turkeys and Hotter's beloved silver-laced Wyandottes (who don't yet lay). Ugh!
*   I read something on a blog the other day that really rankled me. I'm not going to say whose or give a link because I refuse to propagate blog-drama, but the general gist of it was that someone was blagging (using their blog to brag about their life) and, along with a lot of uber-materialistic hokum that didn't bother me a bit (I'm not a particularly covetous person when it comes to Things Material, although I do envy those of you who have Kitchen Aid mixers) they blagged at length about their children. The way they're able to afford to give their kids lots of things I can't give mine did smart a tiny bit, but the line that really stuck in my craw (ha! Like that pill! Oh haha!) was something to the effect of "my kids don't have special needs!" I'm kind of conflicted about getting my hackles up there, because if none of my children had any special needs I guess I might privately include that in the things about my life I was grateful for, but...well, I don't know that I'd blag about it openly. If your children don't have any special needs then hey, that's great for them and for you, but...it's not like that's a measure of your success in life. With the exception of things like FAS and prenatal drug exposure, a child's having special needs isn't usually indicative of their parents' mistakes or misdeeds. It just...is what it is. I'm not sure exactly why it bothered me so much to read that line in a blog that's in the "trainwrecks" section of my reader anyway (oh don't act like you don't have blogs you read solely because they make you feel better about your own life...I at least own my schadenfreude), and I certainly don't wish any special needs upon the blaggart-in-question's children or anything mean like that. But that line has stayed with me. I guess maybe I ought to take that one out of my reader...
*   This certainly has turned into a mishmash of pissing and moaning, hasn't it? To make up for that, at least in part, here is a picture that I am extremely proud of:
Figure One: Gobble gobble, motherfucker! At last I captured Loud and Crazy the turkey in action! Isn't he impressive?

body:
*   Still no hot water here. Hotter is not taking it well, but I'm fairly philosophical as long as there's electricity and running water to be had, and took a cold washcloth-scrub and shower-rinse after my run today (it was very invigorating, thanks!) and heated water on the stove to wash up the necessary dishes to bottle tonight's batch of water kefir and get tomorrow's going in new room-temperature sugar-water. The landlord wasn't able to get a repairperson out today but a truly obnoxious one is coming tomorrow. I know he is obnoxious because I spoke to him over the phone, and in the space of a five-minute conversation he asked for my phone number in an innuendo-laden tone followed by "honey," also called me "baby," "sweetheart" and "dear," and then after I mentioned a morning appointment being no good tomorrow due to my HUSBAND having a doctor's appointment he started calling me "ma'am" and signed off with "God bless you!" Clearly someone has some Madonna/whore issues toward women and/or has seen too many pornos and I am not only offended on MANY levels but also skeeved out enough that if I was not married I'd probably ask the XY to come over rather than be alone with this asshole. Blech!
*   I went running again today, and did not die, which is pretty much the only criterion by which I judge a run a success or failure. I have this weird love/hate relationship with running; I love it but it hates me. Between the connective tissue disease, the exercise-triggered asthma, the deformed feet (nothing anyone would pay to see, they're just not quite right), and probably at least two other things I'm forgetting at the moment I have to be rather careful with running, but I'm trying to work on improving my general health and stress levels with the idea that blood pressure and blood sugar both influence glaucoma and obviously I want to do everything possible to save my eyesight and there's an app, so: RUNNING! WHOO! The main things I do to avoid hurting myself are mostly geared toward SLOWING THE EFF DOWN. That seems to be the number one piece of advice I get in life, be it from a family therapist, an academic advisor, teachers and coaches in everything from piano to public speaking...I seem to have two speeds, fast and off and neither of those serves me well in running without hurting myself, so here is what works for me in case you have this problem too:
1. Use something to keep time and alternate running and walking. RunKeeper is perfect for this because I don't have to watch a clock. It frustrates me, because the run intervals always end just as I'm hitting my stride, but it also keeps me from outrunning my lungs and/or joints.
2. Breath-counting. I breath in through my nose for a count of eight and out through my mouth for a count of eight. Each number is a footfall, and if I am struggling to get the full count of eight in then I know I'm going too damn fast and/or headed toward trouble with the lungs.
3. Listen to slow stuff. This is counterintuitive, because what is more fun than pounding around the track to some Guns N Roses? Very few things! But what is less fun than a stress fracture? EVEN FEWER! I run to chanting Benedictine monks a lot. If I'm in no mood for the monks then I try to stick to songs like At Last by Etta James or Satellite by DMB. Nothing any faster than that, which is a buzzkill but also keeps my legs in no more pieces than they should be.
4. Think about posture as you run. Keep your shoulders back and your chest open, hold your head up and make sure you're centered over your feet. If you're leaning forward? You're going too fast.
*   I was not my most fabulous self today. I was impatient with my children this morning and irritated with my husband right up until he sensibly threw me a make-up bang. I wasn't in a very good headspace due to being laid off; I had grown complacent with the idea of staying at that job for another month and building up a little nestegg "just in case." Fortunately it has stopped hurting to swallow unless it's a very large gulp and I'm hoping this means I've avoided the possibility of surgical intervention being necessary, but our minivan still isn't getting any younger and now I've got it in the back of my mind that I need to be ready to re-litigate custody and well, OY. I'm going to try not to be an angst-ridden shrew tomorrow but can't make any promises, because we're spending the morning at Local Teaching Hospital for Hotter's yearly Big Checkup with Transplant and, well. Y'all know how I feel about that place. But I'm still going to try to "go quietly amid the noise and haste," and we'll see what happens.

body:
So a few days ago a FRIEND got a pill stuck in her throat (or possibly in the pouch of her hiatal hernia--I know, it's like we were separated at birth!). Said friend has seen evidence of considerable upper GI bleeding (having been schooled by various GI doctors on how to tell the difference between upper and lower GI bleeding for someone else she was caring for at some point, and therefore being certain that that's what this is) but can't go to a doctor on a weekend without totally upsetting the delicate financial balance in her household and isn't really sure that's warranted at this point, anyway. A doctor would no doubt send my friend to the emergency room, where she would probably end up getting, at the very least, a 23-hour observation admit to let her stomach empty and then an EGD that would probably show the source of the bleeding, and then my friend would probably be sent home with some Nexium and orders to stick to a soft diet for a bit. My friend doesn't feel as though she's lost enough blood to be dangerously anemic (and she is well aware what THAT feels like), her gums aren't pale, and the pain in the area that said bleeding is most likely coming from is not getting any worse. So probably nothing needs to be cauterized and the only purpose in my friend spending the weekend and every penny to her family's name in the hospital would be in going "huh, yep, look at THAT!" when a) that wouldn't actually HELP my friend right now given that she already has access to Nexium and a soft diet and b) it would eat up all of the funds she may need to save against a LATER date in case strictures develop as this heals, at which point surgical intervention of some kind WOULD be necessary.
   So I don't think my friend is in any mortal danger or anything, but all of that said, she feels like crap and I'm worried about her.

I had carefully composed my face into a mask of gracious good cheer on the drive home but it shattered right then and there and I nearly started sobbing. body: I think I already told y'all that we're down one chicken, but at the time I was a bit distracted by Hotter's medical shenanigans and didn't tell you the back-story there, which is pretty hilarious.   It all started with the six little fuzzballs that arrived in the mail back in mid-May.  Little did we know it at the time, but paying extra for all-female birds doesn't mean squat, and we ended up not with six hens (which would have been a bit much, but I thought one or two might not...travel well...and didn't want to end up with only one or two chickens) but with four hens and two...non-hens.  Which I wouldn't be so bitter about, since it wasn't very MUCH more, except that allegedly there are professionals involved on the shipping end of things and after only three days I'd figured out that we had at least one cock with the aid of the innernet.   One might've been okay, but any more than that and you're going to have feathers flying at some point, so we found ourselves contemplating alternative living arrangements for the non-hens in our little flock.   Meanwhile, about a week after we got our chickens, my brother in law, Loud and Crazy, decided to do the same.  He still lives with my mother-in-law, The Wrath, on her small farm up in the Arctic Tundra, so he got quite a few chickens, several different varieties in fact, from several different sources and...threw them all together.   Bad idea.  Chickens are vicious creatures and it's called a PECKING order for a reason.  Apparently the bigger ones ganged up on one smaller chick and pecked his eyes out.   Now, Loud and Crazy is a man's man, a manly man indeed, who hunts and guts his own deer in the field, but when it comes to domestic animals he's...well, he's got a softer touch with them, and rather than wring the poor chick's neck, he invited my other brother-in-law, Big and Scary, to bring his seven-year-old daughter over to visit and meet the chickens.  Then took the child aside and gifted her with the blind chick behind Big and Scary's back.     This was problematic in that Big and Scary did not have, nor did he want to have, any chickens.  But Big and Scary is a total sucker for his baby girl, and so the blind chick, who they named "Patches" (after the sad little skin-flaps over his eye-sockets when the wounds had healed), found himself in the very lap of luxury. And I found myself on the receiving end of many profane diatribes about how Loud and Crazy was going to wake up with a dead chicken under his pillow and no eyes to see it with via Facebook chat courtesy of Big and Scary, which amused me greatly.  I'd log in and ask how the "livestock" was doing, and he'd rant and curse, and I'd read it aloud to Hotter, and we'd laugh our arses off.   Until a hawk swooped into the deluxe accommodations Big and Scary had fashioned in his back yard, and carried Patches off in plain view of the little girl via the kitchen window.  At which point you couldn't so much as IMPLY to Big and Scary that Patches had been any less than a cherished member of the Big and Scary family; he was outraged, and grief-stricken, and so was his daughter, until he bought her her own small flock of chickens and installed a roof on their enclosure, at which point he began cursing and complaining about the new chickens, and plotting revenge on Loud and Crazy once more.   Big and Scary might sound rather, well, big and scary, and perhaps a tetch crazy as well, and he is all of those things, but the guy loves the hell out of his little brother, and during Hotter's worst night in the hospital of struggling to breathe, when I stayed up all night slapping him awake and reminding him to do that, Big and Scary kept me company on the facespace via hospital wireless.  He fretted and brainstormed, and consulted Dr. Google, and generally helped make the night more bearable, and when my mother-in-law was being...difficult...about coming down here to see her ill son he helped convince her that keeping her word was important.  It was good old Big and Scary who let me know, via the facespace, that the Wrath and Loud and Crazy were finally on their way.  "You owe me," he said.   And I did.  So when the in-laws got here I reminded them that they'd told Hotter he could bring at least one non-hen up there to their place if we did in fact have one, months earlier.  See, Hotter's family all suffer from an inability to say no, that leads them to agree to things they have no intention of actually doing, and the Wrath had answered the question without consulting Loud and Crazy, who didn't want an extra cock at all, but I had a hen-detta to carry out.  I waited until Loud and Crazy was using the restroom prior to driving the Wrath home again, and cornered the old lady, and said I'd just get her a box for that cock she'd promised Hotter she'd take off our hands.  "I said if it didn't work OUT, I didn't--" she said, but I cheerfully ignored her and fetched the box.  Loud and Crazy came out and was not pleased at all to see that his mother had given up protesting when I ignored her and effectively agreed to take Blondie off our hands, but they eventually got on the road for the six-hour drive home with a box containing a cock.  As they pulled out of the driveway Loud and Crazy was ranting and the Wrath was reassuring him that if the other chickens didn't accept Blondie they could always give him to Big and Scary.
title: hen-detta, or "three brothers, one cock"

body:
*   My cold, which had been no biggie, has started to do that thing where it's 50/50-ish whether I'll end up with an ear infection. Which I obviously do not want. As much as ear infections suck, though, AT LEAST IT'S NOT THE LUNGS! Currently I'm keeping on top of my decongestant dosing, using the Neti Pot, and hoping for the best.
*   Of course, the fact that I'm working tomorrow and all weekend and have a big family outing planned for my day off on Monday virtually guarantees that this will turn ugly. As does the fact that the XY will be in attendance.
*   WHAT? Yeah, I don't entirely know how that happened either; yesterday I spoke with him for the first time since his accident and he not only didn't thank me for handling his shit for him (you know, providing the hospital with his SSN and blood type, tracking down and notifying his family members, and making sure his elderly and very ill father had his meds straight) but also went so far as to scold me for telling CATHERINE! that he'd walk away from it without so much as a broken bone (which? He did). He felt like that was insensitive of me and added to her trauma. Uhhh...yeah. So I thought about it, and ranted on the facespace, and called Dr. Redzils and shrieked at her (in typical Dr. Redzils, PhD style she pointed out that I had been a nice person about the whole thing and the XY was having a hard time wrapping his injured head around that and responding appropriately because he is NOT a nice person), and talked it over with Hotter, and finally ended up calling the XY and telling him how I felt about things (nobody thought that was a good idea, but I needed to get it off my chest for my own sake so I did it anyway). And he...apologized. And was nice. And get very emotional when (after he said he was going to try and take his weekend despite his not yet being medically cleared to drive again) I said NO WEEKEND VISITATION UNTIL THE DOCTOR SAYS IT IS OKAY (and I mean VERY emotional; I guess the concussion really did ring his bell), and the next thing I knew I'd told him he could tag along on the family outing if he promised to nice and thereby spend some time with the kids in a way that would be safe for everyone concerned.
*   I blame the cold medicine.
*   Hopefully the XY a) behaves himself as promised and b) doesn't think this means we're friends or anything, because he and CATHERINE! are NOT invited for Thanksgiving and I'm not loaning him any money or electronics or the MFA Minivan or even allowing him into my house. His behavioral history makes certain precautions to keep him out of my home and away from my stuff the only sane way of handling him no matter HOW nice he is with a head injury and on painkillers. He's excellent at hiding it but deep down at his core he is a narcissistic, amoral, reprehensible little man and not to be trusted. Honestly, I'm worried that any gestures of goodwill on my part will only lead to him overstepping, me setting limits, and him then getting pissy and causing trouble. Grrr.
*   I took comments back off moderation since there haven't been any more scary ones since the one way back in May. Plus now that I have The Precious (that's what I call my iPhone, which I lovelovelove) I can unpublish a comment any time, any place if need be. Please remember not to use my actual name in comments if you know me outside of the blog (Dr. Anon, I am looking at you--I've censored you for that twice now!), and play nice in the sandbox.
*   How are all of YOU?

body: I try to avoid asking y'all for things, but this?  It breaks my heart, y'all.  I know what it's like to have a geneticist and a dysmorphologist tell you your baby isn't going to live to adulthood, and in Little Child's case, thankfully, definitive testing proved them wrong (they thought he had MPS; I linked in case you're curious but trust me, it's awful).  In Tanner's case, though, the prognosis is certain, and I can't even imagine what his mother must be going through.  I'm broke as a joke over here, but I'm doing what I can, by running through Central Park in a tutu in August and displaying BHJ's widget on my sidebar.  If any of you are in a better place financially, it would be great if you could chip in.  Thanks.

body:
*   Neurology and Transplant went well, thank goodness.
*   Things got a little hairy at the dentist, because I am sick AGAIN, like doctor-sick, and was going to cancel part of the planned work, but they are so nice they told me I could pay the rest next week. So Hotter got Phase One of the dental work done.
*   Then I went to the doctor (my actual doctor's office doctor), where things went utterly to shit: apparently I am "out of antibiotic options due to allergies" and "beyond the skillset of a general practitioner." They want me to "see a specialist" and "talk surgical options." But surgeons are specialists, which is a higher co-pay, and if I can't afford the $40 that would be, I sure as hell can't afford any of the things said specialist would do (just for shits and giggles I looked up ear tubes on Anthem's website last night and they are $800 APIECE after insurance). I could, however, give the fuck up and burst into tears on the spot for free, so that's what I went with.
*   The doctor (not MY doctor, but one of her partners), to his credit, said he would do his best to treat me given that a specialist was not currently an option and had his nurse give me a whopping big shot of steroids in the ass. He doesn't think any oral antibiotics would help me at this time, but sent me home with some steroids and says that's my best bet right now for staying comfortable and upright, but that he really thinks I need ear and possibly sinus surgery.
*   We came home to find that the refrigerator AND freezer had quit, and all of the food has to be tossed. Naturally we'd just been shopping.
*   I...don't even know what to do with this. Apparently I am seriously ill and there's no fixing it without money I don't have, and if I can't work I can't make any more money, and I don't even know what we're going to EAT when all the nonperishable stuff is gone because I had shopped to stock the pantry in advance of spending all the money on Hotter's teeth, and now that is gone. I appreciate the suggestions to try and talk to a social worker, but the thing is, we're not poor enough yet that Social Services would step in. If we get that poor, I will absolutely talk to a social worker. But first I'd have to lose my job due to being too sick to work, so...I guess give it time? Fuck me.
*   I seriously think I am losing my shit, y'all. The nurse came to give me the steroid shot and I bent over the exam table and she did her thing and then I stood up and she saw my face and was like "oh my, are you OKAY it's OVER NOW" and I was like "lady my behind is the least of my problems" and then on the way home we saw a truck with one of those metal cage-boxes in the bed full of hunting dogs and I burst into loud, open-mouthed sobs and came undone entirely. "WHY THE HELL DO PEOPLE DO THAT TO DOGS," I shrieked at the top of my lungs. "WHAT THE FUCK IS WRONG WITH PEOPLE?" I don't think it was about the dogs, obviously. I think maybe until I am at least a little bit more sane or end up hospital-sick and out of work and can get some government healthcare to straighten my ass out I should get off the innernet and tend to other things. The kitchen floor, for example, is covered in blood that leaked out of the defunct freezer from all the thawed venison, and my landlord is apparently on a plane to Japan and unreachable until tomorrow. Fuck. Me.
title: people in hell just want a cold drink

body:
Thank you to 2nd.MD for providing me with a $200 stipend to test-drive this revolutionary online medical service.

   When I saw that Clever Girls Collective had a sponsored post opportunity that involved trying out a  revolutionary new way to get in touch with a top specialist from home, I was really excited, for obvious reasons. I mean hello, every single person in my household has complex medical issues necessitating entire TEAMS of specialists, who aren't always all that available for questions that aren't life-or-death. When I found out I was selected for this opportunity I thought long and hard about which specialty to consult with. I don't think there's any specialty we HAVEN'T had dealings with, after all, so I was a little bewildered in the face of SO. MANY. OPTIONS. And the combination of medicine and social media was RIGHT UP MY ALLEY, OH MAH GAH.
   I finally decided to narrow it down by ruling out specialties we were already happy with (like I hate the eye doctor LIKE POISON, but that said mine is one of the best in the nation so I don't really need a second opinion there), ones with a heavy hands-on clinical aspect (for example, to effectively address specifics of the connective tissue disease my children and I all have, a geneticist would want to move our joints around, feel our skin, have us do various physical things not easily captured on webcam...), and specialties where prescriptions are heavily involved (for example, I need to get back on ADD meds but while a psychiatrist-inside-the-computer might be able to make recommendations for specific drugs, they obviously can't prescribe that way and I don't know how well it would go over if I went to see MY psychiatrist and told him I wanted to try X controlled substance because Dr. Y from-the-innernet told me I should...).
   I finally decided I wanted to go with a sports medicine doc; many of the sports medicine specialists on 2nd.MD have SUPER-impressive credentials and I'm not realistically going to shell out a co-payment and day off to see one on my own. Plus the reason I wanted to see one (namely to get some tips on exercises, specific taping techniques/compression garments, etc. that might help me avoid the recurrent injuries I am so prone to when I run) was something I felt could be effectively addressed in a videoconference. Yay!
   My enthusiasm started to fizzle around the time the second specialist declined to take me on. I get why they have this option; obviously not everyone is very medically savvy and some people might select specialties that are wildly inappropriate or doctors within a specialty who don't often handle their particular issue, but...any able-bodied person can run and women in particular are prone to stress fractures. I didn't feel like mine was such a crazy concern. Finally I found a doctor who was willing to talk to me: WHOO!
   Unfortunately he didn't show up for our "appointment." Booo...here is where I have to say that 2nd.MD's customer service is AMAZING. If a doctor doesn't show up for your appointment (which given that doctors have, um, emergencies and stuff, isn't such a far-fetched idea) you automatically get a refund from 2nd.MD, but what the fine print doesn't say is that when that happens they go ABOVE AND BEYOND to make sure you don't give up on the service itself. The rep's exact words when I contacted him, frantic, at COB on a Friday when my post was due no later than TODAY, were "you go and have a good weekend and let me work some magic." 
   I won't lie. Initially I was not impressed with the magic. Because it took the form of a rush-appointment with...drumroll...a rheumatologist. Yeah, 2nd.MD's sports docs unanimously wanted nothing to do with me because of the rare and freaky connective tissue thing, and I was...pretty offended, honestly. Because what the heck was a rheumatologist going to know about this (I mean yeah, technically I have an autoimmune disease that falls under their specialty AS WELL, but it has no impact on my running and all symptoms that have majorly impacted my life have been effectively addressed through drugs and surgery)?
   At this point, I think if I'd been a regular paying customer I might've given up on 2nd.MD. Since I wasn't actually paying for the service out of my own pocket, though (and uh, wanted the income from this sponsored post opportunity), I decided I had nothing to lose by going into my appointment with Dr. Kirkwood Johnston with an open mind.
   Y'all, I am so glad I did that.
   Dr. Johnston isn't just a rheumatologist, he's also an avid runner and something of a rare disease afficionado. Instead of one of the two usual reactions medical professionals tend to have when I tell them about my specific connective tissue disease (either "umm...how do you spell that? I've never heard of it!" or "HOLY CRAP YOU POOR THING, YOU SHOULD TALK TO A GENETICIST OR PRETTY MUCH ANYONE WHO ISN'T ME!"), Dr. Johnston said "tell me about your [insert condition name here; it's rare enough to be potentially identifying so I'm not putting it up on my personal blog], what subtype is it and how severely affected are you?" He went on to explain, laughing, after I told him how the sports docs had all shied away from seeing me, that a lot of the time people's reaction to rare stuff that can impact mobility is one of "CALL A RHEUMATOLOGIST!" and this was actually right up his alley.
   I'd love to show you a screenshot of my consultation with Dr. Johnston, but apparently Awesome Screenshot and the 2nd.MD chat interface don't play well together because when I took one I ended up with this:
Figure One: Not-so-awesome screen shot. 
   So you'll kind of have to use your imaginations a little. Here is what Dr. Johnston looks like. And here is what I looked like during our consultation, modeling my anti-asthma attack running mask for running in cold weather (taken with my iPhone during the actual consultation, which you can sort of see in the reflection off my glasses) (last time I EVER don't shell out for the anti-glare coating on lenses, incidentally):
Figure Two: You didn't really think I'd out myself for this post, did you? Also? Funny story: I thought Dr. Johnston would be in on the whole "you are talking to a blogger who is being paid to review your services" angle, because COME ON, but apparently he was NOT in on the joke and when I said, apropos nothing, that I blogged anonymously and whipped out the mask in the middle of a chat about joint and muscle health I think the poor guy thought he was about to become an unwitting participant in some kind of fetish porn. But he was a good sport about it!
   So, my actual, honest-to-goodness opinion is that this is an amazing service. I got some truly excellent advice on how to minimize the risk of further injury (although Dr. Johnston was careful to stress that this would only REDUCE the risk, because "as you know you're going to hurt yourself a lot no matter WHAT you do," which shows he knows the condition I have pretty well, actually), from an unexpected source, and aside from the technology failing me when it came to the screen shot (AHEM, AWESOME SCREENSHOT) I have no complaints at all despite the false start. I was actually really impressed, not least in that after I caused a super-awkward moment by whipping out that mask it was SUPER-easy to exit the appointment with the remaining shreds of my dignity. Because it's easy to trip over your own feet on the way out a physical door (um, not that *I* ever did that while beating a hasty retreat from a horrified medical professional, hoooo no), but even I can't manage to hurt myself clicking the x at the top right of a screen.
Thank you again to 2nd.MD for sponsoring this blog post. Please click here  to learn more about 2nd.MD. I was selected for this sponsorship by the Clever Girls Collective. All opinions are my own. #Clever2ndMD #spon
title: 2nd.MD: The doctor is in! (a sponsored review)

body:
Forgive me for this post; it's not very amusing but I need y'all's expertise.
   I texted Hotter from work to ask how the MFA Childrens' first day of the schoolyear went, having decided that asking for the day off was probably silly given that my current job is VERY easy money that we sorely need and Hotter was capable of handling things. His reply gutted me and I spent nearly an hour bawling at my current workplace (fortunately this job is VERY easy and provides me with lots of downtime alone, which allowed for me to compose myself before anyone needed me to DO anything): Middle Child had a horrible first day of school because Tuesday is library day for his class and he was only permitted to choose from a very small pile of damaged books at the kindergarten level because of the library situation of last year.
   I forget if I wrote about it on here or just on the Twitter, but in essence Middly was not permitted to borrow books for the latter part of his kindergarten year due to an overdue book, which I found while cleaning out the older boys' room and returned when I went to the school to register Little Child for kindergarten, but which the school librarian CLAIMED was still missing, resulting in his not being permitted to borrow books for most of his first-grade year (largely because we were very poor that year and I couldn't afford the exhorbitant price the librarian alleged it would cost to replace the book, which was some three times what said book would likely garner on the open market). That year (last year) I called the vice principal and raised hell, and she promised me she would Handle The Situation.
   Apparently either a) the bitchy school librarian went rogue, because she's obsessed with the notion that that book wasn't returned EVEN THOUGH IT WAS or because I embarrassed her at this year's open house by dragging my terrified kid in and making her promise she'd be nice to him this year (Middly is now afraid of libraries and especially this school librarian, who I would give the benefit of the doubt and maybe say that she just LOST the returned book or reshelved it somewhere it wasn't immediately findable, except that she evidently yelled at my kid AND BOTH HIS BROTHERS and therefore doesn't particularly deserve a head on top of her fat shoulders as far as I'm concerned) or b) the vice principal's idea of Handling The Situation included treating a seven-year-old like a second-class citizen, and since neither of those options is acceptable to me I need y'all's help.
   Do any of you know whose call it is to hire/fire school librarians and/or vice principals? What is the smartest way to approach this (my mind is only yielding things like "ASK THE LIBRARIAN IF SHE WAS DROPPED ON HER HEAD AS A CHILD," "pull everyone out of this GODDAMN school and homeschool them," "pick Middly up every Tuesday and take him to the public library next to the school," etc. and therefore I have reason to suspect I am not being very logical about this whole debacle)? Please bear in mind that I can't afford a lawyer. Who do I talk to next, and what do I say?
   I kind of doubt at this point that even paying the ridiculous sum the librarian asked me for in order to replace the book would get her off my kid's back, even if I HADN'T already returned the FUCKING book. Which isn't to say that I won't pawn something and TRY throwing money at the situation; I'm not ruling that out. I've decided to sleep on it before doing ANYthing, though.
   What would YOU do? Are any of you lawyers, or librarians, or even teachers or schoolboard members who could maybe clue me in on who's in charge of this nasty woman's job? I intend to first ensure that it was the librarian's call and THEN take action of SOME sort. If it wasn't her call (and I'm betting it was, but I want to make SURE), then she's off the hook and I need to know what to do if the vice principal is behind this. I wouldn't be so upset, except that DAMN IT my poor Middle Child can't catch a break. I got him out of a bad situation with his father, bad things happened to him that necessitated CPS involvement (CPS did SQUAT, incidentally), he already HAS an inferiority complex fer fuck's sake...I just can't deal with the fact that someone at that school (which is rated #1 in the district)  is crushing his spirit over a BOOK. Especially when it's a freaking miracle he's learned how to read in the first place given all that he's had to overcome to get to where he is. Maybe the school just sees this as another Special Ed. student being a space cadet and the parent failing to let their special precious snowflake be held accountable, or maybe because Middly can mostly "pass" and is mainstreamed they just think he's a naughty little boy who needs to learn a lesson, hell, I don't know, but I need to fix this.
   Your thoughts?
title: the one where I crowdsource my outrage

body:
Okay, so the big fantastic thing I wasn't telling you about, because I wanted to make sure it was for real?
   A company called Brighter.com apparently pitched my friend Morgan for an advertising deal on her blog, and Morgan (who has a background in PR and has apparently been brainstorming ways of getting me a new tooth) turned around and pitched them right back all "so I see you provide dental discount plans...would you like to work together or maybe help me do a tooth-related fundraiser for my friend who is a very sad panda about her busted grille that she can't afford to fix?" (I'm paraphrasing, obviously). And they were like, NOPE! We'll just pay the whole thing.
   Yeah. You read that right:
 Figure One: OH MY GOD, Y'ALL (my first name redacted, obviously--clicking the voucher the wonderful folks over at Brighter.com sent me takes you to their website).
   I...don't even know what to say about this (except for the eleventy-hundred e-mails, facespace chats, and Twitter direct messages I have sent Morgan over the course of the past week that all said "OMG OMG OMG"). As y'all know, it costs a LOT of money to fix a dental disaster of the magnitude of That Tooth. And they just...heard I needed help and stepped in in a big way. WOW.
   I didn't want to say anything until I knew that this was for real (in fact, I didn't even mention it to Hotter until the Brighter.com folks e-mailed me directly), but this morning someone from Brighter.com called my dentist's office to arrange payment of my portion of the bill in advance and I guess this is really happening! They didn't ask me to dedicate a certain number of posts/tweets/whatnot to promoting their company or anything, but if you want to do me a favor you could share this post; I'd love it if they saw a bunch of hits come into their website from mine as a sort of virtual thank-you note.
   Happy Tuesday, y'all. It's gray and rainy and gross here, but I'm smiling, busted-but-soon-to-be-fixed tooth and all :)

I...am still down in the dumps, fighting another sinus/ear infection (it's not bad enough that I'm ready to throw in the towel and take antibiotics yet, I mean, in theory half of ear infections resolve on their own, right?), my eyes are bothering me (but I don't want to talk about it), and work is very work-y (I am solely in charge of completing a Very Big Project, which everyone seems to think I'm doing a great job of, and I am, but it's giving me agida because we have a deadline and I can't do the WHOLE thing without other people's participation and I haven't specifically asked but probably PseudoCorp would frown on it if I roamed the cubicles on my floor with a stick prodding people who aren't getting back to me) (yes, I can be a TEENY bit goal-obsessed when I am working on something big).
   I need some garden porn to cheer me up. 
   I don't think I ever specifically mentioned it to y'all en masse (although I've talked about it with some of you), but LeaseGate 2012 reached a peaceful conclusion involving the magical cooperation of my landlord and my ex-husband BOTH at the SAME TIME. I know, I'm shocked too! The key to handling the XY, maddeningly enough, was for me to remove myself from the communication process and have Hotter be the MFA Mouthpiece. See, the XY is one of those narcissists who have a desperate need to be widely-liked, and only shits on people who know him intimately, and while I no longer think that applies to me, apparently I've been grandfathered or something because he will still nut up and scream at me and be utterly horrid. With Hotter, however, he's still trying to do that thing he often did with great success during our marriage, namely to convince the third party he's just the nicest guy alive and I am some kind of crazypants whackjob for thinking ill of him because LOOK HOW NICE, SEE HIM SMILING AND OFFERING TO HELP YOU MOVE? Of course Hotter knows this is bullshit, and dislikes the XY thoroughly, but if HE flat-out asks the XY to do something like pay the child support, or make a pharmacy run for a sick child while I am at work, or keep his word on the extra $50 a month to let us stay in this house, it's all "of COURSE! GLADLY! You look fabulous, have you been working out?" Barf.
   The upshot of the ludicrous mindfuck of that whole paragraph up there is that we're not moving, and I have a garden to plan! I ALMOST bought seeds and stuff the day before Leasegate 2012 erupted, and am kind of glad I didn't because I don't just want to grow whatever is the seed catalog with the best sale. I want to grow FABULOUS THINGS! To that end, if you grow vegetables, what are your favorite varieties and why? What is a fabulous producer/super-cool looking/damn-near-impossible-to-kill? I am intrigued by Novella Carpenter's Triamble squash...has anyone ever grown those? Last year I did Royalty Purple Pod string beans and they were good but not the best producers...what bush beans have y'all planted with good results? Tell me your gardening stories!
   And now I have to go and eat something and get ready for an early bedtime, because I am working New Weekend Warrior Job tomorrow at an obscenely early hour. Ole!

body:
*   No, PseudoCorp hasn't hired me. DANG IT. But today I volunteered to learn a new job-specific skill that hopefully increases my value to the company. I asked fully expecting to get shot down, because it's a Very Important Duty, but didn't. WIN! I will ingratiate myself to them until they make me an offer, SO HELP ME GODIVA.
*   Oh, right. TOWDM is on vacation for a while. A good long stretch free of One Who Dislikes Me-ness! Not that she's ugly to me, really, anymore. She's as pleasant to me as she is to anyone since I made my peace offering, but she "doesn't like to converse" and it's weird when we work side-by-side for eight hours with ZERO SMALLTALK. I don't even try anymore, since it pisses her off. The day before she left for vacation, though, PseudoCorp had VIP visitors and The One Who Dislikes Me was wretched enough to those of us below her station in general that I don't think anyone will miss her; there's a much different feel to my job without her around. More people stopping at my desk to chat, more friendly banter, etc. It's nice.
*   PseudoCorp = corporate FEEDER. Holiday lunch. Holiday dinner for lunch in the cafeteria. Free gourmet boxed lunch from place that has been featured on Food Network. Cookies from vendors. Cookies (OMG TRANSCENDENTLY FABULOUS COOKIES) from The Boss (who, I have since found out, used to be a professional pastry chef). Box of chocolates from my department. Holy wow. I've still continued to lose weight overall, however, as the ticker reflects.
*   The power company let us get back on budget billing. As you may recall, they booted us off for no apparent reason, and I'd been worrying about the upcoming very-cold months (Casa MFA has electric heat) resulting in monster bills despite our efforts to be energy-conscious, because that's just how it is when the furnace has to run around the clock to maintain a remotely livable temperature for weeks at a time. We'll still have the monster bills, but we'll pay a fixed amount that is doable. YAY! I have also ordered some window insulation film kits to install next week, and am eager to see what kind of results we get from those.
*   The holiday shopping is ALL DONE and the stuff has ALL ARRIVED. This is huge, because I wasn't sure if I'd even be able to GET holiday gifts this year (I only bought stuff for the kids, really, as Hotter asked if he could subscribe to something for recreation purposes as his gift...I was kind of pissed because I'd picked out something for him and gotten excited about the idea, but he's a big boy and can pick his own gift if he wants to and this way I know he's happy with what he got, but I think they will be happy). I actually got everyone really NICE gifts, even, in part by starting months ahead and doing my bargain-hunter thing and in part thanks to readers Becca and Devivo and the ever-fabulous Dr. Anon, the self-appointed elves who helped me take care of the final touches after things went to hell. I still need to wrap everything, but Hotter and I are practically giddy in anticipation of watching the MFA Children's reactions to their loot.
*   I'm not working AT ALL this weekend, nor am I taking on any work if any of the temp agencies call me. Instead, I am doing some house-stuff, grooming, bathing, and preventative-caring both dogs, and baking panels to build gingerbread houses with my family. WHOO TITS! 
*  Big Child's results from the county's Gifted Testing came in today's mail, and he is officially gifted in the areas of English and Social Studies. This is good news in that he is eligible to participate in enrichment activities and opportunities that I can't afford to expose him to, on the school system's dime, and I think he's going to love it. It's BAD news in that he was already kind of insufferable. HEE!
*   I think I'm finally on the way down the other side of the misery mountain, and apologize for the recent sparse posting. Tell me how all of YOU are doing!
