*****************************************************************************************************************************   
   This was supposed to be a post about an "everyday victory," and honestly I was going to come up with something a little more poetic, but some days my victory is that I survived. 
   Those of you who have been reading along for a while know that the past year and change have been pretty tough here at Casa MFA. After losing my teaching job of nearly a decade when Middle Child was admitted to the hospital the day before a key deadline, I temped and held various "weekend warrior jobs" to make ends meet. It hasn't always been pretty. Heck, I don't think it's EVER really been pretty. But you know what? I made it work, and pulled us through it.
   I haven't wanted to say too much about what's been going on at my new job, but now that the crisis is over I feel like I can talk about it. About a week ago, when things were looking so very grim, I was informed that the person who'd hired me on as "fulltime with benefits" had overstepped in doing so, and that I was (and would remain) a part-time employee (sans benefits). This really took the wind out of my sails, because it meant not only that I'd left my temp job at PseudoCorp for a job that paid $3 LESS per hour (but was supposed to come with benefits), but also that I'd have to go back on the job-hunt, because Hotter needs benefits through me before January rolls around and the Medicare "donut hole" becomes an issue. Today, though, after much complaining to HR and Management on my part and the serendipitous (for me and mine, anyway) firing of a former co-worker, I was informed that I'd been changed over to "full-time" in the system and would be eligible for benefits once my ninety-day probation was over with.
   The news couldn't have come at a better time. Today was not an easy day. Due to the afore-mentioned termination I was the only person waiting on a banquet room of seventy people tonight. I pretty much had to be like an octopus busing those tables, but you know what? I pulled it off, the guests were happy, and I wish the couple whose wedding rehearsal this dinner was a part of all the best.
   If that's not an everyday victory, I don't know what is.

title: oh DELL no!

body:
After spending forty minutes on the phone, all Dell's agent agreed to do was send UPS to pick up the battery they sent me DESPITE MULTIPLE DELL AGENTS ASSURING ME THAT ORDER HAD BEEN CANCELED. They are not going to compensate me for the overdraft fee. They are "very sorry" that I have spent a month waiting for a working computer, including TWO days spent at home waiting on a technician (who did not show up on the original scheduled date of service because DELL screwed up and sent a part out twice). SO AM I. But nobody is willing to take any responsibility for fixing this whole mess moving forward. They are sorry to hear that I won't be buying anything from them ever again. That's...it.

   I am so angry, y'all. I have had a LOT of overdraft fees over the past year and a half while I've changed careers, because we just haven't had any money. This one, though, is because someone ELSE effed up, and it's really sticking in my craw. I could have delayed some grocery shopping had I known this was coming and avoided it. Right now due to the lack of available hours at my main gig we're in this weird place overall of "things SHOULD be better, but they just aren't." I'm doing everything I can to MAKE things better (tightening our belts again, some more, bargain shopping, etc.) up to and including getting a second job, even though working that into my schedule along with my main gig is practically guaranteed to give me an ulcer...and then Dell goes and does THIS.

   It's not Dell's fault that their MULTIPLE screw-ups over the past month culminating in this most recent one have collectively added up to The Straw That Broke The Camel's Spirit.

   But it really would've been nice if they'd fixed THEIR part in it all.

Sent from The Precious
title: NEVER buy a Dell computer

body:
So yeah, thanks to Dell's "we'll screw up multiple times, mail double parts and delay the tech, swap your system for ANOTHER one that doesn't work, mail you a part for the original machine, then empty your bank account and make YOU eat the overdraft fees while you CONTINUE to not have a working laptop!" style of customer disservice, it went from "we'll make rent by the skin of our teeth" to "we'll be about thirty bucks short and there'll be fuck-all we can do about it." Today I worked nine hours at Job #2, and I'm due at Job #1 in about five hours to work the early shift. Which means that, since there's no extra gas money, I and both my uniforms are camped out in the lowermost level of a dark, creepy parking deck in the bowels of downtown MFA City, where I'll hopefully catch a nap, then work some more and hopefully make some cash tips (possible but doubtful). Then I'll go home, sleep, send the MFA Children off to the first day of school, come back and work an extra shift I picked up and hopefully make some MORE cash tips (also possible and SLIGHTLY more likely), and maybe--MAYBE--if I then raid everyone's piggybanks I can drop the rent off a few days late and claim to the landlord that we were on vacation (ha. HAHAHAHAHA!), and he won't cash the check until I work another double on Thursday, make more tips, and deposit same, and it'll all work out okay. Godiva willing and the van don't break. And if I don't come down with the cold I can feel lurking in my sinuses. Probably some real sleep in an actual bed would help me fight that off but mehhhh.

   If I sound motherfucking FURIOUS at Dell and thoroughly sorry for myself it's because I'm both. Also, it's a little early to hate on the entire month, but so far I do not care for the cut of September's jib ONE LITTLE BIT.

   How are all of YOU?

body:
So yeah, Hotter and I picked the boys up from school early and we went to a very small local fair today (that's the family outing the XY was supposed to join us for). I'm not sure what happened to him, because he didn't show up and left me a cryptic voicemail, then when I called him back I couldn't really hear him over the unholy din around me. Fortunately I know him better than to have told the children to expect him, so the only ones disappointed by his no-show were Hotter and I (we were both looking forward to checking out his staples).
   Honestly, I was rather disappointed in the fair. It was quite a bit smaller and less impressive than I'd been expecting, especially considering the price of admission. It was too chilly for half the animals on display to be out in the elements, which made me sad. And fried Oreos? Are GROSS. Plus Hotter wanted to go to the freak show, and got the children going on about it, and I had a small nervous breakdown in the middle of the midway and was apparently a total buzzkill railing against the gawking at of people whose bodies are different and reminding three-fifths of the people present that four-fifths of us present suffered from a genetic condition that many "freak show" performers have and that is NOT FUNNY...but I stand by that rant. The MFA Children, however, had a wonderful time, which is all that really mattered to me. Plus this:
 Figure One: Fancy pigeon! Hahaha, look at him! I took a lot of photos in the small animal tent, but it wasn't so much the animals I was interested in as their cage tags...
  Figure Three: "Hey Mommy, are you taking ANOTHER picture of that pigeon?" "Yep, he sure is cool-looking!" Snicker snicker. OH HAI I'M TWELVE! Figure Two: I wanted to steal this one to tape to Hotter's desk chair!
   So yeah, no danger of me growing up any time soon. How are all of YOU?
 
P.S. Yes, I am well aware of my apparent hypocrisy in wanting to gawk at the XY's body in the same post as I decry the evils of freak shows. However, as a friend of mine from grad school who I recently reconnected with thanks to the facespace pointed out, the XY is less of a human being and more of an extraterrestrial visitor, so I think that's fair play. Carry on.

body: Today, after work, once The XY showed up to take his visitation (a miracle unto itself), Hotter and I went berry-picking. We're still overdrawn, and I don't much care for the pesticidal ways of most "pick-your-own" places anyway, so we went first to a nearby roadside I've had my eye on and then to a clear-cut then overgrown access path through the woods under some power lines. Blackberries were plentiful in both places, although the season is just getting started here, and the sun was shining.   About a quarter-mile into the woods we came across a muddy washout in the path, teeming with tadpoles--when I scouted this location out a few days ago by myself I saw lots of little adult frogs, too, although Isis scared them all away today. We let her offleash while I picked (Hotter doesn't see color or perceive depth well enough to pick safely or effectively, but came along to keep me company and wrangle the dog) and she went nuts! I have rarely seen her so rampantly joyous--she ran through the foot-deep water as fast as she could, snapping at tadpoles as she ran. When she came to the end of the water she'd go just far enough to get a good running start, turn around, and do it again; she did this over and over, getting filthy and soaked, tongue streaming. She had a blast! We all did. At home, I picked the blackberries from our backyard, and that gave us slightly more than eight cups of berries. I made them into seven eight-ounce jars of seedless jam. The kitchen is trashed, and I'm sorely tempted to judt pitch the food mill, but all in all today was a wonderful day.   I have tomorrow off, and am getting sleepy after my bedtime snack of fresh jam on a biscuit and milk, but I just wanted to let y'all know it's not all gloom and doom over here. Sometimes it's also jam.  Sent from The Precious

title: making me want to diephone

body:
Last night my right fuck-you finger started hurting; it felt like maybe I had a splinter but the skin was intact, there was no redness or anything, and even checking it out with a bright light and the iPhone's zoom (which is damn-near as good as a microscope) showed nothing so I shrugged it off and went to bed. This morning I woke feeling rested, albeit extraordinarily achy, and for the first time in ages my teeth didn't hurt (I squeezed in a trip to the dentist before the fair and he fixed my nightguard, which hadn't wanted to play well with the new front tooth). My co-workers were happy to see me and said they'd missed me on my day off (seriously LOVE those people!), and I was fully prepared to call today a good day except that my finger now felt like I'd burned it. Around nine in the morning I posted the following photo and caption on the facespace:
 Okay Dr. Facebook, let's play "Spider Bite or Burgeoning MRSA," the home game! Sudden onset yesterday, stupidly painful, no visible break in the skin, hot to the touch: go!
   My friends had variously helpful things to say, and it was kind of funny in that the people who only know me offline (yeah, I'm not "out" as a blogger on the facespace) were all "what is MRSA? Why would it be MRSA? Don't be a pessimist!" and the people who have known me online for years were all "it's MRSA cellulitis, go to the doctor, do not pass GO, do not collect $200." I was disinclined to do that, because I am currently making a REDONKULOUS sum per hour and while it hurt quite a bit, on a scale of 1-10 where 1 is a papercut and 10 is a gallstone I would only have given it a 4-5 at that point. 
   A couple of hours later it started swelling:
 Oh goody, it's getting bigger!
   I still wouldn't have rated the pain as greater than five, although it was sobering when one facespace friend cut and pasted the symptoms of cellulitis per the NIH and I had all of them except for fever (which I pointed out, upon which said friend provided anecdotal experience wherein a family member of hers had cellulitis withOUT the fever). People started trying to reason with me all sneaky-like, as in "oh just go to the doctor, it might not be MRSA!" I pointed out that while the rule on House is "it's never Lupus," the rule of MFA Mama is "it's always MRSA," but at that point I was still hoping it was a spider bite. Dr. Anon flat-out stated that unless I was allergic to spider venom she really thought I ought to seek medical attention. I am allergic to spider venom, though, so I continued to hold out hope this would be nothing requiring antibiotics but compromised with my friends list: I would draw a line around the margins of the thing and if it crossed it by four o'clock I'd leave early and go to Urgent Care in time to get a script filled.
    Shortly after that, the finger started to itch a bit and I happily declared it to be a spider bite after all and left work at the usual time, stopped at Target to get a pair of dice and a bag of Smarties, both of which various MFA Children needed for homework assignments (the hell?), came home and ate dinner with the family (they'd already eaten since I work 7-7, but they all sat with me bickering for my undivided attention anyway), and then went and took a shower.
   Something about the hot water seemed to aggravate things, because the finger then increased in size by another 20% or so and turned black in the center, with some other SLIGHTLY less-alarming colors in various other spots, none of which were the color a finger ought to be. 
   Hotter took one look and pointed sternly at the door saying "GO!" and I realized I was being an asshole about it and went.
   At Urgent Care the doctor poked and pressed on my poor sad finger, looked at it up close with bright lights, and had me move it in various ways, then pronounced it to DEFINITELY be infected with "what looks to me exactly like MRSA, although with your history of MRSA septicemia after an aggressive culture you couldn't pay me to lance that thing, so we're just going to assume the worst and treat you for MRSA."
   Ugh. Also? How sad is it when the local Urgent Care doc knows your medical history?
    
    So I went and filled my five (yes, FIVE antibiotics, antifungals for after the antibiotics, antiemetics to keep the antibiotics down, and something for pain since at this point that was creeping up the scale toward a six) prescriptions at the all-night pharmacy and headed home, but you know what?
   I feel really freaking fortunate. Don't get me wrong, cellulitis sucks and MRSA scares the pants off me, but all day long I was enveloped with the concern of friends and coworkers and lovingly nagged as needed by various parties to do what I needed to do about the situation, I went home to a husband who was concerned and didn't complain about doing the bedtime routine alone so I could get to Urgent Care before they closed, I got prompt and compassionate medical care, and then I didn't have to prioritize which prescriptions to fill based on cost and necessity but just sighed ruefully and filled them all. Coming from a place where I didn't have any of the above just a few short years ago (and where as recently as last month the money part would have been harrowing at best) I feel like one lucky person, black finger and all.
   Although I still reserve the right to bitch and whine if the finger falls off or even if I just spike a temp and end up needing IV drugs :)
   How are all of YOU?
title: the one where I get MRSA but feel pretty damned lucky anyway

body:
I didn't even mention it, since she's done it before, but Houducki disappeared again. She's been gone for about three days this time, although Hotter swears he saw four ducks around the pool briefly a couple of days ago. I haven't been home during daylight to go out and look, but we suspected that she was holed up under the shed and after loosening my achey back up with a hot bath and a good book (and a Dentist Pill, which I'm very glad to have a few of still if my back is going to pull this mess) I went out looking. Which entailed much getting down on the ground and sticking the iPhone under the shed in various spots until I hit paydirt:
 Figure One: Just as I thought. It's not the best photo because she started honking at me like a goose and furiously pulling the leaves and down in closer with her bill; I didn't have the heart to disturb her. I kind of doubt she'll succeed in hatching anything as it's pretty chilly for that, but we'll see I guess. At least she had the sense to choose a hidden spot that's protected from the elements so I don't have to worry TOO much about her!
title: the case of the disappearing duck

body:
I feel lame for even being unhappy about things right now since we've got enough money and nobody's in the hospital, but I feel a whine coming on...
   The XY is skipping his weekend; he says he doesn't feel well enough to take it. I shouldn't complain, but I was looking forward to a day off to spend lazing around pantsless with my husband. Oh well.
   Temp Agency #2 has a banquet going on downtown today whose guest-list suddenly multiplied like water kefir cooties and called me yesterday, desperate. I asked Hotter what he thought and he said since the XY wasn't taking the weekend I might as well help them out as they've been very good to me and we can always use money. So I'm working a banquet today, which wouldn't be a problem exactly except...
   ...I don't feel so hot. I've got a little bit of a sore throat and a little bit of a fever (although STAND DOWN, the finger looks excellent and is almost entirely normal in size and color so whatever fresh hell this is it is NOT MRSA sepsis, necrotizing fasciitis, or anything else truly vile along those lines, and therefore I probably ought to STFU and suck it up, which is pretty much what I plan to do...in a minute) and a LOT of body aches and swelling. I really don't see how the hell this could be strep, since I'm on enough Clindamycin to throw a pony's intestinal flora out of whack for a year (ahem), and am therefore declaring it a virus. I think my immune system is flipping me the bird right now. RIGHT BACK ATCHA, ASSHOLE.
   Also sick and needy children are sick and needy, and want me to go out shopping before work, and I'm worried about Hotter (who while he IS the healthiest person in the house does after all have some after-market organs including a kidney which seems to be strep's favorite organ meat) and not looking forward to the effect being on my feet for seven hours on a concrete floor will have on my body given that it's already achy and irritable. Blahhhhh...
   How are all of YOU? Don't forget to comment on this post with small appliance-related wishes if you want a chance at a visit from The Fairy Hobmother! So far Lala's comment has made me giggle an unseemly amount :)
title: the one where things go a little bit to hell

body:
*   I'm still not particularly interesting, between being at work more than I am at home and being queasy/heartburn-y at all times from the GOT-DAMN clindamycin and being achy and swollen and blahhh from the autoimmune "we can't be arsed to fight off infections but here is what we'll do as a response INSTEAD" bullshit my body does in the wake of anything bacterial. SO lame, that.
*   That said, I am feeling much better than I was last time I posted. I did in fact feel like utter crap on a cracker last night at the banquet, but as it was another Republican Party shindig (the second I've worked for Temp Agency #2 in the past month!) I didn't waste any time feeling guilty about going to work sick, and it was so incredibly fast-paced that I didn't have time to feel overly sorry for myself (we had a NAPKIN EMERGENCY in that they were folded in thirds and artfully draped over the edge of the table at each place-setting and then with only an hour until guests started to arrive management decided they all needed to look like this instead, which is problematic when you've got 1,200 napkins to refold, place and fluff and you also still need to drop cream-pitchers, salad-dressing boats, salads, desserts, waters, and iced teas at each of 120 tables and yes, believe it or not the twenty of us did somehow get it all done with the help of some of the kitchen staff) (after that there were salad plates to clear, entrees to serve, coffee to fetch, and the room to break down afterward). Between being crazy-busy and a kind co-worker's suggestion to keep sucking bits of ice "to bring down yo culluh en hep yo throat" I got through it rather more easily than I would have predicted.
*   The virus is responding well to Dr. Anon and dulcian's advice in the comments section to drink, drink, and DRINK SOME MORE. I was trotting back and forth to the bathroom ALL DAY LONG at my six-day-a-week job today, but that's okay because there was NOTHING to do. Seriously, Sundays are dead there; on-site middle management let us leave an hour and a half early and in the nine hours and forty-five minutes I was on the clock (I take a forty-five minute lunch) I read one and a half books on The Precious with a Kindle app, played Words With Friends, shopped online, ate lots of snacks...and trotted back and forth to the bathroom a lot. So it's all good.
*   I'm even starting to deflate some, bloat-wise, which is a relief because a) I was on the verge of needing to bust out the maternity yoga pants I still have for such occasions, which is always particularly soul-crushing but particularly since my last baby is now in elementary school and I don't even have a UTERUS anymore and b) I was worried my body might just be a TOTAL asshole and hold onto the extra fluids I'm forcing down to flush out the virus. As the finger is now 95% improved in size and color I think the bacteria triggering that whole hot mess are mostly (if not completely) dead at this point, and hopefully you won't be able to see each stitch of the socks I wore in bas relief when I take them off for the day by the middle of this coming week. 
*   I seriously want to marry the iPhone and have its' user-friendly little babies, especially since Twitter told me how to disable autocorrect (on an iPhone 4 it's settings>general>keyboard>autocorrection - YOU'RE WELCOME!). LOVE The Precious. CAPS-LOCK LOVE. Today at one point I was simultaneously listening to streaming radio on Pandora through my earbuds, reading a book on Kindle, playing twenty games of Words With Friends and telling Twitter all about it and I realized that the iPhone is basically Jobs' gift to ADD. I really don't ever want to not have an iPhone again. MFA Mama + iPhone = true love 4ever.
*   How are all of YOU?
title: inarticulate grunt

body:
So yesterday and today have sucked with one notable exception: I got a visit from The Fairy Hobmother! She seems to be an exceptionally creative SEO fairy who flits from blog to blog granting small appliance-related wishes (I'd previously commented on a blog and wished in the comments that I had an icecream maker, which I had since acquired...undaunted, the fairy then sent me an Amazon.com gift card to use on the gadget of my choice, asking only that I throw her a link. Fair enough, my fairy friend, fair enough; I certainly have nothing against energy-saving appliances and while I still would have been game had you just gotten in touch and asked to buy a text ad with a link, I love your sense of whimsy! Plus I really enjoy a chance to let my readers win something, and word on the street is that anyone with a blog who comments on this post and makes a small appliance-related wish could be the fairy's next stop. *Ahem*
   Other than that, my finger is still swollen and discolored and gross, but much less painful and so I think the antibiotics are doing their job. Which is good, since I feel pukey and gross from them and they put a horribly bitter taste in my mouth ALL DAY LONG. Which would make me furious if they weren't also helping my finger, although since they are I guess I can put up with them. I'm still feeling pretty damned grateful; I have had MRSA septicemia before and therefore know that this could all have been a LOT worse had I waited to see a doctor and ended up with something systemic.
 Figure One: This is the shape of the stricken finger compared to the same finger on the other hand. Clearly it still has some healing to do. I took this picture with my nose!
   Hopefully soon this whole ugly infection dealy (and the associated swelling, because oh lordamercy do I ever puff up when I've got any sort of bacterial infection going on; I forget just how ridiculous it is every time it's been a while and made the mistake of alarming poor Dr. Anon by asking an "at one point ought one to worry when..." type of question where the answer, for a normal sort of person, is "OMG RIGHT NOW WHAT THE HELL WOMAN?" Clearly I not only forget the quirks of my lemon of a body but just what a freak I am...sigh) is nothing but an unpleasant memory, because I fear I won't be very interesting until then. I can't even tell you funny Hotter stories to bridge the gap, because the poor man is pretty worn out caring for all of the animals, especially these two, in my absence while I'm working twelve-hour days:
 Figure Two: This is the picture the XY texted me from the pediatrician's office today after Hotter called him to let him know the littles were poorly. They both have strep.

title: the one with The Fairy Hobmother

body:
That was my work gchat status for much of the day today. Because while I got up and out the door on time, and arrived at the office in a good mood and tackled my project with renewed enthusiasm after yesterday's fabulous meeting, I had to pick up and leave after only a little over two hours.
   Middle Child woke up puking, puked up the Zofran Hotter gave him, and wouldn't take another dose or let anything near his mouth. Hotter messaged me at work to wave the white flag, and initially I was all "the kid can't be dehydrated yet, what am I going to do that you're not," but then he came back with "I think he needs his mom."
   Ooof.
   Fortunately, my new job is portable and my new managers are some seriously nice people, and I was able to bring my work laptop home. I knew I'd made the right choice when a pitiful little voice greeted me with "fanks for coming home Mommy, I'm rillwy sick." I put The Fear of Mom into Middly by presenting it as "you need this medicine to help you feel better and if you won't take it at home with your mouth I'll have to take you to the hospital to take it with a needle so how about we try one more time," crushed the Zofran to a powder that I mixed with sugar and water, and got it into Middly with a syringe. Less than an hour later he was sitting up and eating ramen and I was dialed in and working from home. YAY!
   In the end I only lost an hour out of my workday, and the best news of all is that Middly hasn't thrown up again and never did run a fever, so I think he'll be okay to go to school tomorrow (it's Pajama Day, which he would have hated to miss) (also, the last time he threw up was riiight before the school-day started, so technically he will have been twenty-four hours vomit-free when he walks into his classroom).

I don't want to blow my own horn, y'all, but...actually screw that YEAH I DO!
   Today's work-meeting thingy went as well (from my standpoint) as it possibly could have. I had to "sell" a group of people on the importance of proper document formatting in relation to end-user absorption of written technical material, which is a nit-picky thing that not everyone can appreciate, and to make this extra-hard I was addressing a group of people who are about as far removed from the language arts discipline as you can get. I came up with an analogy, though, that I think helped it "click" for them (it also helped that I was addressing a group of super-smart people; I don't mean to sound superior by implying it was a challenge to convey the information--I'd be equally unlikely to intuitively grasp concepts from their area of expertise) and saw real excitement over the concepts whose importance I was trying to call to everyone's attention in a couple of faces. It was really neat to see that, and also means good things for my work-project, so I'm feeling pretty satisfied about the whole thing. That's kind of a new experience for me, taking pride in my professional performance in a capacity relating to my years and years of higher education (I always take pride in my work, whether it's constructing a well-made sandwich, watering an acre of seedlings, or being the fastest female worker on the job-site with a ratchet tool--it's just EXTRA-neat to feel like my studies contributed to my success in a work environment...teaching, while something I was qualified to do and sometimes did very well, isn't exactly what I studied so that wasn't quite the same).
   Today, despite my catching my stiletto-heel in an elevator-door gap and torquing my bad ankle unpleasantly, was a good day. My stockings even stayed in one piece!

Fevers are weird. Anyway, I've had issues with those kinds of bad dreams being a regular occurence for long periods at various points in my life, and so it was kind of a relief to be able to say "aha, the fever was just baking weird things out of my brain" as opposed to worrying that the nightmares were coming back to stay a spell.

I was very grateful to have him, because if I'd been on my own today would have been very, very ugly. body:
*   There is nothing quite like finding out you've been fucking ROBBED before 6 a.m. to start your day off shitty. Well okay, not technically robbed, but apparently Temp Agency #1 reset everyone's W-4 status to "single, no exemptions" as of Valentine's Day for who-knows-what-reason and I was supposed to know to refile my tax forms? I don't know. What I do know is that my paycheck this week was light by about 20%, which? UNACCEPTABLE.
*   Don't tell me I'll get it back next April, because I won't. The Department of Education will get it next April. I think this is part of why I was so deeply unhappy about the whole thing (aside from the whole "money snatched from my pocket while attempting to save up for badly-needed medical care for my husband" bit); it reminded me that I suck and am a loser.
*   Speaking of things that suck, why the buggery FUCK doesn't Medicare cover preventive dental care for transplant recipients, anyway? I get that a lot of dental work can be considered cosmetic, and that technically one can get by without teeth, but here's the thing: in an immunocompromised person a dental infection can kill. There is nothing optional about getting the very worst of what's wrong with Hotter's mouth fixed, and Medicare isn't even saving Uncle Sam any money by not covering this stuff, because I'm guessing not a lot of single transplant recipients go on to marry people who are willing to work their ass off and handle this shit. Which means that some of those who are even more fucked than Hotter is end up getting infections, which if they are too poor to have broken teeth extracted and cavities filled and already scrambling to cover their 20% of the medications they need to take every day to not DIE they probably aren't going to go in for right away. When they end up septic Medicare then covers their ambulance trip, their ER bed, their emergency oral surgery and week of IV antibiotics, their echocardiogram to see if they have vegetation on their heart valves, their maintenance meds and ICU bed, and whatever else they need while they're in-patient (and taking a transplant patient to the hospital is like taking a teenaged car to the mechanic--you may go in with a specific goal in mind but they WILL find more work to do while you're there). And all of that for the unfortunate few? Costs a HELL of a lot more than two cleanings and a set of x-rays every year for everybody, even if those DO reveal the need for a few fillings and maybe an extraction or two. /soapbox
*   So I had kind of a crappy day, but it wasn't entirely without merit. For one thing, today I wore a new scarf (this scarf was the last frivolous thing I bought before money went utterly to hell again) that thrills me to the very core for two reasons. First, it's a fabulous scarf (half silk, half pashmina, butter-soft and utterly gorgeous). And second, it was an AMAZING deal ($9.99, free shipping, 1% cash back).
*   Speaking of deals, this free app gave me a sick little thrill earlier today. It's designed to help you find the cheapest gas around, but that's not what I use it for. I already know that Big Box Membership Store will have the cheapest gas around and so unless I have some fuel points from Local Grocery Store to use elsewhere I just buy gas there. No, I use GasBuddy to GLOAT. Yesterday I paid $3.36/gallon for gas at Big Box Membership Store and today that same gas (from the same place) is $3.42/gallon!!! So I saved a little over a dollar by filling the MFA Minivan up yesterday on my way home instead of waiting until today. WHOO TITS!
*   Also my dog is crazy-cute:
Figure One: Of *course* I mean Isis. Bumpus? IS NO DOG OF MINE! He's on his second psych med now; the first one didn't work and while on it he ate a door. I love how Isis does the homie lean, or maybe she's just trying to get AWAY from Bumpus (actually they are the best of friends, which is one of the only two reasons Bumpus still draws breath under my roof, the other one being that so far the cost of the therapy Big Child would need if I got rid of the stupid dog still outweighs what we'll lose of our security deposit thanks to his crazypants antics).
*   And then a sweet friend did something incredibly kind that really raised my spirits. I don't know if she'd be okay with my saying what she did, exactly, or naming her, but I really needed something to cheer my sorry ass up, and this did the job. 
*   I am off to bed, because tomorrow is a seventeen-hour day. Ooof. God, I hate money.

body:
SO! I felt like my dirty hippie-cred was somewhat diminished after a conversation that happened on my wall over at the Facespace (basically I admitted that while I knew good and well Splenda was already showing up in our waterways and having unknown effects on the feeding pattern of key bottom-of-the-foodchain small critters, I found powdered Stevia in coffee to be utterly repulsive and resorted to some sweet, sweet molecularly-muddled sugar product instead like a damn ecoterrorist and then a bunch of friends weighed in until finally a friend of mine from a third-world country pointed out that were were all a bunch of overly-precious assholes, although not in so many words), plus we were almost out of laundry detergent. So today I followed some instructions I found in several spots around the innernet, added my own little twist, and made us some at home.
 
Homemade Laundry Detergent
  You will need Ivory soap: 

washing soda:

borax:

and (optional) an essential oil of your choice to scent your detergent (I used lavender):


Step One: gather your ingredients. You will also need a large pan or mixing bowl, a grater, and a whisk, as well as something to put your detergent in (I re-used a laundry detergent box that already had a scoop of the right size--you're supposed to use two to four tablespoons of this stuff per load of wash).
 
Step Two: grate one bar of Ivory per "batch" of detergent that you are making. I found that five "batches" filled our detergent box to about the same level as its' original contents, which was important since I wanted to do a price comparison. Use the fine side of the grater; the soap is very easy to grate and ends up looking a lot like something you'd want to put on top of spaghetti.

Step Three: add one cup per "batch" apiece of the washing soda and borax, blend with the whisk until you reach a nice "scoopable" texture. Then add a few sprinkles of essential oil and blend some more.

   And there you have it: homemade laundry detergent. Here is my box with four of five "batches" in it.

   I did a test load of wash, and in my opinion the homemade detergent works at least as well as what I had been using before (in fact, I think it works BETTER for removing odors--included in the test load were some hand-me-down sweaters my co-worker/friend at PseudoCorp gave me, and she is a smoker so to me they kind of reeked going in but smelled nice and clean coming out). But does this actually save any money? Here are the prices I paid for the ingredients.
Ivory: $18.06 for 32 bars = $0.56 per barWashing Soda: $5.97 for 55 oz = $0.87 per cupBorax: $7.88 for 76 oz = $0.83 per cupLavender Oil: $8.75 for 0.5 oz* = I figure I used about $0.10 worth of this per batch
   So one "batch" of homemade detergent costs $2.36, and it took five batches to fill my detergent box. Therefore, the per-box cost of the homemade stuff is $11.80. How does that measure up against the retail equivalent (green-friendly, scented)?

   VICTORY! I saved $2.25, plus there's the intangible value of being insufferable and saying I make my own laundry detergent any chance I get, which you really can't put a price on. Probably I could get the cost down a little further if I bought my ingredients from an actual store (with the exception of the Ivory I ordered mine from Drugstore.com in order to use eBates and get cash back at the rate of 12% as of when I made my purchases, plus "Drugstore dollars" [5%] and accounted for my savings in the prices I listed), but I prefer shopping online, and pretty much ONLY do so when I can score free shipping. This saves me time and schlepping. Plus to really save I'd most likely have to patronize a Soulless Corporate Megalith store, and I don't like to do that; I don't know for a fact that Amazon and Drugstore.com treat their workers well, but I DO know for a fact that Soulless Corporate Megalith treats their workers like SHIT, and that's to say nothing of what they do to small businesses when one comes to town. So I'll take saving the $2.25 and earning bragging rights and call it a day.
   And how are all of YOU?
 
*  If you're looking at what I paid for lavender oil vs. the price listed on the Amazon Affiliates widget and wondering if I be cray, the answer is yes and no. The lavender oil I used was what I had on-hand, which was organic and therefore kind of pricey, but I prefer to use organic essential oils since I mostly use them for bath and body products and other things, like detergent, that will come into contact with human skin. We have sensitive skin here. So I didn't overpay, but I did consciously choose a more expensive product.

body:
This week wins. I got up after less than five hours' sleep and dragged my sorry ass into the office, but something wasn't right. I felt like I'd been hit by a bus and my sinuses were draining a lot, but I didn't really feel all that sick, and believe you me I was on symptom-watch after last night:
Figure One: I really wanted to be wrong, but I knew what this meant.
   Usually when I get an ear infection, I spend a couple of days dithering over whether or not this is an actual thing and whether or not I want to cave and get medical attention; the ear that always gets infected is also the one that hurts like hell if I'm about to get a migraine or sometimes even when there's a storm coming, so wretched ear pain isn't always indicative of infection plus I hate hate HATE taking antibiotics. Today we've had rain, thunder, and even a tornado warning, so when my ear started to hurt around nine this morning I kind of shrugged and kept working. I had some emergency NSAIDs (I know, I know, I shouldn't be taking those but my H&H are pretty respectable since the hysterectomy so I use them sparingly during autoimmune clusterfucks and migraines) in the pill-fob on my keychain and took those in case it was an impending migraine (and also because my SI joint is KILLING ME), but I wasn't terribly concerned at that point. I was doing some field-work today, running around talking to people with my uber-sexy fits-over-eyeglasses safety goggles on, so I was pretty distracted although I did notice that where the goggles rested against the top of my cheekbone on the left side it kind of felt like a brick was sitting on my face.
   At eleven I thanked the folks helping me and headed back to my desk, and pretty much the moment I sat still I realized that I had A Problem. I messaged Hotter on gchat and told him I didn't want to lose any hours in light of our current financial clusterfuck, but didn't think I'd make it all the way through the workday. He suggested that I hang in until my usual quitting time (I'd planned to work two hours past that), then swing by Urgent Care on the way home. I agreed, then yawned and OH MY FUCK, HELL NO, OWWW. I shot my boss a quick e-mail letting him know that I wasn't feeling well and asking if I could take my laptop home to finish what I was doing and go ahead and leave to go see a doctor. My boss, who is one of the nicest people I have ever met, came over to my cube and said he'd thought I looked a little unwell, and to absolutely go and get that checked out and not worry about working from home, just rest over the weekend and try to feel better. I knew I'd made the right call when that brought tears to my eyes; I am NOT usually a Weepy Willie, as k calls it, unless I am hella sick or have missed a Synthroid or something.
   By the time I got to Urgent Care I was absolutely miserable with pain and the entire left side of my face had a heartbeat. The triage nurse took my blood pressure twice, then went and got the doctor right away because apparently I was starting to go into shock a little: IT HURT THAT MUCH. The doctor was a very nice Russian lady who looked in my ear and exclaimed "ohhhh eardrum is rupture, is no wonder you haff pain!" She made me lie down and put some topical anesthetic drops in my ear, which helped some, prescribed Levaquin and Vicodin, and strongly suggested I see an ENT about getting a tube put in after this heals since this is the second time she's seen me for an ear infection this winter and she could see notes from two others in the past year alone, all in the same ear.
Figure Two: Ballllls!
   I feel quite a lot better now that I am home and in bed and the Vicodin has kicked in, but I'm still hurting pretty badly and shocked at how quickly this came on, and I'm also absolutely GUTTED over losing five hours today and having to spend sixty dollars on medical care and drugs (thank goodness I have insurance and Levaquin has gone generic--I'm upset and feeling rather cheated by life but also well aware this could have been a lot worse) on top of what I already lost to Temp Agency #1's tax-form fuckery and Temp Agency #2's payroll gaffe. Probably we'll end up with an overdraft, and it all just seems so very fucking futile; why am I busting my ass at three different jobs if we're fucked in the end anyway? So fine, I cry Uncle, this horrible week has defeated me entirely. I don't know why I can't fucking catch a break lately, but for right now, and definitely until at least Monday morning, I just give up.
title: defeated

body:
I do not want to do a single goddamn thing. I don't want to get out of bed, or plant the broccoli, or clean the rabbit cages.
   I ABSOLUTELY do not want to go to work tomorrow. I'm known there for my cheerful enthusiasm for what I do, and I don't have that in me right now (of course I will go anyway and fake it 'til I make it).
   My body is doing that thing where it tries to self-destruct in the face of stress, I think. My autoimmune sacroiliitis is flaring, my head and left cheek and ear are pounding, and last night the place on my left knee that I skinned so badly back in the middle of DECEMBER reacted to my drying it with a towel by shedding all of its' newly regrown skin in a large sheet and bleeding profusely. I'm used to things taking forever to heal (thank you, connective tissue disease, you asshole) but UN-healing is a new one on me.
   My official letter of "blah blah corporate lingo blah restructuring yawp yawp economy blah thank you for your hard work and all that you have done for the company" from Job #2 came in yesterday's mail. And I just spelled that m-a-l-e and only barely noticed.
   The spelling is the last thing to go. Someone please tell me the depression and bad spelling is all the Vicodin's fault.
   I think part of why I don't want to go to work tomorrow is that I am waiting for someone to say "y'know what, what you do really isn't anything special, and no one cares about your field anyway, so we're letting you go." I don't know whether that's Imposter Syndrome or another one of my pseudo-psychic predictions, like on Thursday when I said that after all the past couple of days had done I kind of wondered if Friday would come to my house and kick my dog.
   Oh, dog.
   I'll definitely update the Twitter after I take Isis to the vet tomorrow, but maybe it's time I took a little break from the blog since all I can seem to do on here right now is panic about how I can't afford necessary medical care for family members or get enough work, and how all of the work has caught up to me and made me sick. Speaking of which, I feel like ass; according to the paperwork from Urgent Care if I am not feeling better by tomorrow I need to go back in and possibly get my antibiotics changed up. I really, absolutely, catefuckinggorically CANNOT afford another round of co-pays. Maybe I'm just being a big old baby? Does an ear infection with a ruptured eardrum take longer to heal than a regular garden variety ear infection? Let me know, please, if you have any experience with that.

body:
Lots of you have asked, via various social media, so here is the non-update on Isis: doggy pathology takes "a couple of days" (this per the supremely unconcerned veterinary receptionist I spoke with today). So I guess MAYBE tomorrow we'll know something? The patient is in good spirits; we played a game of tire tug-o-war earlier today and she seems to be enjoying getting held like a baby twice a day while we apply the hot compresses to her lumps.
   I meanwhile am bleeding freely from my sinuses and GI tract (I know: whaaaat? I think this is just a combination of "took forbidden NSAIDs recently" and "all my body's bullshit gets worse under stress" and also "infections irritate sinuses" and "opiates irritate the GI tract") and feeling really tired and beat-down. I'm trying to convince myself that those two things are unrelated (fuck no I am not going to a doctor; labs come out of my deductible and I do not have the time, money, or driver for any -oscopies right now) (that said, my gums are not pale, my resting pulse is a respectable 82 bpm, and it is not an OBSCENE amount of blood so, you know, NOT DYING). I'm concerned, but not WORRIED.
   Also, uh, does anyone know the signs and symptoms of a hernia in a six-year-old? A...friend wants to know.
 
The observant among you will note that I changed the Tip Jar icon on the right sidebar to a Donate button. This is because a couple of people asked why I didn't have a way for people to chip in and help out with the current financial clusterfuck; apparently the Tip Jar is not terribly obvious. I was hesitant to do this because TROLLS but also did not want anyone who wanted to help to not feel like they could, because I am totally drowning and willing to grab any lifeline at this point. I had saved almost half the cost of Hotter's upcoming dental work (three weeks from now, OHMYGOD), but spent all of it yesterday at the vet. If you feel like that was stupid of me, you are entitled to have that opinion and part of me even agrees with you. But, as a wise friend on the Twitter pointed out, if human beings always made rational decisions we would not be human. Also, if the tables were turned, my dog would do whatever it took to save MY life (judging by how courageously she protected me from her own reflection in a window the other day, bless her poor unselfconscious little heart). So.

body:
So. I didn"t go to work, which should tell you everything you need to know about how my back is. I got up when the alarm went off, and shuffled to the bathroom, holding onto the hallway wall all the way, and then in transferring into the bathroom, proper, almost fell flat because my right leg twitched out and then buckled at the knee. I caught myself on the vanity (my arms are okay--it hurts to move them, but only because that pulls on my trunk; whatever this is is down at L5, which I know because that is where I broke my back and it is ALWAYS L5), and took a moment to get my shit together and think. Seeing as it's my right leg that's the most wonky (and given that I have nerve damage in my left leg from the break twenty-one years ago that alone is pretty alarming), that was one strike against going to work anyway. Because that's my pedal-pushing leg, obviously, and while the MFA Minivan has cruise control, braking in a timely manner is essential to safe driving. The whole "not able to walk/balance worth a shit without holding onto things" scenario was strike two, obviously. I mean, I do possess a Rollator, but all concerns of personal dignity aside (I pretty much got over those when I had to use the thing to get around for months and months a few years ago), the idea of lifting it in and out of the MFA Minivan seemed tremendously optimistic at best (and downright idiotic at worst) (in the Rollator's defense it is VERY lightweight, but it weighs more than string cheese. So). Strike three was the fact that I had an hour-long anxiety attack* in the wee hours of the morning after sternly telling myself I NEEDED to sleep to go to work and that it was mind over motherfucking matter, and I looked and felt like someone operating on three hours' nightmare-riddled sleep following an hour's helpless tears.
   I so totally can't even afford this, y'all.
   But since my body doesn't seem to give a shit about what I can and cannot afford or tolerate, I have to decide what to do about this, and since I cannot, even with unpacking and examining my reasons for liking or disliking any one option, discern what the best way to handle this would be, I'm crowdsourcing it and giving y'all a chance to weigh in.
Option One: Do nothing, by which I mean continue to take NSAIDs and Tylenol-laced narcotics, ice my lower back, and move as little as possible up until VERY CAREFULLY stretching, applying heat, and gradually ramping my level of activity back up is feasible. This is what I've been doing so far. Pros include not costing anything, not having to leave the house, and the fact that historically this always turns out to have been the wisest course of action in cases like this. Cons include possibly running out of leftover dentist pills before the pain is less terrifying, the possibility of overlooking something like a disc issue, and the fact that seeking some medical attention MIGHT have me back in fighting (or at least white-collar working) form sooner than this.
Option Two: Drag my sorry ass to Urgent Care (my GP, in addition to being on my shit list, doesn't have an x-ray suite in her office). Pros include ruling disc issues in or out via x-ray and neuro exam, documentation to show my boss (who doesn't care about such things and kind of rolls his eyes when I present him with doctor's notes after absences, but I like to demonstrate accountability), and possibly obtaining better pain relief in the form of steroids and/or more narcotics. Cons include costing money,having to leave the house, and  the fact that realistically and based on precedent this won't actually make me feel any better any sooner than waiting it out.
   What say ye? At this point I could argue either side, and Hotter is the KING of "whatever you want to do about it, baby," so I'm interested to see what other people think.
 
*   Which...what the fuck? All self-deprecating hyperbole aside, I haven't had a genuine anxiety attack like that in YEARS, like, probably at least three of them. And yet there I was having a conversation with myself in the wee hours that went something like "There is absolutely no reason to hurt yourself rolling over to make sure nobody is standing at the end of the bed, because the dogs would've gone nuts if someone had broken in and ZOMBIES ARE NOT REAL YOU ARE JUST BEING STUPID ABOUT THE ZOMBIES, THIS IS NOT AT ALL LIKE YOU WHAT THE ACTUAL FUCK, ANYWAY I MEAN ZOMBIES, SERIOUSLY???" And then I finally went to sleep and had nightmares about my maternal progenitor until the alarm went off.
title: crowdsourcing, because I really don't even know what to do with this

body: Thank you to everyone who weighed in on my back problem. I decided to take y'all's advice and see a doctor, but only after it had been forty-eight hours (at which point I figured whoever would have a more accurate picture of the damage; barring something ridiculous like a mobile fracture waiting a bit wouldn't be dangerous, and at no point did I have a continence issue or consistent inability to use my lower extremities).  The first thirty-six hours were absolute misery, and I think staying home and resting most of Tuesday was a good call.  After that, however, I noticed that while I was still in a lot of pain, I was able to move a lot better and the pain went from incapacitating to merely excruciating and cranky-making (ask Hotter how well I coped when he was an hour late taking his pills, or better yet don't...). So I decided to give it another day and quit taking narcotic pain relief to make sure I wasn't just masking symptoms (that was doubtful, as narcotics don't actually help me much, maybe because I've had to take them at least a couple times a year since I was in elementary school due to a combination of sod's luck and faulty connective tissue). I also may have removed a piece of string cheese from the offending packet and eaten it in front of the open refrigerator, just to show the rest what I'm capable of! Heh.  Sans-narcotics, I'm still not anywhere near my baseline level of function. But the pain has lessened by at least twenty-five percent at this point, and what I can't do, I can't do because it hurts, not because my body won't work. THIS IS A GAME-CHANGER! Since I doubt I would've seen this kind of improvement if this was a disc issue, I'm just going to keep taking it easy and taking NSAIDs (and avoid lifting and sharp objects) for now and see how that goes.  So. I'm achy and pissy, but grateful I got my garden in before this happened. How are all of YOU?  Sent from The Precious
title: game-changer

body:
*   Y'all might get sick of it, but now is ze time on Sprockets ver ve list vat ve planted: Red clover, white clover, common vetch, and alfalfa, separately, in pots, and everything but the vetch as a cover crop in the two large containers I use to grow lettuce when it is warmer (you are not supposed to use vetch as a cover crop before lettuce; I have no idea why but read it in several places so ALRIGHTY THEN! Vetch has much larger seeds and needs to be planted deeper than the other stuff, which is all wee bitsy seeds that you can broadcast onto loosened soil, so it would've been a pain in the arse ANYWAY). I figure that stuff'll all make for good bunny-fodder as well as fixing nitrogen into the soil and aerating it. I also planted Premier kale and repotted my ailing dwarf Meyer Lemon.
Figure One: No, YOUR desk is covered in plastic and pushed up against a South-facing window being used as a plant hospital!
*   Today I overheard something I wasn't meant to at work. I was lost in the cubicles (it happens at least once a day still; I try to orient myself within the building by remembering which side I can see the river from at my desk but end up lost on the way back from the loo on a regular basis) and two young Turks were conversing and one of them said "OHHHHH you know The One Who Dislikes MFA Mama? Who works in X department? Yeah!" and made an obscene gesture that I believe was meant to convey carnal knowledge thereof. Which, well, the fellow wasn't bad-looking, but mostly I felt a) scandalized by the vulgarity, because apparently I am eighty now and b) bad for her that he was bandying it about in such a manner. I even made a mental note to add "kissing and telling" to the round of "YOU DO NOT DOs" next time I'm lecturing my boys on The Importance of Being Non-assholes, because yeesh!
*   Speaking of star-crossed lovers, the bunnies are eight weeks old now and I decided it was time for them to go all Heloise and Abelaard and move into separate quarters to avoid a too-early breeding stunting anyone's growth. I kind of hated to do it, since they SNUGGLED and it was ADORABLE, but it's for their own good and I positioned the cages so that their food-loft platforms are next-door and they can visit through the bars. Has is enjoying having a clear shot at the food and water. Pfeffer the Heifer didn't want to move cages and I ended up hauling her out by the scruff. She was pissed! Poor bunny. I gave each of them an old sweater to snuggle up to, and they took to those immediately.
*   The new hoe is all I'd imagined, and more. I arrived home and immediately shouted out "WHERE MAH HOE AT?" It's so excellent for both hoeing and cultivating; I <3 my new hoe.
*   How are all of YOU?
title: plant all the things!

body:
*   Y'all are too kind. Thank you for your comments, your tweets, your e-mails, your WWF chats and facespace comments and messages and oh, hell, there is something in my eye. I'm not going to stop blogging. I just don't want to be a big fat downer, y'know? 
*   Since so many of you expressed concern about Isis and I'm not facespace friends with all of you and not everyone is on the Twitter, here is the deal with Isis. We spent three hours at the vet. It sucked a lot. They had a poor little mutt come in as an emergency who was hit by a car and we had to wait while they patched him up as best they could. His owner was bawling in the waiting room. I felt awful for her! Meanwhile, Bumpus flying-tackled Hotter, launching himself from the exam table directly into Hotter's face and knocking him onto the floor, Little Child climbed the exam table, Bumpus humped the shit out of Isis, both dogs and at least one human had gas, and chaos pretty much reigned. You think I'm kidding? Here is the only picture I snapped that doesn't show any of my kids' faces:
Figure One: Believe it or not this is them playing, not fighting to the death.
*   As for Isis's lump, the vet didn't like the look of it and did a needle biopsy. The mass in Isis's abdomen is a lymphnode, and the vet is more concerned about the superficial lumps (there are two now). She was hoping they were cysts and that she would be able to drain them with the needle, but no such luck. She did get enough of a sample to send to pathology, and in the scuffle I forgot to ask when that would be back (I know, I suck! I'll call tomorrow). Meanwhile, Isis is on a broad-spectrum antibiotic that kills "everything but MRSA" and we're to apply hot compresses twice a day to encourage any infection to come to the surface and drain. If that doesn't happen they'll need to operate. Between the cost of the biopsy and HALF the course of antibiotic (I'll have to go back for the rest after I get paid), here is what our bank accounts now look like (I actually thought we'd be overdrawn and laughed the laugh of the unhinged when I saw this):
Figure Two: HAHAHAHAHAHAHAOHFUCK.
*   The MFA Children, exam-table climbing aside, were absolute angels during the long wait. Middly said "your face is worried about my dog and so I am worried, too." Take that, people who said he'd never read faces or show empathy! When I saw the bill and he saw my face, he teared up and gave me a hug. "Thank you for saving my dog," he said happily. Oh, buddy. I hope this works.
*   I...am not even a little bit okay. I don't really feel anything except wheezy, because our vet treats cats, too. I'm a little concerned that my priorities are out of whack. My husband desperately needs a ton of dental work and I just spent everything we had trying to save a dog? The trolls of the world are going to love this shit. Physically I think I am on the mend; my ear and sinuses were not terribly painful today and things are draining. Some of what is draining is blood, but I think that's just what I get for taking NSAIDs. At this point I'm more concerned about my mental health (see: priorities, above) and so I am going to get back off the innernet. I'll let you know when we know something about Isis.
title: because I know y'all are worried about Isis too

title: and the bottom drops out

body:
...in that all it did was kick my ass, spend my money, and waste my fucking time.
   *rimshot*
   Seriously though, the ER did a CT scan of Hotter's head and some bloodwork, said everything looked good and they had NO idea why he was so ill, and discharged him with instructions to follow up with...TRANSPLANT. So it's like a giant medical circlejerk with my husband in the middle (barfing, most likely), and this is why Hotter usually isn't allowed to go to the doctor without me. Because I probably would've cut Transplant off at the knees when they sent him to the goddamn ER, or at the very least put the kibosh on the ER being all "your brain and blood are normal so have fun throwing up and passing out at home, sucka!" Since he's been hypotensive for the past week I'm thinking SOMEbody probably needs to scale back one or more of his BP meds, which only Transplant can really do (they manage those, plus nobody else will alter a transplant patient's meds). Either that or Hotter just needs to sack up and quit being such a wussy about having a BP in the 90s over 60s, because I walk around like that every goddamn day and you don't see ME retiring to my fainting couch over it.
   The MFA Children and I were actually on our way to go and get our bees when Hotter called to say he'd been discharged. So everybody got to go along for the ride! I was kind of worried because I have the kind of veil that goes over a hat (that is the cheapest kind) and my feral children destroyed my straw gardening hat (which I'd been planning to use with the veil) doing some kind of Mexican hat dance on the thing, but then I realized that their plastic Bob the Builder hard hat would a) fit me and b) have enough of a brim all the way around it to hold the veil. So I swiped that to use (really, it's the least those rotten kids could do!), and my beekeeping instructor at least had the courtesy to go and laugh at me in private. And now we have bees!
    Man, I hope I'm well enough to go to work tomorrow.
title: today was a lot like my ex-husband...

body:
So I'm still home sick, although I think I'm on the mend (I can make a noise besides a whisper today, although I still sound like a pubescent goose). This gave me a chance to go and mess with the bees, though! When I picked them up the beekeeping instructor showed me where they'd built one of the frames out a bit too far. "You'll want to go in tomorrow and trim that back," he said nonchalantly. Okay! Right! 
   So this morning I set out to do just that, and about the best thing I can say about how it went is that I am DEFINITELY not allergic to beestings. Note to self: do NOT forget to rubberband your pants-legs next time! I got the comb trimmed, but made kind of a mess of it, and I'm sad that I ended up killing the three bees that crawled up my pants and stung me (plus however many I may have smooshed in manipulating the frames). I guess it's kind of a good thing I got that over with, though. The last time I was stung by a bee before today I was just a kid and I remember it as SEARING AGONY. The me of today found the stings to be less unpleasant than mosquito bites (I am VERY allergic to mosquitoes) and won't be scared to mess with the hive next time.
title: MFA Mama: 0/MFA Honeybees: 3

body:
*   MFA Landlord, when Hotter e-mailed him to ask about a new lease, voiced his intention to raise the rent by a hundred a month. Which...well, if it was JUST that it wouldn't QUITE break us, but with that AND my health insurance going up AND the MFA Minivan being, unexorably, drifting away toward The Big Junkyard In The Sky...no. So our lease is up at the end of the month, and we may have to move. We'll see. The house clearly wants us to stay, being as it's unsaleable without $20k in septic system renovations, tiny, possessed of only one bathroom (in need of tilework), drafty, reminiscent of nothing so much as a brick shoebox, and in a very odd little neighborhood. To rent it out to anyone else the landlord would have to paint the entire interior, fix the bathroom up, repair a few other miscellaneous things, and generally spend at least one month of vacancy sprucing it up. And realistically he's not likely to get any more for it than we're already paying. So there's that. We've countered with "well in that case can we have three months at the old rent amount to find a new place to live; we wanted to stay but can't afford (another) rent increase, plus you promised us there would not be one." We'll see, I guess. I am Very Worried and also bitter as when this news came I was moments away from clicking "confirm purchase" on seeds and other supplies for this year's garden. Balllls.
*   But that's not all! Apparently PseudoCorp told me the truth in the interview about my position being temporary. Which means that either they weren't truthful with Temp Agency #1 or else Temp Agency #1 was overly optimistic when they described the job to me as being temp-to-hire (I have no way of knowing which it was and would be maligning an entity that has helped to feed my family if I ventured a guess either way, so I will refrain from verging into conjecture; either way it sucks). Apparently now that they've hired someone for a key position, The One Who Dislikes Me (who has been downright decent lately...all in all there are much worse people to work with and if my next job is with a bunch of lazy cretins I know I will miss her quiet and innocuous competence) will go back to doing the job I've been doing, and I will be going the way of the dodo. Sigh. There are three potential rays of hope that I am trying to cling to right now or I'd be a total basketcase: first, the co-worker who is on the way to becoming a friend may have a lead on a permanent position within the company that I'd be suited to, second, there was mention of another department within the company needing a temp (said department has one of those incomprehensible corporate-speak names that tells me NOTHING about what they actually do, so I dunno whether I'd be qualified or even able to fake it convincingly just yet) and I'd have a leg up in that I already know a lot about the company, know people's names and positions, and have a badge and a parking pass, and third, Temp Agency #1 might have something for me (they're looking--I expressed my dismay to them about the situation and they were apologetic). I've also been scouring local job postings and there's at least ONE full-time with-benefits position listed currently that I think I'd be qualified for. Which is approximately 100% more than there's been in weeks. 
*   I can't really tolerate even thinking too hard about being potentially jobless and homeless by the end of the month, because it will break me, so let's not discuss either of those possibilities any further. The landlord will surely be reasonable and I will find something. That is how it HAS to work out. SO LET IT BE WRITTEN, SO FUCKING WELL LET IT BE DONE.
*   It's Hotter's and my second anniversary today. Things could be a whole lot better in our lives right now, but the marriage itself is still a great big win and as I told him earlier today, "there is no one else I would rather be co-piloting this flaming shitshow of a plane with besides you." He made this for dinner and it was fabulous. So at least there's that.
*   How are all of YOU?

body:
So y'all know I'm on this LOSE ALL THE WEIGHT kick, right? It's less to do with vanity (Hotter is the only person who has to see me naked on the regular, and he actually PREFERS me zaftig, bless his poor blind little heart) and more to do with stuff like "not getting the Type Two Diabeetus" and "spare the joints!" My family tree is full of hideous, but largely preventable conditions either caused or exacerbated by being overweight, and I'm not getting any younger. It's hard. I'm not gonna lie. I fell wayyyy off the wagon over the holidays and gained back everything I'd lost in two months of hard work, partly due to an injury and partly due to lack of restraint. That sucked. But now I'm back at it, and I am sloooowly seeing results.
   All of that is to say that sometimes I would sell one of my children for some damn chocolate cake, but I've learned that I can't cheat on The Diet without going buck-ass wild and gaining ten pounds. Then I found this lady's blog, and thought "well hell, I could have some of THAT cake!" But I didn't have black beans, or liquid stevia, and I don't even want as much sugar as is in that much honey, and I have cholesterol issues, and I suck at following directions...anyway here is what I made, which isn't exactly her recipe, but is its kissing cousin:
MFA Mama's Poot-cakes
Trader Joe's Cannelini Beans - 1 can (420 calories)Five egg whites -  80 calories (16 ea.)Two egg yolks - 100 calories (50 ea.) Unsweetened cocoa powder - 6 tbsp (120 calories)1/2 c. Horizon Whole Milk - (80 calories)Coconut Oil - 7 tbsp (840 calories)1 tsp. vanilla extract1/2 tsp salt1 tsp. baking powder1/2 tsp baking soda1/2 c. Splenda
   Blenderize everything, ladle into a cupcake pan (WITH LINERS!), bake at 350 for about 20 minutes (until a butterknife comes out clean), and eat before going to bed facing AWAY from your spouse (HA!).
   They're really good, high in protein and fiber, and honestly you'd never guess about the beans if you just took a bite without knowing what they were. Next time I think I'll use actual black beans, I just didn't have any in the house, and maybe a teensy pinch of vanilla sugar sprinkled over the top of each one. These would probably be KILLER with peanut-butter on top, but obviously that would add a ton of calories (each of these has 136.666666667 total calories, which I rounded to 140 since there's no nutritional information on the ingredients without calories listed but they have to have a TINY amount, right?). 
 
All calorie counts courtesy of Myfitnesspal

body:
Yesterday wasn't done hurting me after I published my last post, because one of my bedtime pills stuck in my hiatal hernia on the way down.
   I spent the night mostly awake in searing agony. I got up several times, to take TUMS, to take naproxen (yes, I know, horrid for the stomach actually but it was 2:30 a.m. and I was desperate), to eat yogurt...nothing helped. It's not quite as bad as the last time this happened, I think because it wasn't motherfucking Clindamycin in the capsule in question, but it's close. Hopefully the GI bleeding won't be as bad this time, because last time I did have a few dizzy spells.
   I almost didn't go to work this morning. Hotter literally nudged me, moaning, off the bed with his foot, and before you hate all over him (keep reading, he gets his later I promise) it was a good thing I went in because I managed to finagle another temp job out of PseudoCorp that'll keep things afloat for another two months.
   Then comes the part that pushed me over the edge, and I wish I could tell y'all about it, especially since nobody at work was being an asshole (quite the contrary, actually), but I am too paranoid about what Eyeballs Who Dislike Me would try to make of it and who they would try to make it to so I can't. So instead I'll just say that everyone involved in my new position seems positively lovely and I really look forward to showing them my gratitude for the job by rocking it.
   I went home, and Hotter made a fabulous Bambi Stroganoff for dinner, and then the children were acting out because they need more attention, but I was tired and bitter and in an unbelievable amount of pain, and we proceeded to have a horrible evening. EVERYBODY demonstrated the absolute worst facets of their personalities. EVERYONE. And then I sent the grounded children to bed crying with admonitions that I just couldn't. Take. One. More. Thing. and then Hotter accidentally wiped a hunk of raw chicken ALL OVER THE KITCHEN in the process of preparing the dogs' food and I LOST IT. I have issues with raw chicken. It is gross. He knows this, and chose to berate me for using hot soapy water to clean it up when there was hand sanitizer closer to the scene of the crime against my sensibilities, and that, gentle readers, is when I as a grown-ass woman of nearly thirty-three years old beaned my husband with a large, wilted carrot.
   Do I really have to say anything more about my mental state than that? I assaulted the person who loves me most with a wilted root vegetable. Shiiiiit.
   In the midst of my subsequent bawling, Middle Child got out of bed and apologized for his role in the evening and told me not to cry, that he knew I was doing my best, and oh, y'all. My kids deserve a better mother.
   Tomorrow is my birthday. I can't afford to take the day off, even if it's just to go to the doctor, because I don't have the co-pay. Honestly I kinda hope I get lucky and bleed out in my sleep, because it's the happiest ending I can think of right now, but chances are I'll wake up feeling like death itself and a torrent of shit will rain down on me from the sky the moment I walk out the front door.
   And you?

title: clusterfuck

body:
...when I predicted that today would suck.
   I spent today wondering why everything was so fucking awful. I thought it was that all of the "OMG I almost ended up without a job when we had NO savings" (but I got the new job, which it turns out is something I could rock with one hand tied behind my back and the people I am working with continue to be lovely) plus "GAHHHH HIGHER RENT NOOOO!" stress had finally caught up to me, but while that is MORE than enough to ruin a gal's sunny disposition it was worse than that. 
   I woke up this morning in the throes of a fullblown autoimmune clusterfuck, complete with sacroiliitis (which, well, I guess that'll teach me to snivel over the World's Worst Heartburn sensation of a gelcap disintegrating in my lower esophagus). As something of a pain connoisseur I have to say that sacroiliiac pain is really up there and one of my very least-favorite things. Booo, body.
   It got preempted by the Day of OMG SUCK yesterday, but I meant to tell y'all that the XY had been a (reluctant, heavily coached, but I was still prepared to give credit where credit seemed to be due) mensch and agreed to kick in an extra fifty dollars per month so we wouldn't have to move IF I could talk the landlord into a fifty-dollar raise in rent instead of the proposed hundred-dollar one (yes, the XY is STILL underpaying in terms of child support but oh well). But that was yesterday, and today when I called to tell him that yes, I had succeeded in talking the landlord down to a fifty-dollar increase and make extra sure before agreeing to sign a new lease that he would keep his word the XY cursed me out, accused me of "nickel and diming" him, called me a liar about the rent, and threatened to sue me and take the children away if I left the school district. Which was how I came to spend nearly an hour discreetly weeping at work.
   And then the PMS Buddy reminder e-mail arrived, an apparent day late. Ballllls. Et tu, ovary?
   All in all I feel like I've been beaten heavily with a bat and left for dead by my thirty-third birthday, and my hiatal hernia is still killing me, and I'm working an eight-hour shift tomorrow as a prep-cook for a local banquet through Temp Agency #2. If my stomach was up for it and I didn't have to work and I had the cash to go to the liquor store I think I'd be looking for the bottom of a bottle right now, but as it stands I'm going to...
...EVIDENTLY PASS THE HELL OUT! The above was written yesterday, 1/13 and I fell asleep writing it. Work today was good. Still in hella pain but oh well. Feeling slightly less grim about things over all; it seems Temp Agency #2 might be able to find me weekend work on the regular and maybe the demise of Weekend Warrior job won't have such a major impact on my little family, after all?
