body: I woke up with what feels like the world's worst hangover this morning, except problem is?  I didn't have a drop to drink yesterday.  So I'm feeling rather betrayed over the whole thing, especially the pounding headache, and to distract myself I've been lazing around reading blogs and found out that some people have been up to some noteworthy shenanigans.  Such as:*   k. at Two Adults, One Brown Baby totally needs to change her blog-name now, because in addition to the original brown baby (who incidentally is so damn handsome it's sinful), now a toddler, she finally got to bring brown baby #2 home after a lengthy hospital stay (Iris was very premature and is the surviving twin of sweet baby Noah; she has some interesting cardiac anatomy and "jenky lungs" going on, but is scrappy enough to be home rocking O2 and a g-tube, which I happen to know correlates strongly with extra-cute babies *ahem, Little Child*).  Go tell her congratulations!*   Aubrey over at Vagina Drum posted a recipe for bubblegum-infused vodka.  'Nough said.*   Tara (TAR-a, not TERR-a) of Bite The Bedbugs has a sad, and I know that feeling all too well.  She also does that thing I do where she has a sad or a scared and turns it into the funny, but she's funnier than I am.  It makes for good reading but she's also pretty hilarious when she's not sad so go and cheer her up in the comments section before she recklessly accepts any more friend requests on the Facespace from people who are all "OHHAI it's ____ from the blogosphere but shhh I'm not out as a blogger here, I mostly use it to keep tabs on my elderly mother-in-law and mock my brother-in-laws' penises, not that I've ever seen them, the penises that is, I've met my MIL before."  You know, other people who aren't me.*   Facespace, by the way, as far as I can tell, is ™ Café Darkness, which is a pretty funny blog; I didn't realize I was borrowing it from there until just last night and don't like to use stuff without giving credit where credit is due.  This post from them cracked my shit up, and also this one.*   This dude from the Twitter is seriously funny.  I mean look: HAHAHAHAHA!*   I discovered the last three people/places courtesy of "mom" at Fuck Yeah Motherhood, who is all-around full of The Awesome.  This is probably my favorite post of hers, although this was was hilarious as well.  She's got to be doing something right, because she's raising seriously cool kids.  Also if I make it to BlogHer I'm sleeping with her.  No, really, we're roomies!   Okay, Little Child has gotten out the roaring/screeching dinosaur toy that my kids only play with when Mama has a hangover or migraine (it's Of The Devil, that thing, and is like a zombie in that it's unkillable--same batteries for FIVE YEARS?  ZOMBIESAURUS!) and is putting it through its paces for Hotter, and I have to go and kill lovingly redirect them both now, so while I'm doing that feel free to leave me some funnies in the comments.  I will need them after family therapy later today (barf).
title: link love on a Thursday morning

body:
I've said this before, and I'm saying it again; y'all are some seriously amazing people. Just this week, readers of this humble website have:
*   Dropped enough spare change in the tip jar that I was able to fill the gas tank of the MFA Minivan and get some necessary groceries. I didn't say anything, but part of my gloom last week was that getting to work and making sure we're not out of milk between now and the first of the month was going to be dicey. But thanks to a few of y'all it's all good.
*   Sent me AH-MA-ZING "everything cream." I saw my pal RainbowSouffle mention this stuff on the Twitter in the context of "if I offered this for sale in my Etsy shop would anyone maybe wanna buy it?" and pre-disaster e-mailed her and said "YES, I would totally buy that" and she was all "NO, I will NOT take your money" and just sent me some. It's full of awesome stuff like coconut oil and beeswax and vitamin E oil and she can scent it with sweet orange or peppermint essential oil (I chose sweet orange) and OMG THE AMAZINGNESS. It's solid but spreads smoothly, all natural, antimicrobial (coconut oil is magic, y'all), and you can use it on your lips, face, hands, cuticles, or pretty much anywhere. Except for probably your eyes. I mean, I haven't tried it, but...yeah. Currently it's not up in the shop but if you ask nicely I'm sure RainbowSouffle'll list it; she certainly should. AHEM, RAINBOWSOUFFLE.
*   Offered to custom-make something AWESOME for me that is a seeeecret for now because Hotter doesn't know what it is (HAHAHA, HOTTER).
*   Filled the comments section of this post with all kinds of pink-puffy-heart love.
   Between you wonderful people, my family, and what's looking to be a longer-term job at PseudoCorp (which continues to grow on me; it was a tough adjustment initially but I think it's actually good for me to have to present a thousand people per day with a dazzling smile and a chipper greeting in a fake-it-till-you-make-it kind of way, and also I really like a lot of my co-workers there) I can't hardly stay in a foul mood. My life may suck at times, but by and large it's full of the awesome.
   Thanks to all of y'all who helped remind me of that :)
title: the one where I feel the love

body:
This morning is already bringing The Crazy to Casa MFA, but out of the chaos did come something so cute that I actually wanted to make sure I wrote it down and remembered it forever.    Hotter was letting me sleep in/sleep off the maximum safe dose of Benadryl (because last night I had hives, BAD ones, the kind where I wanted to rip my skin off but couldn't stop smacking, rubbing, knuckle-grinding, and every other non-scratching fake-out maneuver my skin's nerve endings laughed at me for trying long enough to try it) (and no of COURSE I don't know what gave me the hives, but this happens to me once in a while and has only culminated in my needing the emergency room and lots of shots of epi twice so it's mostly just annoying and I generally wake from a Benadryl coma hive-free) this morning even though he was up and down all night, er, indisposed, because even when he's cranky and sick he thinks I deserve a break most of the time.  Oh wait, did I tell you we ALL HAVE THE STOMACH FLU?   I think I'll keep him.   Anyway, apparently Hotter stepped outside to call CVS about a prescription foul-up (presumably to play Good Cop before I woke up) and the MFA Children made use of his being out on the front porch to open up, root through and partially empty a box that had been sitting inside the (unused, clean and vacuumed out) fireplace in the family room.  The box doesn't live there because we're that desperate for storage, but because what appears to be the flue for that stupid fireplace is on the bottom of it and doesn't close fully unless you weight it down, allowing cold air inside during the winter and camel crickets, skinks, and mosquitoes inside in the summer, something needed to go there and a heavy box that I'll never unpack (it contains everything I have saved from my life before the age of twenty-one, things I didn't have the heart to just destroy because SOMEone ought to care about them but don't really want that much because most of those years I've managed to wall off through a well-placed fugue of PTSD non-memory) worked well.   Until this morning.   I lurched out of bed, checked in with the children, who informed me that Hotter was outside on the phone, and went out to say good morning to my husband.  When we both came back in Big Child (a.k.a. The Informer) came to report that his little brothers were "going crazy" and were convinced Santa Claus had come (The Informer still believes too, but gawd, y'all, he only comes at Christmas and have you stepped outside lately THIS IS NOT CHRISTMAS WEATHER).   Yeah, my kids believe in Santa.  I give them free reign to enjoy the secular magic associated with major retail holidays, because why should their being Jewish and my being a lifelong atheist to boot keep them from getting to believe in Santa?     Little Child came pounding down the hardwood flooring of our hall on his fat baby-feet and, wide-eyed, exclaimed that "YES!  Santa CAME BACK TO OUR HOUSE AND LEFT PRESENTS, he hid them inside a box RIGHT IN THE FIREPLACE which is totally from him because THAT IS HOW HE GETS IN and he left it there after he came down the chimney MOMMY LOOK MOMMY MOOOOOMMMMMYYYYY LOOK!  He left us a map to where the rest of the presents are!"  Middly had slunk up quietly with his hands full of evidence, which Little Child proceeded to show me like a QVC presenter.  "SEE?  And he put plastic on it in case we need to go outside wasn't that smart of him?"  It was a laminated child's drawing of a map of a house trailing yellowed tape-streamers, which I recognized as the cover to my first Young Authors Award submission when I was Middly's age.   Little Child went to grab the next item, but at that point, Middle Child couldn't contain himself and spoke up, too: "SHARKTH TEESE, LOOK MOMMY THANNA BRING ME SHARKTH TEESE TO UTHE WHEN I BIL-DA SHARK!  Thanna tricked me like it wuth a card but I untied it an got it open LOOK!"  He thrust a souvenir package of calligraphy nibs that I think The Narcissist bought at the Sistine Chapel when I was sixteen after she threw me out of the house at me, which were stitched into their stiff cardboard display packet, shaped like an envelope and shut with fabric ties.  "THEE HOW POINTY," Middle Child raved.  "Be careful Mommy!"     I gently explained what the things in the box were (at least the "treasure map" and the "shark teeth") and put them back into the box and replaced the lid.  I haven't unpacked those in several moves and don't really want them, but as I have no family to hold these things dear on my behalf I hold onto them myself.  Because I know my kids will really enjoy hearing about them sometime when I'm less overwrought and also not flu-stricken or in an antihistamine fog, god dammit.   Hotter apologized for letting the boys jump up in my grille before I'd had my pills or any caffeine, like they didn't do just that every day of their lives that they were with me prior to his coming along (read: 99% of their existence) and said that CVS had been kind enough to just offer to GIVE him two days' worth of medication until he can get a new prescription called in.  "They still fear you there," he said, shaking his head in awe.  I said okay, I'd go pick that up, stepped into some pants and out the door.   I passed the local middle school on my way to the pharmacy and noticed what appeared to be a massive yardsale/fleamarket scenario going on in their parking lot.  I am broke and never carry cash, but noticed some framed art and thought about how I could use a couple of frames...on the way back I decided to see if anything there spoke to me and whether I had enough quarters in my purse to be worth the stop.   The stop was worth it.  They were getting ready to pack everything up and haul it to the dump due to the heat and lack of interest, and cheerfully invited me to go ahead and take anything I could haul off, which SCORE, Y'ALL!  We rent one of the cheapest addresses in one of the most affluent school districts in town and there was a lot of NICE STUFF.  I scored a flour-sifter, cheese cutter, set of wine glasses, rolling-ball foot massager (unused), mens' fedora in mint condition in its original box from the turn of the century (!!!), one of those brass desk lamps you used to see in libraries and banks, a floor lamp for the older boys' room, an onion/potato bin (solid wood with nice hardware trimmings), a few t-shirts and pairs of shorts for the boys, Operation and a couple of other games, and...AND...OMG Y'ALL THIS DESK!     I took the brass lamp off of it and admired it a moment, because it was huge and solid dark wood, with the dining-room table-sized top of it consisting of four or five massive thick planks stained dark walnut and ohhhh so pretty.  Then I decided I couldn't even spare the twenty-five bucks and didn't have a way to get it home and left.  Then I decided the desk would haunt me, and did a U-turn and came back and asked the men loading the furniture up what their bottom price was.  "Five bucks if you don't tell anyone, I just don't want to take it back to the storage place," said one guy.    This is where I preface the rest of this story by saying that a) it wasn't a yardsale to benefit the school but rather a church group of some kind and b) I get the dirty end of the wimmen-are-so-stupid stick enough that sometimes I feel like accepting the clean end to swing to my advantage is a pretty okay thing to do and possibly even karma in action.  Okay?  Okay.   I smiled sweetly and said "well in that case why don't I just take it 
off your hands as a favor," and he said alright but how will you move 
it."  And reader, I got the toolkit out of the MFA Minivan and announced brightly that I'd just take it apart and shove it in in pieces (mind you, I saw no bolts or screws; this desk is pre-IKEA for sure and I wouldn't be surprised if it was older than I am), I mean how hard could THAT be!  The older men running the sale were horrified and it took all of thirty seconds for one of them to volunteer to run the desk home for me in his truck if I lived close-by, and another to say he'd help lift it in, ma'am, why don't you get out of the sun, and just like that I showed up in Casa MFA's driveway home from my pharmacy run with a chase vehicle bearing a great hulking magnificent desk, and Hotter was gobsmacked but just shook his head and laughed.     We were really happy for about thirty seconds and then the MFA Minivan blew up in the driveway.  MFA Mechanic assured me via telephone that it "just" sounds like a "hose blew" but y'all there was a BOOM and then a cloud of furious steam and smoke hissing out for a good five minutes and ALL OF THE COOLANT LEAKED OUT.   Mother.  Fucker.   The desk was a great find, though.  Hotter's father refinished fine furniture for a living and taught him how to strip and refinish wood for fun and profit, and when Hotter got a chance to examine the desk himself ("THIS IS SOLID WOOD!  LOOK!  LOOK HOW THICK IT IS!") he popped a total boner and praised my eye and exclaimed over what a find the desk had been, so I'm managing to ignore the vehicular carnage for the moment and just, you know, revel in the stomach flu.   And oh what else, the peas are blooming, the beans are making tiny baby beans, I caught the skink that got into the house and released it, and...yeah.  Anyway.  Strange days, y'all.  How are YOUR weekends going?
title: strange days

body: ...because everyone else has recovered from what I am now in the throes of: GI DOOOOOM!!!   Also, Middle and Little Children have gone into the unpacking business together.  Today they: "WERE JUST LOOKING IN THE BIG CLOSET IN THE BIG BOYS' ROOM BECAUSE HE WANTED TO AND I FOWWOWED HIM AN HE FOUND A TUMBLE STICK, A MISSING TUMBLE STICK, MOMMY LOOK MOMMY IT'S IMPAWTANT AND THEN HE FOUND A CLIFFORD BOOK FOR ME!  I WUV CLIFFORD AND WHY DID YOU HAVE A CLIFFORD BOOK FOR ME HIDING?  MOMMY--"   And that is when Hotter pried their little fingers, toes, noses and eyeballs out of the crack underneath the bathroom door and took them elsewhere.   I still plan to keep him.   Even if he is the one who gave this to me, the bastard.   Family.  Heh.  Wouldn't trade it, y'all!*ETA:     We do know where it came from.  Big Child came home from school drinking from a bottle (water) that was not-ours.  When I questioned him he said it had belonged to the older Bus Stop Brother, who is a filthy urchin, "but it's okay!  I rinsed it!  It's clean!  Daddy says--" and I lectured him about drinking after friends and discussed how plain water doesn't necessarily kill germs, and I would have sounded all paranoid but look, you see, the first time one of them drinks after a filthy urchin...said filthy urchin isn't at school or the bus stop the next day or the day after...Big Child was MFA Patient Zero and then Hotter fell as he's immunosuppressed and I was next because he is a snuggler.  Balls!  I could deal with being right just a little less, honestly.     Anyway with Hotter being a chef and someone having asked me on the Facespace what in the world we ate, STAND DOWN!  THE MFA HOUSEHOLD FOOD SAFETY STREAK CONTINUES UNBROKEN!

body:
I have to interrupt my normally at least somewhat high-brow narrative of our lives and times here to be positively nasty, because I can't vent my damn bladder in my own house and I've gotta let off some pressure somehow.   If you're easily offended by humorous recountings of scatological interludes both human and animal, perhaps this is not the blog for you right now.   I just had to holler the following through the closed bathroom door here at Casa MFA:You need to stop doing this every night at bedtime.  If it is taking you an hour two or three times a day to poop then you need to go to a poop doctor and we will take you tomorrow.  If you're not really pooping, I don't need to know what you ARE doing, but you need to do it behind a closed door OTHER than that one on your OWN time, not at bedtime.  I'm going to set a timer for three minutes and you're going to be back in bed.  The end.   Lawd help us, I thought I had at least a couple of years before the kind of bullshit I think was going on in there, and more importantly, every moment that The Unnamed MFA Child isn't doing whatever he's doing in there Hotter is in there because he is indisposed and Little Child is still potty-training and I DON'T THINK I'VE POOPED IN A WEEK and I had to take a Lasix because I'm retaining a lot of hormonal water-weight and DEAR GOD PEOPLE I AM THE GIRL HERE SO I AM SUPPOSED TO BE THE BATHROOM HOG, NOT THE ONE WHO WATERS THE BUSHES OUTSIDE AND SWEARS AT THE TOP OF THEIR LUNGS AT THE VEHICLE IN THE DRIVEWAY BECAUSE EVEN IT PISSED LIKE A RACEHORSE, THE WHOLE COOLING SYSTEM'S WORTH...   Wait, in the time it hit me to save on that that the beans were spared a watering; The Unnamed MFA's back in bed now, and I heard no flush.  Eww.  Having one bathroom is for the birds.  See?
  Figure One: Adolescence isn't kind to anyone at Casa MFA, not even or perhaps you might say especially not to the MFA Flock.  Ha!
title: I'm the only double-X up in this piece and I never get to pee indoors: OMGWTFBBQ

body: *   Last month our finances here at Casa MFA were all "ouch, crap, well stuff happens I guess but srsly MFA Minivan?  Fine, so this month and next month will suck, I dig it."*   This month I am noticing that my husband (who started his tenure as MFA Alpha Male only about five months ago at the same weight-class I am in, that of "red beans and rice din't miss ya but who cares about the extra ten pounds, that's an easy fix") actually looks gaunt, and oh crap, he really is Not Healthy on top of having been smacked with the GI Flu and damn, you really will be having a staycation at Local Teaching Hospital when they go to fix this because no way are they letting him out the same day.*   About that same-day thing (yes the Unseen Administration at Local Teaching Hospital really did book this originally as "same-day surgery" and sent us to the Acronymous Same-day Surgery Highlights Or Lowlights, Explained Simply branch of the hospital to have a nurse ask questions about Hotter's surgical history and a nurse-anesthetist tell him what to expect from general anesthesia.  HA!  Yes, really.  And I was all "But ASSHOLES, you realize the transplant team is performing the operation and I asked for the head of anesthesia due to Hotter's floppy airway, history of smoking, and rampant thus-far untreated sleep apnea, yes?  I think we are in the wrong place.  ASSHOLES aren't supposed to work with us, we've been at this so long we could RUN this piece").  The honest to Godiva truth of it, y'all, is that Hotter and I went to the meet-and-greet with the transplant surgeons with concrete agendas, which I guess you could say were a little bit different.  Mine included making sure they were familiar with his case history, had accounted for known risks, were aware of his actual symptoms and the ways in which they veered from the usual presentation of Surgi-ma-callit-itis, and were as aggressive as we wanted them to be in correcting both current and potential surgical problems and making good use of the anesthesia time.  Hotter's included "making sure I get to leave the same day because man, I hate doctors and I WILL HAVE THE ANGRY FACE THE WHOLE TIME!"  So after I exchanged friendly fire with them over the nitty-gritty of what they'd be doing and the merits of not being pansies in general given how ugly this had the potential to become given Hotter's surgical history, current list of meds, sup-optimal functioning of one donor organ, and pitbull of a wife and they made some really big decisions about saving his life, when he stuck his lip out and asked about going home the brilliant minds with the golden hands looked at me like "is he serious" and I looked at them like "dudes you are ALMOST OUT THE DOOR" and they said "potentially, in the remote hypothetical possibility wherein we could get this done laparoscopically and without any complications SUUUUUURE!" and beat feet.  And one of the trailing minions checked "same-day surgery" on a form and there you have it: ASSHOLES.  Who were all "OMG THEY CAN DO THAT KIND OF SURGERY NOW?" and while I was extremely impressed with the nurse-anesthetist I am also just being a total cunt about MDeities Only and No Residents Please this time around because the margin for error here is very, very slim.  The surgery is in one week and clearly Mama needs to lovingly redirect a certain major teaching hospital in that time.*   But hey, ALSO the finances this month?  Are kind of like "okay, well, we're as weak as a baby kitten and we've got an audience with the Pope, but hey what's the worst case scenario?"  Then the MFA Minivan was all jazz hands and we and the mechanic were both like "just needs a hose, HAHA, that's what she said" but guess what?  It was really the radiator.  Broke right in half.  Well, shit.*   This leaves us, by which I pretty much mean me, with some very unpleasant choices to make in the seven whole days before Hotter's major surgery, involving things like selling jewelry and cancelling my Ladies' Social Media Convention plans and such, just to keep our heads above the water, and I has a big sad.  I seriously got up this morning feeling wobbly and gassy but otherwise potentially okay, got the call from the mechanic, went back to sleep, and here I am.  The MFA Children missed the bus and I let them stay home because the MFA Minivan isn't home and well screw it, they're just watching cartoons and having extra recess at this point anyway.  And Hotter is pissy because he hates poverty and is about done with small boys and his wife being useless, and has already yelled at me about the money and how I need to make MFA Mechanic take payments or something twice and I'm all "MFA Mechanic cuts me big breaks on labor as a favor and is a good guy but there's favors and then there's oral sex and financing a part he pays for up-front is more like oral sex than a favor and I don't feel comfortable asking MFA Mechanic for oral sex."  *   Sigh.
title: well, shit

body:
*   Poe ate Balzac!  You may already know this if you follow me on the Twitter.  Of course, he couldn't do it while anyone was WATCHING or anything cool like that (MFA Family: 0/Animal Kingdom: 1).  The innernet informed me that rat snakes need to feel like they're ambushing their prey in order to eat voluntarily, and suggested providing a cereal box for Poe to hide in (as to what the innernet suggested if that did not induce Poe to eat the damn mouse, do your own search for "feeding snakes" and "braining," or just take my word for it that the cereal box saved the damn snake's life).  Apparently this did the trick, although why Poe felt the need to "ambush" a creature that spent all of its days dragging its nuts over his face in every direction is beyond me.  Animals are ridiculous like that, I guess.  I was elated though.  Hotter was not.*   The chickens.  Are growing.  Like weeds.  We still have to keep them inside at night, but they're getting a bit crowded in the box:
  Figure One: It's gotten a little cramped in there since the last group photo.   During the day, they go out in their coop.  They travel via paper bag:
  Figure Two: "Peep peep peep peep peeeeeep!" (translation: "fuck ALL of y'all!")   They're also getting a little harder to handle.  Mofos can FLY now!  The MFA Children are always wanting to hold the chicks, who now want to get on your SHOULDER, and last night a chick tried to flap and scramble up onto Little Child's shoulder and scratched his face (just a tiny scratch, but it scared him).  Little Child was all "WHICH CHICKEN DID IT???" and when I said Geronimo did he announced "I don't WIKE Geronimo anymore!" (MFA Family: 0/Animal Kingdom: 2).   Yesterday was Tuesday, the two-week anniversary of the MFA Flock, and so I dutifully went outside to take a picture of Speck so that y'all could see how she's grown.  The first week's picture was easy because the chickens were all stunned from their epic journey.  The second week's picture I forgot to post because I had PMS and then Middle Child said something hilarious, but here it is:
  Figure Three: Still pretty cute.    This week, though...I went outside and opened the door of the coop, and Speck (who has emerged as mama's clear favorite) came running out and hopped onto my wrist, and I went to take a picture, and here is what I got:
  Figure Four: There was a chicken there a second ago, I swear...(MFA Family: 0/Animal Kingdom: 3)   I got about twenty more like that, and a couple like this:
  Figure Five: "PEEP!" (translation: "BITCH, WHAT THE FUCK!")   But I didn't want y'all to think I was some kind of chicken-torturer wanted to get a shot of her sitting on my hand for consistency's sake (because I'm anal-retentive dedicated to blogging like that).  So I chased the damn chicken around the yard casting aspersions upon her ancestors to the neighbors' great amusement for about half an hour (no lie) until I was drenched with sweat and she was panting from the effort of dodging the Blackberry and my stream of terse invective en route from my hand to my shoulder to the ground, rinse, lather, curse, repeat.  I won't show you what I looked like at the end of the chase to preserve my pseudonymity, but Speck looked like this: 
  Figure Six: Much more humane.  Not.*   As I staggered inside, perspiring and utterly defeated by a creature with a brain the size of a lentil, a damn skank got into the house, and it's still at large.  Joy.  (MFA Family: 0/Animal Kingdom: 4)  I suppose I ought to clean behind the toilet.ETA: Imma leave that typo in because it's hilarious, but it was, in fact, a skink (thanks terri c.) and not a skank.  My mother was not involved in this afternoon's shenanigans.  I'm chalking the error up to my having just had my arse handed to me by a pullet which makes the score 0/6.*   Tonight the MFA Children are having dinner visitation with The XY, and Hotter and I went to Trader Joe's and then stopped at the nearby pet store to buy Poe another mouse.  When we got home, we dumped the mouse into Poe's tank, turned our backs long enough to put the frozen food away, and the damn snake ate the damn mouse before it even acquired a blog-name AND WE MISSED IT AGAIN.  BALLS!  (MFA Family: 0/Animal Kingdom: 5)*   I'm going to go ahead and publish this before any of us is savaged by a wild boar or anything.  How are all of YOU?

20.09% is just a funny-looking discount and they were thinking ahead) but I told Justin how I would be the PERFECT BLOGGER to review their stuff because I COOK LIKE A MOFO and I was MARRYING A CHEF I just wanted to pop in and let y'all know that the principal said all of the right things, and gave me her personal WORD that she was going to END THIS. "This is outrageous. The school can absorb the cost of the book if she can't locate it, and I am aghast to hear of any member of my staff treating a child like that. I'm very sorry. Please tell him he can borrow any book he likes next week," she said as I left her office. I ran into Middle Child's Special Education case manager in the hallway after the meeting and she asked how the school year was going so far, so I told her and she was HORRIFIED. Horrified but not particularly surprised. Apparently Nasty Librarian no likey the Special Ed. kids. Which...well, I can't even. So the case manager is going to check in with Middly and speak to his classroom teacher, because as she put it, after asking me not to take it the wrong way, "some kids can withstand that kind of treatment from an adult but Middle Child is not one of them; she CANNOT do that to him!" Yes. THANK you, wonderful Special Education case manager, for getting it.
   The principal called me later in the day to follow up and said that she spoke to Nasty Librarian and told her in no uncertain terms not to say one single negative word about ANYTHING to ANY of my children ever again and to pass any necessary communications about any future problems that may come up through her office to me. "She verbalized understanding of my expectation with regard to all of that," was how the principal put it, so yeah, we'll see. I plan to attend Middle Child's next class library session to keep an eye on things, and so does the Special Education case manager.
   The dental work (which it turns out was not a root canal after all but something else hideously painful) went well from a results-oriented standpoint. My dentist insisted on trying some new kind of block on me, which succeeded in numbling the left side of my face all the way out to the cheekbone and up to the eyeball and paralyzing half of my upper lip for several hours but alas did not keep me from feeling what he did to That Tooth. It pretty much feels like I got punched in the face, but thanks to the temporary crown for the first time since March I don't LOOK that way :)
   Other than that it's gray and rainy here to the point that we're under a floodwatch, I have a stomach bug and a migraine, and The Top Secret Job of Legally-Binding Confidentiality and Nondisclosure ended early. Booooo, life. I picked up the refill on my Pristiq today though, and by tomorrow I should hopefully be less miserable about it all. Hey, Thursday? Don't let the door hit you in the ass, mmkay?

*   I was up most of last night COUGHING. The hell? NO THANK-YOU, LUNGS. JUST STOP IT. STOP IT AT ONCE!
*   A merchant I purchased something from charged us twice. I pointed it out and they said the soonest they could fix it was Friday. I said fine, whatever, I usually get paid Tuesday night or Wednesday morning. Except the holiday effed that up and currently our bank account is overdrawn. Eff.
*   I'm having a root canal tomorrow as part of the crown-prep, which on the whole YAY because OMG FINALLY and also THANK YOU, BRIGHTER.COM! But that said, and with the caveat that I KNOW I ought to just be grateful, I am not looking forward to this. Because, well, nobody enjoys a root canal. On top of which I am immune to dental anesthetics so I'm going to feel the whole effing thing. And also my dentist is a very sweet and gentle man who truly hates working on me because he hates hurting people, so I'm going to have to try and play it off all "NO REALLY IT'S FINE" for his benefit, because I don't want to make him feel bad or, worse, say he can't go on because it's inhumane. Again, this is a HAPPY THING for the most part because not having a front tooth sucks and so does all of the toothache with (almost) none of the tooth, and I promise and swear that I am incredibly happy and grateful to be able to get this done...I'm just dreading the actual doing bit.
*   I'm still gutted--GUTTED--over what happened yesterday. I've e-mailed the principal and let her know we urgently need to have a sit-down, because that's the next step up the chain of command and if I'm going to go over her head I have to let her fail first (gee, is my lack of optimism showing?).
*   Because life loves me, I was supposed to pick up a refill of the medication that keeps me from being a panicky, pessimistic wreck 24/7 today, but now I can't until tomorrow when I get paid thanks to that merchant effing up. Which...great and also OH HAHA, THIS KIND OF CHAIN-REACTION CLUSTERFUCK WOULD BE KIND OF COMICAL IF IT WAS HAPPENING TO SOMEONE ELSE. Missing even one dose of that stuff has a catastrophic effect on my general outlook, and at this point I think I can objectively say I have every right to be in a shit mood, but by tomorrow I'm going to be in The Bad Place regardless, so...yeah. I think Imma shut it for a couple of days until I have something less Eeyore to say.
*   It's gray and rainy here, and supposed to be ALL WEEK LONG. Because OF COURSE. 
*   How are all of YOU?

My dear friend Aurelia, who often reads from her Blackberry, pointed out that MFA Mama was not very easy to read that way. Something about the text column getting really narrow? I don't know, if she'd just get an iPhone she wouldn't have that problem, because along with every OTHER way they're superior to Blackberries* they're MUCH EASIER to browse the web with, but not everyone is a) rich** and b) discerning enough to have an iPhone and I like to include everyone whenever possible.

It turns out there's no easy way to set your Typepad blog to display in mobile format when viewed from a mobile device, although you CAN accomplish that by adding /.m to any Typepad URL. Entering URLs is a pain in the butt on Blackberries too though, not to mention that /.m is hard to remember, so I've put up a link at the wayyyy top of the right sidebar where you can click to view MFA Mama in mobile format. I hope that makes it easier on those of y'all who like to read from your mobile devices of ALL kinds! xox

That's mostly just smacktalk for Aurelia's benefit, because she's Team Blackberry and I'm Team iPhone :)**   Yes, I know, I have an iPhone and am far from rich, as someone has already pointed out in the comments. body:
Dear Sir:
   Hi there! It's me, the lady who you ran into at the high school soccer field earlier this evening. You know, the one powerwalking with the dog on a leash, who your two dogs came galloping up to out of nowhere in the dark? They seemed like nice dogs, and you seemed like a nice guy, so I'm not going to be rude or anything, but I really wish you'd leash them when you take them walking at night.
   See, I am a dog person. I have two dogs myself (a guard breed and a mutt also) and I like dogs in general. So I didn't freak out when your dogs rushed at me, and knew to stand my ground and wait for you to come over and tell me that they were friendly before I tried to pet either of them. If I'd been afraid of dogs and carrying mace, that's the first point where your failure to leash your dogs could have ruined both our evenings.
   I was glad you came running over immediately with your flashlight to supervise your pets, but I was a little taken aback when you asked anxiously whether my dog was male or female. It was a relief when you said that the Doberman wouldn't "mess with" a girl dog, but half the time I go powerwalking in the field where we met I have a boy dog with me, and what would have happened THEN? That's the second point where your failure to leash your dogs could have ruined both our evenings.
   The third point wasn't really an issue, because my girl dog is friendly and obedient, and sat on command at my feet rather than trying to roughhouse with or dominate either of your dogs, but you know how I pretended not to hear when you asked what kind of dog I had? That's because I worry about other people making assumptions due to the fact that Isis is a pitbull (you may not have been able to tell because her ears are not cropped; I wish your Doberman's ears hadn't been either because that's really ouchy, although I'm not necessarily judging YOU as for all I know your Doberman was a rescue). She was raised in a loving home by a responsible owner, and she's the friendliest dog I know, but my next-door neighbor has an unneutered male pit that he sometimes walks in the area, and he's a little LESS responsible than I am. I don't think he fights the dog or anything or I would have called the police on him, but my point is that when you chose to let your dogs run loose in that field you didn't know if someone would come along walking a Chihuahua they would have viewed as a tasty snack or a mastiff that would have viewed them as a tasty snack. You never know what's going to be on the end of someone else's leash (or, you know, orbiting them freely in a radius the approximate size of a city block, as the case may be) and that is another reason why it's a good idea to keep your dogs on leashes (well, that and it's the law, although I'm not going to get preachy about the law as technically we were both trespassing).
   Finally, while it may not have ruined anyone's evening TONIGHT, how do you know my dog wasn't carrying something contagious that your dogs could have caught from her, and for that matter how do I know YOUR dogs aren't carrying something contagious that she could have caught from one of THEM? You don't. Maybe the reason one of us was walking our pet in a deserted high school soccer field was that they had bordatella from a stay in a kennel and couldn't go to a dog park. That's not why I was there, and I didn't hear either of your dogs coughing, and my dog has had the bordatella vaccine, but that particular vaccine isn't the MOST reliable (don't get me wrong, it's still worth getting for your pet, I just worry because my dog has a weak immune system). 
   In conclusion, while nobody's evening was ruined tonight, you're placing yourself and your animals at risk physically and legally by not leashing them. I get that you probably work all day and your dogs need the exercise, and I know it's fun to see them run, but it's really not worth the potential ramifications, particularly if, like both of us, one of your dogs is a guard or fighting breed. People make assumptions about these dogs that can cause them to be rude, belligerent, or fearful, and none of those things lead anywhere good. I would never let MY dog run loose in public, even if no one seemed to be around, because while the only way she'd ever hurt anyone is by accidentally tripping them up or bowling them over exuberantly, and that may well be true of your Doberman as well, that's not generally going to be someone's first assumption when they see a large, muscular dog come barreling toward them in the dark. If I had to judge you as a pet owner based on the five minutes I interacted with you and your dogs I'd say you seemed fairly caring and attentive, but you still put me and my dog at risk and I don't appreciate it one little bit. Please be more responsible and considerate of others in the future. Sincerely, MFA Mama
title: an open letter to the guy with the Doberman and the mutt

body: *   We are still Rather Unwell here; it's a strange and vicious strain of the stomach flu we've got wherein you'll spend one day, pardon me for speaking so bluntly, shitting your everloving brains out, literally sitting there with your sphincter making the Mr. Bill face for upward of twenty minutes at a time while you grapple with the knowledge that your house is NOT big enough to contain the echoes of your flatulence, but your sphincter isn't done yet and you're trapped, trapped like a rat, and there's no avoiding facing the people on the other side of the door when you're done by mucking around because THEIR sphincters want to make the Mr. Bill face TOO...and then a day where you feel perfectly alright if a bit windy and off-kilter, and might do something so stupid as having an entire box of Trader Joe's Creamy Spinach and Artichoke dip followed by a huge salad for dinner, followed by another day of the other...well, pretty much indefinitely, if you're an adult.  *   As for the MFA Children, Big Child now convulses sobbing and pees himself if you show him a picture of a clean and decent child drinking after a filthy urchin from up the street or if he hears Beethoven's 9th Symphony, but his bowels seem okay, Middle Child's bowel habits are shrouded in darkest mystery (as Hotter noted when he moved in and, after about a month, said "Middly, do you even poop at all?  I don't think I've ever seen you pooping and you NEVER close the bathroom door..." and then he went to visit his mother and Middly woke the house screaming "OH MY POO-POO IT HURTS OH NOOOO!" and I gave him some Miralax but other than that I'm not entirely sure he's gone boom-boom at all since I potty-trained him at gunpoint, which is fine by me), and Little Child hasn't had a solid poop in about three years due to chronic issues so who knows on him either...children are resilient.*   Hotter holds the house record at...six...?  AN UNACCEPTABLE NUMBER OF DAYS OF THIS.*   This is causing problems in the MFA Marriage, because a) I had hoped to spend the time before Hotter's big farking surgery stockpiling orgasms and here we can't get within ten feet of each other unless one of us is on the throne and the other one is trying not to hover within the blast-radius but really does need to get into the bathroom next and b) there has been a serious breech of etiquette that we may never recover from: prior to this I could count on both hands if I wanted to the times that either of us had broken wind in front of the other and now IT'S OPEN SEASON, OH MY GOD, STOP FARTING and you see, my fear is that this will continue right up until The Big Day at which point I will be sex-starved and half-death from the thunderous volleys he's unleashed JUST WHILE I'VE BEEN TYPING THIS and then there's the post-op grace period where I suppose I have to tolerate whatever his digestive system has to say about what the transplant team will do to it (although I would like to hereby go on record as having Never Once That I Know Of farted in front of HIM while recovering from my hysterectomy-plus-peritonitis-disaster-and-massacree last summer, not that I expect him to do as well but the lofty example I have set in the area of post-operative intestinal fortitude bears mentioning, is all I'm saying), and...I'm just worried that he'll become set in his ways and in six months when I'm like "JESUS CHRIST, ENOUGH ALREADY" he'll act all put-upon, like when I actually made him quit smoking, for real.*   The word rectum never stops being hilarious.  Ditto sphincter.*   You stop caring about things like your chicken's weekly portrait getting done on time when you've taken eleven showers in one day, all absolutely necessary.  Sorry about that.
title: stomach flu redux or things the GI flu has taught me

body: *   That was extremely unpleasant.  By which I mean "The GI 'Flu" and also "Big Child Having The GI 'Flu" and "Hotter having the GI 'Flu" and "everyone in the house thinking I want to hear about their rectums when I don't even want to think about anyone else's rectum, hell, I don't want to think about my OWN rectum" and also "actually having the GI 'Flu my own damn self."  Lord.  Oh and let's not forget "______ having the GI Flu when The Unnamed MFA Child is Up To Nothing Good or Holy In The Bathroom With The Door Locked."*   This is maybe only the second time Hotter has seen me Dreadfully Ill and he doesn't yet understand that the Mark of Doom on me (like when a housecat stops grooming itself) is cleaning.  If I am cleaning with a grim and relentless determination and without cease I am either so mentally or physically ill as to need prompt professional assistance, and also paranoid about someone saying I am too crazy to be a good mother or else paranoid about someone saying I am too ill to be a good mother (both of which, well, let's just say they're reasonable and legitimate paranoias, not irrational ones, on my part IN GENERAL).  *   You know what I should do when I feel that awful?  I should go and lie down.  But no, see, I associate a blood pressure THAT LOW with having to be scraped up by paramedics and maybe someone attempting to intubate me in a moving vehicle or something and I am all about making sure there are clean sheets on the bed, no signs of use (at all, ever) in the bathroom area and fresh bags in every trashcan so that nobody judges if I don't pass out somewhere convenient like the front porch.  So I run around until Hotter while cooking asks me to find a vegetable for dinner because he doesn't know I'm dying, and I am so exhausted by the thought of cutting lettuce for salad that I open the freezer, find only corn, my brain breaks because that's more like a starch and then I realize that "splat splat splat splat" is the sound of drops of sweat falling off me while I stare aimlessly into the freezer and everyone really is looking at me.  Whoops.*   So then I stuck my arm into our blood pressure cuff (which runs about ten points higher than the one at Dr. Kidney's office--they have us check that) and my BP was 86/65 and Hotter stared at me a lot and asked me if I'd had any salt at all today and I was all "eeeeeat?" and he was like "I thought you were feeling better, you cleaned the whole house."  Communication FAIL!*   What this means I guess is that what I heard Hotter exclaiming at one or more of my children while they ganged up on him while I was Indisposed probably applies to me also: YOU WOULDN'T BE STRUGGLING RIGHT NOW IF YOU HADN'T JUST PUT THAT IN YOUR OWN WAY DO YOU SEE HOW YOU MAKE THINGS HARDER FOR YOURSELF???*   No, apparently not.  That poor man.  At one point as I lay dying today all I could hear was the murmur of plaintive child voices punctuated by the dad-voice going "NO, NO, BEFORE YOU ASK NO, AND NO TO YOU AS WELL SIR, NO!"*   Much to everyone's relief, it appears that I will survive.  Actually I jest (well okay the "no and no and no some more" thing really happened but what I'm not mentioning are the hundreds of very wise parenting choices he made today).  I mean, I did have to remind him at once point to "make the time fit the crime, you're doing a good job isolating and interrogating the witnesses, just don't go crazy with the sentencing, okay?" but on the whole the children got away with very little and nobody tried to pry open the bathroom door and demand a higher-court ruling so the first day Hotter's been in charge since everyone dropped the company manners was made of win.*   Especially since nobody actually lifted their leg indoors or mounted anyone else to establish their dominance.  I like to think that nobody wanted to take my place in doing those things while I was out of play.  Aww.*   Pictures of that desk are up on the Twitter.  I didn't feel up to finding the cable-doohickey to get them from the (still-ailing) Blackberry to the laptop directly, so Ubertwitter to the rescue.  Gotta love enough data-transferral redundancy that even I can't fail at life entirely when it comes to the important things like showing off the awesome free desk I liberated from the church-folk.  *   Rectum.  Ha!

body:
I went to college and grad school, because I thought it would prepare me for "the future."
   All it really did was saddle me with $63k plus mounting interest in student loans (currently in default).
   I taught for almost a decade, then stopped, in part because I could make more as a temp.
   Currently I'm a receptionist during the week. On the weekends I have two other jobs for which I am even MORE "overqualified."
   My husband, who was a Type I diabetic, worked sixty to seventy-hour weeks until his kidneys failed. His second chance at life came in 2003, when he received the second ever kidney/pancreas transplant at his transplant center. After the transplants he suffered a stroke that left him unable to drive due to seizures (his vision is also pretty poor due to numerous laser surgeries for diabetic retinopathy).
   Medicare just announced that due to my having the three jobs, which barely pay our regular monthly bills, they're cutting off his "extra help."
   What that means is that we're coming up on a "gap" during which we will need to come up with roughly $7k out of pocket before they'll go back to covering their 80%. That's about seven times what we have managed to save "in case of emergency." Our only vehicle is currently leaking antifeeze, and needs a new valve cover gasket and an alignment. Without it I can't get to work. Even with me working three jobs we'll never have $7k in time.
   My husband will die without his drugs. We might be able to keep him alive if I drop my health insurance and stop taking all of my prescriptions (without which I cannot function) and we all eat a lot of ramen. If he dies or has to go in-patient for an extended period, I will lose my job (no childcare) and my (rented) home. My kids can go to their father's if need be but I don't know what would happen to me.
   This right here is what is wrong with America.
   We are the 99%

*   Thank you, from the bottom of my black little heart, for the e-mailed and Twitter-DMed offers of cash, help with "the system," contacts in high places, etc. You are wonderful people. Let's not all rally to Do Something just yet, though; while I can't rule out the possibility that I'll ask anyone and everyone for anything and everything they can do or give if it comes to it, at this point I think we should all hold off on doing anything drastic until we know for sure that "the gap" applies to Hotter's situation.
*   After reading up on the "extra help" criteria, I don't see how he WON'T re-qualify (he has received "extra help" up until now because he was on Medicaid for a while before we got married, and being on Medicaid AND receiving Social Security benefits automatically qualifies you). It may be (and I am hoping LIKE HELL) that this only a matter of us needing to go through the application process (which we have already done online), and the letter Hotter received yesterday was just to let him know what would happen if he did NOT qualify. According to the online assessment thingamajig he "probably" qualifies. So let's all just hold onto the hope that he will qualify, and that I will stay sane while we wait to find out (yesterday I had my first panic attack in over a year, and lordamercy it was a doozy).
*   For several days now, my right upper arm area has ached the way it does when I've just had a shot (like a flu or tetanus one). The last shot I had was several weeks ago, and was in the OTHER arm. The pain isn't particularly debilitating, doesn't get better or worse with exertion or changing position, and there isn't any bruising or other discoloration of the skin over the area (although if I press it does get a lot worse for a few minutes). So it's not a big deal, it's just kind of "there." What gives, body? Why you gotta do me like that?
*   I think I have solved the problem of The One Who Dislikes Me by giving her a small gift of a type of electronic charger I heard her say she was looking to acquire (I had one because I used to have the type of equipment it charges, but I no longer have that equipment so it was of no use to me; I figured at the very least giving it to TOWDM was better than sending it to a landfill). The charger was not the standard model, but rather a nicer type that I'd purchased through an after-market source, and TOWDM was thrilled with it. Since I gave that to her she's been much nicer to me; she is still fundamentally lacking in the sense of humor department, but that's okay. I can handle humorless but friendly; it's humorless and HOSTILE that gets to me. Between that and someone's brilliant idea to bring Stalky up with HR myself so that it's on record in case some wacky accusations come in from an unidentified source I would ABSOLUTELY take a permanent job at PseudoCorp if one was offered to me. 
*   Temp Agency got back to me with "the job is ongoing for the time being," which gives me absolutely nothing to go on, and I finally decided to go the white lie route and told my boss at PseudoCorp's assistant that I'd gotten a call about an interview for a job that wasn't better than PseudoCorp but was, you know, at least a JOB and wouldn't dream of going IF PSEUDOCORP NEEDS ME because I LOVE the company, but the month I was quoted during the interview is up next week and therefore I need to know if I'm done with the company next week or if they would like me to stay on longer. I made sure to tell her to please make it clear I wasn't trying to run out on PseudoCorp AT ALL, but just, you know, needed to know whether to go on said interview.
*   The boss's assistant DID say it was news to her that I'd been told I was there for only a month, and that the vacant job position TOWDM is covering "until we find a replacement" (this is allegedly why PseudoCorp brought me in, to cover for TOWDM while she covered for that position) hasn't even been POSTED yet, which would seem to imply that they need me to hang around, and also that she'd only heard positive things about my performance from the higher-ups and would be shocked if they didn't want me to stay on for at least the forseeable future. So there's that.
*   Maybe they're thinking of promoting TOWDM to the vacant position and hiring me on to do TOWDM's old (and my current) job? That would be pretty awesome. Once I thought about not having the job any longer I realized that it's really grown on me, and a lot of the perks (the building is gorgeous and offers spectacular views, is near a super-nice public park that I can walk through on my lunch hour on nice days and has a secure and enclosed parking garage I can walk through on my lunch hour on rainy/snowy days, and while it took some adjustment on my part I'm coming to enjoy the corporate culture) are very agreeable. Plus I imagine that if they offered me something fulltime it would entail benefits and ohhhhhh beeeennnnnefiiiiiiiiiits...even if they just kept me on indefinitely as a temp the money is good enough that I don't have to worry about losing my self-paid coverage, and that would be a huge load off my mind (assuming "the gap" doesn't apply to Hotter, in which case we all panic because life is shit and OMG).
*   One positive thing came of all the panic over "the gap;" Hotter announced that he "had some feelings" and went out and started kicking the shit out of the busted back-hatch of the MFA Minivan. I didn't expect it to do any good but seeing as how my LAST husband would have kicked the shit out of me or one of the children didn't say anything to dissuade him, and he actually bent the hatch in such a way as to render it functional again. WHOO TITS!
*   I have to go and transport the turkeys (minus Thanksgiving), two ducks, and half a dozen chickens plus the parts of the pen they reside in to my boss at Temp Agency #2's house about an hour away. Loud and Crazy the turkey will be riding in a giant burlap sack. WISH ME LUCK because I AM GOING TO NEED IT. If you hear about a minivan full of poultry going off an overpass on the news and I never post again, you'll know why.

body:
Well, we got the poultry moved. It wasn't easy (think all of the parts to a 7x12 chain link enclosure, ten birds, three kids, plus Hotter and me packed into the MFA Minivan at once for a long drive to the middle of nowhere) or pretty (turns out tom turkeys don't enjoy being bundled into giant burlap sacks--WHO WOULD HAVE GUESSED?) but we got it done. My boss texted me this morning to let me know that Loud and Crazy was puffed up and gobbling and scared the crap out of her horses (whoops--she's more amused than annoyed, though) and she got two eggs already. Heh.
   As some of you already know, I mentioned the poultry exodus on the facespace and Lefty (my prodigal stepson) decided the time was ripe for a flame war (apparently he takes exception with my blaming his IDIOT UNCLE for the deaths of the first wave of refugees). So I unfriended and blocked him, because life is too short to suffer fools regardless of relation by blood or marriage. Hotter was all "OMG ARE YOU THAT DEFENSIVE, HE'S JUST BEING HIS SARCASTIC SELF" and I was all "apparently so! Or alternately: he is an irresponsible, entitled, shiftless little punk and I'm still pissed about him complaining when I couldn't take a weekend off with zero notice that one time he wanted to have a party and calling me and the boys your 'fake family' and am also sick of having to defend my right to work like a goddamn dog to provide for us. Either way? BLOCKED!" Then he backpedaled some with "well I'm fine with it if you don't wanna associate with him" and I was all "good because it wouldn't make any difference if you weren't!" So yeah, everybody was an asshole. GO US!
   I'm kind of conflicted here. On the one hand, I feel for Lefty, because his mother is an unmedicated bipolar waste of skin and breast implants and he and I have that in common, plus I think somewhere deep down under all of the tattoos and bad attitude he's a good egg. I probably shouldn't take much of what he says personally, because he'd probably be jealous and resentful of me and the boys regardless, and I am the grownup and all that noise. I've become fiercely protective of my own serenity, though, and can't say I particularly regret anything. I guess I just wish things were different and everybody could get along a little better.
   Oh well. It was nice to have a day off to spend with my family yesterday, and I'm making the most of my lazy Sunday morning today (I'm working an event for Temp Agency #2 later on). It looks like Hotter and the boys aren't the only ones who miss having me around more:
Figure One: She's been in my lap, on my feet, or snuggled up to me like this most of yesterday and today. Awww...

body:
I don't know what is going on with my job. Temp Agency #1 thought it was temp-to-hire (and therefore so did I, initially). PseudoCorp said "maybe a month, maybe after that part-time, we'll see," so I adjusted my expectations accordingly. But come to find out the temp before me was there for six months (and apparently sucked), then she quit and they hired me, and there have pretty much always been two people doing my job (currently it's me and The One Who Dislikes Me, who has been there for over a year but started off as...a temp). So I don't know if that means PseudoCorp is hedging their bets in case I suck and keeping me as a temp to see what kind of worker I am before they offer me a job outright, or is one of those places (and there are many) that THINKS the temp is temporary but always has a temp and therefore you can stay as long as you do good work, or lied to Temp Agency #1 in order to get one of their better workers, or what. I asked Temp Agency #1 to see if they could find anything out, and if they don't get a straight answer I guess I'll ask my boss myself when it's been a month? I dunno. This is all further complicated by the fact that I don't love working at PseudoCorp (well...if PseudoCorp and I were in a relationship on the facespace it'd say "it's complicated;" I don't think I dislike the job itself so much as I am growing to loathe The One Who Dislikes Me, who was downright nasty to me today for no good reason).
   If PseudoCorp offered me a fulltime job with benefits tomorrow I honestly don't know what I'd say. I mean, on one hand steady income would be fantastic, obviously, but on the other hand I don't want a job that makes me miserable with no end in sight, and I think PseudoCorp might eventually do just that (although if I was a fulltime employee and had some job security I think I'd have an easier time handling The One Who Dislikes Me, because we'd be on more equal footing and I could call her on her rudeness, and to be fair to PseudoCorp TOWDM is 80% of what makes me not love the job and the other 20% I could totally live with).
   I think part of my dilemma is that for all of the uncertainty it entails I really like being a temp for multiple agencies; it means it's pretty much impossible for Stalky to somehow find out where I work and threaten my livelihood (again, some more). I don't like to admit it on here knowing that she reads, but Stalky has changed the way I look at life: I like to be a moving target. Standing still for too long makes me antsy. If I could afford it I'd move, and I've even seriously considered changing my name. Taking a job with no end date in sight would make me vulnerable in a way that I'm currently not, and not having to worry about Stalky somehow getting me fired has worked wonders for my mental health.
   Maybe it's a good thing this is all so unsettled for now.

body:
So Big Child's fifth-grade class has a group blog.
   I KNOW! What the hell, right? Actually I was wild about the idea at first; sneering left and right at other parents who were having a harder time with their babies embracing the brave new world of social media in the classroom.
   That stage lasted all of ten minutes. Which is how long it took my kid to join his classmates in collaborating on a fan-page for their teacher. They were each posting their favorite things about her, and I was still loving it at that point, because awwwww and YAAAAY, but then Big Child asked me how to spell "emotional" and I started to worry. A few minutes later, he brought his laptop into my room to confirm my worst fears. 
   "How does this sound, Mommy," asked my kid who has recently hit five feet and is starting to get blackheads (WTF? Noooo), "My favorite thing about Mrs. Teacher is that she does not yell at her students and says she never will because she does not like to be yelled at. I especially don't like when adults yell* because I hate yelling and also I am very emotional and start to tear up any time someone yells at me or even just around me."
   Uhhh...crap. This is where Big Child's developmental delay makes him a prime target for schoolyard bullies. I go back and forth a lot on whether to try and help him avoid catching grief for his unselfconscious naivete or whether that's something he just has to learn to do on his own, but in the end I'm his mother and I just don't want anyone to hurt my baby.
   "Well, son, here's the thing about revealing stuff about yourself on the innernet," I began, trying to choose my words with care--
   "THE INTERNET IS FOREVER, I KNOW," he said, wearily.
   "Yes, yes it is. But more than that, the innernet is accessable to everyone, whether they like you or not, and therefore you want to be careful what you put out there. Because anything you write that someone could use to hurt or embarrass you CAN AND WILL come back to bite you in the butt." 
   "What do you mean?"
   I sighed. "I think you could maybe just say that you hate yelling and leave it at that."
   "Why?"
   "Because...well, kids are horrible, and our ER copayment is a lot of money--"
   "MO-mmy!"
   "I just don't want to see you get hurt, your feelings OR your face! It's up to you what you write on there, but...just think about it, okay?"
   Then Hotter totally undermined my parenting by telling the kid to write what he felt, because he had a lot more respect for someone who came right out and said what they believed, and anyone who had a problem with that wasn't a good friend anyway, and Big Child was all "thanks Hotter, I really needed to hear that" and they man-hugged and Big Child went to bed.
   "THANKS A LOT," I told my idiot husband, after we finished making the rounds tucking everyone in and kissing foreheads. "They're going to KILL HIM, you know."
   "Nah. They're FIFTH-GRADERS. He's a BLEEDER. They'll panic when they see the blood and stop punching him," Hotter said smugly, like he had it all worked out.
   Godiva help us all next year when the kid goes to middle school. I might as well enroll him in Aflac now.
 
*   My house is a no-yelling zone because I happen to hate yelling too. But the XY is a yeller...

I found the app (a NON-FREE one, no less!) to be anything BUT user-friendly, and ended up programming the intervals it seemed to be suggesting for Day One, Week One into Runkeeper (which is free, which would seem to defeat the purpose of paying for Couch to 10K). You win some, you lose some, I guess. The good news is, I went running (or run-walk-run-walk-run-walkOMGing) and did not die. My legs felt alright. My lungs were a little bitchy. So yeah, you put them in smoothies or float them in beverages (I like them in kefir, both the milk and the water kinds). If you float them in beverages they swell up and sort of en-goo-ify to a tapioca consistency. So if you are skeeved out by tapioca they are not for you, but I happen to love the stuff! Textural bliss aside, the things are packed with Omega 3s and fiber.

EVERYONE WANTS DIFFERENT THINGS, OH THE HUMANITY.

Sorry about the title, y'all. The devil made me do it!
   So today I set about doing some of the many wonderful things I have discovered on the Pinterest, and so far I've been pleased with all of them. First I made this; my parsley survived the winter in fine style, and the fresh parsley really adds to the flavor nicely; I used homemade white-balsamic vinaigrette as my dressing, substituted white kidney beans for the chickpeas since that is what I had in the pantry, and crumbled in a little feta. SO GOOD! I packed it up into five little tubs for my work lunches this week. Then I went out and put a HURT on the DIRT! I got a small bed ready to plant (cleared away weeds and hauled them to the compost pile, dug down and removed encroaching roots, turned some organic vermiculite into the soil, and spread a layer of last year's dark, rich compost overtop) and used this little trick when I set out my cabbage seedlings. Not only will it help prevent the cabbage moths from eating my plants, but I also found it helpful to position the squares of waxed carton before transplanting the seedlings to ensure even spacing.
Figure One: Look at that gorgeous compost!
   Here is one of my little seedlings wearing its waxed-cardboard cabbage-moth shield.
Figure Two: Double eco-nerd points for pesticide-free pest-control measures AND re-using the milk carton itself (our locality does not recycle these).
   And yes, I know, the cold weather isn't TOTALLY over. That is why I covered the bed up with a hoop-tunnel when I'd finished planting my seedlings and surrounded them with freshly-planted radish and clover seeds:
Figure Three: All tucked in until after the last frost date!
   Finally, we finished a bunch of celery today and I planted the base of it like this. I'm getting kind of a crap germination rate on celery this year, so I really hope it works--if it does I'll just plant the base of each bunch as we use it and in theory I'll end up being able to harvest new celery at the same rate we go through the store-bought bunches! So neat.
   What have YOU done after seeing it on the Pinterest? How did it turn out? And how the heck was your weekend? I'd really like to know!
 
P.S. We took Isis's cone off this evening, since she's pretty well healed up and her stitches can come out on Thursday. She's delighted to be able to lick her arse again, the nasty dog. Don't forget to go and check out every one of the fabulous advertisers who made it possible for her to have her surgery!

body:
*   I love my GP, y'all. Yesterday I started to panic about going into the weekend with my lungs sucking as badly as they have been (yeah, I haven't said much on here but...it's gotten bad, like "wake up in the middle of the night to use the nebulizer" bad, and asthma is an asshole, GAWD), and called to see if she or any of her partners could see me. They could not, but she had the front desk call me back and read me a note from her saying that if I was willing to come in it MUST be bad, she was leaving me a sample of Symbicort at the front desk, and we both knew that if that and albuterol nebs weren't helping then I needed the ER. LOVE. HER.
*   Yesterday I was able to do my run without having an asthma attack, which was a major victory.
*   After my run yesterday afternoon I planted ten feet of beets and ten feet of turnips. Whoo, root vegetables! Also a bed of beans.
*   Today? Oh my lands, y'all, today I planted fifty-three strawberry plants and many borage seeds before breakfast, then dug up a row, dug and hauled two loads of compost, planted my fertilized row with onions and bush beans, dug two wheelbarrows full of crabgrass from the front walk and garden, planted leeks, fennel, two kinds of shallots, horseradish, moonvines, and a triamble squash seedling, and my lungs finally let me know that they were DONE but holy cow I am pleased with the day!
*   There's also this:
Figure One: Tonight Hotter and I are grilling a couple of porterhouses and I am having some hard cider, and I am not going to feel even a LITTLE bit bad about that!
*   Speaking of weight and calories and things, MyFitnessPal is A-MA-ZING (you can SCAN BARCODES OF FOODS to enter them!), I am updating the weight ticker again, and I think the reason it's moving so slowly is that I'm building muscle like crazy as I lose fat, so that's all good!
*   Funny story: I am using kelp meal as fertilizer for the first time this year, because I have heard wonderful things about it. It has a tendency to make the yard smell like a fishmarket though, especially when I water things I've used it on. Hotter and I were standing outside on the porch and I remarked that the kelp meal sure was stinky in the manner of yucko rotten fish and he said "OH THANK GOD, I THOUGHT...well, you're really working up a sweat and...I didn't realize the kelp stuff...well. You just saved us a VERY awkward conversation, the end." So I punched him in the face.

body:
I am still scraping my head back together in the wake of the Great Steroid Taper of 2012/PMS Week clusterfuck over here, and Hotter's looming dental appointment plus Weekend Warrior Job II going bust are not helping (OH MY GOD, NOTHING IS ALLOWED TO BREAK DOWN OR GET INFECTED UNTIL THAT IS DONE, EVERYONE STOP EATING SO MUCH!). My Pinterest-inspired lunch today was lovely, however, and my angst-fueled attack on the garden resulted in an entire front bed weeded/rooted/vermiculite-and-composted. So there's that.
   Plus I went running. Which, ugh. My legs feel fine! My lungs are another story. What the stinking hell, lungs? This run and the last one I was juuuust on the verge of quitting and heading home to the nebulizer the ENTIRE TIME. The only reason I didn't is that I'm a stubborn asshole the burning/tightness didn't progress to actual wheezing. Also, the Couch to 10k app's crazy-assed run-walk-run-walk-run-walkOMG system is well-suited to asthmatic runners in that the walk intervals give you time to cough up a lung and catch your breath in between the run intervals. I don't know if this is just my lungs' way of being all "damn, bitch, we're not so sure about this exercising again thing" or whether the recent sickness knocked them down a peg or what; it's been months since my lungs got in the way of my doing anything I wanted to do...I am not liking this! Hopefully they just have to relearn to deal with cardio? I did start taking a daily antihistamine in case it's pollen-related, but that hasn't made any difference (although I'll probably continue it at least until I stop having so damn much trouble, since in my experience that's the first thing an allergy/asthma specialist would have me try anyway). The day after tomorrow is going to be a real bitch, because it's the first day of a new Cto10k week, which seems to be designed to make you feel fortunate for the REST of the week that it isn't Day One. I may go ahead and use the nebulizer BEFORE that one...
   How was YOUR Monday? Frequent commenter and friend of the MFAmily krlr's little girl is having her adenoids out tomorrow, and while that's no biggie, the bonus chromosome is cause for some extra angst and eating-of-feelings any time general anesthesia is involved. So if you have any spare good thoughts or dirty jokes, maybe point them her way?
title: Monday schmonday

body:
*   The good thing about being a temp, or one of the good things anyway, is that generally even if you make an ass of yourself to your writes-the-paychecks boss, if you're golden with your tells-you-what-to-do boss (these are always two different people) it doesn't matter a bit, and vice versa. Today, half-delirious with what passes for a fever according to my craptastic immune system (yeah, when my eardrum ruptured I was at 98.8 and yesterday at Urgent Care I was 98.2...maybe my thyroid is sucking more than usual?) and hopped up on antihistamines and decongestants, I managed to inadvertently act the fool with BOTH OF THEM. I also, at one point, had to Google the word "windshield" to ascertain the correct spelling. It was THAT BAD, TEH DUMB. Mind you, both my writes-the-paychecks boss and my tells-me-what-to-do boss think I'm fabulous on the whole, and this was more of a "WTF, MFA Mama?" than anything along the lines of a costly or humiliating error in both cases, but...yeah. BOTH feet in my mouth today. Awesome!
*   I dragged my arse home and proceeded to try and salvage the day, biking to the grocery store and coming home and planting garlic and spinach and then mowing for half an hour. No, I'm not TOTALLY insane. See, if Doogie Howser, MD had been correct about the OMGSEVEREALLERGIES yesterday, I would DEFINITELY have had an asthma attack. I didn't even wear a mask while mowing. And I was FINE. Yes, I am on tons of medication including albuterol and inhaled steroids and generic Allegra and whatnot to prevent me from reacting badly to allergens, but I think if I was this sick from allergies I would've gone tits-up in the yard AND I DIDN'T. This is actually a huge win, in that if I was suddenly going to have severe, debilitating, sick-in-bed allergies it would put a real damper on my gardening and exercising and pretty much surviving. The bad news is, Doogie was wrong and I'm sick, but then we already pretty much knew that. 
*   Then we had a charge hit our bank account that neither Hotter nor I made. Not a big charge, but it definitely wasn't one of us. EFFF! We called the bank immediately and had them shut down the debit card the charge was linked to (Hotter's), and we're filing a claim with the fraud department. Lovely.
*   Then the whole freezer thawed itself for no apparent reason. Because WHY THE FUCK NOT? 
*   Also, and I'm going to be vague here, because there's a possibility we'll all change health insurers in the next six months and this isn't likely to be taken care of anytime soon, but someone in our household (no, not a child) needs surgery and the out-of-pocket after insurance would be about $1,500. That's obviously out of the question right now, and while said surgical issue is not even REMOTELY life-threatening, it has grown increasingly painful and would be stupid-easy to fix. I mean, this could be done with local anesthesia. It's SO DUMB. I don't think The Patient is going to permanently lose any function or suffer anything more than constant minor (like, four and under on the infamous pain scale) discomfort, so it could absolutely be MUCH WORSE, but...well, it's still a real pisser. And I feel like a loser because we live in the first-world and I should be able to get things like this taken care of when they happen to a member of my family, and I can't even really complain about it around the water-cooler at work, because that kind of problem is so totally foreign to the 1%ers I work with. I can't even fully vent about it on my blog, because it might (or maybe not, I haven't researched it) constitute a pre-existing condition and should our insurance situation change before it's been dealt with I wouldn't want Stalky to be able to describe The Situation to my new insurer. This...thing...is something that's been a part of The Patient's life for years and years, and didn't suddenly get worse today or anything, but when I am sick or stressed or both things like this get to me a lot more. Boooo.
*   Tomorrow is transplant-neuro-dental-appointmentfest, possibly with a side of DMV, and I'm not even kidding. Cross your fingers that it all goes okay (no, I and my "allergies" will not be accompanying Hotter to Transplant Clinic; I'm dropping him off at Local Teaching Hospital and going into the office, which is right by the hospital, for a couple of meetings while he gets inspected, injected, et cetera then collecting him to take to the dentist) because I really am not feeling up for handling even ONE. MORE. MOTHERFUCKING THING.
*   And how are all of YOU?
